title: Talk About Doctors Instead of Athletes
description: As Arthur Ashe said, all black parents should get their kids to read, should get them to go to school. But it's easier said than done.

title: The Struggle Over Redlining By Banks Is Intensifying
description: To community leaders and a growing number of government officials, the process is redlining, a graphic term that implies the conscious act of individuals and groups. To bankers and other mortgage lenders, the process is disinvestment, an academic phrase that connotes the workings of larger, more abstract economic and social forces. Whatever the name, the situation purported to be described is the same: the difficulty, if not impossibility, of getting mortgage and propertyimprovement loans in numerous urban neighborhoods.

title: House Tours
description: The following chronological listing, compiled by Ruth Rejnis, is a selection of notable house tours in the metropolitan area through the summer.

title: Misleading Data
description: THE use of grade equivalent scores to report the results of standardized tests given to school children in New York City and throughout the country borders on fraud, according to a growing number of experts.

title: Cynthia White Married to Richard A. Hesel
description: Cynthia Klondean White, cofounder and educational director of the ChilAfees All Day School in New York, was married yesterday to. Richard Allen vice president and account supervisor with the BartonGillet Company, a concern specializing in institutional communications and marketing.

title: Aliens: Where They Come From What Awaits Them
description: HOUSTONAs is usual during periods of high unemployment, considerable attention has been focused on a particular group of newcomers to the United States who cherish the American dream so much that they are willing to leave their homelands behind, endure exploitation and violate laws to become part of it.

title: 8 in Deep Throat Case Receive Prison Sentences
description: MEMPHIS, April 30 (AP)A Federal judge has sentenced eight men convicted in the Deep Throat obscenity trial to prison terms ranging from three months to one year, and has imposed fines of up to $10,000. Three corporations involved in the case also received fines of $10,000 each.

title: PED.'s Look Beyond the Ivory Tower
description: ROBERT SRAWER specialized in 15th century cycle plays when earning his Ph.D. in English literature. He now studies the cycles of buying and selling as a marketing manager for Maidenform Inc.

title: Metric Symbols to Go On Road Signs by 78
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)A timetable set down this week by the Federal Highway Administration called for the first appearance of metric symbols on the nation's traffic signs by July 1, 1978.

title: FISHING
description: MACKEREL arrived in the Sound and along the South Shore last week and should provide good lighttackle sport fishing for the next couple of weeks. But there are indications that the rapid decline in mackerel stocks of recent years from foreign fishing will once again curtail the season.

title: News Summary
description: The blowout on an oil well in the North Sea was successfully capped yesterday morning after four previous attempts had failed. The well had been out of control for eight days and had poured millions of gallons of oil into the sea between Norway and Britain. The capping was carried out by a crew of Americans and Norwegians, including an oildisaster expert from Texas, Paul (Red) Adair. [Page 1, Columns 14.]

title: $100,000 Trentonian 200 Captured by Dallenbach
description: TRENTON, April 30 (AP)Wally Dallenbach squeezed past his teammate, Gordon Johncock, with six laps to go after fighting side by side for 20 laps, and went on to win the $100,000 Trentonian 200 race today for Indianapolis cars.

title: Dean Urged as Head of College in Purchase
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 30The College Council of the State University of New York at Purchase, which is approaching the end of a yearlong hunt for a new college president, has nominated, the school's dean of music and acting dean of dance for the position, turning aside the candidate proposed for the post by a 12 man search committee, according to informants close to the selection process.

title: Job Outlook Is Dim for Education Students
description: ANITA LUDWIG comes from a family of teachers. Her mother, two older sisters, brother and sisterinlaw are teachers. And last June, when she graduated from Brooklyn College with a major in. education, Miss Ludwig expected to follow in their footsteps.

title: The Bat Is Not as Blindor as Uncuddlyas Thought, but It Has Had Some Bad Publicity
description: An assistant professor of biology at Barnard College has disputed the adage blind as a bat and hopes to removethrough scientific researchmany of the other stigmas and myths that have made bats the social outcasts of mammals.

title: The Horn of Good Luck
description: The United States is being lucky and looking sophisticated in its retreats and advances in the strategic Horn of East Africa. The expulsion of more than threefourths of the American personnel from Ethiopia is only the latest in a series of events reversing the diplomatic geography of the region. The radical military dictatorship now running Ethiopia has been shedding a once substantial American connection and turning instead to the succor of Libya, Cuba and the Soviet Union. At the same time, the revolutionary regimes of Somalia and South Yemen, formerly aligned with the Russians, have been noticeably improving relations with Saudi Arabia and the United States. In this game of musical chairs, it appears that the Russians may be ending up with a fairly wobbly stool.

title: Boy on the Couch
description: WE have as the hero of this book a 14yearold boy. Perhaps that makes I Am the Cheese a juvenile. This boy is biking from Massachusetts to Vermont to see his father in the hospital, and is bringing him a gift. On the way he has adventures.

title: Indonesia's Regime Has Left Little to Chance in the Election
description: LONDONThe elections in Indonesia tomorrow will not be a demonstration of democratic virtues: Democracy conceived by the militupbased Government of President Suharto is primarily an exercise in approbation.

title: ART
description: WE HAVE been led to believe that minimal art is an esthetic phenomenon in which the imagery is reduced to a minimum, in which the visual incidence has been pared down to rudimentary pictorial expression. It is also a phenomenon that is supposed to offer little in the way of drama and that abjures romantic indulgences. Minimal works are said to refer, generally, to nothing but themselves. They have frequently been called nonreferential and nonallusionary.

title: college Withdraws Job Offer to a Jew, Touching Off Furor
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 30Presbyterianaffiliated Davidson College educates students from places as disparate as Zaire, Sweden and Garden City, L.I., but it balks at hiring a nonChristian professor.

title: We are all aiming for the same bull's eye, said Miss Harris, and we all know when we've hit it.
description: It was hardly Chekhovian: Tovah Feldshuh, hunched over a coffee table, swiftly and insatiably putting away a grilled sandwich like small starved kitten; Ellen Burstyn, swathed in black, clutching halfgallon plastic container of unpleasantly greenish soup to her chest and eating it cold, with a plastic spoon, while warning everyone against looking at the mess; and Rosemary Harris, overseeing it all from a chair, her feet in patent leather shoes propped up on a coffee table, stoutly defending the borough of Brooklyn to no one in particular.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY houses in this area still have old style fullheight window screens that are taken down each fall, then replaced over the.windows each spring. (It is surprising how many homeowners still prefer these over the modern combination units because the removable ones permit opening a window top and bottom for better ventilation).

title: In Little Italy, the Word Is Risorgimento
description: Uptown, in Sheep Meadow perhaps, they can speak of the bobbin robin. Downtown, when the sweet cliches of spring hold forth, a young man's fancy more likely turns to Little Italy. Now more than ever.

title: Carter and Aides Report Progress In Preparing Welfare ReformPlan
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)president Carter and top officials in his Administration made considerable progress today as they approached a selfimposed deadline for presenting welfare reform proposals, a spokesman said.

title: POLITICS
description: MOST of the candidates in the Democratic and Republican gubernatorial primaries are breaking the spirit, if not the letter, of the state's election law, and those who haven't broken it yet wish they had.

title: Par or Better
description: He walked into a hazard the way Bogart would walk into a bar. Watching him on television on Sunday afternoons during the 60's I always felt that no matter where he wasin the woods, in a sand trap, in the water of America's golf courseshe had a chance to pull the shot off, get his hall on the green, save his needed par and, when I was greedy for his heroics, I'd root for a birdie.

title: U.S. CONCERN SELLS EGYPT NEW BUS THAT CARRIES 187
description: RICHMOND, Ind., April 30 (UPI)The Wayne Corporation here has built the world's longest bus body and will soon be sending its I87passenger model to Egypt.

title: Stars in the Making at
description: In ballet, the words coming up have very special significance. They mean that a specific young dancer, one who may have been a member of a company for several years, is suddenly being noticed by critics and public alike, making them take note of the fact that something new and different is happening to his or her dancing. It may be the fresh way a plie, pirouette or arabesque is executed, the way a certain variation assumes new life or a given role takes on a new dimension when danced by someone who heretofore may have turned in merely serviceable performances. This mysterious transformation is seldom a matter of technique alone, but more a case of individual growth and maturity  a coming together of those components that announce the emerging ballet artist.

title: Boggs and Miss Salness Triumph at Diving Meet
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 30 (AP)The top three national threemeter diving champions finished first, second and third today at the International Hall of Fame meet. But in the women's 10meter tower event Kit Salness of Long Beach, Calif., upset the national champion, Barbara Weinstein of Ohio State University.

title: For Shad Enthusiasts
description: Further Information for Shad Enthusiasts: The Windsor Shad Derby will be held May 722. Any shad caught during that time in the Connecticut River or its tributaries is eligible for the competition. Trophies will be awarded at the finale for the 10 largest buck and the 10 biggest roe shad.

title: Antiques Fouts o New Studio
description: Georgian silver tankards are analyzed as expertly as are moon rocks, and with the same sophisticated equipment. And should anyone question the age of the jcints on a William and Mary chair it is sent to the leadlined Xray room at the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum here for staff conservators and their students to settle the dispute.

title: Acting Mayor of Chicago and Socialite to Wed
description: United Press International

title: The Argument Over Mexican Justice
description: After repeated inquiries made by The New York Times to various Mexican Government and U.S. State Department officials about the imprisonment case of Paul DiCaro and Deborah Friedman, the Mexican Government announced what was described as a change of policy:

title: COURT ORDER ALTERS SEAFARING TRADITION
description: The maritime tradition under which ships provide free assistance to other ships encountering emergencies on the high seas has been shattered by a Federal court ruling here awarding $9,000 to a British passenger liner for expenses in taking aboard a sick American seaman.

title: Wood, Field & Stream: Youth Recaptured
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass.Attempts to recapture happy experiences of youth are often disastrous, but once In a while success can be yours.

title: Dana Hubbard Has Nuptials
description: Dana Ackerly Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Richardson Hubbard of West Hartford, Conn, and Wianno, Mass, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Mare Edward Kaminsky of Savannah. Ga.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In formulating an energy policy for the U.S., the Carter. Administration need to face up to two fundamental facts. The first of these facts is that the U.S. is running out of sources of conventional fuels. It is becoming an accepted fact that we really are running out of petroleum reserves worldwide and that our continued reliance on this form of fuel is impossible.

title: Let's Look Out for No. 1!
description: strategies are those whose economies are growing fastest and which are able to rely on commercial loans in place of handouts. The export record of five marketoriented thirdworld countries last year is revealing. South Korea's exports rose by 68 percent; Taiwan's by 51 percent; Chile's by 29 percent; Thailand's by 27 percent; Argentina's by 21 percent. (The Governments of these countries often come in for criticism in the West, yet they are neither more nor less repressive than the thirdworld norm.)

title: G.O.P Finds Some Strength In Weakness
description: ALBANY, April 30Who are the Senate Republicans and what do they want anyway?

title: SHOP TALK
description: WOMEN'S EXCHANGES proliferate in Fairfield County and environs, but connoisseurs of the genre say there is no question which is tops. The Fairfield Women's Exchange at 332 Pequot Road, Southport, is considered somewhat of a marveleven among the Women's Exchange Federation.

title: Letters: Fish Dishes According to Scale
description: To the Editor: In Ignorants Abroad: Touring France Without French, (Travel Section, April 17) Gerald Astor mentioned the barnyard noises used by M. le Proprietaire at the Auberge des Seigneurs in Vence to signify the fowl on the menu. He regretted failing to ask for fish. We can assure him that the host's ingenuity does not fail there either. The menu included truite au bleu the night we dined there and our host interpreted this by singing the first few bars of Schubert's Die Forelle.

title: Bell of U.S.C Looms as First Pick the N.F.L Draft
description: Provided that John McKay, the coach, and his independent personnel expert, Ron Wolf, do not launch into a lastminute disagreement, the National Football League's annual draft of the best college players will commence Tuesday at 10 A.M. with a prompt selection.

title: Spence School Names New Head
description: The board of trustees of the Spence School has announced the election of Juliana Schmemann as the ninth head of the school, succeeding Dustin H. Heuston. Spence, on East 91st Street, is a secondary school for girls with more than 500 students. Mr. Heuston has headed the school for eight years and is leaving at the end of June to establish a nonprofit educational institute.

title: Paraprofessionals Face an Uncertain Future
description: ATER A LUNCH of ham, vegetables, pineapple and milkand the accompanying lesson in table manners and getting along with friendsthe 13 kindergarten nunils settled in a corner to read.

title: ART VIEW
description: The name of Man Ray is now firmly established in the history books as the only American painter and objectmaker to participate in the Dada and Surrealist movements from their very inceptionnot one of the major figures, perhaps, but an artist promptly and decisively shaped by the ideas and the ethos of these movements. The friendship he formed with Marcel Duchamp in New York in 1915 was clearly the turning point of his lifeit was tantamount to a conversion provided him with a point of view. It also gave him entree the inner circle of Surrealism in Paris in the 20's and 30's, and this was the milieu in which Man Ray's career prospered. Although he was always to remain something of a satellite Duchamp, even in his prime, he nonetheless achieved a distinct, if minor, artistic profile of his own.

title: Bonnie Barr, J. P. Morgan 3d Are Engaged
description: Bonnie Allis Barr and John P. Morgan 3d, teachers at the North Country School in Lake Placid, N. Y., plan to be married on the school grounds June 18. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parent, Mr. and Mrs. Vernon C. Barr of Columbia, Mo. Mr. Morgan is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan 2d of Mill Neck, L. I., and a greatgreatgrandson of the first J. Pierpont Morgan, the financier.

title: Grateful Dead Play the Palladium With That Special Winning Blend
description: It is a clich of the rock world that the experience transcends music alone. To be a real rocker, one has to get into the life style, the politics and even, maybe, the drugs that the music epitomizes in sound.

title: Ethiopia Reported to Establish a Camp for Training Thousands of Civilians for Drive on Rebels in North
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 30The Government has set up a training camp for thousands of militiamen about 20 miles north of the capital, and the camp has already begun receiving truckloads of volunteer fighters, Western diplomats said today.

title: City U. Revamping Its SEEK Program
description: Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the Chancellor of the City University of New York, has disclosed that the university will soon make major changes in the structure and operations of the controversial SEEK program for disadvantaged students.

title: Jackson, Munson Homer as Yanks Win, 72
description: The Yankees feasted on the expansion Seattle Mariners again at the Stadium yesterday afternoon as they defeated the struggling new team, 72.

title: Pro Soccer At the Yale Bowl
description: THE Connecticut Bicentennials, the state's majorleague soccer team, have placed all their wishes and dreams in a bowlthe Yale Bowl. That's where they will play all their home games this season, beginning with the Cosmos and Pele next Sunday.

title: Against: They Don't Measure Learning
description: THE CONTROVERSY over achievement testing starts from a simple fact: Achievement tests reward testtaking skills as much as they reward achievement. Different children who know a subject equally well can still receive very different scores on a multiplechoice achievement test.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: It's that time of the year again. The music season is nearing its end (not that it is ever really over in New York, with its airconditioned halls), and it is the moment of recapitulation as one major organization after another starts puttingaway its costumes, its instruments and its music, and says goodbye to its subscription audience.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Some of the most invigorating pictures ever painted by an American are on view at the Guggenheim Museum as part of the Kenneth Noland retrospective exhibition which has been organized by Diane Waldman and will be there through July 5. It would be an unlucky visitor who did not come away from this exhibition with a lightened step and smile on his face.

title: Sport Fishing Gains Popularity
description: SPORT FISHING is one of the most important activities on Long Island Sound and its rapid growth in recent years is expected to continue, according to the Sound study by the New England River Basin Commission. The study estimates that more than one million people fish the Sound's waters each year.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACEThe Fantasticks. Today at 2 P.M. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Route 6. $5.50. 6281169.

title: Brenda G. Sadler Is Married In South to Ray J. Erickson
description: Brenda Gaye Sadler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Sadler of Charlotite, N.C., was married there yesterday afternoon to Ray Josef Erickson, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Raymond Erickson of Orange, N.J. The Rev. Steven Shoemaker of Raleigh, N.C., performed the ceremony in the Malberry Presbyterian Church.

title: Handicapped End Demonstration
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (AP)Singing, laughing and crying and drinking champagne, about 60 handicapped persons ended today their 3week sitin at the Federal Building here, held to demand Government approval of the new regulations. Nobody gave us anything, Kitty Cone, a 33yearold victim of muscular dystropyh, said of Mr. Califano's signing Of the regulation. We showed we could wage a struggle at the highest level of government and win.

title: MUSIC
description: THE CULTURAL scene in Ridgefield has not been the same since Beatrice Brown came to town, and Miss Brown, for one, is proud of it. It may have taken a bit of toetreading, a dollop of evangelical zeal and perhaps a minor revolution or two, but the Ridgefield Orchestra has blossomed significantly since she became its music director in 1970.

title: Scratch
description: Howard Senzel, when not descending to rhetorical gibberish against the evils of technology, Republican Congressmen and various modernist curses, is a good writer and an entertaining one. It's difficult to tell whether he takes himself as seriously as some of the more pretentious passages proclaim, though one hopes not and sometimes suspects that he does not. Baseball and the Cold War is an uneven and muddled work, perhaps grandly conceived but badly executed, though it would be nice to think that perhaps Mr. Senzel may someday again take a turn at the literary bat and produce more than a scratch single. Mr. Senzel's comment on more conventional baseball books is applicable, to some tiny degree, to the FordMantle offering as ghosted by old pro Joseph Durso: The ghostwritten autobiographies of aging baseball players are, in one sense, all the same. These players have a need for money and recognition, the two things that came most easily in their playing days. But when the time for memoirs comes, so does the knowledge that whatever their efforts, they can never recapture what they have lost. And so these autobiographies begin in disappointment, frustration, and bitterness. The motivation is to expose professional baseball to its adoring fans as the agony, pain, insecurity, and bewilderment that it is. And, having done that in the first chapter, the author runs out of bad memories and is forced to turn to pleasant memories and anecdotes in order to complete his own story. In doing so, he brings himself to a state where he confesses that he loves baseball and always has, whether or not baseball loves him, and that he would do it all over again in exactly the same way, the

title: NAVY SEEKING TO SEND MORE WOMEN TO SEA
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The Navy, in a major break from tradition, is quietly seeking to assign more women to duty on ships.

title: The Nation
description: President Carter has formally delivOdd his package of energy measures to Congress and begun to feel the first stirrings of resistance among the legislators, both in his own party and in the opposition.

title: Hawaii Tops Whitecaps On Penalty Kick, 21
description: HONOLULU, April 30 (AP)Jim Henry, a midfielder, converted a penalty kick to help Team Hawaii defeat the Vancouver Whitecaps, 21, in the North American Soccer League last nieht.

title: Wind At the Summit
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The seven leaders of the industrial nations have so many things to discuss at their London summit meeting that they will scarcely have time to define the issues, let alone resolve any of them.

title: RUNAWAY OIL GUSHER IN NORTH SEA CAPPED IN A FIFTH ATTEMPT
description: STAVANGER, Norway, April 30A crew of American and Norwegian workmen succeeded this morning in capping the offshore well that shot out of control eight days ago and dumped millions of gallons of crude oil into the North Sea between Norway and Britain.

title: Amy Bloom Fiancee Of Dr. James D. Moon
description: Mr. and Mrs. Murray Teigh Bloom of Kings Point, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Beth Bloom, to Dr. James Donald Moon, associate professor of government at Wesleyan University. He, is son of Helen Surges, a consultant in special education in Minneapolis, and of Dr. James Moon, a nuclear physicist in Remington, Va.

title: LaSalle Quartet Plays as a Guest
description: The LaSalle String Quartet made a guest appearance with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Friday night in Ahce Tully Hall. The concert will be repeated this afternoon. Two of the four pieces on the prorgarn featured the quartet on it's own, Schubert's Quartettsatz in C minor and Berg's String Quartet. Op. 3.

title: New Doubts About Special Zones
description: Since its introduction here about a decade ago, the concept of special zoning districts has become a key instrument with which planners have sought to protect the characteristic features of neighborhoods faced with development.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Seattle Slew, jack Nicklaus and Our Hero Worship
description: To the Sports Editor: My wife turned to me at the table the other day and said, Who is Seattle Slew?

title: Article 4  No Title
description: In Bayley's unhurried study of D.H. Lawrence, E.M. Forster and Kipling, of Dickens and Austen, of Keats, Larkin and Shakespeare, his other touchstone, besides division, is character. Character is not some antique term found in a Victorian attic and refurbished for contemporary use. It is a subtle speculative hinge. What distinguishes Shakespeare, Austen and Tolstoy is their skill in creating characters who cannot be fixed or placed. In a Macbeth, an Emma, a Natasha we discern and participate in the rich accumulations of contingent lifefamily ties, friendships, social duties, contradictory impulses of ambition and altruism  that escape the writer's own prejudices, formulas and esthetic fiats.

title: and a Move to Tax State Land
description: ALBANY One short sentence in the typically understated language of the state's propertytax law has become the fightin words of three Long Island state legislators.

title: Increasing Women in Army Viewed as a Way to Offset Drop in Quality of Recruits
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)The quality of recruits entering the Army during the past three months fell to the lowest level in at least a year, and if the trend continues it could lead to recruitment of more women military sources say.

title: Paul Nunes Is Fiance Of Elizabeth Waller
description: Elizabeth Waller, who this month Will complete studies for a Master of Divinity degree at Union Theological Seminary, and Paul V. Nunes, who expects to receive a Juris Doctor degree this month from the Syracuse University College of Law, will be married May 28 at the James Chapel of Union Theological Seminary.

title: Famed Burlington Zephyr Trains Begin a New Career in Saudi Arabia
description: DAMMAM, Saudi Arabia, April 29 (UPI) Fortyone years after capturing the imagination of Depressionera travelers in the United States, the famous Burlington Zephyr trains have begun a new career in Saudi Arabia.

title: Measles Epidemic Causes Rush to Be Vaccinated
description: LOS ANGELES, April 30 (AP)Hundreds of parents and anxious children waited in lines up to three miles long today to get measles vaccinations in a, lastminute effort to beat Monday's deadline imposed by the county board of health.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Research by Dr. Gerald B. Phillips of columbia University points to a hitherto unsuspected factor as the prrincipal predisposing condition for heart attachs: an imbalance in sex hormones in the bloodstream.

title: GREEK DENIES ROLE IN KILLING OF POLK
description: ATHENS, April 29Gregoris Stactopoulos, a former Communist who spent 12 years in jail for involvement in the murder in 1948 of an American journalist named George Polk, contends now that he was innocent, and he wants a new trial.

title: The Trials and Tribulations of Utopia, Limited
description: Utopia, Limited, which enjoys one of its rare revivals this month at the Light Opera of Manhattan beginning Wednesday night, is unlucky No. 23 in the canon of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, a work that never shared the success of its predecessors.

title: Dial an Answer To Almost Anything
description: BARBARA PETRELLO is supervisor of foreign languages for the Woodbridge public schools, in which a dozen Viet namese children are enrolled. When she wondered recently if there was a bilingual publication to help refugees adjust to life in the United States, she picked up the phone and called DialanAnswer. Two days later, she got an answer: Doi Song Moi /New Life, a bilingual newspaper that is published in Washington.

title: Legislative Hearings Planned This Week
description: The following public hearings will be held in the New York metropolitan area by state legislative committees this week:

title: Heroic Image of Athletes: Does Public Crying Hurt?
description: There was Al McGuire, the street kid from Queens, the toughgut guard from Knick days, the wise apple, wisecracking courtwise coach of Marquette, trying to hold back tears as his team outfoxed and outplayed North Carolina for the National Collegiate basketball championship. But the tears wouldn't hold back; when the final buzzer sounded, tough Al McGuire wept before a television audience of millions.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IN THE last scene of The Cherry Orhard, Mrne. Ranevsky weeps as she hears the offstage sound of axes beginning to chop away at her beloved trees. To her, it symbolizes the end of all the fragile loveliness of the world.

title: Javits Lends Support To the H.M.O.
description: SENATOR JACOB K. JAVITS is no stranger to the healthmaintenance organization, and last week he came to White Plains to promote the county's version: the Westchester Community Health Plan.

title: Westchester County Dedicates Hospital At Grasslands Site
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 30Westchester County dedicated its new and stillcontroversial medical center In Valhalla today, capping what County Executive Alfred B. DelBello called a decade of planning and hard work.

title: Where Theatrical And Conceptual Art Are Blended
description: O pening this Thursday, in one of the innermost niches of Joseph Papp's Public Theater, is a virtually unpublicized production called Dressed like an Egg, created and performed by Mabou Mines. That's not a misprint; the group's name is Mabou Mines, not Mimeseven though the rambunctiously physical nature of the evening might lead one to suspect otherwise. Named after a Nova Scotia mining town where the group worked one summer, the members of Mabou Mines have chosen to live with the fact that careless typetsetters often lead their audiences to expect a company of aspiring Marcel Marceaus.

title: Entrepreneurial Ideas Popping As Pupils Learn About Business
description: Eddle, a darkhaired 7yearold, put the dime in his pocket and handed the older boy the bag of popcorn. He waked awa? counting his profit, hut probably unaware that each piece of corn in that bag symbolized a kernel of learning in mathematics, language arts, reading, writing and value.

title: The PreVacation Willies: New Hope For the Fearful
description: Heebiejeebies. Butterflies in the stomach. Fantods. Prevacation anxiety can turn even the most experienced traveler into an emotional basket case. But take heart. Though the malady has not yet earned much formal psychological attention, experts know the enemyand have ideas about how to cope with it.

title: Out on the Shad Run
description: SLICING the state in half, from Suffield to Saybrook, the Connecticut River quietly goes about its ageold business, as boats and barges pass up and downstream. Then comes spring. The river begins its even, older business. Spawning shad turn tail on the ocean and press singlemindedly upstream to reproduce in the clear, cool river waters of their birth.

title: Vietnam, 2 Years After War's End, Faces Painful Problems of Peace
description: HONG KONGIn the two years since the final collapse of the Saigon Government the problems of peace have proved almost as painful and intractable as the

title: 100Mile jockey
description: Hey, a man said, I've just learned that down in Virginia they have a 100mile horse race that takes three days to run. It's an annual thing, and this year the winning jockey was Paul Mellon. You know, the guy that owns Rokeby Farm and won the Belmont Stakes with horses like Arts and Letters and Quadrangle and gives $10 million or so to Yale about as often as the rest of us tip a cab driver. I'm not sure Stevie Cauthen could stay on a horse for 100 miles and he's a 16yearold. This Mellon has to be close to 70. That ought to give him permanent possession of the Geritol Cup, shouldn't it? Why, I remember one time Eddie Arcaro rode in a race, we used to have called the Pimlico Cup at 2 miles, and they practically had to lift him out of the saddle at the end. Even Johnny Longden, he was still riding when lie was a grandfather but even he was finished at 59.

title: GARDENING
description: WHICH is the most important month to the gardener? A rose enthusiast might favor June; a chrysanthemum fancier might prefer. October. All things considered, however, it would be difficult not to put May at the head of the list.

title: MUSIC
description: ONE of the most encouraging signs of cultural health these days is the proliferation of community groups designed to further all manner of artistic expression. There are some 100 local arts councils in New York State alone, and they are helping immeasurably to improve the cultural climate around us.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: Three youths were arrested in Chinatown for reportedly threatening to kill Jim Chan and burn his herb and jade store at 3 Elizabeth Street unless he nave them jewelry. The suspects are Kenneth Chung, 21, of 10 Avenue C, and David Lee, 20, and Eng Wing, 17 both of 56 Mott Street After fleeing in a stolen car with $12,800 from the Chemical Bank branch at 423 Canal Street, shortly before noon Friday, two armed and masked robbers struck a car nine blocks away, firing a shot at the frightened driver. Two blocks farther, at Houston and Wooster Streets, another accident disabled ??? car and they fled on root A27 yearold Bronx man was shot and critically wounded after being knocked down by an armed man during a dance at the Parkside Plaza Elegant, at 56 East Mount Eden Avenue, in the West Concourse section. The victim, Charles Foster of 1511 Fulton. Avenue, was admitted to BronxLebanon Hospital.

title: The Story Of a Question
description: Each question on a standardized test is the end product of a complex process of thought and pretesting that tries to make sure that the question measures what it is supposed to measure in the best way.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Just as every classic dancer can trace pedagogical genealogy back to Vestris, and even beyond, so almost every moderndancer can trace his heritage back to Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn. The two principal schools stemming from the original Denishawn School are, of course, those of Doris Humphrey and Martha Graham. Today, most moderndance derives from GrahamMerce Cunningham, Paul Taylor, Erick Hawkins, for example, or Paul Sanasardo, or even, at a further remove, Twyla Tharp. Naturally, all of these dance/choreographers have imposed their own style upon their basic heritage, yet the roots are there.

title: 2 Employees of Shooting Gallery Held in Slaying of Brooklyn Man
description: Two employees of a Coney Island shooting gallery were arrested yesterday on homicide charges after they fatally wounded with two gallery rifles a man with whom they had had an altercation, according to the police.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THE FIRST time the Rev. Gerard Gaeta and his wife, Jane, saw their daughter, Susan, was in a snapshot in the early fall of 1972, when she was 2 months old.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeKennedy's Children. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30. P.M. (through May 19). $3.90$5.50; students and the elderly, 52.50$3.90. (201) 6751881.

title: Brooklyn Residents Plan a New Protest At Local Firehouse
description: Many of the same Brooklyn residents whose 15month 24hour vigil at a firehouse in the Northside section resulted in its reopening are now protesting the alleged underuse of its engine.

title: Children in a Deadly Trade
description: The idea of a 15yearold driving a $12,000 MercedesBenz sedan or placing $500 and $1,000 bets on schoolyard basketball games boggles the mind. That hundreds of youngsters are making that kind of money from the narcotics trade is appalling. Yet they are, in Harlem, in the Bronx, in Queens and central Brooklyn. Some prosecutors blame the involvement of the young in the city's harddrug traffic on former Governor Rockefeller's drug law, which mandated life sentences for adult peddlers. They say the law caused the masters of the drug trade to turn to juveniles to carry on its most visible and vulnerable aspects.

title: CHIEF AT V.A. HOSPITAL A KEY FIGURE AT TRIAL
description: DETROIT, April 30He was on sabbatical in London when the epidemic of mysterious breathing failures occurred to patients at the Ann Arbor, Mich.,Veterans Hospital two summers ago. But Dr. S. Martin Lindenauer, chief of the hospital's staff, has now become a central figure in the trial of two Filipino nurses accused in the alleged murder of two patients and the nonfatal poisoning of seven others.

title: DINING OUT
description: FOR 49 years, Vincent'sin a stone and stucco house that sits atop a Clifton hillside, perhaps providentially, adjacent to a monastery and retreat househas been a family affair. First the Curcios, then the Montovanos (inlaws), have operated the restaurant from its early days as a suburban sneakeasy.

title: Controversy Over Testing Flares Again
description: CONTROVERSY over the use and misuse of standardized tests is once again raging through American education. Four years ago the National Education Association, the country's largest teacher organization, called for a moratorium on the use of standardized intelligence, aptitude and achievement tests on the ground that their results were usually misleading and unfair. Minority groups have attacked them for cultural bias and consumer groups tor excessive secrecy. Legislators have moved to give students greater access to testing data, and at least one court has awarded damages for what amounted to misuse of test scores by school officials.

title: Brazil Five Beats Arkansas
description: RIO DE TANIERO, April 30 (AP)Mascel de Sousza, who played collegiate basketball in the United States, scored 30 points last night in leading Brazil's National team to an 8477 victory over the University of Arkansas in the final of an international tournament. De Sousza, who played at Bradley University, led Brazil's 10point burst in the final seven minutes.

title: Jeanine D'Ermilio Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. D'Ermilio of West Brighton, S. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeanine Marie D'Ermilio, to Midship; man Alfred Edward Stuart Jr. of the United States Naval Academy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart of Tottenville, S. I.

title: BRIDGE
description: Every expert, sooner or later, has the following experience in tournament play: He plays a difficult hand unsuccessfully and realizes just too late that he has missed a brilliant stroke which would have earned him some immortality in the literature of the game. There are three common reactions to this situation.

title: West Indies School Wins 3,200 Relay
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30Clarendon High School, a late starter at the Penn Relays this year, became an early finisher today in the 3,200meter relay When it won the event in the carnival record time of 7 minutes 42.1 seconds.

title: AntiPerspirants Won't Help
description: Last year, when my wife was in a Manhattan hospital, I would often look cut of the window of her room across the East River to Queens and see the large sign above a redbrick factory that read PearlWick. The sign was a symbol of hope to me, much like the lighthouse across Long Island Sound I had seen through my bunk window when I was a child at summer camp, lonely and frightened.

title: Mindy Kaplan Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kaplan of Hicksville, L. I., have announced the engagement of their duaghter, Mindy Kaplan, to Michael David Taragan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Taragan of Westbury, L. I. A September wedding is planned.

title: An Inwood Rabbi Devotes Himself To Word of God and Words of Man
description: Maurice Wohlgelernter struggles to keep his footing in two worlds.

title: A Python Comes to Grips With Lewis Carroll
description: Himself alone a TV comedy writerartistperformer and the director of a killingly funny new film, the expatriate American Terry Gilliam is not at all a funny manunless you count his mod androgynous look and his muted Bugs Bunny laugh. He's irreverent (put me down as a carpenter's son who hated Zef fire!. li's Jesus of Nazareth'), and of course, irreverence was an integral part of his recently past persona as a member of the BBCTV writerperformers known as Monty Python's Flying Circus.

title: Good Vibes From High School Radio
description: WHEN a teacher at the J.F. Kennedy High School in PlainviewOld Bethpage became ill for several weeks last January and could not get to the school, he conducted his class in advancedplacement biology from his bedroom.

title: Man Without Qualities
description: A biography written in French by a French woman about this most American writer invites a chauvinistic reading. And Genevieve Moreau's calm good sense and familiarity with American places and styles survive the most skeptical parochialisms. Her translators provide an English idiom that is inoffensive if uninspired. Moreau's facts feel trustworthy and often hard won. Though her judgments are predictable and incline toward the simplistic, they are sound. Yet The Restless Journey of James Agee is a lifeless and perfunctory biography that gives the sense of having been written against its author's will.

title: After Windfall, Back on the Job
description: MINEOLA Three months ago, Anthony J. Califano won $980,000 in a Colossal YearEnd Bonus Prize, run by the New York State Lotery. It was said to be the largest chunk of money ever awarded in an American sweepstake.

title: L.I. BUILDERS' GROUP TO GIVE AWAY HOUSE
description: MELVILLE, L.I., April 30People aren't buying homes on Long Island like they used to, so the Long Island Builders Institute is giving one away.

title: Elizabeth Mackey Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adam Richard Mackey of Valhalla, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Clark Mackey of New York, to James Campbell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Campbell of Montrose, N. Y.

title: Benched by Seniority
description: THIS WEEK John A. Speziale is to be sworn in as a justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court. He has been, for many years, a wellregarded trial judge, with a reputation in the bar for integrity and good sense. But Judge Speziale's personal qualities were, at best, marginal factors in his appointment. Far more important was the fact that he had reached the position of chief judge of the Superior Court and was therefore in line for an automatic promotion to the Supreme Court.

title: CONVICTION IS OBTAINED WITHOUT VOICE PRINTS
description: SCRANTON, Pa., April 30Adam Topa, 57 years old, of Scranton has been found guilty of murder in the first degree without the use of voice prints.

title: For: They Reflect the Real World
description: ARE STANDARDIZED tests headed for extinction? To judge from news reports, magazine articles and some popular books the answer might seem to be yes. A variety of charges have been laid against them, and there is substance to some. But the effects are neither so overpowering nor so harmful as the critics imply. On balance the case for standardized tests is persuasive.

title: Still Missing, Still Hope
description: THE Vietnam War has finally ended for the families of the 11 American pilots whoso bodies were repatriated by Ifahgr last month. But Jeanne and Salvatate Mascari of Caldwell are still waiting On May 2, 1969, their son Phillip was on a routine reconnaissance missios over Laos in an 02 A Cessna. The plane disappeared, and Phillip, a first lieutenant in the Air Force, was listed as missing in action. He has not been seen or heard from since.

title: COMMENTARY
description: British managementlte style and purposebaffles me. I have functioned as a manager, I have advised scores of British firms on management, and latterly I have scrutinized their productivity as a member of a House of Commons committee. At the heart of my dilemma is the same reaction that visiting American executives have when faced with recruiting the local Brits. British managers seem to lack any honesttogoodness motivation to do the job.

title: Ballet: Miss Gregory's Sylphide
description: There is a vast diffeience between the tragic and poignant although it is a difference more readily evident than easily definable. Let us take those two famous early 19thcentury ballet classics, Giselle and La Sylphide, the latter on Friday night being revived for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House by the American Ballet Theater, which, between ourselves is why we are taking them.

title: GARDENING
description: THOUGH tomatoes are the most popular vegetable gardeners grow, lettuce is certainly a close second. There is nothing to equal succulent leaves picked minutes before lunch or dinner and tossed in a summer salad. The seeds are so easy ??? grow; even those who hate to garden could be convinced.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: NINETYFIVE percent of what is sold in Westchester antiques shops and shows is paraphernalia bought for fun. A pair of Model T Ford headlights are purchased in Hartsdale to be electrified into bathroom sconces. Ten old wooden molding planes are bought from a dealer in Nyack. A 19thcentury English coal scuttle is sold in a shop in Larchmont. The buyer tellR Roberta Wexler, proprietor of Coldstream Antiques, that she loves it and will use it to hide dogfood cartons.

title: Peter
description: sits not on but all over her tiny chairsPotter says:

title: Negotiations on Philippines Insurgency Are Broken Off After 6 Months
description: MANILA, April 30A sixmonth diplomatic effort to end the Moslem insurgency in the southern Philippines failed tonight when a panel of Islamic negotiators abandoned the talks and prepared to leave for the Middle East.

title: The World
description: Although Ethiopia's decision to close United States agencies and expel their staff of 300 seemed dramatic, the order was a logical extension of Ethiopian policy.

title: U.S. Opposes Hunts on Soybean Holdings
description: Few commodities touch the lives and pocketbooks of Americans as much as soybeans, although it is a rare consumer who has ever seen the peasized, buffcolored legumes, much less bouaht them.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are sof tcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This analysis is based on reports from representative wholesalers and chains with more than 10.000 outlets in the United States.

title: Governor's Race; Women Step Aside
description: Not since McSorleyse Bar opened its doors to women or the College of Cardinals elected the Pope has there been such an assemblage of men. A virtual brigade of the male species of various types and qualifications is stampeding the primary campaign trail in search of that muchheralded political prize: the Governorship of the State of New Jersey.

title: Littler Leads by 5 in Houston Golf
description: HOUSTON, April 30 (AP)Gene Littler birdied the par5 16th hole after a controversial shot to the green, finished with a fiveunderpar 67 and opened a fivestroke lead over George Burns in today's third round of the $200,000 Houston open golf tournament.

title: Robert W. Ballin, 74, an Executive In Advertising for Major Agencies
description: Robert W. Ballin, a New York and Hollywood advertising executive who was active in radio entertainment and programming, died March 20 at his Silver Falls Ranch in Montague, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: Tarrytown Digs Into History
description: GLODE REQUA, a moderately welloff tenant farmer who came to live around Tarrytown in 1723, never achieved the immortality that was conferred upon his landowning neighbors of the Colonial era, Frederick Phillips and Stephen Van Courtlandt.

title: U.S. AID AGAINST HANOI IS ASKED BY DEFECTOR
description: AWA KOMINATO, Japan, April 30A member of the Vietnamese National Legislature in Hanoi, who escaped to Japan earlier this month, urged the United States today to give military assistance, in the form of supplies and money, to Vietnamese who want to overthrow the Communist Government.

title: Cancer Scientists Find Fluorescent Lamps Can Cause Mutations in Chromosomes of Hamster Cells
description: Scientists at the National Cancer Institute have found that the light from ordinary fluorescent lamps can cause mutations in the chromosomes of hamster cells grown in glass dishes.

title: MOUNT VERNON SEEKS AIRRGHTS BUILDING
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 30Officials, of this suburban city have proposed that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority allow them to build office buildings and hotel facilities on air rights over the tracks of the New Haven Division commuter line, which cuts the city in half.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE'S a lot more to Hungarian cooking than paprika and goulash, hardly news to those experienced in the gourmet world but worth repeating for those who are only beginning their adventures in eating. Guided by some Hungarian friends thoroughly acquainted with the cooking and serving of their classic dishes, we visited Chinta, perhaps the only true Hungarian restaurant in the Westchester area.

title: What the Test Scores Do and Don't Say About a Child
description: PUTTING, ASIDE all the sticky questions about whether standardized tests are good or bad or whether they measure anything worth measuring, what do the scores really mean statistically? How precise are they? How much do they tell you, about how well your child is doing in comparison with others?

title: GIANNI CUCELLI
description: MILAN, Italy, April 30 (AP)Gianni Cucelli, Italy's leading tennis star in the late 1940's and a veteran of a number of Davis Cup matches, died here today of an internal hemorrhage. He was 60 years old.

title: HENRY KOPEL
description: Henry Kopel, founder and president of the Kopel Creative Productions Service Company of Union, N. J., died Friday at his office. He was 71 years old and lived at 806 Morris Turnpike, Short Hills, N. J.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Offices put up small posters Is Gambling Making Your Life Unhappy?as part of a campaign by the National Council on Compulsive Gambling to wean gambling addicts from their habit. The posters suggested a call to (212) 6866160.

title: Hetty Tebbs Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Binds Tebbs of Ridgwood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hetty Harris Tebbs, to HermannGtinther Hoyt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Larkin Hoyt of Newburgh, N.Y. The future bride attended Ostra Gymnasiet in Umea, Sweden, and graduated from Rutgers lege. Her fianc, an alumnus of the Kent School and Rutgers, teaches German at Rutgers University.

title: GARDENING
description: Though tomatoes are the most popular vegetable gardeners grow, lettuce is certainly a close second. There is nothing to equal succulent leaves picked minutes before lunch or dinner and tossed in a summer salad. The seeds are so easy to grow; even those who hate gardening could be convinced.

title: U.S. HOSPITAL PLAN GAINS IN NEW YORK
description: President Carter's legislative plan to cut soaring hospital costs has generated the widespread opposition that Administration leaders in Washington anticipated from the healthcare industry across the country.

title: Blair Is Making Inroads in Arts
description: BLAIR ACADEMY'S new Bindeman Music Center is a renovated threestory wooden house that was built before the turn of the century. It was last used as a nursery school, and before that it served as an infirmary.

title: Mary Metzger Wed To John C. Harvey
description: In St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Mary Catherine Metzger of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Asher Metzger of Houston, yesterday afternoon became the bride of John Christopher Harvey, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Condit Harvey of Bereenfield. N. J.

title: NEW YORK EXECUTIVES TO PROMOTE THE CITY
description: Creation of an Ambassador, Corps of businessmen to boost New York City as they travel around the country and the world was announced ???? yesterday by the Office of ??? Development and Bankers Trust Company.

title: VIETNAMESE REFUSE TO SELL U.S. ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, April 29The Vietnamese Government has quietly turned down offers from several African and Asian nations to buy American weapons, much of them no doubt in poor condition, left after the collapse of the South Vietnamese Government two years ago, according to State Departmment and Pentagon sources. The Vietnamese have also declined to supply guerrilla movements in Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines, the sources said.

title: Budgetary Snub From Albany
description: THE state giveth and the state taketh away, Suffolk County Executive John V.N. Klein wrote recently, paraphrasing an earlier martyr to a power beyond his control.

title: Deaths
description: SACKSMax, The Long Beach Memorial Hospital Auxiliary and myself mourn the passing of Max Sacks, husband of Pauline and Honorary Vice President of the Board of Directors. Pauline becks was riesident or the Auxiliar, for 9 years. Sincere sympathy to the family.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market opened last Monday with a jarring declineits worst of 1977, as measured by the Dow Jones industrialsand then spent the rest last week regaining its equilibrium.

title: COYERUP IS CHARGED IN GEORGE POLK DEATH
description: The possibility of a massive coverup of facts relating to the disappearance and murder of George Polk, a CBS correspondent who was working in Greece at the time of his death in May 1948, has been raised by two journalists who spent nine months researching more than 3,000 documents and interviewing dozens of people connected with the case.

title: En Route to Mr. Carter's First Summit
description: WASHINGTONIn the 17th Century townhouse of George Downing, where British prime ministers have lived and worked since 1935, the leaders of seven industrialized countries will gather next weekend for a little group therapy and to greet a new member of the club, President Carter.

title: Does Coaching Help on Tests? Sometimes.
description: CAN YOU improve your scores on standardized tests by coaching, cram courses or doityourself home study books? The answer appears to be a qualified yeswith the strongest qualification applied by the test makers.

title: Briton Breaks Walk Mark
description: EWELL, England, April 30 (UPI)Don Ritchie of Britain set a world record for the 50kilometer run today with a time of 2 hours 51 minutes 38 seconds at a regional meet. Ritchie sliced five minutes off the previous mark held by another Briton, Joe Keating.

title: INTERVIEW
description: UNTIL this week, Jeff Orvedahl, a 17yearold Waldwick High School senior, could look forward to a stimulating summer stint of packing boxes on a factory assembly line. Now he will have to settle for a month of free vacation and education as a New Jersey delegate to the National Youth Science Camp.

title: COMMENTARY
description: British managementlte style and purposebaffles me. I have functioned as a manager, I have advised scores of British firms on management, and latterly I have scrutinized their productivity as a member of a House of Commons committee. At the heart of my dilemma is the same reaction that visiting American executives have when faced with recruiting the local Brits. British managers seem to lack any honesttogoodness motivation to do the job.

title: ART
description: GOOD artists create works that yield something to different ages. It may or may not be the same thing, depending on the point of view, but the art work continues to live, vital with the essences and realities of man and life.

title: Vorster Reports Progress On SouthWest Africa
description: VRADENDAL, South Africa, April 30 (UPI)Prime Minister John Vorster said today that progress has been made in talks on the future of SouthWest Africa with representatives of five Western nations.

title: Survivor of Canary Islands Crash Files Damage Suit for $9.5 Million
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 (AP)A survivor whose husband died in the collision of two jets at a Canary Islands air port last month filed yesterday a $9.5 million damage suit contending that the illfated last leg of the flight could have been avoided.

title: Mets Win
description: SAN DIEGO April 30The famous Out of Order Offense of the New York Mets got Tom Seaver the runs he needed to post his fourth victory of the season tonight in a 41 decision over the San Diego Padres.

title: In the Corporate World More Talk Than Progress
description: The young investment banker, who was a partner in a New York venturecapital firm, a director of a manufacturing firm and a consultant in international finance, was being considered for a subCabinet position in the Commerce Department.

title: The Debate: Pro and Con
description: Increasingly, major educational organizations are calling for an end to standardized achievement tests, contending they provide faulty measurement of student achievement. Others defend the tests as effective and efficient. The following argument against the tests is by Mitchell Lazarus, a psychologist, and Edwin F. Taylor, a physicist, who are working on alternative testing methods at the Education Development Center in Newton, Mass. The defense is by Robert L. Ebel, professor of educational psychology at Michigan University.

title: Andy Lobell Captures Meadowlands Feature
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 30 Andy Lobell paced the fastest American mile of the season tonight as he beat Shadyside Trixie by two lengths in the $30,000 freeforall feature before a crowd of more than 28,182 at the Meadowlands.

title: Getting In the Swim and Staying There
description: IT is 6:55 A.M. and the swimmers standing alongside the Huntington Y.M.C.A. pool display the eagerness of earlybird bargain hunters awaiting the opening of a super sale.

title: Cup Yacht Too Light?
description: The designer of Courageous, 1974 winner of the America's Cup, has admitted that the yacht was 297 pounds wider the weight requirement when it won the most prestigious event in international yacht racing.

title: The F.B.I. Once Honored Its Bag Jobs
description: WASHINGTONZIn the 1950's and early 60's, it was a point of pride for a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent to be picked for a bag job, the bureau's euphemism for an illegal breakin. For one thing, it meant that the agent was wellregarded by his superiors; we didn't pick lunkheads for bag fobs. we picked seasoned experienced veterans. one former bureau official insists. For another, bag jobs often meant cash incentives of $150 or more, known within the bureau as M.V.P. (for Mast Valuable Player) Awards.

title: Locked In A Library In Search Of Bodoni
description: Giambattista Bodoni. An eminent type designer and printer around the turnofthe19thcentury in Italy, his work became known to me in my nowdistant youth. Each time I finished a volume published by Alfred A. Knopf, I turned with fascination to the last leaf, which customarily contained A note on the type in which the pages were set. There I first became aware of typographyand of Bodoni. [For a sample of his work, see the fourline headline at right.]

title: New Way to Grow
description: THERE is a green streak in all of us that a seed catalogue brings out, but this year, while friends are being seduced by the palatepleasing pictures in the succulent seed sellers and battling within themselves whether to be or not to be organic gardeners, I will be planning my own garden sans seed catalogue.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IM thrilled, said an exuberant Wesley W. Horton, the 35yearold lawyer from Canton who brought the suit on behalf of his son Barnaby that led to the ruling by the Connecticut Supreme Court earlier this month ordering a reform of publicschool financing.

title: Events Today
description: YANKEE PEDDLER FLEA MARKET: Antiques, handicrafts, plants; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; parking lot behind the courthouse, off Richmond Road, Richmondtown, Staten Island. (Admission 50 cents for adults and 25 rents tor children. Benefit of Staten Island Historical Society.)

title: North and South: The Differences Endure
description: SAIGON, Vietnam (AP)A recent 1,000mile trip from Hanoi to Saigon by road and air disclosed a stillspartan way of life in the North and a relatively affluent one in the South. A freemarket system prevails in the southern sector, with food and consumer goods more in abundance than in the North.

title: Rumania Team Gains
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 30 (AP)Rumania clinched its Davis Cup European zone tennis series with Belgium today when Ion Tiriac and The Nastase defeated Tillery Stevaux and John de Muynck, 62, 61, 64, in doubles. The victory gave Rumania an unbeatable 30 lead.

title: DINING OUT
description: FOR warmth and charm of setting, or imagination of menu, few restaurants on the Island can compete with the Brasserie St. Germain in Manhasset. Walls of mellow brick graced with paintings and curios, each bathed in a circle of soft light, provide the background for a series of rooms furnished with dark wood tables and comfortable pseudosueded armchairs.

title: Marie Davidson Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Davidson of New Rochelle, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Merle Suzanne Davidson, to David Leland Klein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Klein of New Rochelle. Miss Davidson is a special education teacher at the Clear View School in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. Mr. Klein is an assistant district attorney of Westchester County. Miss Davidson's father is a dentist, as is her fiance's father. Wellesley, founder and president of the United States Patent Corporation, and of the late Dan Sullivan of Newton, Mass., the pianist and songwriter who wrote Macushla. His father, regional service representative for the Pontiac division of General Motors, also played clarinet and banjo with several jazz groups.

title: The Motor Vehicle Torture
description: AS many highschool students throughout New York already know, by your 16th birthday you are eligible to obtain a classsix learner's permit, and consequently classsix license. This means that you are permitted (by law) to be psychologically tortured by the White Plains Motor Vehicles Bureau.

title: Television This Week
description: 10:30 A.M. (2) LOOK UP AND LIVE. A rebioadcast of a halfhour examination of the goals and methods of genetic research; with Dr. Victor A. McKusick, chief of the Department of Medicine at John Hopkins University School of Medicine; Prof. Francisco Ayola of the University of California's Department of Genetics; Rev. Bernard Haring of the Kennedy Institute's Center of Bioethics; and Rev. Roger Shinn, president of the Union Theological Seminary.

title: Insulation by the Gas Company
description: ONE of Connecticut's five major utilities has already begun a program resembling one proposal in President Carter's energy program that would require utilities to offer their customers a residential energy conservation service, such as home insulation.

title: Monmouth Tunes In On its String Band
description: ELEVENYEAROLD Chad Irons wasn't a gleam anywhere when songs such as Alabama Jubilee, Alabama Bound and Avalon were in their heyday. However, today, when he sits down to play with the Happy Days String Band of Monmouth County, he bangs them Out with the best of them.

title: A Full House of Lhasa Apso Champions
description: Steve Campbell loves to play poker and he should be lucky because he has a royal flush of Lhasa Apso kings and queens at home. Ch. Tabu's King of Hearts will be only 7 years old June 2, but he has been the breed's reigning News of Dogs stud in the nation for more than two years. Among the 18 champions King has sired is a bestinshow dog, Ch. Rimar's J. G. King Richard, bred and coowned by

title: Anglican Leader Leaves Rome
description: ROME, April 30 (UPI)  The Arch. bishop of Canterbury, ending two days of talks and prayers for Christian unity with Pope Paul VI, left for Istanbul today to meet with Orthodox Church leaders. Before boarding the flight to the Turkish capital, Dr. Donald Coggan visited St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City for an hour.

title: PAULINE FONTANA
description: Pauline Fontana, the mother of Dr. Vincent J. Fontana, chairman of Mayor Beame's Task Force on Child Abuse and Neglect and medical director of the New York Foundling Hospital, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived at 8757 96th Street in Woodhaven, Queens.

title: COUNSEL FOR KOREANS QUITS OVER BRIBE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 A former member of the House Select Committee on Intelligence has withdrawn as legal counsel to the Korean Embassy because diplomats there rejected his advice to cooperate with the Department of Justice in the Korean bribery scandal.

title: Multiple Alternatives to Multiple Choice
description: SCHOOL SYSTEMS across the country are developing new ways to measure student progress without the drawbacks ascribed to standardized tests.

title: A Disputed Tap Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April. 29Foreign intelligence is the last area in which the Government may engage in electronic surveillance on its own initiative and without a court order. High Carter Administration officials say they are now circulating to interested members of Congress a draft measure that would close the door to this final area of unrestricted bugging and tapping, and that is improved in three major particulars over a Ford Administration bill that foundered last year.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN LEGEND (USL). Le Havre May 14; sails from Howland Hook, Staten Island.

title: When a Rocky Road Is Fun
description: THERE are discotheque rock and cradle rock, candy rock and coastal rock, supporting rock and pet rock. Then there are collectors' rock and lapidary rockwhich spell hobby rock and make the Long Island Rock Shop, one flight up at 2704 Grand Avenue in Bellmore, a place of fascination.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I believe Barbara Wolfson may have done'a disservice [Speaking Personally, March 27] to all those jurors who will be called to serve in the future. It is only recently that women have the obligation to serve. To discourage them with the negative impressions Barbara Wolfson received and reported is to reinforce the familiar attitudes expressed by many men when they receive the dreaded subpoena to appear for jury duty.

title: Testing for Legality
description: THE controversy over standardized testing is forcing courts to consider delicate questions of equal protection, secrecy and liability. In 1973, a Federal appeals court let stand the dismissal of an Iowa teacher who contended that she had been dismissed solely because her students performed badly on a series of standardized tests. The appeals court found that the local school board's action was not so unwarranted as to be an abuse of discretion and therefore the teacher was not protected by the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.

title: Getting Into College: What Counts at Cornell
description: CORNELL'S admissions office is the smallest in the Ivy League, with only four fulltime professionals. Each heads a selection.

title: Changes Come To Wall Street
description: On the surface, Wall Street hasn't changed much in the last two years. The New York Stock Exchange still faces the SubTreasury Building in the heart of the financial district, and the salesmen at nearby brokerage and investment banking houses are still on the phone making thousands of telephone calls daily to stimulate interest in buying and selling stocks and bonds.

title: FOOD
description: DEFINE dumpling. According to The Dumpling Cookbook by Maria Polushkin (Workman Publishing, 1977, $3.95, paper), it is a meatball, a fritter, a turnover, a filled bit of noodle dough. It maybe called vareniki, gnocchi, shui mai, pelmeni, calas. The category is vast and allinclusive, and the subject is a tasty, savory morsel that exists in virtually every cuisine.

title: Cosmos Look to the Stars and Hope
description: After last Sunday's disheartening loss to Dallas, evening their record at two victories and two losses, the Cosmos need a victory today against the St. Louis Stars to cure their blues. The game, which will start at 2:05 P.M.,

title: New York State Employees Rate Treatment by Agencies as Low
description: ALBANY, April 30A poll of New York State civil servants found that they rate the agencies they work for high in terms of service to the public, but low in terms of the way the agencies employees are treated.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BETHELSperry Andrews, regional landscapes in oil and watercolor. Today through May 25, Bethel Gallery, 186 Greewood Ave. Wednesday through Sunday 11 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.

title: A Football Draftnik Tells How He Got That Way
description: People like me have been called draftniks. Despite the name, there is nothing foreign about my work. What I do for a living is rate every college football player who has a chance to be selected by a National Football League team.

title: A Time to Raise Sails And Start Engines
description: TODAY is the traditional start of the sixmonth boating season in the metropolitan area. Although memories of winter remain, most large marinas have been able to repair floats and docks destroyed by ice.

title: Why Schools Use Standardized Tests
description: THERE were shouts of scandal when it was discovered that copies of a reading test that was to be administered in a majority of New York City's schools had been widely distributed among teachers and pupils. Groups of parents and educators charged those who had broken the test's security with deliberate fraud, and the State Supreme Court temporarily barred the use of the compromised examination. City officials complained that the episode had possibly wasted hundreds of thousands of scarce school dollars.

title: High Trails for the Tyro
description: There is something new under the sun, at least for our family: the pleasurethe exhilarationof hiking up mountain trails. During a 16day August vacation in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, we hiked five trails, not pickandrope stuff but hard work over many hours with some occasional climbing on all fours.

title: Linda M. Lobel Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon Lobel of New Hyde Park, L. I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Marlene Lobel, to Dennis Angel son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Angel of North Woodmere, L. I. Miss Lobel, an artist, and her fiance, a lawyer, plan to be married in Great Neck on May 15. Mr. Lobel, a partner of M. Lobel & Sons Inc, a New York retail meat concern.

title: Pauline Covington Wed to William Tucker 4th
description: Pauline Wyatt Emery Covington was married yesterday to William Grant Tucker 4th in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Terence J. Finlay.

title: Raggedy Ann to Riches
description: CAN a wholesome Hoosier rag doll survive that ultimate American perilsuccessand still hang onto some shred of her homespun integrity?

title: A Crop of Nevelsons Picked for Purchase
description: IN North Haven, Conn., about 75 miles northeast of White Plains, in an area of factory lofts and light industry, travelers pull off the road to gape at a 14acre field filled with what look like giant totems. They loom on the horizon, near a red mound of earth, staring straight ahead with disturbing persistence. There is nothing timid about themjust as there is nothing timid about the woman who created them.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor: That Glyn Daniel (March 13) dismisses as rubbish Harvard professor Barry Fell's America, B.C.: Ancient Settlers in the New World, is unfortunate, as it discourages scholars from examining hard evidence underpinning Fell's theories.

title: The Forties Revisited
description: SALLY J. FREEDMAN is an adolescent Jewish girl from New Jersey in this novel set in the 1940's. She has a dentist father whom she adores, a moody conscientious mother, a fink brother with health problems and a folksy livein grandmother. The Freedman family moves to Florida for a school year to speed the boy's recovery from a bout with nephritis. The father must stay behind to see to his dental practice and can only visit his family infrequently, leaving them to deal alone with their new surroundings  new schools, new people and a culture of senility and suntans.

title: Faulty Education In a Coloring Book.
description: RYAN GEORGE MENDOZA is 5 years old. He plays the guitar and mandolin. He has been stream fishing in Yugoslavia, where he pulled in many brown trout. He is beginning to read books quite well: He sines and boxes, hunts and pecks wards on an old typewriter I gage him and says grace before every evening meal. I call him Rascalhe is my son.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Last call to feed roses and finish pruning After flower petal fall is a critical time for application of many fruit tree fungus disease controls: check spray schedules on labels of multipurpose mixtures The garden soil is still cold for planting corn, beans, melons and cucumbers; wait a week or two Finish dividing old clumps of perennials; plant new ones Control birch leaf miner with three applications of Cygon or MetaSystoxR in midMay, late May and midJune.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW JERE EDITOR
description: So New Jersey is making a major effort to bolster the state's medical manpower (April 10). The article itself admits that progress has been impeded by a cutback in medical education funds to the state medical colleges.

title: COLLEGE GIFTS TOTAL $2.41 BILLION FOR '7576
description: Donations to the nation's colleges and universities reached a new high of $2.41 billion in the 197576 academic year, according to the annual survey released yesterday by the Council for Financial Aid to Education.

title: A Shepherd in New Canaan
description: IT'S A FAR piece from the frontiers of the Old West to the tidy precincts of New Canaan, but to a visitor ambling through the town it might seem that something like a latterday range war had been fought there.

title: The Maypole's Close Call
description: HOORAY, hooray, it's the first of May, and anybody who doesn't know what that means had better get over to the North Shore Community Arts Center in Great Neck and find out that, yes, there Is a maypole, and that as sure as sap and a summer day, a troupe of maidens will 6e dancing around it this morning.

title: New York City Optimistic Over Rate of Tourism The Highest Since 1969
description: Visitors to New York City this year are exceeding those for the corresponding period in 1976, which was the city's best year for tourism here since 1969. And the rise is expected to continue.

title: Carter Has Yet to Make a Real Mark in Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTONPresident Carter goes abroad this week to begin to practice at first hand what has come to hold much of his attention in Washington: the conduct and shaping of foreign affairs. He takes with him a record of vigorous involvement but a record of mixed results.

title: Miss Theimer Bride of V. L. Nepomnyaschchy
description: Catharine Stephanie Theimer. and Vyacheslav Lvovich Nepomnyaschchy were married yesterday in Rumson, N.J., seven years after they met in the Soviet Union.

title: For Sale: Ph.D.'s, Etc.
description: SANTA ANA, Calif. CALIFORNIA Western University does not have ivy, a quadrangle, a gymnasium, a fraternity row or, for that matter, classrooms. But as Steven B. McNanama points out: Our degrees are printed by the same organization that produces them for S.C. [the University of Southern California] and Stanford. We have class rings, too.

title: Mixed Feelings
description: Only a few years ago, the indictment of a former official of the Federal Bureau of Investigation would have been a national trauma. But an official has been indicted, and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has said he is not likely to review the indictment. He clearly has mixed feelings in the matter.

title: Oil Slick off Florida Keys Breaking Up at Sea
description: MIAMI, April 30 (AP)A 60milelong smear of oil that floated dangerously close to the Florida Keys and the continent's only living coral reef began breaking up today, still safely at sea, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Pesticide Poisoning Found In Imported Cut Flowers
description: The center said the poisoning occurred last October among florist employees in Colorado. It said the suspected poison was organophosphate, which caused neurologic symptoms including double vision, headaches, blurred vision and muscle weakness.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Continued From Page 67 Frazetta is a Sicilian boy from Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay section, who passed up a chance to play professional baseball to lead the more solitary role of artist. For years he turned out realistic drawings for comic strips (L'il Abner), magazines (Playboy) and comic books; then, in the mid'60's, a chance to do covers for a new edition of Edgar Rice Burroughs's Tarzan series allowed him a chance to abandon traditional artistic restraint. His paintings, glistening with muscles and breasts, dark with fearsome beasts, soon began collecting a cult. His wife Ellie developed a great little business selling, tens of thousands of his pictures in poster form by mail and through head shops and bookstores. Then, in late 1975, came the Peacock album; its recordbreaking success established his position as lord of the genre.

title: Bottling Up the Bottle Bill
description: WHEN the Connecticut House of Representatives last month passed the socalled bottle bill which would ban fliptop cans and require that deposits be paid on beer and softdrink bottlesthe people in the gallery rose to their feet and cheered.

title: New York Projects Some Growth
description: The New York City economy is expected to grow modestly over the next few years, but nut enough tho sustain the current level of services the city's government is providing for its citizens. That is the view of First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti and other top city officials, and it is based on the findings of an econometric model of New York that was used to predict tax revenues for the 197778 budget Mayor Beame proposed last week.

title: Engagements
