description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Shuldman of Great Neck, N.Y. happily announce the engagement of their daughter Beth Rana to Mr. Gary Ronald Brill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Brill of Englewood Cliffs, N.J.

title: Keeping Rain Water Out Of the Basement
description: A high percentage of wet basement problemsa chronic spring headache for many homeowners, especially this year when many areas have experienced heavierthannormal rainfalls and some flooding are caused by poor drainage of surface water around the outside of the house. Water accumulates in the soil surrounding the house, then seeps down next to the foundation where it finds its way into the basement through cracks, porous sections in the masonry, or poorly sealed joints (such as where the basement floor meets the walls).

title: Conference on Economics: The Record Is Quite Spotty
description: PARISWhen President Carter and heads of governments from West Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and Japan meet next weekend to discuss the world's economy, there is a natural expectation among ordinary mortals that they might plan to do something about the economy. But this is unlikely. All the participants, in advance, are in agreement on the kind of world economic picture they would like to see. But they don't agree on how to complete it.

title: SUFFOLK IS OPPOSED ON ENVIRONMENT ACT
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation is opposing moves by Suffolk County to enact its own environmental protection act to bypass state enforcement procedures in local pollution cases.

title: CRIME
description: Here are two novels with an African locale: TO CATCH A VIPER by John Wyllie (Doubleday, $5.95) and DEATH IN THE DESERT by John R. L. Anderson (Stein and Day, $7.95). Both are books in continuing series. Dr. Quarshie, the big Canadiantrained black physician, is Wyllie's hero; this is his third appearance. Col. Peter Blair, who has appeared in four previous Anderson books, now finds himself in Africa in Death in the Desert.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: Apparently Alvin Ailey has been as busy as bee this winter. His threeweek spring season, which opens Wednesday at City Center, offers five premieres. The openingnight gala includes The Wait, choreographed by Milton Myers for Judith Jamison, and Crossword, choreographed for Ailey's American Dance Theater by Jennifer Muller. On Thursday, it's Coverage II, and on Friday, Countdown, both solos choreographed by Rudy Perez. And the following week has Dianne McIntyre's Ancestral Voices, with music by Cecil Taylor, and scenic and costume designs by artist Romare Bearden. (See Dance)Clamma Dale, who may be remembered as one of the three sopranos who rotated as Bess in Porgy and Bess on Broadway this season, also has on her, rsum, at age 28, a master's degree from Juilliard, the first prize in the Naumburg Voice Competition and a threeyear contract with New York City Opera. On Thursday, at Alice Tully Hall, Miss Dale will give a recital of songs ranging from an Alban Berg lied to Johnny I hardly knew ye. (See Music)Since Breezin, which sold almost two million records, jazz guitarist George Benson has moved a bit off center, from strictly jazz to jazzpop, in his latest album, In Flight. Now he has decided it's about time to play, live, in his home town, where he hasn't performed in nearly year, and not just once but four times. The concerts, scheduled next weekend with a hangover on Monday, include an unusual mix of performing artists accompanying Benson. On Friday, at the Metropolitan Museum, Benson will hold guitar jam with Les Paul, Bucky Pizzarelli and Gabor Zabo; on Saturday, at the Palladium, he will be joined by pop female vocalist Minnie Riperton; next Sunday, at Avet y Fisher Hall, the Dance Theater of Harlem will perform three works choreographed by Arthur Mitchell to Benson's music; and on Monday, again at Avery Fisher, it's back to basics in a hardcore jazz program with contemporaries Joe Sample, Grover Washington Jr., Harvey Mason, Ralph McDonald and Alphonso Johnson. (See Music)

title: Cardinal's Condition Serious
description: SOUTHFIELD, Mich., April 30 (AP)John Cardinal Dearden, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit, remained in serious but stable condition today as he recovered from a heart attack. according to archdiocese officials. Cardinal. Dearden, 69years old, was In the cardiac care unit at Providence Hospital, where he was taken Wednesday after suffering the attack at his home.

title: Bringing Back the Ink and Pen
description: AFTER the electric typewriter, calligraphy. The art of beautiful handwriting, the graceful script of the dippen rather than the graceless scribble of the ballpoint, is being revived. Inkmanship is a status symbol.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Eidtor:

title: July Bridal Set By Miss Oxnam
description: Mary Elizabeth Oxnam, a musicalcomedy actress known as Marybeth Oxnam, plans to be married in July to Francis Grant Sullivan 2d, a powersystems engineer with Unitid Engineers and Constructors in Boston.

title: A Secular Lover
description: Everyone has seen, I imagine, the picture of Robert Greeley that for years was used on his book jackets and elsewhere: lean figure, black hair and beard, sitting slouched vet tense on a table, a statuette of a falcon in front of him; dark, enigmatic, fierce, sexyromantic. Indeed, among all the poets who have followed the line of William Carlos Williams and Charles Olsen  Projectionists, Black MountaineersCreeley is most the romanticist; even, as he has unabashedly said, the sentimentalist. It isn't simply the romanticism of Shelley either, but on back through Lovelace and Herrick, the troubadours, Catullus, to the ancient Arcadians; and forward too into our own time. Odds are that when Creeley was young he read the poems of Elinor Wylie, not without appreciation.

title: Group to Buy Flamingos for Zoo
description: PHILDELPHIA, April 30 (AP) The McDonalds Operators Association in the Philadelphia area, a restaurant operators group, has pledged $4,800 to the Philadelphia Zoo for the purchase of six flamimgos to replace most of the eight killed by vandals, a zoo spokesman said.

title: VANCE ASKS REALISM IN U.S. RIGHTS POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, April 30Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the United States, in promoting human rights abroad, must be realistic and avoid rigidly trying to impose its values on other countries.

title: Sports Today
description: National Hot Rod Association's Spring Grand Nationals, at New York National Speedway, Center Moriches, L.I., 2 P.M.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Jack Mitchell

title: The Region
description: Using their control of the Senate as leverage, Republicans in the New York State Legislature have scored political advantage on measures concerning rent regulations and mortgage Interest rates that are important to voters in this year's municipal and next year's gubernatorial elections.

title: Barbara Ridder Long Wed to David Irwin In New Vernon, N.J.
description: The Presbyterian Church in New Vernon, N. J., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Barbara Ridder Long of New Vernon to David King Irwin, also of New Vernon. The Rev. George E. Chorba performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: The name of Dr. Richard Eisenberg, professor of chemistry, University of Rochester, was inadvertently omitted from the list of John Simon Guggenhelm Memorial Foundations fellowship awards in The Times of April 10. He was given the award for studies in organometallic chemistry.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: Colette, Spies, Relations

title: Polly Williams Wed To Peter T. Zarella
description: Pony Connor Williams, daughter of Mrs. John Avery Ingersoll Jr. of Old Saybrook, Conn., and the late Donald Turnbull Williams, was married yesterday afternoon in New York to Peter Thomas Zarella, a partner in the Boston law firm of Sullivan & Zarella.

title: Indian Sketchbook
description: AHUNDRED years ago the United States Army exiled its military prisoners of the Indian Wars to a sultry Siberiaa dank and deadly dungeon known as Fort Marion in Florida. Bear's Heart and about 70 other Cheyennes, Arapahos, Kiowas, Comanches and Caddos lived or died there.

title: Gertrude Bondy, 87, Ran School With Her Husband and Her Son
description: Gertrude Bondy, who with her late husband, Max, ran the Windsor Mountain School in Lenox, Mass., from 1939 to 1951, died yesterday in a nursing home in Franklin, Mich. She was 87 years old and for the last year had been living with her daughter in Franklin.

title: Plea by Wilmington 10 Denied
description: RALEIGH, N.C., April 30 (UPI)The North Carolina Supreme Court denied yesterday a request that the nine members of the Wilmington 10 who are still in jall be leleased on bail pending a postconviction hearing May 9 at Burgaw. The group was convicted of conspiring to buns a whiteowned grocery store and ??? at firemen and policemen amid ?? violence in Wilmington in 1971. However, three prosecution, witnesses hays since recanted testimony that helped convict them.

title: Legislators Seek An Energy Czar
description: REACTING swiftly to the prospects of future energy crises in the state, New Jersey legislators are putting together a proposed new law creating a state energy czar.

title: Learning the Ropes As Camp Counselor
description: AT 16, MICHAEL MAHRER was an unpaid but unpaying coop camper at Camp Idylwold on Schroon Lakein the Adirondacks. It was a terrific free vacation. the New York City youngiter said. At 17 he was a paid counselor aide. Last. sununer, at 18, he was back at Camp Idylwold as a full counselor.

title: Behind the Best Sellers:Clive Cussler
description: As an old pro at the typewriter, Clive Cussler is happy to pass around some of the credit for the success of Raise the Titanic! to his editors at The Viking Press. Having been in advertising and writing TV commercials, he says, you develop a rhinoceros skin about your prose.

title: Realty News
description: The F. & M. Schaefer Corporation is expanding its corporate headquarters here and returning after 61 years to Park Avenue.

title: MassTransit Plan Calls for Subsidies
description: AT FIRST glance, New Jersey would seem to he the ideal state in which to develop a comprehensive masstransportation system. It is the most densely populated of all the states and its highways have been criticized for decades as decrepit and inadequate, with many of them turning into parking lots during hot summer weekends or workday rush hours.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE NATION'S BASIC MONEY supply [cash plus checking account balances] declined $300 million in the latest week to $321 billion March building contracts, at $9.93 billion, were up 9 percent over March 1978, F. W. Dodge reported. Residential building at $5.14 billion rose by 42 percent.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Anyone looking up the Cayman Islands in the National Geographic Index will be directed to a 1943 piece entitled Capturing Giant Turtles in the Caribbean. They were speaking of the green turtle (Chelonia mydas) that really is a giant. If fishermen netted one weighing less than 100 pounds they would call it a chicken and turn it loose.

title: High Noon Nears in the Assembly
description: W0ITHOUT serious argument from either Democrats or Republicans, inconsequential and marginal legislation is being cleared away by both parties in the General Assembly, much as the decks would be cleared by hostile fleets moving toward each other for decisive battle. The deadline for adjournmentJune 8is little more than five weeks away.

title: Shawi, $16.80, Defeats Proud Delta by Nose at Aqueduct
description: As if burdened by the knowledge that almost $300,000 had been bet on her to win, Proud Delta twitched and fussed and sweated before taking the Aqueduct track yesterday as the overwhelming choice in the $80,475 Top Flight Handicap.

title: Chartering: Means to an End
description: Money has always been synonymous with yachting and I suspect the relationship is going to last. But there's more than money involved, there's time.

title: Headliners
description: The number of Spanish exiles who have returned home because of the liberalized political environment there in the postFranco era continues to grow. Rafael Alberti, a poet who spent 38 years in voluntary exile, returned to Spain last week. A crowd of hundreds greeted Mr. Alberti (now 74) at Madrid's airport, where, in tears, he told the group: We now return with the outstretched hand of reconciliation. Federica Montseny, the Minister of Health in the last government of the Spanish Republic, and the only woman ever to hold cabinet rank in Spain's history, also returned last week.

title: Dr. Anthony Tarasenko TO Wed Anne Mahaney
description: Anne Marie Mahaney and Dr. Anthony John Tarasenko plan to be married in June. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Miss Mahaney's mother, Mrs. John Walter Mahaney of Natick, Mass. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Tarasenko of Cleveland and Parma. Ohio.

title: Foss's Quartet Plus Given Debdt By Concord Strings and Additions
description: Friday night's premiere of Lukas Foss's Quartet Plus at the New Brooklyn Philharmonia's Festival of Modern Combos at the Brooklyn Academy of Music was actually the first performance of an embellished, expanded version of an earlier score.

title: Hungry Hamster
description: WHEN Max arrived in the mail I had a headache. Growling, I popped an aspirin and scowled. Cartoons! I grumbled. Mickey Mouse Somebody without a headache thinks life can be funny Aware that this was the wrong time to look at Max, I stole a disgusted peek. Max, plump and smiling hamsterlike rodent, was juggling five apples. In a series of eight drawings he gained speed, grace and overconfidence. Galunk, Max swallowed all five apples. Intrigued.

title: Juleps, Roses and Colts: Yes, This Is Derby Week
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30The difference in mint juleps between a winner and a loser, Kentuckians will tell you, is in how you handle the mint.

title: Health Plan Dispute Grows
description: THE Westchester Community Health Plan is one of a new breed of medicalcare programs, the healthmaintenance organization. its advocatesamong them Senator Jacob K. Javits, who was in White Plains last week to speak in favor of the plansee it as a major advance in healthcare, but to many county doctors, it resembles what they call creeping socialism, and they are not reluctant to say so.

title: Soviet Routs U.S., 82, At Hockey Tourney
description: VIENNA, April 30 (AP)The Soviet hockey team swept easily to an 82 victory over the United States squad at the Stadthalle tonight and for the first time took sole possession of the lead in the world championships.

title: SENATE PASSES BILL ON UNINSURED CARS
description: ALBANY, April 30The New York State Senate approved a measure this week that., would require automobile insurance companies to notify the state when their cancel a policy. The aim of the legislation is to keep, uninsured drivers off the road.

title: Showtime On the Raritan
description: EARLY this spring, Sidney Neuwirth of East Brunswick saw a production of Agatha Christie's The Mousetrap at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick. As he walked out of the theater, he spotted Eric Krebs, the playhouse producer. Wait, he told his wife, I want to tell Eric how good the play was.

title: The Delaware: A Canoeist's View
description: Half a mile down from the Delaware River village of Belvidere, we headed the canoes into a likely looking sandy beach and made up our minds to camp for the night. A level, grassy area above the beach would do for our two small tents. A dirt track led back through the thick, riveredge growth of scrubby birch and willow to the village where, a few minutes earlier, we had landed to talk to an elderly shad fisherman and ask about a place to camp. This was the spot he'd suggested, much favored by local anglers.

title: 2,000 Occupy Nuclear Plant Site In New Hampshire, Vow to Stay
description: SEABROOK, N.H., April 30About 2,000 demonstrators moved onto the conStruction site of a nuclear powergenerating plant this afternoon, vowing to occupy it until plans to build it were abandoned.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY houses in this area still have old style fullheight window screens that are taken down each fall, then replaced over the windows each spring.

title: POLITICS
description: AT THIS TIME of year, with their adjournment deadline beginning to close in on them, and with debate warming up in the two chambers of the General Assembly, Connecticut's legislators get that familiar, uneasy feeling that there will not be money enough to pay for all the legislation they want, or promised; and their thoughts turn inevitably to the taxpayer and to new ways, as the French statesman JeanBaptiste Colbert put it three centuries ago, to pluck the goose to get the most feathers with the least hissing.

title: Gertrude Bondy, 87, Ran School With Her Husband and Her Son
description: Gertrude Bondy, who with her late husband, Max, ran the Windsor Mountain School in Lenox, Mass., from 1939 to 1951, died yesterday in a nursing home in Franklin, Mich. She was 87 years old and for the last year had been living with her daughter in Franklin.

title: Just Like the Fifties
description: REMEMBER those college movies of the 50's with letter sweaters, frosh hops, dorm pranks, darling dialogue? Paper Chains is that kind of novel, and except for the fact that the dorms are now coed, nothing much seems to have changed since the Golden Age of Eisenhower.

title: Julian Welch Connolly to Marry Amanda Chilton Cabot on June 18
description: The engagement of Amanda Chilton Cabot to Julian Welch Connolly has been announced by Louis W. Cabot of Boston and Mary Louise Cabot of Wenham, Mass., parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Connolly is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Connolly of Newburyport, Mass. The wedding is planned for June 18.

title: Jeanne Johnson, R. R. Thompson Are Married
description: Jeanne Susan Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Raymond Ford Moreland of Pittsburgh, and Robert Henry Johnson of Highland, Ind., was married yesterday to Robert Read Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Edward Thompson of Wallingford, Conn.

title: Jean Wyatt Corley, William H. Yankus To Be Wed July 30
description: Jean Wyatt Corley plans to be married July 30 to William Henry Yankus of New York, a vice president and account supervisor with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the advertising agency.

title: WILDLIFE SANCTUARY PLANNED OFF VIRGINIA
description: The Nature Conservancy has announced acquisition of all or parts of 13 islands along the Virginia coast for what it says will be the nation's largest privately managed wildlife sanctuary.

title: Arizona State Sets Mark; Waigwa Takes 3:53.8 Mile
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30Arizona State University turned back the clock at the 83d annual Penn Relays today by sweeping the 400, 800 and 1,600 meter relays in spectacular style after Wilson Waigwa won the Ben Franklin Mile in 3 minutes 53.8 seconds with another Silky Sullivantype finish.

title: Miss George, D. E. Kennedy Are Married
description: Heningham Fulton George and Davis Lee Kennedy of Alexandria, Va, were married last evening in Ruxton, Md. The Rev. David F. Gearhart performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Good Shenhenl.

title: TV VIEW
description: After tonight, on Channel 13 at 9 P.M., the Bellamys and their servants will move permanently to the preserved land of reruns. The elegant residence at 165 Eaton Place, in the Belgravia section of London, will be left empty as Upstairs, Downstairs is brought to a gentle but firm conclusion, completing one of the more intriguing production cycles presented on American television. The impact of this British import has certainly been out of proportion to its relatively low ratings. Over the past four years, the series has mustered an average rating of 7, equal to about five million homes nationally. For public TV, that much exposure is substantial, but in the commercialTV market, Upstairs, Downstairs would be relegated to the bottom of the weekly lists. Shows such as Laverne and Shirley regularly score ratings of 32 or higher. Nevertheless, the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, hardly immune to commercial considerations, has twice bypassed the drivel at the top to bestow Emmy Awards on Upstairs, Downstairs as best series of the year. Quality must still be recognized, at least occasionally.

title: Trade in Deficit
description: Energy conservation is as important to the United States as a nation as it is to individual motorists and homeowners. That was the lesson to be learned from last week's announcement of a record monthly trade deficitlargely a result of a huge increase in oil imports.

title: Capeman Tells of Drifting 2 Weeks Around Arizona, Looking for Work and Living Outdoors With Hobos
description: Salvador Agron, the Capeman killer who absconded from a New York State prison studyrelease program on. April 15 and was captured in Phoenix Thursday, said yesterday that he spent most of his two weeks of freedom drifting around Arizona, living outdoors with bums and looking unsuccessfully for menial work.

title: IN AMERICA
description: No Fear of Flying

title: Police Commanders Patrolling Yonkers During Pay Protest
description: Police commanders patrolled Yonkers yesterday as virtually the entire complement of rank and file officers who were scheduled to work called in sick to protest an arbitrartor's contract award made Friday.

title: I.Q. Tests Once Again Disturb Educators
description: T HEI.Q. TEST is once again in the news and once again controversial. As part of its proposed legislation on the handicaoced, the United States Office of Education has proposed a plan to identify children with learning disabilities by looking for discrepancies between the intelligence quotient score and standardized achievement test results. Although the intent of the formula was clearly to force a more specific definition of learning disabled, many educators believe its effect will be the mislabeling of a large number of children.

title: Italy Suspends a Law After Killing of Lawyer
description: ROME. April 30The Government today approved a decree suspending the automatic right of prisoners to be freed pending trial if their case has not been brought to trial within a maximum time limit.

title: Miss Neilson Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis Neilson of Doiset, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Kane Neilson, to William Lawrence Herrick of South Londonderry, Vt. He Is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anson Boulton Herrick of Englewood, N. J.

title: Having a Ball, Racing Through Derby Season
description: LEXINGTON, Ky, April 29The McGraths were having a ball, and why not? They had spent a good part of the winter in Florida, as do many here; the Derby season was on they were, in fact, at a ball, and the early evening torrential rain hadn't caved in the tent.

title: Maureen P. Harnisch Is Wed to John J. Foley Jr.
description: Maureen Patricia Harnisch and John Joseph Foley Jr. both of Atlanta, were married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Christ the King. The Rev: Leo J. Bulger performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. John F. McDonough.

title: Study Says Nassau Needs a Master Plan If It Is to Retain Young People as Residents
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 30Nassau County will have to deal more creatively with the basic problems of housing, employment and job training to retain young people and young families as permanent county residents, according to a study on youth released this week.

title: NEW YORK CITY HIRES COLLECTION AGENCIES
description: New York City's Real Estate Depart ment has hired two private collection agencies to bring in more than $19 million in back rents owed by, tenants of buildings the department manages.

title: Does Yonkers Face
description: JUST two weeks ago, Yonkers officials were jubilant when the city's Emergency Financial Control Board approved the city's first foray into the borrowing market since fiscal problems pushed it to the brink of default in 1975. They looked forward then to the next stepthe withering away of the Control Board by June 30, which would signal that the city's budget was in balance and yet another hurdle had been passed in the 18month financial plan.

title: But in Detroit, Profits Roll In
description: In contrast to the gloom in Pittsburgh last week, the atmosphere in Detroit was gleeful.

title: Deaths
description: STEMPLERSamuel (Smith, to most). Cherished husband of Janel. Adored father of Gaff and Stuart Lab, ??? and ??? Dear ??? of Sylvia Raptra??? Renee Dinoffth, Jack and the late Far. Treasured friend and counselor. Rest in peace, darling. Services Sunday at 12 noon, the Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck (opposite RR station). Gifts to the American Cancer Society will be appreciated.

title: Hail to Thee, Bridge to Nowhere
description: STONY BROOK As if having a halfcompleted bridge in the center of the campus for 10 years was not dubious enough, the students at the State University center here have emblazoned their Tshirts and notebooks with pictures of it and daily spice their conversation with references to it.

title: Seven Splendid Reasons Why Annie Is a Smash
description: First, you notice their facesNorman Rockwell faces, wholesome, appealing, cherubic, seven heads you want to pat and 14 cheeks you want to pinch. And there's more: they sing like angels, they tap like troupers, they do a mean kickline that could teach the Rockettes a thing or two. And their ensemble acting is so tightly knit that you think they've been doing it for yearswhich, of course, they haven't, since they're just kids. Their ages: 7 through 14.

title: Notes: The Forecasts That Bloom in Spring
description: Each spring, as surely as the blooming of daffodils, the travel industry flowers with predictions of the summer season to come. Herewith some of this year's crop:

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayNational Hot Rod Association drag races at National Speedway, Center Moriches, L. I. (Exit 70, L. L. Expressway,) Gates open 8 A.M., finals at 1 P.M.

title: Picture Credits
description: 1 CONTACT GIAN ??? GONI

title: Knock
description: NUTTY NUMBER RIDDLES, by Rose Wyler and EvaLee Baird, (Doubleday, $5.95), combines some fairly complex and thoughtprovoking riddles with interesting facts, fine Whitney Darrow Jr. illustrations, and a few disappointingly old chestnuts like the one about how far a creature can go into the forest, the answer to which is half wayif it went farther than that it would be coming out the other side, yes?

title: Katherine Kohnstamm, Teacher, Engaged To Charles luster Piven, a Law Student
description: Katherine Kohnstamm and Charis Juster Piven, who graduate with the class of 75 from Washington University in St. Louis plan to be marrid May 29. The ceremny is scheduled for Waveney House on the former Lapham estate in New Canaan, Conn.

title: NEW TAPES LINK NIXON TO WATERGATE SCHEME 3 DAYS AFTER BREAKIN
description: WASHINGTON, April 30More than a year before he resigned the Presidency in disgrace, Richard M. Nixon was so preoccupied with the Watergate matter and aware of the risk of his impeachment that he spent days on end trying to extricate himself from the scandal.

title: What's Doing in NAIROBI
description: BASE CAMPFor most of the thousands of tourists who pass through Nairobi, the city is a pleasant stopover on the way to somewhere else: the game parks in the shadow of Kilimanjaro and Mount Kenya or the Indian Ocean beaches that stretch from Mombasa. More's the pity because the Kenyan capital is a delight in itself. There are few places in the world that offer such a blend of inexpensive sybaritic pleasures and the sights and sounds of diverse cultures. You can sip on a Campari and soda and watch from a cafe as barefoot, robed Masai stride proudly by, mingling with turbaned Sikhs, welldressed Kenyan elite, Somalis, walrusmustached British colonial holdovers and, yes, cameraladen tourists in newlypurchased safari suits.

title: Youth, 18, Questioned In 44Caliber Case
description: An 18yearold youth who allegedly used a 44caliber bulldog revolver to rob a man at an intersection in midtown Manhattan was questioned. yesterday in connection with a series of murders of young women with the same kind of weapon, the police said.

title: A Confrontation Without Issues
description: Personality and perceptions rather than hard and fast county government issues are likely to be the major points of contention in the struggle for the Republican nomination for Nassau County Executive.

title: Violinist a Success
description: BEVERLY Somach, the violinist, will celebrate her 30th anniversary on the concert stage this year. From her suburban home in the Wykoff Hills, this multitalented 42yearold woman simultaneously follows careers as wife, mother, teacher and musician indeed, Miss Somach's current endeavors before consistently enthusiastic audiences appear likely to propel her rapidly into the vanguard of today's violin virtuosos.

title: U. S. Captures Doubles, Trails in Davis Cup, 21
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 30 (UPI)The doubles team of Fred McNair and Sherwood Stewart kept the United States in the American Zone Davis Cup tennis final today with a 63, 64, 63 victory over an outclassed Argentine pair. The United States trailed, 21, in the threeoffivematch series with the last two singles scheduled tomorrow.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ALBERTSONCounterpoint, a oneman photography show by Frank A. Baldi; through Wednesday; today 1 to 5 P.M.; Monday, Tuesday 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Wednesday 2 to 9 P.M.; Shelter Rock Public Library, 165 Searington Rd.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: SOME observers here laughingly call it Pike's Pique. They're referring to that heap of disdain that Representative Otis G. Pike of Suffolk County has shown for certain key portions of such major proposals before Congress this year as the new ethics code for members and the President's economicstimulus package.

title: Dennis Richey, a C.P.A., Weds Nancy Maggard
description: Nancy Ruth Maggard and Dennis Reynolds Richey, both of New York were married yesterday afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church in Goshen, N.Y., by the Rev. Douglas Glasspool. The Rev. James Leo of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., assisted.

title: Russians Find New Audience
description: FOR the last six months, the sound of strings and a mixture of Russian and broken English exclamations have filled Manhattan living rooms and synagogue halls.

title: Passing Judgment on the Judges
description: JUDGE Arthur J. Simpson Jr., the Acting Administrative Director of the Courts in New Jersey, said on this page (March 20) that there was a compelling need to raise judges salaries. There is, He also said that the present judges of our state are, on the whole, a highly qualified; hardworking group who are overburdened by the caseload in a constantly growing system. I agree.

title: Radical Approach to Literacy
description: SOMETIMES innovative education turns up in strange settings. Even so, the Consolidated Edison Company is one of the last places you might expect to find an experiment using the technique developed by Paulo Freire, the radical Brazilian educator who teaches impoverished peasants how to read and to change society.

title: The Tennis Clinic
description: So there you are, up at the net in a brisk, competitive match. And here comes the ball, zipping toward your backhand side.

title: Draths
description: ALBERTLawrence J. Age 25, dearly beloved son of Bert 8 Regina (Sills) and brother of liene and Philip suddenly, Tuesday, April 26. Services were held Friday, April 29.

title: AndoverAirport for Sale
description: WHEN Horace Lockwood is hired to appraise a tract of land in Sussex or Warren Countyin the stillrural foothills of Northwest Jerseythe first thing he does is go over to the airfield in Andover, take off in his fourpassenger Skyland and fly above the property.

title: Harvard Crew Takes Compton Regatta
description: PRINCETON, N.J., April 30Harvard's crews scored a sweep at the Compton Cup regatta here today, with Princeton's always second and those of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology third. The Crimson varsity won by almost two boat lengths, the second varsity by four, and the freshman eight by threeauarters of a length.

title: Lassa Fever Examinations Urged
description: LONDON, April 30 (AP)A man who may have caught Lassa fever while in Africa has been hospitalized and officials said yesterday that other persons on the same French airline flight should have medical examinations as soon as possible. In Paris, the Health Ministry said that 96 persons were on the flight, which made stops in Freetown, Sierra Leone, and Bamako, Mali. A spokesman said the ministry did not know the whereabouts or nationalities of the passengers.

title: Deaths
description: DEGENGeorge F., on April 29, 1777 of Garden City, N.Y., beloved husband or Mary, loving father of George, Jr., Joan M., Robert and Ricnard, dear brother of Beatrice Martinez and Do lores Young. Frinds may all at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave. at It St., Garden City, Sunday and Monday, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 P.M. Funeral Mass, St. Joseph's Churcn, Garden City Tuesday, 10 A.M. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: South Korea Is a Test of the Human Rights Issue
description: SEOUL, South KoreaA black car pulls up to a bus stop where a secretary stands, two men grab her and the vehicle speeds off. Some college students suddenly fail to attend classes. A minister sits down to lunch but when his wife arrives with the food, he is gone. Only the next day, when police officers return for the man's shoes, does she learn her husband's whereabouts.

title: CITY U. IS CRITICIZED ON ITS HOUSING POLICY
description: A New York State audit report yesterday called for a reexamination of the City University of New York's policy of providing housing for the chancellor and eight college presidents.

title: Corrections
description: In an article on seaside architecture on April 17, The Manor Inn in Larchmont was incorrectly described. The inn is a residential hotel for guests wanting accommodations for a week or longer.

title: For Land, a Cinematic Triumph
description: Dr. Edwin H, Land, founder and chairman of the Polaroid Corporation, has made a fortune and earned place in the photographic hall of fame by catering to the American desire for instant gratification.

title: Soldier in the Energy Trenches: The Homeowner
description: This winter's frigid weather has given the owners of singlefamily homes their first taste of what it could be like on the front lines of the war against excessive energy consumption.

title: Pater ex Machina
description: The one common denominator of all four of these problem stories is the inadequacy of fathers. This is a most welcome development since mothers, inadequate, vicious or just plain neurotic have been occupying center stage in realistic children's books for the past 10 years or so. In two of the books, God himself steps in to supply the empty place left by the protagonist's earthly father, and in a third, God as a father also proves a bust.

title: SungJu Lee Proves FirstRate Violinist
description: The list of firstrate young performers coming from the Far East continues to grow. Last Tuesday night, SungJu Lee, a 21yearold Korean violinist, made her debut in New York as a winner of the 1976 Young Concert Artists International Auditions, and proved to be a worthy addition to that list. A performer with the Seoul Philharmonic before she came to this country at the age of 13, she has studied with Ivan Galamian, Margaret Pardee and. Dorothy Delay. She has won competitions in this country and Finland.

title: Refugee Publishers Form a Cooperative
description: AN old twostory house next to the Pleasantville Post Office is headquarters for a group of eight refugees from the New York publishing world who have banded together to form an unusual writing publishing venture.

title: Good College Loan RisksMiddleIncome Parents
description: THE VERY RICH can afford to send their children to college. The very poor can qualify for assistance to help them pay rising college costs.

title: Nostalgia, 61, Captures Stepping Stone by 4 Lengths
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30Before a record cpeningday crowd of 26,092 at Churchill Downs, Nostalgia jumped into the Kentucky Derby picture today with a strong perforrhande in the Stepping Stone Purse.

title: Quality of Test Questions Is at Center of Debate
description: AMAJOR element In the debate over standardized tests is the issue of quality. Critics charge that they usually contain poorly conceived, ambiguous and discriminatory questions. Test makers reply that careful drafting and pretesting assure quality.

title: Questions Parents Should Be Asking
description: A5YEAROLD fidgets on a vinylcovered sofa as across the room a boy of 13 slumps in an armchair. Three mothers also wait, wearing their anxiety visibly.

title: CHESS
description: The game between Grandmasters Vladimir Liberzon of Israel and Gudmundur Sigurjonsson of Iceland from the fourth round of the Geneva International tournament did not fit the classic mold of a brilliancy prize winner, although it did get this award.

title: EXU.S. AIDE SCORES MAIN RICE EXPORTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 30A top Government food aid official, in one ofhis last actions, before resigning this month, recommended suspension of the country's largest rice exporter from doing business under the Food for Peace Program.

title: Soviet Fights Alcoholism With Beer That Is Safe for Children to Drink
description: MOSCOW, April 30 (UPI)The Soviet Union, battling to reduce alcoholism, has developed a beer so low in alcohol that it is safe for children and healthy for elderly people and athletes in training, the trade union newspaper Trud reported today.

title: Mary Carillo Has Style To Reach Top in Tennis
description: Mary Carillo's confident smile and easy manner bespeak a maturity greater than her 20 years. Her body is that of a young athletewillowy but strong, though a bit unfinished. The big smile never stops, and one suspects that the energy never stops either. Mary Carillo is one of the likely successors to the ranks of tennis stardom. A pro for only four months, Mary has won more than $12,000 playing the Avon Futures and Virginia Slims circuits during that time. And Mary is off to Europe this summer, where she will compete in the Italian and French opens and at Wimbledon. For Mary, things are just beginning.

title: Ambulance Drivers Gather at Reunion Of Volunteer Corps
description: They risked death as volunteer ambulance drivers during World Wars I and II, and those they saved will always be grateful. But most of the more than 100 American Field Service drivers who got together Friday night passed up the chance to extol themselves and their actions.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: IF the late Camden poet, Walt Whitman, really believed, as he said, that the dirtiest book of all is the expurgated book, he might be most distressedif he were still around by recent censorship developments in his home state.

title: Vanderbilt U. Makes Offer
description: NASHVILLE, April 30 (UPI)The new poet of president of Vanderbllt University has been offered to Emmett B. Fields, president of the State University of New York at Albany, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the school's board of trustness.

title: It Is Much Easier to Criticize Welfare Than to Reform It
description: WASHINGTONIf I'm elected President, Jimmy Carter used to say In his standard campaign speech, you're going to have welfare reform next year. It was a line designed to generate applause, and it nearly always did.

title: MUSIC MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: There is no question that Harold C. Schonberg's depiction of the desperate condition of American arts organizations is correct (A Bright Idea to Help Fund the Arts, April 3, 1977), and that the Richmond bill, H.R. 1042, enabling taxpayers to designate funds fol the arts would be welcome indeed.

title: Canadiens Early Surge Topples Islanders, 40
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 30The Islander bubble, which had hardly had a chance to rise in the semifinals of the National Hockey League playoffs burst tonight. Three Montreal Canadien goals in the first 8 minutes 18 seconds shot New York dead and led the defending Stanley Cup champions to a 40 victory at Nassau Coliseum.

title: INVESTING
description: An old adage in the commodity market defines an investor as nothing more than a speculator laboring under the illusion of permanency, because comodity trading has always been regarded as so fastpaced and risky that it had no investorsonly speculators.

title: INTERVIEW
description: So my friend said, Rober ta, for such a private person you certainly have been in the news a lot.'

title: A City Terrace Deserves ShowOff Shrubbery
description: Gardeners have an opportunity their country friends do not have. They live more closely to their gardens and can learn to appreciate the subtle textures, leaf shapes and forms of the trees and shrubs. For this reason, a few selected specimens of choice trees and shrubs can become conversation pieces on a rooftop.

title: Man's Best Friend Is Also the Boss
description: IN the small South Jersey town where I grew up, as I remember it, the dogs were a part of the extended family. Dogs and people wandered about freelyloving, hating or being just plain ornery in much the same fashion as the people themselves.

title: Extending Horizons For Retarded Pupils
description: IN the hours after her daughter Valerie was born, Sue Fine was told that the child was severely retarded and would require lifelong institutional care. As a result, vaiene spent most of her school life in special programs held in a variety of settings, from church basements to residentialcare facilities.

title: 44TH STREET LEADING AS CONVENTION SITE
description: After months of examining alternatives, a special committee appointed by Mayor Beame and Governor Carey is leaning toward locating the longdelayed New York City Convention Center at its original site at 44th Street and the Hudson River, acording to city and state officials.

title: College Radio's Lively Air
description: IF your radio had been turned to 88.1 FM in the last few weeks, you might have heard a critical analysis of The Blob. Or you might have heard an account of what it's like to ride Amtrak and the Starship Enterprise. You could have earned part of a college degree. If you had tuned to 88.7, you would have heard advice on what happens after you break off your engagement, or a roundtable discussion about homosexuality in the clergy.

title: Working on the Railroad
description: IT REALLY DIDN'T look like the start of something big. And it certainly didn't seem to have anything to do with Connecticut.

title: SHARING A SON WITH HARE KRISHNA
description: I didn't raise my son to be a Krishna. It isn't, as they say, work for a Jewish boy. But Paul has been in the International Society for Krishna Consciousness nearly four years now, so it's beginning to look like a steady gig.

title: Frightened Fox
description: J OYCE Stranger has published a number of books in England, and though I am not familiar with them, The Fox at Drummers Darkness is evidence enough that she can write. She has also been blessed with a rare talent for observing and describing animals. It is sad, therefore, to report that her current book is so badly organized that it is difficult to read.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: ALTHOUGH President Carter has had little to say:about the role of mass transit in conserving energy, top transit motor men in both houses of Congressboth New Jerseyansare already moving on proposed legislation.

title: Nolan Resumes Workouts
description: CINCINNATI, April 30 (AP)Gary Nolan, Cincinnati Reds pitcher, has resumed workouts after missing the first three weeks of the season with foot problems and a case of mononucleosis.

title: Check Awaits Nadia
description: There's a $10,000 check waiting here for Nadia Comaneci, Rumania's 14yearold gymnastics star of the 1976 Montreal Olympics. The people holding it want to get rid of it right away. It's gumming up the books.

title: Daniel Kilner Hunt, JoanDeidre Ziegler Plan June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Ziegler Jr. of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Deidre Ziegler, to Daniel Kilner Hunt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Torrence M. Hunt of Pittsburgh.

title: Return of the Limner
description: DURING the 17th and 18th centuries, limners were just about indispensable to life in the New England colonies. These craftsmenartists traveled the countryside painting signs for merchants and turning out boldly colored, unshaded portraits of staunch Puritans, New England sea captains and humble farmers.

title: In Business Terms, Testing Is a Success
description: TESTING is big business. Each year, more than 50 million young Americans take up to three tests and the testing industry receives $200 million or more in revenue.

title: 52 in Public Life, Including ExSenator, ExQuarterback and Author, Admit Alcoholism
description: SAN DIEGO, April 30 (AP)A year after 52 prominent Americans admitted publicly that they were alcoholics, another group of former alcoholics, including Rod Cameron, the actor, and Daniel Brewster, former Democratic Senator of Maryland, was announced today.

title: Plains, Ga., Bestirred As Soviets and Tennis Take Over for the Day
description: PLAINS, Ga., April 30Bobby Salter was standing at his usual spot behind the cash register at his souvenir store on Hudson Street, watching the traffic build on Route 280 this morning. Today would be a great day for selling, with all those people coming into town for the tennis match.

title: A Taste of China
description: In an afterdinner speech recently an illustrious ??? sand that he always wanted to he the first to get to a place or the last to leave Although his goal is not my ??? motivating force, It did influence my decision last February to depart from Bangkok oil the Dancea brandnew Greek luxury ???? whose restaurants I had designed and become the first United States restaurateur to visit mainland China on the first Western cruise stop to enter Chinese waters since the Communist revolution.

title: Carter Keeps Nixon Informed of U.S. Secrets
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (UPI)President Carter is providing former President Richard M. Nixon with secret State Department and Central Intelligence Agency data on United States relations with other nations. He said that Mr. Nixon had a perfect attitude toward him.

title: A Homespun View of the Revolution
description: IT NOW COMES our turn to flee before our Enemies. So wrote Mary Fish Noyes Silliman to her parents 200 years ago last Thursday. Her husband, Gen. Gold Selleck Silliman, and her stepson had gone to fight the British who had landed at Compo Beach, near Westport. They were marching north toward Danbury, where the American rebels had stored military supplies.

title: In Street Theater
description: THE title of The Street Theater's latest production, Inside/Outside, has a special meaning for Allen James, one of the actors. His parole from prison had been granted just two days before the opening performance late last month.

title: From Office to Dream Boat
description: CENTRE ISLAND AT LAST rides easily at anchor in Oyster Bay, protected from the spring northerlies by the mass of Centre Island, a North Shore community of multiacre estates and quiet lanes.

title: The Nixon/Frost Interviews
description: The Nixon Interviews With David Frost come to WNEW /Channel 5 this Wednesday, at 8:30 P.M., with the first of four 90minute programs culled from 24 hours of taped material. For his first formal public appearance since his resignation, the former President Is reportedly being paid $600,000, prompting some observers to complain about checkbook journalism and the precedent of making executive privilege available to the highest bidder. While Mr. Frost says that Richard M. Nixon has promised to tell all, the project thus far has been shrouded in secrecy to protect Its exclusivity value. The presentation agenda, however, has been fixed. This week the scheduled topic is Nixon and Watergate. In following weeks, Mr. Nixon will discuss his term of office, first in relation to foreign affairs, then domestic policies. And last, he will comment on events since his having left public office. A press release announces that the interviews ask the questions that remain unanswered. Confident that he can obtain some answers, Mr. Frost maintains that he is in direct control of this project.

title: Zaire Says East Germany Supplies Arms to Rebels
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 30(UPI)Zaire's Governmentcontrolled press today accused East Germany of supplying arms to rebel invaders and called for a break in diplomatic relations with the Communist nation.

title: LastMinute Publicity Drive for Nixon TV Series Helps Swell Ad Revenues and Network of Stations
description: Largely on the strength of an 11thhour publicity blitz, which includes major articles this week in Time, Newsweek and TV Guide, and a 20minute segment on CBS's 60 Minutes tonight, David Frost's series of televised interviews with former President Richard M. Nixon has gained both additional stations and advertising support in the last few days.

title: Hendrick Victor at Talladega
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., April 30 (AP)Ray Hendrick, in a Nu Style Chevrolet, won the first Talladega 300 latemodel Sportsman race toddy at the Alabama Motor Speedway. Hendrick averaged 136.283 miles per hour in winning the inaugural race for the weekly shorttrack racers at the 2.6mile track. Randy Tissott finished second in a Chevrolet and was followed by Darrell Waltrip in another Chevy.

title: One Day His Advisers Read the Data One Way, the Next Day Another
description: WASHINGTONIt has been said that if all the economists in the world were stretched end to end they still would not reach any conclusion. But the Carter Administration's economists apparently are bent on refuting that maxim. On a number of key economic issues, the Administration has reached not only one but two conclusions, and the second has often appeared to reverse the first.

title: Jean Rawson, Editor, Is Married to Allen Terhaar
description: Jean Rawson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Rawson of New York and Cohasset, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Allen Terhaar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Severin Terhaar of Pierz, Minn.

title: Bhutto Presses Political Attack as Clashes Continue
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan. April 30Roaming bands of antiGovernment demonstrators today fought running street battles with the police along stretch of Rawalpindi's main street as Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto continued to take the political offensive against the opposition Pakistan National Alliance.

title: ROUNDUP
description: With steel profits plunging, can price increase for a wide range of steel products be far behind? Many observers of the industry think not.

title: V. S. Naipaul, Novelist as Thinker
description: HIS full name is Vidiadhar Surajprasad Naipaul; he is small and dark; wary and kindly by turns; sometimes a bit huntedlooking. He looks far more Indian to me than did India's recently deposed prime minister. (The one time I saw Indira Gandhi was at a gathering of writers in New York who had been summoned to ask her friendis, ntiactianc She gravely listened as Allen Ginsberg. palms reverently pressed together, chanted mantras at her. Another writer asked her how often she had her hair done.)

title: When Citizens Sit in Judgment
description: BEING a juror was a terrible thing, recalls one of the 10 men and two women who convicted Juan Corona in 1973 on 25 separate counts of firstdegree. murder. I'm not smart and I'm not educated, and I don't know if it's right to put a person like me.

title: LETTER FROM UCONN
description: IT'S CALLED SUITCASING, and it is what almost half of University of Connecticut resident students doevery weekend from September to May. Every Friday about 3,300 students load their suitcases, duffelbags or knapsacks with laundry and textbooks and go home. They form carpools, they hitchhike, they ride buses and, from 2 to 6 P.M., they jam Route 195, the usually uncongested state road cutting through the Storrs campus.

title: ExKing of Burundi Dies
description: GENEVA, April 30 (Reuters)Former King Mwami Mwambutsa IV of Burundi, who fled his African realm in 1965, has died, a member of his household said today. The farmer King, who was 65, had been hospitalized, but returned to his apartment in a Geneva suburb and died there on Tuesday. The funeral will take place next Wednesday.

title: National Sciences Academy Cites 60 for Contributions to Research
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The National Academy of Sciences has announced the election of 60 new members. Election to the academy is recognition of a person's important contributions to scientific research.

title: Hooray For Harriet
description: LOS ANGELES. Harriet Selwyn has got fashion's number. The clothes collection she designs, called Fragments, has a base of six simple pieces. These pieces, worn frontwards, backwards, layered and over and under each other, add up to an infinite number of fashion looks. The components come in one size that ?? all, wrap and tie for easy fit, and must are made of machine washable (liana matte jersey. As a results of their practicality, wearability and fairly good prices$:16 to $75 per piecea whole cult of Fragments fans has developed across the country. That is why on May 11 in New York, Selwyn is receiving the first Lord & Taylor Creative Design Award. Five years ago, Selwyn, a transplanted New Yorker right down to her accent and aggressive style, started selling her idea of complete dressing with $50 in her pocket. Today her Fragments business volume is at a healthy $1.5 million and growing steadily. The base for a Selwyn wardrobe is the tank dress. Everything else can go over and under it. Because the tops, skirts, pants and dresses are simple and comfortable to wear, Selwyn is right in saying, These are clothes for real peoplenot just modelspeople of any age, any size. She also encourages customers to add anything you already have in your wardrobe. It makes a new and individual look that's pm. Below, some of the pieces in stores now. In New York, in addition to Lord & Taylor, Fragments is sold in Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue, Macy's and B. Altman's.

title: Stories That Test Scores Don't Tell
description: ALTHOUGH NOT the stuff of legends, standardized tests nonetheless fuel a great many stories, many of them emotionally charged tales attributing failureand sometimes successto performance on these examinations.

title: Radio
description: 89 A.M., WKTU: Mellow Child. Children's songs and stories.

title: Senate Confirms G.S.A. Head
description: WASHSINGTON, April 30 (UPI)The Senate yesterday confirmed the nomination of Jay Solomon of Tennessee to be administrator of the General Services Administration, the Govern??? building and maintenance ???

title: Pleasures for the Eye
description: JUST as you can get anything you want at Alice's Restaurant so, too, a child is unlimited in his choice in picture books. He can order a fantasy souffl, sliceoflife au jus or a fact ragout. The palate and the stomach can be pleased; the eye also, for each dish is garnished with colorful illustrations. And maybe you won't mind the tab if the child has had a nourishing meal. So let's testtaste these offerings'of the season.

title: In the Carter Administration Big Jobs for Young Lawyers
description: WASHINGTONDespite its widely publicized initial difficulties in finding toplevel women for the Cabinet, the Carter Administration is having much more success at the middlemanagement level.

title: Tapping Carter's
description: THIS was one of those weeks that mystify foreignersand perhaps Connecticutters, toowho try to fathom American parti san politics.

title: It's School Budget Time
description: THE president of the Lakeland Board of Education is a bridge, softball and tennis addict. But at this time of year, only one contest occupies the mind and time of Gerald S. Marvinthe struggle to pass the dist ricl's annual school budget.

title: Whitewash Alleged in Inquiry on New Haven F.B.I.
description: NEW HAVEN, April 30The executive director of the Civil Liberties Union in Connecticut has charged that the Justice Department has whitewashed its inquiry into allegations that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation knew of illegal wiretapping by the New Haven police.

title: EQUITY FOR DISABLED LIKELY TO BE COSTLY
description: WASHINGTON, April 30The regulations approved by the Federal Government to guide health, education and welfare programs in ending discrimination against handicapped persons show one thing, if nothing else: Discrimination is expensive for its victims to live with and for society to erase.

title: Over 100,000 Bridges Are Called Inadequate
description: DALLAS, April 30 (UPI)More than 100,000 American road bridges currently being used are inadequate, the American Society of Civil Engineers warns, It said that 6,000 others had major structural deficiencies.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: Suddenly we're as free to pick musicals as we are to pick flowers'Annie and I Love My Wife and Side by Side by Sondheim all opened during a single weekand the only thing we don't know is whether the springtime burst of song and dance is a mere accident of booking or whether it's a sign that our creative energies are set to get cracking again. Side with. His name is Lenny Baker and he looks like Marcel Marceau might look if Marceau's mother ever called him into the house and scrubbed that white stuff off his face. He even behaves like Marceau, once in a while: watch him seem to be walking slowly against the wind, for no good reason whatever, as he reluctantly unbuttons a shirt. He is more nervous than Marceau, to be sure: his idea of relaxing is to hike his shoulders into the air six times, twitchily, and then skip a beat before starting all over again, and he is able to parlay the alarm in his eyes as he takes a drag of a joint (he isn't really a today person at all) into something like three minutes of laughter without help from the librettist, those sneaky musicians, or anybody. The presence of a clown in a contemporary musical is an innovation all by itself; the occasion should be marked. Do go, and do mark it.

title: Poland Plans to Give Music Manuscripts To East Germany
description: EAST BERLIN, April 30  Music lovers may rejoice because, after yeali of delay. Polish authorities have cated that they are willing to send to East Germany a collection of priceless musical manuscripts that had disappeared in World War II, among them Beethoven's handwritten scores of his Ninth and Seventh symphonies.

title: A New Bill Seeks to Open
description: DOPTING a suggestion of the New Jersey Supreme Court, three State Senatcirs have proposed a law that could help open up suburbs and bedroom towns to all residents of the state by creating state master plan for housing.

title: Paddling Goes On as Does the Debate
description: IS CORPORAL punishment the use of the paddlethe only language some schoolchildren rstand? Few Americans would dispute that student vandalism and vialence are on the rise. The Senate Subcommittee on Juvenile Delinquency recently reported 70,000 assaults on teachers in one year, and that an estimated $600 million was spent as result of school vandalism. A National Education Association study showed a 58 percent increase in the number of school assaults between 1970 and 1974.

title: Police Could Be An Issue in 77
description: WESTCHESTER'S voters, already facing a hectic political year with the struggle by Republicans and Demo crats for corftrol of the county government may be enmeshed in another dispute with political overtoneswhat to do about countywide police services.

title: Helping Your Child Succeed in School
description: TEN YEARS AGO a parent asking a teacher, How can I help my child in school? was likely told: Don't try. We teach the new math, and your ways will only be confusing. Or, Leave the teaching of reading to us. We don't use the pnonetic approach, so please don't ask your child to sound out words at borne.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: With the exception of the United Kingdom, all of the nations attending next week's economic summit meeting in London have made reasonably complete recoveries from the 197375 recession. This is a major recent finding of our international economic indicator project. Started in 1973, the project has been devoted to measuring business cycle developments in other countries along the lines pioneered by the National Bureau of Economic Research and now used widely for the United States.

title: Late TV Listing
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 2) Lamp Unto My Feet: The Ethical Years:

title: Jong Young Lee, Cellist, Plays Worthy Recital
description: A cello recital of considerable merit was played in Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday night by Tong Young Lee, a Korean who came to the United States in 1963 to study, and who has taught at the University of Vermont. Her debut was a special award presentation of Artists International.

title: PLAY SCHOOLS ASSOCIATION TO CELEBRATE 60 YEARS
description: The Play Schools Association said Mayor Beame would be a scheduled speaker at a luncheon celebrating the 60th anniversary of the national voluntary agency. The affair will be held May 18 on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

title: Letters
description: I.Q. by Thomas Sowell and An Issue That Won't Go Away by Edward B. Fiske, March 27) have dime with their group generalizations of I.Q.'s is to evoke undeserved smugness on the part of the favored and the rancor of the insulted. The researchers averaging of I.Q.'s resembles the bigots attempts to generalize personal traits of members of groups. But I.Q. grouping is worse; it hears the label of science.

title: Geneva Group Votes To Let Soldiers Refuse Orders Violating Accords
description: GENEVA, April 30 (Reuters)Negotiators at a 150nation conference here to update the Geneva war conventions voted by a narrow margin this week to give soldiers the right to retuse orders that violate the internationally agreed rules of war.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayPenn Treaty K.C. 34th allbreed show and obedience trial, Ludwig. Corner Horse Show Grounds, Ludwig. Corner, Pa.; 1,731 dogs; 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: The heavy shoe that President Carter dropped a week ago, as he made known his farreaching proposals for dealing with the nation's energy crisis, had hardly hit the floor when Administration officials let loose the other oneenew and slightly more pessimistic assessment of economic growth prospects and expectations of sharply higher inflation for 1977.

title: George Kirby, Comedian, Arrested On Heroin Charges in Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April. 30 (UPI)George Kirby, comedianimpressionist, arrested on charges of selling heroin, waited in jail today to be turned over to the Federal authorities for arraignment Monday.

title: Buffalo Bill's Nebraska Hideout
description: It was an interesting divorce case: the man claimed that his wife of 39 years had attempted to poison him on four separate occasions; the wife countersued on grounds of adultery. The man was Col. William Frederick Buffalo Bill Cody, the woman, Louisa Lulu Cody. The alleged corespondent: England's Queen Victoria.

title: BigGame Fishermen Can Find Excellent Hunting Near the Metropolitan Area
description: Anglers in the New York metropolitan area are fortunate in having good biggame fishing within reach of the average sport fishing craft. During some seasons, the greatest of all gamefish, the giant bluefin tuna, can be found at the Mud Hole, located within sight of New York City's skyscrapers on a clear day.

title: Camp NYDA to Benefit
description: A theater party at the May 17 performance of Side by Side by Sondheim at the Music Box Theater will benefit the junior division of Camp NYDA for diabetic children in Burlingham, N. Y. Tickets for orchestra seats $65. $50. $90 and $25 can be obtained from Adele Weinstock, 215 East 68th Street.

title: STAMPS
description: The Coloradans have been persistent despite rebuffs, and so now a 13cent United States commemorative is coming out for the 100th anniversary of Colorado's admission as a state in the Union, an anniversary that actually took place last year.

title: Editors Choice
description: A FEAST OF WORDS, by Cynthia Griffin Wolff. (Oxford University Press, $15.95.) Psychologicalcritical study of Edith Wharton's life and art.

title: M.A.C. Is Upheld
description: The New York State Court of Appeals last Tuesday lifted a cloud from New York City's financial horizon when it upheld the constitutionality of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: GARDENING
description: WE can anticipate the end of frost danger in northern New Jersey, for May 12 is the average date of the last killing frost. Gardeners who feel inclined to save a little money by growing at least some of their annual flowers from seed can sow seeds of marigolds and sunflowers outdoors on the first sunny day.

title: Canadian Wind Quintet Performs With Promise
description: A wind quintet from Canada, the York Winds, made its New York debut at the 92d Sreet Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Thursday night in the series of concerts sponsored by the Center for InterAmerican Relations.

title: Writer's Death Laid to Drowning
description: The death of John F. Murray, a writer whose body was found Thursday in the Kill Van Kull off New Brighton, S. I., was attributed to asphyxia by drowning after an autopsy yesterday, according to a spokesman for the New York City Medical Examiner's office. The spokesman said that no evidence was found of any injuries inflicted by violence. The 53yearold author had been reported missing since early January.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: There is a show so rich, so beautiful, so superbly documented and so full of splendor at the Cooper. Hewitt Museum, 90th Street and Fifth Avenue (through May 23), that only in New York could be submerged in an overload of highdecibel cultural events.

title: LETTERS TO WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Sometimes you have to wonder whether Con Edison officials really believe some of the things they say. Or are they just going through the motions of defending the indefensible because it's part of the job?

title: Firepersons and Other Characters
description: NORMA KLEIN has a nice sense of what teenagers today might be feeling about themselves, each other, their bodies and minds, their friends and parents. Her novel of an orphaned young Midwestern WASP, who meets a more sophisticated Jewish girl in New York with an assortment of fatherfigures courtesy of a mixedup but nonmalevolent mother, is lowkey, credible, frank and gutsy.

title: House Tours
description: Six months after giving up a higherpaying and lessdemanding job to become New York City's top housing offial, Thomas Appleby, a quiet, detailminded man, is trying to make his presence felt as a creative administrative technician rather than an urban spokesman or social philosopher.

title: ART
description: HEMPSTEAD WHEN does a print not look like a print? Usally when it comes out of the Tyler Graphics Workshop. Some of the 105 prints currently on view at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery. which were all created and crafted at Tyler's by 15 contemporary artists, proclaim themselves as paintings or sculptures, or something in between, but their assertions as prints are less incisive. They are rare mixtures of different media, singular hybrids of the creative spirit and modern technology, produced in firm collaboration.

title: Janet Grainger Becomes Bride In Westchester
description: Janet Virginia Grainger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund C. Grainger Jr. of Rye, N.Y. was married there yesterday afternoon to Steven Thompson, on of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Thompson of Pelham Manor. N.Y.

title: Office Tests Women FacesSexual and Social
description: Finding a style that will work effectively, that doesn't come across as too masculin (hard, tough, aggressive, unfeminine) or too feminine (not tough enough, overmotional, too hesitant not enough of an initiator) is Catch1001 for women in male work groups.

title: Nursing Progress?
description: CHANGE is fraught with a great deal of anxiety and conflict, but it is essential to the progress of humanity. We were disturbed by a recent opinion expressed by Dr. Robert Glass (Feb. 13) that nursepractitioners are poorly trained personnel.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: You are stranded on a deserted island for a week with nothing to read. Sensing a captive audience, a kindly bookperson from the mainfland hires a helicopter and flies overhead, dropping off a mixed bag of books plucked from the shelves of a noted newspaper. You rip open the package, and here's what you find.

title: Ann WoxidCahusac Wed to D. R. Augenthaler
description: Ann Blythe WooddCahusac and Douglas Robert Augenthaler, Boston College graduates, were married yesterday aftembon in the chapel of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn, by the Rev. Samuel C. Walker. He was assisted by the Rev. Dennis J. Whelan.

title: The Jets Need a T.D.
description: Tony Dorsett is the celebrity rookie the New York Jets need now that Joe Namath is gone. And the HeisMan Trophy running back from Pitt hopes to be chosen by the Jets in the National Football League draft. I think the Jets, says his agent, Michael Trope, would be his personal pick. But the Jets must hold their breath through the first three selections by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the Seattle Seahawks and the Cincinnati

title: Open House by Ridgefield Artists
description: Some of Ridgefield's more than 200 artists are throwing their studio doors open and letting the public see what goes on inside. Sponsored by the Ridgefield Guild of Artists, a tour of famous artists studios will be held on Sunday, May 22, from noon to 4 P.M. Seven studio workshops are included on the tour the cost of which is $6 a person or $3 for a student. Since one of the studios features a husbandwife team, a total of eight artists will be showing their works, which range from portrait and landscape paintings, illustrations and drawings to photograhy and woodwork.

title: Olympic Group Extends Individual Sports Power
description: COLORADO SPRINGS. April 30 (UPI) The United States Olympic Committee approved a constitutional amendment today that will give individual sports autonomy through franchises to oversee each of the activities. Robert J. Kane, the new U.S.O.C. president, said each of the new franchises would have a governing body and would be responsible for the development, promotion and regulation of its own athletes for Olympic competition.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY houses in this area still have old style fullheight window screens that are taken down each fall, then replaced over the windows each spring. (It is surprising how many homeowners still prefer these over the modern combination units because the removable ones permit opening a window top and bottom for better ventilation).

title: In Search of a Novel at MacDowell
description: PETERBOROUGH, N.H. For the first time in many years, there is total silence in my life. No bombs going off outside my window; no Teletype machines; no buttstrewn linoleum floors; no editors rotating in screeching circles. For the first time in many years, I have absolutely nothing to write about except what's inside my own head.

title: Births
description: Mr. Mrs. Lawrence G. Bergman (nee Helene D. Dansker) joyfully announce the birth of Jennifer Lauren's sister Allison Rachel on April 21 1977. Proud grandparents are Mr. & Mrs. Jerome Dansker of NYC &Mr. & Mrs. Harry Slone of Roslyn, N.Y.

title: That Palace School a Long Way From The King and I
description: BANGKOK EACH MORNING before eight o'clock, scores of limousines pull through the heavilyguarded gates of Chitlada Palace, the residence of the King and Queen of Thailand. Swinging down the long drive past the broad playing fields to collection of low gray buildings, the cars stop and children, neatly dressed in white shirts and navy shorts or skirts bounce out.

title: St. Peter's College: Period of Change
description: ST. PETER'S. COLLEGE, more than a century old, is going through a difficult period of transition as it seeks to adapt to changes within Hudson County and within the Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Vietnam Leftover
description: Since 1970, when the Defense Department stopped spraying a defoliant known as Agent Orange over Vietnam, the Air Force his been trying to find a way to get rid of several million gallons of stored herbicide. Now the Air Force is ready to burn the chemical on an incinerator ship in the Pacific Ocean. Agent Orange is chemically known as 2,4,5T and was formerly used as a household and agricultural weedkiller. It is considered especially dangerous because It is contaminated with dioxin, an extremely toxic substance which has killed farm animals in accidents in Italy and the United States, and is thought to cause birth defects in humans.

(It is surprising how many homeowners still prefer these over the modern combination units because the removable ones permit opening a window top and tgittom for better ventilation).
