title: A.C.L.U. Names a Stoff Attorney As New Nationl Legal Director
description: The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday announced the appointment of a new national legal director, Bruce J. Ennis, 36 years old, who has won national recognition for establishing the rights of mental and retarded patients to receive treatment.

title: INTERVIEW
description: MEET Clint Smith. He's part cop, part sailor, part doctor, part mechanic, part fireman, part scientist.

title: Small Trains, Big Investments
description: THE diesel engine took the turn too fast and as the 15car train rounded the sharp bend, the cars fell, one by one, onto the embankment. Warren Portman didn't run for help.

title: LEADER OF DOCK UNION SEES POSSIBLE STRIKE
description: CORNING, N.Y., April 30The leader of the Atlantic and Gulf Coast longshoremen warned this week of the possibility of another dock strike unless Government agencies take steps to help protect waterfront jobs.

title: A Golden Age Upon the Stage
description: GREENVALE NINETEEN SEVENTEEN was a good yearfor C.W. Post's School of the Arts, at least. Looking for a play to serve as he focal point of this year's American Theater Festival, the school came up with Leave It to Jane, a vintage musical first produced in that year that not only offered a colorful period in the nation's cultural history to explore, but also provided a valid excuse to mount a retrospective of The Golden Age of Musical Comedy.

title: City Council Hearings For the Coming Week
description: The following public hearings will be held by City Council committees this week:

title: Questions/Answers
description: I have a problem with my rhododendrons. The black vine weev?? ?? ?sewed notches along my rhododendron leaves. What susbstitute control is there since chlordane is now a restricted pesticide? P V., Valley Stream, N.Y.

title: Is Chevy Chase Immune to Phenomenitis?
description: LOS ANGELES He is Chevy Chase, and we are not, and he is saying, All through my 20's I kept thinking, Boy, if they'd give me an hour on television to myself, what I couldn't do! All of a sudden they give me an hour to myself and I find myself thinking, Holy Smokes, what am I going to do? And here I sit at 33 with the hour I've put on tape, hoping to make a Bminus into a Bplus.

title: Chicago Seminaries Share Students, Faculty and Ecumenical Ideas
description: CHICAGOPresbyterian students from McCormick Theological Seminary are being taught the rigors of spiritual discipline by members of the nearby Jesuit School of Theology in the Hyde Park section of the city.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The Yankees conclude their series against the Seattle Mariners at 2 P.M. today in Yankee Stadium. Then the Yankees play home games against the California Angels at 8 P.M. Tuesday and Wednesday and the Oakland A's at 8 P.M. Thursday and Friday and 2 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday. The Mets are on the road all week.

title: A 17Day Glider Race Begins Tuesday
description: Even a bus will get there faster, but to that small group of sailplane pilots, strapped in so tight a pencil can't be wedged between their jump suits and harness, there is only one way to travel.

title: Tradition and Transition
description: HEWLETT BAY PARK AT the Lawrence Country Day School, the boys must wear coats and ties. The girls are excused from wearing dresses only the wintertime. There is a list of privistudents drawn up, not on the basis of grades, but on the basis of each student's efforts. These students do not have to go to supervised study hall and have other special rights. There is also a nonprivileged list, for students who aren't trying hard enough.

title: God and Death in Ireland
description: LONDONThe only legally accepted and prominently recognized leaders of a united Ireland, including both the Republic of the south (or Eire) and the British province of the north (or Ulster) are the three principal religious chiefs.

title: Drought Endangers Wild Horses On the Army's Test Range in Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITQ, April 30 (UPI)Wild horses on the Dugway Proving Grounds could die of thirst this summer unless action is taken soon to reduce their numbers, Army officials have warned.

title: DINING OUT
description: THERE'S a lot more to Hungarian cooking than paprika and goulash, hardly news to those experienced in the gourmet world but worth repeating for those who are only beginning their adventures in eating. Guided by some Hungarian friends thoroughly acquainted with the cooking ana serving of their classic dishes, we visited Chinta, perhaps the only true Hungarian restaurant in the Westchester area.

title: What Price Car Insurance?
description: IN 1973, proponents of nofault automobile insurance sponsored legislation that was intended to alleviate all problems related to automo bile insurance. Four years have passedand now these very same people and others they have enlisted are advocating additional changes in the law to again solve our automobileinsurance problems.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayRice Farms, Middle Island Arena, Rocky Point Road, Middle Island, L.I. Regular, green, junior and amateurowner working hunters; intermediate and junior jumpers, ponies, equitation. 9 A.M.

title: A Look Back at the Ills of Public Health
description: IN three years as Suffolk County Health Commissioner, Dr. Mary C. McLaughlin created a superagency that even her critics conceded provided county residents with far better health care than was available under the old Department of Health.

title: Power Struggle on Regional Health
description: ONE DAY in the not too distant future, at least as Congress envisions it, the Southwest Connecticut Health Systems Agency Norwalk will plan and coordinate every aspect of health care in lower Fairfield County, including the number of hospitals and nursing homes and perhaps even the concentration of internists and pediatricians.

title: G.O.P. Committee Opposes Carter's Proposal to Allow Voters to Register on Election Day
description: CHICAGO, April 30The Republican National Committee went on record today In amrihnously opposing President Carter's proposal that all otherwise eligible voters be allowed to register at the polls on Election Day, to increase participation in the electoral process. Without debate, the National Committee approved a resolution declaring that such legislation would discourage citizen participation in the election process, owing to the greater degree of Federal regulation, with all the attendant confusion and unreasonable burdens which inevitably accompany such regulations.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Duffy Dyer of the Pittsburgh Pirates, whose homer against the St. Louis Cardinals was the first at Busch Stadium since the markings were converted to the metric system: Maybe they should have gone to the metric system earlier. That's the first homer I've hit in this ball park in nine years.

title: Laetitia Frothingham Married
description: Laetitia Kelly FrothIngham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Frothingham of New Canaan, Conn, and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Mead Jr., son of Mr. Mead. 2d of Boston and Virginia L Mead of Wenham, Mass.

title: Road to the Derby
description: *Not nominated for Derby. 1, 2Florida Derby run in two divisions.

title: Court Sets Limits On Crash Liability Of A irline Workers
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that airlines and their employees are protected against damage claims of more than $75,000 a passenger for deaths and injuries resulting from crashes on flights into or out of the United States. The unanimous decision, which

title: FILM VIEW
description: Encouraging news: the word from Hollywood this week (see story below) is that the special effects people have never been busier whomping up the kind of fantasies that have been an essential part of cinema ever since man's first successful space trip in Georges Melies's Voyage to The Moon (1902). I wasn't around then but I was around at the age of four or five, in the early thirties, to see a film called Hell Below. It was a submarine melodrama much like others of that era but it was apparently so effective that when poor, croakervoiced Sterling Holloway was caught in a flooded compartment, which had been locked against his escape in order to save the rest of the ship, I had some trouble sorting out reality from movie illusion.

title: Rally in Hanoi Marks Date of Saigon's Fall
description: BANGKOK, Thailand. April 30 (AP)Vietnam today observed the second anniversary of the takeover of Saigon by Communistled forces, with rallies, special newspaper supplements and broadcasts lauding the country's great successes.

title: Suzanne Morris Is Bride
description: In St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, Suzanne J. Morris of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Morris of Setauket, Li, became the bride of Douglas Gibson Boller of Wilmington. Del. He is the son of Mrs. John Douglas Boller of Glasgow, Scotland, and the late Mr. Boller.

title: GIRL, 17, ACCEPTS $782,000 IN SUIT OVER MALPRACTICE
description: WHITE PLAINS, (UPI)A teenage girl rendered blind, mute and paralyzed after a gymnastic accident four years ago has accepted a $782,000 settlement in a $3 million malpractice suit.

title: Carew Gets Hit by a Pitch, Throws Punch, Is Ejected
description: A beanball war seemed to be heating up in the American League yesterday.

title: Papers in Richmond Fitted for Reporting On Inquiry of Judges
description: RICHMOND, April 30 Richmond Newspapers Inc. was convicted and given the maximum fine of $2,000 by a Rich, mond Circuit Court jury yesterday on two counts of violating a state law that makes it a crime for news media to report that judges are under investigation.

title: Liquid Assets or Public Trust?
description: THE ISSUE of watercompany lands in Connecticut is a difficult one for public policymakers, but with the stakes high, the consequence of inaction is predictable.

title: Employee Jailed in Jobless Case
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 30 (UPI)James D. McTier collected $771 in unemployment benefits from the state of Alabama before the state found out he had a jobworking for the same state agency that hands out the checks. Mr.

title: Prison for Women at Bedford Hills Ordered to Improve Medical Care
description: Improved medical service at a women's prison has been ordered by a Federal judge who ruled that prisoners were denied the necessary medical care at the state prison for women in Bedford Hills. N.Y.

title: Daniel Heifetz Shows Secure Violin Technique
description: Daniel Heifetz's career began officially when he won the Mermeather Post Competition in 1969, and in 1970 he played the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto in New York with the National Symphony, but until Tuesday night he had not Riven a New York recital.

title: Some Groundcovers Give Off Fragrance When Trod Upon
description: Gardeners often get into a rut using the same old groundcovers: ivy, myrtle and pachysandra. Low growing herbs can offer fragrant and attractive alternatives. Most varieties have colorful blooms and some serve well in the kitchen.

title: Stuffed Quartet
description: If anyone were to study our enthusiasms, they would find a welldefined fondness for stuffed vegetables. Who cares or needs to reason why? Perhaps it is just the sheer fun of stuffing them. Hence this delectable quartetstuffed Onions, sweet peppers, tomatoes and zucchini. These dishes are excellent when served as a main course. Most of them are equally good the next day.

title: ART
description: WE HAVE been led to believe that minimal art is an esthetic phenomenon in which the imagery is reduced to minimum, in which the visual incidence has been pared down to rudimentary pictorial expression. It is also a phenomenon that is supposed to offer little in the way of drama and that abjures romantic indulgences. Minimal works are said to refer, generally, to nothing but themselves. They have frequently been called nonreferential and nonallusionary.

title: After Briarcliff, Who's Next?
description: WITH Briarcliff gone, can Manhattanville and New Rochelleor even Smith, Vassar and Wellesleybe far behind? The recent demise of 75yearold Briarcliff College illustrates with particular clarity the tenuousness of the hold on life of the nation's private colleges for women.

title: 2 STATES SETTLE DISPUTE OVER LINDBERGH ESTATE
description: HARTFORD, April 30 (UPI) Hawaii and Connecticut have ended a threeyear tax battle over the estate of Charles A Lindbergh.

title: Subtracting Anxiety From Math
description: ITHOUGHT I had a terminal case of math anxiety. For as long as I could remember, I suffered from panic, embarrassment, resentment and selfloathing when faced with the simplest problem of mathematics. Quickl What is twothirds of 40? How do you rigure the to percent tip on a lunch tab of $12.35? How do you compute miles per gallon on your Volkswagen?

title: Marc Falconer's New Music Startg on Street
description: An evening of new music by Marc Falcone and Mithael Convertino in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night began with a piece for flute and one for trumpet prayed outside on 57th Street. The first piece performed wholly inside was a kind of speechsong in French recited by a young woman lying inside a piano. At the piano was a young man who mimedan accompaniment.

title: Dratlis
description: HELLERReuben on April 29, 1977. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of Marilyn Paul and Letitia Davidson. Brother of Nettle Rogers. Grandfather of Andrew, Jonathan, Elizabeth and Matthew. Friends may call at Parkside Chapel, 9860 Queens Blvd., Saturday evening from 79. Services will be held at the chapel Sunday at 10 A.M.

title: 83% IN POLL OPPOSE REVERSE BIAS PLANS
description: An overwhelming majority of Americans believe that reverse discrimination should not be used in hiring people or determining admission to college, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: F 16 FIGHTER PROGRAM IS HURT BY DELAYS
description: The multinational, multibilliondollar F16 fighter program is plagued by production delays and cost increases, according to a report drafted for Congress by the General Accounting Office.

title: Roosevelt Hopeful as Meeting Ends.
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 30Still showing a distinct loss of business because Of competition from New Jersey's Meadowlands Track; Roosevelt Raceway closed its 54program spring meeting tonight with an attendance of 20354.

title: Variety Club Honors Kissinger
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco April 30 (UPI) Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has received the International Variety Club's annual humanitarian prize. Lord Mountbatten of Britain, president of the organization, handed the award to Mr. Kissinger yesterday in a ceremony commemorating the club's 50th anniversary. The club was founded in 1927 by American show business personalities to help underprivileged children.

title: Shock Workers of Soviet Labor Follow a 5,000YearOld Tradition
description: ASHKHABAD, U.S.S.R.Red and yellow banners hailing the shock workers of Communist labor hung from the upright wooden looms. A hundred weavers sat two or three to a bench, their fingers flying across the stretched woolen strands in an effort to meet their individual quotas of 10,000 knots a day.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: Several years ago, Louis Zukofsky explained: If you want me to understand, you'd better speak in a different anguish.

title: Mary Murphy Bride Of Robert B. Koegel
description: Mary D. Murphy was married yesterday in the chapel of Manhattanville Colliege in Purchase, N.Y., to Robert B. Koegel. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by the Rev. George H. Kuhn.

title: BOOKS
description: It's not listed in the job description, but the chairman of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System is expected to play a parttime role as a martyr. How often we've seen Arthur F. Burns as a beleaguered defender of Fed independence and fiscal orthodoxy, braving the onslaughts of Congressional inquisitors.

title: Crime Control and Money
description: THE Federal Government does not require the health field to eradicate cancer as a condition for receiving Federal grants. Nor does it ask the educational system to maintain a specified level of intellectual excellence. Why then does it impose narrow guidelines, rules and plans before communities are eligible for funds to improve their criminaljustice services?

title: FISHING
description: PATCHES of fastmoving mackerel zipped northward along the New Jersey coast last week and should continue to provide good lighttackle fishing froth Atlantic City to Sandy Hook. However, there are indications that the rapid decline in mackerel stocks of recent years because of the presence of foreign fishing fleets will once again curtail the season.

title: Celtics, 76ers Face Last Clash
description: The Philadelphia 76ers oneonone show against the Boston Celtics fiveman show.

title: They Are Not Alone
description: TO its credit, our society, which otherwise pumps children full of sugar, mayhem and slack English, prints books meant to teach them about the handicapped. These cannot be easy books to write, but they are urgently necessary instruments of the civilizing process; after all, most children find it hard to fathom what is normal, never mind what is not, and they need all the help they can get.

title: U.S. Record on Disposal Of Atom Waste Assailed
description: SALZBURG, Austria, April 30An American environmentalist said today that the United States's record on atomic waste disposal was dismal.

title: May Day's Wake Saw Merger Of Reynolds and Baker, Weeks
description: The realignment on Wall Street since May Day  May 1, 1975, when fixed brokerage commission rates disappeared  has had many manifestations. One of the most visible was the acquisition by Reynolds Securities, Inc., a fullservice national securities firm, of Baker, Weeks & Co., a leading institutional research concern, which took place six months ago.

title: Leftists Gather in Beirut For a Show of Strength
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 30Lebanese and Arab leftists and Communists, with backing from the Soviet Union, have gathered here in a big show of strength.

title: Merrymaking for Mothers &Others
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE Leviathan Newsletter rolled through the door with the usual tide of mail the other morning and it brought with it the smell of the sea that clings to its pages whenever it arrives, which is several times a year. The Leviathan Newsletter is not a journal for hunters of large fish. It is about a reconstruction of one of the world's most famous and loved passenger liners that is taking place in Sea Cliff.

title: White Rhodesian Party Expels 13
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 30 (Reuters)The governing Rhodesia Front Party yesterday expelled its chairman, Harold Coleman, and 12 members of Parliament who opposed the idea of allowing Rhodesia to be governed by its black maiority. Prime Minister Ian D. Smith should now have a unified party behind him if he decided to back new proposals for a transition of power to black rule next year. The 12 rebel members of Parliament may set themselves up as a white opposition party.

title: Auto InsuranceThe Struggle Over Rising Rates
description: RANICED like targets at a firing range, a halfdozen pasteboard posters rest along the wall of Commissioner of Insurance James J. Sheeran's office: Travelers; granted a 20.7 percent increase on July 10. reauested another 29.2 percent increase; State Farm, granted a 20.7 percent increase July 1, requested a 21.4 percent increase. And there are requests from other auto insurance companiesReliance, Hartford, Aetna, Chubb.

title: Judee Mader Bride of Donald Roberts Jr.
description: Judee Mary Mader, daughter of Mr.. and Mrs. Maximilian A. Mader of New York and East Hampton, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon in New York to Donald Hargreaves Roberts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts of Summit, N.J.

title: Future Planner or Present President?
description: A fable: It was decided, in one of the United States, to build a large state hospital in a small farm town. The residents recognized that the bulldozers would cause months of disruption and that the presence of the finished hospital would alter their town permanently. Still, they decided to accept the change; of was their civic duty to do their share for the state as a whole. Good? No, said the state. You townspeople must do more than live with this hospital. You must also pay for it.

title: Camden to Get V.A. Hospital
description: THE advertisement was on the technical side, much to the point and certainly devoid of any extravagant claims or verbal window dressing. Nor was it published in Vogue, or in a fashion supplement.

title: The Doctors Who Need the Care of Other Doctors
description: One out of every twenty doctors in the United States suffers from a psychiatric disturbance severe enough to damage his or her ability to care properly for patients, the American Medical Association has estimated.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: In recent years there has been a proliferation of lens attachments designed to radically alter the normal images produced by the standard camera lens. In the forefront of this technological revolution is an innovative business executive, Fred Spira, of Spiratone, Inc.

title: Red Adair's Oil Daredevils Are Cowboys to Norwegians
description: STAVANGER, Norway, April 30The Norwegians call them the cowboys, and like the heroes of countless Western epics, they are laconic, selfreliant and individualistic.

title: Constitutional Conflict Ends in India as Acting President Accepts Order Dissolving Nine State Legislatures
description: NEW DELHI, April 30B. D. Jatti, the Acting President of India, tonight accepted the Government's recommendation that he dissolve nine state legislatures, the first step toward new elections in the states.

title: Deaths
description: KRAFTGerald. Memorial services Monday, May 2, 11:00 A.M., at Metropolitan Synagogue, 40 E 35th St., N. Y. C.

title: The Phantoms of the Ocean
description: IT was a clear evening, Ed Bellfountain of Greenport recalls, and he and Capt. James Davis were out 12 miles in Peconic Bay, trapfishing.

title: Hollywood's Secret Star Is the SpecialEffects Man
description: LOS ANGELES once upon a time, when a moviegoer walked out of a theater his head was full of images of striking personalities who had made a powerful impact on his emotions. These biggerthanlife individuals had names like Bogart and Gable, Crawford and Davis, and they were acknowledged to be stars. Today, Hollywood is entering a new era, one in which the biggest stars of all seem to be those spectacularly impersonal attractions known as Special Effects, and the images that cling to a moviegoer's mind are apt to be those of burning skyscrapers, crumbling cities, grumpy shirks, enormous bees and giant locusts.

description: The beach at the front door. ??? woodlands at the back the kind of house that people dream about on the first of May Its the weekend escape hatch of illustrator Jay ??? Crawford (left). who is also partner in the New Yorkbased fabric ??? of Quadrille, Inc He had architect ??? Gifford the ??? ??? a three part pavilion nestled on the ??? ??? Bay on Fire ???? nine year ado and it has weathered ??? Outside the sharp edges of the architecture ???? softened arid the ??? ??? has ??? to silver. Still, the house exudes the ??? and tranquillity that one yearns for on ???? The house is no longer as ??? it ??? the owner says ??? treat it with more respect.

title: LETTERS FROM WESLEYAN
description: As a senior at Wesleyan I feel compelled to comment upon the Letter From Wesleyan [Opinion Page March 26] in which a freshman woman describes the university as a kind of den of iniquity. In her eyes the dorms are riddled with sexual promiscuity and the orgy is neverending. I may not be a freshman any longer but my perception of sex on campus is a far cry from the illicit portrait that she paints.

title: COLLEGE or HARD KNOCKS
description: A city's financial crisis shows up, perhaps most visibly of all, in the essential, unglamorous operations of its public sanitation services, of its garbagemen. Because of budget cutbacks since 1975, there have been fewer men on New York's payroll to pick up the garbage and sweep the streets, fewer men to repair the aging trucks and not much money to buy new ones. The trash continues to come along, but the men, machines and morale needed to cope with it are in shorter supply. So, too, it would seem, are public sympathies for the city's sanitationmen. As an easily identified and readily accessible city employee, the sanman serves as a handy, personal target of public disgruntlement over public services and public workers in general.

title: Sacrificial Pits Unearthed
description: HONG KONG, April 30 (Reuters)Chinese scientists have disdovered hundreds of pits containing the remains of slaves killed as human sacrifices more than 3,000 years ago in Honan Province, Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, has reported. About 250 sacrificial pits were excavated, it said.

title: Oerter Wins Discus Throw
description: MOUNTAINSIDE, N.J., April 30Al Oerter of West Islip, L.I., a fourtime gold medal winner in the Olympic Games, won the discus today in an Amateur Athletic Union track and field meet at Mountainside High School. The 40yearold Oerter took first place with a heave of 205 feet 1inch.

title: In the Heart Of the Highlands
description: We wanted a quiet town in the Highlands, with some theater and concerts, near castles, lochs and forests. Why not try Pitlochry, in Perthshire? the woman at the Scottish Tourist Board in Edinburgh suggested. Half an hour later my husband, Ron, and I were crossing the Firth of Forth on the Great North Road to the Highlands.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Sunday Observer

title: Three Reed Players Improvise at Kitchell
description: Roscoe Mitchell, Joseph Jarman and Anthony Braxton, who performed music for varying combinations of saxophones, clarinets and flutes at the Kitchen Friday, were the most promising young reed players of the Chicago jazz avantgarde 10 years ago. Today they are practically elder statesmen. A school of improvisational reed playing has sprung up behind them, and this is not surprising, for they have opened jazz to an unprecedented palette of instrumental sounds while demonstrating that spontaneity and a thoughtful approach to structural organization need not be incompatible.

title: 40 of 80 Americans Who Hijacked Planes Out of U.S. Are Still Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)Of the 80 or so Americans who have hijacked planes to foreign nations, about half are abroad as fugitives from United States justice, the Statte Department has reported.

title: A Medieval Town That Time Forgot
description: Die Romantische Strasse  West Germany's Romantic Roadwinds through the Tauber Valley like, the twisted trail of Teutonic history, through gnarled country villages, farms, orchards and musky vineyards. smack In tne middie: Rotnenourg on the Tauber, the 1,000yearold fortress town that endures as an extraordinary window on medieval Europe.

title: Lit Store in Philadelphia Closes in Labor Dispute
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (UPI)The Lit Brothers Department Store in downtown Philadelphia closed yesterday at the end of the business day.

title: Federal Panel Rejects Proposal To Pay Postage on Questionnaires
description: WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP)The Commission on Federal Paperwork has declined to adopt a suggestion that Federal agencies be required to pay for the postage of businessmen and others who must answer their questionnaires.

title: Macken, an Irish Rider, Captures Prize in Italy
description: ROME, April 30 (AP)Eddie Macken of Ireland won the Il Tempo prize today in the closing event of the Rome International Horse Show and captured the award as leading rider in the weeklong competition.

title: SelfPaced Instruction, An Innovation That Stuck
description: Despite considerable fanfare and commotion, many socalled innovations in education prove to be little more than fads. Educational innovations, though often announced, as often fail to leave a permanent mark on educational practice. When two psychology professors launched their experiment in selfpaced instruction at Arizona State University back in 1965, many of their colleagues were understandably skeptical. Since then, however, selfpaced instruction has become so widespread among colleges and universities across the country, it is no longer even regarded as an innovation.

title: joyee Trisler Dancers at Church
description: Last year Joyce Trisler's Danscompany caused a minor sensation by successfully adding a cluster of 50yearold Denishawn works to its overwhehningly modern repertory. A handful of these haye Wisely been kept, and the company commissioned a new work from Donald McKayle for its current season to keep its contemporary repertory growing. The enjoyable progrant Was given Friday eyening at the Theater of Riverside Chnich.

title: Top Ratings for Radio Classes
description: THREE MILLION Kenyans turn on their radios every Sunday. to listen to a new kind of comedy, a 15minute serial that uses a massmedia format to teach about health. The show is so popular that the station wants it moved to prime time Saturday night.

title: A Rising Barometer
description: The Government provided some new evidence that the economy was moving strongly upward when the Commerce Department reported Friday that its composite index of leading economic indicators had scored its best gain in 20 months in March.

title: Best Sellers
description: NOKIICTION

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendinent to provide a permanent reduction in Federal tax rates for taxable income brackets below $20,000, rejected, 59 to 90, April 27.

title: Marguerite Tenney Is Married
description: The marriage of Marguerite Sedgwick Tenney, a fashion editor with Modern Bride magazine, to Talton Robert Embry, a vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York, took place yesterday in the chapel of St. James Episcopal Church. Horace W. B. Donegan, retired Bishop of New York, performed the ceremony. A reception followd at the Colony Club.

title: BUSTED IN MEXICO
description: Paul DiCaro and Deborah Friedman left Guadalajara on Thursday morning, Jan. 22. 1976, Three weeks of camping on the Pacific beach at Puerto Valiarta and visiting Paul's American friends at Guadalajara University in westcentral Mexico had reduced the couple's finances to their last $40. Paul and Debbre were anxious to return to their Sonoma County. Cahf.. home. DiCaro, 29. installs winery irrigation systems, and Friedman. 26, helps run their 55acre coop farm. Paul arid Debbie have been living together for three years. The two Americans spent most of Wednesday night packing their 1963 Volkswagen. Debbie carefully hid the remains of an ounce of marijuana she had bought to smoke on the beach inside two cards sealed in envelopes and addressed to their house in I lealdsburg. Calif., U.S.A. Debbie threw them in among 15 other letters in her hag and she expected to mail the whole hatch somewhere along the way. By 7:3(1 Thursday morning. Paul DiCaro

title: Stuff Shows Talent But Lacks Identity
description: Stuff is a jazzfunk sextet made up of some of the most active and talented session men in New York. The group grew around Gordon Edwards, the bass player, and has been working in this or similar configurations for years. backing artists as diverse as Joe Cocker, Aretha Franklin, Paul Simon and Van McCoy. As Stuff they've been appearing on their own for nearly two years, with one record out and another on the way.

title: Young Says Third World Nations Can No longer Have Unified Policy
description: OXFORD, Pa., May 1 (AP)Andrew Young, the United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that there can no longer be a unified foreign policy for thirdworld nations.

title: Reunited Cast Bids Last Adieu to Eaton Place
description: BOSTON, May 1For a little while, it could have been 1910 at Eaton Place all over again. There was Edward, the footman, serving Lady Marjorie a boiled egg. And there was wise, dependable Rose, speaking for Edward, saving how excited he was to be there.

title: Canada Delays Offshore Project To Study Blowout of North Sea Rig
description: OTTAWA, May 1The Canadian Government has postponed a decision on whether to permit drilling for oil in the Beaufort Sea in the Arctic pending study of factors in the North Sea blowout of an offshore well that was capped yesterday.

title: School Band Plays a Charitable Tune for 24 Long and Tiring Hours
description: MONTGOMERY TOWNSHIP, May 1 The Montgomery High School Band took a deep breath and began to play here at 8 P.M. Friday. And the band played on ... and on ... and on ... and on ...

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Badge of Madness, by James Willwerth (Lvans, $8.95). Story of psychotic police officer.

title: Waltrip Etlges Yarborough And Claims Winston 500
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., May 1 (UPI)Darrell Waltrip outdueled three other Chevrolet drivers today to claim narrow victory in the $236,885 Winston 500, a competition of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

title: Slight Gain Seen in FirstQuarter Profits
description: Corporate profits, depressed in steel, coal and other key categories, are expected to show only a slight aftertax gain at best for the first quarter, according to leading economic forecasters,

title: Littler Wins Houston Open
description: Gene Littler won the Houston open golf tournament by three strokes with a twooverpar 74 for a total of 276. Details on page 50.

title: From the Police Blotter:
description: A Brooklyn man was shot to death as he drove another man who had been wounded to the IND station at Shepherd and Pitkin Avenues in the East, New York section. The men were shot, during an apparent dispute over a girl. The dead man was identified as Edward Lopez, 26 years old, of 610 Essex Street., A suspect was being questioned. .

title: Henriette Helene Ellner Bride of Daniel Hasley
description: Henriette Helene ElIner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Ellner of Kew Garden Hills, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Daniel L. Hasley, son of Louis L. Hasley, professor emeritus of English at the University of Notre Dame, and Mrs. Hasley, known as Lucile Hasley, a retired personal essayist and lecturer, of South Bend, Incl. Prof. Hasley taught at the university for 42 years.

title: RALLY FOR SOVIET JEWS: Some of the more than 200,000 people who participated in a rally supporting civil rights for Jews in the Soviet Union carry
description: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros

title: Argentina Sinks U.S. in Davis Cup
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 1 (AP)Guillermo Vilas, Argentina's No. I tennis player, beat Dick Stockton today, enabling his country surprisingly to eliminate the United States in Davis Cup play.

title: Phoenix House Marks 10 Years With a New Home
description: In the ornate lobby of what used to be the Riverside Plaza Hotel, under chandeliers and ceilings with handcrafted designs, several young men were polishing and sweeping the hardwood floors and marble stairway.

title: Charges of Police Abuse Are Reported Increasing
description: CHESTER, Pa., May 1 (UPI)A former state investigator says that police abuse is no longer confined to large cities and ghetto areas.

title: People
description: Robert N. Harris has been named an executive vice president of Creamer/ FSR.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MAY 2, 1977

title: Bruins Subdue Flyers by 30 And Gain Final
description: BOSTON, May 1The Boston Bruins stunned themselves and the Philadelphia Flyers tonight by sweeping the Stanley Cup hockey semifinals with 3.0 victory behind the superb goaltending of Gerry Cheevers, who stopped 21 shots.

title: Drayton Simpson Married to Peter D. Jenkins
description: In the National Arts ChM in Ni York yesteruay afternoon, Lliniir Drayton Simpson, daughter of Hoke Smith Simpson, associate dean of the Columina link ersity Graduate School of Business, and Mrs. Simpson of I.archmont, N. Y., became the bride of Peter David Jenkins. lie is the son of Dr. Shirley Jenkins of New York, and the late Dr. David Ross Jenkins.

title: Harry Levine, 81, Active Zionist And a Manufacturer of Plastics
description: Harry Levine, a plastics manufacturer and a founding governor of the Weizmann Institute in Israel, died yesterday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 81 years old.

title: Olegna Fuschi Emphasizes Pianistic Drama
description: Olegna Fuschi seems to be a pianist who enjoys playing largescale works with a maximum of drama and contrast. As a result, the two major pieces in her recital yesterday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, Schumann's Davidsbundler and Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7, catered to her best instincts.

title: Kelley Says Public Pressure Prompts Agents to Break Laws
description: GADSDEN, Ala., May 1 (UPI)Public pressure to solve a crime is more likely than excessive zeal to prompt law enforcement officers to use illegal investigative methods, Clarence M. Kelley, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said yesterday.

title: Experimental Clinic Gives Legal Aid to MiddleIncome Philadelphians
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 1 (AP)  The American Bar Association has turned twostory row house in West Philadelphia into an experiment that could revolutionize the legal profession.

title: Catholic Church and Hungary Seeking Collaboration
description: ESZTERGOM, HungaryThe Hungarian Communist system and the Roman Catholic Church have reached what priests in this ancient religious center call an uneasy accommodation. Now, there are groping attempts at improving the relationship.

title: BELL AND 2 SENATORS AGREE ON A REVISION OF U.S. CRIMINAL CODE
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Senators John J. McClellan and Edward M. Kennedy and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell will announce tomorrow an agreement on a proposed new Federal criminal code that would modify or eliminate provisions that have been attacked as threats to civil liberties.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Commodities
description: No sooner had the Government asked a Federal Court in Chicago last Thursday to force members of the oilrich flint family to liquidate their allegedly excessive holdings of oldbrop soybean .futures contracts, than commodity traders started asking questions.

title: Cambodia Defector Says Army Grows But Is IllEquipped
description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand  Six months after the fall of Phnom Penh in 1975, Communist troops swept through Wat Preyrog, a Buddhist temple north of Pursat in western Cambodia. Disrobing the 30 monks, they carried them 20 miles to a military camp deep in the jungle.

title: St. Louis Fetes Al Hirschfeld, a Prodigal Son
description: ST. LOUIS, May 1St. Louis welcomed on Friday a long overdue prodigal son, Al Hirschfeld, theater caricaturist extraordinary, who last visited his native heath just over half a century ago.

title: P.L.O. Insists on Geneva Invitation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 1The head of the political department of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Farouk Kaddoumi, today set forth the conditions for Palestinian attendance at a reconvened Geneva conference on the Middle East. He also warned that if the conference was held without the Palestinians, it will become an obstacle to peace.

title: United Press International CAMPAIGNING: Shimon Peres, Defense Minister and Acting Prime Minister, shaking hands with Arabs at Umm El Fahm yesterday. Israelis go to the polls May 17 for their national elections.
Major Airlines Seek New Routes To Serve Atlantic City Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 24Major commercial airlines, which have shown little interest in Atlantic City in the past, are competing vigorously to serve the resort now that gambling casinos are due.

title: COLSON DISPUTES REPORTS ON TAPED TALKS BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)Charles W. Colson, who was special counsel to President Nixon, said today that reports that he and Mr. Nixon discussed a coverup three days after the Watergate breakin were filled with gross inaccuracies, cross distortion.

title: Hundreds Arrested in New Hampshire Atom Protest
description: SEABROOK, N.H., May 1The state police moved into a crowd of about 2,000 demonstrators against a nuclear energy plant and began arresting them this evening, charging them with trespass in their occupation of the site of the proposed plant.

title: TILLIE LEWIS, 75, FOUNDER OF COAST CANNING CONCERN
description: Tillie Lewis, who founded Floti11 Products Inc., which became a major vegetable and fruit canning concern in Stockton, Calif., died there Saturday. She was 75 years old and a director of the Ogden Corporation, a diversified concern that had acquired Tillie Lewis Foods Inc., as her company came to be known.

title: From Phil Bieber's Dream Book
description: This is the week of the Kentucky Derby. A time for dreamingPhil Bieber reminds usa time of doubts and fears, of clashing opinions, quickening optimism. Owners and trainers who think they have an outside chance winning, Phil writes, are in a constant turmoil. A good workout or a fair race encourages the dream of bringing off a surprise, coupled with the fear of being wrong. The uncertainty otfen makes for good fields and unexpected results, It isn't necessary to go hack a quartercentury for an illustration  Dust Commander, Canonero 11 and Proud Clarion brought off more recent upsetshut the 1951 Derby provides a good one. Jack Amiel, the stout and popular proprietor of the Turf Bar, was known as the softest touch for a hard luck story on Broadway. He owned a modesit stable that was trained by Sol Rutchick, who had once earned his living with a pushcart in Lower Manhattan. Sol's partnership with the Broadway restaurateur was a union made on the sidewalks of New York.

title: Chess:
description: Of the seven lastround games in the Geneva International Tournament, only one  between Grandmasters Genna Sosonko of the Netherlands and Werner Hug of Switzerlandproduced victory. The others resulted in draws that were for the most part perfunctory, taking about a dozen moves.

title: On Breaking Promises
description: WASHINGTONJimmy Carter owes his election to narrow victories in two states: Louisiana and Texas. He squeaked through in each of those states thanks to his oftenrepeated campaign pledge to remove government controls on newly discovered natural gas.

title: Carter's Science Adviser Warns Deficit May Curb Research Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 1. The expectation of a boom in Federal research funds for science and technology, following the election of the first technically trained President in a generation, may turn out to be an unfounded hope.

title: Children Meet Some
description: BOSTONAn 11footlong rock python wrapped its thick body around several children. A large, furry tarantula crawled calmly up someone's arm, and a pointyfaced ferret made straight for another child's lap.

title: WHO PAYS FOR REPAIRS TO BRIDGE IS DISPUTED
description: RUTHERFORD. May 1When a bridge joining two communities in different counties is knocked out by a barge, who pays for its repairs?

title: Manila Hopes to Resume Talks on Insurgency
description: MANILA, May 1 (AP)Foreign Secretary Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines said today that he hoped that negotiations un the Moslem rebellion in the south would be resumed, but Moslem representatives left the country today following a breakdown in the talks.

title: Penn's Revised Crew Defeats Yale, Columbia
description: DERBY, Conn., May 1Pennsylvania's varsity crew beat Yale and Columbia here today for the Blackwell Cup and thereby set up a major confrontation with unbeaten Harvard for the Adanis Cup at Cambridge Saturday. The Red and Blue boat, revised in five of its eight seats on Friday, beat the Elis by two lengths of its 60foot shell and the Light Blue by four, and had a commendable winning time of 6 minutes 12 seconds against a moderate headwind on the Housatonic River.

title: Writers Get a Bit Of Advice and See Authors Get Prizes
description: NEWARK, April 29A couple of hundred fewer rejection slips are authoritatively predicted for the 150 writersexperienced and aspiring, but mainly the latterwho took part in a conference at the New Jersey Institute of Technology here today.

title: Metropolitan Area Relatively Efficient In Its Use of Energy
description: For cooking, heating, watching television, operating washers and driers and general traveling around, the average resident in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut metropolitan region uses about onethird less energy than the average person in the country as a whole.

title: Bronx Drug Project Says It Is Cleared, But U.S Disagrees
description: The Bronx drugrehabilitation program in which state auditors last month found wideranging irregularities said yesterday that it had been given a clean bill of health by investigators from the National Institute on Drug Abuse. But Robert J. Roberton, the director of the institute's division of community assistance, which conducted the audit, disputed the assertion of the program, S.E.R.A.

title: David Belsky Weds Dr. Janet H. Kaplan
description: The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Belsky of New Rochelle. N. Y. His father is retired treasurer of the Bell Textile Company.

title: Arab Envoy Leaves Pakistan; Negotiations Remain Stalled
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May IWith Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto in conitrol of his divided nation at least temporarily, negotiations with the imprisoned leaders of the opposition Pakistan National Alliance remained stalemated today.

title: States Attack Carter Plan to Let Federal Officials Sue for Inmates
description: WASHINGTON, May 1In a constitutional controversy, the Carter Administration and attorneys general of the states strongly disagree over proposed legislation that would enable the Justice Department to initiate legal actions on behalf of inmates of state prisons, hospitals and mental institutions.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Forest Fire Rages at Plymouth
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass., May 1 (UPI)A forest fire, covering more than 200 acres and fanned by winds gusting up to 30 miles an hour, raged out of control in the Manomet section of Plymouth today. The fire crossed Route 3A, several miles from the coast, and was headed toward the ocean. About 200 firefighters from 15 communities were fighting the blaze.

title: New York Mayoral Hopefuls Polish Their Election Images
description: I'm going to be the next Mayor of this city because this city needs the best and I am the best, proclaimed Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan before a West Side Democratic audience last week. The declaration reminded some in the audience of Muhammad Ali's prefight News fencing. But it was also Analysis highly significant in the context of the Democratic mayoral primary in September and probably the general election in November.

title: Archeologists Explore Temple of LongOvershadowed Egyptian Goddess
description: CAIRO, May 1A team of archeologists from the Brooklyn Museum has begun to explore the temple precinct of Mut, queen of the gods of ancient Egypt. In their first season, they have made discoveries that add to knowledge of the second largest temple precinct of ancient Thebes, at Luxor in Upper Egypt.

title: Molina Ballet Is Dominated By Flamenco
description: Jose Molina, a highly individual Spanish dancer who has acquired an enthusiastic following in the United States, capivated a packed house again Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

title: Advice to the Press
description: HOUSTONA recent Harris poll indicated that public confidence in the press fell from 26 percent in 1975 to 20 percent in 1976. Confidence in television news declined from 35 percent to 28 percent.

title: Right to Refuse Dangerous Jobs Is Recommended by I.L.O. Group
description: GENEVA, May 1 (Reuters)A worker ishould have the right to refuse jobs that he knows from experience can be dangerous, a committee of the International Labor Organization said today.

title: Valerie A. Maloof Is Married To Richard Watson, City Aide
description: St. Anthony's Eastern Orthodox Church in Bergenfield, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Valerie A. Maloof, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Maloof of Tenafly, N.J. to Richard T. Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Watson of Wctfield, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rey. Joseph Allen.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: Curious what sticks in some people's minds. A friend reminisced recently of a trip she took to France, during which she dined at the Pyramide Restaurant in Vienne, when the owner and great chef, Fernand Point, was still alive. She recalled very well the foie gras en brioche, the gateau of chicken livers, a timbale of crawfish and so on, but what she distinctly remembered was a prune dessert made with bordeaux wine and vanilla.

title: Small Business Hit Hard By Cutback
description: Jesse and Belle Estroff of Brooklyn say their concern is theft, unimpeded, because there are no neighborhood policemen pounding the beat. Alexander Plummer in Queens says his concern is inadequate parking. Bernard Harris in the Bronx says his is the continuing cutbacks in mass transit. John Lucci on Staten Island complains about the sales tax and shoppers fleeing to New Jersey. And Cy Berget in Manhattan talks about a complete breakdown of all city services.

title: WANTED: TWO TO LIVE WHERE WHITMAN DID
description: WEST HILLS, L.I., May 1The Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission is looking for a couple with passion for lilacs and literature to live on the homestead of a great American poet.

title: Eve Binswanger Married
description: Eve Binswanger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Binswanger Jr. of Jenkintown, Pa., was married there yesterday afternoon to Leighton A. Wildrick, son of Dr. and Mrs. Laurence E. Wildrick of Moorestown, N,J. Rabbi Bertram W. Korn performed the ccre moray at the Binswanger home, The bride is an interior designer. Her father is president of the Binswanger Company, industrial and commercial real estate concern in Philadelphia. Mr. Wildrlek is the general manager of E. 0. Ashamu & Sons Holdings Ltd, in Wilmington, Del. His father is a child psychiatrist.

title: CZECH EXAIDE SAYS PRAGUE CALLED ROSENBERG AGENT
description: A former high Czechoslovak official who was allowed to come to the West last year says that Czechoslovak intelligence documents refer to Julius Rosenberg executed as a spy with his wife in 1953, as our agent, Time magazine reports today.

title: Degrees Are Givenby Yeshiva U. To Chief Justices of 3 Countries
description: The Chief Justices of the United States, Canada and Israel were awarded honorary Doctor of Law degrees by Yeshiva University yesterday at a Law Day convocation honoring the inauguration of Rabbi Norman Lamm as the university's new president. ing the cause of justice for the common man. He has served on Israel's Supreme Court since the early 1950's.

title: Washington Delay Seen as Threat To Costly SewageTreatment Plans
description: WASHINGTON, May 1A delay in Congress threatens to break the momentum in that has been built up in carrying forward sewagetreatment projects in New Jersey costing hundreds of millions of dollars, Representative Robert A. Roe, Democrat of Wayne, said today.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Abolish unemployment insurance? Dismantle the system that protects 75 million workers from the indignities of welfare? Such thoughts used to be the exclusive preserve of misanthropic couponclippers and rightwing ideologues. But no longer. A growing number of economists, none of whom are known to delight in abusing the helpless, are questioning the value of this seeminelv sacred institution.

title: High Noon for an Heiress In a Cdurtroom Shootout Over Land and Riches
description: IRVINE Calif.Joan Irvine Smith has been compared to a postbellum Scarlett O'Hara, a tough, resourceful woman who is also as wily as the foxes in the Virginia hunt country, where she keeps an extensive horse farm. ly, courtly gentlemen who had run the foundation and the company since the death in 1947 of her grandfather, James Irvine 2d. Chief among these men was Loyal McLaren, a crusty patrician who had dominated the'foundation until his retirement last year, and whose business acumen had not been challenged inside the boardroom until Mrs. Smith entered the picture and immediately became a gadfly.

title: Plane Forced to Land Near Queens Houses
description: A single engine airplane developed engine trouble shortly after taking off from Flushing Airport yesterday and made an emergency landing in a muddy cove about 30 feet from a row of houses in College Point, Queens.

title: Refugees Depict Grim Cambodia Beset by Hunger
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 1  Two years after the Communist victory, Cambodia is pictured by refugees arriving here as a desolate country, beset by crop failures and disintegrating irrigation systems.

title: League Leaders
description: By The Asscioated Press

title: Indonesian Leader Urges His Countrymen to Vote
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May I (Reuters) President Suharto appealed to Indonesians tonight to vote in tomorrow's general elections for a new parliament and pledged to uphold democracy and constitutional rule.

title: CHARLES LOCKE DIES; WROTE TEXAS NOVELS
description: Charles O. Locke, a newspaperman who wrote for the stage and later concentrated on Western novels, died yesterday in a nursing home in Burbank, Calif., where he lived. He was 81 years old.

title: U.S. QUIETLY BEGINS TALKS WITH CHINESE ON FINANCIAL CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The United States and China have begun unpublicized negotiations in Washington to settle financial claims between the two countriesa necessary step toward the establishment of normal trade relations.

title: China Outlines Conditions For Dalai Lama's Return
description: PEKING, May 1 (Reuters)China made A conciliatory move toward the exiled Dalai Lama today, indicating the former Tibetan leader would be allowed to return to his homeland if he accepted Communist rule.

title: A Southpaw Charges Post Office Is Biased
description: COVINGTON, Ky,, May 1 (AP)A postal clerk has filed a union grievance alleging that the United States Postal Service is discriminating against him because he is left handed,

title: WELFARE COMPLEXITY SURPRISE TO CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  President Carter and his Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califsino Jr., have found It much more difficult than they once imagined to develop fundamental changes in the nation's welfare system, according to Government officials who have worked with them.

title: Observers of Soviet Fishing Ships Report Friendly Visits, Good Food
description: WOODS HOLE, Mass., May 1When officials of the National Marine Fisheries Service sent eight observers to board Russian ships under the new 200mile fishing zone law three weeks ago, they had no idea what to expect.

title: Market Place
description: Last December, when citizens band radio companies were heavily discounting 23channel sets, they resurrected the famous rallying cry of Brooklyn Dodger baseball teams after being denied the pennant: Wait til next year.

title: O.E.C.D. ASKS REGULATIONS TO GOVERN OFFSHORE RIGS
description: PARIS, May 1 (Reuters)International regulations should be drawn up to govern the safety of offshore oil rigs, the 24member Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recommended in a report today.

title: Rare, Superb Sylphide By Martine van Hamel
description: Dancing is bodies or a body moving in a manner consistent with the kinetic needs of the performer and, if present, the esthetic sensibilities of an audience. (There are other definitions, but if there were not other definitions for everything, dictionaries would make dull reading and Roget would never have compiled a thesaurus.) It will be readily seen that the dimensions, style and kinetic impulses of the body in question is of crucial importance in the space/time/movement equation of dance. Which is why Martine van Hamel is such fascinating dancer. There are other ways of putting it, but at basis it must be admitted that her personal treaty with Terpsichore is an unusual one.

title: N. Y. U. President Joins a Cleanup Crew In Park to Strengthen Ties to Community
description: As the lights in the downtown apartment buildings and brownstones began snapping on in New York City about 6:45 the other morning, John Sawhill, the president of New York University, just finishing his daily twomile run around Washington Square Park, joined a group of 20 volunteers for their twiceweekly cleanup of the park.

title: Why They Cry, Why I Cry
description: Dear Friend,

title: 1,800Mile Marine Relay Race
description: SAN DIEGO, May I (AP)Six.Marine. reservists took off running today for Gila Bend, Ariz., 270 Miles away, in the first: leg of an 1,800mile relay on foot to NeW Orleans. The Fourth Marine Division is moving its headquarters from Camp Pendleton, north of here, to New OrleanS.. In a symbolic stunt, men of various units plan to relay its colors from one unit to another.

title: Disillusioned Incumbents Tell Why They're Leaving After Years of Battles on Community School Boards
description: Lee Stookey gave the community school board a oneterm try and then dropped out of the race. Marjorie Matthews has stuck with it since 1961. Lenore Engle thinks it should replace the Board of Education entirely. Hector Aponte had similar feelings until his name came up in the search for a new central board member.

title: Brendel Piano Recital Explains Genius of Beethoven Lucidly
description: Beethoven is one of the few composers whose music can easily stand up to scrutiny throughout an entire program, and Alfred Brendel is one of the uppercrust pianists whose allBeethoven recitals, year in and year out, show us why.

title: Mets Romp And Randle Sparkles
description: SAN DIEGO, May 1The spotlight remained on Lenny Randle today as he made his first start for the New York Mets and helped them complete a threegame sweep of the San Diego Padres with an 82 victory.

title: EGYPT PLANS TO SEND ITS PILOTS TO ZAIRE
description: CAIRO, May IPresident Anwar elSadat announced tonight that he would send Egyptian pilots to Zaire to operate its air force and help President Mobutu Sese Seko put down a rebellion by Katangan force in the southern part of the country.

title: Bel Canto Unit Stages Tsar By Lortzing
description: The Bel Canto Opera, nestled in the small parish auditorium of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at 31st Street, has ben successfully exploring the byways of the operatic repertory for eight years, reviving many esoteric novelties, from Korngold's Violanta to SaintSafts Henry VIII.

title: 100 Indian Smugglers Take Pledge to Obey the Law
description: NEW DELHI, May 1A hundred smugglers in India say they have quit their profession to become lawabiding citizens. They took the pledge yesterday, in the presence of Jaya Prakash Narayan, the renowned spiritual leader of the ruling Janata Party, who is in a Bombay hospital with a kidney ailment.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Police Return
description: Agreement on contract issues ended a oneday sickout by the police in Yonkers and police protection In the city was reported back to normal. Al Portanova, the president of the Yonkers Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, began calling P.B.A. members Just before 7 P.M., urging them to report for work.

title: ECONOMISTS DIVIDED ON A SUMMIT ISSUE,
description: FRANKFURT, May 1A group of United States and European economists wound up an inauspicious dress rehearsal here this weekend for President Carter's forthcoming economic summit meeting with other Western leaders in London. The economists were brought together by Claremont College in California at the invitation of the West German Bundesbank, the central bank, whose headquarters is in Frankfurt. But in two days of debate they could not agree on one of the most important questions next weekend's summit meeting must address.

title: Marine Research Vessel Boarded And Held by Cubans for 2
description: MIAMI, May 1 (UPI)A marine research vessel, the Venture, returned home over the weekend after spending two and a half days under interrogation by the Cuban authorities.

title: TV Role for Agnew Is Reported
description: ATHENS, May 1 (AP)Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, once a critic of television news, will become a special political commentator for two American television networks, a Greek newspaper reported yesterday. The newspaper, Vima, did not identify the networks. It also quoted Mr. Agnew as saying in an interview that he hopes to begin again his political career soon. Mr. Agnew, visiting Greece with his wife, could not be reached for confirmation.

title: Saturday's Fight
description: Merida, MexicoGustavo (Gutv) Espartos, Mexico, stooped Alfonso Lopez, Panama, 13 rounds, retaining the World Boxing Association flyweight title.

title: Connors Downs Ramirez
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 1 (AP)Jimmy Connors fought off a determined Raul Ramirez and gusty winds today to win the $250,000 Alan KingCaesars Palace tournament. The scores were 6.4, 57. 62.

title: Who Shall Make the Ultimate Decision?
description: The Karen Quinlan case, like Karen Quinlan, lives. It continues to pose perplexing questions in the hazy area where medicine, law, religion and public policy converge. In April, 1975, the 21yearold woman fell into a coma, from which, physicians agreed, she would never emerge. Her case engaged national sympathy when her parents sought and finally gained court permission to have a mechanical respirator turned off in the belief that this would mercifully end her life. The respirator was turned off, in April 1976; contrary to medical predictions, Miss Quinlan did not die,. but continues to survive a coma.

title: Yonkers
description: Meadowlands

title: Seattle Slew Ambles a Mile,. Just What Turner Ordered
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1You can't buy horses like this one, Seattle Slew's trainer was saying at Churchill Downs today. You can't breed em, and you can't steal em. One day you just look up, and there it is.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL BLOC IS HAPPY WITH CARTER
description: LOS ANGELES, May 1  As President Carter's first 100 days are reviewed, there is probably no segment of the electorate more pleased with his performance than the environmental community.

title: Yachting
description: AT LARCH MONT. N.Y.

title: Use of Laetrile Approved By Indiana Legislature
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 1 (AP)The Indiana Legislature has approved the use of laetrile as a treatment for cancer.

title: I.R.S. Agent WhO Used Informer To Obtain Bank Data Is Suspended
description: The Internal Revenue Service hds suspended from further work on the case the special agent who developed Project Haven, one of the most extensive investigations ever conducted by the service against tax evaders who use secret bank accounts.

title: RALLY FOR SOVIET JEWS: Some of the more than 200,000 people who participated in a rally supporting civil rights for Jews in the Soviet Union carry
description: 200,000 at Rally for Soviet Jews Hear Carter Administration Pledge

title: Goalie Switch Is Considered By Islanders
description: The Islanders need a kind of miracle now. They trail the Montreal Canadiens, three games to one, in the National Hockey League playoff semifinals, one defeat away from elimination, and they play the next contest tomorrow night in the Montreal Forum, a house of horrors for visiting teams.

title: Advertising
description: Those corporate giants whose advertising you might expect to see as national advertisers in a major, wellpublicized, newstype television show will be missing during the FrostNixon interview series, starting Wednesday.

title: EGYPT PLANS TO SEND ITS PILOTS TO ZAIRE
description: CAIRO, May 1President Anwar elSadat announced tonight that he would send Egyptian pilots to Zaire to operate its air force and help President Mobutu Sese Seko put down a rebellion by Katangan force in the southern part of the country.

title: Recital: Beroff
description: Michel Beroff chose a splendid program for his Sunday afternoon piano recital at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. He Opened with four of the exotic short pieces Liszt wrote in his final years Nuages grin, La lugubre gondola I, En reve, and TrauerVorspiel and Marsch.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Rep. Jordan Says Doctors Fail To Push Preventive Health Care
description: NEWPORT, RI., May 1 (AP)Representative Barbara Jordan, Democrat of Texas, has taken the nation's doctors to task for what she calls their failure to encourage preventive health care. Miss Jordan said that she believed doctors were lamely responsible for the absence of an effective nutrition policy in the United States.

title: Indian Leader Announces Merger Of His Group With Ruling Party
description: NEW DELHI, May 1Defense Minister Jagjivan Ram announced today that his political party, the Congress for Democracy, would formally merge with the ruling Janata Party, adding more political strength to the Government of Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai.

title: John Greenburgh, 97, Former Head Of Mining and Banking Concern
description: John G. Greenburgh, former president of Adolph Lewisohn and Son, a mining and banking concern, died Saturday at his home, 936 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan. He was 97 years old.

title: Cosmos Lose to Stars, 32, in 2d Straight Shootoue
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, NJ., May 1The Cosmos lost to the St. Louis Stars, 3.2, today in their second straight shootout,

title: Nixon Is Reported to Say He Tried To Limit Watergate Only Politically
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon insisted in a television interview with David Frost that he had not sought to cover up a crime in his response to Watergate but had merely tried to contain the situation politically, Time and Newsweek magazines reported yesterday.

title: BELL AND 2 SENATORS AGREE ON A REVISION OF U.S. CRIMINAL CODE
description: WASHINGTON, May 1Senators John J. McClellan and Edward M. Kennedy and Attorney General Griffin B. Bell will announce tomorrow an agreement on a pro posed new Federal criminal code that would modify or eliminate provisions that have been attacked as threats to civil liberties.

title: 8% Returns and a Major Scandal At the Credit Bank in Switzerland
description: CHIASSO, Switzerland, May 1Ernst Kuhrmeier, manager of the Swiss Credit Bank's important branch in this town touching the Italian frontier, had a big edge on his competitors. He was able to win customers by offering them much better return on their money.

title: Reunited Cast Bids Last Adieu to Eaton Place
description: BOSTON, May 1For a little while, it could have been 1910 at Eaton Place all over again. There was Edward, the footman, serving Lady Marjorie boiled egg. And there was wise, dependable Rose, speaking for Edward, saying how excited he was to be there.

title: Senator Calls Energy Plan Not DoAble
description: WASHINGTON, May 1 (UPI)Americans should not rush out and buy fuelefficient cars on the assumption that gas taxes are going up or that there will be rebates, two members of Congress said today.

title: Cuban Children's Replies Show Lessening Hostility Toward U.S.
description: HAVANA (UPI)If the voices of children are any indication, Cuban hostility toward the United States has lessened markedly.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALLL

title: Little Wins by 3 Shots At Houston on 74276
description: HOUSTON, May 1 (UPI)Gene Littier one of the few old pros still battling, the horde of talented young lions on the tour of the Professional Golfers Association, won a $40,000 paycheck today with a threeshot victory in the Houston open. The triumph was the 29th in his career on the tour.

title: Books of The Times
description: Going over the notes I kept while reading The Thorn Birdsand there were many pages of them because an awful lot happens in Colleen McCullough's novel about 54 years in the life of an Australian, sheepfarming family  I found that one entry wanted to check read Dane drownsP. 485. This was curious, because when I actually turned to the cited page it turned out that Dane had not actually drowned until page 487. And

title: Carter Fear of Brown Doubted
description: SAN DIEGO, May 1 (AP)Kenneth M. Curtis, Democratic National Chairman, said yesterday that there was no strategy in the White House against a possible 1980 bid for the Presidential nomination by Gov. Edmund Brown Jr. of California. Mr. Curtis, speaking to the executive committee of the Democratic State Central Committee, said that, in meetings with Mr. Carter and his aides, he had seen no indication of strained relations involving Governor Brown.

title: Reunion Hails Bronx Housing Experiment of 20's
description: With shouts, laughter, tears, kisses, powerful backslapping and rocking embraces, more than a thousand'people whose lives were shaped by an extraordinary Bronx experiment in cooperative housing in the 1920's and 1930's gathered Staurday to commemmorate the birth of the project 50 years ago.

title: DR. HANS L. BLUME
description: Dr. Hans L. Blume, a member a the staff at Lenox Hill Hospital for more than 30 years and a fellow of the American. College of Chest Surgeons, died Saturday at the hospital, where he was a patient. He was 75 years old and lived at 20 West 77th Street.

title: Concert: Philip Glass Ensemble
description: The Philip Glass Ensemble's concert yesterday afternoon in the Diplomat Hotel's Grand Ballroom, a part of Performing Artservices series of experimental performing artists there, was not an unqualified success. But the differences in effectiveness of the various pieces proved illustrative of what makes Mr. Glass's music work best.

title: Legislature Taking Action On State Budget, Fraud In Relief and Rent Agents
description: TRENTON, May 1 (AP)The proposed state budget, welfare fraud, rentallocation agents, correspondence schools and penalties for crimes by public officials are among the topics scheduled for legisIative action today.

title: Energy Plan Gives Coal Industry A Great Black Hope
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The nation's railroads, whose hauling capacities have been underused for decades, are among the most ardent supporters of President Carter's energy program, especially the proposed emphasis on coal production, It's the great black hope, said James R. Wolfe, president of the Chicago & North Western, in Congressional testimo. ny this week.

title: U.N. GROUP FORMED TO HELP NEW YORK
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 1Four United Nations diplomats who look fondly on New York as their adopted home have set themselves the goat of polishing the city's image and, it is hoped, attracting some corporate business its way.

title: Deaths
description: BARSHOFSKYAnnle, loving mother of Philip and Helen Burman, Molly and Nathan Finkel and Dorothy Barshotsky, beloved grandmother of Esther Honer, Nathan and Harriet ftershof. sky, Jeanne and Iris Finkel, devoted treatgrandmother of Sam and Sara Hones. Funeral services Monday at 10 A.M. at the I. J. Morris Inc. Funeral Hems, 1195 Flatbush Ave., (1 block north of King's Highway), Brooklyn.

title: Stylish New Elvin Jones Quartet
description: The quartet that Elvin Jones was leading at the Village Vanguard last weekend has been together only since February and, the drummer notes regretfully, it has spent a good deal of that short time not working. But, despite this, it is already a tightly unified group with an identity that stems not just from Mr. Jones's wellestablished drumming but even more from the interesting musical personalities of Chico Freeman on tenor saxophone and Ryo Kawasaki on guitar.

title: CBS Cancels a Third of Its Shows In Evening in a Shakeup for Fall
description: In a sweeping revision of its primetime schedule. CBSTV yesterday announced the cancellation of onethird of its evening programs, including Phyllis, Who's Who,and Sonny and Cher, and their replacement by 10 new weekly shows next fall.

title: Women as Priests Disputed By Church Leaders
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 1 (Reuters)The Archbishop of Canterbury and the Orthodox Ecumenical Patriarch Dimitrios engaged in a public dispute here today over the issue of women priests.

title: Issue and Debate
description: With the hot breath of competition now only as far away as Atlantic City. the debate over casino gambling for New York State has warmed considerably.

title: Israeli Military Prohibits Kahane From Visiting Towns on West Bank
description: TEL AVIV, May 1, (Reuters)The Israeli military authorities have banned Rabbi Meir Kahane from visiting occupied towns on the West Bank of the Jordan River. His presence would provoke public disturbance and he has been informed that he will not be permitted in the area, a military spokesman announced today.

title: British Rugby
description: flY Teuton

title: Fate of Many Korean Jobs Tied to Shoe Export Talk
description: SEOUL, South KoreaChon ChAe Son has not learned much about the United States during her 22 years.But she does know one thing: Americans, she says, 'have very large Feet.

title: 200 Demonstrate in New York Against Pakistan's Government
description: About 200 people protested against the Government of Prime Minister ZulfiKar Ali Bhutto in a demonstration yesterday in Times Square and on West 43d Street opposite The New York Times building, under the leadership of the Pakistan Students Association of America.

title: U.S. QUIETLY BEGINS TALKS WITH CHINESE ON FINANCIAL CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, May 1The United States and China have begun unpublicized negotiations in Washington to setle financial claims between the two countriesa necessary step toward the establishment of normal trade relations.

title: Job Action Cancels El Al Flights
description: TEL AVIV, May 1 (AP)Most of El Al's mechanics failed to show up for work today, forcing the Israeli airline to cancel 10 flights to the United States and Europe. An El Al spokesman said the airline was trying to arrange alternate transportation for stranded passengers. Several angry passengers forced their way into the airline offices to complain, while others milled around the terminal at BenGurion International airport.

title: San Francisco Sheriff In Jail for Contempt
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., May I (AP) Sheriff Richard Hongisto of San Francisco is spending his first weekend in jail on a fiveday sentence for contempt of court.

title: Rural New York State Reversing A Trend by Gaining in Population
description: Rural and other nonmetropolitan areas of New York State are registering increases in population, sometimes dramatic and reversing past declineswhile the state's population as a whole is nearing stability.

title: BOND INVESTORS HAIL RULINGS PROHIBITING MIDSTREAM CHANGES
description: For the investor from the Northeast who putshis money into taxexempt state and city bonds, the 1970's have been a trying time of defaults, moratoriums and broken covenants, And the bad news has been prevailing over the good. Recently however, the pendulum has swung. This important sector of the financial markets has brightened significantly, thanks to two court decisions that have strengthened its philosophical foundation.

title: Refugees Depict Grim Cambodia Beset by Hunger
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 1  Two years after the Communist victory, Cambodia is pictured by refugees arriving here as a desolate country, beset by crop failures and disintegrating irrigation systems.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Auto Exchange Auto Exchange Auto Exchange Auto Exchange

title: Met Singer Killed in Backstage Elevator in Cleveland
description: CLEVELAND, May 1A member of the chorus of New York's Metropolitan Opera Company was killed here last night when her flowing costume was caught in the grille of a backstage elevator.

title: 76ers Oust Celtics With 8377 Victory As Free Hits 27 Points to Lead Attack
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 1Lloyd Free was the ultimate playground player today. He was arrogant, confident, brash and at times disrespectful of John Havlicek and the Boston Celtics.

title: O Canada, O Canada
description: Premier Levesque of Quebec has taken a fateful step with the introduction of his Government's Bill No. 1. It would give the French language not merely dominance in the province but a virtual monopoly, to be employed as a weapon of economic warfare against the Englishspeaking community. That is a harsh but inescapable translation of the Government's stated purpose, that the measure will accompany, symbolize and favor a reconquest by the Frenchspeaking majority of Quebec of the control that belongs to it over the levers of the economy.

title: Rabbi Praises Carter's Position On Human Rights as Courageous
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., May 1 (AP)  A leader of Conservative Jews today praised what he called the courageous manner in which President Carter has made concern for human rights a cornerstone of his foreign policy.

title: Vietnam Official Says U.S. Follows Erroneous Policy
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 1 (AP)The head of the Vietnamese delegation that is to open talks with the United States in Paris this week said that America must in Paris this week said that Washington must give up its erroneous policy toward Vietnam before relations can be established, the Vietnam press agency reported today.

title: EXXON KEEPS 1ST PLACE IN INDUSTRIAL RANKING
description: Although the Exxon Corporation topped Fortune magazine's list of 500 industrial companies for last year, General Motors Corporation narrowed the oil company's , lead and the Ford Motor Company passed I Texaco Inc. to move into third place.

title: New York Is Completing Process Of Reconverting Its Debt Structure
description: New York City has nearly completed the twoyear process of converting $6 billion in shortterm debt into longterm obligations, and fiscal experts familiar with the projections for the next 10 years believe that the city's annual payments to retire that debt will be well within its means.

title: Exioos End Dodgers
description: Some people in the National League began wondering recently when the Los Angeles Dodgers were going to lose a game. The Dodgers, with a team batting average of 307, had won 17 of 20 games in April and opened a 7game lead in the Western Division.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DREAM TEAM Tonight and tomorrow at 8, New Yorkers have the rare opportunity to see a small but distinguished theater unit from Germany in action, with a GermanEnglish production of Franz Kafka's Dream of the Ape Redpeter. The place is the CSC Theater, the Off Broadway showcase at 136 East 13th Street.

title: Nobody Heard Lions Roar
description: The lions that nobody hears roar in Leslie Holzer's play are the domesticated, couchant stone beasts that guard the entrance to the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue.
