description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman is serfously considering running as the Republican candidate for Mayor even if he does not get the Liberal Party endorsement.

title: New Mayor Is Elected In West Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, May 2  Dietrich Stobbe, a 39yearold Social Democrat, took office today as West Berlin's mayor. He succeeded Klaus Schutz, the city's mayor for 10 years, who offered his resignation Friday after it became known that a close aide was involved in a financial scandal.

title: NEW GENESCO CHIEF AIMS TO CONSOLIDATE DIVISIONS
description: John L. Hanigan, who yesterday was elected, as expected, the new chairman, president and chief executive of Genesco Inc., said that he would act to consolidate divisions of the troubled apparel conglomerate and ensure that more decisions will be made at lower leveli.

title: Nordiques Triumph, 83, And Gain W.H.A. Final
description: QUEBEC, May 2 (UPI)The Quebec Nordiques tonight gained the final series of the World Hockey Association's playoffs by defeating the Indianapolis Racers, 83. Quebec won its semifinal series by four games to one.

title: Tax Unit Criticized
description: The New York City office of the State Tax Department costs the state millions of dollars a year by failing to audit enough taxpayers, according to a state audit. The department collects New York State's 4 percent sales and use tax and all local levies as well.

title: Masterwork or Nightmare?
description: This is a place of refuge, a sanctuary, said John Hejduk, dean of the school of architecture at Cooper Union, of the new Bronx Developmental Center designed by Richard Meier, To Mr. Hejduk, the centera long, low building sheathed in aluminum panelsis a masterwork, a place where architecture can lift up the spirit and make life a little better. To Anthony Pitto, a parent active in the parents organization of the Willowbrook State School for the retarded, the new building is an architect's nightmare of a submarine.

title: New Play by Miller Is Faulted in Washington
description: Arthur Miller's newest play, The Archbishop's Ceiling, his first since 1972, had its world premiere in Washington Saturday night and the critics who saw it there have given the work unfavorable reviews.

title: CARTER WOULD SCRAP WELFARE PROGRAMS FOR A NEW SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, May 2  President Carter declared today that the nation's present welfare system should be scrapped and a totally new system implemented.

title: Blundering on the Budget
description: The new budget procedure which enables Congress take an overall view of Federal revenues and expenditures is valuable but vulnerable. There are always conservatives who think Federal spending is too high, liberals who think it is too low, and singleinterest blocs which want certain programs fully funded regardless cost or compromise. This year's first budget resolution failed in the House of Representatives last week when a coalition of just such divergent, incoherent opinions united against the recommendations of the Budget Committee.

title: New Center for Retarded Opposed as Obsolete
description: After all the horrors of Willowbrook the wretched conditions, the human misery, the exposs, the repeated contempt motionsthere is now a new, bright, beautiful building into which Willowbrook's retarded patients can be mcved. And there is also a move afoot to keep the retarded out of itfor their own good, the critics say.

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday, May 3, 1977

title: Variety of Companies Report Their Sales and Earnings Figures
Promotions for Police Above Rank of Officer Are Weighed by Codd
description: For the first time in two years the Police Department is considering resuming promotions of officers to the ranks of sergeant and captain, Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd said yesterday.

title: Communist Changes in Laos Upset Easygoing Way of Life
description: VIENTIANE, LaosShortly after dawn, loudspeakers around this capital begin broadcasting revolutionary music and people leave for work. Most city people are employed by the Government nowadays, and in the hot season working hours are from 7 to 11 A.M. and from 2 to 5 P.M.

title: Eastern Leases And May Buy Four Airbuses
description: The European consortium that makes the Airbus A300 jumbo jet landed its first United States airline customer yesterday.

title: U.S. BISHOPS WEIGHING PROPOSED REFORMS
description: CHICAGO, May 3After months of behindthescenes maneuvering, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops moved today toward an initial major response to the hotly debated packet of reform proposals adopted by the Call to Action Conference last October in Detroit.

title: POSTAL AGENCY READY TO ASK FOR RATE RISE
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The United States Postal Service began preparing request today for a rate increase to 16 cents for a firstclass letter and a cutback to five days of mail deliveries a week, with both actions to take place early next year.

title: Private Lives
description: IF YOU WERE at the Felt Forum last Wednesday night, as I instructed you to be, you would have noticed that Mira the singing barmaid was not. There or singing. In the history of evil and disappointment in our city, this is merely a footnote. But most of us are merely footnotes, and maybe we got together there would be enough of us to crawl over the face of one of those big people who do all the laughing. I dream so.

title: Dance: Voluntaries
description: AMERICAN BALLET Theater's eightweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House is ambitious, bold and so many of those other adjectives that might be thought more germane to a political nlatfnrm than an artistic prospectus.

title: PreInaugural Memo Urged Carter To Emphasize Style Over Substance
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A preinaugural political strategy memorandum from Jimmy Carter's campaign pollster suggested that he build a new coalition of support for 1930 by emphasizing style over substance in his early days in the White House.

title: Tea by the Book, A Taxing Task
description: WASHINGTON bid you ever stop to think what life would be like if the people who wrote the Federal tax laws decided to write a cookbook?

title: Beame Propoies Exempt Status. For Supervisors in Union Pacts
description: In a move likely to provoke at least some union opposition, Mayor Beanie's office announced yesterday that it would seek to remove hundreds of supervisors from collective bargaining and take other steps to strengthen the hand of management in assigning and hiring civil servants.

title: Amin Charges Tanzania With Attempted Invasion
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 3 (UPI)Presi dent Idi Amin of Uganda said today that he had foiled a Tanzanian plot to invade Uganda and put his armed forces on alert. Tarzania denied the charge.

title: U.S. MILITARY AID IS BARRED FOR THAILAND, INDONESIA
description: WASHINGTON, May 3(AP)A Senate subcommittee voted tentatively today to bar continued military aid grants to Thailand and Indonesia.

title: Scientists Voice Fear on Uranium Output for Bombs
description: SALZBURG, Austria, May 3As though debating which of many bottles contains the most perilous genie, specialists in uranium enrichment discussed here today new ways of doing the job and argued which, if any, would make it too easy.

title: Letters
description: MSG Reactions

title: People and Business
description: F. Ross Johnson, 45, who has been president and chief executive officer of Standard Brands Inc., has been named chairman of the board of the diversified food company. He continues as chief executive officer of the company, whose directors met yesterday after the annual shareholders meeting in New York.

title: Halliburton's Net in First Quarter Jumps by 15.4%
description: The Halliburton Company, a leader in oil well services and in construction and manufacturer of industrial and electronic products, reported yesterday a 15.4 percent jump in firstquarter net income to a record $68.1 million, or $1.16 a share. Revenues, however, were unchanged at $1.2 billion from the yearearlier period.

title: Search to Fill Budget Review Post Ends Months Later Across Street
description: After a sixmonth search for a director of the new Legislative Office of Budget Review, which included screening 200 applicants from as far away as California and Florida, a joint City CouncilBoard of Estimate committee finally found its man across the street from City Hall.

title: Players Spur Efforts to End Davis Cup Schedule Conflict
description: The Association of Tennis Professionals will intensify efforts to achieve major revisions in the scheduling and format of future Davis Cup competitions, Bob Briner, the executive director, said yesterday.

title: CONFEREES REJECT INVESTMENT CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A SenateHouse conference compromised today on the bill President Carter wants for his economic stimulus, approving tax cuts for business and individuals but rejecting an increase in the 10 percent investment credit that had been originally proposed to increase capital spending.

title: New Yorkers Take Powell of U.S.C.
description: There was a wail, as if some prized jewels had fallen off a train, and then came the booing.

title: General Strike in Ulster Is Ignored by Most People.
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 3A general strike by militant Protestants aimed at closing all but emergency services in Northern Ireland got off to an uncertain start today.

title: New York Schools Planned Test In Reading Today, but Dropped It
description: The New York City Board of Education made plans to give the city's 700,000 elementary and junior high school students the citywide reading test today, but then dropped the idea around midday yesterday follwing a hearing at the State Court of Appeals.

title: New Honeywell Building To Rely on Solar Energy
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 3 (AP)Honeywell Inc. will build a solar energy system that will provide about 60 percent of the heating and cooling for the company's eightstory office building under construction adjacent to the corporate headquarters in Minneapolis.

title: CAMPAIGN SPENDING PUT AT $55 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The Senators and representatives elected last November spent more than $55 million of their own and other people's money on their political campaigns and still had more than $5 million left over to dispose of as they wished,

title: Carter Hoping to Rally U.S. Allies At Summit Conference in London
description: WASHINGTON, May 3The United States does not expect the complex economic, political and military problems facing the Western industrialized nations to be solved at the forthcoming London summit and NATO conferences, but it does hope the talks will encourage greater sense of leadership and more political impetus toward their solution, Administration sources said today.

title: Carey Adds to His Denunciation Of Members of I.R.A. as Killers
description: ALBANY, May 3Governor Carey, who last month stirred up a rhetorical storm by denouncing members of the Irish Republican Army as killers and Marxists, said today that he had no regrets about his controversial remarks and went on to add Maoism and Trotskyism to his list of the I.R.A.'s offenses.

title: A Cruise to Havana, The First in 18 Years
description: Cruise passengers from the Port of New York can soon take a sea voyage to Havana, for the first time in 18 years.

title: GERTRUDE JOHNSON WILLIAMS
description: CHICAGO, May 3 (UPI)Gertrude Johnson Williams, who provided the collateral in her son's founding of the nation's largest blackowned publishing enterprise, died Sunday. She was 85 years old.

title: PHILIP DI SPROUSE, 7D A FORMER U.S ENVOY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3Philip D. Sprouse, a retired diplomat who served in Nationalist China and later in Cambodia, died here Thursday of cancer. He was 70 years old.

title: Social Security Checks Sent to the Wrong Place
description: BOSTON, May 3 (AP)About 150,000 Americans got their monthly Social Security checks at their listed residences instead of in their bank accounts as they ordered because of a computer error, the Social Security Administration said today.

title: Summer Job List of 200 Youths With Political Ties Is Canceled
description: First Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti yesterday canceled a list of 200 names of politically connected youths seeking unadvertised summer jobs in New York City. The list had been quietly submitted to the Parks Department by another Deputy Mayor.

title: Giants Hire Feeney's Son
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3 (AP)Charles Feeney Jr., son of the National League president, Chub Feeney, was hired today as assistant to the San Francisco Giants general manager, Spec Richardson. Feeney, 27 years old, has been director of park operations for the Chicago Cubs. He will join the Giants next week.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Red Smith
description: LOUISVILLE. Ky., May 3There may be days this summer when management of the New York Mets will wish the club could draw a crowd like the one around Barn 42 this gray and spattery morning. Before the late Col. Matt Winn had sipped his first bourbon julep, Barn 42 was the place where Kentucky Derby horses lived through the first week in May. It still is, only this week it's where the Derby horse livesSeattle Slew. Others share the barn, like the Blue Grass Stakes winner, For the Moment, and Sanhedrin,

title: Ouster of a SwineFlu Scientist In Jersey Brings Call for Inquiry
description: The New Jersey Public Health Association called yesterday for an investigation into all aspects of the state's publichealth system, following a plan to reorganize the State Health Department in which an internationally respected scientist was forced out as assistant commissioner.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Arafat Meets With Saudis On P.L.O. Demands
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 3Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met in Riyadh today with King Khalid and Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia on what Palestinian sources here described as forthcoming SaudiAmerican talks on the Middle East.

title: Hooton Beats Mets by 41 For Dodgers
description: LOS ANGELES, May 3Manager Joe Frazier shook up the New York Met lineup tonight, but not as badly as Burt Hooton of the Los Angeles Dodgers shook it up when they came to bat. The 27yearold righthander, who used to torment Met teams for the Chicago Cubs, struck out 10 in the first seven innings and completed a 4I fourhitter for the 19th Dodger victory in 23 zames.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: FRANCE EVACUATES 449 FROM MAURITANIAN TOWN
description: PARIS, May 3France evacuated the dependents of French technicians yesterday from the Mauritanian iron mining center of Zouerate and said today that it would seek through diplomatic means to free the six French nationals reportedly abducted there over the weekend.

title: Books of The Times
description: WE THINK of the American 1920's in cliched images of jazz, gin, Charlestons and flappers, which, in case you've forgotten, or, like me, never anew before, took their name from the fact that the young women so called took to wearing their galoshes open. We also think of the 20's as the time when traditional institutions and values lost respect among the middleclass young, and, depending on your point of view, youth waseither free to be damned or liberated to progress into better future.

title: Date Set to Oppose Settlement in N.F.L.
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 3 (AP)A continuance has been ordered on hearings regarding the proposed settlement of the lawsuit between the National Football League and the Players Association.

title: Carter Satisfied on Flood Relief
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., May 3 (AP)President Carter's son Chip said today that his father was satisfied with efforts to aid the victims of last month's flooding in the Tug Fork Valley of southern West Virginia. Mr. Carter, 27 years old, and Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, flew here on the way to the Williamson area for an inspection of relief work.

title: Rape and the Law: A New Approach
description: LINDA FAIRSTEIN finds it easy to recall the first rape case that she handled as an assistant district attorney in Manhattan.

title: Wine Talk
description: SOME WEEKS AGO we reported on a tasting in Paris that attempted to open a new assault on the 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux. The article mentioned that Alexis Lichine had proposed an updating many years ago and that Baron Philippe de Rothschild had succeeded in having his Chateau. MoutonRothschild elevated from the first of the second growths to the status of a first growth, along with chateaux HautBrion, Marguax, Latour and Lafite.

title: To Join You Need An Italian Palate
description: FOR A WHILE at the dinner of the Accademia Italiana Della Cucina, held this month at the Ristorante II Monello Monday evening, things were a bit chancy for Samuel Bowman.

title: Youth, 18, a Jail Suicide
description: BUFFALO, May 3 (AP)An 18yearold youth hanged himself in a suburban jail early today just before his mother arrived with $50 bail money, police said. The body of the youth Michael Jurgielewicz, was found in his cell at Cheektowaga police headquarters. He had been arrested for being in a town park after closing. The police said he was drunk.

title: Notre Dame Statuary, Lost In 1793, Unearthed in Paris
description: PARIS, May 3Twentyone heads of church statues from Notre Dame Cathedral, chopped off during the French Revolution and believed lost, have been recovered here together with 350 fragments from other statuary.

title: A Day in a Bewitching Kitchen With the Siren Scent of Gumbo
description: M Y DOCTOR WANTS me to open a restaurant, Mrs. Agnes Anderson Johnson explained as she sliced hot Creole sausage in her neat and shiny New Orleans kitchen.

title: A. H. Raskin
description: The most embracing effort undertaken by American labor and industry to shift the balance of power in an international agency is nearing its showdown phase. What happens in Geneva next month will determine whether the United

title: PRESIDENT PROPOSES ETHICS LAW TO BAR CONFLICT OF INTEREST
description: WASHINGTON, May 3In a special message to Congress, President Carter called today for a new ethics law to establish farreaching safeguards against conflicts of interest and abuse of the public trust by Government officials.

title: Candidates Try Out Chemistry At a Pharmaceutical Company
description: SUMMIT, May 3New Jersey's campaign for Governor turned into a political flea market today as candidates of both parties met some of the 1,800 employees of the CibaGeigy Pharmaceutical Company during a work break.

title: Congress Approves $4 Billion to Create Public Works Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)Congress completed action today on the first of President Carter's economic stimulus programs when the House authorized a $4 billion public works jobs program.

title: Energy Legislation Coordinator
description: WASHINGTON, May 3When the 40 members of the new House Ad Hoc Committee crowded around tables in a Capitol room for their first meeting recently, their committee chairman, Representative Thomas L. Ashley. assured Man in the News the diverse collection of Representatives that he would try to work with each of them. We will have divergent views, but our purpose must and will be a common purpose, the Ohio Democrat said as he peered over his glasses at his colleagues. I will operate on the basis of inclusion rather than exclusion.

title: STANLEY MILLER DIES; EXU.S. AIDE WAS 61
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  Stanley A. Miller, for many years a Voice of America aide in Washington, died here today of pulmonary ailment. He was 61 years old.

title: Senate in New York Adopts Bill to Alter NoFault Insurance
description: ALBANY, May 3Senate Republicans, using almost visible armtwisting, mustered a bare majority today to pass bill eliminating the $500 threshold at which an automobileaccident victim may sue for medical payments under the nofault insurance program in effect in New York State for the last four years.

title: 5 Killed as R.A.F. Plane Crashes on Houses
description: HARTFORD, England, May 3 (AP)A Royal Air Force photo reconnaissance plane today crashed into a row of houses, killing its twoman crew and three children.

title: Robinson Wins Broad Jump
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, May 3 (AP)Arnie Robinson, United States gold medalist at the Montreal Olympics, won the long jump with a leap of 25 feet 71/2 inches at the Oda memorial track and field meet today. In the 5,000meter run, Garry Bjorklund of the United States was second with a time of 13 minutes 50.5 seconds, losing narrowly to Japan's Hideaki Kita, who had an identical time. Another American runner, Marty Liguori, was fourth in the 5,000meter race, finishing in 14 minutes 13.8 seconds.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: DEMOCRATS CRITICIZE CARTER ON PRIORITIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A deepening diyision, both political and philosophical between President Carter and Democratic leaders in Congress emerged today at second White House meeting on legislative priorities.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: On Friday and Saturday, he was in Madison, Wis., competing in the national intercollegiate finals. The event was won by Martin Fleischer and Alan Heubert of Teaneck, N. J., representing Swarthmore College, and Robinson and his regular partner, Art Moore of New York, placed third for Yale.

title: Oilmen Urge Second Look
description: HOUSTON, May 3A highlevel New York City promotion team, expressing strong support for Atlantic offshore oil development, impressed a meeting of oil company executives today by what the oilmen described as the city's new attitude toward their industry and toward drilling off the East Coast.

title: Turnout Lighter Than Expected In Local School Board Elections
description: As poll watchers bemoaned parent apa: thy and stacks of paper ballots went untouched, voter turnout in community school board elections yesterday was reported even lighter than had been expected, with an estimated 5 percent of all eligible voters going to the polls.

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: THE ULTIMATE main course in the world of hasty cooking is doubtlessly a slice of beef. If the meat is of first quality, it is culinary sacrilege to:cook it for an extended period. There is an interesting misconception in the public mind about a filet mignon, which is generally considered the'inost luxurious cut of the animal, it is not the most expensive steak on the market my local supermarket, for example, at today's prices, a slice of filet tallies out about $2 a servingall meat, no waste. The cost of a shell steak comes to the sum of about $3 a serving.

title: Oilmen Urge Second Look
description: HOUSTON, May 3A highlevel New Yorx City promotion team, expressing strong support for Atlantic offshore oil development, impressed a meeting of oil company executives today by what the oilmen described as the city's new attitude toward their industry and toward drilling off the East Coast,

title: Soups for All Seasons
description: In a society where a sizable segment of the public is said to prefer reconstituted orange juiceeven in a powdered stateto the freshly squeezed product, it is scarcely surprising that soups out of cans taste to some palates like ambrosia.

title: COL. CHARLES W. BLYTH, WROTE MARINE'S PRAYER
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 3 (UPI)Col. Charles William Blyth, U.S.M.C., retired, who wrote the official Marine's Prayer, died of a brain tumor in a Little Rock hospital yesterday. He was 53 years old.

title: 2 Soviet Critics Find Dissent Exhilarating
description: MOSCOW, May 3It is still a writer's living room. Heaps of books and magazines overflow from shelves onto floors. A half finished page is in the typewriter, and the surrounding desk space is strewn with sheets of freshly written copy.

title: Kodiack Wins Derby Trial in Unimpressive Time
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3Hope gives way grudgingly to logic here at this time of year, so it would be premature to guess how many of the seven 3yearolds in today's 50th running of the Derby Trial would also start in Saturday's 103d Kentucky Derby.

title: Douglaston Groups Lose Round in Fight to Halt the Building of a Tennis Spa Adjacent to Alley Pond Park
description: Community groups in the prosperous residential Douglaston area of Queens lost a crucial round yesterday in their twoyear fight to prevent construction of a building that would contain eight tennis courts and also have an adjoining parking area for 36 cars. The tract is 300 by 200 feet and is adjacent to Alley Pond Park.

title: Tax Decision Favors Bergman
description: STOCKHOLM, May 3 (UPI)A municipal tax court said today that the Swedish tilm director Ingmar Bergman need not pay retroactive taxes in Sweden on profits from his Swiss firm Personna. The court's decision was the second conseculive verdict in Mr. Bergman's favor since the police questioned him 15 months ago about alleged tax evasion. He left Sweden last year, saying he could not withstand threats and blackmail from tax authorities. He now lives in West Germany.

title: King Sounds Out N.B.A.
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 3 (AP) Bernard King, Tennessee's allAmerica basketball player, said today he had applied for undergraduate consideration in the National Basketball Association draft to he held in June. King, a junior from Brooklyn, said he hadn't decided whether to leave his name in the draft poll until June. King led the Southeastern Conference in scoring last season with a 25.8 average.

title: PUERTO RICO MOVES TO SAVE TWO BANKS
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 3Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo has asked the Puerto Rican Legislature to quickly approve the transfer of $60 million to two small local banks he says were in precarious positions, largely because of questionable loans that may be unrecoverable.

title: 2 Jersey H.U.D. Officials Charged On Deals to Circumvent Bidding
description: NEWARK, May 2 (UPI)  Two highranking officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in New Jersey have been indicted in Separate schemes to circumvent normal, bidding procedures on federally owned property.

title: TV: Pilobolus Style Is Unusual Dance
description: ALTHOUGH the content has already been substantially leakedthrough official and unofficial, paying and nonpaying sourcestonight's first installment, at 8:30 on Channel 5, of The Nixon Interviews With David Frost was not made available for prereviewing. Presumably, the remaining shreds of mystery and suspense could boost the ratings. The builtin duriosity factor, nowever, could begin to wane after about a half hour into the 90minute

title: Pop: Sally KellermanAll Icing, No Cake
description: Sally Kellerman, a film actress who is best known for her roles in MvAuS*H and Welcome to L.A., began a weeklong run as a cabaret singer at the Grand Finale on Monday evening. Her betweensongs patter was anrhantina

title: FIREBOMB DAMAGES CAR OF A UNION NEGOTIATOR
description: The car of a union negotiator in school custodians strike in Hicksville, L. I., was firebombed last night outside Hicksville High School, according to the Nassau County police.

title: Books: Adult History
description: IN The Great Republic, a textbook for adults by six of the heaviest sluggers (see names above) in academic historiography, judgments are rendered with authority and facts with certainty. The book, designed as a history of the American people, is not a flagwaving tract but surprisingly hardhitting view of why, somehow, the nation worked. There are heroes and charlatans, great and mediocre Presidents and a Civil War that almost destroyed the Republic.

title: Outlet Announces an Accord To Acquire Hughes &
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 3 (AP)The Outlet Company, a Providencebased broadcasting and retail company, announced today an agreement in principle to acquire the assets of Hughes & Hatcher Inc. of Detroit.

title: Court Refuses to Bar Soybean Corner Suit
description: CHICAGO, May 3 (Reuters)A Federal judge today refused to dismiss Federal suit charging the wealthy Hunt family of Texas with trying, in effect, to corner the soybean market.

title: MARIA T. GRONICH RUNES
description: Maria Theresa GronichRunes, editor in chief of Current Digest and cofounder with her husband, Dr. Dagobert D. Runes, of the Philosophical Library, died yesterday at Woman's Hospital. She was 71 years old. She lived at 44 West 77th Street and in Grahamsville, N.Y.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUNG LINKS JUSTICE TO ECONOMIC GROWTH
description: GUATEMALA, May 3Andrew Young asked Latin American countries today to join in forging a new relationship in the hemisphere in which economic development would be linked to social justice. He assured them that the United States wanted to contribute to the relationship and not dominate it.

title: Cancer: More Than a Disease, for Many a Silent Stigma
description: Cancer isn't just a disease. It is stigma few want to discuss, remaining a study in ignorance, irrationality and fear. People who have cancer sometimes speak of themselves as the new lepers; of being rejected, overprotected and misunderstood, all at the same time and by the very people they look to for support. And among those who want to help cancer patients, there is a sense of guilt they cannot define, a foreboding that they cannot understand.

title: 8 New Fall Series Added by NBCTV
description: IN A SCHEDULE that is to be frequently, marked by multipait movies and adaptations of novels, NBCTV next fall will introduce eight new weekly series, most of them onehour dramas involving little or no violence.

title: High Court's Ruling Doesn't Bring Rush of For Sale
description: WILLINGBORO, N.J., May 3Despite a United States Supreme Court decision ruling that an ordinance in this Burlington County township banning for sale signs in front of homes was unconstitutional, real estate people here said today that there would be no immediate move to put them on the lawns of the approximately 480 homes listed with brokers.

title: Gunsmoke
description: CAPE MAY, N.J.Now that more than two years have passed since the House Judiciary Committee voted upon the impeachment of Richard M. Nixon, the public should be getting a little closer to what really happened.

title: Ray's Lawyer Says Witness Could Prove an Alibi
description: PETROS, Tenn., May 3 (UPI)An attorney for James Earl Ray said today that there was a witness who could place Mr. Ray at a service station on the afternoon of April 4, 1968, when the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King .Jr. was assassinated in Memphis.

title: Black Press Supports King
description: Don King, the black boxing promoter, got support yesterday from some of the nation's black newspapers. The televised bouts recently billed as the United States Boxing Championships, promoted by King and ABC, are currently under investigation. Dr. Carlton B. Goodlett, president of the National Newspaper Publishers Association, Black Press of America, headed a news conference at the Hotel Pierre to support King's charges that the white press is conspiring to discredit him in the boxing world and therefore restore white promoters to the control of boxing.

title: Cancer: More Than a Disease, for Many a Silent Stigma
description: Cancer isn't just a disease. It is stigma few want to discuss, remaining a study in ignorance, irrationality and fear.

title: Report From New Orleans: Food Is the King
description: WEW ORLEANS

title: U.S. Sextet Defeats West Germany by 41
description: VIENNA, May 3 )UPI)Bob Miller of New Hampshire College scored two goals within 3 seconds today to lead the vastly improved United States team to a 41 victory over West Germany in the first United States playoff game of the world ice hockey championships.

title: Despite U.S. Order, 2 State Units Oppose East River Bridge Tolls
description: Two state agencies in charge of the environment and transportation in New York recommended in a report made public yesterday that tolls not be imposed on bridges over the East and Harlem Rivers despite a Federal court order requiring the tolls as part of a plan to comply with cleanair standards.

title: Best Buys
description: FOOD PRICES, continuing their ascent, last week reached the second highest total recorded by the Department of Consumer Affairs since that city agency began its weekly 41item compilation four years ago.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, May 3, 1977

title: Topics
description: In little more than a week, three engineers on Conrail's New Haven division were injured by stones tossed through windshields. One suffered a fractured skull. Conrail's passengers, too, are acquainted with the startling sounds of missiles striking and sometimes shattering their windows. The suspected culprits are youngsters who wait at overpasses in the Bronx, Westchester or Connecticut and heave rocks at the trains as they go by. Catching them in the act is virtually impossible; the New Haven line's railroad police force consists of ten officers, only two of whom are on patrol at any one time along the 61mile stretch from Woodlawn Station to !slew Haven, New types of highimpact, unbreakable glass are being tested for the engineers cabs and ought to be installed without delay, especially since Conrail reports that the stonings are becoming more frequent; 110 such incidents were reported in March, mostly In the suburbs. This is not mischief but madness.

title: Mondale to Emphasize to Vorster That Apartheid Must Be Ended
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Vice President Mondale will emphasize at a meeting with Prime Minister John Vorster in Vienna on May 19 the Administration's conviction that South Africa must abandon apartheid, officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the percentage gains in the CocaCola Company's sales and earnings for the first quarter were switched in the Times yesterday. Sales were up 18.9 percent, and earnings were up 11.4 percent.

title: U.S. AND HANOI OPEN FRANK
description: PARIS, May 3The United States and Vietnam opened formal negotiations here today looking toward normalizing relations, in the words of the American spokesman.

title: Record for Drunken Driver Arrests
description: WOODBRIDGE, May 3 (AP)  State police arrested 788 drunken drivers on Garden State Parkway last year, the highest number in the highway's 25year history, authorities said. Almost half of the 33 fatal accidents on the parkway last year involvedv drivers under the influence of alcohol, they said. During the first three months of 1977, the number of drunken drivers arrested on the parkway increased to 222, 41 higher than during the same period last year.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: California at New York (8 P.M.)

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Hot milk and chicory coffee is poured at Morning Call
Blazers Wait With Mixed Expectation
description: . Jack Ramsay will be in the Forum in Los Angeles tonight on a scouting mission. The Portland Trail Blazer coach will watch the deciding game of the National Basketball Association Western Conference playoff semifinal between the Lakers and Golden State Warriors with mixed emotions.

title: U.S. AND HANOI OPEN FRANK
description: PARIS, May 3The United States and Vietnam opened formal negotiations here today looking toward normalizing relations, in the words of the American spokesman.

title: CONFEREES REJECT INVESTMENT CREDIT
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A SenateHouse conference compromised today on the bill President Carter wants for his economic stimulus, approving tax cuts for business and individuals but rejecting an increase in the 10 percent investment credit that had been originally proposed to increase capital spending.

title: Suarez to Run in Spanish Election
description: MADRID, May 3 (UPI)Prime Minister Adolfo Surez announced today that he would run in the general election June 15 as a middleoftheroad independent, campaigning as the architect of Spain's democratization

title: Bruno's Health Cited
description: The lawyer for Angelo Bruno of Philadelphia told an appeals court that her client would die if returned to prison. She said the reputed underworld figure was once again experiencing intestinal bleeding.

title: Academy and Ives Fund Aid 10 Composers
description: Ten composers will be given awards or scholarships and two organizations are to receive grants, according to an announcement by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters.

title: Personal Health
description: THIS IS bad back season. Come spring and millions of Americans take to gardening, house repair, spring cleaning, tennis courts and golf courses. Not a small percentage of them will end up with aching backsall of them miserable for varying periods of time and some incapacitated for weeks or months.

title: Reputed OrganizedCrime Figure Charged With Running a $10 Million Yearly Racket
description: A reputed Mafia figure, his brother and five other men were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of conducting a major gambling operation that allegedly accepted at least $10 million annually in illegal policy wagers in Manhattan.

title: Skinny, Silly Schlump
description: CURTAINS DOWN in the theater district. The lights on Broadway shine over the heads of crowds carrying programs, and from curbside a teenager approaches young man wearing jeans and a newsboy cap and holds out a square of paper for him to autograph.

title: New Orleans Restaurants: Not All Stars Are Famous
description: NEW ORLEANS Unless they have friends who are New Orleanians, visitors to this graceful old city will have to sample native fare in restaurants, and certainly there is a bewildering array. Since time will probably be limited, it is wise to confine one's eating to those specialties that cannot be found elsewhere.

title: GEORGE E. JUDD, EXHEAD OF THE BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: George E. Judd, former manager of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, died Monday at his home in Unadilla, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: Parking Lot Bill Voted
description: The City Council's Committee on Consumer Affairs voted out a bill yesterday that would require locked gates on certain parking lots that are being used for prostitution. The bill now goes to the City Council, where it is expected to be approved.

title: Freed to Attack Again
description: The following are some of the cases handled by the Sex Crimes Prosecution Unit of the Manhattan District Attorney's office:

title: Court's Ruling Poses a Problem For Communities in Three States
description: About a year ago, Hartford adopted an ordinance forbidding the posting of for sale signs in front of homes.

title: Business/Finance
description: Chrysler directors approved a 10cent increase in the quarterly dividend to be paid in June from the pattern of 15 cents a share started last summer. At the stockholders meeting preceding the directors session, an exceptionally high 20 percent supported stockholders proposals, opposed by management, to tighten formulas for incentive or bonus pay to top executives and elated matters. [D1:12.]

title: Checker Is Off as Trading Reopens
description: DETROIT, May 3  Shares of the Checker Motors Corporation, the Kalamazoo, Mich., company which Edward N. Cole bought an interest in two months ago, reopened for trading today, and fell $2.50 a share on the Midwest Stock Exchange to close at $19.75 on a lot of 100 shares. Trading had been halted'following Mr. Cole's death in a plane crash Monday.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: There's punk and then there's nebbish punk and for reasons certainly unknown to me, it is the latest look in jewelry. Punk apparently first saw the light of day with rock musicians in London and it consisted of messy clothes, decorated with safety pins and razor blades. Now commercially made punk is available and one the first items around is a belt of safety pins, fastened with a coppercolored buckle studded with nuts, bolts, paper clips and other items you've always wanted to walk around with. Nebbish punk, according to a local Wit,

title: Bridge:
description: Veteran tournament performers cannot fail to marvel at the energy and enthusiasm displayed by the latest crop of experts who are making their mark on the New York scene. Consider for example the case of Eric Robinson, 20yearold student at Yale University.

title: Market Place
description: The Tobin Packing Company, Rochester meatpacker whose listing on the New York Stock Exchange has been imperiled by continuing losses_and depressed market value, Apparently has A new tease on life. .

title: Long, Tortuous Route in Congress Expected for Energy Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, May 3When James R. Schlesinger, the President's assistant for energy, appeared before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee this morning, the event signaled the opening of the next phase of the development of a national energy policy.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, MAY 3. 1977

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 4, 1977 The United States and Vietnam opened talks in Paris. two years after the Communist takeover of .Saigon, aimed at normalizing relations. The American delegation called the first session frank, friendly and useful. There was speculation that an agreement in principle might be reached, with a long list of issues to be dealt with later by pccial commissions. (Page A1, Col. 2.1 The coming London summit meeting and North Atlantic Treaty Organization conference are not expected to solve the complex economic, political and military problems of the Western industrialized nations, according to White House sources. The Administration does hope to encourage a greater sense of leadership and more political impetus toward their solution. [A14:12.]

title: Absent Friends Delays Opening
description: Asserting that there is now no theater available, because of the current hooking jam, the producer Claire Nichtern has decided to delay the Broadway opening of Alan Ayckbourn's Absent Friends until late summer or early next fall,

title: A.M.C. Ads Stressing Energy Conservation
description: In advertising in some 525 newspapers and on radio stations in 68 markets, American Motors today will try to hook its small cars into President Carter's energy proposals.

title: Carey Seeks to Revamp State Athletic Board
description: ALBANY, May 3 (AP)Governor Carey said today he wanted to reorganize the State Athletic Commission, but he declined comment on whether he would remove the commission's chairman, James A. Farley Jr. Farley has suspended himself without pay pending investigation of allegations that he had improperly assisted a boxing promotion croup.

title: NET EARNINGS DOWN AT BOTH EXCHANGES
description: The New York*Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchanged the nation's two largest securities exchanges, yester1 qua dpyrter. reported lower earnings for the first

title: Islanders Stave Off Elimination On 43 Overtime Victory at Forum
description: MONTREAL, May 3After matching the Montreal Canadiens goal for goal in the first three periods tonight, the New York Islanders won in overtime, 43, on Billy Harris's goal at 3 minutes 58 seconds.

title: Handshake Agreement
description: SAN DIEGO, May 3What had been reported here to be a handshake agreement ending the American tuna fleet's deadlocked dispute with environmentalists collapsed today, halting a flurry of preparations for the immobilized vessels immediate return to sea.

title: Two West Bank Arabs Killed in Clashes With Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, May 3Two Arabs were killed today in two clashes involving Israeli occupation forces and Arab protesters near the West Bank town of Jenin, a military spokesman said. One was 15yearold boy and the other a 55yearold woman.

title: Seymour L. Cromwell, Oarsman, Won Silver Medal at 64 Olympics
description: Seymour L. Cromwell, a champion oarsman who helped the United States win a silver medal in the 1964 Olympics at Tokyo, died of cancer Monday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 43 years old and a resident of Bridgehampton, L.L

title: The Welfare Promise, Local and National
description: There's a message for New York City in the President's policy statement on welfare reform. It's not drop dead exactly. It's more like, I know you folks are bleeding, but you'll just have to wait. For at least four more years.

title: Study Group Says Coops Need Government Support
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)Coopers lives could save consumers a lot of money, but without Government help they are not likely to expand to a useful scale, according to a study released to day.

title: Senators Give Skeptical Reception To Schlesinger Energy Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  James R. Schlesinger made his first appearance before Congress today as the chief designer of President Carter's energy program and ran into skepticism and resistance from Republicans and Democrats.

title: Film: Dizzying Style
description: Trollstenen (Swedish for trolls rock), which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Gunvor Nelson's 125minute meditation upon ner relationship to the members of her family in Sweden and the land where she grew up.

title: Florence Dunlap, an Actress, 94; Appeared in Many Noted Plays
description: Florence Dunlap, who had a long career as a stage actress, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She lived at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue. and was 94 years old.

title: Itinerary of Journeys By Carter and Vance
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP)Following is the schedule for the overseas trips by President Carter and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance beginning on Thursday:

title: Giants and lets Select Tackles as Top Choices
description: Coach John McVay and the Giant braintrust didn't get Tony Dorsett yesterday. They were very happy, though, gaining two almostcertain starters from the National Football League draft.

title: S.E.C. Plan Draws N.Y.S.E. Opposition
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday voiced opposition to a Securities and Exchange Commission proposal that would permit the agency to obtain more data about foreign accounts with United States brokerage firms.

title: PRESIDENT PROPOSES ETHICS LAW TO BAR CONFLICT OF INTEREST
description: WASHINGTON, May 3In a special message to Congress, President Carter called today for a new ethics law to establish farreaching safeguards against conflicts of interest and abuse of the public trust by Government officials.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: John Corry

title: Accused in 1941, Cleared in 1977
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 3 (AP)For 36 years Margaret Wunderle begged generals, admirals and Presidents to clear her of charges that she had been a Nazi collaborator.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: WITH MOTHER'S DAY just ahead and Father's Day right over the horizon, seems appropriate to turn some light on the current state of children, parents and grandchildren.

title: Perspectives of U.S: Foreign Policy Sharply Altered Since Saigon's Fall
description: WASHINGTON, May 3You know, a ranking foreign policy official observed, no one talks about Vietnam any more.

title: House G. O. P. Fails In Move to Weaken Carter Voting Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 3  President Carter's program for registration of voters on Election Day on a national basis won its first tests in Congress today as Republican attempts to weaken and delay the plan were defeated in the House Ad ministration Committee

title: Beame's Plan for School System Gets Carey's Qualified Support
description: Governor Carey gave qualified support yesterday to Mayor Beame's plan to supplant the Board of Education with a commissioner appointed by the Mayor.

title: $10.6 Million Suit Against Nixon By Two Radicals Thrown Out
description: SAN DIEGO, May 3 (AP)A Federal judge has dismissed a $10.6 million damage suit accusing former President Richard M. Nixon and others of violating the civil rights of two selfproclaimed radical activists.

title: View of State Income Tax
description: A public opinion poll reported that the program for state property tax rebates had failed to change the opinion of a majority of its respondents that the state income tax should be ended.

title: Carter Sees No Evidence Of Soviet Laser Beam
description: HONOLULU, May 3 (UPI)President Carter, speaking by telephone to a group of newspaper editors, said today that the soviet Union was many years away from developing a weapon that could neutralize United States missiles.

title: Pavarotti to Give Recital at Met
description: Luciano Pavarotti is a tenor with such a large following that when he gives his recital next Feb. 12, under the auspices of Lincoln Center, he will sing in the Metropolitan Opera House. It will be something of a precedent, because in the classical field only Vladimir Horowitz has given a recital in the 1 I venrold structure.

title: About Real Estate
description: When the postwar midtown office buildings, of Manhattan were new five and more years ago, their major ground floor commercial tenants were rarely retailers. Often there would be a bank branch, or a showroom for a company with office space upstairs. An institutional use, in the jargon of the realestate trade.

title: Argentina Closes a Bank Charged With Handling Funds of Guerrillas
description: LA PLATA, Argentina, May 3 (Reuters) The Argentine central bank today closed down the main bank of a financial group here charged with handling millions of dollars of guerrilla funds gained from kidnappings and robberies.

title: House Panel Cuts Zaire Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)The House International Relations Committee defeated a move today to delete all $30 million worth of military aid that had been requested for Zaire, but it did reduce that country's share of the 108 arms export bill to $15 million.

title: SIGN RULING PRESENTS PROBLEM IN SUBURBS
description: About a year ago. Hartford adopted an ordinance forbidding the posting of for sale signs in front of homes.

title: F.D.A. Orders Sun Lamp Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (UPI)  The Food and Drug Administration announced today the recall of 14,000 General Electric sunlamps with allegedly defective timers that would cause serious burns to users. The agency said that 5,000 of the TimeATan Suntanner kits had already been recovered from G.E.'s distribution system but that 9,000 more were still in retail channels or had been sold to consumers.

title: New York State fo Start A New Weekly Lottery; Top Prize Is $1 Million
description: New Yorkers will have a chance to gamble on two state lotteries beginning next Tuesday. A new $1 weekly lottery will be offered on that day with prizes ranging from $20 to $1 million.

title: Hearings on DeMarco Nearing Conclusion
description: Dr. Peter T. DeMarco was characterized yesterday as both a dedicated and attentive physician and an incompetent doctor who lacked good moral character at the conclusion of nine weeks of state hearings to determine his New Jersey medical license should be suspended,

title: Presidents
description: It had to happen sooner or later. Lillian Carter is the first Presidential mother in American history to have produced her famous son in a hospital. Well, a small clinic really, right in Plains, Ga., and yet, Sunday being Mother's Day and the time to reflect on such things, an era does seem to have ended. All the way from George Washington to Gerald Ford, every other executive was born at home.

title: Formula 2 Race Canceled
description: PARIS, May 3 (UPI)The International Sports Commission canceled today the European Formula 2 Rheinpokal auto race scheduled for June at Hockenheim, West Germany spokesman said local regulations restricted the circuit to six races a season and the Rheinpokal had been scheduled too late for inclusion.

title: West Point Cites Black Graduate Of 1877, Its First
description: WEST POINT, May 3.The United States Military Academy paused today to honor Henry Ossian Flipper, who persevered here as a virtual outcast to become West Point's first black graduate 100 years ago.

title: Cowboys Draft Dorsett After Trading Four Picks to Seahawks
description: Exercising the theme of their No. 1 rival, George Allen of the Washington Redskins, that the future, is now, the Dallas Cowboys, pulled off the great coup of the National Football League draft yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt. They traded four draft choices at the last minute for the rights to Tony Dorsett, the University of Pittsburgh's star running back and Heisman Trophy winner.

title: Big Car of 1985 Is Expected to Be a V6 Weighing 3,000 Lbs.
description: DETROIT, May 3  The American family car of 1985, the year when the Carter Administration's plan to drive gasoline guzzlers off the road would have maximum effect, is not on the drawing board yet. But a general picture of it can be discerned.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Child's World
description: WHEN ALL IS said and done, it is probably better for child to be a Yankee fan than a Met fan. Never mind that the Yankees have the more powerful team (even if one has to forgive their lapses). Never mind that the Yankees have a history more deeply rooted in New York than do the Mets and have had sluggers somewhat more illustrious than the likes of Mary Throneberry and Choo Choo Coleman.

title: Zaire's Troops Reported Ambushed.
description: KINSHASA. Zaire, May 3 (UPI)Zairian and Moroccan troops advancing against an invading force of Katangan exiles in Shaba Province have suffered, scores of casualties in the most serious battle since the conflict there began, !Western military sources said today.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, yesterday confirmed reports that the company had received a proposal form Cia. Vale do Rio Doce to purchase United States Steel's 49 percent interest in the Carajas iron ore project in Brazil's Amazon region.

title: DEMOCRATS CRITICIZE CARTER ON PRIORITIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 3A deepening division, both political and philosophical, between President Carter and Democratic leaders in Congress emerged today at second White House meeting on legislative priorities.

title: Study Finds Urban Mental Health Better Than That in Rural Areas
description: Residents of big cities, including New York, appear to be mentally healthier than their counterparts in small towns and rural areas, a Columbia University psychiatric sociologist has found in an interpretation of several sources of new evidence.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BEST BOW FORWARD Finalists in the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation's competition for cellists are performing today from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. The event is free. This is rare chance for the public to look in on this group's first contest for just cellists, with concert bookings and cash awards in store for the young winners named by a panel of cello experts.

title: Beame Aides See a RiskIn PensionFund
description: The reluctance of union pension funds to purchase longterm New York City bonds could endanger Mayor Beame's plan to put a cap on realestate taxes, city sources said yesterday.

title: Treasury Sells $2.75 Billion Notes In Refinancing at a Rate of 7.28%
description: The Treasury sold $2.75 billion more of its 71/4 percent notes maturing in 1984 at an average rate of 7.28 percent yesterday as dealers and investors were somewhat more eager than expected to buy the securities. part of the Government's ef

title: Old
description: BENNY GOODMAN brought something old and several things new to Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening, in concert for the benefit of Planned Parenthood. at which he led both a big band and a small group.

title: Metropolitan
description: Urban mental health, Including that of New Yorkers, seems better than mental health in small towns and rural areas, according to Dr. Leo Srole, a psychiatric sociologist at Columbia University. His interpretation of new evidence suggests that mental health of New Yorkers is substantially better than 20 years ago. [A1:12.]

title: Alioto Is Awarded $350,000 In Libel by Look Magazine
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 3After almost eight years and four Federal trials, former Mayor Joseph L. Alioto today was awarded a libel judgment of $350,000, plus costs, against Look magazine, which had said that he was linked to the Mafia.

title: Notes on People
description: OLLOWING HER attendance at her first rock concert, Princess  Alexandra, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, popped backstage to chat with the star performer, Elton John. The princess, a vivaciously outspoken woman known to her friends as Sandy, had a straightforward question for Mr. John: Do you take cocaine?

title: DOLLAR MIXED IN EUROPE; GOLD PRICES SHOW DROP
description: LONDON, May 3(AP)The dollar had a mixed day in Europe today, losing against the French franc and the Italian lira and gaining against the West German mark, the Swiss franc and the Dutch guilder.

title: U.S. Issues Text of Message
description: WASHINGTON, May 3 (Reuters)The United States today responded to renewed criticism from Pakistan by publishing the text of a private cablegram sent to Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Indonesia's Ruling Party Leading in Election
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 3 (Reuters) Indonesia's ruling Golkar movement appeared headed for a comfortable victory as results were reported tonight from yesterday's election for a new central parliament.

title: Expert Says Developing Nations May Be Buying Unsafe Reactors
description: SALZBURG, Austria, May 3Developing countries are buying and installing nuclear power plants that are less safe than those operating in the supplier nations, according to an American expert, Morris Rosen, who is on the staff of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.

title: Minuteman III Output Is Continued
description: WASHINGTON, May 3Defense Secretary Harold Brown today ordered the Minuteman III missile production line kept open for two more months.

title: What, and When, Did We Know?
description: There they are, on the front page, stars that exploded light years ago. Indochina. Nixon at the Watergate. Do they still belong to our lives? Would Vietnam be ended now without the burglary? Would the burglary have occurred without the war? That (expletive) war, Mr. Nixon used to say, long before he could know that without it he might have survived. That (inaudible) Watergate, General Thieu might say, reckoning that without he might have survived. Cosmic collisions they were, but why should we still care?

title: 27 Poles in Denmark Ask West German Asylum

title: Careers
description: Five years ago, when Americans were spending mere money in the cities than in the outlying areas, a transfer of mainstore executive to a suburban store was widely viewed as a ticket to Siberia. But timesand the proportion of branchstore volume to total saleshave changed.

title: Advertising
description: The Society of Advertising Music Producers, Arrangers and Composers has not only survived its first year, but also appears to be thriving. And to think, a number of people were betting the jingle makers couldn't make a go of it.

title: Woman Found Slain In Lido Beach Home
description: A 38yearold woman of Lido Beach, L.I., was found lying in the living room of her home at 271 Harbor Drive by her 14yearold daughter at 8 o'clock last night.

title: Life Support for Youth Ended
description: MIAMI, May 3 (AP)A University of Miami football player, comatose since an April 16 auto accident, has been declared dead and disconnected from hospital lifesupport systems on the order of the county medical examiner. Mike McNichols was the second young man to be disconnected from the machines on the order of the medical examiner, Ronald Wright. The examiner said that the youth's parents and the parents of the other young man had signed consent forms for the patients to be disconnected

title: Technology
description: An engineering program designed to make satellites an equal partner in the nation's longdistance communications system is under way, with research antennas in Crawford Hill, . N.J., and around Tampa, Fla., the most visible outward signs.

title: Ola: C. Cool Sr., at 87, Founder Of the Labor Relations Institute
description: Ola C. Cool Sr., who retired in 1961 from the Labor Relations Institute of New W which he founded in 1940, died yesterday in his home, 13 Orchard Street, Bernardsville, N.J., after a long illness. His age was 87.

title: National
description: President Carter asked for a new ethics law to set farreaching safeguards against conflicts of interest and abuse of the public trust by Government officials. In a special message to Congress he also said that he would support pending legislation authorizing appointment by Federal judges of temporary special prosecutors to act on any misconduct by highranking executive branch officials, including the holder of the Presidency. [A1:6.]

title: Gilliam's Transfer Approved
description: NASHVILLE, May 3 (AP)Legal action was taken today to allow Joe Gilliam to transfer to a New Orleans drugtreatment center so the quarterback could attend the training camp of the New Orleans Saints. Gilliam is presently at a drugtreatment center in Richmond.

description: WASHINGTON, May 3President Carter's Cabinet committee on what to do about the 6 to 8 million illegal aliens in the United States has how sent its recommendations to the White House, and these recommendations raise some fundamental questions of public policy.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES UP BUT COFFEE DECLINES
description: Prices of oldcrop soybean futures jumped the expanded daily limit of 45 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean meal and oil futures were also strong, but the grains were again under pressure.

title: Recital: Nojima Dazzles On Piano
description: MINORU NOJIMA is not the sort of workman to set himself small tasks. For his recital at Carnegie Hall on Monday night the Japanese pianist selected three of the most formidable pieces that the repertory offers. He began with a late Beethoven sonata (Op. 101), went on to Ravel's fingertwisting Gaspard de la nuit and closed with the Liszt Sonata in minor. For that kind of work, mere talent won't do; courage and endurance must be present in great quantity.

title: Conservative Judaism Approves 2Year Study on Ordaining Women
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., May 3The leaders of Conservative Judaism agreed today to form a study group that would produce a definitive judgment within two years on the question of ordaining women.

But Jimmy Carter will stay through the second half of London's diplomatic marathon.

It has rarely worked, but the attempts continue. One of the most recent efforts, David heck's Panchaloham, had its New fork premiere Monday night in Carnegie Hall performed by the merican Brass Quintet, assisted by the composer playing the veena, Carol Reck, the tambura and Douglas Knight the mridangan.

title: BHUTTO'S OPPONENTS PLAN NEW PROTESTS

description: MOSCOW, May 3it is still a writer's living room. Heaps of books and magazines overflow from shelves onto floors. A half finished page is in the typewriter, and the surrounding desk space is strewn with sheets of freshly written copy.

description: ALVIN LUCIER'S concert Monday night at the Diplomat Hotel, another in the Performing Artservices series there, was boring. Now, that may seem a tedious way to summarize a newmusic concert, because conservatives have been dismissing all sorts of interesting experimental work for decades with just that adjective.

A spokesman said 90 workers would be laid off in June when the company closes down part of its giant plant and transfers production of plastic and polystyrene to its plant in Marietta, Ohio.

title: REFUNDING BY U.S. ENDS FOR QUARTER
description: The Treasury yesterday completed its S7.9 billion quarterly refunding by selling $i billion of longterm bonds at an average yield of 7.77 percent. The sale took place as Government and corporate bond prices rose moderately and tax.I exempt local government bonds eased amid a heavy schedule of new security sales, including a pacesetting $250 million sale by Valdez. Alaska. In the money market, the effective Federal funds rate rose to 5.26 percent yesterday from 5.18 percent, an increase that brought the average rate for this key, shortterm rate to 5.15 percent for the banking week ended yesterday. This was its highest weekly average rate since the period ended last Oct. 6, and it was 33 basis points (hundredths of a percentage point) higher than its average last week.

title: To the Editor:
description: Consider two terms: free enterprise and socialism. Mr. Carter's plan to regulate doctors fees is a frightening step toward the latter. Why are not plumbers fees fixed, or lawyers incomes controlled? Surely, if we are dedicated to. equal justice for all, then any citizen is entitled to the Service of the best lawyer made avail7 able at one uniform price. Free enterprise dictates that when the lawyer or the plumber finds his services in demand, he has the liberty to charge the highest fee supported by that demand. The doctor's freedom of en terprise is challenged; now, any citizen's service is subject to government regulation, and any individual's liveli; hood may be submitted to socialist control. If this is the system advocated for the national good, perhaps socialand all citizens labors. TODD ROSENGART Lido Beach, L.L, April 27, 1977

description: QABATIYA, Israeli  Occupied West Bank, May 4This West Bank agricultural village of 12,000 Arabs remained tense and angry today in the wake of yesterday's clashes with Israeli occupation forces that left two Arabs dead and four wounded.

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT The Redolent Romance of Garlic
description: MOST PEOPLE find it difficult to consider garlic romantic. Particularly in a society bombarded with advertisements promulgating the concept of tweet breath as the key to happiness and immortality. However, to one who spent a childhood reading about the Mongol hordes of Central Asia as they traveled through the mountains and deserts of Kirghiz, Uzbekistan, Kazaksten, and all the other scans, garlic was a romantic symbol based on descriptions of campfire cookery redolent with its essence. I never actually ate any garlic until much later, of course.

Too many candidates are vying for a limited attention span, and their appeals to date apparently have not inspired much popular support. Possessing neither a distinctive voice nor an outoftheordinary performing manner, Miss Reddy really has depended on radio.

title: Personal Beauty

Hairdressers Rowthe 57th Street blocks on either side of Fifth Avenuenow has several on einnng Elsewhere last year's boutique or townhouse is now a salon, and popular shops have sprung up in areas such as SoHo and the garment district.

description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (UPI)The House Education and Labor Committee approved a bill today to transfer enforcement of Federal mine safety laws from the Interior Department to the Labor Department. The measures would also bring hard rock and metal mines under the same standards as the coal industry.

In a broader sense, though, Mr. Pryor's attempt is considerably more ambitious and interesting.

The entry deadline is midnight, Wednesday, with Rich Bris coe of 705 Orange Avenue, Crantora, N.J., the race secretary.

title: New York as Oil Base
description: Mayor Hearne is doing the right thing in trying to persuade the oil industry to use New York City as a land base for offshore drilling operationsif such drilling for gas and oil is ultimately allowed by the courts. The city government has all along favored drilling Hip cncalled Baltimore Canyon, running southward from Long Island, as a source of both energy and jobs. Other New Yorkers have been more skeptical, not so much about the project itself as about the haste with which it was being pursued. They feared that state and local concerns were being left out of the planningat considerable peril to the environment.
