title: Film: Warhol's Descent Into Gore
description: At the start of the next century it may well be possible to look back on these years of the 1970's and identify this very particular periodif not as the turning point from the Old Movie to the New, then as the time when New Movies began to supplement Old in such number that it wasn't always easy to tell them apart. The situation is disorienting. To experience some current movies is to go scuba-diving in murky water. Which way is up?This, I think, has as much to do with the various degrees of turn-off we all feel in relation to certain films as with whether or not the films are really any good. Robert Altman's "3 Women" is very much a New Movie, but its dreamlike form makes that self-evident. We don't expect to be told everything. Weespecially if we have admired Altman's work in the pastare prepared to make all sorts of adjustments when looking at one of his films, which we aren't when, say, we watch a rather absurd little horror film like Larry Cohen's "It's Alive" (about a murderous newborn child), which is also a New Movie.It says something about the movies' traditional role as a mass entertainment medium (which, of course, is no longer true) that so many people who have peacefully and sometimes enthusiastically accepted experiments in drama, fiction and painting, refuse to allow filmmakers to seek new forms of expression. That could be because the new movie forms of expression don't look so flamboyantly new. If they did, there would be a lot less trouble. Nobody is running old socks through the projector and calling it art. New Movies look like Old Movies but they aren't providing the same kind of release.There is also a lot of reverse snobbism involved in the way New Movies are watched by people who would rather die than say anything nice about Andrew Wyeth. Movies aren't supposed to be different from what they were when we were kids. This is the sort of person who goes to see "Rocky" and loves it just because it is schlocky. The other-half goes to see it and loves it because it is a slice of romanticized real-life.These thoughts are partially inspired by "Andy Warhol's Bad," the latest film to come out of the Warhol Factory and certainly a New Movie though not exactly a supreme example. Like all Warhol films, especially "Trash" and "The Chelsea Girls," "Bad" means to bewilder the audience by presenting, without moral comment and with a certain amount of glee, a picture of an absolutely rotten society. In this case the absolutely rotten society is the household of a well-upholstered, bleached-blonde Queens housewife, a Mrs. Aiken (Carroll Baker) who, in addition to removing unwanted hair (650 hairs an hour) from customers who come to her dining room-clinic, also runs a local Murder, Inc.Mrs. Aiken is less malicious than supremely acquisitive. Because her husband is ineffectual, she does what she has to do to make ends meet as a member of the great consumer society. She acts as the booking agent for a string of operativesmostly ill-tempered young women  who are prepared to carry out such contracts as the murder of unpleasant babies and autistic children and the maiming of other beings (including a dog) and who, simply out of boredom, may spend an off evening burning down a movie theater."Bad" is a New Movie but it is a less pure New Movie than the earlier Warhols in that it contains a hint of sentimentality and there is little doubt what we are meant to feel about what is happening on the screen, even when it's not easy to watch the gory details. "Bad" is a conscious send-up of America-TheAbsurd, a satire, but its own fondness for bad taste forces the audience to come to some adjustment to it, to find a way to accommodate its piled-on vulgarities. It is this insistence that we come to it, rather than the other way around, that is one of the distinguishing features of the New Movie, which is more truly avant-garde than any 80 hours of films that experiment with abstract images, superimposition of images, associative images and single-frame editing.The difficulty with the New Movie is that we still tend to bring to every film the same set of expectations and demands we carried with us when we went to see "Gone With the Wind," "North By Northwest," "Grand Illusion" and "Potemkin." That would seem a perfectly reasonable thing to do, since we're still sitting in the same old theater seats, looking at the same old theater screen from the same old point of view. Yet we aren't always walking out of the theater with the same old feelings. Something most unsettling is taking place.In such Rainer Werner Fassbinder films as "Mother Kusters Goes to Heaven," "Chinese Roulette" and "The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant," there is often a complete lack of psychological background. Fassbinder couldn't care less about how his characters get to be the way they areI suspect he'd say that to attempt to explain would be to oversimplify and thus to mislead, which is not the purpose of his films. All that we can know about a Fassbinder character is revealed on the screen in the course of the contemporary action but because the contemporary action is not always clear, we have to step in and make our own assumptions. We can, and there's nothing wrong in that but it may be a waste of time. In Fassbinder's films people, place, time and event are so thoroughly fused that we simply cannot isolate and analyze characters in any conventional way, any more than we can criticize a piece of non-representational sculpture in terms of whether or not it physically resembles its model. Freud is not dead for the New Moviemaker, but someone like Fassbinder sees a totality that involves a great deal more than character explanation.Strictly speaking, the New Movies aren't new. Luis Bunuel has been making them since 1928. Sometimes, as in "Un Chien Andalou" and "The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie," they have been surreal, but quite as frequently they've been as straightforward as "Tristana." Bunuel's films have the fantastic clarity of a landscape lit by a bolt of lightning. We see more detail than we can immediately understandand more than he cares to waste his time and ours by explaining. There's seldom any music on the soundtrack of a Bunuel film to tell us whether we should laugh, cry, be furious or shocked. The delight in a Bunuel film is that we may feel all those emotions in a succession of splitseconds. Movies like that don't quickly pass from the mind.Another difficulty with the New Movie is that it doesn't present us with any obvious point of identification. Sometimes there's no one with whom we can sympathize, which, as a rule of thumb, is not great box office, though Stanley Kubrick has brought off such successful New Movies as "2001" and "A Clockwork Orange." The success of these films, I suspect, lies in their "spectacle"the mind-boggling visions of space in "2001" and the wittily grotesque projection of the-way-we-are-now into the future of "Clockwork."Without their spectacle the Kubrick films would probably be intolerable for many people. Audiences accustomed to Old Movies equate the dispassion of "A Clockwork Orange" with a conviction that Kubrick himself takes no moral stand on the events depicted. He does, of course, but he doesn't announce it. He refuses to make things easy for us. He doesn't footnote his movies with reassuring messages. Instead, he insults our sense of order by showing a system of rewards and punishments that is totally confused. There is no Clark Gable or even a Steve McQueen to act as our surrogate in "A Clockwork Orange"no one we immediately recognize and whose popular identity establishes our relation to the film. We watch the New Movie at a distance, on our own. It's no coincidence, I think, that there has been an increasing number of New Movies since the decline of the old star system. New Movies deal in the unfamiliar.Many horror films are New Movies, including the dreadful "The Omen," if only because they require audiences to swallow nonsense that they'd reject in the light of day. But people who go to horror films are prepared to make adjustmentsto stand comfortably ouside the filmas the price of thrills. Horror movies are spectacles, too.Fellini's "Casanova" is a New Movie and "Amarcord," which is awash in sentiment of the most appealing kind, is Old. There's no doubt about how one is supposed to feel about the characters of Fellini's recollected youth, but "Casanova" is as cold as ice. Temperature is not necessarily a surefire way of determining the difference between New and Old Movies, but it is an indicator. The New Movie tends to be cool, distant, without reproach. It says, "This is the way it looks. How do you feel about it?" and then it leaves you on your own. It is suspicious of answers. Bergman's films are Old in the best sense, and they are Old even when they are ambiguous. They are full of unmistakable emotionslove, sorrow, longing, dread, confusion.Wim Wenders's screen adaptation of Peter Handke's "The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick" is a quintessential New Movie, being a vivid film equivalent of the kind of New Novel written by Handke in Germany and Alain Robbe-Grillet and Marguerite Duras in France. Both Robbe-Grillet and Duras have made their own New Movies but they've been unendurably boring. Duras ("Nathalie Granger" and "India Song") refuses to give us enough information of any kind to excite our interest, while Robbe-Grillet ("L'Immortelle" displays a fondness for fashion-magazine photography and pretty images that have the effect of denying any emotions whatsoever. While his writing is clean, his movies are full of purple prose."The Goalie's Anxiety at the Penalty Kick" is a stunningly straightforward story of a man cutting himself loose from his society, going over the edge into lunacy the way the rest of us take off on a summer vacation. Methodically, Wenders uses no tricks. We recognize the world in which his hero travels. It is so ordinary that for about the first third of the movie we wonder what is up, at which point we begin to notice that although we recognize the world of the goalie, it's not all that ordinary. Everything is a bit too precise. We are aware of noises we wouldn't usually hear. At times the landscape seems uninhabited, then suddenly full of menacing strangers. There are portents of disaster everywhere, sometimes in the hysterical way children play when they're excited.The manner in which Wenders draws us into the goalie's mind (without one subjective camera movement) is so remarkable that the film rivets us, though to this day I'm not sure why or what it all means. It's too easy to call it a study in alienation. The film and the responses it prompts are more mysterious than that. The New Movie need not be gloomy. I think an argument can be made to the effect that all of Woody Allen's comedies from "Take the Money and Run" through "Love and Death" are New Movies, while his new movie, the marvelously affecting "Annie Hall," is Old. A lot of people who had trouble finding a handle for the "early" Woodythe out-and-out ratare discovering him for the first time in "Annie Hall," which is the first time he's presented himself as a character of intelligence and feeling.New Movies are neither better nor worse than Old. They are different. They ask us to look at the screen with skepticism instead of expecting to be lulled into euphoria or having our prejudices (good and bad) reaffirmed. Sometimes New Movies aren't worth the effort. Sometimes, though, as in films like "Mother Kusters" or Terrence Malick's "Badlands" or Woody Allen's "Bananas," the experience is to remind us that movies have only scratched the surface of their possibilities.

title: In Praise of Objects That Need Care
description: MAINTENANCE free  that is the advantage cited for many of today's produCts, and indeed it is an ideal toward witkh much of the world seems to be moving. Not to have to repair, refurbish, repaint or keep up is conSidered a supreme virtue. But I am not so sure. I would like to say a few words on behalf of things that do need care, and that are more loved and more valuable as a result.

title: Propane Leak Causes Concern
description: SWEDESBORO, N. J., May 4 (UPI)A fourblock area was evacuated for four hours late yesterday after a propane gas tank ruptured at a food processing plant. The residents were allowed to return to their homes today after repairs were made to the tank at the Del Monte Corporation food plant. The police in Woolrich Township said the rupture in the 31,000cubic feet tank at 8:45 P.M. set off a fire, but plant employees extinguished the blaze before the fire companies arrived. No one was injured.

At the same time, a spokesman for the poll said yesterday, the majority of those polled would prohibit all other contributions.

title: About the Yankees ...
description: Catfish Hunter, who was supposed to make hiS firSt start last night since opening day, Will try and make it tonight against the Oakland As and Vida Blue. That's his old team, but it doesn't have too many of his old teammates. . . .The Yankee pitchers for the rest of the series with the A's will he Ed Figueroa tomorrow night, Don Gullett Saturday and Mike Torrez Sunday. Gullet will be making his first start since he was hurt on Baltimore's wet field April 26. Torrez will pitch against Dock Ellis; the chief man for whom he was traded.

title: Swiss Socialist Seeks to Tighten Reins on Banks in a Referendum
description: GENEVA, May 4The president of the Swiss Socialist Party told the National Assembly today that Swiss banks were a state within the state that must be brought under public and parliamentary control.

title: Recruitment Contract Is Awarded to Grey
description: Grey Advertising has won the contract for the Department of Defense's new experimental allservice recruitment advertising effort. The total budget is $2.5 million, and the contract is for one year, with two oneyear options.

Or a dinner set in which the faces of bank presidents stare up you. Or a cachepot in the shape of a postal worker. Animals, however, are quite another matter.

title: In Connecticut, Nuclear Plants Generate Goodwill And Cheap Power
description: WATERFORD, Conn., May 3The unlikely spectacle of 2,000 New Englanders protesting against a cheap and clean source of electricity last weekend in Seabrook, N.H., was a puzzling one for many people in this state, which committed itself to nuclear energy a decade ago and nnw consumes more nucleargenerated electricity than any other state in the country.

title: Hunts Seek Ban on Further Release of Soybean Data
description: CHICAGOMay 4The Hunt family of Dallas, in a countersuit filed in Federal District Court today, asked for a restrain ing order to prevent the Federal Commodities Futures Trading Commission from releasing any more information about family possessions in the soybean market.

title: Job Training for Disabled Found Going to Those With Feigned Ills
description: The New York State Commission of Investigation yesterday characterized New York City's operation of the vocational rehabilitation programintended to train the disabled for jobsas so poor that persons claiming nothing more disabling than uptightness or inability to sleep had been trained to be truck drivers at state expense.

title: Nicholas Magallanes, Dancer, 54; City Ballet's First Orpheus, in 48
description: Nicholas Magallanes, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet since its inception, died of cancer Monday at his home in North Merrick, L.I. He was 54 years old. at the Ford Pavillion's A Thousand Times Neigh at the 1940 New York World's Fair. Mr. Magallanes also danced with the Catherine Littlefield Ballet, in 1942, and the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo from 1943 to 1946. In that company he created the role of the Poet in Night Shadow, of Cleonte in Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme and of Jean de Brienne in the BalanchineDanilova production of Raymonda.

title: Car Buying Pattern Mixed In Time Since Energy Plan
description: DETROIT, May 4Auto sales figures issued today for the periods, since President Carter's energy proposals showed a confusing pattern in consumer buying, but a surge in sales of fuelefficient cars appeared at hand.

title: Quebec Study Showing French Speakers Earn Less Adds Fuel to the Controversy Over Languages
description: MONTREAL, May 4A recent study showing that Frenchspeaking wage earners are at the bottom of the income scale in Quebec has added ammunition to bitterly contested drive by the provincial government to make French the prevailing language of social and economic me here.

title: Vietnam Is Preparing Its People For a New American Presence
description: BANGKOK Thailand, Thursday, May 5For more than a month, Vietnam has been building up a campaign to educate its people to the fact that after two years bf absence and 20 years of war, Americans may soon be returning to Vietnam In peace.

title: Notes on People
description: AJURY IN Litchfield, Conn., yesterday awarded $377,525 to Winston Frederick Churchill Guest, the socialite, for serve ices rendered under a contract to recover one of czarist Russia's great pri;ate art collections. Mr. Guest had claimed in a suit that the late Russian Prince George Scherbatoff contracted to pay him a percentage on the sale of recovered art works, and the prince's estate owed him commissions on several recovered treasures. Among these were paintings of Adam and Eve by Lucas Cranach the elder, the 16th century German master, which Prince Scherbatoff sold for $800,000. Mr. Guest who testified he took on the art search for the prince only because he was financially embarrassed at the time, is the 71yearold godson and second cousin of the late Winston Churchill.

description: Theater

description: WASHINGTON  Like a football game that ends in a tie, often described as no more satisfying than kissing your sister, the outofcourt settlement last Monday of a fiveyear Securities and Exchange Commission suit against White & Case led to no wild celebration.

description: John Travolta, seen recently with Sissy Spacek in Carrie, has been signed to star in the movie version of Grease, to be produced by Allan Carr and Robert Stigwood for Paramount Pictures, it was announced by Michael D. Eisner, president of Paramount.

description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 4The British Government and some of Northern Ireland's leading politicians became noticeably tougher today in their efforts to end a twodayold general strike by hardline Protestants.

description: LONDON, May 4Labor councilmen fell like ninepins in Scotland's municipal elections yesterday, and their fate foreshadowed grim times for the Labor Party and its leader, James Callaghan.

description: BRIDbEPORT, Conn., May 4Arrest warrants were issued in Superior Court here today charging the president of the Sponge Rubber Products Company and two business associates with conspiracy in the bombing of the company's factory in nearby Shelton two years ago.

description: DETROIT, May 4The Chrysler Corporation's incentive pay plan for executives, which came under sharp attack from stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday, provided for bonuses when net income plus the provision for bonus pay exceeded earnings of $3 a share on common stock.

description: ALBANY, May 4The Governor's office today sent the Legislature a plan for getting state scholarship awards paid on time next year or, failing that, at least advancing the money directly to the colleges so that their own bills can be paid.

description: ipEG 0 MY HEART wears its age gracefully. It is 65 years old and far from ready for retirement. This is the 1912 comedy that J. Hartley Manners wrote for Laurette Taylor, who later became Mrs. Manners. The Lion Theater Company revived the play Off Off Broadway this year, and last night, essentially with the same cast, moved Off Broadway to Theater Four.

title: Dance: Sylphide
description: WHEN THE HANDFUL of Romantic classic ballets is toted up, La Sylphide is often forgotten, and yet it can claim primacy among those 19thcentury masterpieces still performed more or less intact. R. is the oldest of the survivors and has a wellbred quality that enfolds its magical tragedy. Gelsey Kirkland was the enchanted creature Tuesday evening at theMetropolitan Opera and radiated delicacy in American Ballet Theater's production.

In April, Velez had seven doubles and five hoMe runs ands drove in 18 rafts:

title: Carter Says Sacrifices on Energy Will Be Less Than He Expected
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  President Carter, who urged the American people last month to make sacrifices for an energy program that would be the moral equivalent of war, reportedly told the House energy committee today that those sacrifices would be less substantial than he had then envisioned.

title: Harlettes Regroup
description: Sharon Redd, Ula Hedwig and Charlotte Crossley used to make up the Harletces, the vocal group that backed Bette Midler. Now they have regrouped, as Formerly the Harlettes, and settled into a twoweek run at Reno Sweeney, and if the reaction of the capacity crowd at Tuesday's late show is any indication, they are going to claim major portion of the audience thatput Miss Midler over the top.

title: Supplies of Crude Oil Set Record for Week; Gasoline Stocks Down
description: Inventories of crude oil stood at record levels in the week ending April 29, according to the latest weekly supply figures released by the American Petroleum Institute. Crude oil stocks reached 300.5 million barrels, the highest level since the early 1940's, the trade association reported. This compares to 294.9 million barrels of crude oil in the previous week, and 279.3 million barrels in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Rep. Tonry, Figure in Vote Fraud, Resigns but Vows to. Run Again
description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)Representative Richard A. Tonry, a freshman Democrat from Louisiana, submitted his resignation from Congress today because of alleged vote fraud, but he vowed to Win the scat back in a new election.

title: French Hamburger King Deposed
description: PARIS, May 4Jacques Bore!, the man who taught the French to cat hamburgers and founded Europe's largest restaurant and hotel chain, was overthrown in a board room revolution here last night.

title: At Your Service: Donating Used Apparel and Furnishings
description: IT'S SPRING cleaning time. The windows are sparkling and there's been a vigorous setto with the moldings behind the radiator. But what to do about the clothes that have suddenly become too big, too small or just not quite right since last spring? Or the jammed closets? Or the armchair that guests must be warned away from?

description: A North Carolina gun dealer was Indieted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of conspiracy to transport military ammunition stolen from Camp Leieune by a group of United States marines.

description: WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP)The Senate Environment and Public Works Committee approved a major revision of the 1970 Clean Air Act today, giving United States automobile makers just one more year to meet stiff air pollution standards.

description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, normally deferential to each other, got into a nasty skirmish yesterday in an unusual exchange of audits and reports.

description: LONDON, May 5 (AP)The price of gold dropped $1 to $1.50 per ounce today and the dollar remained largely unchanged in a day of heavy trading in Europe.

description: HARTFORD, May 5The Connecticut Senate tonight blocked a socalled bottle bill that would have banned fliptop cans and required that deposits be paid on peer and soft drink bottles.

description: WASHINGTON, May 5A political struggle was joined today between the Carter Administration and a formidable group of senators over the future status of the Voice of America and its parent organization, the United States Information Agency.

title: 4 Croatian Nationalists Convicted Of Hijacking LaGuardia Jetliner
description: Four Croatian nationalists were found guilty last night in the hijacking of Trans World Airlines jet last September. A New York City bomb squad officer was killed by a bomb left behind by the nationalists.

title: Stan Getz, at 50, Is Still Studying the Saxophone
description: On the handstand at Hopper's in Greenwich Village, Stan Getz plays his saxophone as though time had stood still. The big, open melodic sound that is his trademark pours out on the hossa novas that he has been playing since 1962. A set may include his first bossa nova hit, Desafinado, and a more recent one, O Grande Amor,

title: Oregon Faculty Opposes R.O.T.C.
description: EUGENE, Ore. May 5 (UPI)The University of Oregon faculty voted 86 to 76 yesterday to recommend an end to Reserve Officer Training Corps programs om the campus.

title: CHAUNCEY M'PHERSON, 85, RETIRED I.T.T. OFFICIAL
description: Chauncey Ryder McPherson, a retired vice president and director of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its predecessor, the AllAmerica Cable and Radio Company, died Wednesday in his home, Creag Dhu, on Minebrook Road, Bernardsville, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: A Louisville, Ky., mother who approves of corporal punishment in the schools said the other day that it wouldn't be necessary to strike children In school if the parents gave their children proper discipline before they entered school. ing and some did poorly. He came to the conclusion that other factors, such as the child's innate temperament and how well suited that temperament was to a particular school or family life, probably had as much impact on the child as parental style itself. And he came to the belief that pediatricians or other authorities on child rearing should not attempt to change a family's method of child rearing as long as nothing patently dreadful was happening.

title: Bhutto Arrests More Opponents and Imposes a Curfew on 3 Cities
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, May 5On the eve of planned nationwide demonstrations, grayuniformed police this afternoon swooped down on the headquarters of the opposition Pakistan National Alliance and arrested most of its leaders of any standing who were still at large.

title: Pop Music: Irene Reid Sings
description: Like Ella Fitzgerald, who got her start in an amateur contest at the Apollo Theater, Irene Reid came out of the Apollo's Amateur Night 30 years ago and has been polishing her talents as a singer since then, including a period with Count Basle's Orchestra in the 1960's.

title: Yankee and Pirate Owners Making Runs for the Roses
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5Kenesaw Mountain Landis would have denounced it, maybe even forbidden it. But the big leagues of baseball will make an unusually strong appearance in the big leagues of racing Saturday when owners of the New York Yankees and Pittsburgh Pirates send horses to the post in the 103d Kentucky Derby.

title: Art: Prendergast of Several Moods
description: AURICE PRENDERGAST was in Paris at a time in the early 1890'swhen it seems in retrospect that it was virtually impossible to paint a bad picture. That's nonsense, of course. Appalling pictures abounded, then as at any other time. But it remains true that Paris at that time was tremenaously alive and that something of that aliveness was contagious. Americans, Englishmen, Canadians, Australiansall went far beyond what the sports writers call their personal best in emulation of Monet and Degas, Gauguin and Cezanne, Bonnard and Vuillard.

title: Farm in Jersey Stays. OneFamily Affair for 280 Years
description: SAYRE'S NECK, N.J., May 5It's on the road map, but there is no post office here, no store, no village. Just cluster of farmhouses on a sandy neck of land that .becomes a swamp of sawgrass, marsh elder and sweet gum trees before disappearing into Delaware Bay.

title: Dance: A Balanchine Dream
description: The intricate patterns of George Balanchine's choreogrphy for A Midsummer Night's Dream rival the tangled passions of Shaktspeare's characters. Just when everything seems permanently knotted, though, a graceful passage loosens the conflicts lines. Kay Mazzo was the proud Titania on Thursday evening at the New York State Theater and Robert Weiss danced the affronted Oberon.

title: Reichhold Resin Price Up
description: Reichhold Chemicals inc announced a price increase on all chemical coating resins containing soybean oil, effective May 20. The increase applies to long oil, medium oil and short oil alkyds and will range from 5 percent to 10 percent.

title: First Soviet Ambassador In 38 Years Is in Spain
description: MADRID, May 5 (UPI)The Soviet Union's first ambassador to Spain in 38 years presented his credentials to King Juan Carlos today on the same day that Santiago Carrillo, the Communist leader, appeared for the first time on Spanish television.

title: FALSE PATIENT DATA REPORTED AT HEARING
description: Doctors frequently falsify medical records to cover up evidence of negligence or poor judgment, both to protect themselves in malpractice suits and to improve the appearance of their professional skills before other doctors, a New York State Assembly hearing was told yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: HE BOOK OF LISTS Is exactly thata collection of nearly 500 lists, written by everyone from Richard M. Nixon (20 enemies) to Bing Crosby. (10 favorite performers of all time) and compiled by David Wallechinsky and his father, the novelist Irving Wallace, and sister, Amy Wallace. Why did these perfectly intelligent people decide to perpetrate such a book? Well, apparently there is a section of lists buried in The People's Almanac, a successful offbeat reference book that Mr. Walleahinsky helped write a couple of years ago, and these lists, among which is The Nine Breeds of Dogs That Bite the Most, have stirred readers up and got them arguing and writing more lists. The message to the authors was, List, list, 0, list! as the ghost in Hamlet put it. So, they've listed.

title: Merck Is Expanding Research Facilities
description: Merck & Company is engaged in a $60 million capital expansion program of its research and development facilities. The expansion includes new biological and chemical research laboratories, large pilot plant facilities, a major unit for natural products isolation and, facilities for toxicology and virology.

title: Agreement Reached to End Philadelphia Transit Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (UPI)Another tentative agreement to end a costly 42day citywide transit strike was reached today between the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority and Transport Workers Union Local 234.

title: An Outraged Artist Battles With Renault
description: PARISJean Dubuffet, who opposes Laws, Institutions and a traditional vision of the world in favor of merry invention, is engaged in a vehement court battle to enforce judicial protection of his biggest and most ambitious work.

title: Housen Captures Medal in Richardson Golf on a
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 5Many a hacker who has bogeyed and double bogeyed his way over the rolling courses on Long Island's North Shore or the hilly tracks of Westchester County has made the 19thhole statement, Give me a flat layout and I'll score. Just you see.

title: Phone Company Says It Has Pulled The Plug on FreeCall Blue Boxes
description: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that it had won the 16yearold guerrilla war with phone freaks who developed ingenious devices called blue boxes which allowed them to make free telephone calls to any place in the world.

title: Cabaret: Jesse Winchester
description: ESSE WINCHESTER. who's at the Bottom Line through tomorrow, made his New York debut Wednesday night in direct com

title: Soviet Complains to U.S. on Denial Of Visas to Union Representatives
description: MOSCOW, May 5 (AP)The Soviet For eign Ministry complained to the United States Embassy today that the Helsinki accords on international contacts were violated by denying entry visas to Soviet trade union representatives, the Tess press agency said.

title: Workers in Ulster Are Defying Strike Amid New Violence
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 5The Protestant general strike aimed at halting all but emergency services in Northern Ireland lost ground today.

title: ALBANY COURT ORDERS READING EXAMINATION
description: New York City's annual reading tests wil! be administered to 700,000 elementaryschool and juniorhighschool students this Tuesdaysix weeks later than originally scheduledunder stringent conditions imposed yesterday by the State Court of Appeals in Albany.

title: The Rev, Moon and Companions Arrested for Trespassing Upstate
description: ANANDALEONHUDSON, N. Y., May 5(UPI)The state police arrested the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and 10 companions today for trespassing at Bard College in this Dutchess County community.

title: State Dept., After a House Vote, Affirms Hanoi Will Get No Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The State Department pledged today once again that the United States would not offer any economic aid to Vietnam. The policy was affirmed after the House of Representatives, in a surprise move last night, voted to prohibit even the discussion of assistance to Hanoi.

title: Senate Votes Research Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)The Senate voted today to authorize $892 million for the National Science Foundation, to be used for research grants to colleges and universities in the fiscal year 1978.. The authorization is $100 million more than the 1977 sum for federally sponsored research.w1

title: Senate Panel Votes Rise in Housing Aid To Northeast Cities
description: WASHINGTON. May 5The Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs reported approval today of an amendment to the Carter Administration's communitydevelopment blocgrant program to channel more money to Northeastern cities with large amounts of old housing.

title: Corporate Bribery Bill Approved by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, May 5(AP)  The Senate today voted to approve legislation that would establish fiveyear jail terms and $10,000 fines for corporate officers who bribe officials of foreign governments.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: ARAMOOR, with its Mediterranean air, its pinkstuccoed walls and redtiled roofs and its arcaded courtyard, offers more treasures than one might ever hope to see in a country mansionentire rooms from European palaces recreated down to the last detail and filled with enormous collections of medieval, Renaissance and Chinese art and furnishings.

title: ]Anatomy Isn't Destiny
description: My purpose is consciousnessraising. In order to legislate relief from sex discrimination  with conviction and urgency  I believe that lawmakers must confront the deep cultural origins of our behavior and attitudes toward women.

title: RABBINICAL MEETING REJECTS 2 NOMINEES

title: CORRECTION

The Babcock and Wilcox facility involved is near Apollo, Pa.

A little stream flowing into it from the Hackenjack River served as a swimming hole, discarded cans and other trash were ideal targets for BBgun practice and berries abounded for picking.

description: VIENNA, May 5The doormat finally stepped back on somebody here tonight, as Rumania, beaten in all eight of its previous games in the world ice hockey championships, stunned the United States, 54.

title: Donald McGraw, Group President, Resigns Post in Family Company
description: Donald C. McGraw Jr., 51 years old, a group president since 1974, has resigned from the publishing and information services company cofounded by his grandfather. James H. McGraw.

title: SHORTCOMINGS CITED IN MARIJUANA CURBS

description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)A special tax should be levied on airline tickets to help pay up to 35 percent of the cost of new, quieter jetliners, Transportation Secretary Brock Adams said today.

description: Benson X Four this weekend is the name of a oneman fournight festival, a smorgasbord of jazztopop musical offerings, a showcase for the bluesy singing voice of George Benson and the nonelectric beauty of his guitar.

description: WASHINGTON, May 5The Carter Administration proposed today to ease controls so that the price of oil from Alaska's North Slope would rise to the same level as crude oil imported from other countries.

title: U.S Plans to Impose Duties On Nuts and Bolts From Japan
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)  The Treasury Department said today that would impose duties on imported nuts and bolts from Japan because the Japanese exporters are subsidized by the Government.

title: Samuel Lanin, Retired Leader 0f Orchestra in New York City
description: Samuel C. Lanin, a retired orchestra leader whose groups included several musicians who later led famous bands of their own, died yesterday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 85 years old.

description: SEMIFINAL ROUND

description: Black Lady Macbeths do not happen often in the theater, and this is probably the first time anywhere there will be two simultaneously.

title: Sutton Seeks EqualTime Ruling
description: Percy E. Sutton asked for an official definition yesterday of when a candidate for Mayor of New York City is official and, thereby, subject to Federal equal time broadcast rules.

title: Dance Springs Onto Center Stage
description: EXCITEMENT and Cuban dancers have always been synonymous, and the highlight of a noveltypacked dance weekend with the Alvin Ailey company is tomorrow's American premiere of a prizewinning duet from Alicia Alonso's company, performed by two of her protgs from Havana.

title: Jersey Medical Aide Assailed Again
description: TRENTON, May 5Dr. Joanne E. Finley, New Jersey Commissioner of Health, in the latest exchange between her and a top member of the department's scientific staff, accused him today of action that could constitute a serious breach of duty.

title: Some Who Knew Him Are Still Divided
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Nearly three years after leaving the Presidency, Richard M. Nixon remains, in exile as in power, a divisive figure who stirs clashing emotions in many Americans, judging by the reaction to the 90minute interview shown on television last night.

title: House Panel Approves Carter's Election Day Registration Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 President Carter's plan to increase American voter turnout by permitting registration on Election Day was cleared today for prompt House floor action over united Republican opposition.

title: French Tell of Chemical Method
description: SALZBURG, Austria, May 5France's statement that it had found a way of enriching uranium for power plants and of avoiding the danger that the material could be used for bombs came during a debate that had been going on all week here on how to accomplish just that.

title: Screen:Class Struggle on the Plains of Patagonia
description: THE HISTORY of Hector Olivera's 1974 Argentine film, "Rebellion in Patagonia," is almost as full of reversals in fortune, followed by success, followed by other setbacks, as the tumultuous social history it documents.The film, which opened yesterday at the Thalia and Jean Renoir Cinema on a double-bill with "Union Maids," is about the series of bloody strikes that marked the first attempts to organize by urban and rural workers in the southernmost province of Argentina in the early 1920's.Those attempts succeeded, failed, succeeded, and ultimately were decisively destroyed by the government. The Argentine Army imposed a sort of order-by-execution that has since become a way of life for the huge, potentially rich, underpopulated country that stretches from the subtropics almost to the Antarctic."Rebellion in Patagonia" takes a long view of history but when it was ready for release in 1974, at the time the presidency of Juan Pern was turning more and more to the right, the military men thought it advisable that the film be shelved. When, after a lot of controversy, the movie finally was released in Buenos Aires, it became a hit and then went on to be honored at film festivals in Berlin and Taormina.Since then, several of its principal actors, their lives threatened by the Argentine Anti-Communist Alliance, a very busy, aggressive, right-wing vigilante group, have taken up residence abroad. The furies that motivated the action in the filmthe historic schisms between the Argentine right and leftlive on.To use the terms right and left implies that the disagreements that separated Argentinians after World War I were politically more sophisticated than they really were.It was the haves versus the have-nots, the wealthy landowners allied with city interests against the rural and urban workers. Though each group had many members who were not Argentinians, each liked to warn against the influences of "foreigners" in the ranks of their enemies. In a land populated by immigrants, there's nothing lower than the late arrival."Rebellion in Patagonia" covers a great deal of ground in the sweeping style of the muralist, opening with the assassination of an Army colonel in Buenos Aires in 1923 and then going back several years to describe the events leading up to that assassination.Most of the action takes place on the broad plains of Patagonia, one of the most beautiful, most spooky landscapes on earth. It was there that a coalition of Communists and anarchists had successfully organized the workers on the sheep farms. When the landowners later refuse to honor their agreements, new strikes break out and the Army chief, once sympathetic to populist cause, sets out to break the movement in a campaign that's estimated to have taken the lives of 3,000 workers.The film is a collection of vignettes, richly detailed with the sort of character and incident that recall nostalgically but without sentimentality the sense of high purpose of early trade-unionism. The movie has a great fondness for these seminal labor fighters, including a young Spanish activist (Luis Brandoni) who is also a realist, and a fine old German idealist (Pepe Soriano) who puts his life on the line for his beliefs.It's not all black versus white, though. Mr. Olivera defines divisions within the ranks of both sides, sometimes tragically and often wittily, as in an early trade-union meeting when the success of a strike is celebrated by the Communists with a rousing anthem while their nonpoliticized Chilean compatriots look on aghast. They haven't yet been taught that politics can be expressed in song.

title: Judge Sentences 17 Seabrook Nuclear Protesters to 15Day Jail Terms
description: HAMPTON, N.H., May 5After the State Attorney General called the occupation of a nuclear power plant site at Seabrook one of the most wellplanned acts of criminal activity in the nations's history, a judgein a sharp break with legal practicebegan sending some of the 2,000 demonstrators to jail.

title: SAFETY RECALL SET FOR COFFEE MAKERS
description: WASHINGTON. May 5 (UPI)The Consumer Product Safety Commission announced today the recall of 3.1 million Mr. Coffee machines because of electrical defects in some that could cause shock or fire hazards.

title: A Tribute From Belafonte
description: Harry Belafonte is famous as a singer of popular and folk songs, as an actor and a producer, but tonight at 8 o'clock in Carnegie Hall he will be seen and heard in quite a different role. He will be the narrator in a performance by the New York Choral Society of Hans Werner Henze's Moralities, a contemporary concert piece of some complexity. How in the world did he get involved?

title: PRICES FOR BONDS SHOW A LATE DROP
description: The credit markets, surprised by the size of the increase in the money supply disclosed yesterday afternoon, declined in price late in the day. Bond traders and money market analysts concluded that the Federal Reserve was headed into a protracted period of attempting to slow the growth Credit of the monetary aggregates, Markets a process likely to push interest rates higher. Threemonth Treasury bill rates rose from 4.73 percent prior to the release of the money supply figures to 4.78 percent an hour later. The 7 percent notes that mature in 1984, an issue that was sold on Tuesday, dropped in price from 1002/32 to 9924/32, lifting their yield from 7.24 percent to 7.30 percent.

title: A's, Blue Beat Yanks And Hunter
description: As if calling for the candy bar that was named after him only a few hours earlier, fans at Yankee Stadium started chanting Reggie, Reggie, Reggie when Reggie Jackson came to hat in the eighth inning last night at Yankee Stadium with two runners on base, no outs and Oakland leading, 51.

title: JOSEPH J. LAMARK SR.
description: PITTSBURGH, May 5Joseph J. Lamark Sr., who retired several years ago as the personnel manager of the Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Division of Shenango Inc., died today at Allegheny General Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Coraopolis, Pa.

title: Premier of Israel Welcomes Forthcoming U.S. Suggestions
description: JERUSALEM, May 5Israel's Acting Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, said today that he welcomed Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's remarks that the United States would soon set forth its suggestions for a Middle East settlement between Israel and the Arab nations.

title: GOVERNOR IS SNUBBED BY BRONX DEMOCRATS
description: In the first fallout from the feud between Governor Carey and Mayor Beame, the Bronx Democratic organization snubbed the Governor last night by not inviting him to its annual dinner.

title: Surveys Rank Program With Leading Series
description: Early ratings from four cities for David Frost' s televised interview with former President Richard M. Nixon indicate that the Wednesday night telecast was the most watched news interview in the history of television and one of the highestrated news broadcasts ever.

title: STUDY SAYS BATTERY PARK IS BEST CONVENTION SITE
description: An engineering study commissioned by the DowntownLower Manhattan Association has found that Battery Park City, at the tip of Manhattan would he the best site for the proposed New York City ConventionExhibition Center, the association announced yesterday.

title: Music: Works by Serly
description: OR A NUMBER of years Tibor Serly has been developing a method of musical composition called Modus Lascivus. Some examples have been played here, but on Wednesday night in Alice Tully Hall piano recital was devoted exclusively to works of this kind. They included the Sonata of 1947 and 40 Etudes written between 1946 and 1960. The etudes were being, played for the first time in public, and the artist was Miriam Molin, a well regarded pianist who is the composer's wife.

title: PRESIDENT IN LONDON FOR SUMMIT TALKS WITH ALLIES OF U. S.
description: LONDON, May 5Jimmy Carter, on his first trip abroad as President, arrived in London today for meetings with other world leaders that he described as great undertaking to bind ourselves closer together.

title: Carter Doubts Enlightenment
description: LONDON, May 5 (UPI)President Carter said today that he thought Mr. Nixon had been candid in conceding that he had lied to the American people in the Watergate affair, but Mr. Carter doubted that the David Frost interview had enlightened thepublic.

title: Member of Energy Group Assailing Mobil Is Also Rival in Bid to Irvine
description: A major participant in a group competing against the Mobil Corporation for the valuable West Coast real estate holdings of the Irvine Company was identified yesterday as one of seven members of a newly formed Committee for Energy Sources, of Washington.

title: Ambassador Shannon
description: We do not normally comment on commendable ambassadorial appointments. But a Senator named Kennedy has informed the Irish on both sides of the Atlantic that their next United States Ambassador is to be William V. Shannon, our own Bill Shannon, who has been sorting out right from wrong on this page, with rigor and wit, with signature and without for the last 13 years. With selfish reluctance, we approve President Carter's choice. The full measure of the nation's gain will become evident only when we contrive to publish his forthcoming ambassadorial dispatches, predictably full of good works and perceptive analyses.

title: A Broken Promise?
description: Just as Richard Nixon emerged from two and a half years of obscurity, representatives of the United States and Vietnam ended their first round of talks on establishing normal relations talks over which the secret diplomacy of Mr. Nixon and Henry Kissinger casts a dark shadow.

title: Revlon Dividend Rise
description: Michel C. Bergerac, chairman of RevIon Inc., told the annual meeting here yesterday that he would recommend an increase in the quarterly common dividend, to 25 cents a share from 22 cents. The increased dividend would be payable July 15 to holders of record June 15.

title: Giscard Under Growing Pressure To Call Early Elections in France
description: PARIS, May 5Pressure is mounting on the Government to call elections, which, according to polls, the SocialistCommunist alliance is almost certain to win. The latest poll shows the left ahead with 56 percent, the largest margin ever, and 32 percent of those questioned in favor of an early election.

title: French Report on a Nuclear Fuel That Cannot Be Used for Bombs
description: PARIS, May 5The French Government said today that it had developed what it described as a safe way of producing nuclearreactor fuel that can be used to run power stations but not to make nuclear explosives.

description: A Second Visit

title: British Exhibitions Set For Chinese Gymnasts
description: LONDON, May 5 (AP)China is sending a gymnastics team to Britain to honor Queen Elizabeth IT's 25th anniversary on the throne. It will be the first appearance in Europe by team from the Republic of China.

title: Fluor Raises Its Offer for Shares of Daniel
description: The Fluor Corporation, after conferring with the Daniel International Corporation, announced yesterday that it had raised its cash tender offer for Daniel shares from $30 to $31.20. The offer begins today. At the new price, the Fluor offer for the 7.1 million outstanding shares of the large construction company will total about $221.5 million. Buck Mickel, chairman of Daniel, said that the board had not taken a position on the Fluor offer and that it fel? each shareholder should make his own decision. The company has furnished Fluor with a list of its stockholders.

title: The Bronx Is Up for a Salute to Arts and History
description: New York, New York, it's a wonderful town. The Bronx is up  And up and up and up.

title: Suspect in Killing of Rabbi's Son Ordered to Undergo Mental Tests
description: Lawrence Gordon, the parttime security guard charged with hurling the 8yearold son of a rabbi to his death from the roof of a sixstory apartment house in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn, has been ordered to Kings County Medical Center for psychiatric examination. The order followed his arraignment late Wednesday night.

title: M. A. C. AUTHORIZES NEW SALE OF BONDS
description: Responding to word that New York City was faltering in the drive to pay off its moratorium debt, the Municipal Assistance Corporation yesterday authorized a new sale of $100 Million in bonds including socalled MiniMac bonds in $50 and $100 denominationsto provide a cushion for the city's cash needs this year.

title: Recall of 2.7 Million Cars By Three Makers Weighed
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)Possible safety problems with 2.7 million Volkswagen, Ford and General Motors vehicles are being studied to determine whether recalls will be ordered, the Transporta tion Department said today.

description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)President Carter plans to answer questions from the public for about an hour during a oneday visit to California later this month, the White House says.

description: The Whittaker Corporation's coatings and chemicals group has introduced two waterborne coatings for beer can linings. The company said the coatings, called Aquaspray and Aquasize, are based on the first waterborne interior can coating system to pass a Federal Food & Drug Administration review.

description: TOKYO, May 5 (AP)Chairman Hua Kuofeng has toured the Soviet border region of northeastern China, where border clashes are often reported.

One is the first comprehensive exhibition of glass cut and engraved in Corning, N. Y.once dubbed America's crystal citywhich went on view there at the Corning Museum of Glass. The show

title: Cleveland Electric Gets Nuclear Plant Approval
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company has received permission from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to start aboveground construction of two nuclear power plants in North Perry Village, 35 miles northeast of Cleveland.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON. May 5The State Senate appealed to the New York State Legislature today to join in reauesting Congress to require the Federal Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers to halt dumping dredging, was tein the New York Bight.

title: Rain Delays Seattle Slew's Sprint as 15 Enter Derby
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 5They call it a frog strangler around here: rainstorm so fierce even the frogs can't survive.

title: Four Die as Plane Hits Street
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. May 5 (AP)Four persons were killed today when their small plane crashed and burned on a city street, the police said. The plane apparently ran out of fuel, but the cause of the crash was not certain, officials said. The passengers were not identified.

title: Sharp Rise in Money Supply
description: The nation's money supply in April grew at an annual rate of about 20 percent, well above the target range for the month. Analysts were mixed as to whether that indicated further increases in interest rates. Page D2.

title: Music: When Twice Is Enough
description: HE DA CAPO Chambers Players, a young group now in its seventh season, makes a practice of performing contemporary pieces twice on the same program. The term de capo, you may remember, is the musical instruction that directs players to repeat a work or a section of a work from the beginning, so the name is right to the point.

title: Toward Safer Matchbooks
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AM)The Consumer Product Safety Comm's sion issued regulations yesterday to make matchbooks safer, but the rules do not include a childproof matchbook, which drew some criticism when it was proposed as a consumer safety measure last summer.

title: House Bill Would Force A Rise in Crop Supports If U.S. Barred Exports
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)The Government would have to raise majorcrop price supports to the legal maximum it suspended export sales of the commodities, under a measure adopted today by the House Agriculture Committee.

title: New York Ends Cleanup And Repairs on Streets Under Federal Program
description: Federal funds for a spring campaign to repair and clean up the city's streets after an extremely cold winter ran out today and more than 800 workers, who were hired for the cleanup on a parttime basis will be removed from the payroll.

title: Soviets Lose to Apples And See a MiniProtest
description: Every day brings something new and exciting for the Soviet Union in World Team Tennis.

title: Technicolor Dividend
description: Technicolor Inc. declared a quarterly common dividend of 10 cents a share, the first paid by the company since June 26, 1970. The dividend is payable July 1 to stockholders of record June 1. The company said it intended to continue payment on a quarterly basis at an annual rate of 40 cents a share.

description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa. May 5 (AP)A Federal judge, saying that a shift of the Missouri River had caused a pathetic loss of and for the Omaha Indian Tribe of Nebraska, has still refused to grant nearly 3,000 acres to the tribe.

description: FRIDAY, MAY 6, 1977

title: The Rev. Cormac A. Walsh, 61; Highly Decorated in Korean Wai
description: The Rev. Cormac A. Walsh, a Franciscan priest and chaplain at Dannemore State Prison, Clinton, N.Y., since 1959, died of a heart attack Wednesday while visiting in Tampa, Fla. His age was 61.

title: Cey's Slam Helps Sink Mets by 72
description: LOS ANGELES, May 5 (AP)Ron Cey broke out of a weeklong slump with a grandslam home run to highlight a sevenrun fifth inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers completed a fourgame sweep of the Mets, 72.

title: Manes Assails Proposed Budget For Queens as Not Acceptable
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens, a longtime political ally of Mayor Beanie, denounced yesterday proposed allocations in the Mayor's budget for Queens as disgraceful and totally unacceptable.

title: State Tells Con Ed To Buy 2 Kilowatts From a Windmill
description: ALBANY, May 5Consolidated Edison, which had said it could not buy power from a 2kilowatt rooftop windmill because it was afraid surges might damage its 10millionkilowatt system, was ordered by the state today to buy the wind power anyway.

title: Art: Big Heads By Chuck Close
description: OU DON'T HAVE to have been in a Byzantine church (though it helps) to know that there is something peculiarly disquieting about a very big head. To be stared back at by eyeballs many times larger than our own is an experience that puts us in our place: and who better to do that than the Saviour of mankind?

title: C. DURYEA SMITH 3D, TEACHER OF DRAMA
description: Retired as Head of the Speech Department at Alfred University

title: Nixon, Who Seemed to Be Buckling, Was Given a 10Minute Time Out
description: Richard M. Nixon's aides called time out when he seemed to he, buckling under pressure in the David Frost interview, giving him time to collect his thoughts for his final monologue, a program aide disclosed yesterday.

title: $1.6 MILLION IN PAYMENTS DISCLOSED BY STUDEBAKER
description: WASHINGTON, May 5StudebakerWorthington Inc. has found that subsidiaries made $1.6 million in improper payments to obtain foreign business between January 1971 and February 1977, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Wholesale Prices Up 1 .1 % in April; 3d Surge in a Row Stirs Concern
description: WASHINGTON, May 5  Wholesale prices, generally a portent of prices at the retail level, rose at a doubledigit annual rate in April for the third consecutive month, sending new inflation tremors through the economy.

title: Aide Stays by Elderly Woman's Side While Pay Remains in Computer
description: Edna Walch, who had received no pay since Jan. 13 for her fulltime job as a home attendant for New York City's Human Resources Administration, will not be evicted from her apartment in the Jamaica section of Queens and will not have to apply for welfare.

title: The Court, the Port Authority and Transit
description: The Supreme Court provoked a tempest when it ruled that the Port Authority may not spend bond proceeds on rail mass transit because New York and New Jersey had told bond buyers it would not. Approving commentators say the decision will strengthen the municipal bond market because it holds public bodies to their promises. Opponents insist that the Court has blocked mass transit development in the region, posing major threats to its econoanic health. Both sides exaggerate.

title: At the Movies
description: D LOVE to play Caligula, said the poetically intense chap with the lean face, the searching eyes and the softly tousled brown hair. Camus's play is filled with passion. So is Henry Winkler as he peeps optimistically into his artistic future. It may not be so simple for fans of The Fonze on TV's Happy Days to picture their unflappably hip hero sloshing perversely about in maniacal scenes of rape, incest and murder. Still, Mr. Winkler, the earnest Yale Drama School graduate who astonished himself by flowering into a superstar as fingersnapping, ducktailed dropout of the 1950's, yearns to spread his wings in what's left of the 70's.

title: Walking the Ferry's Far Side
description: To many New Yorkers, Staten Island is that place where the ferry docks. And there are probably quite a few Staten Islanders, too, who would be surprised to hear that the island contains examples of important architecture as old as a 1640 stone farmhouse and as modern as a Frank Lloyd Wright home on Lighthouse Hill.

title: Canadiens Eliminate Islanders in 6th Game
description: UNIONDALE, LI., May 5For the third straight year, the New York Islanders National Hockey League season has ended in the semifinals of the playoffs. Tonight, the Montreal Canadiens eliminated them, 4 games to 2, with a 21 victory, Last year the Canadiens did it in five games.

title: P.L.O. Delegation Meets With Israeli Communists
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5Talks were held in Prague this week between a Palestine Liberation Organization delegation and representatives of Israel's Communist Party, according to Palestinian sources here, who described the meetings as the beginning of contacts by the P.L.O. with progressive Israelis who recognize the national rights of the Palestinians.

title: MacGregor Steps Down at Amax And Gousseland Succeeds Him
description: Ian MacGregor, one of the leaders of the nonferrous metals industry, conducted his last stockholders meeting yesterday as chief executive of Amax Inc. Mr. MacGregor, while remaining chairman until Oct. 1 when he reaches the mandatory retirement age of 65, said he was stepping down as chief executive.

title: CORRECTION

The Babcock and Wilcox facility involved is near Apollo, Pa.

title: The U.S. and the Splintering West
description: in the absence of some dramatic blow, continuity, not change, is generally desirable in foreign policy. But by now the splintering effects of the Western alliance can no longer be planed away. The economic disequilibriums within the European Community and the nolongerunthinkable fragmentation of the United Kingdom and Canada should force the United States to face up to the radically changed Atlantic alliance.

The hill, sponsored by 100 House members and approved 28 to 11, would create a new Federal agency to allocate $250 million a year in low inter est loans to nonprofit, consumerowned coops.

description: PORT HURON, Mich, May 5 (UPI)William H. Bailey, a Rhode Island Representativeelect, was jailed today after being flown to Michigan under police escort. Tomorrow he is to be transferred to Southern Michigan Prison to begin setrving a sentence for larceny.

There have been attempts from both camps to bridge the still very considerable gap between contemporary art music and the wilder shores of popular entertainment, with concerts by Peter Gordon at the Kitchen and some of the work of Brian Eno immediately coming to mind.

title: Notes on People
description: The outgoing chief of the United States Liaison Office in Peking, Thomas S. Gates Jr., was given a farewell informal dinner in the Great Hall of the People last night, and his host was China's Deputy Prime Minister, Li Hsiennien. The fact that Mr. Li ranks second as a state leader was seen as an indication that Peking places great importance on its relations with Washington. The 71yearold Mr. Gates has been in Peking for a year. President Carter is said to be considering Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, as Mr. Gates's successor.

description: OTTAWA, May 5An Ottawa newspaper reported today that one of its reporters had been approached by an officer of the security branch of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and asked to obtain information for him on the activities of four Soviet correspondents stationed here.

title: Brazil Increases Soybean Aid
description: BRASILIA, May 5 (UPI)The Brazilian Government today announced an increase in emergency credit for soybean seed pro. duction of (LOSS cents per 132 pounds. This brings the minimum price for 132 pounds of seeds to $15.77. The Government said the object of the credit increase was to keep Brazilian producers from selling their best seed in the international market,

title: McDonald's Sees Gains
description: Fred Turner, chairman of the McDonald's Corporation, told the annual meeting in Oak Brook, Ill., that the company expected a super year in 1977 with a nice increase in sales and earnings. In 1976, the fast food chain earned $110 million, or $2.72 a share, on revenues of $1.17 billion. Directors after the meeting raised the quarterly dividend to 5 cents from 2 cents a share.

title: Art: Anthony Caro Adds New Forms
description: OR SOME YEARS NOW, Anthony Caro has been widely recognized as the leading English sculptor of his generationhe was born in 1924and an artist of considerable influence on both sides of the Atlantic. His retrospective exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art two years ago, though it met with some criticisms, especially of the (then) most recent works, certainly confirmed this position of special eminence. His new show at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, 41 East 57th Street (through May 17), is likely to enhance his reputation still further. It is not often that we see work of this quality and ambition.

description: Cronyn, Tandy

title: ALBANY HALTS SYSTEM OF PRISON FURLOUGHS
description: ALBANY, May 5The Senate Committee on Crime and Corrections, responding to an angry attack on New York State's program of temporary release for inmates of correctional institutions, will withhold extension of the program pending an investigation of alleged abuses.

title: Swiss Voters Asked to Resolve Abortion Dispute
description: GENEVA, May 5The Swiss Parliament agreed today to ask the voters ??hether expectant mothers should be allowed to have abortions within the first three months of pregnancy.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: ERHAPS it's merely because INBC is in third place in the 197677 ratings race, behind ABC and CBS, but the network has been bubbling recently with assorted specials, some good, some dreadful, some just curious. Executives appear to have entered the we'll try anything phase of Drogrammine panic.

description: Italian Food Worth The Wait and French On the Modest Side

title: Police in Westchester Get an Armored Vehicle For Use in Siege Wdrh
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 5Westchester County police officials decided during the deadly siege in New Rochelle by Frederick Cowan, the Nazi sympathizer, last February that the county needed increased armoredvehicle protection.

title: Surveys Rank Program With Leading Series
description: Early ratings from four cities for David Frost's televised interview with former President Richard M. Nixon indicate that the Wednesday night telecast was the most watched news interview in the history of television and one of the highestrated news broadcasts ever.

title: Philadelphia Banker Favors a Loan To Schools if They Balance Budget
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (UPI)John Bunting says that the city's banks may be willing to bail out the financially troubled public schools if the school board shows it has learned a lesson.

title: State Dept., After a House Vote, Affirms Hanoi Will Get No Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 5The State Department pledged today once again that the United States would not offer any economic aid to Vietnam. The policy was affirmed after the House of Representatives, in a surprise move last night, voted to prohibit even the discussion of assistance to Hanoi.

title: ALBANY COURT ORDERS READING EXAMINATION
description: New York City's annual reading tests will he administered to 700,000 elementaryschool and juniorhighschool students this Tuesdaysix weeks later than originally scheduledunder stringent conditions imposed yesterday by the State Court of Appeals in Albany.

title: 3 TOP CARTER AIDES CONFER WITH SPEER ON PRICING OF STEEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 5Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, discussed steel costs, imports and price increases today with the Carter Administration's three senior economic policy makers.

title: Film: Civil Wrongs in Canada
description: "Les Orders," written and directed by Michel Brault, is an angry, beautifully acted French-Canadian film basedlike those of Costa-Gavrason an actual event. The time is October 1970, shortly after the kidnapping of a British-diplomat and a provincial cabinet minister by an urban guerrilla group calling itself the Quebec Liberation Front. The Canadian Government subsequently suspended civil liberties in Quebec arrested 450 people, few of whom apparently had anything to do want the kidnapping, and held them without charge, some for as long as several months.'Les Ordres" is not about French-Canadian liberation, though it clearly finds the English to be villains. Rather it's about the terrifying speed with which democratic processes can be liquidated and even more about the psychological effects of imprisonment.The film follows the case histories of five persons who had peripheral associations to politics  a union representative and his wife, a physician, an unemployed laborer and a social worker. Although only one man is tortured, by being made to endure what turns out to be a mock-execution, each of the victims is effectively traumatized through humiliation, fear and loss of identity.These scenes are harowing to watch, but one suspects that the director has loaded his dice. Would such treatment be condoned if the victim was known to be guilty? That question isn't answered, but because the characters in "Les Ordres" are presented as innocent, one wonders, whether the film's humanitarianism has its limits.Mr. Brault, who was the cameraman for Claude Jutra's "Mon Oncle Antoine" and "Kamouraska," is immensely good with his actors, none of whom is known to me, but he hasn't been able to resist some of the less interesting stylistic affectations of the day.These include the arbitrary switching back and forth between color and black and white, overlapping sound and terribly tedious, phony interludes in which the narrative is interrupted to have the actors talk about their roles. Ingmar Bergman got away with this once ("The Passion of Anna") and once turns out to have been enough."Les Ordres," which opened at the Film Forum yesterday, will be seen there through Sunday at 7:30 P.M. and repeated at the same hour next Thursday through Sunday.

title: Soviet Leads in Capital In Penalties f or Parking Not Paid by Embassies
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP)The Soviet Embassy in Washington has collected more unpaid parking tickets than any other embassy in town, with 12,270 as of March 31.

title: Mrs. Chesimard's Bid to Transfer To Another Prison Denied by Judge
description: TRENTON, May 5A Federal judge has denied a request by Joanne Chesimard who was convicted of killing a state trooper, for a transfer from the allmale Yardville Correction Center.

title: Corrections
description: In the recipe for okra gumbo that appeared in The Living Section Wednesday, the list of ingredients should have included a tolpound ham steak, cut in Iinch cubes. In the same recipe, 2 tablespoons of cider vinegar is the correct amount.

title: New Face: Charles Weldon
description: Charles Weldon, who plays the title role in the Negro Ensemble Company's production of The Great MacDaddy, has led a life as charmed, in its own circuitous way, as the life of MacDaddy himself. In Paul Carter Harrison's play, which is enjoying a successful run at the Theater De Lys, MacDaddy triumphs over starvation, racism and other deviltry despite his egocentric naivet. He's a black superhero, Mr. Weldon explains. He is naive, but he endures everything and comes through because he has the JuJu, the power.

title: Saturday
description: INSIDE THE ATOM ON L.I.

title: New Face: Michael Palin
description: Ghastly things happen to Michael Palin in the course of Jabberwocky, the hit British film comedy now at Cinema I. People pour garbageand worseon his head. Wildeyed religious fanatics lash him to a catapult and talk gleefully of what a splendid projectile he'll makeafter he's been set ablaze. A selfmaimed beggar offers him a partnership in the begging businessalong with a sharp knife. An armored knight drags him into battle against the most unspeakably horrible maneating dragon ever to ravage the countryside of medieval England. Muddling through it all, his only defense a beamish smile, Mr. Palin manages to create one of the most likable movie dunderheads to come along since the heyday of Danny Kaye.

title: Unfriendly Mayoral Race Is Straining the Ties of a CloseKnit Hoboken:
description: HOBOKEN, May 5All over this milesquare riverfront city, campaign signs hang from windows and storefronts urging either the reelection on Tuesday of Mayor Steven Cappielio or the election of Anthony H. Romano, a City Councilman who is leading an insurgent move against the Mayor's organization.

description: ENTRIES

title: This Summit Counts
description: Jimmy Carter's first trip abroad as President takes him to several meetings, but the critical one is the third economic summit of the democratic world's principal industrial powers. Twothirds of the world's production, trade and monetary reserves will be represented when the President sits down in London with the chiefs of government of Japan, Canada and the main Common Market countriesBritain, West Germany, France and Italy. How their power is managed in the coming months can determine their political as well as economic fortunes.

title: Lillian Kemble Cooper, Singer In Broadway Shows in 20's, 30's
description: Lillian Kemble Cooper, who was a leading singer in a number of Broadway shows, many in the 1920's and 1930's, died Wednesday in a Los Angeles hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: ExC.1. A. Employee Convicted of. Trying To Sell Secret Data
description: BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP)A, Federal jury today convicted a former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, Edwin G. Moore 2d, of stealing secret documents and trying to sell them to the Soviet Union.

title: Books: A Fading Vision
description: SIMPLICITY IN WRITING is a hardwon virtue and one not always prized in novelwriting these days. Put it down to Hemingway's having been done to death, to the lingering reverberations of the Henry James revival in academe, to the belief that anything simple either lacks profundity or sufficient inscrutability to give the appearance of profundity. The causes don't matter; what I am really here for is to praise Jonathan Penner's new novel, of which simplicity, clarity and lucidity are among the virtues.

title: People in Sports
description: At noon today, Duane Bobick and Ken Norton will hold a ropeskipping contest in front of Madison Square Garden on Seventh Avenue for the benefit of cystic fibrosis. Yesterday, they traded insults at a Garden luncheon.

title: Bonn Chancellery Worker Held as Spy Suspect
description: BONN, May 5 (Renters)West German Government officials said today that secretary who had worked in Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's offices for the last 17 months had been detained on suspicion of being a spy for East Germany.

title: Bridge: Strongest Pairs Tournament On Tonight at Cavendish Club
description: The world's strongest pairs tournament begins tonight at the Cavendish Club, 680 Madison Avenue, when the players assemble for the preliminaries of the annual Cavendish Invitational. Play begins in earnest tomorrow, and the winners will be known late Sunday night.

title: Now In New York
description: Tradition is the key word this Sunday down at Luchow's Restaurant. The venerable landmark is planning its 95th Mother's Day tribute to all those fantastic ladies who have helped turn us all into the marvelous, adorable creatures we are today. The main dining room will be done up in traditional Old World style, and the menu will be featuring those traditional Mittel European specialties that have earned Luchow's a worldwide reputation for gastronomic excellence. But the highlight of this Sunday's celebration is that each family's first child will have a free Mother's Day dinner, courtesy of. Luchow's. There are no raffles involved, no lucky numbers to draw, no special people to knowjust join the celebration by 2 PM this Sunday and you can take advantage of

title: Female Designer Originals Make Their Mark on Fashion
description: Some of the most inventive, individuallooking clothes being turned out at the moment are designed by women. All over the world, women are making an imprint on fashion far stronger than they did, say, 10 years ago.

title: Bill to Aid Crime Victims Backed
description: WASHINGTON, May 5 (UPI)The. Carter Administration today endorsed legislation for Federal reimbursement to states that compensate victims of violent crimes but recommend that the maximum payment be $20,000 rather than the $50,000 now under consideration.

Marquard, president, also told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Wilmington that directors raised the quarterly dividend to 421/2 cents from 37 cents, marking the second increase this year. The latest rise is payable June 24 to holders of record May 24.

title: It Was Canadiens

But the miracle worker of the Islanders precarious 1975 playoff season found himself without miracles against the Montreal Canadiens.

The company's current theater piece is a natural progression: A Thousand Nights and a Night, based on the Scheherazade tales better known as The Arabian Nights. The show runs through May 22 at the Theater of the Open Eye on the Upper East Side.

description: New York City's first fiscal crisis  or the first one in what now is New York City  occurred more than 300 years ago, when British traders from New England gained control of wampum production on Long Island and forced the Dutch colony on Manhattan Island, which used the Indianmade beads as money, into economic ruin.

title: Dow Up 2.72 as Stocks Advance Despite Rise in Wholesale Prices

title: The Trial of Richard Nixon and of America
description: The judge: He was not the Chief Justice, not a Congressional committee chairman, not even an American. The moral magistrate of Richard Nixon's guilt was, finally, a British journalist who, like the defendant, stood to gain great profit from the trial. Still, despite advance fears of mushy deference, David Frost played his role boldly, even brilliantly. Admit, he exhorted this epic figure. Apologize!

description: ZURICH, May 5 (AP)Fritz Leutwiler. president of the Swiss National Bank, said today that the Credit Suisse Bank scandal pointed to Inc need for increased surveillance of incoming foreign capital.

title: Crampton Quits Rigor of Golf Tour
description: DALLAS, May 5The professional golf tour, most of whose members are grimfaced or morose on the course, lost today the matt who for 20 years carried the reputation as the most peevish of them all. One of his regrets, he said in parting, was that he could not be more outgoing or relaxed.

The antiboycott resolution was presented by a Houston attorney, E. Stanley Topek. He represented Alexandar Altschuler, John Bass, Robert S. Long, Stephen B. Narin, Evelyn H. Osterweil and Frank A. Sanders, all of New York, who offered their resolution on behalf of the American Jewish Congress.

For President Carter, with relish and nostalgia, turned today's goodwill visit to this green but grimy corner of industrial Britain into something closely resembling the thousands of campaign stops he made in a long American political contest.

description: ENTRIES

title: Seattle Slew at Center Stage: Today the Object Is Roses
