Or we can examine the frailties and excesses of people in power. Each of these books offers a different method of looking at American social and political life. After reading all of them I found myself amazed that they were all talking about the same society.

title: Susan Peet Bride Of Richard Miller
description: Susan Graves Peet of New York and Richard Nolan Miller of Bloomfield, N.J., were married yesterday afternoon in Bloomfield. Msgr. Vincent P. Coburn performed the ceremony in St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church.Mark H. Peet and the late Fanny Carr P

title: With Few in His Corner, King Urges U.S. Ring Study
description: Don King, the promoter who is up against the ropes because of the latest boxing scandal, called yesterday for a fullscale Federal investigation for the good of boxing into the charges of fixed or rigged fights, falsified records and the kind of kickbacks that made him wobbly in the first place.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MAY 8, 1977

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: REPUBLIC STEEL and Youngstown Sheet and Tube raised the price of hot rolled and cold finished steel products by 6.5 percent, effective May 15. The Council on Wage and Price Stability called the increase excessive ... Wholesale prices rose 1.1 percent In April, the same increase as in March, the Labor Department reported. At the end of April the Wholesale Price Index stood at 194.3 percent unadjusted of the 1967 average, up 8 percent from 181.3 in April 1976... Unemployment In April fell to 7 percent of the work force from 7.3 percent a month earlier...

title: Mt. Vernon Sets Bait for Baseball
description: MOUNT VERNON, which has attempted to brighten its image with sloganeering Mount Vernon, more than a city  with an aggressive campaign to rehabilitate its downtown area and with an ambitious development plan for office and hotel facilities, is now turning to baseball as another ingredient in its recipe for urban revitalization.

title: The Man Behind the Megahotels
description: SEATTLEThe Olympic Hotel penthouse, although converted into offices, still suggests the opulence of a bygone era: terracotta fireplaces, a secret room behind a walnut library panel that hid spirits during Prohibition, vases of fresh flowers reflected in baroque mirrors.

title: A Reply to Turquoise Erving
description: I read Turquoise Erving's article (Regrets of a Player's Wife, March 13) with interest and appreciation for her feelings and thoughts. She sounded as if she really cared, too, especially for her husband, as we all do about our husbands, We have all suffered with them through their agonies and hurts, both physically and mentally.

title: Power, Politics And the Executive
description: THIS IS a key political year in the county, with Alfred B. DelBello, the first Democratic County Executive, seeking a second term, and all 17 members of the Republicancontrolled Board of Legislators also up for reelection. The election itself, and the somewhat frayed relations between executive and legislature, with its nine Republicans and eight Democrats, that are developing as campaigns begin, will serve to focus increasing attention on the nature of Westchester government and on the role of the County Executive.

title: France Can't Forget Its Special Mission
description: PARISThe last French colony in Africa, Djibouti, is about to gain independence, but France remains at least as involved on the continent as it was before the decolonization boom of the late 1950'searly 60's. It is a deliberate policy that contrasts with Britain's withdrawal and the United States cautious reserve.

title: Spring weekend Along the Potomac
description: Energy crises, diplomatic brushfires, Congressional bickering. It may simply be the price Washington pays for being the seat of governmentor, as critics charge, It may be a function of how journalists define news. But the words and images that flow from the nation's capital are downers.

title: Defying Demographics
description: Lady Madonna is not alone in apparently defying the demographics of a declining birth rate. Michael O'Dowd, a merchandise coordinator at the New York buying office of Frederick Atkins, says that maternity sales to 20 stores across the country have been tremendous.

title: Growing Up a Lindbergh
description: Reeve Lindbergh Brown, the youngest Lindbergh child, was burn in 1915. Radcliffeeducated, she lives with her husband, Richard Brown, in Vermont. where she is leaching school and raising two daughters. In her spare time, she writes short stories; a collection will be published by Doubleday. Like her Britt hers and sistersJon, Land. Anne and ScottReeve Brown prefers to live unostenlatiously and inconspicuously. Recently, she answered Alden Whitman's questions one day while visit ing her mother's house in Connecticut.

title: A Race Track That Had Class
description: THEY used to complain about the traffic along Route 70, and now they complain about the lack of it. The Garden State Race Track is gone, and the merchants, politicians and taxpayers of this uppermiddleincome community miss it even more than the horse players.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE greatest enemy of brick walls, chimneys and other structures made of brick is waterthat is, water that penetrates the surface through crumbling mortar joints, cracked or missing bricks and similar defects.

title: Combined Copter Pilot Training Seen Saving Pentagon $104 Million
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)A new Pentagon study recommending consolidating of military helicopter training at a single Army base predicts the move could result in savings of nearly $104 million over five years.

title: Grand Juries: Where to Now?
description: BOTH the New Jersey Supreme Court's Criminal Practices Committee and the State Bar Association are now supporting the abolition of grand jury proceedings in most criminal cases. Instead, a minitrial would take place in open court, with both sides' lawyers present to offer witness testimony and to crossexamine opposing witnesses. It seems likely that this important decision will be made by the voters through a Constitutional amendment.

title: The Nation
description: Two key statistics reported last week serve as a reminder that the United States remains in the strange economic state it has been in for most of the last decade, with inflationary pressures strong and unemployment stubbornly high.

title: Italy to Open Liceo in New York For Its Nationals and Americans
description: The Liceo Italiano, a school for the children of the growing number of Italians temporarily in New York City, will open this September under Italian Government auspices, Consul General Alessandro Cortesede Bosis announced yesterday

title: RCA Homebody Roams the World to Help Keep the President in Touch
description: I really am a homebody. I mean I live out on Long Island, and the farthest afield I've ever taken my wife on vacation is Montauk Point and somewhere in Pennsylvania, says Robert Mollenhauer.

title: Friends of Central Park Oppose Plan to Renovate Wollman Rink
description: The Friends of Central Park, conducting one of its periodic walking tours of the park, said yesterday that a plan for the renovation of the Wollman Rink would irreversibly damage the natural character.

title: MAILBAG
description: There is something very disturbing about Walter Goodman's The Artist and the PoliticianNatural Antagonists? [April 24], respectable as his essay may seem in its defense of artistic freedom and its classification of the artist as a higher species on the scale of evolution. His construction of society is to the human condition as the game of Monopoly to economics; surely, there exists no such unpolitical or apolitical world for the true artist to live in. That was a 19thcentury illusion, still clung to by our liberals, the illusion of vacuum in which we can pursue our quests for truth and beauty. When we write or paint in peace, this is because of political actions here and worldwide. The glory of Rembrandt was paid for, in a way, by the slave trade of the Dutch East India Company; an audience of connoisseurs could afford and appreciate Diaghilev because Algerian villages were being burned down and natives were tapping rubber at ten centimes a day. There is a connection, and our ivory or wooden towers are erected on and

title: DINING OUT
description: SAN FRANCISCO. The name fairly quivers with appetizing vibrations. Can anyone east of the Rockies resist a restaurant that advertises San Francisco cuisine? Well, almost. Especially if you know that most of the recipes have grown iust a bit tired after 20 years of toofaithful service.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Mike Marshall, who lives in East Lansing, Mich., has not reported to his new club, the Texas Rangers, saying he would prefer to play somewhere in the Midwest, closer to home. Somewhere like Detroit? he was asked. That's too close, he replied.

title: Better Days Ahead for Glamour Stocks?
description: The bigname growth stocks, the high fliers of four years ago, are thudding to earth these days like so many clay pigeons. The selling pressure conies mainly from pension funds and other huge investors caught redfaced with portfolios bulging with issues once fabled as the Nifty Fifty.

title: Deborah Archibald Is Married
description: Deborah Archibald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Archibald of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday morning to Michael Gorney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Gorney of Buffalo. Msgr. Edward M. Connors performed the ceremony in the chapel of Good Counsel Academy, the College of White Plains. The bride is a graduate of Marymount College in Arlington, Va., and her husband graduated from St. Vincent's College. Latrobe, Pa.

title: The State's Congressmen And What They Think of Each Other
description: IT'S almost like being asked to vote for your motherinlaw, one participant said wryly. The question before the Houseor rather, before the 15 members of the House from New Jersey was a simple one. It called for putting aside rivalry and selecting the state's most effective members of Congress. One rule, of course, was that a Representative could not vote for himself.

title: Trial by Television?
description: WASHINGTONBut for Gerald R. Ford's pardon, Richard M. Nixon might have been obliged to answer Wednesday night's $600,000 questions for free, in a court of ]aw. Nixon's trial by television, a bizarre, uniquely American spectacle, was not the real McCoy, but did demonstrate that the former President has no credible defense to the Watergate evidence against him.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: Refuting an idea that goes back to Thomas Jefferson and other 18thcentury detractors of city life, a new study finds that mental health is better in cities than in small towns and rural areas.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: John PopeHennessy is consultative chairman of the department of European paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Arts and Leisure Guide
description: I WAS SITTING ON MY PATIO THIS GUY APPEARED I THOUGHT I WAS HALLUCINATINGA twoact, twocharacter play performed and codirected by Lucinda Childs and Robert Wilson. Written by Mr. Wilson, with music by Alan Lloyd. Cherry Lane, 38 Commerce St. (YU 92020) Opens Tues.

title: The Standings
description: Sunday, May 8, 1977

title: Father of Claimant To Spanish Throne Dies in Switzerland
description: CHUR, Switzerland, May 7 (Reuters)Prince Xavier of BorbnParma, 88yearold head of the Carlist family of pretenders to the Spanish throne, died here today, a family spokesman said.

title: Olympian Task of Unity Is Being Tackled by U.S.O.C.
description: The United States Olympic Committee concluded its quadrennial meeting in Colorado Springs last weekend with an optimistic outlook for the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow.

title: JAWORSKI SAYS NIXON DIDN'T ADMIT ENOUGH
description: Leon Jaworski, who was the Watergate special prosecutor when Richard M. Nixon resigned the Presidency, believes that Mr. Nixon made insufficient admissions in his first television interview with David Frost.

title: World Leaders Walking in Step On Way to Lunch in London
description: LONDON, May 7St. James's Park, which runs from Buckingham Palace to the Horse Guards Parade, was laid out as a deer park by Henry VIII and converted into a pleasure gardenwith an aviary, a tranquil pond and a series of footpathsby Charles II.

title: General Stores Live On
description: THE American general store is pretty much a thing of the past. The monuments to its passing, ironically, are wellintentioned reproductions aimed at the touristreplicas of oldtime shops, outfitted with brand new antiqued wood, carefully chosen calicos and barrels of oldfashioned candy.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YOU'LL never fully realize how appreciated you are by those who have never met you until you move to a suburb or from one to another. Even before the new sheetrock had settled on the old plastered walls, before the pine floors had taken to their final coat of polyurethane magic, an address book filled with names of local merchants had arrived in our morning mail. It came from Getting To Know You, a postal version of the familiar Welcome Wagon that draws up to your house or apartment and greets you with cheery neigborliness, lots of helpful hints, loads of coupons, discounts and plastic pens.

title: MRS. RODOLFO MICHELS
description: Lily Michels, the wife of the late Rodolfo Michels, Chile's Ambassador to the United States from 1940 to 1944, died Friday at her home in Middlebury, Conn. She was 80 years old. Mrs. Michels is survived by a daughter, Cristina Tencher; a son, Rodolfo, and six grandchildren. Her husband died 12 years ago.

title: A Learning Role for Retarded
description: THERE'S a small luncheon spot in Levittown that has emerged as the in place for midday meals and business lunching. The eatery, known as Center Six, does business only one day a week, just for a luncheon crowd, and reservations are a must.

title: GARDENING
description: PLANTING a garden is fun. There is something about turning over the soil, tucking in young plants or seeds and watching them grow. Now, while the planting season is at its height, many new homeowners are getting near their soil for the first time. What they used to call dirt becomes something rather special. What is more, it is alive.

title: Seeking the Emotions That Stirred The Ancient Greeks
description: In a dingy rehearsal hall near the Bowery, 29 actors are scatteredsinging, chanting, and intoning in time to rhythms clapped out by composer Elizabeth Swedes and watched closely by director Andrei Serban. A few of the men shriek ominously like vultures; a cluster of women wail their woe in sobbing vowels. Other members of the chorus speak sometimes in verse, sometimes in song, sometimes in syncopated rhythms. Strange elongated oos, grs, and trs, soft sliding shs, and triggerlike consonants reverberate through the room to produce a combination of sounds from another time and another worldthe mythic world of the primordial Greeks, as expressed in the classic tragedy of Agamemnon by Aeschylus.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: In Making a Caesarean Birth, by Rita E. Watson (March 6), considerable attention was paid to making the Caesarean section experience more meaningful for the family through a repeat Caesarean section. While I agree that this is a necessary and positive step forward in handling patients for a repeat Caesarean section, I do believe both your writer, and the people she quotes, missed a major pont.

title: For the Fort Greene Merchants Who Stayed: Vindication
description: Millie Mandy's little Italian ices store has the green, red and white colors of Italy in its striped awning and festive strings of little colored flags flapping overhead.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: Saturday, May 7. 107th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: Managing Headache
description: Sometimes I just keep throwing up, the pain is so bad. Sometimes 1 pound my head on the wall. At times I've thought of boring holes in my head. I get so nauseated I can't take my pills. I hate taking pills al any time. Some days I just hold one in my hand and stare at it for 10 minutes, says Yvonne Wilson, a pretty, 30yearold artist and writer who has been afflicted with migraine headaches since her teens.

title: Alexandra T. Lally Is Married
description: Alexandra Teresa Lally, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lally of New York, was married yesterday afternoon at the meeting house of the New York Society for Ethical Culture to Frederick Warburg Peters. He is a son of C. Brooks Peters of Dallastown, Pa., and Mrs. Philip Farley of New York and Bedford, N.Y.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: EARTHLY POSSESSIONS By Anne Tyler. 200 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $7.95.

title: 19 Killed in Soviet Train Crash
description: MOSCOW, May 7 (Reuters)  Nineteen people died when two passenger trains collided In Byelorussia on Monday. The Minsk daily Sovetskaya Belorussiya said the trains had crashed at Krizhovka, about 400 miles southwest of Moscow.

title: AROUND THE  Garden
description: That homespun wisdom on vegetable gardening that comes over the PBS channels as Crockett's Victory Garden is now in book form. James Underwood Crockett, TV's own garden sage, has organized' tile planter's year in a handsome tome published by Little, Brown and Co., $17.50 hardcover; $9.95 paperback. His informal style pervades with appealing downtoearth pointers.

title: Lucinda Lee Myatt Married To John Cravenho in Bay State
description: Lucinda Lee Myatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Myatt of Boston, was married yesterday evening to John Cravenho, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Cravenho of West Dennis, Mass.

title: Annie Harris Married to Andrew Lippman
description: Annie Clay Harris of Lexington Mass., an architect and cityplanner, was married yesterday to Andrew Benjamin Lippman of Boston. Dean Ernest Gordon of the Princeton University Chapel performed the Presbyterian ceremony in the chapel.

title: GARDENING
description: IT is doubtful that the flowering crab apples have ever been more spectacular than they were this year. Weather conditions must have been ideal last June when the buds for this year's flowers were formed.

title: Events Today
description: Sixth Annual City Island Outdoor Art & Craft Festival music, artworks, crafts, clowns; 11 A.M. to 10 P.M.; City Island, The Bronx.

title: Headliners
description: After five days of freedom, Hugh J. Addonizio, the former Mayor of Newark, has been forced to return to jail. Mr. Addonizio was sentenced to a tenyear term in 1970 for his involvement in a scheme with organized crime figures to arrange kickbacks on some city contracts. Last month, the Federal judge who had presided over the case ordered Mr. Addonizio freed, because he said he had never intended for the former mayor to spend more than a third of the sentence in prison. But the United States Attorney's of fice immediately moved to have him returned to jail, maintaining that only the parole board, and not a judge, had the right to grant a prisoner's release. A Federal appeals court ordered Mr. Addonizio returned to prison pending a ruling on the Government's motion. Mr. Addonizio has served five years and two months of his sentence; he will be eligible for parole in eight months.

title: The Hostess of Yaddo
description: ONE late spring afternoon in the 20's George Foster Peabodythe distinguished philanthropist and financierguided a young widow from Minneapolis named Elizabeth Ames through the damps of the vast Spencer Trask mansion in Saratoga Springs, One can imagine the whole scene; the chill in the countless rooms, the dry fountain in the atrium, the baptismal fonts and the throne chairs covered with sheets. When a beam of light caught Mrs. Ames's lovely face Mr. Peabody decided that it was she who had been chosen to administer a curious last will and testament that named creative men and women the heirs to this kingdom. They were both, I imagine, too highminded to think this scene fanciful and preposterous. Later that afternoon at tea in Mr. Peabody's house he presented Mrs. is Ames with The Trask Pearls. This was a fat cable's of small beads with an enormous diamond saddlebuckle and a pair of diamond tassels. The beads were to signify his choice and her acceptance of the job, Mr. Peabody's splendid manners and the heavy pearls may have graced the hard facts of this contract, but were these: Elizabeth had agreed to channel the income from a milliondollar portfolio into the maintenance of a turnofthecentury castle for the benefit of artists, writers and composers.

title: TV Commercials on a Shoestring
description: MAMMOTH corporations can afford to spend thousands of dollars a second to produce a commercial for primetime network television. But what happens when a local retail business with a limited advertising budget wants to send a message out on the airwaves?

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: NEW Jersey's five largest cities Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Elizabeth and Trentonhave had a combined popula tion loss of more than 79,000 since 1970, according to newly released figures from the Census Bureau.

title: Penn Depth Wins Heptagonals Track
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7  James Brown, who seemed to be everywhere at once, led the University of Pennsylvania to its seventh straight team championship in the 43d Heptagonal track and field championships at Franklin Field today. Penn won with 66 points, followed by Army with 51 and Cornell with 46.

title: How Nassau Employees Got Organized
description: MINEOLA IRVING FLAUMENBAUM concedes that he is overweight at 250 pounds from eating too many chicken and roastbeef dinners on the banquet circuit in his 22 years as the president of the Nassau County chapter of the Civil Service Employees Association. But he may lose some weight now that he has decided not to run for reelection.

title: Anne Tyler, Writer 8:05 to 3:30
description: TWO plus nine is eleven, carry the one, Mrs. Anne Tyler Modarressi says she bends over 9yearold Mitra and her math paper. I don't think you should write down the one you carry it's too confusing. Used cereal bowls and signs of school lunches already packed are scattered around the kitchen. Dinner is in the oven, but morning tea is still brewing as Mitra and her older sister Tezh slam the front screendoor on their way to school. It's 8 A.M.

title: $5 Million Found Hidden in Home Of Slain Heiress in Indianapolis
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 7 (AP)  A wealthy recluse was found shot to death today in her home here, and the police discovered more than $5 million in cash stuffed in trash cans, drawers and tool boxes.

title: A Year Off
description: ANUMAL MEXICO AT 1 A.M. last July 1, a sleek, white Boles Aero trailer pulled by a small camper edged out of Mario Lane in Hauppauge. Its occupants, Penny and Eugene Famighetti and their three children, Mitchell, 14, Lori, 11, and Craig, 6, had taken a year off to travel through the United States, Mexico and, they hoped, into South America.

title: Crusader for Camp Safety
description: MITCH KURMAN would rather go fishing on weekends as he used to do with his 15yearold son, David, but he can't because he is driven by the memory of a personal tragedy. Nearly 12 years ago his son was drowned on a canoeing trip in Maine while attending a summer camp.

title: A Showplace That's on how Again
description: WINFIELD Hall, the former country residence of Frank Winfield Woolworth in Glen Cove, will be open to the public for the first time tomorrow.

title: A New Environment
description: WASHINGTON. When the Carter Administration's elaborate screening machinery began sitting thousands of job applications last fall, one name never got into the hopper: Cecil D. Andrus, Governor of Idaho. The reason is simple: Jimmy Carter had already decided he wanted Cecil Andrus to he his Secretary of the Interior. The two first met in 1970, when they were both Governors, and, Carter remembers, We hit it off from the start. Now, Jimmy publicly calls Cecil my good friend.

title: Recent Rains Brighten Outlook for Corn Belt Crops
description: AMES, Iowa, May 5Farm experts in the Middle West have become cautiously optimistic this week about the chances for an end to the drought in the Corn Belt.

title: Music: Fervent Ninth in Brooklyn
description: If their fervent performance of Beethoven's Ninth on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music is a fair indication of how Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonia are faring these days, they are faring very well indeed.

title: The Eternal Senior Prom
description: WE were looking at the sky one day and it was such a pretty blue, I decided that was the color tuxedo I was going to wear. Cathy hasn't decided the color of her dress yet, but it's going to be something that won't clash, like maroon.

title: Patricia Xeller Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. August J. Xeller of Levittown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Xeller, to Richard Alan Steyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Steyer of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Jazz: Four Guitarists Solo in Jam
description: The prospect of a Guitar Jam with George Benson, Les Paul, Bucky Pizzarelli and Gabor Szabo might suggest an evening of freewheeling giveandtake among the four guitarists. But in the actual eventa concert in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday eveningit did not turn out that way.

title: Melinda Doubleday Wilson Engaged to William Fuller
description: Mrs. Donald Stanton Wilson of Bronxville and Ticonderoga, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Melinda Doubleday Wilson, to William Brewster Fuller, son of Mrs. Stanley Saunders Raymond of Short Hills, N. J., and North Stamford, Conn. The wedding is planned for August.

title: From Farms To Mansion
description: Frank Winfield Woolworth, the fiveanddime tycoon, was born in 1852 on a farm near Rodman, N.Y., owned by his uncle and maintained by his parents.

title: Terese Treman Ross Bride of Joseph Williams
description: St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Terese Treman Ross of Greenwich to Joseph Hill Williams of Tulsa, Okla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard F. Van Wely.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: There are some buildings that the world watches and some buildings that the profession watches, and one of the most watched by architects right now is the Bronx Developmental Center by Richard Meier and Associates  the recently constructed addition to the Bronx State Hospital complex adjacent to the Hutchinson River Parkway. It is also a building very much in the news because of the Willowbrook scandals and lawsuits; commissioned seven years ago for the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene by the State's Facilities Development Corporation, the new facility will receive a part of the Willowbrook population.

title: 3 Horses Are Winners In 2 Divisions of Carter
description: Not everybody in horse racing went to Churchill Downs yesterday. The sport was well represented at Aqueduct by the 77th running of the venerable Carter Handicap, by a legendary English jockey champion from Australia who now trains a substantial stable here for a shipping magnate from India, by perhaps the best horse in Norwegian history and by Steve Cauthen.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Ken Norton will oppose Duane Bobick in a 12round heavyweight fight Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, where boxing, according to Mike Burke in the corporate tower, is alive and well and living cleanly. Not that cleanly. On redandyellow showcards all over town Duane Bobick is advertised as the Unbeaten Heavyweight Contender Rated No. One in the World. If the Ku Klux Klan rated boxers, Duane Bobick, as the leading white heavyweight, surely would be listed as the No.1 contender for Muhammad Ali's title. But most boxing people consider Duane Bobick to be the No. 4 contender, behind Jimmy Young, George Foreman and Ken Norton.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: A recent letter [April 3] insisted that the recent limitations on earned income for Congressmen would make me a better Congressman and Representative. With this I must disagree.

title: Not Surprisingly, Its Reasons Are Largely Economic
description: CARACAS, VenezuelaThe Carter Administration's linkage of human rights to other economic and political issues, repeated last week at a hemispheric conference in Guatemala by Andrew Young, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, has provoked irritation in many Latin American countries. An important exception, however, is Venezuela, which for its own reasons has endorsed President Carter's concerns.

title: Latin Art Song Heart of Recital By Eva de la O
description: Eva de la O's song recital Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall amounted to a minisurvey of Latin art song in this century, with works by nine composers from eight countries (Spain was represented twice). For those who might expect such a traversal to be overweighted with folksy fluff, it turned out to be an evening full of variety. But sometimes the best pieces as with a group of Seven Popular Songs at the end by Manuel de Fallawere those that most openly reveled in their folk inspirations.

title: A Tonsorial Guide for Men
description: Women are not apt to have their hair cut overseas. Men are, by all accounts, braver. I never miss an opportunity to have my hair cut in a foreign country, says an oil company executive who traveled more than 100,000 miles last year. Sure, I've had barbers who ruined my hair. So, it grows again. In Marrakesh, I sat on a rickety stool in an outdoor bazaar. Kids scampered around my feet. A vendor peddled peanuts to me. Some fellow who spoke a few words of English came over to practice them. I wasn't Just on an old barber's stoolI was seated on the pulse of Morocco.

title: CAREY VOW ON CUOMO IS A SHOCK TO BEAME
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that he was dumbstruck by Governor Carey's reported decision to support Mario M. Cuomo through the November election even if Mr. Cuomo did not win the Democratic primary in September.

title: Banks, Unions Form Alliance To Assist City
description: A couple of years ago, two of the most influential men in New York City Walter Wriston, the aristocratic chairman of Citicorp, and Jack Bigel, the toughtalking consultant to the ??nicipal labor unionshardly knew each other. More recently, they got acquainted, but were barely on speaking terms. Today, the two men have brought in their colleagues in an extraordinary display of cooperation to create an independent base of influenceindependent, that is, of City Hallwith potentially farreaching implications for local, and perhaps even national, politics.

title: OTB Payoffs
description: Bettors at 156 parlors in the New York Offtrack Betting Corporation's separate pool on the Derby received payoffs very similar to those at the track. Seattle Slew returned $3 for win, $3 to place and $3 to show.

title: Growth Slowing Black Exodus From the Rural South
description: MENDENHALL, Miss., May 6For more generations than the blacks of southcentral Mississippi can remember, May has always been the cruelest month.

title: Fragmenting Children
description: At least 100,000 and perhaps 300,000 children with no families are in foster homes or institutions in this country waitingin most cases hopelesslyfor adoption. Incredibly enough, nobody knows for sure how many such children there are, which suggests the lack of organization and cooperation in the field.

title: Razing a Witness to Time
description: THE BRANCH AN old English barn that had withstood time, tempest and termites for 250 years has finally succumbed here. the victim of virulent historical preservation.

title: Ed Cole: A Dashing G. M. General Who Fought Big Battles
description: Not too many years ago Detroit's great ones were like dashing combat generals, leading their designers and salesmen in colorful charges against the enemy across town: George Romney, Robert S, McNamara Lee A. Iacocca, Semon E, (Bunkie) Knudsen. Their cars were a part of their personalities.

title: Karen Augusta Worden Wed to David Anderson
description: Karen Augusta Worden and David William Anderson were married yesterday by the Rev. John T. Galloway in the Chestnut Grove Presbyterian Church in Phoenix, Md.

title: Oil and Gas Reserves: Figures Open To Question
description: WASHINGTONIf we are asking sacrifices of ourselves, we need facts we can count on, President Carter told a joint session of Congress two weeks ago when he unveiled his energy program. The statement demonstrated that one of the principal energy issues has been the amount of oil and gas the United States and other countries have left in the ground.

title: Doctor Fills McGinnis's Order
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 7From the very beginning, George McGinnis was in on the deal that brought Julius Erving to the 76ers.

title: Swastikas in Retaliation
description: LESS a testament to the frivolity of evil than to the evil consequences of frivolity, Unity Mitford's life is well worth this quest undertaken by the British journalist David PryceJonesalthough, in the final analysis, the journey has proved to matter more than the arrival. One of the celebrated Mitford sisters who have left their marks on 20thcentury literature and politics, Unity unwittingly personified what Samuel Hynes has called the furious theologies of the 1930's, a decade when contemporaries were propelled to extremes in pursuit of moral certainties. Democracy, conspicuously lacking in dynamism, was written off as wet by the jeunesse d'ore of the age. PryceJones doubtless exaggerates when he considers Unity emblematic of them. But his fundamental point is well taken.

title: Lauren L. Gill Is Married to David Hemphill
description: Lauren Leinbach Gill and David Van Scoyoc Hemphill were married yesterday by the Rev. Norman Catir in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York.

title: Remedial Reading by
description: AT FIRST glance it seems to be simple, oldfashioned method of teaching, dating back to colonial days, with its emphasis on drill, phonics and reading aloud. But on further investigation the remedialreading program at the Marion Batchelder Learning Center in Bridgeport seems closer to the Space Age.

title: The 1927 Yankees: The Best Then and Still the Best
description: Those who know little about either like to see parallels between war and sports. Nonsense, of course. The only similarity, and it is a faint one, lies in the tendency of the military and the fan to perpetuate the memories of great figures.

title: In County Basement, Artists at Work
description: THERE are no hobbyists here, said John Ruddley, director of the Westchester Art Workshop. This is a real, honesttogoodness art school. Mr. Ruddley was speaking about the 50yearold workshop tucked away in the basement of the Westchester County Center in White Plains.

title: RHODESIA SAYS GUERRILLAS KILLED SEVEN MISSIONARIES
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 7An Inquest in Rhodesia has ruled that the seven white missionaries who were killed by rifle and machinegun fire on Feb. 7 were shot by black guerrillas, as the sole survivor, the Rev. Dunstan Mysercough, reported at the time.

title: 5 Provinces Oppose Quebec Trade Ties After independence
description: MONTREAL, May 7Five of the largest provinces are now lined up against proposal by Quebec's government to continue an economic association with the rest of Canada if Quebec achieves independence.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: AFTER CONVICTION, by Ronald L. Goldfarb and Linda R. Singer. (Simon & Schuster/Touchstone, $8.95.) The way our criminal justice system works, from sentencing through incarceration to parole and rehabilitation, with some attention on the way to prison architecture and administration: this useful compendium acknowledges that at present there are shortcomings, but suggests no alternatives.

title: In His Own Defense
description: The nation has had its first sustained look at former President Nixon since he resigned in disgrace almost three years ago, and the spectacle was, in many respects, a familiar one. In his 90minute television inteview, Mr. Nixon moved closer than before to admitting culpability in the Watergate coverup, but he insisted, as before, that he was guilty of no crime and portrayed himself, in typically Nixonian terms and gestures, as a victim of circumstance whose errors sprang from good intentions.

title: Lakers, Rockets Trying to Even Things Today
description: The Los Angeles Lakers must get the ball into Kareem AbdulJabbar more often, must contain Maurice Lucas and must find a way to contend with the Portland Trail Blazers' quickness.

title: Platform Tennis Bounces Ahead
description: PLATFORM tennis, an outdoor winter sport invented by two Scarsdale residents too old to go sledding, is finally threatening to emerge from 50 years in the deep freeze.

title: RUTH SHERMAN STUART
description: Ruth Sherman Stuart, wife of John M. Stuart, former press information officer of the United States Mission to the United Nations, died of heart failure yesterday. She was 63 years old.

title: WHERE TO GO FOR BIRDWALKS
description: Among the preserves, parks and nature centers that provide the best possibilities for birdwatching are the following:

title: The Democrats Did It Too
description: NOW, here's a funny thing. Victor Lasky, who made a reputation of a sort with unrestrained attacks on John and Robert Kennedy, has written a book charging the press with unrestrainedly attacking Richard Nixon and in fact driving him from office.

title: Miss Foxen Has Nuptials
description: Kathleen Amy Foxen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Foxen of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. J. Milburn Jessup, who soon will start a surgical residency at the University of Texas Medical School in Houston.

title: Eastern Shore Fishing Provides Mixed Results
description: LOCUSTVILLE, Va.If one lives in the Northeast, the urge to go South in spring to meet certain northwardmigrating fish sometimes becomes irre sistible, particularly when an invitation to do that comes from two cherished friends.

title: Argentine Official Reported Injured
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 7 (AP)Foreign Minister Cesar Guzzetti was seriously injured today by leftist guerrillas who attempted to kidnap him, police sources reported.

title: Sheelah Strong Wed To L. William Black
description: In St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Mamaroneck, N. Y., yesterday afternoon, Sheelah Bankhead Strong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Delbert P. Strong of New Orleans, became the bride of L. William Black of New York. He is the son of Mrs. Leonard F. Black Jr. of Bronxville, N. Y., and the late Mr. Black.

title: On Bills to Control Wiretapping, The Infighting Goes On and On
description: The President proposes. Congress disposes. That is the classic description of how legislation gets on the statute books of the United States. But if reality ever was as neat as the epigram, it no longer is. What the President suggests is often the result of long dispute and negotiation within the executive branch, dispute that may continue after the legislation is submitted. And Congress does not wait passively for bills to reach Capitol Hill: Members become intimately involved in the executive drafting process.

title: New Money for Old Cities
description: THE DREAM of city officials is to discover new sources of revenue, some untapped cache of hidden dollars, to keep the lid on property taxes. But they awaken to find their fiscal crises remain the same or worse. There are no acres of diamonds in the backyard. I submit, however, that all is not lost. With some aggressive digging in the nooks and crannies of local finance, I believe there really is money to be found.

title: Carter Termed Flexible on Energy
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  President Carter has told Congressional leaders that he fully expects legislative changes in his energy package, Senator Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, said today.

title: Connecticut Gets a Third Fronton
description: MILFORD, Conn., May 5Connecticut, which has found parimutuel jaialai extremely lucrative since the sport was introduced in the state last May, had its third fronton open in this Long Island Sound community tonight.

title: Trial of Soviet Jew Postponed
description: MOSCOW, May 7 (Reuters)A Moscow judge yesterday postponed the trial on vagrancy charges of a Jewish activist Iosif Begun because his cellmate was suffering from an infectious disease, Jewish sources said. Mr. Begun was detained outside the United States Embassy on February 28 while trying to hand over documents on an unofficial Jewish symposium to an American diplomat.

title: How They Keep Them Down On The Farm
description: Seven years ago a man named Stephen Gaskin led 63 school buses of San Francisco hippies out of California and landed them on a muddy plot of land in Tennessee. They settled in to live communally turning their DayGlo buses into houses, their 60'sinspired beliefs into the law of their land. The group, named The Farm, is located two hours southwest of Nashville, in Summertown, Tenn. While other com

title: Upstate Assessor Backs Exemptions To Universal Life Church Ministers
description: HARDENBURGH, N. Y., May 7The Town Assessor in this small Catskill Mountain community said this week that he would approve all taxexempt applications submitted by residents who had become ordained ministers of the Universal Life Church.

title: Athletes May Dream, But Their Hard World Is Hardly for a Child
description: As a longdistance runner reading Dr. George Sheehan's article (A World Made Just for Running, April 17), I could appreciate and understand the childlike world of running to which he referred.

title: FOODSTAMP CHANGES DECRIED BY MOYNIHAN
description: WASHINGTON, May 7Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan has assailed the Carter Administration's plan for reforming the foodstamp program as one more instance of the plunder of New York by the Federal Government.

title: FOOD
description: ARAMBLING gray barn called the Common Market in Westport houses a collection of boutiques that includes a distinctly uncommon emporium called the Market Basket, an imaginative shop for irresistible prepared foods and baked goods.

title: Penn Crew Ends Streak Of Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7Pennsylvania's varsity crew beat Hatvard by onetenth of a second today in a blazing race for the Adams Cup on the Charles River. It was the Crimson's first loss after 26 straight victories over the last five seasons. The last time a Harvard varsity eight had failed to win was in 1973 at the Eastern sprint championships, taken by Northeastern.

title: Celebrating a Rich Diversity
description: SOUTHERN Westchester, sometimes called New York's sixth borough and containing almost 40 percent of the county's 880,000 population, is multiethnic, multiracial, multilingual and multitalented.

title: Who Should Harvest Shellfish Beds?
description: THE FRESH Long Island oyster featured on restaurant menus is actually a native of Connecticut, where the natural setting beds have been producing for centuries. But hurricanes, storms and pollution have played havoc with the industry, almost destroying it for a period of about 15 years in the 1950's and 60's.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeKennedy's Children. Thursday through Saturday. 8:30 P.M. $3.90$550; students and the elderly, $2.5053.90; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Cynthia Parker Sets Fall Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Perkins Parker of Gibson Island, Md., formerly of Washington, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Anne Parker, to Stephen Abbott Cook, son of David T. Cook of St. James, L.I., and the late Mrs. Cook.

title: Joy L. Turner, S. M. Cowan Jr. Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Turner of Danielson, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joy Louise Turner, to Spencer Morris Cowan Jr. of Allston, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cowan of Concord and Nantucket, Mass.

title: A Look at the Ebb and Flow of Life in the Sound
description: LONG ISLAND SOUND as we know it today is relatively new on the landscape. Twenty thousand years ago  which appears to be a long time on a human scale, but is only a few seconds in the severalbillionyear history of the earth  a huge glacier covered the Sound with ice, terminating on what is now Long Island.

title: White, Rivers and Nettles Homer
description: Looking more and more devastating as the innings rolled by, the Yankees pounded their way into first place yesterday at the Stadium by overpowering the Oakland A's, 112.

title: CRIME
description: William Murray has gone to the headlines for his latest book, THE MOUTH OF THE WOLF (Little, Brown, $8.95). Kidnapping in Italy is a thriving industry these days. Not political kidnapping, which also has been hitting the international headlines, but kidnapping in the oldfashioned sense for money. One only need think of the Getty case a few years back.

title: The Rewards of Volunteering
description: FEMINISM versus volunteerism has been the subject of many interesting and provocative articles and debates during the last six years, with a great many of them focusing on irreconcilable differences between the two. Less notedif at all notedare the similarities.

title: They Are Working Hard to Prevent Opposition Factions From Getting Together in Congress
description: WASHINGTONSome angry night in the fall It may all come apart. Liberal Democrats may decide the bill is too nice to the oil companies. Republicans may find the assorted taxes just tricky ways to help balance the budget or fund new programs. Another three dozen representatives with auto plants in their districts may decide the gasguzzler tax makes the package indigestible.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT'S a drag to be speaking about the automobile so often, but it's absolutely stunning  or soporific  to realize how much of a staple it is in conversation in the suburbs. The automobile is for us what the camel is to desert dwellers, except that the camel gets much better mileage.

title: McCARTHY ANNIVERSARY IS OBSERVED AT A MASS
description: A memorial mass for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy observing the 20th anniversary of his death was offered yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Energy: Is the Breaking Point Near?
description: IF President Carter's energyconservation program fell on a nation weary of the subject, what Westchester County felt was something more serious than exhaustion. I'm looking for a breaking point in this county, said the County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello.

title: Michael Ryan, Editor, Weds Debora Gilbert
description: Debora Dorothea Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan A. Gilbert of Ladue, Mo., was married yesterday to Michael Ryan of Boston, special projects editor and columnist for The Boston Herald American. The Rev. Gilbert Bowen performed the ceremony in the Kenilworth Union Church in Kenilworth, Ill., where the bride's parents lived until last year.

title: U.S.PAKISTANI RIFT ON ATOM FUEL GROWS
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 4Differences over Pakistan's potential role as a nuclear nation apparently lie at the heart of the embittered relations with the United States. These broke into the open last week when Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto accused Washington of financing his opponents.

title: AIR ARMY RETAKES AGRICULTURAL TOWN
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 7 (AP)A joint ZairianMoroccan task force recaptured the agricultural town of Sanikosa in Shaba Province today after bitter fighting with rebel troops, the Government press agency reported.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: Is Anybody Listening?
description: WASHINGTON, May 7One of the odd things about life in America these days, as Eric Hoffer and many others keep pointing out, is that we don't know what is happening to us. We have the most advanced and sophisticated communications systems the world has ever known, but somehow despite our computers, pollsters and information satellitesthe elemental facts don't seem to penetrate the American mind.

title: The State Copes
description: AFTER Governor Grasso ordered that the floodlights that brightened the State Capitol at night be turned off, who in her government would have risked being careless and thought of as a squanderer of energy?

title: Siegfried Park: Spring of '77
description: I'M proud of my German heritage and I will never forsake it. There are some sad memories for us, but most of. the past has been good, not bad, Herbert Faust said.

title: Outlook on Energy
description: LOST/ UNAVAILABLE ENERGY 412.6

title: Shampoos for the Peripatetic
description: In Istanbul, I settled myself in the beauty salon chair, glanced at my Turkish phrase book and confidently said, Tras olmak istigorum. The customer in the next chair giggled while the hairdresser tried unsuccessfully to stifle a polite titter. I was asking for a shampoo, but my eye had slipped down one line too many. What I had actually said was: I want a shave.

title: Victor Mill 3d Plans to Wed Miss Maulsby
description: Allen F. Maulsby of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Monica Damon Maulsby, to Victor J. Mill 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mill Jr. of Andover, Mass.

title: Prize Winner
description: This year's winner of the Pulitzer Prize in music was Richard Wernick for a work caned Visions of Terror and Wonder. It seemed only fair to write few words about him, so a call was put in to him at his home in Media, Pa.

title: SELECTION
description: The wind sprays pale dirt into my mouth

title: A Secretary's Life
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (Reuters)The United States has asked South Africa to approve a controversial visit by Andrew Young, the delegate to the United Nations.

title: Chappaqua Hears the Music of Drums
description: COME on! And let it rock! shouted James Leyden, a music teacher at the Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, trying to get the attention of the 16 bluejeaned and sneakered teenage steel drummers who were arranged in a circle around him.

title: What to Expect
description: THE WAY the experts in Connecticut view it, President Carter's energy proposals would be a burden an the stLte. its businesses and and its peoplebut the load here would be lighter than in many other states.

title: INTERVIEW
description: I WAS one of those kids who used to hang over the airport fence, watching airplanes. I would pedal my bicycle from Oradell down to Teterboro to watch. That's where I first flew, at Teterboro. I'd rather not admit to that, but it had to be somewhere in the late 1930's.

title: Mt. Vernon Fights A Federal Landlord
description: FOR YEARS, the ceiling over Pearl Sharperson's bedroom window has been slowly allowing bigger and bigger drops of water through from somewhere in the walls of Azalea Gardens, an apartment building at 300 East Prospect Avenue in Mount Vernon that is now owned by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. The drops have worn away the white paint on metal radiator enclosure and left a large rust spot that stands out in contrast to the crisp curtains on the window and the general tidiness of the room.

title: An Angry Composer Forbids His Music To Be Performed
description: CHICAGO One of the most searing, terrifying and altogether extraordinary compositions this listener has ever heard was played in the final concert of the Composer's Forum. So began a 1961 New York Times review of Ralph Shapey's Incantations for Soprano and Ten Instruments. His output forms the finest and most substantial body of music by any American composer of our time, wrote another critic in 1969 in The Chicago Daily News, further describing him as an authentic genius. A more recent critique in Stereo Review last February, following the release of Shapey's oratorio Praise by Composers Recordings (CRISD 355), compared his importance and influence in new music to that of De Kooning and Kline in modern painting.

title: CAMERA VIEW
description: The era of instant movies is here!

title: The County Sings
description: EVERY Tuesday night from September through May, at least 270 Westchester residents take a deep breath and sing laaa, usually on a Cmajor chord. Thus begin the weekly rehearsals of four of the county's eight amateur choral societies.

title: Carter Asks Rise In Taxes to Aid Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The Carter Administration, in what officials describe as a major policy shift, has decided to ask Congress to increase by billions of dollars a year the Social Security taxes paid by employers.

title: LETTER FROM THE COLLEGE OF NEW ROCHELLE
description: WHEN I was younga sophomore, sayI used to proclaim that the art majors at the College of New Rochelle were comparable to the athletes at some big Southern football factory. They were, after all, a good deal different from the rest of us. While we slaved feverishly over The Identity of the Ravens in The Dream of Rhonabwy and other vital research, they spent most of their time drawing arms and legs and the occasional nose.

title: Major League Scores
description: EGRichards, Almon, Ivie, Champion 2, Sawyer. LOBMontreal 9, San Diego 10. 28Perez, Cromartie, Tenace. 3BAlmon. HRWinfield (5), Perez (5), Unser (2), Tenace (4). SBAlmon. SStanhouse.

title: Around the Nation
description: CHICAGO, May 7 (AP)A Federal appellate judge today upheld soybean delivery restrictions imposed on the Hunt family of Texas.

title: Use a Scrub BrushInstead of a Paint Brush
description: When a homeowner examines the outside of his house and finds that the paint looks dingy or dirty, the first thing he usually thinks of is that his home will soon need a new exterior paint job. Yet in many cases repainting the entire outside of the house is not only unnecessary, it can actually be harmful especially if the existing paint job is only two or three years old and is still basically in good shape on most parts of the house.

title: ELIZABETH G. MacDERMOTT
description: Elizabeth G. MacDermott, a longtime supporter of the New York Philharmonic and the Juilliard School of Music, died Thursday after a long illness. She was 83 years old and lived at 1 West 72d Street in Manhattan.

title: As Energy User, City Is Both Rich and Poor
description: When Citicorp lost a bid to put six stories of apartments atop its new 72story corporate headquarters in 1973, energy saving was big in the news. So, at the suggestion of Con Edison, the building's beveled roof was turned to the south to collect solar energy.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: The most refreshing new style in Soviet dissidence, a type of rebellion understandably not distinguished for its humor, is that of two young artists, Vitali Komar and Aleksandr Melamid, who live and work in Moscow. Functioning as a team, they have made their art the substance of their protest, parodying the propaganda posters and street banners designed for public consumption by Soviet officials, ridiculing the myriad documents carried of necessity by Soviet citizens and taking potshots at such sacred cows as Soviet Socialist art.

title: Residents of Rural New York Valley Upset by Publicity About Fires
description: NEW LEBANON, N. Y., May 6  A series of at least 200 fires and perhaps more over the last six years has made the people in the hamlets of the Lebanon Valley edgy, suspicious and fearful.

title: Miss Urie Fiancee Of R. D. Thorpe Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Urie of New York and Swampscott, Mass., have annouced the engagement of their daughter Sandra Ann Urie, to Ronald D. Thorpe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thorpe of Carlisle, Pa. An August wedding in Swampscott is planned.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: GIVEN that 40 percent of the population is, by insurance company tabulations, overweight (and given the social stigma attached to this condition), you can understand the profusion of diet and exercise books noted by our reviewer over on page 26.

title: Jaworski to the Rescue
description: TWO of the young assistant special prosecutors in the Watergate coverup trial have written a book that both makes news and should have lasting significance. The news is in their attack on Special Prosecutor Leon Jaworski's judgment in going along with President Ford's pardon of Richard Nixon and their plausible speculation that he may have encouraged Mr. Ford to act quickly.

title: Boating Slate Takes New Races Aboard
description: A number of new races are on the horizon this season. The New York Times and Newsday have taken the plunge into sponsorship. The New YorkNew London Invitation Sail Regatta sponsored by The New York

title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on amendment reducing by 3.9 billion funding for Public Service Jobs, rejected, 46 to 33, May 2.

title: Sweden, France Win In Tennis
description: STOCKHOLM, May 7 (AP)  Sweden clinched a victory over Austria in the European Zone of the Davis Cup today by winning the doubles for an insurmountable 30 lead. Ove Bengtson and Rolf Norberg outplayed Hans Kary and Cliff Letcher, 64, 64, 63.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IN ALL the world there are three Stratfords that owe a debt to William Shakespeare. The one on the Avon where he was born and died, another in Ontario and a third on Connecticut's Housatonic River.

title: THEATER
description: LANA Turner, discovered or not discovered on a sodafountain stool, is a nothing story compared to the star who dazzled Broadway on the night of April 21 at the Alvin Theater in New York City. That was the night that Annie, the musical first seen last summer at the Goodspeed Opera House, opened.

title: Belgian Castles: Portals to the Past
description: It wasn't Tuesday, but I was in Belgiumlost in Belgium. Even though I was armed with two good maps, Beloeilthe castle and the town of the same namecontinued to elude me.

title: Reflections on the Lakes of Yugoslavia
description: Most Americans who visit Yugoslavia stake out beachheads along the Adriatic Coast and stay put. But I wanted to go beyond the mountains that edge the sea. I wanted to see the Yugoslav lakes.

title: Choral Society Sings From a ThreeCentury Range
description: No one could complain about a lack of musical variety in the concert given by the New York Choral Society on Friday night in Carnegie Hall. Robert DeCormier conducted a program for chorus and orchestra that ranged widely over three centuries, taking in the Baroque, Classical, Romantic and contemporary eras.

title: Clydesdales Will Step Out Again in Devon Show
description: The Devon horse show, scheduled for May 28June 4 in Devon, Pa., has engaged the Budweiser Clydesdales again as an added attraction.

title: Frisbee, Ships and Discipline
description: TO the students' who live there, it's an environment they call the Webbisphere. To someone reading the bronze plaque near the wroughtiron entrance gates just off Crescent Beach Road in Glen Cove, it's the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture, a school that has as its campus the former estate of the oil baron Herbert L. Pratt.

title: Hanna Bloomfield Fiancee of J. B. Rubins
description: Prof. and Mrs. Morton W. Bloomfield of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hanna Ellen Bloomfield, to Jeffrey Bennet Rubins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Rubins of Kansas City, Mo.

title: Did Rose Live Happily Ever After?
description: One of the proposals of the Carter Administration that received little or no public notice, and not even James Reston seems to have heard about, was the draft of a joint resolution, to he submitted to both Houses of Congress, declaring Sunday, May 8, 1977, a day of national mourning, on account of the sudden demise of the Bellamy family on May Day.

title: Cosmos to Shuffle Lineup Against the Bi's Today
description: Gordon Bradley, the coach of the Cosmos, has told his players that there will be several changes in today's North American Soccer League encounter with the Connecticut Bicentennials at the Yale Bowl. Pel and Giorgio Chinaglia have been absent from the team's scoring statistics in recent games, though it is very unlikely that Bradley changes will involve them. In the Cosmos' five games, three of them losses, Pel has had a goal and no assists, and Chinaglia, the league's leading scorer last season, has only 3 points, with a goal and one assist.

title: Tripping Around China
description: TRUE to its tradition, our relationship with China proceeds on many levels, with some abrupt changes of direction. Our impatience is large and our memory is small, and we want more from the link than it can quickly yield. We are disappointed that five years of dtente have not brought more engagement between the two peoples and their values.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE greatest enemy of brick walls, chimneys and other structures made of brick is waterthat is, water that penetrates the surface through crumbling mortar joints, cracked or missing bricks and similar defects.

title: The Terhune Legend Recalled
description: TODAY'S television generation has no idea what real, thrilling adventure is, said Irving Litvag. The kids are ignorant of the adventures of Lad and Lady, two of the noblest collies, two of the finest dogs that ever lived.

title: $3.5 Million Arboretum to Use SolarHeat System
description: MILLBROOK, N.Y., May 7After a cloudy morning, the sun came out and shone brightly here today as the Cary Arboretum held a cornerstonelaying ceremony for its new $3.5 million plantscience building, described as the largest privately financed solarheating structure in the country.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: FOR most of us, May is that peculiar time of the year when we remove all traces of winter past. We bag the few remaining leaves from last fall. We get on with the mowing. We spotpatch the blacktop. We enjoy our trees again. And we shop for houses.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: (OTB payoff ssubject to 5% municipal surtax.)

title: Track and Field
description: AT PHILADELPHIA HEPTAGONAL CHAMPIONSHIPS

title: Controversya Political Need
description: TODAY, every individual in the Nassau Republican Party faces a test of his or her belief in, and in the promise of, our system of freedom. In this country, we Americans are inclined to enroll in political parties, to immerse ourselves in group opinion and to take as our own ideas those of a party. The propagation of an idea thus organized and compact is surely more effective. But individuality, the free desire of the spirit, every independent vibration of the soul, are sacrificed.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: How odd and remote much of the avantgarde art of the 1930's and 40's looks today. How divorced not only from its own time but from any later time. I am thinking particularly of the photographs of Gyorgy Kepes on view at the Prakapas Gallery, 19 East 71st street, to May 21.

title: Dance: Countdown by the Ailey
description: Years and years ago, in the ice age of dance's avantgarde, a young man called Paul Taylor found notoriety, if not fame, by standing dead still on stage and saying it was a dance. Well, it certainly wasn't a foxtrot, but then again neither was it a poem or a chicken coop.

title: Hackensack: Rebirth Via Art
description: WHILE the city fathers of Hackensack continue planning for revitalization projects that will woo shop pers back from the nearby malls, a group of artists and art patrons has quietly launched ventures that are helping to upgrade the community.

title: ROUNDUP
description: The greening of executive suites by shareholders last week never looked lusher. As the annual ritual of company meetings reached its fever pitch; stockholders lavished rewards on their corporate managersbut some of the giving didn't come easily.

title: Engagements
description: CamhiHausler

title: Memphis Bishop at Center of Dispute on Services of Reconciliation
description: CHICAGO, May 7In the past week's meeting of the American Catholic hierarchy here, the portly, slightly rumpled figure of Bishop Carroll T. Dozier of Memphis, Tenn., often stood somewhat apart from the crowd. It was indicative of his position of relative solitude among many of his fellow bishops since last December when he performed two services of reconciliation in which general absolution was granted.

title: Jeffrey Barr Fiance Of Robin Lee Cragg
description: Robin Lee Cragg, who is studying for a Ph.D. degree in linguistics at Harvard University, and Jeffrey Nelson Barr, who is completing his first year at the Harvard Law School, plan to be married in July.

title: What's Doing in SEATTLE
description: EVERGREENSeattle was born amid tall timberas a lumber port when loggers arrived at Puget Sound in the early 1850'sand the city still wears the yearround green of forested hills. Water brims close everywhere: the city is corseted between the Sound to its west and 24milelong Lake Washington to the east. Amid this natural finery, Seattle has been given an urban facelift in the past decade. The downtown skyline has been festooned with 14 new buildings more than 20 stories high, Pioneer Square has been restored to its 19thcentury winsomeness and a bevy of imaginative parks has been added to downtowners' amenities. Seattle used to be notable chiefly for Boeing airplanes and some interesting women in its past (the pioneer Mercer girls inspired the TV series, Here Come the Brides; Alice B. Toklas, Mary McCarthy, Frances Farmer and Gypsy Rose Lee lived here; in 1926, Bertha K. Landes was the first woman elected mayor of a major American city). Today it is a variegated city of 485,000, with six professional theaters as well as the opera and symphony housed in Seattle Center, heritage of the 1962 World's Fair. In spirit as well as environs, Seattle has grown to be a pleasingly evergreen

title: A Correction
description: Because of a typographical error, the identification of Emily Jefferson (Opinion Page, April 24) was partially incorrect. Miss Jefferson is an employee of the Wilton Gallery.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THE art, or at least the enterprise, of literary biographythe writing of the lives of writers flourishes so prodigiously these days that conies as something of a surprise to realize how little critical attention is normally paid to this particular form. Indeed, we tend not to think of it as a form at all. The usual thing is to devour biographies for their content, and to complainfor our criticism, to the extent that it exists at all, generally takes the form of a complaintonly when their shapelessness or prolixity actively inhibits easy access to the content.

title: POLITICS
description: AS THE candidate for Mayor of Jersey City handed out campaign literature, a woman asked him, Do you speak Pol ish? No, only enough to order some kielbasa, the candidate replied, as he gave a pamphlet to her companion.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: David Kopay
description: Passing by the sports department at The Times, David Kopay remarked, I once had my picture in your paperwhen I was cocapta:n of the 1964 University of Washington Rose Bowl team.

title: Raceway Asks for Help
description: WESTBURY ROOSEVELT RACEWAY, which has paid the State of New York $650 million in parimutuel and franchise taxes since it opened as a harness track 37 years ago, now contends that it is in a precarious financial position because of declining attendance and competition from the new harness track in the New Jersey Meadowlands Sports Complex.

title: N.C.A.A. Puts Hawaii Five On TwoYear Probation
description: SHAWNEE MISSION, Kan., May 7 (UPI)  The University of Hawaii's basketball program was placed on two years' probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for what were termed most serious violations involving improper recruiting inducements and extra benefits to athletes.

title: Hurling Matches Listed
description: Top players from Ireland will compete at next Sunday at Gaelic Park, 240th Street and Broadway. Carroll's AllStars will play Cork, the allIreland champions, in hurling at 2:30 P.M. At 4:30, Carroll's AllStars will meet Dublin, the alllreland football champions. There will be additional football games at 1:30 and 5:15.

title: Kirstein The Man Who Brought Us Balanchine
description: As the New York City Ballet swings into its spring season at the New York State Theater, the excitement within the company centers on George Balanchine's forthcoming new ballet, Vienna Waltzes.

title: Carter's Stand on Nuclear Issue Is Dividing Leaders at Conference
description: LONDON, May 7President Carter's proposals for curbing the spread of nuclear technology with military potential have now emerged as the most difficult and divisive issue at this weekend's summit conference of seven leading industrial nations.

title: All Those Allens Back a Broadway Hit
description: Look who stands to make money backing the new Broadway hit, I Love My Wife, (a scene from which is at the right).

title: Twyla Tharp Has Something For Everyone
description: Twyla Tharp looked tired. Still alert, witty and intense, mind you, but tired. She had her reasons, though. She'd been working all day, she hadn't eaten anything, and now she was doing an interview. What she'd been working on was three related projectsthe final editing of an hourlong Public Television special that will air in the fall, her portions of Paul Simon's NBC special, which will probably be telecast in November, and above all the preparations for her 10day stint beginning Thursday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which will be the major New York showcase for her company this season.

title: Miss Bokman Fiance Of Brian MacNamara
description: Maureen Bokman, who graduates this month from Cornell University, plans to be married June 18 to Brian Scott MacNamara, who is completing his first year at Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine.

title: A Modified Carey Plan to Revamp MentalHealth Agency Is Drafted
description: ALBANY, May 7Governor Carey's proposal to reorganize the mammoth Department of Mental Hygiene, called moribund by the State Senate's Republican leadership six weeks ago, appears to be gaining some new signs of life.

title: AnneStarr Holmes White, Teacher, Sets August Wedding to Philip Trout Snead
description: AnneStarr Holmes White, a teacher at the Greenwich Country Day School, and Philip Trout Snead, a former faculty member of the Moses Brown School, will be married in August. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bradley White of Watch Hill, R.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of the Rev. and Mrs. Paul B. Snead of Dover, Pa.

title: The Core of Soviet Foreign Policy Is to Go With Winners
description: MOSCOWIt appears that no vacuum is going to be left anywhere, an African diplomat remarked last week, commenting on the seemingly ceaseless SovietAmerican competition for influence in the developing world, a compulsion to fill every gap in each other's presence. Scarcely diminished by dtente, the struggle continues to pour arms into small countries, magnify local conflicts and drain resources from human needs. It shows no sign of abating.

title: Yankees' Box Score
description: OAKLAND (A.)

title: Public Hearing Set By the City Council
description: The following public hearings will be held by New York City Council committees this week:

title: Jonathan Jones Marries Nina Barbaresi, Illustrator
description: Nina Barbaresi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Peter Barbaresi of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Cornwell Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer D. Jones of Princeton. N. J.

title: Eizabeth Jacob Sets Nuptials Next Spring To Leeber S. Cohen
description: Elizabeth Louise Jacob, who is completing her first year at the Columbia Law School, plans to be married next spring to Leeber Solomon Cohen, a student at the Northwestern University Medical School.

title: House Panel Votes $1.3 Billion To Develop Energy Programs
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (UPI)A House subcommittee has agreed to authorize $1.3 billion for the Energy Research and Development Administration to develop such projects as advanced automobile engines and the use of geothermal energy.

title: Medicine
description: The brain of a young adult contains about 12 billion neurons, the cells that send nerve, impulses through the body's most complex organ, and each day, as part of the aging process, the brain shrinks from the death of 100,000 neurons. After decades of losing these irreplaceable cells in an uneven pattern through the brain, the mind of the older individual may wander and he may no longer be able to care for himself. In a word, he becomes senile.

title: Love From a Madman
description: THE FAN is a funny and astonishing account of a madman, an actress and their chillingly inevitable meeting, which hangs over the pages like a circling buzzard. Sally Ross, a Broadway luminary, tough and lovable in the Margot Charming tradition, is preparing for the opening of her new play So I Bit Him (Why do costume designers always want to bury me lb feathers? Do I look like chicken?); she and her exhusband Jake, now a producer in Hollywood, are working their way out present loves and back toward a primeyears' rediscovery of each other. Meanwhile Douglas Breen, Sally's No. 1 fan, pursues her with increasingly irrational and threatening correspondence.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: LECTURES

title: THREE AREA STUDENTS WIN TRUMAN SCHOLARSHIPS
description: Three young persons from the metropolitan area have been awarded the first scholarships from the Harry S. Truman Scholarship Foundation. They will receive their prizes at a ceremony Sunday at the Truman Library in Independence, Mo., on the 93d birthday anniversary of the late President.

title: Experts Argue Whether Computers Could Reason, and if They Should
description: Can machines think? Should they? The computer world is in the midst of a fundamental dispute over those questions because an eminent computer scientist wrote a book arguing that machines could never be made to reason like people and, what was more, should not be.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WHEN Joseph Abaldo Jr. was growing up in Huntington, his father used to bring him magic tricks. I was interested in magic, he said, and I did magic around the house. But I never intended to become a professional magician.

title: Nehemiah Hurdles 13.2, Ties U.S. School Mark
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., May 7Renaldo Nehemiah of Scotch PlainsFanwood High School tied the national interscholastic record for the 120yard high hurdles at the Minuteman Games held last night at Williams Field.

title: Joel Reingold Fiance Of Allison Jean Funk
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Harley Funk of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison Jean Funk, to Joel Seth Reingold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Reingold of Scarsdale. N. Y. The wedding is planned for July 17.

title: Blacks Are Now Discovering. Urban Ills in Southern Cities
description: NEW ORLEANSFor Yasin Muheimen, who was born Bernard Wilson 27 years ago in the little town of Zachary, La., migration to the city of New Orleans was an experiment that failed.

title: Pension Funds Are Building Up Large Portfolios Of Properties
description: Pooled property investments by pension and profitsharing trust funds are becoming an influential force in real estate throughout the country.

title: Medical Villains and Heroes
description: ASCIENCE author (The Year of the Intern), practicing ophthalmologist and clinical instructor at Harvard Medical School, Dr. Robin Cook has now worked up a classy first novel that begins as a medical mystery and climaxes as a meller with the heroine drugged on the operating table and about to be ... dissected? Turned into a braindamaged vegetable? Well, some kind of Manchurian horror.

title: It's Almost Time To Set Out The Tomato Seedlings
description: There probably are as many ways to grow tomatoes as there are recipes to use them. Those who are new to the tomatogrowing cult or dissatisfied with their own method of growing may like some point. ers on the process.

title: I Am Widely Regarded as the Ghost Of a Writer
description: Of course no one is more acutely aware than I that I am widely regarded as the ghost of a writer, a ghost still visible, excessively solid of flesh and perhaps too ambulatory, but a writer remembered mostly for works which were staged between 1944 and 1961.

title: The. Sound of Folk Music
description: WITHIN every failure, like dormant seeds, successes He waiting to be watered and fertilized. For Bla Bartk it was a series of bitter failures as a young pianist and composer that turned him toward the study of Hungarian peasant music and set him on the road to international recognition as a folksong scholar. In 1904, the 23yearold musician entered his Opus 1, the Rhapsody for Piano and Orchestra, in the Anton Rubinstein competition in Paris, and lost to a certain Brugnoli.

title: Evelyn Martin Becomes Bride Of C. Hemphill
description: The Old Stone Presbyterian Church in Lewisburg, W. Va., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Evelyn Frances Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Martin of Lewisburg. to Clifford Joseph Hemphill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Hemphill of Rumson, N. J. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Apperson performed the ceremony.

title: HEALTH
description: This season's selfhelp books arrived at my apartment a week ago. Thirty  seven of them. They're all over the place in piles on sofas, scattered around the edges of my bed, stacked next to the tub. They came in every size, every color, every category, from the sublime to the silly: books on obscure vitamins and hardtofind nutrients; sexercises; six different ways to success; five books on stress and where to put it; mental health through nuts; at least a dozen diets, one of which promised dynamic living; health through handwriting; and a final extension of the modern American Dream, the essence of laziness, how to lose weight while sleeping.

title: Nobel Laureate Watches Fish for Clues to Human Violence
description: ALTENBERG, AustriaKonrad Lorenz, whose research on animal behavior has won him a Nobel Prize, spends four hours every day in front of a big glass tank here watching tropical fish fight or make friends, and at times he muses about the rise of violence in human societies.

title: Goldin Is Pressing a Major Audit Of the New York School System
description: The New York City Comptroller has initiated a major investigation to determine whether the $2,500 that the Board of Education says it is spending each year on every child in the city school system is being put to good use.

title: HAT UNION BUILDING IS TAKEN OVER BY U.S.
description: The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Federal agency created under the 1974 pension reform act, has replaced the Millinery Workers Union pension fund as landlord of a 17story loft building in the heart of Manhattan's onceflourishing millinery center.

title: A Candid Academic at Commerce
