description: WASHINGTONAs Juanita Kreps, the first economist to serve as Secretary of Commerce, sits at her desk, she looks directly across at a slightly offcenter picture of Herbert Hoover, the only Secretary of Commerce to have become President of the United States.

title: A New Drug's End Run Around the F. D.A.
description: LAS VEGAS  He is going to take them all on if he has tothe skeptics, the Nevada State Legislature, the United States Food and Drug Administrationand he just might win.

title: Vegetable Oddities For May Planters
description: Last year, I experimented with some odd sorts of vegetables. The results were so fascinating, I plan to repeat the same crops again this year. This is what I grew: bush sweet pota to, curled parsley, parsnips, kohlrabi and Jerusalem artichoke.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Baseball.

title: LETTER FROM FAIRFIELD
description: THE UNIVERSITY STUDENT has hit upon hard times. From the outside looking in, one might think that college campuses have not been so peaceful since the 1950's. The unrest has subsided and the student has finally settled down to prepare himself for life in the world.

title: Nancy M. Vaughan Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Vaughan of Roslyn Heights, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy M. Vaughan, to Hobart Doremus Van Deusen of New York and Wentworth, N. H. He is the son of Katherine Mac Lane Van Deusen of Montclair, N. J., and the late Hobart M. Van Deusen. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Presenring his new designs for bed and bath fabries in an advertisement in The New Yorker, Oscar de la Renta says, My designs are for the woman who believes her bed and bath should be as welldressed as she is ... the woman who makes as much of a personal statement with her room decor as her wardrobe

title: Making Music in Mercer
description: THE violinists were having a bit of trouble with the 244th measure of Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overturethey screeched in stead of shimmered. And, 72 measures later, when a soursounding string played an errant Aflat, the conductor smiled wryly and accused them of committing the annihilation of civilized culture. No one will be upset with you if you go home and practice that.

title: Rosa Baumanis Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Rosa Maria Baumanis, a junior at Princeton University, to Terry Lee Hakala, a Princeton senior, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George Baumanis of Maracaibo, Venezuela, parents of the bride tobe. Mr. Hakala is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Hakala, of Yakima, Wash.

title: Televising the Least Known Of Civilized People
description: Since I was going to Indonesia anyway, it seemed a bright idea for me to add to my list of 26 programs over the past 7 years for Camera Three, CBS's weekly highculture show. John Musilli, the executive producer of the program, agreed. Sure, why not, was his response last November to this project which seemed at the time simpler than it does now in the retrospect of getting in, getting out and getting on.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Life of a 10YearOld Gymnast, As Told by Her Dutiful Mother
description: Life with a 10yearold gymnast has ups and downs that outsiders can't know about.

title: Connecticut/ThisWeek
description: ART

title: Letters
description: Radioactive wastes

title: DANCE VIEW
description: When you stage Shakespeare's Hamlet, you knowwithin certain reasonable limitswhat you are getting. When you stage the ballet Swan Lake, you do not. What is authenticity in dance? How far can such authenticity be trusted? And does it matter? These are vital questions to ballet. They concern ballet history and also, to an extent, the whole philosophy of dance and choreography.

title: Praise From Burns
description: When Arthur F. Burns, the doughty chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, climbed Capitol Hill once again last week, it was, surprisingly, not to hurl thunderbolts at the Administration's economic policies.

title: Koosman in 3Hitter, Seaver in Apology
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 7Jerry Koosman's threehit pitching and a revised batting order brought the New York Mets a 60 victory over the San Francisco Giants today and ended a fivegame losing streak, while the offfield rhetoric surrounding the club cooled down.

title: Aussie Outback Lures the Tours
description: Eight years ago, a couple of geologists from the Western Mining Company bellied up to the bar of the Kalgoorlie Palace Hotel and allowed as how their outfit, which had been mining gold in this remote area of Western Australia with diminishing returns, had struck nickel and would soon start mining it in a 35mile radius of Kalgoorlie, taking in the adjacent town of Boulder and two nearby ghost towns: Coolgardie (which once had seven newspapers, two stock exchanges, three breweries, a 14doctor hospital, and a population of 15,000, but, by the 1960's, had barely 400 residents) and Kambalda (turnofthecentury population: 2,500; 1960 population: 12).

title: Fashion
description: Here they are, the great new looks from the great American designers' fall collectionsthe clothes that have been zipping down the runways while cameras clicked, hands clapped, and pencils scribbled. What America's women will wear next was being decided. For the past three weeks, New York's Seventh Avenue garment cenler has been the hub of fashion activity, and the news is good. The fall 77 clothes are not laddy, they're fashion. The look, different, but wearablesofter than before, yet sensible. Hemlines stay right where they've beensomewhere under the knee. And the colors and combinations of fabrics make a lot of these clothes almost irresistible. Here, a fivepage report on the best of the best. The clothes themselves will start arriving in stores across the country next month.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: British Football
description: SCOTTISH FA CUP FINAL

title: Realty News
description: Botticelli, the shoe, luggage and leather accessories store, has leased the former Delta Airline office at 610 Fifth Avenue for about 18 years at an aggregate rent of about $1.75 million.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: come into a room. You would go into a group and everybody would be unnatural, especially at the beginning.

title: Page Kjellstrom Sets Marriage to a Lawyer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Nils David Kjellstrom of Richmond of the engagement of their daughter, Page Michaux Kjellstrom, to Clyde H. Slease 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Slease of Ligonier, Pa. The wedding is planned for June 25.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., May 7Andrew Jackson, led by Steve Skinner's double victory, captured the team title today in the Dwight Morrow High School Games.

title: Hitch in Farm Policy: Subsidies
description: CHICAGOCompared with his proposals on energy, welfare and governmental reorganization, President Carter's plans for agriculture are not particularly innovative, yet they are proving to be a serious point of contention between Mr. Carter and farmstate members of Congress. The struggle is over dollars, not basic principles.

title: LEADERS IN LONDON IN GENERAL ACCORD ON ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: LONDON, May 7The leaders of the seven major industrialized democracies reached broad general agreement this morning on a strategy for combating unemployment, but their unanimity buckled when they turned this afternoon to the question of the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: ART VIEW
description: In the catalogue of the Robert Irwin show, which currently occupies the spacious fourth floor galleries at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street (through May 29), there are no illustrations of the works actually to be seen in the show. Mr. Irwin has expressly forbidden the publication of such reproductions. There is, however, a longish text by the artist entitled Notes Toward a Model, which is itself drawn from an even longer work in progress called On the Nature of Abstraction. Also in the catalogue are some aerial photographs of Manhattan, a photographic record of some of Mr. Irwin's earlier exhibitions, and diagrams for various onsite installations, as they are called, including the enormous Scrim VeilBlack RectangleNatural Light, which the artist has created at the Whitney for this occasion.

title: Arms Sales: Another Wobbling Promise
description: As a candidate, Jimmy Carter used to assail his predecessor for his unsavory and cynical role as the world's leading arms salesman. Within days of moving into the White House, Mr. Carter spoke again of the necessity for reducing arms sales. The State Department and other agencies were sent a tasking memorandum with allegedly jolting questions about how to carry out the President's wish. Washington's mountain of a bureaucracy labored for three months and it appears to have produced a mouse.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Today Jacques Offenbach is universally accepted as a classicone of the three supreme 19thcentury composers of light music, the other two being Arthur Sullivan and Johann Strauss, Jr. Listening to the Village Light Opera's production of La Vie Parisienne the other week, one could only endorse posterity's estimate. The music has charm, sparkle, originality. It is an evocation of one side of Paris: sophisticated Paris, funloving Paris, elegant Paris. There is more to the Offenbach librettos, too, than at first meets the eye. Offenbach and his librettists, like Gilbert and Sullivan, delighted in poking fun at the Establishment, and some of the satire penetrates very deeply indeed.

title: A Majority in Poll Oppose Carter Plan To Register Voters
description: President Carter's plan to permit unregistered adult citizens to vote on Election Day by identifying themselves at the polls is opposed by a sample of the American public, 55 to 40, the Gallup Poll reported yesterday.

title: A Businessman For Her Deputy
description: WASHINGTONIf anyone can feel comfortable at the Department of Cottmerce, that wildly heterogeneous institution whose interests range from EastWest trade to fire prevention, it ought to be Sidney Harman, an iconoclastic Long Island businessman.

title: Arrested Nuclear Foes Vow To Keep Movement Going
description: SEABROOK, N.H., May 7The letter that came out of the makeshift jail in tie Dover National Guard Armory last night was 10 pages long, bore the handwriting of several persons and was signed The Dover 265.

title: A Letter From a Mother
description: I SPOKE to a friend tonight, and when I mentioned the way you felt, she suggested that I write to you. I have never done anything like this before, but I think it's about time.

title: FISHING
description: THE mackerel run off the South Jersey coast should be winding up this week, but fastmoving schools on their northerly migration still may provide good action in northern waters. The faster the water temperature rises, the quicker the mackerel will leave, with the bluefish. following in their wake.

title: In Memoriam
description: BURGERAlexander. May 13, 1932. Ever sacred to the memory of a dear father and grandfather. The BURGER and LEVY families.

title: John Bisceglia to Wed Dorren Mary Murphy
description: Mr. and Mrs. James B. Murphy of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Darren Mary Murphy, to John Frederick Bisceglia, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Bisceglia of Greenwich. Conn.

title: Governor's Race: Byrne Is Still Strong
description: GOVERNOR BYRNE, the man who couldn't be bought in 1973 and the candidate who probably can't be sold in 1977, is still the center of attention as the gubernatorial primary races get under way in earnest.

title: Dickens's Uncanny Camera Eye
description: Charles Dickens anticipated a number of the devices and techniques that are ordinarily thought of as having been invented by filmmakers. This accounts in part for the fact that several of his novels, such as David Cooperfield and Great Expectations, have been adapted many times to film. It also partly accounts for the selection b Granada TV of Hard Times, which has been filmed only once before in England in 1915. The first episode in this madeforTV adaptation will be shown this Wednesday evening at 9 on Channel 13

title: Australia, a Land of Seeming Plenty, Falls on Hard Times
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, May 4Australians, who have long thought of themselves as a lucky people, blessed with enormous natural resources and an unusually comfortable style of living, have become embattled in a seemingly endless fight against inflation, unemployment and recession.

title: Molloy Sweeps ShotPut In St. Anthony Games
description: SMITHTOWN L.I., May 7Archbishop Molloy of Queens swept the first three places in the shotput today at the annual Spring games of St. Anthony's High School.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WHEN I RAISED my hand, the moderator recognized me and called my name. I was attending a monthly session of Westport's Representative Town Meeting as an elected Representative.

title: May Is a Bonanza Month for Watching Birds in Transit
description: FOR months, Westchester has been invaded by night. It began in late February with the arrival of the redwinged blackbirds, gained momentum with the robins, yellowthroats and myrtle warblers of March and April, and will build to a climax this month as more than 150 species and thousands of individual birds pass through the county on their way to northern breeding grounds.

title: Deborah Scofield Heintz Is Bride of Bruce Miller
description: Deborah Scofield Heintz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold C. Heintz of Clinton, N. Y., was married yesterday evening to Bruce Lawrence Miller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton H. Miller of Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Ghost. This morning Loretta Lynn is en route from Buffalo, where she gave a concert last night, to Flint, Mich., where she gives a concert this eveningpart of a onemonth, 19city tour that's proving once again her claim to be America's Queen of Country Music. Wherever she goes, copies of her autobiographical Loretta Lynn: Coal Miner's Daughter (Warner) are promoted and sold side by side with her latest MCA record album. Tieins of paperbacks with movies are an old story, but this is probably the first time there's been a threeway deal with a record company and a performer.

title: HOUSE NEARS A VOTE ON URBAN FUND SHIFT THAT AIDS NORTHEAST
description: WASHINGTON, May 7The House of Representatives is expected to pass next week a bill that would fundamentally alter the Federal Government's approach to urban aid, shifting millions of dollars from the Sunbelt to the older cities of the Northeast.

title: Clashes Recur at New Tokyo Airport
description: TOKYO, May 7 (UPI)Student radicals hurled firebombs and stones and scuffled with the police today in protest against Tokyo's new international airport just before a plane made the first landing at the field.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: One current coin glossary answers the question, What is an exonumist? with a neat sidestep: A person knowledgeable in the science of exonumia. Taking it from there exonumia is a wide and roomy basketword to include anything in the field of nongovernmental issues that is of numismatic interest. Here we can lump together medals, wooden nickels, transportation tokens, scrip, love tokens, and decorated silver ingots such as the Nassau 1836 shown here all these are items of exonumia.

title: Philosophy
description: The following article is the fourth in a series on the state of the academic disciplines. The series, to be published at intervals in The Week in Review, will discuss the outstanding debates and question to which each of the disciplines is addressing itself.

title: STAMPS
description: The only body that the governments of the world have ever entrusted with primary responsibility for maintaining world peace, the Security Council of the United Nations, is the subject of four new commemoratives being issued on May 27 by the U.N.

title: Housen Defeats Sacks, Takes Richardson Golf
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 7Bob Housen, medalist in the 30th annual William. D. Richardson Memorial golf tournament, went on to win the title of the tourney today, going to the final hole to do so.

title: 2d RangerRoyal Battle Gets Lucchesi, 4 Ejected
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., May 7 (AP)The Texas Rangers and Kansas City Royals, who brawled earlier this season in Kansas City, had another melee tonight, this one lasting 15 minutes and resulting in the ejection of the Texas manager, Frank Lucchesi, and three of his players.

title: Bonny Campbell Wed to Mefford Runyon 2d
description: Bonny Adair Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Alexander Campbell 2d of Essex Fells, N.J., was married there yesterday to Mefford Ross Runyon 2d, son of H. Mefford Runyon of New York and Shelter Island, N.Y., and the late Anne Henderson Runyon. The Rev. David St. George performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: TennTom and Senator Stennis
description: WASHNGTON. Among the first of the waterdevelopment projects to be taken off President Carter's hit listthe 30 projects he wanted reconsidered was the $1.5 billion TennesseeTombigbee waterway, and the reason may be a courtly silverhaired gentleman named John C. Stennis. Leaning back in a chair in the Vice President's office on Capitol Hill, where for more than 30 years he has been the junior Senator from Mississippi, Stennis allowed the other day that he had been more than somewhat disturbed when he heard some little while ago that TennTom, as the project is known back home, was in danger. There was inflation; there were the environmentalists; and the 1976 Presidential aspirants were all talking about too much government spending.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: In his splendid picture books about an excitable horde of church mice and their courageous protectorcat, Graham Oakley reminds me of God. For one thing he has an Olympian view, like God, who somehow sees the whole universe at once; and for another he seems to have a sort of zoom lens for small detail, again like God, who sees the least sparrow fall.

title: Suspect's Suicide Prompts Family To Investigate Connecticut Slayings
description: GREENWICH, Conn.When 38yearold James M, Klein, a bankrupt New York businessman who had been indicted for the slaying of his former wife, Kim, and her Colombian maid, Martha Lema, committed suicide in February, the case seemed closed before it could be tried.

title: McGovern Charges Carter Has Broken Economic and Welfare Pledges
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Senator George McGovern accused President Carter today of adopting Republican economics, and said that liberals will not be a cheering section for tinkling symbols that may signify nothing.

title: Gina Brill Engaged To Thomas Koger
description: Gina Susan Brill and Thomas Louis Koger, candidates for master's degrees at Michigan State University plan to marry in December.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: EAST ISLIPThe Art of Chivalry, a loan exhibition from Metropolitan Museum of Art; Tuesday through June 5; Public Library, 381 Montauk Hwy. For hours call 5819200.

title: Maternity Fashion BusinessJust Expanding
description: A store for maternity fashions in these days of declining birth rates might appear as relevant as one selling down jackets in the desert. In the peak babyboom year of 1957, 122 babies were born for every 1,000 women aged 15 to 44; by last year the number had dropped to 65 babies. The absolute number of births fell from 4.3 million in 1957 to 3.2 million last year.

title: Legislative Hearings For New York Area
description: The following public hearings will be held in the New York City area this week by committees of the State Legislature:

title: HOME CLINIC
description: THE greatest enemy of brick waifs, chimneys and other structures made of brick is waterthat is, water that penetrates the surface through crumbling mortar joints, cracked or missing bricks and similar defects.

title: ART
description: GREENVALE ACANVAS by Alfred Maurer in an exhibition at the C.W. Post Gallery is simply called The Arrangement, but the breathtaking beauty of the work belies its indifferent title. On loan with nearly 60 other works from the Whitney Museum's permanent collection, the oil, which depicts a young woman in the center of a room, is a luscious homage to a sumptuous palette, sensual paint and a singular attitude toward color and light.

title: High Court Snags New PATH Link
description: STATE and legislative leaders have tentatively concluded that a proposed extension of the PATH rapidtransit system from Newark to Plainfield is dead, at least for the moment.

title: THE FRESH AIR FUND: 100 YEARS OF SUCCESS
description: Sonia Vasquez has never met the Kirby family in West Chester, Pa., but she says that her 8yearold daughter, Dolores, known as Lola, has been growing up with the children of the Kirby family. For the last three summers, Lola has been able to leave the steaming South Bronx to spend some time in a place where, says Lola, It's pretty far to go to the next house.

title: ART
description: WHEN we think of secondaryschool art, which is not too often, we don't tend to think much of it. Our natural prejudices are that creative activity and lower levels of education do not go together.

title: Whither, O Silence? Diary of a Search For Suburban Quiet
description: Isn't it kind of noisy, living so close to the road? a visitor asked.

title: The Bowling Clinic
description: There being 10 pins, and rather strange pinfalls, an almost infinite number of spare combinations are possible when the howler fails to strike. Luckily, though, the same combinations keep cropping up and there are many opportunities to convert them all.

title: DINING OUT
description: IN A COUPLE of years, Chez Leon has become one of the more popular restaurants in its corner of Essex County, the area south of busy Route 46. On a recent visit, it was clear that the atmosphere was friendly and the host attentive and interested in making guests welcome. The staff, too, was polite and industrious.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Arab students in the United States were reported involved in fraudulent insurance claims that might total $5 million. The funds were going, investigators believed, to the Palestine Liberation Organization overseas.

title: Warnke Cites Danger of New Arms
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)The chief United States disarmament negotiator, Paul C. Warnke, says new developments in strategic weapons could increase the danger of nuclear war and might tempt one of the two superpowers to mount an unanswerable first strike against the other.

title: Harnessing TV's Power to Improve Reading Skills
description: AN innovative project in Mount Vernon has enlisted the aid of televisionusually regarded as a deterrent to improved readingto raise the reading, socialstudies and orallanguage scores of students in grades 2 through 12. Modeled on a program in the Philadelphia schools, the Mount Vernon project utilizes carefully selected videotapes and printed scripts as substitutes for standard reading texts.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: CHESS
description: About the middle of the last century, the British player John Owen introduced his defense, 1 PK4, PQN3, but although he defeated the great Paul Morphy with it, it never caught on, virtually disappearing from tournament play around 1890.

title: Two Sides of Perez in His Dances
description: The two sides of Rudy Perez are on display at the Theater of Riverside Church  the intensely personal solos and the playful group pieces. The latter, though, seemed a little diffuse and in need of editing, while his own System was as powerful as ever.

title: The World
description: A general strike in Northern Ireland, called by Protestant extremists to try to force the British to crush the Catholic Irish Republican Army and to restore power to a Protestantdominated Assembly in Belfast, has failed to meet its objectives.

title: Miss Werner Has Nuptials
description: Barbara E. Werner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Werner of New York, was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen C. Kratovil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil A. Kratovil of Greenwich, Conn. Msgr. James G. Wilders performed the ceremony in St. Thomas More's Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Samuel Walker of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: This Local Draft Expert Is at Odds With Selections of the Jets and Giants
description: Joel Buchsbaum, the pro football draft enthusiast from Brooklyn, was less than ecstatic about the skills of the players the Giants and Jets, chose at the National Football. League's selection process last Week. In his thumbnail scouting reports published weeks in advance of the draft, Buchsbaum ranked 600 players and the ratings were either overlooked or ignored by people like Jerry Shay, the Giants' chief scout, or Mike Holovak, who has the same job for the Jets. No pro person has any special interest in giving heed to an amateur like Buchsbaum. Who is right? That cannot be determined until late next summer, or next year if then.

title: THEATER
description: LANA Turner, discovered or not discovered on a sodafountain stool, is a nothing story compared to the star who dazzled Broadway on the night of April 21 at the Alvin Theater in New York City. That was the night that Annie, the musical first seen last summer at the Goodspeed Opera House, opened.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: UNLIKE Lassie, who came home, my beloved 1964 Chevelle is gone for good, I fear. It was stolen on Feb. 25, snatched as I groaned with the flu at my home in Jersey City.

title: Idahoan Sure He Can Thwart Safety Agency
description: POCATELLO, Idaho, May 7Ferrol G. Barlow has been battling the Occupational Safety and Health Administration for two years, and he believes that he has the agency on the run.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Critics are notorious for their hostility toward sequels. True, sequels are often terrible films, quickly and sloppily turned out to cash in on the popularity of a smash hit. Yet critical hostility also may be related to something more basic than esthetics. When a movie ends, all of us, whether we admit it or not, have some idea of what will happen next, or what we want to happen next, and very few sequels can match builtin expectations that are as firmly held as convictions.

title: POLITICS
description: MOST New Yorkers have doubtless forgotten it, but until a little more than three centuries ago the town of Southold, L.I., was the southernmost holding of New Haven Colony. It was bitter loss to New Haven when Southold was written out of the Royal Charter.

title: Golden Fleece
description: SO much money has changed hands as a result of The Thorn Birds one should review Colleen McCullough's financial statement along with her novel. There may be as much drama there as in the book. Avon paid Harper & Row $1.9 million for paperback rights. The Literary Guild is distributing the book as its selection for June, and Hollywood is smiling in the literary shadows, dipping its pen in green ink.

title: Daniel Goodman to Wed Nina Swift on June 11
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Swift of Arlington, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nina Swift, to Daniel Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goodman of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: INTERVIEW
description: GERALD HARRIS, the tall, softspoken lawyer who resigned Friday as county attorney to take on an unaccustomed political role, was reminded recently of his days as assistant district attorney under the late Frank Hogan.

title: The High Cost of Fresh Air
description: Hundreds of thousands of city children have, for the last century, shared these joys. For a few weeks, during the summers, they have been offered an escape from pavements and tenements, as beneficiaries of an annual magic known as The Fresh Air Fund.

title: California Welfare Rolls Rise
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., May 7 (UPI)The number of Californians receiving public assistance in March totaled 2.6 million, an increase of 17,211 from February, state welfare officials reported yesterday. The largest increase, 14,403 people, occurred in the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program, the Department of Benefit Payments said.

title: Depiction of Light
description: On a thematic level, these books have much in common. Both deal with the depiction of light in Italian and FrancoFlemish painting in the first half of the 15th century. Both deal with the relationship of Flemish to Italian landscape painting. Both deal with Renaissance paleography. Yet their approach is so diverse as to be all but irreconcilable.

title: ART
description: HEDDA STERNE, whose art is the subject of an engaging retrospective at the Montclair Art Museum, is an artist of extraordinarily multifarious talents. Her work is so characterized by variety, complexity, richness and discovery that one concludes that no exhibition, no matter how big and representative, Could reflect all of her diverse gifts.

title: Where the Fish Is Always Fresh
description: SOMETIMES it seems as if there is no such thing as fresh fish available any longer; fresh as opposed to fresh frozen, that is. But at the Ocean Fish Company on East Main street in Bridgeport, they deal in nothing but fresh fish every day except Sunday. With changing times, however, it is now trucks, not boats, that bring the fish to this market on the harbortrucks from Fulton, Boston, Point Judith and Maine, carrying everything from squid to steamers, hundreds of pounds of pisces from the cold waters of the Atlantic Ocean and Block Island Sound.

title: RICHARD J. WEIL
description: Richard L. Weil, a former floor partner for the brokerage firm of Burnham & Company, now Drexel Burnham Lambert, died Friday in Miami Beach after a short illness. He was 59 years old and had lived in Wilmington, Vt., since his retirement in 1971.

title: New Rates and Hot Days
description: AN official of the State Public Service Commission has predicted that timeofday and temperaturesensitive rates for. the 900 largest residential and religious customers of the Long Island Lighting Company will be approved by early summer.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIt's the most elusive and exclusive monetary club in the world, an international Skull and Bones that meets in French chateaux, English country houses or on Presidential yachts on the Potomacwhen Presidents still used them.

title: ART
description: WHEN we think of secondaryschool art, which is not too often, we don't tend to think much of it. Our natural prejudices are that creative activity and lower levels of education do not go together.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Sound Cleanup Bog
description: SIX YEARS ago, Congress considered creating a commission to oversee the tremendous cleanup job needed to save Long Island Sound. Instead, another study was scheduled.

title: The Nixon Legacy: Substance Is Second Priority, Style Is First
description: WASHINGTONOn the day that Richard M. Nixon made his emotional reappearance on national television, a news story out of Washington disclosed a confidential memorandum by President Carter's pollster, Patrick H. Caddell. It warned Mr. Carter shortly before he was Inaugurated that unless he stressed style over substance In the early days of his Administration and persuaded the American people of his openness and honesty he might not be able to overcome the strong negative feelings about Washington officialdom. Thus, both his Presidency and his programs could founder.

title: ENCOUNTER
description: The night express from Bucharest to Sofia. Before we reached the Bulgarian border my husband, Richard, had developed severe stomach cramps and a high fever.

title: 1977 National Football League Draft
description: ATLANTA FALCONS

title: Photographer Among Artists
description: ALFRED STIEGLITZ is a figure shrouded by paradox. All biographical accounts suggest a man of immense ego and indomitable selfconfidence. Nevertheless, Stleglitz sacrificed his own career as a photographer and much of his personal financial security for the cause of American modern art. In the early years of this century, he counseled and sustained John Marin, Arthur Dove, and Georgia O'Keeffe and many other important talents with a selflessness that seems to contradict his reputation as dictatorial. insufferable monster.

title: Samuel Blitz, 88, ExAide Of United Jewish Appeal And Leading FundRaiser
description: Samuel Blitz, a former executive vice president of the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York and a fundraiser for Zionist causes, died Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived at 225 Central Park West.

title: Kathryn M. Carey, Jonathan W. Strom, Banker, Wed in Rye
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Kathryn Marie Carey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Carey Jr. of Rye, to Jonathan Whitcomb Strom, son of Mrs. Frank A. Strom of West Falmouth, Mass., and the late Mr. Strom. Msgr. Edward J. Mitty performed the ceremony.

title: The Violence of One Week
description: There is no pattern, no thread. There Is no larger social meaning to drawn, except what Is tired and obvious and painful: This is a time of unspeakOble violence. Last week in the New York metropolitan area, there were four crimes that were particularly grotesque.

title: 40 Decorators, 45 Projects, 1 Mansion
description: THE WHEELER mansion in Fairfield, only recently in crumbling decay, has been transformed into a literal show house. It's a show house for decorators a charitable project of the Junior League of Greater Bridgeport.

title: THE PRICE OF FAME
description: If Charles Lindbergh really did not consider lumsel a hero, he would be at ease visiting Aviation High School in Queens, New York. Most at the students there don't consider him a hero, either.

title: BRIDGE
description: BRIDGE tournaments, with few exceptions, are open to all corners, so in the Connecticut Championships some of the titles usually go to visitors from New York, Boston or other centers.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: New York 11, Oakland 2.

title: Casinos Bring Atlantic City Woes
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 7Fires, the condemnation of slum housing and the destruction of small hotels are driving out many elderly and poor as this seaside resort begins to experience sociological consequences in a prelude to the opening of gambling casinos.

title: Births
description: Ashen

title: 7 Counties Reduce Spending for 1977
description: THE mandated cap on budget increases, additional state aid to education from the income tax and strenuous efforts at economy have decreased county expenditures for the first time in 10 years, a study of new appropriations discloses.

title: Slaying Suspect Kills 3 Hostages And Takes Own Life Despite Pact
description: LINCOLN, Kan., May 7 (AP)A man being sought for a murder in St. Louis tool three members of a farm family hostage today, then killed them and took his own life despite a police agreement that would have allowed him to flee unharmed, officers said.

title: U.S. Six Captures Finale
description: VIENNA, May 7The United States team closed out its stay at the World hockey championships tonight with a scrappy 32 victory over Finland. The Americans finished with three victories, a tie and six defeats.

title: Robert Wilson Builds a New Play
description: Last December, less than two weeks after the second (and probably final) New York performance of his Einstein on the Beach, Robert Wilson said that he was writing a new theatrical worka oneperson piece that would represent another departure in his remarkable, original theater. After his collaboration onEinstein (principally with Philip Glass as the composer and Andy de Groat as the choreographer), and after working with scores of performers in his earlier theatrical works, Wilson planned something conceptually simple, about 90 minutes long, with just himself as author, director, designer and sole performer. I feel like I want to go back to myself,, he said, and see what will come from me. The work, which starts performances at the cherry Lane Theater on Tuesday, has the monstrous title of I Was Sitting on My Patio This Guy Appeared I Thought I Was Hallucinating.

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: DR. MARTIN GOLDFIELD, former Assistant State Commissioner of Health, has learned that there may be some truth in two old adages: that the boss may be wrong, but that he (or she) is still the boss, and that a prophet is without honor in his own country.

title: Italian Communist Party Offering A Key Position to Czech Dissident
description: VIENNA, May 6  The Italian Communist Party, in a gesture that irked Czechoslovak officials, has offered a job in Rome to a leading signer of the human rights manifesto known as Charter 77. He is Milan Hubl, who headed the Communist Party College when Alexander Dubcek unsuccessfully attempted to liberalize the system in 1968.

title: Gregorek's 4:17.1 Mile Leg Wins for St. Anthony Team
description: John Gregorek, St. Anthony's junior, lost a tough twomile race on Friday in a violent storm, went to his junior prom that night until 3 A.M., and returned to the New York Relays yesterday afternoon at St. John's University to anchor the Smithtown, L. I., foursome to victory in the distance medley.

title: In Washington, Tennis Nets the Guests
description: WASHINGTONTennis is a great equalizerSenators don't seem quite so senatorial in tennis shorts, said Richard Jencks, former vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting Company. That perhaps helps to explain why the Washington indoor tennis party and tennis fundraiser are beginning to give the little diplomaic dinner and the charity ball some competition on the local social scene.

title: Babylonian Mysteries
description: MARK MIRSKY is not a peaceful man. He'd rather argue than talk  a Talmudic trait, he would say  and doesn't mind browbeating his reader. Above all, he is a Jew of the wandering variety: disheveled, madcap, a little angry most of the time. He probably wouldn't get past the doorman of those sleek suburban synagogues which, to him, represent a Jewish nightmare.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: Today  Trenton K.C. 48th allbreed show and obedience trial, Mercer County Park, Edinburgh and Old Post Road, West Windsor Township, N.J.; 2,859 dogs; 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: May 14  Triumph Sports Car Club of New Jersey 60mile T.S.D. rally; start at Club House, Route 46 westbound, Fairfield, N.J. Registration: 7 P.M., first car off 8:01. Information: Emil Lavagno, phone (201)3348321.

title: His Rivals Hail Victor As Class
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7When it was over, Seattle Slew still was undedeated, untied and unscoredupon, and the first admiring vote was cast by his trainer, Billy Turner, who said: He did what he had to dohe overcame adversity.

title: Canadiens Rout Bruins To Open Cup Finals, 73
description: MONTREAL, May 7The Montreal Canadiens, having won a rugged semifinal series from the New York Islanders on Thursday night, thought they were too tired. The Boston Bruins thought they were too rested.

title: The news service that nourishes the intellect...and the inner man.
description: An increasing number of newspapers and other journals in this country and abroad now utilize The New York Times News Service as a basic news source. For these publications, the News Service is not just a supplementary or extra wire. It's a fundamental resource for major national and international news; for background coverage, analysis, columns, consumeroriented featuresand much, much more.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$9,000,pace, mile.

title: Engagements
description: Mass. announce the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolyn Cordula, to Mr. Paul Fagerburg of Oakland, Calif., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. L. Fagerburg of Bloomington, III. The marriage ceremony and reception take place at the home of the bridelobe on Saturday, September 24th at 5 P.M. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Jones of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church will officiate.

title: Even With Partition (in 1920), They've Never Entirely Relaxed
description: BELFAST, Northern IrelandIt would be easy to say that the origins of the Protestant rage in Northern Ireland are lost in history. But little of Ulster's bloody history has ever been lost, and that is a large part of its trouble.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: FOR those who have been skeptical about the power and stamina of the current recovery cycle in the American economy, recent developments provided little confirmation for their fears. Only the discordant tenor of the news on the inflation front has lent substance to their belief that the economy may soon be headed for significant trouble. Even there, however, the dark clouds may appear more ominous than they really are.

title: The Favorite's Day
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 7  Like most of the other tourists at the 103d Kentucky Derby, Seattle Slew had precious little sleep last night, and perhaps that is why he was dozing in the gate when J. T. Wagoner pressed the starter's button today. Jean Cruguet woke his mount up hastily and the unbeaten colt ran the race of his young life to whip 14 of the best 3yearolds in America. He had raced six times before without ever finding a horse that could test him but this time they asked him the question. He had the answer, putting the pacemaking For the Moment away as he turned into the stretch and holding off Run Dusty Run in the last punishing quarter. He did it on three hours' sleep, for it was 1 A.M. and the Churchill Downs stable area was silent before he lay down on his bed of straw last night. Within minutes he was snoring.

title: India's Health Plan Seeks Birth Control Without Coercion
description: NEW DELHIThe Indian government has drafted new programs for providing health care for villagers and promoting birth control. They were announced at a twoday conference here of health officials.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The most interesting tensions at the Longacre, where Al Pacino is appearing for a limited engagement in a revival of David Rabe's The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel, are tensions that were never written into the script, tensions that don't even belong to it. Pavlo Hummel, as David Rabe wrote him, is a nonentity, a loner and a loser whose father deserted him and whose mother didn't even come to see him off at the station when he left for Vietnam, a boy who's changed his name from Michael to Pavlo a vain search for identity and who is now counting on finding that identity in the new role of soldier. War, he is certain, will make him into something deserving of respect; what it makes him is dead, dead of a hand grenade maliciously tossed into a brothel. A cipher to begin with and, at the last, a cipher zipped into a rubber bag headed for a refrigerated morgue. From nobody to nothing, without trumpets, without drums.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE AISLES in Sagaponack's Greek taverna, the Old Stove Pub, are too crowded for dancing to the plinking beat of recorded bouzouki music. In the weathered farmhouse set back from the highway, the Johnides family seats dinner guests in rustic, whitewashed rooms at the start of another season. The atmosphere is as relaxed and friendly as ever. The comfortable informality appeals to weekenders and vacationers who regard the Hamptons as a place to unwind and who have no patience for pretensions.

title: TV VIEW
description: In the supermarket of television programming, few products are more essential to the basic diet than comedy. The ability to laugh remains a fairly reliable indication of sanity. Unfortunately, the comedy product frequently is highly perishable. The standup comic can no longer depend on a single hour of material to get through a year or two of steady employment. One appearance on national television gobbles up the act. Fresh items are demanded. The cycle is relentless. There's a builtin escalation of expectations. Even Ernie Kovacs, widely recognized as an early master of the medium and whose shows are now being revived on public television, must be presented with a warning that he takes his time, that he does not conform to today's slicker standards. The sheer acceleration tends to breed hysteria.

title: Who Should Audit the Auditors?
description: If the accounting profession offers a public good, the question of regulation is in order, Regulation by whom? At present the profession's own. Financial Accounting Standards Board sets guiding principles and the standards for reporting. This is selfregulation by experts of the private sector, Should this continue? Some people think the job has fallen short, and a hard debate is now going on in the profession and in Congress.

title: A Fair Test for the Concorde
description: THE AngloFrench Concorde SST has been flying in commercial service for well over a year. In that time, and in more than six years of testflying leading up to commercial operation, the aircraft has visited airports throughout the world. The one major airport it has never visited is John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: GARDENING
description: PLANTING a garden is fun. There is something about turning over the soil, tucking in young plants or seeds and watching them grow. Now, while the planting season is at its height, many new homeowners are getting near their soil for the first time. What they used to call dirt becomes something special it's alive!

title: Rx for a Dying Lake
description: GLOBS of red algae appeared recently on the surface of Lake Wononscopomuc, a visible sign of the pollution that is killing the body of water, one of the largest and most beautiful in the northwest corner of the state.

title: Leaders Voice a Growing Concern Over Unemployment Among Young
description: LONDON, May 7The leaders of the major industrial democracies expressed growing concern today at their economic conference about the continuing high level of unemployment, especially among young people. About 40 percent of the 15 million unemployed in the 24 Western member countries of the Organisation of Economic Cooperation and Development are under 25 years old.

title: Notes: Trade Ban Slows Cuban Tourism
description: President Carter announced the removal of the ban on travel by Americans to Cuba two months ago, and tour operatorsanticipating the move had already created tour packages with the cooperation of the Cubans and invited travelers to sign on. However, the explosive demand (as one operator described it) from Americans to visit the island has not been satisfied. No groups of ordinary tourists have set foot in Havana to dance the rhumba in celebration of the resumption of travelstopped when the Eisenhower Administration broke off diplomatic relations with the Castro Government in 1961. The reason: financial restrictions.

title: Carter Urged to Spend Fuel Taxes on Transportation
description: WASHINGTON, May 7  Transportation Secretary Brock Adams has urged President Carter to use petroleum conservation taxes first to meet transportation funding and to use them for other purposes only after transportation needs were met, it was disclosed today.

title: 2Party Pact in Colombia Falters as Elections Near
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 2The national agreement under which the Liberal and Conservative Parties have cooperated in governing Colombia for nearly 20 years has been badly weakened under President Alfonso Lpez Michelsen.

title: New Suspect on 10 Most Wanted
description: WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)Raymond Levasseur, 30 years old, described as a member of a revolutionary group that finances its operations through criminal activities, was placed yesterday on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's 10 Most Wanted List.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 2) Lamp Unto My Feet: Pope Shenouda 3d of the Coptic Church.

title: Insurance Cancellation:
description: IF you have an automobileinsurance policy, the odds are that your premium will increase, and that before too long you will receive computer notice saying: Your policy will not be renewed. Contact your agent for insurance coverage. The notice will not tell you why your premium dollars are no longer acceptable; you will have to sit down and review the events involving your car to try to ferret out the reason.

title: THE PRICE OF FAME
description: papers printed millions of hyperbolic wordsa good many of them farfelchedabout the flight about Lindbergh's reception in Paris and about him. Within days, honors, medals and receptions were pressed upon him. Crowned heads vied to receive him, including George V of Britain, who wanted most to know how the ther had relieved his bladder on the long trip, it was just the sort of commonsensical question Lindbergh liked, so he explained in some how his relief tube worked.

title: City Prison Inmates Are Only Part of the Trouble
description: At 6 A.M. today, like every other day, New York City's 4,000 House of Detention prisoners were awakened by prisonguard whistles or amplified radio music to start another day during which boredom would seem to be the least difficulty. In the last seven years, the city's penal system has been wracked by riots for better conditions, racial fights among inmates and numerous escape attempts.

title: Judaism Without Supernaturalism' Celebrates 55 Years
description: The sounds of Israeli dance music mixed with laughter and a few tears at the rooftop dining room of the Time & Life Building Saturday night. About 170 members of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism were there to celebrate the 55th anniversary of their synagogue, one that has been controversial since its founding, and to mark the 50th birthday of their radical rabbi, Alan W. Miller, whom they imported from England 15 years ago.

title: Israel Is Worried U.S. May Change Arms Export Rules
description: TEL AVIV. May 8Israeli leaders said today they were deeply concerned that their special arms supply relationship with the United States might be threatened by a proposed change limiting preferrednation status in arms exports to nations with formal security treaties.

title: First St. Augustine to Be Rebuilt
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., May 8 (AP)The nation's first permanent settlement will be recreated as it looked in 1580, the St. Augustine Restoration Foundation announced yesterday. The recreated settlement will be built on a site off U.S. 1 at the northern edge of the city.

They didn't waste the opportunity as Keith Eddy scored, giving the Cosmos a 32 victory over the Connecticut Bicentennials before 17,302 fans at the Yale Bowl.

title: Teachers in Kansas City Vote to Return to Work
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 (UPI)About 700 striking teachers voted today to return to their classrooms tomorrow and end a sevenweek walkout.

description: WASHINGTON, May 8 (UPI)The Government's program of preparedness against nuclear and natural disasters is an uncoordinated, manyheaded monstrosity that is filled with duplication and neglect, says a Congressional report released today.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 8 (AP)The police investigating the killing of an eccentric widow are looking for three men whom they suspect may have previously burglarized her home. The woman, in whose home the killers overlooked more than $5 million in hidden cash, once refused to prosecute the three, the police said today.

description: TRENTON, May 8 (UPI)New Jersey prosecutors have sharply criticized lawenforcement authorities, saying they neglected crimes committed by minors, and have called for an overhaul of the juvenile justice system, including the upgrading in the status of the Domestic and Juvenile Relations Court.

description: Atop midtown Manhattan's third tallest skyscraperCitibank's new building on Lexington Avenue at 53d Streetsits a metal gridwork slanted to the south that looks like the makings of an ideal giant greenhouse.

title: ExOfficials Quit Congress Party
description: NEW DELHI, May 8 (Reuters)  A member of former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's cabinet and four former members of Parliament were among nine persons who resigned from her defeated Congress Party today. Dinesh Singh. minister in Mrs. Gandhi's cabinet until 1971. and the others said in their resignation letter that they were quitting the party because it was moving away from its basic policies and programs.

description: Mike Torrez shakes his head and smiles in awe and in appreciation. Other people, the ones who don't play for the Yankees, shake their heads and grimacein awe and in fear.

title: News Summary
description: Proclaiming their solidarity, the leaders of the major Western industrialized democracies ended their economic conference in London. They asserted their determination to cooperate on a series of measures against unemployment and their tradedeficit difficulties brought about by the high costs of imported oil. President Carter's proposals to halt the spread of nuclear technology were rejected and the issue was turned over to two study groups. [Page 1, Column 6]

title: Bullfight Sets Off Clash in Portugal
description: LISBON, May 8 (Reuters)Violence flared in the central town of Vila Franca de Xira early today after the arrest of two bullfighters who defied Portugal's ban on killing bulls in the ring, the police said. Several hundred demonstrators protesting the arrests clashed with riot police. Three persons were treated for slight injuries.

title: Grand Jury May Check Press Reports on Crime in Arizona
description: PHOENIX, May 3A month after the last of almost 100.000 words about crime in Arizona were published by an unusual team of investigative reporters, the project remains controversial, both in Arizona and in American journalism.

title: For Many, Turning 30 Is Like Stubbing a Toe on a Milestone
description: Mary Spletter, a California writer and wife of a research chemist, turned 30 the other day and celebrated by cutting her long dark hair and getting her ears pierced.

title: Streamlining the Criminal Law
description: When men of such varying outlooks as John McClellan, Edward Kennedy and Griffin Bell get together to push a project, then the enterprise deserves more than passing attention. In this case what the Senators and the Attorney General are pushing is a 297page revision of the criminal code of the United States. Last year's version, called S. 1, died a welldeserved death. It was studded with a variety of repressive provisions. In the interest of modernizing the Federal criminal laws, Senators McClellan and Kennedy busied themselves between sessions and cleaned up the revision. They have come up with something that merits enactment.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in The Times on April 29, reference was made to a foundation established by John M. Olin. That organization has no connection with the Olin Foundation Inc. of New York, which makes grants to private colleges and universities for the construction of academic buildings.

description: A survey of purchasing agents shows that three out of four expect the economic recovery to continue for the next 12 months but that uncertainty prevails over rising prices and energy problems.

title: 20,000 Reds in Spain Attend Election Rally
description: MADRID, May 8 (AP)About 20,000 Communists, some carrying red banners and wearing red baseball hats, attended a rally in a soccer stadium today to begin the newly legalized party's election campaign.

title: Textile Makers Order More Machinery to Cut Costs
description: The once laborintensive textile industry is moving toward higher capital investment in order to produce goods at lower cost to meet the competition of imports from countries where labor is cheap.

title: 'Black and White in Color' Focuses Less on War Than Leadership
description: The setting is the dry, hot savannah of West Africa in late 1914. The inhabitants of a small French trading post in the interior live in easy alliance with the members of a tiny German garrison a few miles away. They don't fraternize exactly, but they get along in their separate spheres of boredom.The German sergeant spends his days seeing that his handful of black troops maintains military routine. The French sergeant, though, lazes about, drinks wine with the French shopkeepers and their wives and gossips about the peculiar geologist who shares their existence, but never seems to be a part of it. The young Frenchman is different from them, meaning he's educated.This somnolent peace is destroyed with the arrival of an old Paris newspaper with the word of the outbreak of war. "Who with?" asks one Frenchman. "Germany." "That's strange," says the first. "I would have thought it would be with England." The small crew of boozing, foolish French patriots, with the spiritual support of their two resident priests, decides to march on the German fort for the greater glory of France.Their war begins cheerfully with a picnic lunch attended by the ladies, who have come along to watch the tricolor raised over the German fort. Instead, they see their troops (about two dozen hastily impressed, disinterested blacks who carry their guns on their heads) vanquished by a single machine gun.This is the beginning of "Black and White in Color" and it is not terribly promising. There's hardly a clich overlooked by Jean-Jacques Annaud, the director, as he sets his scene for yet another film on the senselessness of war. The Germans are bears for discipline. The French are hysterical, convivial. The priests are fat-bellied and venal and the blacks infinitely patient with the idiosyncracies of the civilized.But stick with "Black and White in Color" a little longer. What starts as a broad, obvious, rather pious comedy peopled by musical-comedy types turns into something much more complex as it goes along. It's less about the senselessness of war (a movie that is pro-war on principle might be more easy to become excited about) than it is about the way extraordinary times and circumstances can create leaders.The central figure of the film is Hubert, the French geologist (Jacques Spiesser), the soft-spoken, self-assured, almost pretty young man who, after unsuccessfully trying to stop the original attack against the German fort, becomes the acknowledged commander of the desperate Frenchmen. The way Hubert takes charge is comic and mysterious. He is decisive, blunt, polite, cruel, high-handed and distant. Like De Gaulle, he always behaves properly, but he doesn't tolerate fools.As the young man finds his character, so does the movie. In an excellent scene in the midst of the crisis, after Hubert has bulldozed his compatriots into some form of order, the young man makes his first official appearance (at a review of the French "troops") with his stunning-looking, ever-mute but extremely haughty black mistress on his arm. There's nothing for these cowed, petit-bourgeois French shopkeepers to do but bow and curtsy to the consort.The performances also improve immensely as the film moves on. At the beginning, Jean Carmet and Jacques Dufilho as, respectively, the lazy sergeant and the hysterical shopkeeper (a sort of spin-off of the characters played by Louis De Eunes), are numbingly predictable, but later, as supporting characters, they become very funny. Mr. Spiesser is fine as the assertive young leader. It's a performance that reveals itself so quietly that it's not until the film is almost over that one understands what's happeningand because I'm not allowed to reveal the ending, I can only say that the final sequence of the film makes everything that's gone before worth attending to."Black and White in Color," which opened yesterday at the Paris Theater, was awarded the Oscar as the best foreign-language film this year as the entry from the Ivory Coast, where the movie was shot. There's been some flak about this because the film's executive producer is Swiss and its director, writers and most of the cast are French. In winning the Oscar, it had to beat both "Seven Beauties" and "Cousin, Cousine," which says less about the quality of the winner than the peculiar rules by which the members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences vote in this category."Black and White in Color," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some minor nudity and a few vulgar expressions that, in subtitles, look like the sort of graffiti one might see scribbled in much larger print on any New York bus or subway car.

title: Aspin Charges Navy and Panel Try to Thwart Carrier Decision
description: WASHINGTON. May 8A Democratic Congressman charged today that the Navy establishment and the House Armed Services Committee were seeking to subvert a decision by the Carter Administration and Congress to build smaller aircraft carriers and end the construction of expensive, Nimitzclass, nuclearpowered ships.

title: Spanish Police Prevent Carlists From Holding Memorial Ceremony
description: PAMPLONA, Spain, May 8 (UPI)Roadblocks manned by hundreds of armed police today turned back thousands of Carlists, monarchists who support a rival to King Juan Carlos as the legitimate monarch, from their annual visit to a holy mountain in the Basque region.

description: WASHINGTON, May 8A deadly virus that is extraordinarily difficult to detect or destroy has apparently been accidentally transplanted through surgery to at least four persons.

description: Under what the New York State Superintendent of Insurance call clouded circumstances, the fourth largest automobile insurer in the state is on the verge of bankruptcy and its 300,000 policyholders are in a limbo of uncertainty over claims and coverage.

title: Beame Jabs Again at Governor's Support of Cuomo
description: Governor Carey doesn't seem to trust the judgment of the very people who elected him. Mayor Beame said yesterday, continuing to express shock at Mr. Carey's reported promise to support Mario M. Cuomo for Mayor of New York, even if Mr. Cuomo is defeated in the Democratic primary.

title: Brooklyn Church Honors a Special Mother
description: Mother's Day, resplendent with festive hats, spring dresses, spirited music, a little politicking and lovely afternoon sunlight slanting through stainedglass windows, was celebrated at a church in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday by a tribute to Ruby Dee, the actress.

title: Market Place
description: Now that institutional brokerage has become only marginally profitable, the small investor, recently a Wall Street stepchild, is being wooed as never before by leading brokerage firms.

title: Arrested Antinuclear Protesters Allowed to Play on Armory Lawn
description: SOMERSWORTH, N.H., May 8On the lawn of the National Guard Armory here this morning, imprisoned antinuclear demonstrators threw Frisbees, danced, flipped each other in the air with a blanket turned into a makeshift trampoline, kicked a soccer ball and played on a guitar and flute under a warm sun. They were held in bounds by a single strand of rope and a handful of casually watching Guardsmen.

description: DERBY. Conn., May 8Cornell's varsity crew won the Carnegie Cup from Yale today by two lengths and there was no third boat. Where was Princeton? The Tigers canceled their participation in the annual regatta because of numerous cases of illness, mostly bronchitis, within the Princeton rowing contingent.

title: Princeton Names Dean
description: Dr. Joan S. Girgus was named dean, of the college at Princeton University. Dr. Girgus, who is currently dean of the social sciences division of the City University of New York, will succeed Dr. Neil L. Rudenstine, whose appointment as provost of the university was announced last month. Her duties as dean of the college will include responsibility for the undergraduate curriculum, and the oversight of admissions, financial aid and other undergraduate services.

title: Danes Badminton Victors
description: MALMO, Sweden, May 8 (UPI)Denmark won the men's and women's singles titles today at the first world badminton championships. Lena Koppen, a 24yearold Copenhagen dental student, defeated England's Gillian Gilks, 129, 1211, in the women's final. Fleming Dells beat another Dane, Svend Pri. 155, 156, for the men's crown.

title: Look Who Came to Dinner
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8Going past the clubhouse the first time aboard For the Moment, Angel Cordero glanced to his right and saw Seattle Slew. I say to my horse, Look who's coming to dinner, Angel said when the Kentucky Derby was over. Twenty seconds earlier, For the Moment and 13 other opponents had left the oddson favorite back at the quarterpole standing in the gate, and when Slew chose to run he slewed around to face the grandstand. In this emergency Jean Cruguet, whom some consider no better than a curse on a horse, took charge. He swung Slew's head around, took dead aim at the horse race, and fired. Within an eighth of a mile, Slew was among the leaders but in a pocket near the rail. But if I take back, Cruguet said later, I'm in trouble. They lost no time, said Billy Turner, the trainer, putting him in tight and keeping him there.

title: RollsRoyce Plan To Build Engines With Pratt Ended
description: The world's biggest builder of jet engines, Pratt & Whitney, disclosed yesterday the collapse of a planned partnership with Britain's RollsRoyce Ltd. in producing the engine it hopes will power the projected new Boeing airliner.

title: Second Case of Cholera in U.S. I In 65 Years Is Found in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 8 (UPI)An official of the Center for Disease Control confirmed today the second case of cholera contracted within the United States in more than 65 years.

title: Heroin Held Less Harmful Than Liquor and Smoking
description: SAN FRANCISCO. May 8 (AP)Alcohol and cigarette smoking are unquestionably more harmful to the body than heroin, according to research by a criminal justice professor.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Have the rich industrial nations of the North made a serious mistake in underestimating the threat to their economic stability and military security in the rising demands of the poor, developing countries for a new international economic order'? And have the developing countries, tries, at the same time, made a comparable blunder in pursuing a strategy based on the assumption that their own economic advancement depends on forcing a transfer of wealth and income from North to South?

title: Partial Rollback for Steel Sought by Administration
description: WASHINGTON, May 8The Carter Administration today stepped up pressure for a partial rollback of steel price increases announced last Friday by the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company.

title: A Mother Gets an Unusual Gift
description: BOONE, N.C. May 8 (UPI)Nora South Eggers, 87 years old, received from her son and grandson a Mother's Day present that rekindled fond memories. They bought her the Methodist Church building where she attended services as a child and put it in her back yard.

title: Ailing Australian Economy Disenchants the Voters
description: CANBERRA, Australia  A year and a half after Malcolm Fraser swept to victory as Prime Minister with the greatest majority in Australian history, he has come under increasing criticism for his seemingly inconsistent and so far ineffectual efforts to restore the country's oncebooming economy.

title: FREDERICK M. STERN, 87, WROTE EXPOSE ON NAZIS
description: Frederick M. Stern, the author of The Junker Menace, an expos of the roots of Nazism, died Friday at his home, 45 East End Avenue. He was 87 years old.

title: FURTHER RISE SEEN FOR INTEREST RATES
description: Interest rates throughout the money and bond markets rose sharply last week for the second week in a row in response to the Federal Reserve's action in raising the Federalfunds ratethe basic rate of the money markethalf a percentage point during the last fortnight. By the end of the week, there seemed to be a consensus that interest rates are headed still higher. But there was some disagreement about how fast the rise would take place and about the extent to which the rise would affect longterm bond yields.

title: EYEWITNESS WRONG, BUT JUSTICE PREVAILS
description: In the long run, Jerome Williams, who was accused of petit larceny, found blind justice more reliable a friend than the stranger who claimed to have witnessed everything and came to court to proclaim the young defendant's innocence.

title: Bridge:
description: Peter Weichsel and Alan Sontag of New York City took the halftime lead in the Cavendish Club invitational tournament held over the weekend, putting together two strong sessions for a score of 1,467. Weichsel and Sontag, last year's winners, were 201 points ahead of Jack Blair of Tulsa, Okla., and Robert Levin of Miami.

description: NEWARK, May 8A conference of black lawyers accused the American legal system today of failing to overcome the racial prejudices of judges, prosecutors and juries.

description: WEST POINT, N.Y., May 8The United States Military Academy's golf course has been described by some tired players as the bestkept obstacle course ever devised for infantry recruits.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 8  The appointment of a San Francisco city supervisor as Assistant Secretary of the Interior has come under criticism here because of his threeyearold campaign debts.

title: Books of the Times
description: There is a story In Max Apple's recent collection, The Oranging of America, called The Yogurt of Vasirin Kefirovsky. Kefirovsky is a caricature of Immanuel Velikovsky. Instead of Worlds in Collision, he wrote Worlds in Confusion. In his old age, he eats nothing but yogurt. He is, indeed, a priest of yogurt, believing it to be the Biblical manna: What is the promised land? Milk and honey and time. What is yogurt? Milk and bacteria and time. Why did people who lived on manna for forty years want a land of milk and honey? Why not a land of pomegranates? Why not a land of barley and sesame seed and olive oil? Why not wine and cheese? Where else do you read about milk and honey? Nowhere. I've looked.

title: Some Army Officers Answer the Call to Beauty
description: A troop of Army officers marched into Kenneth's the other morning and left five hours later, looking just gorgeous in their words. Hair restyled, eyelashes mascara'd, they swore they didn't recognize one another.

title: Patricia Hearst to Be Sentenced
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8 (UPI)Patricia Hearst, the heiress who was first a captive and then a meaner of an underground terrorist group. is to he sentenced tomorrow for robbery and assault with deadly weapon. Miss Hearst, 33 years old. faces possible penalties ranging from life in prison to probation. Under a new California law which goes into effect in July, she could be sentenced to 11 years. The charges, two of 11 for which she was originally indicted, stem from a 1974 incident at a sporting goods store in Englewood.

title: Czechoslovak Six Loses, But Retains World Crown
description: VIENNA, May 8Although, it was swamped by Canada tonight, Czechoslovakia retained its World hockey title here when the Soviet Union, needing only a tie to take the championship, lost to Sweden.

title: In Soviet Turkmenia Today, Camels and Crisp Shashlik
description: ASHKHABAD, U.S.S.RThe camel regarded an interloping newsman through fluffy blond eyelashes, registered a genteel snort of annoyance and sauntered off to inspect a morsel of spring grass that had sprouted through the sand.

title: Intoxication Arrests Banned by New Law
description: A new law banning the police from arresting drunken New Jerseyans goes into effect today despite fears that it is almost impossible to enforce because of the lack of treatment facilities.

title: Inquiry on Pittsburgh Job Program May Touch 3 on the Steelers Team
description: PITTSBURGH, May 8A widening investigation of a federally funded manpower program in Allegheny County may yield evidence of fraud totaling as much as $2 million and may result in criminal charges against more than 50 persons, county officials say.

title: JAWORSKI REPORTS BLANK ON NIXONMITCHELL TAPE
description: HOUSTON, May 8 (UPI)Leon Jaworski, the former Watergate special prosecutor, said today that, in addition to the famous 18minute gap on a White House tape recording, a Dictabelt that was subpoenaed from President Nixon had turned out to be almost blank.

title: Inquiries Center on Tournament
description: The current boxing scandal centers on the United States Boxing Championships, a tournament promoted by Don King, the flamboyant exconvict and exnumbers racketeer who had become the sports biggest promoter. His tournament, financed by ABCTV, was suspended by the network after it found that boxers' records had been falsified.

title: Theater: Silk Stockings Revived
description: A few blocks from the Equity Library Theater, at 103d Street and Riverside Drive, where Cole Porter's 1955 musical Silk Stockings is playing in a handsome, stylish revival, a West Side Marxist festival was going on the other afternoon. During a quick walkby, blaring rock music dominated the festival and, on the way to the theater, one couldn't help wondering how Nina, the stern, nofrills Soviet commissar of the show, would have fit in with these fellow ideologues.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Church Protests at a Topless Bar
description: About a hundred Sunday worshipers, mostly mothers with children in tow, marched from the Ebenezer Missionary Baptist Church in Flushing, Queens, to a topless bar a block away in a Mother's Day protest against sex establishments in their community.

title: Report From U.N. Program Tells How It Used Special Currencies
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 8The United Nations Development Program, the world's largest channel for technical assistance. has purchased computers from the Soviet Union and hired Chinese contractors to work in Laos as part of an effort to reduce the accumulation of nonconvertible currencies, according to a report last week.

title: The Standings
description: Monday, May 9, 1977

title: TRAVERSE CLEMENTS, 77, SOCIALIST PARTY OFFICIAL
description: Traverse Clements, national secretary of the American Socialist Party from 1939 to 1942 and manager of Norman Thomas's campaign for the Presidency in 1940, died ofheart failure Wednesday in Neuchatel, Switzerland, where he had been visiting. He was 77 years old and lived in Bethel, Conn.

title: Commodities
description: If there was one ray of sunshine in the otherwise gloomy inflation outlook last week it was the further sharp decline in the index of commodity futures prices.

title: Stockton and Amritraj Capture Doubles Final
description: KANSAS CITY, May 8 (AP)Dick Stockton and Vijay Amritraj used a flurry of hard smashes and capitalized on the team inexperience of Adriano Panatta and Vitas Gerulaitis to win the doubles championship of World Championship Tennis today.

title: Telling Workers Where to Live
description: Should the people who work for New York City be required to live in it? The question seems simple, but the answers are not. Answers are needed because a bill to require city workers to live in New York moving toward passage in Albany. Since a similar law was repealed in 1962, Republicans have generally blocked its reenactment because some of their suburban constituents work for the city. The new bill would not affect anyone hired before next August, thus mollifying Republican critics. It would, however, require that a person live in the city as long as he holds a city job.

title: Yonkers Joins Waste Disposal Plan
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 7Westchester's effort to establish a countywide solidwaste disposal system moved closer to realization this week when Yonkers, its largest municipality, agreed to participate and the County Board of Legislators asked the State Legislature to give the county the power to enforce the program.

title: Nanny Was Wrong About Mister Roosevelt
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  Nighttime was scary when I was a boy. We didn't have the energy worries like the ones President Carter has been telling us about. It seems nowadays that we conserved more energy then.

title: Marshall Splits With Carter Aides On Estimating Cost of Regulations
description: WASHINGTON, May 8In an open break with top Carter Administration economic officials, Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall has questioned the intent and value of an elaborate plan that would require Government agencies to estimate the cost to industry from proposed regulations.

title: Tennis
description: AT PORTLAND, ME.

title: Trail Blazers Lead Lakers, 20
description: LOS ANGELES, May 8 (AP)Herm Gilliam, a reserve guard for the Trail Blazers, pumped in 14 points in the final quarter, including the goahead field goal, to spark the Trail Blazers to a 9997 triumph over the Los Angeles Lakers today. The victory gave Portland a 20 lead in their fourofsevengame semifinal playoff series.

title: World Team Tennis
description: SATURDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: Chess:
description: To win, says the Danish grandmaster Bent Larsenone of the most successful tournament competitors of our timeit is necessary to accept lost positions.

title: LAWYERS' GROUP TO RAISE MONEY FOR CANDIDATES
description: TRENTON, May 8 (UPI)About 500 New Jersey lawyers formed a group this weekend to raise campaign money for state Senate, Assembly and gubernatorial candidates.

title: Warren Lynch, 62, Vice Chairman Of BookoftheMonth Club, Dies
description: Warren Lynch, vice chairman of the BookoftheMonth Club, Inc. and the chairman of its executive committee, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack while playing tennis in the Bronx. He was 62 years old and lived at 115 East 67th Street.

title: Child Panel Gets Leader
description: The Citizens Committee for Children of New York, a 170member leadership group, has named as its new executive director Larold K. Schulz, who has been executive director of the United Church of Christ's Office for Church in Society since 1973.

title: Pakistani Opposition Rejects Offer By Bhutto for Talks on Its Demands
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 8 (UPI)The opposition Pakistan National Alliance today rejected Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto's offer to hold preliminary talks on its demands for ending the country's political crisis.

title: Terrier Takes Top Prize in 2d Straight Show
description: WEST WINDSOR TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 8Ch. Harwire Hetman of Whinlatter beat more than 5,700 dogs in two shows this weekend, ending with the Trenton Kennel Club's 48th event tonight at Mercer County Park.

title: Yachting
description: AT LARCH MONT Y.C. Y.R.A. SPRING REGATTA

title: DEFENSE CHIEF TELLS INTELLIGENCE GROUPS TO STAY WITHIN LAW
description: WASHINGTON, May 8Secretary of Defense Harold Brown has told the members of the various military intelligence agencies that their operations should be conducted strictly within the law and that he expects them to report without hesitation any abuses, improprieties or illegalities that occur.
