description: KANSAS CITY, May 9 (AP)George Brett, the Kansas City Royals' third baseman, is expected to be sidelined for about a week with an elbow injury he suffered Saturday in a brawl during the RoyalsTexas Rangers game. Brett, the American League batting champion. is hitting .327.

title: Frank A. Pytlak, 68, a Catcher For Cleveland Indians in 1930's
description: BUFFALO, May 9 (UPI)Funeral services will be held Wednesday for Frank A. Pytlak, a catcher for the Cleveland Indians in the 1930's, who died yesterday after a threemonth illness. He was 68 years old.

title: HEALTH DEPARTMENT UNDERGOING CHANGE
description: TRENTON, May 9A controversy over the restructuring of the Stare Department of Health apparently ended today with the provisional approval of the move by the Public Health Council.

title: Norton Believes He'll Be in Right Mood for Bobick Match
description: Ken Norton is reading a movie script these nights, with the idea that maybe he'd like to play the title role in The Animal. The question is whether he is in the mood to fight like one in his 12rounder tomorrow night against Duane Bobick at Madison Square Garden.

title: PETER E. WISSEL, 55, DIES; VICE PRESIDENT OF TEXACO
description: Peter E. Wissel, vice president for finance and economics of Texaco Inc., died Sunday of a heart attack at a Southbury, Conn., golf course. He was 55 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Handicapped Pupils Get Arts Showcase
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., May 9Two retired Long Island Rail Road commuter cars embarked on a new mission todayto foster the creative resources of handicapped children.

title: NIXON MAY BE SUBPOENAED ON VIETNAM AID LETTER
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)A Congressional committee chairman said today that he might subpoena Richard M. Nixon if the former President did not produce a letter promising United States reconstruction aid for Vietnam.

title: Abzug, Beame, Cuomo, Koch or Sutton?
description: The race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York City now finds the runners bunched in two groups: Bella Abzug, Abraham Beame, Mario Cuomo, Edward Koch and Percy Sutton in one loose pack up front, and Herman Badillo, Edward Costikyan, Joel Harnett and Richard Ravitch far behind. John Zuccotti, who might have run past the field, declined to take on his boss, Mayor Beame. A month remains before petitions are circulated for places on the September ballot and much can still change. But realists are beginning to focus on the leaders.

title: Meadowlands Results
description: ?? 2.00 ?? (32) paid $85?? ??bedKri A?? and Sta??ess Steel.

title: Unemployment Benefits Curbed
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., March 9 (UPI)A bill eliminating unemployment benefits for a person who voluntarily quits his job was signed into law by Gov. Mike O'Callaghan yesterday. The measure requires an employee who quits one job to work in another job for 10 weeks before he can qualify for unemployment checks.

title: Topics
description: Suddenly, last year, the American frontier was gone, It was, in fact, officially dispatched. Buried in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 was the repeal of the Homestead Act of 1S62. For 114 years, the Homestead Act was both statute and symbol. It meant that there was always a future, as long as there was an American West; there was always fresh land for a fresh start. For anyone who could survive the hardships of the untamed frontier for five years, there was the promise, from the Government, of 160 acres or his own. Everything the frontier meantfreedom, optimism, the conquest of odds, the sober joy of possessionwas part of homesteading, part of the country's youth and pride.

title: A Value Dwarfing the Purse
description: LOUISVILLEThe Kentuckian was serious. When you get back to New York, he said. I want you to write a new review of Kentucky.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: RESULTS
description: (OTB payoffs subject to 5% State tax)

title: Dr. Hans Strauss, Neurologist, 79; Professor Emeritus at Mt. Sinai
description: Dr. Hans Strauss, consultant neurologist and a longtime expert in electroencephalography at Mount Sinai Hospital, died there Friday. He lived at 315 Central Park West in Manhattan and was 79 years old.

title: 2d Swiss Bank Within Month Fails
description: GENEVA. May 9Switzerland's banking community was hit today by its second scandal within a month with the failure of a private Geneva bank, Leclerc & Company, to open its doors.

title: Aviation Weekly Counters Carter on Soviet Beam
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI)An aerospace weekly today challenged President Carter to specify what he termed inaccuracies in its report that the Soviet Union was developing a weapon that could neutralize strategic ballistic missiles.

title: DEFEAT WORRIES REDS IN SOUTH ITALIAN CITY
description: CASTELLAMARE DI STABIA, ItalyUnder the pruned trees that line the promenade of this seaside town, mothers push their baby carriages, the unemployed lounge in the sun and complain, young men watch the girls go by, the retired protest their low pensions and the Christian Democrats express joy over what has recently happened and the Communists unhappiness.

title: Scandinavian Airlines Struck
description: STOCKHOLM, May 9 (UPI)A strike by 1,300 Swedish and Norwegian cabin attendants crippled Scandinavian Airlines System international flights today, and 700 Danish cabin crew members said they might join the strike next week. Company officials said priority was being given to maintaining North American services. Flights to South America and the Far East were canceled.

title: Truck Driver Recovering From Case of Cholera
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 9 (UPI)An Alabama truck driver who contracted cholera is recuperating at home and there is no reason to believe that the disease has spread to anyone else, a Fedral health official said today.

title: Carter, at Meeting With Syrian, Calls for Palestinian Homeland
description: GENEVA, May 9President Carter met here today with President Hafez alAssad of Syria to discuss the Middle East conflict, and said at a meeting with reporters that there must be a resolution of the Palestine problem and a homeland for the Palestinians.

title: PHILIP BRIDGER
description: Philip Bridger, a pharmacist in New York City, who on retirement took up sculpture and won prizes in Florida, where he lived for several years, died yesterday in Abraham Jacobi Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived with a son at 16634 26th Avenue in the Flushing section of Queens.

title: 3 Big Days Paying Off For Blazers
description: March 27, 1979The Portland Trial Blazers win the coin toss from the Philadelphia 76ers and make Bill Walton their No. 1 choice in the college draft.

title: Soviet Tells Atom Parley of Plans For a PlutoniumBased Economy
description: SALZBURG, Austria  The scientific, technical and economic planners of Eastern Europe are convinced that nuclear power plants contribute to the environmental improvement, and appear to have no misgivings about the use of plutonium as a nuclear fuel.

title: U.S. Steel to Lift Prices an Average 6%
description: The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, announced yesterday price increases averaging about 6 percent on its products that go into automobiles and appliances, machinery and tools.

title: BOND PRICES RISE; TRADING IS SLOW
description: Bond prices rose slightly yesterday after the Federal Reserve injected some temporary reserves into the banking system when the interest rate on overnight loans rose slightly higher than 5 percent. Trading activity was light, however, and dealers did not attach much significance to the market's action.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: DEADLINE CLUB HONORS 3 FROM EDITORIAL PAGES
description: John B. Oakes, senior editor of The New York Times; James A. Wechsler, editorial page editor of The New York Post, and Reuben Maury, who retired in 1972 as editorial writer of The New York Daily News, will be inducted into the Hall of Fame of the Deadline Club tomorrow at the club's annual awards dinner at the New York Hilton.

title: U.S. and North Korea Trade Accusations on Shooting
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 9United Nations and North Korean delegates traded accusations at Panmunjom today after the longest lull between meetings in the 24year history of the Korean ceasefire agreement.

title: From Zahara, Spain, to New York: Photos Trace Paths of One Fernandez Family
description: It would seem that almost everybody's name is Fernndez in Zahara. The village of 150 white stucco houses bakes on a hillside in the unrelenting sun of Andalusia, yielding olives and olive oil and a way of life that has not changed very much since the Moors arrived 12 centuries ago to conquer a crumbling Visigothic kingdom.

title: Texas A. and M. Placed On OneYear Probation
description: KANSAS CITY, May 9 (AP)Texas A. and M. University was placed on a oneyear probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today for infractions in its basketball program, but the penalties include ??o sanctions.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For period ended March 31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Esdense, (A) American Stock Exchange, and (O) overthecounter.

title: Adroit Syrian President
description: When Syrian Air Force commanders were considering pilots to send to the Soviet Union for advanced training 20 years ago, they chose a young lieutenant, Hafez alAssad, who was already a master at aerial maneuvers. Since then Mr. Assad has used his maneuvering skills in the dogfights of Arab politics. His zigzag turns, his swift attacks, his shrewd coursesetting have made him President of Syria and one of the main figures of the Arab Levant, the turbulent region around the Eastern Mediterranean.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: On Federal Encroachment
description: An editorial in this month's issue of Field and Stream magazine registers concern with the recent decision of the United States District Court in Washington halting the culling of wolves on Federal lands in Alaska.

title: Adeline Is Revived Tunefully
description: The Goodspeed Opera House. that gingerbreadhouse landmark on the banks of the Connecticut River. has become the living repository for the American musical. Year after year, this theater rediscovers antiques. such as Very Good Eddie, and occasionally opens its door to new musicals in established traditions (Annie).

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MAY 10, 1977

title: For Cruguet, Big Silence at the Big A
description: Back in Paris, Jean Cruguet was recognized as a Frenchman again in newspaper headlines, but yesterday at Aqueduct he was only a jockey who happened to have won the Kentucky Derby last Saturday.

title: Ballot Drawing in Essex Is Ruled Illegal
description: Judge Arthur J. Blake of the Superior Court ruled illegal yesterday the recent drawing for ballot positions for the June 7 primary in Essex County because Nicholas Caputo, the Essex County Clerk, used capsules instead of cards to conduct the drawing. Mr. Caputo has appealed the action and a a ruling from the Appellate Division is expected tomorrow. The successful challenge to the drawing was filed by Assemblyman Eldridge Hawkins, Democrat of East Orange, who is running for the State Senate, and Senator Raymond Garramone of Haworth, who is running for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination.

title: Middleton Sues Don King
description: BALTIMORE, May 9 (AP)Larry Middleton and his managers have filed a $3 million lawsuit against Don Ring, alleging the promoter signed the heavyweight boxer for a bout with George Foreman that was never put on.

title: Harper & Row Employees on Strike
description: A group of about 240 of the 600 employees at Harper & Row's offices on East 53d Street went on strike yesterday in a dispute over wages and other contract issues. The publishing concern had been hit by a similar strike three years ago. That strike lasted 17 days.

title: Senators Open Partisan Debate on Antifilibuster Rule
description: WASHINGTON, May 9In the shadow of a threatened filibuster, the Senate began debate today on a measure to tighten its antifilibuster rule.

title: A.M.A. LEADER DEFENDS USE OF HYSTERECTOMIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)A top official of the American Medical Association told a House subcommittee today that doctors should continue to perform hysterectomies for no other reason than to prevent cancer or conception.

title: LOUIS WARE, 82, HEADED INTERNATIONAL MINERALS
description: Louis Ware, former board chairman of the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation, died Saturday in his north Palm Beach, Fla. home at the age of 82.

title: TAUBMAN, ALLEN RAISES ITS CASH BID FOR IRVINE
description: LOS ANGELES, May 9Taubman, Allen, Irvine Inc. today raised its bid to $309.3 million in cash to purchase the Irvine Company, which owns more than 70,000 acres of undeveloped land in suburban Orange County, south of Los Angeles.

title: N.B.A. Playoffs
description: SEMIFINAL ROUND Los Angeles vs. Portland

title: Pro Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Market Place
description: For some time, analysts have been bemoaning the fact that airline stocks have not reflected an industrywide earnings recovery and improved financial condition of the major lines.

title: Federal Jargon Obfuscates, Repeats, Exaggerates and Covers Up
description: WASHINGTON, May 9If you work for the Federal Government and want. something typed, do not, Lord forfend, look for a typing pool. Seek instead an information processing center.

title: The Last Hurrah of a Feisty Winter Brings the Latest Spring Snow Ever
description: The latest spring snowstorm ever recorded in the New York metropolitan region blustered over much of the Northeast yesterday, closing schools, snarling traffic and cloaking newly plowed fields and the delicate blossoms of May in a harsh reprise of winter.

title: IN THE NATION
description: named Bob's Dusty, a finisher back in the pack, but under whose name is noted: Bold CommanderCountess Alice by Count Fleet. You don't have to be much of a racing fan to pick up resonances of the past from the name Count Fleet or from those of other past winnersSecretariat or Swaps, Citation or Whirlaway; and was it really 40 years ago that War Admiral won the Derby?

title: Munson Still Lets Bat Do the Talking
description: Fans at Yankee Stadium never will chant Thurman, Thurman, Thurman when he comes to bat. There never will be a Thurman's Throng to sit in a special section and hold up flash cards spelling out his name. No one will name a candy bar Munson's Munchie.

title: East German Leaders Seem Certain That Unrest Is Now Under Control
description: EAST BERLIN, May 9After almost a year of political tension brought on by new stirrings of independence among the country's 17 million people, the East German Communist authorities appear confident that they have regained full control.

title: ALLIES WARN SOVIET AGAINST IMPERILING SECURITY OF BERLIN
description: LONDON, May 9The leaders of Britain, the United States, France and West Germany warned the Soviet Union in firm language today not to endanger the status quo in Berlin.

title: A.A.U. Weighs Staging Of Cubavs.U.S. Meets
description: The Amateur Athletic Union is exploring the possibility of staging international meets between the United States and Cuba in boxing, wrestling and track and field during the next year.

title: First Trading Market Is Planned In OilGas Drilling Partnerships
description: WASHINGTON, May 9  Scott & Stringfellow Inc., a leading regional Investment firm, plans to create the nation's first trading market for partnership investments in oil and gas exploratiOn, according to a proposal outlined to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 37 Reported Killed In Rhodesian Battle
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 9 (AP)Rhodesian security forces and black nationalist guerrillas clashed in what apparently was the first major battle of a new Government counteroffensive, official sources reported today. They said that at least 37 civilians had been killed.

title: Huge Lobbying and Legal Drive Being Pressed for the Concorde
description: A massive lobbying, legal and public relations effort by French and British interests, costing an estimated $4 million and aimed at winning approval of landings by the supersonic Concorde aircraft in the United States, is entering its climactic stage.

title: Harry G. Johnson, Economist, Dies; Taught at Chicago, London, Geneva
description: GENEVA, May 9 (AP)Harry G. Johnson, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago and at the Graduate School of International Relations here, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 53 years old and had been in poor health since suffering a stroke a few years ago.

title: Talks Open Today in Atlantic Dock Workers' Dispute
description: The International Longshoremen's Association and the Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations open contract talks today, but both sides indicate that the key to their success depends, in part at least, on Government actions that would open the way for steps to protect jobs along the docks.

title: 60 Minute Gourmet
description: SOME THINGS SEEM made for each other like Moet and Chandon, Lea and Perrins and Cross and Blackwell. That lengthy list would also include a couple of nowplentiful foods from American, waters, shad and shad roe. Separately either would make good feasting. Cooked together with a bit of shallots, a touch of heavy cream and a final sprinkling of chopped parsley and/or chives, this is food to appease the appetite of most sluggish connoisseur. And the entire kitchen proceedingsminus the eating, of coursecan be accomplished in far less than an hour.

title: Marine Corps Is Softening the bole of the HardBoiled Drill Instructor
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C.The drill instructor, a folklore figure in the Marine Corps who turned fumbling recruits into Spartan, disciplined fighters, is quietly losing his primacy.

title: Text of President's Address to the Conference of NATO Countries in London
description: LONDON, May 10 (AP)Following is the text of President Carter's address to the NATO meeting:

title: Notes on People
description: AMONG the temporary copy persons hired for the summer at The Daily News will be Caroline Kennedy, the 19yearold daughter of President John F. Kennedy, who will earn $156.89 a week, was interviewed and filled out an application Monday. Afterward, she was taken on a tour of the newspaper's editorial department and composing room, where she became an instant autographgiving celebrity.

title: Winter Wheat Estimate Raised, But Crop 6% Under 1976 Is Seen
description: WASHINGTON. May 10 (AP)The nation's winter wheat crop is doing better than originally expected but the output still will be 6 percent below last year's harvest, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 5WEEK TEACHERS' STRIKE IS ENDED IN MILWAUKEE
description: MILWAUKEE, May 10 (AP)The strike by teachers that began April 7 ended today after substitute teachers, teacher' aides and school accountants joined the 5,700 regular teachers in approving new contract proposals.

title: A Time to Talk, a Time to Punch
description: Now that peace has broken out in George Foreman's bosom, removing him from the raffish environs of the prize ring, there remain three logical contenders for the heavyweight championship of the worldKen Norton, Duane Bobick and Jimmy Young. Tomorrow there will be two. For Norton and Bobick have a tryst in Madison Square Garden tonight and each plans to eliminate the other. Muhammad Ali has signed a contract to defend the championship against tonight's winner in Rio de Janeiro in September, but in the wonderful world of fistfighting a signature on a contract is a name writ in water. After taking a whipping and a decision from Norton in Yankee Stadium last Sept. 28, Ali retired forever, and that period has now expired. Corning out of retirement next Monday night, he will honor his commitments by risking violent death at the hands of Alfredo Evangelista, the noted Spanish canvasback. So how do tonight's principals feel about their chances for a shot at the title?

title: Income, Up 9.1% In '76, Is Ahead Of Inflation Rate
description: WASHINGTON. May 10 (AP)  The average American's personal income grew by 9.1 percent in 1976, well above the inflation rate, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Rose Gregorio, Preston Win Derwent Awards
description: Rose Gregorio, who plays Agnes, the devoted daughter of a terminally ill woman in The Shadow Box, the Michael Cristofer 1977 Pulitzer Prizewinning drama at the Morosco Theater, and Barry Preston, the eccentric dancer in the musical Bubbling Brown Sugar at the ANTA Theater, were chosen as winners of the 33d annual Clarence Derwent Awards yesterday.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Tuesday, May 10, 1977

title: FED INDICATES DESIRE FOR RISE IN INTEREST
description: The Federal Reserve signaled yesterday that it would like shortterm interest rates to move higher as it drained reserves from the banking system temporarily when the interest rate on overnight loans dipped to 53/16 percent. The action, most bond traders concluded, meant that the Federal Reserve wanted the Federal funds rate no lower than 5 percent, a slightly higher floor than they discerned last week.

title: SAUDI SUGGESTS P. L. O. WOULD ACCEPT ISRAEL
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, May 10Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia said today he believed that the Palestine Liberation Organization would agree to recognize the state of Israel as part of a settlement of, the Middle East problem.

title: Janet Guthrie Is Unhurt After Crash at 191 M.P.H.
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 10 (UPI)Janet Guthrie, trying to become the first woman to qualify for the Indianapolis 500mile race, crashed into the wall on a practice run today seconds after she was clocked at 191 miles per hour. Doctors said she was uninjured.

title: Victor Merger Into Kidde Subsidiary Is Approved by Directors of Both
description: Directors of Walter Kidde & Company and the Victor Comptometer Corporation approved yesterday a previously announced plan to merge Victor into a whollyowned subsidiary of Kidde. Under terms of the proposal, each of Victor's common shares, other than the 382,341 shares owned by Kidde, would be converted into half a share of a new Kidde series D convertible cumulative preferred share.

title: Dollar Holds Its Ground On European Exchanges; Gold Price Up 50 Cents
description: LONDON, May 10 (AP)The dollar held steady against most major European currencies today following its rebound on the foreign exchanges yesterday.

title: Study Unit Calls for Reorganizing New York Police Medical Section
description: Calling for major changes in the Police Department's Medical Section, an independent research group said yesterday that police physicians were failing to do their primary jobpreventing fake sick leaves by police officers.

title: Summing Up the Economic Summit
description: The message of the Downing Street summit is thus one of confidence ... that we are undertaking the. measures needed to overcome problems and achieve a more prosperous future.

title: Letters
description: Dog Bites

title: Panel in Albany Backs Alternative To Carey Plan on Auto Insurance
description: ALBANY, May 10A bill that attempts to control rising automobile insurance rates by requiring immediate medical payments up to $5,000 and outofcourt arbitration of most claims for pain and suffering was reported favorably from the Assembly Insurance Committee today.

title: GRUMMAN EARNINGS UP 23.4% IN QUARTER
description: The Grumman Corporation, a leading supplier of military aircraft for the Navy, reported yesterday a net income of $7.9 million, or $1 a share, for the first three months of this year, a gain of 23.4 percent. Sales were put at $362.3 million, up 0.6 percent, from the 1976 first quarter.

title: CALIFANO SAYS SHIFT ON SOCIAL SECURITY COULD BE PERMANENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told Congress today that the Carter Administration would eventually like to make a permanent part of the Social Security system the limited transfer of general revenues from the Treasury that it proposed yesterday for an experimental fiveyear period.

title: Australian Strike Delays Mail
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)  The Postal Service warned today that a strike of airtraffic controllers in Australia was delaying air mail to that country. Officials said that more than 17 tons of air mail for Australia was being held in Honolulu and that the Australian postal administration had informed the Postal Service here that it could not accept air mail at this time.

title: Three Women Whose Present Has a Past
description: PARIS IN THE PROGRAM for The Women of Thursday, there are large photographs of each of the middleaged actresses who play the central roles. And there are small photographs showing them as children with sand buckets, and as young women looking triumphantly into the camera.

title: S.E.C. Settles Banque de Paris Complaint
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it had settled a complaint with the Banque de Paris et Des Pays Bas (Suisse) of Geneva over alleged violations of UnitedStates securities laws.

title: EFFORT TO CURB RISE IN AID TO BIG CITIES DEFEATED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 10In a vote crucial to the urban Northeast and the Middle West, the House of Representatives beat back today an amendment that would have scuttled a new formula meant to funnel increased urban development aid to the large older cities.

title: Conferees Are Still Deadlocked Over Spending Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, May 10House and Senate budget conferees argued all day today over defense needs, but wound up in a deadlock that seriously threatened their ability to meet Sunday's legal deadline for setting tentative spending ceilings.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 11, 1977

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Joan Crawford Dies at Home
description: Joan Crawford, who rose from waitress and chorus girl to become one of the great movie stars, died yesterday of a heart attack in her apartment at 158 East 68th Street. She gave her age as 69, but some reference works list her as two to four years older.

title: Blazers Beat Lakers Again
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 10Bill Walton exploded for 14 points in a fiveminute stretch of the fourth quarter and led the Portland Trailblazers to a 10297 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight, giving Portland a 30 lead in the fourofseven western semifinal of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Social Security's Troubles
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Nearly everyone in the country is involved with Social Security in one way or another. More than 100 million workers are paying taxes into the system this year and expect someday to draw benefits. More than 33

title: Air Force Aides Deny Defying Congress on Expenses
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)After stiff charges by Senators that they had tried to deceive Congress, Air Force officials denied today that they had secretly retained expensive computer programs chopped from their budget two years ago.

title: London Rights Stand Is Attacked by Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 10 (UPI)The Soviet Union attacked the leaders of the seven richest democracies today for bringing up the Issue of human rights in the Soviet bloc during their economic summit meeting.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Marine Corps Is Softening the Role of the HardBoiled Drill Instructor
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S.C.The drill instructor, a folklore figure in the Marine Corps who turned fumbling recruits into Spartan, disciplined fighters, is quietly losing his primacy.

title: CONSUMER PROTECTION BILL APPROVED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)The House Government Affairs Committee approved today a bill to create a consumer protection agency.

title: In Memoriam
description: KIRSCHHyman. It's a year since you left us and we miss you so much. In cherished memory of our beloved Dad. Mae, Morris and Bertha, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren

title: Dow Up 3.05 as, Market Discounts Interest Rise and Retail Decline
description: The stock market managed yesterday to shrug off its recent concern over rising interest rates to register a modest advance in accelerated trading.

title: In Its Forties, Ford Foundation Faces Change
description: In its 41st year, the Ford Foundation is going through a midlife crisis. Still recovering from surgery that has cut budgets and staff nearly in half over the last three years, and awaiting new leadership that will come with the changeover of five top officers in 1979, the nation's largest and most influential foundation is in a holding pattern, in a phrase widely used within its humid, glassandgreenery showcase headquarters at 320 East 43d street.

title: Best Buys
description: FIRST THE good news: Two weeks of sharply rising food prices came to an end last week, when the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped by 1 percent, according to the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Abelson to Be Chairman Of Gimbels Philadelphia As Rosenberg Quits Post
description: Stanley Abelson, a former president of Macy's New York and more recently president of Lit Bros., Philadelphia, will be the new chairman of Gimbels Philadelphia stores, reliable trade sources indicated yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I was recently confronted with a question that is beyond me to answer: What is the definition of the word quiche? I am familiar, of course, with quiche Lorraine and so on, but I can't find a definition in any of my dictionaries, even the FrenchEnglish.

title: CALIFANO SAYS SHIFT ON SOCIAL SECURITY COULD BE PERMANENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told Congress today that the Carter Administration would eventually like to make a permanent part of the Social Security system the limited transfer of general revenues from the Treasury that it proposed yesterday for an experimental fiveyear period.

title: N.H.L. Committee Will Recommend Detroit Lawyer as Its New president
description: The National Hockey League's search committee will recommend an American lawyer to succeed 72yearold Clarence S. Campbell as chief of the conservative, Canadianrooted association.

title: SURVEILLANCE WIDENS FOR CANCER RESEARCH
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10Officials of the International Agency for Research on Cancer announced here today that they had taken a major step toward the development of a worldwide cancer surveillance system.

title: Fitting Strategy to Facts
description: LONDON  One thing made strikingly clear to the NATO meeting whose first day's session was attended by President Carter is that the whole character of the threat to the alliance has changed and that new responses military, political and economic  are required to maintain its viability.

title: State Drafts Program to Increase Mortgage Lending in Inner Cities
description: ALBANY, May 10state banking authorities, making public today the results of a yearlong study detailing the extent of redlining by mortgage lenders, said they were drafting a broad program to increase the flow of funds into new and existing housing in the inner cities.

title: U.S. ARMS CURB PLAN IS WORRYING ISRAELIS
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Israel and its supporters appeared headed today toward a confrontation with the Carter Administration over Israel's right to buy or comanufacture advanced American arms.

title: ...And the Secrets of Cooking for One
description: Cooking for one isn't easy, but the results are well worth the effort. When there's a choice between dining out on greasy eggs and ham and dining in on homemade cornmeal crepes, lightly buttered and accompanied by bacon or breakfast sausages, I'll take my own kitchen any day.

title: Careers
description: The nation's corporations have been increasing their support of the arts substantially in recent years. This has led to steppedup demand for trained persons to guide corporations in how to best employ their contributions, although the demand may not yet equal the supply of those interested in such a career.

title: Nixon to Explain Vietnarn Aid Offer
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)Former President Richard M. Nixon is willing to explain why his Administration made a secret offer of nearly $5 billion in postwar aid to Vietnam, a congressman said today,

title: Phils Muffle Giants' Bats and Quiet SecondGuessers
description: When the Philadelphia Phillies got off to a losing start this season. there were grumbles of discontent from the fans and some secondguessing on the part of the experts.

title: 2 Robbed of $12,000
description: Two employees taking money to the Columbia University bookstore at 116th Street and Broadway were held up on the street yesterday and one of them was shot by two robbers who stole $12,000. The police did not release the identities of the victims, who had drawn the cash out of a local bank.

title: Service for Warren Lynch
description: A memorial service for Warren Lynch, vice chairman of the BookoftheMonth Club Inc., will he held on Friday at II A.M. in the auditorium at the library at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Mr. Lynch died Sunday at the age of 62.

title: Estimate Unit Votes To End Drug Project In Bronx by June 30
description: The New York City Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday to cancel financing as of June 30 for a controversial Bronx drug rehabilitation program.

title: Union Leaders Call for the Ouster Of State Official in Casino Dispute
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 10Union leaders called today for the resignation or ouster of an official in the State Department of Environmental Protection for discouraging to the detriment of possible investment plans for a $100 million casino gambling complex on a wetlands site.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter urged the North Atlantic Treaty allies to respond forcefully to a 12year Soviet buildup in Europe creating forces much stronger than needed for any defense purpose. Speaking in London before flying back to the United States, he said the United States would prefer to reduce tensions in Europe by agreements on disarmament and force reduction but said until then military strength must be maintained. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Unacceptable Reasons, Acceptable Mercy
description: The decision by a Los Angeles Superior Court judge not to jail Patricia Hearst for her part in a 1974 robbery and shooting spree raises the inevitable question: Is there one justice for the poor and another for the rich and powerful?

title: 3 Top Officers Quit Swiss Credit Bank
description: ZURICH, May 10 (Reuters) The head of the Swiss Credit Bank. one of Switzerland's biggest banks resigned tonight following a multimilliondollar financial scandal involving one of the hank's branches.

title: Companies Issue Earnings Reports
description: For periods ended March 31 unless otherwise indicated. (N) indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: National's 6% Price Increase Follows U.S. Steel Move
description: The nation's No. 3 steelmaker, the National Steel Corporation, followed the leader yesterday and duplicated the 6 percent price increase that was announced on Monday by the United States Steel Corporation, the top company.

title: CLOSING OF POST OFFICES IN RURAL AREAS IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)The financially ailing Postal Service could operate more effectively and save an estimated $490 million a year by closing post offices in some 17,000 rural communities, a Government study says.

title: Controversial Design Is Given Approval
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday unanimously approved a controversial design by Hugh Hardy, an architect, for a town house to be built at 18 West 11th Street, the vacant site where an earlier house had been destroyed by radicals making explosives in 1970.

title: Smith Easily Beats Macchi in Jersey City, Dimming Jordan's Gubernatorial Chances
description: JERSEY CITY, May 10Thomas F. X., Smith easily won election as Mayor of New Jersey's second largest city tonight by capturing more than 50 percent of the vote against five opponents and eliminating the necessity of a runoff next month.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10The Mobil Corporation, in a daybyday bidding war, raised the ante for the Irvine Company to $316.4 million in cash today, thus edging ahead of TaubmanAllen, Irvine Inc., a group of investors that includes Henry Ford 2d.

title: The State of the Death Penalty
description: The continuing national debate about the death penalty reveals a basic case of schizophrenia. State legislatures seem less eager than the public to revive the death penalty in ways the Supreme Court would accept. Governors, judges and prosecutors seem even less eager; no one has been executed since Gary Mark Gilmore, who effectively waived his legal rights in his rush to die last January. The nation seems to be roaring for blood at one level, while behaving cautiously at another out of a sense that killing even notorious criminals is wrong.

title: Nuclear Parley in Salzburg Tackles Public Attitude and Risk Evaluation
description: SALZBURG, Austria, May 10After a week of debating the difficulties of reactor safety, the spread of nuclear weapons and new technologies, participants in the international atomic energy conference here are tackling their most difficult problems: risk assessment and public acceptance.

title: Awards in Journalism Given by Deadline Club And Hillman Foundation
description: The Deadline Club and the Sidney Hillman Foundation announced their annual awards in journalism and mass communications yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ONE MAN'S HORIZON One of the outstanding American artists of this century, Edward Hopper, is being accorded his first major show in New York in eight years. Included in the display of paintings, watercolors, drawings and etchings going on view today at the Kennedy Galleries are several early works never before exhibited.

title: Patient'S Unmarked Pills Get Him in Trouble
description: WOODRIDGE, N. J., May 10The balmy afternoon weather, a frisky neighborhood dog, and a thoughtful neighbor's good deed combined on Mother's Day to ruin a Manhattan cabinetmaker's trip to suburbia to visit at the home of his business partner's parents in this Bergen County community.

title: Bendix Labor Pact Reached
description: ST. JOSEPH, Mich., May 10 (AP)A second tentative local contract agreement was reached today by bargainers for the Bendix Corporation's hydraulic division plant and the United Automobile Workers. A ratification vote will be held tomorrow. The members of Local 383 walked out yesterday after rejecting a previous tentative agreement by nine votes.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: SAN FRANCISCO AIDES FACING REFERENDUM
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10A proposal to cut in half the present fouryear terms of current city officials and radically alter the political realities of this city has been certified for a special election on Aug. 2.

title: U.S. Judge Visits 600 Schools, Finds Things Bad, and Good Too
description: When a Federal District Court judge visited four New York City special schools for children with serious behavioral problems yesterday, he found what lawyers for the Legal Aid Society said he would findinadequate facilities and truancy among the students, most of whom were black or Hispanic and many who were far behind in basic reading skills.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the possible loss for the Swiss Credit Bank was incorrectly given in The Times yesterday. The bank said in Geneva, it could give no estimate of the final loss until an audit was completed. A headline in some editions mistakenly implled that the bank had failed.

title: Doubt Voiced in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, May 10State Department officials said today they doubted that the Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization had agreed on a formula to solve the Palestinian question.

title: Card of Thanks
description: SPIERER Frieda, Mr. Leon Spierer gratefully acknowledges and thanks one and alt for their kind expression of sympathy for the great loss of his beloved wife.

title: Newburger, Loeb Reorganization
description: Newberger, Loeb & Company, which ceased operations as a brokerage firm in November 1974 when it filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, said yesterday it had obtained acceptance of its plan of reorganization from more than the required number of its creditors.

title: Film: Tokkan,' a Tale Of Citizenry at War
description: KIHACHI OKAMOTO, one of Japan's industrious directorwriters, illustrates once again in Tokkan, the new offering in the Regency Theater's Nipponese film series, that wars are hellish and fruitless for the men who fight and die in them. If that horribly truthful idea is not precisely new to Japanese moviemakers, Mr. Okamoto's perceptive concentration on the personalities of those caught up in conflict and his sense of humor make Tokkan an interesting. sometimes exciting appreciation of the unchanging nature of men in war, even though it is set in a centuryold fuzzy past.

title: Connors Routs Panatta In W.C.T. Quarterfinal
description: DALLAS, May 10 (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors of the United States stalked Adriano Panatta's erratic serves without mercy tonight to route the Italian, 64, 75, 64, in the opening quarterfinal match of the World Championship of Tennis finals.

title: Cancer Institute Puts Further Curb On Breast XRays
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)The National Cancer Institute said today that it had further restricted the use of breast Xray examinations for women under 50 in its nationwide breast cancer detection program.

title: Chess:
description: As part of its centennial celebration, the Manhattan Chess Club, 155 East 55th Street, will hold a Moses Mitchell tournament of champions. The tournament will start Sunday and run through May 27.

title: Wheat Futures Decline To Lows in All Contracts; Soybeans Off Daily Limit
description: Farm products prices dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade for several reasons.

title: JAMES W. SCHLEMMER
description: AKRON, Ohio, May 10 (AP)The body of James W. Schlemmer, dean of Ohio sports editors when he retired at the end of 1969, was found in his Cuyahoga Falls home today. The cause of death was presumed to be a heart attack. He was 77 years old and had suffered three heart attacks in the last 10 years.

title: SAUDI SUGGESTS P. L. O. WOULD ACCEPT ISRAEL
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, May 10Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia said today he believed that the Palestine Liberation, Organization would agree to recognize the state of Israel as part of a settlement of the Middle East problem.

title: The Big SteakOut: It's Not All Filet Mignon
description: Steak, the dictionary tells us, is a slice of meat, especially of beef or of a large fish, cut thick for broiling or frying. Steak, to most of us, means cuts such as porterhouse, Tbone, sirloin, Delmonico, filet mignon, or strip, all of which also suggest high prices.

title: RABBI MOSES LEHRMAN
description: Moses Lehrman, head rabbi of Congregation B'nai Moshe in Oak Park, Mich., and president of the Michigan region of Zionist Organization of America, died Monday in a hospital in Miami Beach, Fla., after a short illness. He was visiting in Florida. Rabbi Lehrman was 69 years old.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold prices Tuesday.

title: Cosmos, in a Crackdown, Suspend Smith Indefinitely, Fine Messing
description: Bobby Smith has been suspended indefinitely and Shop Messing has been fined by the Cosmos, who meet the Sting in Chicago tonight in a North American Soccer League game.

title: Woman, 82, Found Dead in Bushwick, Victim of Robbery
description: An 82yearold woman was found dead in her Brooklyn apartment yesterday, the apparent victim of a robbery.

title: The Artichoke: A Culinary Masterpiece Is in Season
description: Legend has it that Catherine de' Medici of Italy was the mother of classic French cooking. Culinary history tells us that when she went to France to become the child bride of Henry II, the future king, she took with her an assortment of chefs and cooks from her home in Renaissance Italy.

title: Cranston to End Press Briefings After Meetings in the White House
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Senator Alan Cranston of California, the majority whip, responding to what he called solicited and unsolicited advice, said today that he would no longer brief the press after White House meetings with Democratic leaders in Congress.

title: Protest Strike Called in France
description: PARIS, May 10 (AP)Three major French labor unions called on their members today to take part in a nationwide 24hour strike May 24 to protest the Government's economic policies.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MAY 10, 1977

title: Wilde's Earnest Next At Circle in Square
description: Oscar Wilde's The Importance of Being Earnest, the fourth production of the Circle in the Square's current season, has entered rehearsals for a June 16 opening.

title: April Retail Sales Same as in March, But 11% Above '76
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)Retail stores sold about $59.4 billion in products in April, practically the same total as the month before, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Carter Achieved Success in London by Being a Realist
description: LONDON, May 10  After the excitment of his first weeks in office, President Carter flew into London last Thursday night somewhat beleaguered  with his energy package being picked apart by regional interests, his standing in public opinion polls down 10 points, and influential Democrats on Capitol Hill chafing over Administration interference in the Congressional budget process. He headed home tonight after demonstrating his skill at personal diplomacy with some proud and touchy European leaders, after finding new hope for his Middle East peace offensive, winning the obvious and ready affections of the British electorate, and helping restore a sense of cooperation and purpose in the Atlantic community.

title: Books: A High Rise As Society's Parable
description: IN HIGH RISE, J. G. Ballard, as in his previous novels, Crash and Concrete Island, focuses on two favorite fictional themes: technology gone awry, and human regression and savagery. In this instance, the result is less than satisfying.

title: In Its Forties, Ford Foundation Faces Change
description: In its 41st year, the Ford Foundation is going through a midlife crisis. Still recovering from surgery that has cut budgets and staff nearly in half over the last three years, and awaiting new leadership that will come with the changeover of five top officers in 1979, the nation's largest and most influential foundation is in a holding pattern, in a phrase widely used within its humid, glassandgreenery showcase headquarter's at 320 East 43d street.

title: Negative Report on Natural Gas Pipelines Arouses a Furor in Canada
description: OTTAWA, May 10Fierce controversy has erupted in Canada following a negative report yesterday by an inquiry, ordered by the Government, into proposed pipelines to bring natural gas from Arctic reserves to southern Canada and the United States.

title: A Grow Truck Is Given to City
description: Green and beautiful was the rallying cry yesterday at City Hall when Mayor Beame and Marian S. Heiskell, cochairmen of the Council of the Environment of New York City, inaugurated Grow Truck, a mobile gardentool and booklending service for community groups.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A bill that would ban fliptop cans in Connecticut and discourage throwaway bottles by requiring deposits on all beer and softdrink containers was kept alive in Hartford yesterday by a ruling by the Speaker of the State House of Representatives, James J. Kennelly, that the General Assembly's Joint Environment Committee should consider a version of the bill passed last week by the Senate.

title: Home Juicers: Surveying the Crop
description: WHILE JUICE extractorstouted by manufacturers as veritable fountains of youth and renewed health are hardly household words in the kitchens of the 70's, they are making their way into more and more homes, as consumers become increasingly health conscious.

title: Music: New but Nostalgic
description: The evening of new music that David Behrman and Gordon Mumma offered Monday night at the Diplomat Hotel the last event in the laudable In Performance at the Diplomat avantgarde music and dance serieshad a sort of nostalgic glow to it.

title: Senate Panel Votes to Allow Cuba To Buy U.S. Food and Medicine
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to ease the trade embargo against Cuba to permit it to buy medicine, food and agricultural supplies in the United States market. However, it balked at opening United States markets to exports of sugar and other Cuban agricultural products.

title: Matlack Is Fed Up, Wants to Be Traded
description: The revolt by the ranking stars of the New York Mets against management steepened yesterday when Jon Matlack asked to be traded because he was fed up with the way the team had been handled.

title: CALIFORNIA STORMS BRING SCANT RELIEF
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 10Rain has been falling intermittently on widely scattered parts of parched California since Saturday, but not nearly enough in most sections to do more than slightly ease the effects of the twoyear drought.

title: Equity in Limiting Strategic Arms
description: WASHINGTONSix weeks after President Carter's alternative proposals for strategic arms limitations were rejected in Moscow, formal negotiations are resuming in Geneva Jr. this interval, the thrust of Soviet bargaining has shifted to the arena of American public opinionits target the malleable amalgam of views held by Government officials, the news media and private experts.

title: Carter Appears to Have Adopted Quieter Human Rights Approach
description: LONDON, May 10Although President Carter continued during the London economic summit conference to express his concern about the issue of human rights in countries with authoritarian governments, he had apparently begun long before to take a more conventional, cautious and diplomatic approach to the problem.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jersey's Beach Access Study Commission said in a report that the Legislature should act to make sure that the 48 oceanfront towns provide equitable access to the shore to both residents and visitors.

title: Ford Reports Egypt Approves Assembly Of Trucks, Engines
description: DETROIT, May 10The Ford Motor. Company said today that it had received approval for a plan to build trucks and diesel engines in Egypt. No timetable was given for the start of production.

title: Major League Scores
description: Women's Interclub Golf Results

title: Dinner for 1, Please James
description: There are times when all of us, no matter how married or how popular, find ourselves alone and hungry. Most often, this leads to eating alone.

title: Lykes Antiboycott Move Fails
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 10(AP)A plea from the American Jewish Congress that Tykes Steamship Corp. investigate the extent to which it is affected by the Arab boycott was rejected at a stockholders meeting Tuesday.

title: India's Press Gains Verve, but There Are Some Qualms
description: NEW DELHI, May 10West Bengal in the grip of a severe drought, Indian newspaper readers learned the other day, and there was a violent transit strike in Madras.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Saudis, Stressing Moderation on Oil, Call Shift Possible
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, May 10Saudi Arabia is determined to pursue its policy of moderation on oil prices for the foreseeable future, Crown Prince Fahd and other top Saudi officials said in interviews here today. But they indicated that there were economic factors that might induce them to change their position.

title: L.I. Parkway Toll Upheld by Court
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday upheld the 15cent increase in the Southern State Parkway toll imposed in 1974 and said that the Legislature had deprived bondholders of their rights in rescinding the increase. The Legislature had rolled the toll back to 10 cents under heavy pressure from Long Island motorists and residents of the neighborhoods that were used by drivers seeking to bypass the toll booths in Valley Stream, L.I. However, because of court action, the rollback never took effect.

title: White House Collides With Nixon, Backs Off
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The White House backed away hastily today from a potential television ratings contest between President Carter and former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: TV: Hard Times Is True to Dickens
description: THERE IS ALREADY a plan under way in Britain to produce all of Shakespeare's plays in a new package for television. A suggestion is hereby respectfully submitted that the same electronic thoroughness be applied, by way of intelligent adaptations, to the works of Charles Dickens.

title: 2 More Say They Lied at 1972 Wilmington, N.C., Trial
description: BURGAW, N.C., May 10Two more prosecution witnesses in the case of the Wilmington 10 told a hearing today that the testimony they gave in the 1972 trial had been false.

title: Japan to Aid Asian Games
description: TOKYO, May 10 (UPI)The Japan Olympic Committee said today it would contribute money and possibly coaches and equipment to stage the 1978 Asian Games in Bangkok, Thailand. The Asian Games Federation had asked Japan for $200,000 as its share in helping stage the games. South Korea had declined to be the host for financial reasons and Bangkok was picked as a substitute site.

title: Wine Talk
description: DURING THE LAST two weeks. of September 1973, I was in Tuscany. It was hotoh, yes it was hot. It was dry, too, and the breeze crackled through the olive trees, turning up the silver underside of the leaves every minute or two. Great fall weather for Italian grapes.

title: U.A.W.'s Next Chief and Energy Program
description: The nation's most innovative union is about to get an imaginative new leader. But his hopes for exploring new avenues of social inventiveness by labor are already being sidetracked by an unexpected collision between Governrent policy and the job security of many of his members. The leader is Douglas A. Fraser, now vice president in charge of the Chrysler department of the United Automobile Workers, whose election as president of the 1.4 millionmember union at its convention in Los Angeles next week is considered certain. The challenge that has suddenly preoccupied him is presented by President Carter's energy program and the disastrous effects on auto employment and on workers life styles that Mr. Fraser believes it would have, if enacted in present form.

title: Todd Begins New Role as Jets' No. 1 Quarterback
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 10The young man who wants to be called just plain Richard began his takeover today of the Jets' quarterback position, which had been held by a fellow nicknamed Broadway Joe.

title: Technology
description: TUSTIN, Calif.In the energyconservation field as In any other, it is a rare invention indeed that becomes a commercial success. Besides promising unique or at least unusual advantages, the invention must be developed to the level of practical usefulness, win public attention and find the right pattern of ownership. financing and marketing.

title: RIGHT TO SHOOT TO KILL URGED FOR ATOM PLANTS
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)Guards at nuclear power plants should be authorized to shoot to kill any terrorists attempting to steal nuclear materials, according to a Government study.

title: Smith Wins Easily in Jersey City, Dimming Jordan's Political Hopes
description: JERSEY CITY, May 10Thomas F. X. Smith easily won election as Mayor of New Jersey's second largest city tonight by capturing more than 50 percent of the vote against five opponents and eliminating the necessity of a runoff next month.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Money
description: Tuesday, May 10, 1977

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the possible loss for the Swiss Credit Bank was incorrectly given in The Times yesterday. The bank said in Geneva it could give no estimate of the final loss until an audit was completed. A headline in come editions mistakenly implied that the bank had failed.

title: Seattle Slew Shipshape Despite Travailin Derby
description: Billy Turner, the trainer of Seattle Slew, reported yesterday that his prize 3yearold pupil remained in perfect health despite his rugged trip in winning last Saturday's Kentucky Derby. My colt has come back better from the Derby than he did from the Wood, said Turner after having the fleet son of Bold Reasoning loaf around Belmont Park's 1mile oval in a morning outing. Turner's report was received with some surprise. In last month's Wood Memorial, Seattle Slew had won by 3 lengths after an easydoesit trip during which he led almost all the way.

title: Market Place
description: The shares of three popular technologically oriented stocksUniversity Patent, Energy Conversion and Telecreditwere pounded in Monday's overthecounter market as rumors of trouble concerning them circulated in Wall Street.

title: Brown Is Warning The Armed Forces On Spending Plans
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)Defense Secretary Harold Brown is telling the armed services they may have to trim spending plans by $15 billion to $30 billion over five years.

title: Carter Payroll Tax Plan Is Opposed by Business
description: Business executives. economists and members of the financial community said yesterday that they sharply opposed the Carter Administration's plan to enact a big payroll tax increase for employers to bolster the beleaguered Social Security System.

title: About Education
description: One of the most remarkable turnabouts in the nation's schools involves the change in attitude toward mentally and physically handicapped students, who for years have been relegated to the basements of educational concern.

title: A New Kidney: Life on the Edge
description: THE DRAMA OF kidney transplantation has made it one of the best known achievements of modern surgery. Who is not aware that the operation can rescue the gravely ill from dependence on kidney machines or from death itself? Less well known the fact that even while conferring great benefits, the procedure can also cause great emotional pain for patients and their families. Indeed, some behavioral researchers have questioned whether transplantation is really worthwhile.

title: Atom Controversy One of Many for Gov. Thomson
description: CONCORD, N.H., May 10When Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. met at Seabrook with the demonstrators against nuclear power, he quietly asked them to leave the tent city they had set up, and said at one point: I doubt that I could persuade you, and I doubt that you could persuade me, but that's America.

title: A Patient's Unmarked Pills Embroil Him With Police
description: WOODRIDGE, May 10The balmy afternoon weather, a frisky neighborhood dog, and a thoughtful neighbor's good deed combined on Mother's Day to ruin a Manhattan cabinetmaker's trip to suburbia to visit at the home of his business partner's parents in this Bergen County community.

title: Agency to Destroy Atom Power Booklets
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., May 10 (AP)The Energy Research and Development Administration has ordered the destruction of more than 250,000 booklets on nuclear energy because they do not reflect current policies.

title: Youth, 16, Held as Thrower of Rock That Injured Engineer for Conrail
description: MAMARONECK. N.Y., May 10A 16yearold youth here has been arrested and charged with having thrown a rock that fractured the skull of an engineer on a New Haven Division commuter train on April 21.

title: EFFORT TO CURB RISE IN AID TO BIG CITIES DEFEATED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 10In a vote crucial to the urban Northeast and the Middle West, the House of Representatives beat back today an amendment that would have scuttled a new formula meant to funnel increased urban development aid to the large older cities.

title: Energy Rebate or RakeOff?
description: Why are taxes a key part of President Carter's energy plan? According to Republican National Committee Chairman Bill Brock, it's because he'd like to have $70 billion of our money, presumably to fund new social programs. Mr. Brock is paid to put the worst face on the President's motives. But unless millions of Americans with no partisan suspicions can be convinced that Mr. Carter has something else in mind, proposals for energy taxes may well die in Congress.

title: Letters
description: Mayor Beame's proposal to abolish the Board of Education, to appoint his own Commissioner of Education and treat the school system as another department of the city contradicts American educational policy and would, in my opinion, worsen rather than improve schools. Under our state constitution elementary and secondary education is a state function performed by local educational authorities.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Of course, it helps if you can cook, but if you're not the world's best, it may be an idea to take one's mind off the victuals by setting an interesting table. One theme you may not have tried is wild life (who has?) and if the idea intrigues you, collect any china, straw or pottery animals you have around as a centerpiece, use as much wood as you can (service plates, salad bowls, salt and pepper) and zip off to Bergdorf's to order their carved wooden napkin rings from Kenya. There are six animals representedlion, elephant, zebra, antelope, leopard and two kinds of giraffeand each is $4. The gift department on the 4th floor doesn't have them in stock yet but will by the end of the month. In the meantime, they'll accept orders.

title: Ramses II, Pronounced Cured of All Infection, Goes Home From Paris
description: PARIS, May 10The mummy of Ramses II was flown back to Egypt today after scientists here had pronounced cured of all infection and immunized for the future.

title: Fireman Killed in Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP)A fireman was killed today and four others were injured fighting a blaze in a 37story office building here. The death of Joseph Bayne Sr., 42 years old, apparently occurrecl as he stepped off an elevator on the 11 th floor of the building and encountered Intense heat and smoke, officials said. Investigators said that the blaze apgarently occurred in the offices of an insurance compeny, but the mice was unknown.

title: Bid to Exchange New Car Led to Arrest of Suspects in Widow's Murder
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 10Dissatisfaction with a luxury automobile purchased for $13,500 in cash last Thursday led to the arrest late yesterday of three suspects in the slaying of Marjorie V. Jackson, widow of the founder of the Standard Food Store chain, and to the recovery of nearly $2 million.

title: The Labor Scene
description: A.H. Raskin reports that the Government's energy policy is providing problems for Douglas A. Fraser, who is slated to become the next leader of the United Automobile Workers. Page D5.

title: HAROLD SPIVACKE
description: WASHINGTON, May 10Harold Spivacke, retired chief of the music division of the Library of Congress, died yesterday at George Washington University Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Young, Opening Africa T rip, Meets In Ivory Coast With 33 U.S. Envoys
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 10Andrew Young began another African tour today by joining 33 American diplomats from African posts in a meeting here on United States policies toward Africa.

title: Smithsonian Faces House Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, May 10An investigation into the Smithsonian Institution's relationship to the Federal Government will be undertaken by the House Appropriations Subcommittee on the Interior and Related Agencies, was decided today by subcommittee members.

title: Disputed Reading Test Given in 30 School Districts
description: Thirty New York City community school districts gave the longdelayed citywide reading test to more than 600,000 secondto ninthgraders yesterday, but two Queens districts refused to test 43,000 pupilsand the use of any results remained blocked in the courts.

title: Mediation Director Sworn In
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)Wayne L. Horwitz was sworn in today as director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, the Government's labormanagement peacekeeping agency. Mr. Horvitz had been chairman of the Joint LaborManagement Committee of the Retail Food Industry. He succeeds James F. Scearce, who resigned.

title: 12 Jockeys and Trainers Indicted For Fixing Races at Garden State
description: Twelve jockeys and trainers were indicted yesterday on charges of widespread race fixing at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill, N. J. The indictments were a result of an investigation that. began in 1975 and led to one indictment involving, five defendants and four prison toms for race fixing at Atlantic City race track in February, 1976.

title: Annie Garners 10 Tony Nominations
description: ANNIE, the hit musical in town that opened last month, has won almost twice as many nominations as any other show for the American Theater Wing's 1977 Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards.

title: EASTERN WEIGHS BUYING 50 AIRBUS JETS ABROAD
description: BONN, May 10 (AP)Eastern Air Lines is considering ordering more than 50 FrenchGerman A300B Airbus jetliners if it is satisfied with a trial lease this winter of four planes, Frank Borman, Eastern's president, said today.

title: Child's World
description: Now, there have been a lot of things written and said about what went wrong with the 1960's and why. But one littlerealized problem with the latter part of that decade was that the YoYo was gone. There was none of that hypnotic play, none of that staring at the wooden orb as it kept spinning and spinning. No wonder youngsters set off in search of other revolutions.

title: Meadowlands
description: Horses listed in order post positions

title: Cuomo Formally Announces His Bid for Mayoralty; Declares His Independence Despite Governor's Aid
description: After two weeks of public cheerleading and private maneuvering by Governor Carey on his behalf, Mario M. Cuomo formally announced his candidacy for Mayor of New York City yesterday with a declaration of independence from the Governor.

title: Israelis Censor Dispatch on Issue
description: TEL AVIV, May 10A press report from Washington about the policy paper on arms sale restrictions was censored today from Davar, the Labor Federation's newspaper.

title: ACCOUNTING LEADER ASKS U. S. CONTROLS
description: WASHINGTON, May 10The head of Price Waterhouse & Company surprised Congressional critics today by proposing farreaching legislation that, among other things, would place all accounts with publicly owned clients under continuing, formal performance supervision by the Government.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LITTLE WONDER, sometimes, that outoftowners carry away the impression that life in New York is totally insane. Take the case of the Southern man on his way to the airport when a young woman opened the door of his cab while it was stopped in a traffic jam in Queens and implored him to let her share his ride to La Guardia.

title: Joan Crawford Dies at Home
description: Joan Crawford, who rose from waitress and chorus girl to become one of the great movie stars, died yesterday of a heart attack in her apartment at 158 Cast. 68th Street. She gave her age as 69, but some reference works list her as two to four years older.

title: Albany Mall Ball Set
description: ALBANYThe New York State Legislature plans to go out in style this year, as the sponsor of a Constitution Ball, an evening of entertainment open to the public, both to mark the state's bicentennial and to provide a highsociety inaugural for the new convention center at the Albany Mall.

title: Jersey Police Start Campaign
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., May 10 (AP)The state police have started a campaign to stop juveniles from throwing rocks at cars from overpasses on the Garden State Parkway. The program, which includes talks at schools and patrolling by plainclothes troopers in unmarked cars, follows the arrest of 11 youths in rockthrowing incidents during the last two months.

title: DR LOCKE L. MACKENZIE, WORKED ON THE PAP TEST
description: Dr. Locke L. Mackenzie, a gynecologist and obstetrician who helped Dr. G.N. Papanicolaou develop the Pap test for discovering cervical cancer, died yesterday in Veterans Hospital here after a long illness. He lived at 829 Park Avenue and was 77 years old.

title: A Drama and Frost Hurt the Networks
description: SPRING, as it always does, has taken a nip out of the network audiences. Daylight savings time has had something to do with that: Television usually has trouble competing with the sun.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ??ses listed in order of post positions Letter desigoates OTB list??

title: JACK W. DUNLAP, FOUNDER OF DUNLAP & ASSOCIATES
description: Dr. Jack W. Dunlap, who retired in 1970 as chairman and president of Dunlap Associates Inc., industrial and research consultants, of Darien, Conn., died Sunday in a nursing home inTucson, Arizona. He was 74 years old and lived in Green Valley, Ariz.

title: Yanks Send Ricks to Farm
description: The New York Yankees sent a relief pitcher, Ed Ricks, back to their Syracuse farm team yesterday. Ricks, a 26yearold righthander, was called up from the International League club by the Yankees April 26, but had not appeared in any games.

title: Dean Doubts a Place in Abbey for Dylan Thomas
description: LONDON, May 10 (UPI)The Dean of Westminster Abbey has disappointing news for Jimmy Carter. It could take years before the President's favorite poet. Dylan Thomas, is commemorated in the abbey's Poets Corner, if the Welshman is ever so honored.

title: Plan for Palestinian State
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10The Palestine Liberation Organization has reportedly joined with Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia in proposing the establishment of an independent Palestinian state in the Israelioccupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip as part of an overall Middle East settlement.

title: China's Top U.N. Post Again Filled
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10Chen Chu assumed his duties today as China's chief delegate to the United Nations, taking over the position that has been open since Huang Hua left it more than six months ago to become his country's Foreign Minister.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: NEW YORK is fickle, the fickleness being a chief part of its excitement, and so establishments enjoy great popularity one season and die the next. Studio 54, the city's newest big discotheque, opened with the mandatory crowds and publicity the other day, and then insured its future, at least for the time being, when Mick gave a party there for Bianca, and Misha was among the guests. (Obviously, you know who they are.)

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, May 11, 1977

title: Did You Know Kids Still Yell Yaaay?
description: THE BEST POKER GAME in town is at the Bijou, a tiny and hence rarely used playhouse hiding just under the wing of the Morosco. Indeed, because the house is so rarely used, you probably pass it on the street and never notice it, just like My Bill in that KernWodehouse song. You may also give it the goby because the signs adorning its marquee just now say Mummenschanz, nothing but Mummenschanz, and, while you have undoubtedly read recommendations from all of my colleagues for Mummenschanz, you are still nervously evasive about it because you can't quite figure out what it is.

title: Cappiello and Slate Gain Easy Victory In Hoboken's Vote
description: HOBOKEN, May 10 (UPI)  Mayor Steven Cappiello swept to an overwhelming victory tonight over Councilman Anthony H. Romano to win a second fouryear term.

title: The Summit And the Valley.
description: WASHINGTON, May 10President Carter is back from the London economic summit meeting, rather pleased with the principles and personalities he encountered there; but always the test of these highaltitude meetings is what the great men do when they descend into the political valley back home.

title: Open Interest
description: Tuesday, May 10, 1977

title: Political Fighting in U.M.W. Seen As Threatening Energy Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 10In its final month, the listless but nonetheless nationally important campaign for the presidency of the United Mine Workers is beginning to show more clearly why the chaotic politics of the coal fields is of growing concern to Government energy planners as well as to the coal industry.

title: Mailing Lists: You're the Target
description: IF YOU'RE an animal lover, a Harvard Business School graduate, or an osteopath, your name and address are worth 21/2 cents. If you're a magician, a waitress, a solar energy engineer or policeman, your name and address are worth 3 to 5 cents.

title: Canadiens Win by 30 For 20 Lead
description: MONTREAL, May 10If the Montreal Forum goes up in smoke during the National Hockey League playoffs, Coach Don Cherry of the Boston Bruins will probably be the No. 1 suspect.

title: About Real Estate
description: The structural dermatologists who have been examining the terracotta skin of the Woolworth Building over the last year have issued their prescription and the treatment will soon begin. In August, probably.

title: 2 Surrogates Get New Posts
description: The designations of Surrogate Samuel A. Spiegel as administrative judge of Surrogate's Court, New York County, and Surrogate Millard L. Midonick as coordinator and liaison with bar associa tions, were announced yesterday by Presiding Justice Francis T. Murphy Jr., for the justices of the Applellate Division, First Department.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OR DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONE TO OXFORD ??11 UNTIL 9.30 PM. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9.00 AM TO 4.10 PM MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET ??00 WESTCHESTER CO AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (914) WHITE PLAINS 95300 NASSAU CO (516) /4/0500 SUFFOLK CO (516) 6631800, CONNECTICUT (203) 3487767

title: German Climbers Scale Lhotse
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, May 10 (Reuters) An expedition led by Weal Germans has scaled Lhotse, the fourth highest mountain in the Himalayas and the world, the Nepalese Foreign Ministry said today. It said that three expedition members reached the 27,870foot summit on Sunday in the first successful assault on the mountain since it was conquered by the Swiss in 1956.

title: Spoleto Festival U.S.A. Sets 6 Dance Premieres
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., will present six world premieres by major choreographers as part of a daylong Celebration of Scriabin on June 4. The Scriabin Dance Gala will include premieres of a work by Anna Sokolow, performed by the Contemporary Dance System, and five pas de deuxby George Balanchine (for Patricia McBride and JeanPierre Bonnefous), Glen Tetley (for Carla Fracci and Charles Ward), Lar Lubovitch (for Martine van Hamel and Rob Besserer), Frederick Ashton (for Lynn Seymnur and Robert North) and Alberto Mendez (for Alicia Alonso and Jorge Esquivel).

title: Bridge:
description: ARUBA, Netherlands Antilles, May 10 Innovations in organization have marked the first Central American and Caribbean zonal championships, which began here Saturday and continue through next Sunday.

title: Beame Returns Lindsay's Brickbat
description: Mayor Beame, stung by some unexpected criticism from former Mayor John V. Lindsaywho had been stung by criticism by Mr. Beameretorted yesterday that Mr. Lindsay was trying to rewrite history by denying that he had left Mr. Beame with a huge budget deficit.

title: Israel Feels Pressure Of U.S. Comments On the Middle East
description: JERUSALEM, May 10There is growing concern here that recent United States moves and comments on the Middle East are aimed at pressuring Israel into accepting American proposals for a resolution of the conflict between the Jews and the Arabs.

title: At Least 2 Are Dead as Violence Flares in Ulster Strike
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 10Shooting and bombing erupted in Northern Ireland today, raising fears that extremists might he trying to enforce the largely ignored Protestant strike action of the last week.

title: Casino Sill, Amended in Trenton, May Allow Topless Entertainers
description: TRENTON, May 10The State senate Judiciary Committee amended today the casino gambling measure passed last month by the Assembly in a move that could open the way to topless entertainment in Atlantic City casinos.

title: Carter Appears to Have Adopted Quieter Human Rights Approach
description: LONDON, May 10Although President Carter continued during the London economic summit conference to express his concern about the issue of human rights in countries with authoritarian governments, he had apparently begun long before to take a more conventional, cautious and diplomatic approach to the problem.

title: Rain, Chilly Wind in Jersey Cloud Start of Dodge Open
description: DENVILLE, N.J., May 10Today was not a fit day for anyone to be strolling outdoors for five hours. The wind approached gale force and carried a biting cold. Now and then rain splashed down with force, although none of yesterday's snow and sleet was mixed in with the showers.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PAUNCHY MAN in the next seat on the WashingtonNew York shuttle pointed disgustedly at a headline in his newspaper. It told of a $2 million outofcourt settlement by the National Broadcasting Company in a lawsuit by women employees charging sex bias in hiring and promotions.

title: Private Lives
description: ARCHIE BUNKER came into our lives the other morning in an airport bar. It was, of course, too early to be drinking, and in fact nobody really wanted a drink, but travel is a temporary license to shoot breezes and kill time. Like the credit card, travel permits us to multiply our disappointments. And if, in San Francisco, they open the airport bar at 10 o'clock in the morning, somebody has to go in. We might have been on our way from Riyadh to Rangoon. I often think so.

title: Personal Health
description: A HIGH SCHOOL basketball player developed a severe sore throat, swollen glands and a bad headache. A college student had a rash all over her body, swollen lymph nodes under her arms and lowgrade fever. A businessman was bothered by. a recurrent sore throat and became so fatigued that he could hardly do his work, let alone play squash at lunch or go out in the evening.
