A young mother developed severe abdominal pain and was too exhausted to keep up with her housework and two children.

title: The U.N. Today
description: May 11, 1977 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bobick Faces Sternest Test In Bout With Norton Tonight
description: Older and claiming to be wiser, Duane Bobick says he is ready.

title: Connecticut Utility to Make Refund
description: HARTFORD, May 10Agreement was reached here today on the terms of settlement under which Connecticut's major utility company will refund $5.9 million to its customers and reduce the average monthly residential bill by $2 to $3.

title: World News Briefs
description: GENEVA, May 10The Soviet delegate to the arms talks, Vladimir S. Semyonov, said today that the tentative agreement reached at Vladivostok in 1974 must remain the basis for the negotiations that resume here tomorrow.

title: Advertising
description: At thet annual meeting of Ogilvy & Mather International yesterday at the agency, John Elliott Jr., the chairman, treated shareholders to the same upbeat pitch been giving to securities analysts around the country.

title: Leaders in Albany Agree to Plan to Extend Arbitration in Police and Fire Labor Talks
description: ALBANY, May 10The leaders of both houses of the Legislature announced tonight that the yhad agreed to extend for another two years a controversial state law requiring binding arbitration in labor negotiations for police and fire officers.

title: City Ballet Stages Spring Awakening
description: OF COURSE IN actual fact we all know that New York City Ballet began its new season at the New York State Theater not last night but a week ago. But sometimes facts have an odd habit of not being actual. To begin a season with George Balanchine's A Midsummer Night's Dreamnormally used to end the Spring seasonis clearly legitimate enough, but so untraditional as to be disconcerting to simple diehard conservatives. To them at least, it appeared that last night, which was the first normal repertory evening, marked the company's true spring awakening.

title: Dr. Virginia Schein, Peter Bulterman Wed
description: Dr. Virginia Ellen Schein of Guilford, Conn., a visiting associate professor at the School of Organization and Management of Yale University, was married yesterday afternoon to Peter Bulterman of New York, an assistant sales manager with Chandris Inc., a cruiseline concern of New York and London.

title: Cook It Rightand Rare
description: The cuts described in the accompanying article are at their best served rare to medium rare. Longer cooking toughens them and destroys their flavor even more than it would in the standard, expensive cuts.

title: In North Dakota, Too
description: CASSELTON, N.D.I teachor try to teachEnglish to eighth graders in a rural North Dakota community. My school is 1,600 miles from New York City and my students' backgrounds are radically different from those of New York students. So, when I read an article on this page by teacher Marc Bloom about the frustrations of teaching eighthgrade English in New York City, I compared our classes, expecting monumental differences.

title: PRESIDENT BIDS NATO RESPOND FORCEFULLY TO RUSSIANS' BUILDUP
description: LONDON, May 10President Carter urged America's allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today to respond forcefully to a 12year Soviet buildup in Europe that has created forces he described as much stronger than needed for any defense purpose.

title: PRESIDENT BIDS NATO RESPOND FORCEFULLY TO RUSSIANS' BUILDUP
description: LONDON, May 10President Carter urged America's allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today to respond forcefully to a 12year Soviet buildup in Europe that has created forces he described as much stronger than needed for any defense purpose.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN DIEGO, May 10 (UPI)The men who run America's tuna boats voted to remain in port today after the boat owners voted yesterday to resume fishing. Leaders of the Captains and Mates Association, however, summoned members to another meeting tomorrow to reconsider.

title: Deaths
description: ALFORDDonald C., of Norfolk, Conn., died March 11. Husband of Catherine, father of Donald C., 3d, F. S. Jerome, James L. and Linda Alford Sahl, son of Mrs. Henry S. Redmond. Also survived by three granchildren Memorial services Saturday, May 14, 11:30 A.M., Church of the Transfig uration, Norfolk, Conn.

title: Magazine Job for Miss Hearst
description: LOS ANGELES, May 10 (Reuters)Patricia Hearst, freed of the threat of jail yesterday in what her lawyer regarded as the most damaging case against her, plans to work for one of her family's magazines.

title: Findings on Canine ESP Shared by Researcher
description: Do dogs have a sixth sense and, possibly, even a seventh or eighth? Mrs. Sylvia Fisher of Staunton, Va., believes they do. She shared some of her startling experiences related to the field of extrasensory perception in canines with members of a dog fanciers' club yesterday at a luncheon program in the Statler Hilton here. However, the speaker made it clear that ESP in dogs must not be confused with supersensory awareness.

title: Music: Stylish Lieder by Paul Sperry
description: PAUL SPERRY can he counted on for lieder programs that are imaginatively chosen and stylishly performed, and he didn't disappoint Tuesday night at the 02d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. The only pity was the small audienceone hopes the turnout was either because people were discouraged by the feistily demonstrative picket line of Y employees or because everyone was at home watching an academy Awardwinning documentary on old Jewish women on television. But it could he because for all his gifts; Mr. Sperry hasn't really attracted a broad audience.

title: If You Knew Suzy
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Suzy Park Thomson, who has been granted immunity from prosecution so that she can tell what she knows about illegal payoffs to Congressmen by South Korea, is one of the Justice Department's key witnesses before the lethargic Koreagate grand jury.

title: Omaha Elects Writein Mayor
description: OMAHA, May 11 (AP)Al Veys, a grocer, who ran a writein campaign to get on the ballot, was elected mayor of Omaha yesterday. He defeated Betty Abbott a veteran City Council member, 41,630 votes to 29.643, with the tabulation virtually completed. Mr. Veys is a former member of the City Council.

title: About New York
description: The SA 107 is a lustrous console of an instrument, looking as if it were invented for E. Power Biggs and Bach, rather than for suspicious moguls of business and government who want to fathom the sound of silence and be able to sweep for electronic bugs and eavesdropping in 18 different chambers of their domain around the clock.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: KNOCK KNOCK Today marks the 12th annual Riverdale Tour of Houses, an opportunity for New Yorkers to inspect six dwellings in one of the city's most picturesque sectors. The theme this year is Riverdale in Transition, with a selection of buildings that trace architectural history and family living in the Bronx area from traditional fieldstone to contemporary styling. The homes range from formally elegant abodes with large rooms to a remodeled barn and a converted carriage house.

title: Mobutu, Shaken at Start of War, Has New Strength 2 Months Later
description: KINSHASA, ZaireThe war in Zaire's Shaba Province has entered its third month and, while the military advances of the combined Zairian and Moroccan forces remain modest and inconclusive, there is no doubt that on the diplomatic front President Mobutu Sese Seko has achieved a spectacular success.

title: Books: Pages Dance In Sprightly Beat
description: IN 1967, DEBORAH JOWITT, a dancer and choreographer with an interest in the esthetics of the art, began to wrte about dance. Since then, she has been plunging her readers into dance, recreating each performance with something very like its original spontaneity. The fruit of those years of uninhibited dancewatching has now been culled in Dance Beat, Miss Jowitt's first collection of reviews and essays.

title: 54 Israelis Die in Crash of Helicopter During Training
description: JERUSALEM, May 11  Fiftyfour Israeli soldiers were killed last night on a training maneuver when their helicopter crashed shortly after taking off in the vicinity of Jericho on the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Card of Thanks
description: SPIERER  Frieda. Mr. Leon Spierer gratefully acknowledges and thanks one and all for their kind expression of sympathy for the great loss of his beloved wife.

title: Mariners Overcome Yanks, 52
description: SEATTLE, May 11Unlike a fight, a baseball game can't be stopped after one tremendous punch in the first inning, so the Seattle Mariners survived a kingsized homer by Reggie Jackson in the Kingdome tonight and went on to beat the Yankees, 52, in New York's first visit here

title: Legislators Say Abortion Study Invades Privacy
description: ALBANY, May 11The New York State Health Department has been conducting a federally financed study of the effect of abortion involving 48.000 women. without their knowledge, in what two slate legislators charged today was a massive invasion of privacy.

title: U.S. and Seoul to Start Discussion Of Troop Pullout Late This Month
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The United States will begin formal consultations with South Korea later this month on the eventual withdrawal of American ground forces from that country, the State Department said today.

title: G.O.P. in Albany Drops Demand For Delay on Appointing of Judges
description: ALBANY, May 11The Senate Repub lican leadership, in a major change of tactics, today dropped its demand for a delay on a vote on whether to institute appointment rather than election of Court of Appeals judges. The delay would have insured one more election for Chief Judge, in 1978.

title: Mammography Muddle
description: Longoverdue restrictions have just been applied to the routine use of Xrays in screening women for breast cancer in the past four and onehalf years more than 270.000 women have been given mammograms at 27 medical centers around the country as part of a breast cancer detection demonstration project. The goal is entirely laudableto find tumors early, when they are most curable. But evidence is accumulating that the program may actually do more harm than good: the Xrays may conceivably cause cancer in a small number of otherwise healthy women.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY. MAY 11. 1977

title: House Votes Development Bill That Would Give Help to Older Cities
description: WASHINGTON. May 11 (AP)The House voted tonight, 369 to 20, to approve a $14.5 billion housing and community development bill designed to rehabilitate older sections of the country and relieve overcrowding in the new ones.

title: AD EXECUTIVE FORMS GROUP ON INTEGRITY
description: SADDLE BROOK, May 11The heads of several businesses based in northern New Jersey gathered today to form an organization of corporate presidents aimed at halting what the group's director fears is an erosion of integrity and personal identity in the country.

title: With Turner in Dugout, Braves Lose 17th in Row
description: PITTSBURGH, May 11Snakebite . . . We were snakebit.

title: European Proposal For Stock Received By GambleSkogmo
description: GambleSkogmo Inc., a large retail chain and mail order organization, said yesterday that it had a preliminary proposal from an European company to acquire all of the Gamble shares at $45 cash each, for a total of about $200 million.

title: BAN PROPOSED BY '79 ON SPRAYCAN GASES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Three Federal agehcies proposed today that spray can gases that deplete the earth's protective ozone should be phased out and banned within two years.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Bank of California, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bancal TriState Corporation, said it planned to sell 33 of its 74 branches to other qualified California banks. The 33 branches account for about 12 percent of the bank's total deposits.

title: Keeping Up the Game
description: Tenniscourt maintenance costs are significant enough to recall J.P. Morgan's dictumif you have to worry about the upkeep, you can't afford the yacht.

title: DOW LIST SLUMPS 9.24 AS SELLING PRESSURE HITS I.B.M. AND KODAK
description: Selling pressure in two leading stocks, Eastman Kodak and International Business Machines, weighed heavily upon the market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrials slumped more than 9 points in a broad general setback.

title: Music: True to Form
description: SINCE EUGENE ORMANDY'S career has been extraordinarily long and steady, he must have conducted Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 many times. Thus, when he mounted the podium at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night to lead the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Singing City Choir and a quartet of eminent soloists in yet another performance of the Ninth, he projected the confidence of a man who knew exactly what would happen at every instant during the mighty work.

title: CBS Names Chief Officer
description: Directors of CBS Inc., as expected, today formally designated John D. Backe as successor to William S. Paley as CBS chief executive officer. Plans for the change had been announced earlier. Mr. Paley, who had been chief executive officer for 49 years, will continue as company chairman.

title: NORMAN INGREY
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 11 (AP)Norman Ingrey, the British editor in chief of The Buenos Aires Herald for 27 years, died here last night. He was 74.

title: ConsumerPurchase Plans Fall, Pushing Confidence Index Down
description: The Conference Board said yesterday that the Consumer Confidence Index, a measure of how consumers feel about the economy, declined five points from February to April. The index at 85 (19691970=100) reflected the uncertainty that consumers felt after President Carter's talk on energy. The Buying Plans Index now stands at 111.5, showing a drop of two points from February.

title: Dibbs Conquers Nastase In Controversial Struggle
description: DALLAS, May 12 (AP)Eddie Dibbs toppled Ilie Nastase, 61, 46, 62, 63, in a controversial match of the $200,000 World Championship Tennis final tonight. Dibbs meets Jimmy Connors Friday night in the semifinals.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MAY 12, 1977

title: Is Nothing Sacred? Designer Recliners
description: There is sacred furniture and there is profane, a wellknown sociologist once said. Sacred furniture goes in the living roomprofane in the den.

title: Food Shortage and Inflation Beset OilRich Venezuela
description: CARACAS, VenezuelaThis nation, with all its vast oil wealth, is experiencing serious shortages, speculation and inflationary pressures. Prices and the expectations of consumers are rising faster than goods and services can be produced.

title: All's Quiet On the Potomac
description: WASHINGTON I think some people had the notion that the day after the Inaugural the place was going to swing, said Jane Ikard, wife of of the former Texas Congressman, Frank Ikard, who now heads the Washingtonbased American Petroleum Institute.

title: Johannesburg Voters Shun Rightist
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 11Roelof F. Botha, South Africa's new Foreign Minister, looked grimly into the television cameras that trailed him around the constituency where he was elected to Parliament today. I am being accused of selling out the country to blacks, he said, perspiration gleaming on his brow. I've virtually been branded an American agent.

title: Courts Are Told About Appraisal In Hughes Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 11  The process by which a highly publicized appraisal made it appear that Howard R. Hughes's wealth had shrunk by at least 75 percent over 10 years has been described in documents filed in probate courts in Houston and Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Bridge
description: ARUBA, Netherlands Antilles, May 11The defending champions from Panama held the lead halfway through the qualifying stage of the Central American and Caribbean championships here today.

title: BEAME DETAILS PLANS TO REDUCE POLLUTION
description: Plans for a major reduction of air pollution from four large incinerators operated by New York City were announced yesterday by Mayor Beame and the Federal Government. The plans are meant to bring the incinerators into compliance with the Clean Air Act.

title: 2 Other Propellants Are Already in Use
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Two other types of propellants are already in use to some extent as alternatives to the ozonedepleting aerosol gases.

title: 2 New York Republicans Help Carter's Proposals For Stimulating Economy
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Two New York Republicans, John W. Wydler of Nassau County and Frank Horton of Rochester, will be playing major roles tomorrow in trying to push an important part of the Carter Administration's economicstimulus program through a divided House of Representatives.

title: Borge on Broadway Is Arriving Oct. 3
description: Victor Borge, the Danishborn pianistcomedian, will make a monthlong from Oct. 3 to 29 with his new show. Borge on Broadway, at a theater to he announced. The performer opened a limited engagement performance on Broadway in 1953; it lasted through January of 1956.

title: Bus Driver's Killing Protested in Ulster As Strike Weakens
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 11For eight days militant Protestants have tried, with little success, to bring Northern Ireland to a halt with a general strike. Today bus drivers throughout the province refused to work, but not because of any sympathy for the Protestant cause.

title: Business Records

title: Michigan Hesitating on Plans For President Ford Museum
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 11Herbert Hoover, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson all have, or will have, libraries and museums to commemorate their Presidencies. It is getting to be almost commonplace, as Paul Henry, the Republican Party chairman in the Fifth Congressional District here, said yesterday.

title: Toll Now 14 in Amsterdam Fire
description: AMSTERDAM, May 11 (AP)The death count in the Polen Hotel fire climbed to 14 today as workers dug four more bodies out of the debris. Nineteen more persons were still missing two days after the fire. Most were believed to he members of a Swedish tour group, but the police said some may have left the area without notifying authorities.

title: MEXICO WILL FREE 1,943 HELD IN MINOR DRUG CASES
description: MEXICO CITY, May 11The Attorney General of Mexico announced today that about 2,000 Mexicans and foreigners being held on charges of possessing small quantities of drugs would be released in the next few days and that all charges against them would be dropped.

title: How Judge Toils Over a Long Day
description: The figure of Justice in the painting that towers above the bench in Part 35 at 100 Centre Street has her eyes wide open. She was painted in the late 19th century, as Frank Lanotte, the clerk of the court, will tell you, and at that time she was considered modern, because she was not blind.

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary of Joan Crawford in The Times yesterday incorrectly gave the address of her New York apartment. She lived at 150 East 69th Street.

title: Cruguet Gets Overdue Salute
description: Jean Cruguet, the winning jockey aboard Seattle Slew in Saturday's Kentucky Derby, finally received his due at Aqueduct. On Monday, he failed to get the salute from the Big A's announcer always accorded a victorious Derby rider. It was an oversight that could not be remedied until yesterday because the French jockey had only that one mount on Monday and did not ride Tuesday. When he appeared for the first time yesterday (in the second race), he was immediately saluted over the publicaddress system for his Derby success. The crowd responded with a substantial cheer.

title: Market Place
description: The Federal Signal Corporation, a company whose shares traded at 2 a little more than two years ago, has evidently gotten attention from two types of purchasers since then.

title: Bonn, Under Domestic Pressures, Slows Breeder Reactor Research
description: BONN, May 11The West German Government, faced with political Criticism of its nuclear energy policies, is being forced to slow down research on the plutoniumbased breeder reactors that President Carter opposes.

title: Bell Sees Threat to Minority Voting Law in Bill to Ease Registration
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  Attorney General Griffin B. Bell told Congress today that President Carter's plan for Election Day registration should not be used to weaken longstanding civil rights laws that bar discrimination against minoritygroup voters in the South and elsewhere.

title: Three Added to House Energy Unit In Move Linked to Gas Prices Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Liberals on the House Commerce Committee have quietly expanded a key energy subcommittee in an apparent effort to neutralize a Texas Congressman who is pressing for deregulation of natural gas prices. The expansion was a graphic demonstration of the legislative maneuvering that has begun to surround President Carter's energy package.

title: Douglas In Coma
description: LOS ANGELES, May 11  Michael Douglas, winner of an Academy Award as coproducer of the best picture of 1975, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, has been signed to costar with Genevieve Bujold in MetroGoldwynMayer's Coma, Richard Shepherd,. MGM senior vice president and worldwide head of theatrical productions, announced today.

title: Disks: de Larrocha
description: Given the performing heights she has scaled and her current standing in virtuoso ranks, Alicia de Larrocha could very well stay away from new or relatively unknown music without risking much criticism. Indeed, most other artists in her class confine themselves exclusively to recycling old pieces.

title: RETIRED LECLERC CHIEF IS AN APPARENT SUICIDE
description: GENEVA, May 11The police said today that the body of Charles Bouchard, a 69yearold retired manager of a private bank, Leclerc & Company, which was closed Monday, was found floating in the lake here, an apparent suicide. Although retired from the hank since the outset of 1974, Mr. Bouchard is said to have remained in contact with some clients. His car was found parked near the dock from which he is believed to have thrown himself into the lake.

title: Beame and Carey Say Work Goes On Despite Their Feud
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Beame remained at odds yesterday over whether they should sit down and talk about politics, especially mayoral politics. But both agreed that their political feud was not preventing them from discussing the business of government.

description: STUARTRuth Sherman. Beloved wife of John Stuart, Jr. Memorial services to be held at St. Stephen's Church, 120 W. 69 St.. N.Y.C. on Saturday May 14 at 4:30 P.M.

title: ESTELLA GOLDSTONE FOX
description: Estella Goldstone Fox, the widow of David Fox, who was president of Jay Thorpe, the women's specialty store no longer in existence, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived at 101 Central Park West.

title: Hers
description: HILDY and I have finally figured out what to do about the equal rights amendment; we only hope it's not too late. Either way, though, Hildy still plans to finish her book on the E.R.A. She can just change the title from E.R.A. How We Got It Passed to E.R.A.? We Almost Got It Passed, But...

title: Norton Gets $2 Million Young Spurned
description: With a right hand to the Adam's apple that shocked Duane Bobick into submission after only 58 seconds, Ken Norton emerged at Madison Square Garden last night as the $2 million challenger for Muhammad Ali's world heavywe??ght championship at Rio de Janeiro in October but boxing's $15 million man remained mystified as to why Jimmy Young spurned the chance. Ben Thompson made some money selling airconditioning units and cars and now he hopes to make some money as boxing's newest promoter, Ben Thompson is a 36yearold Californian with a boyish face that is betrayed by softly styled steelgray hair and a flock of crow's feet around the eyes. He claims to have a contract for Muhammad Ali's last fight against the NortonBobick winner, with the champion guaranteed $12 million and the challenger $2 million. At least another $1 million has been budgeted, including $250,000 in training expenses for each of the gladiators. But at lunch yesterday in the Statler Hilton across from the Garden, the new promoter was still wondering why Jimmy Young spurned not only the $2 million but also the chance to win the title.

title: Sound
description: THE JOB OF A turntable is deceptively simple. Just going in circles seems easy enough. But spinning a record imposes rather stringent demands if the result is to resemble the true sound of music. One of these requirements the absence of rumble was treated at length last week. Equally important, the turntable must rotate at a constant rate, or else the music wobbles in pitch, a condition onomatopoeically called wow. What's more, it must turn without a trace of chugging, or else the music suffers from a spurious vibrato known as flutter. The latter is not always obvious to the ear, but has a subliminal effect, falsifying the texture of voices and instruments.

title: John Gilland Brunini, 77, Dies; Headed Temple at World's Fair
description: John Gilland Brunini, director of the Temple of Religion at the 193839 New York World's Fair and from 1945 to 1949 executive director of the Park Association of New York, died last Thursday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, York Avenue and 72d Street, where he lived. He was 77 years old.

title: 21,108 Watch Cosmos Defeat Sting by 2 to 1
description: CHICAGO, May 11Vito Dimitrijewic broke a 11 deadlock early in the second half to give the Cosmos a 21 victory over the Chicago Sting at Soldiers Field tonight before a crowd of 21,108.

title: Oakes Appointed by Syracuse U. As Newhouse Visiting Professor
description: John B. Oakes, senior editor of The New York Times, was named yesterday as first S. I. Newhouse Visiting Professor at Syracuse University. He will conduct onceaweek seminars on editorial writing and policy, starting this fall, while maintaining his duties at The Times.

title: Opera: Adriana Lecouvreur
description: OPERAS THAT REMAIN on the fringe of the repertory are usually there for a good reason. They are weak musically or theatrically and they require a great singer or a highpowered personality to give them validity behind the footlights. With her superb artistry, for example, Mary Garden was able to raise many of the feebler Massenet works to a level where they seemed worth watching.

description: BASEBALL

title: Tuna Boats Return To Sea, but Officers Sail Under Protest
description: SAN DIEGO, May 11 (UPI)The United States tuna fleet was going to sea main today but the boats were commanded by captains and mates who voted to go only under protest against Government restrictions.

title: Hunt, ExJailhouse Artist, Exhibits 41 Paintings.
description: MIAMI BEACH, May 11If everything goes well, said Irene Rubin, greeting visitors last night to an exhibition of paintings by E. Howard Hunt Jr., we might take it to New York.

description: Thursday, May 12, 1977

title: Pop: Bit of 3d Ave. El
description: Michael Brown, whose songs have taken him from Le Ruban Bleu to Broadway Different Times in 1972) with stops en route off Broadway and in industrial shows, is presenting a sampling of his work this week at the Ballroom, starting with the song with which he made his cabaret debut at the Ruban Bleu in 1949 and projecting to the anticipated production of a revue called I Think I Just Heard a Discouraeine Word.'

title: Trading in Commodities Surges As Turnover Increases by 41%
description: Trading activity on the nation's 10 commodity futures exchanges continued to surge last month as the turnover rose 41 percent from the yearearlier level. For 1977's first four months, volume was up 52 percent from a year ago.

title: Koch Driving Hard to Get Funds To Pay for TV Campaign Spots
description: One by one, those in the welldressed crowd drifted into Jean Bach's handsome home in the Washington Mews, each pausing on the way to where the maid took the drink order to first shake hands with Representative Edward I. Koch.

title: Bruno Retains Lead in Dodge Open
description: DENVILLE, N.J., May 11Bob Bruno is a 43yearold club professional who has had his day on the golfing tour, competing for those big purses but never quite striking it rich. He spent six years chasing the young Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer at his peak, and the others who were winners in 1961 through 1966.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Rita McGuire, 65; Fordham Professor In Social Services
description: Rita A. McGuire, senior professor of social work at Fordham University's School of Social Service, died at the age of 65 yesterday at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn. She had lived at 245 Henry Street, Brooklyn.

title: Screen: Peckinpah's Gory 'Cross of Iron'
description: WATCHING Sam Peckinpah's "Cross of Iron," you realize it's still possible to take this erratic director"The Wild Bunch," "The Ballad of Cable Hogue" and "The Killer Elite"seriously but it's no longer very rewarding. It's like sifting Coney Island sand for pennies. You work all day to come up with a backache."Cross of Iron" is Mr. Peckinpah's least interesting, least personal film in years, a hysterically elaborate, made-in-Yugoslavia war spectacle, the work of international financiers and a multinational cast, most of whom are supposed to be Germans although they sound like delegates to an international PEN convention.The film, which opened at Loews State 2, the Orpheum and other theaters yesterday, is about a small detachment of German troops on the collapsing Russian front in 1943. There's the gracious German colonel, played by James Mason, who is English; the stiff-backed Prussian captain, played by Maximilian Schell, who is Swiss; the rugged German corporal, played by James Coburn, who is from Nebraska, and the German enlisted men who are played by real Germans.Although throughout the film the artillery barrages are nonstop, the rations are meager, and disease is everywhere, the worst thing these soldiers endure is a speech contagion. Whenever Mr. Schell or the German actors have a scene with the English or American actors, the accents of the English and Americans go suddenly Teutonic as if in the siege of belligerent consonants.There's not a decent performance in the entire film, something for which the director must be held accountable, along with the people who provided the screenplay. This is nothing much more than a frame for the special effects and a slight story about the antagonism between the brave, disillusioned corporal (a Good German) and the aristocratic Prussian (the Bad German). It may be of historical interest to note that there's only one Nazi in the movie and although he's not nice, it's the Prussian who's the villain.Mr. Peckinpah's continuing concern for the corruptibility of children is something, given the once-over-lightly treatment behind the opening credits, which detail the rise and fall of the Nazi war machine, while the rest of the movie is virtually a parody of his machismo themes. "A man is generally what he feels himself to be," says Mr. Coburn at one point, but these characters don't have a convincing feeling among them.I can't believe that the director ever had his heart in this project, which, from the beginning, looks to have been prepared for the benefit of the people who set off explosives. However, the battle footage is so peculiarly cut into the narrative that you often don't know who is doing what to whom. The visual effect, especially when bodies, buildings and vehicles are blown up in slow motion, becomes as Abstractly Expressionistic as a Jackson Pollock. The blood is thicker than water. It's paint.

title: U.S. LIFTS SPECIAL 5% TAX ON TAIWANESE FOOTWEAR
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)The Treasury Department made it a bit easier today for Taiwanese manufacturers to sell shoes in the United States.

title: Crafts Calendar: May's the Month To See a Show
description: MAY is a merry month indeed for anyone interested in crafts. There are gallery shows, store and museum shows, and outdoor fairs, with work ranging from the utilitarian to pure sculpture. Following is a list of shows and events in Manhattan and the suburbs.

title: Harold Brown Bids U.S. Buy More Arms From NATO Allies
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was engulfed by numerous problems that threatened its effectiveness.

title: $118.5 BILLION OUTLAY FOR DEFENSE ADOPTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 11House and Senate budget conferees reached an agreement on defense spending today after getting a reluctant promise of cooperation from key Senate committee chairmen.

title: Vote on Transit Act Is Hoped For Before the Legislature Adjourns
description: TRENTON, May 11Alan Sagner, the State Commissioner of Transportation, expressed hope today that his department's proposed Transportation Improvement Act of 1977 would be voted on by both houses of the Legislature before they recess for the summer.

title: Carter Plans to Hold A News Parley Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)President Carter will hold a news conference tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. The news conference will be carried live by the three commercial networks and the major radio networks.

It was part of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season.

description: Common sense and constitutional law are beginning to converge in the matter of the Concorde, and now New York as well as the supersonic liner must be tested.

title: Juantorena Unlikely to Run at Jamaica Meet
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 11Is Alberto Juantorena really studying economics, as his Cuban teammate, Alejandro Casanas, would have us believe? Or is the great Olympic 400 and 800 meter champion not quite fit enough to risk a race against two eager challengers, Mike Boit of Kenya and Mark Belger of Villanova?

title: People and Business
description: Attorney General Griffin W. Bell yesterday told the Senate Judiciary Committee that he would make antitrust enforcement his No. 1 priority and would place more emphasis on the oil industry and other energy producers.

description: The steel industry appeared to he falling in line yesterday with a price increase of G percent for its products that go into automobiles, appliances, machinery and tools.

title: Union Carbide, Spurning New York City's Appeal, Will Move to Connecticut
description: DANBURY, Conn., May 11The Union Carbide Corporation made final today its announced plan to move its headquarters from 270 Park Avenue in New York City to Danbury.

title: Mrs. Carter to Visit 7 Countries In Latin America Starting May 30
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 Rosalynn Carter's press office has made public the seven countries that she is to visit during her Latin American tour May 30June 12. They are Jamaica, Costa Rica, Equador, Peru, Brazil, Colombia and Venezuela.

title: BRAZILIAN COFFEE CROP IS EXPECTED TO REBOUND
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)  This year's coffee crop in Brazil, the world's leading producer, is expected to rebound sharply from last season's frostreduced harvest, but to lag sharply behind prefrost levels, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Carter to Meet With Senators On Amendments Affecting Israel
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Carter has invited some key senators to meet with him tomorrow morning to discuss their concern that the Administration might he jeopardizing Israel's ability to buy or coproduce advanced American arms.

title: Broad Tax Cut Being Considered In Carter Plan, Blumenthal Says
description: CHICAGO. May 11 (Reuters)Treasure Secretary Michael Blumenthal said today that the Carter Administration was considering a broad reduction of taxes as part of the tax reform package promised for later this year.

title: VANCE FLIES TO SPAIN ON AN OFFICIAL VISIT
description: MADRID, May 11Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, while flying to Spain for a brief visit, today, avoided raising expectations that his talks next week with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would bring a breakthrough in negotiations on arms limitation or even result in a framework for progress.

title: Emergency Landing for 727 Jet
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 11 (UPI)An Eastern Air Lines 727 jetliner with 14 persons aboard made a successful emergency landing today on a foamed runway at Tampa International Airport. The flight, No. 152, was bound from Miami to New York by way of Orlando when the pilot detected what appeared to he a malmunction in the landing gear shortly after takeoff from Miami. The plane was diverted to Tampa for the emergency landing.

title: Korean Shoe Negotiations Fail
description: 7 SEOUL, South Korea, May 11 (Reuters)South Korean and United States officials today failed after three days of talks to negotiate a voluntary curb on exports of Korean nonrubber shoes to the United States, Korean officials said.

title: 6% Steel Price Rise Prevailing; Voluntary Move Hailed by U.S.
ExPolice Aide Convicted in London
description: LONDON, May 11 (UPI)The former chief of Scotland Yard's obscene publications squad was found guilty today of accepting bribes from a pornography peddler. Alfred W. Moody, a former detective chief superintendent, was convicted on three charges in a marathon Old Bailey trial. The jury was still considering 27 other charges against Mr. Moody and five other former detectives of the Yard's obscenity team.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The sons of two reputed members of what lawenforcement officials have called the Angelo Bruno organizedcrime family are seeking to buy a nightclubrestaurant in Atlantic City.

title: FRENCH AND BRITISH PLAN FLIGHTS JUNE 20

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency said today that one of its divisions proposed in 1975 to test a possible cancercausing fungicide on Mexicans, to bypass its own ban on human testing in the United States.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Geier Jr., 42 years old, and Carl Spielvogel, 48, were elected presidentchief operating officer and chairman of the executive committee, respectively, of the Interpublic Group of Companies, the world's largest advertising communications company.

description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)The United States will join Britain in exploring ways of transferring power in Rhodesia from the white minority to blacks, the State Department said today.
