description: WASHINGTONThe Federal Reserve Board is again seeking legislation to bring the 88 foreign banks operating in this country under Federal supervision. And this time, legislative analysts say, the chances for passage are favorable.

title: Callaghan's SoninLaw Named Ambassador to U.S.
description: LONDON, May 11Prime Minister James Callaghan's Labor Government stirred a political tempest today by naming Mr. Callaghan's soninlaw, Peter Jay, a 40yearold journalist and broadcaster, as the new British Ambassador to Washington.

title: The Happy Journey of Holden and Powers
description: Los ANGELES WILLIAM HOLDEN stands beneath a $5.000 Gogodala ceremonial canoe, 30 feet long, in a Los Angeles art gallery while his hand rests on a feathered wooden crocodile that is swallowing a clay man. The canoe, six carved crocodiles and 60 fiber dancing masks, anthropomorphic stools, basket hooks and grotesque chairs shaped like human beingswith their phalluses covered by grass skirtsbelong to Holden and a friend, the actress Stefanie Powers. who stands beside him. Holden and Miss Powers are selling the art work for the Papua New Guinean Government.

title: NEW YORK CITY HELD FAULTY IN INJURY PAY
description: The head of the State Workmen's Compensation Board accused New York City yesterday of heartless treatment of its employees though its failure to pay promptly and properlyworkmen's cornpensationfor injuries sufferedat work.

title: Letters
description: Defense For Yale Students

title: Tougher Marijuana Law Killed
description: AUGUSTA, Mc., May 11 (UPI)The Maine House of Representatives rejected a bill today that would reinstate possession of a small amount of marijuana as a criminal instead of a civil offense. The vote was 57 to 83.

title: Joan Mondale Finds SoHo More Than SoSo
description: It was a pairing of participatory and political art. There was the large white room, filled with sunlight and silence while the wife of the Vice President of the United States was invited to walk, brown pumps and all, on a set of unprepossessing metal plates that turned out to be works of art, there, too, were the onlookers pessing in to ask, for the record, what it felt like to stand on sculpture.

title: An Appalachian Drama Captures Washington Audience
description: WASHINGTON, May 11A troupe of Appalachian Mountain players whose members have spent two years developing a special theatrical form for their own people is discovering that city folks, too, respond enthusiastically to their taletelling drama.

title: OBSTACLES FACING A NATIONAL MARKET
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 11The development of an electronic intermarket execution system linking the nation's securities exchanges and the overthecounter market is close to achievement, but important obstacles still must be overcome, securities officials said today.

title: U.S. Is Said to Fear Peking's Ire If Taipei Names New Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP)Fearing an angry reaction from China, the Stare Department for the last two years has denied requests by Taiwan to appoint a new ambassador here, according to Administration officials.

title: With Morgan Delivering in the Clutch, Reds Set Back Cardinals Again, 51
description: Joe Morgan, the AllStar second baseman of the world champion Cincinnati Reds, had some thoughts recently on the Reds' failure to deliver base hits at opportune times.

title: Money
description: Wednesday, May 11, 1977

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (Reuters)The South African Government has approved a visit by Andrew Young, the United States chief delegate to the United Nationsbut not on the date he had originally planned.

title: Norton Knocks Out Bobick in 58 Seconds Of First Round With a Smashing Attack
description: In less than a minute last night, Ken Norton proved he was still the No. 1 contender for Muhammad Ali's heavyweight boxing crown and Duane Bobick was no contender at allat least not yet.

title: EDWARD E. KNOUREK
description: CHICAGO, May 11 (AP)Edward E. Knourek, an Olympic pole vaulter who in 1916 set a record with a vault of 12 feet 16 inches, died yesterday. He was 85 years old. Mr. Knourek, who retired from competition in 1924, died in a nursing home in the suburb of Berwyn.

title: Historic Pottery: A Craft Endures
description: NOT MANY PEOPLE outside Bucks County, Pa. seem to know about the Moravian Tile and Pottery Works. The pottery has been producing decorative and floor tiles intermittently since its founding in 1912 by Henry Chapman Mercer. If it is no longer the commercial venture it was in its heyday, in the 10 years since it was purchased by the Bucks County Parks and Recreation Department the Pottery Works has begun to function again. One of a very few handmade tile factories in the United States, its relief tiles are an unusual feature. And beyond its significance as a craft center, it is a fascinating monument to the eccentric, courtly and somewhat sad old gentleman who created it.

title: Rockets Rout 76ers, Trail in Playoffs, 21
description: HOUSTON, May 11 The Houston Rockets reverted to their twocenter lineup tonight and that was the difference as they took an early lead and coasted to a 11894 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Log Homes Move Up
description: CHEERS AROSE IN THE mountains of Dutchess County the other day as two flatbed trucks rumbled up a twisty road, carrying what appeared to be a giant Lincoln Log set.

title: ALBANY REPORT CITES MEDICAL COVERUPS
description: Doctors, hospitals and medical societies in New York State have consistently evaded a responsibility to protect the public against harm from incompetent and uunethical physicians, two New York State Assembly committees charged yesterday in a strongly worded interim report after four months of examining medical practice.

title: How Judge Toils Over a Long Day
description: The figure of Justice in the painting that towers above the bench in Part 35 at 100 Centre Street has her eyes wide open. She was painted in the late 19th century, as Frank Lanotte, the clerk of the court, will tell you, and at that time she was considered modern, because she was not blind.

title: Books of The Times
description: I CAN TELL YOU why I had trouble reading Calvin Trillin's first novel, Runestruck; the print wouldnt hold still because the book made me shake so with laughter. What isn't so simple is to explain just why I laughed throughout it. I can thumbnail the plot. It's about how the small MaineCoast town of Berryville is reduced to chaos when a runestone is found there, suggesting that Berryville may be the true location of Leif Erikson's Vinland: the town becomes divided among the natives, who want to exploit what they see as a commercial bonanza; the summer people, who wish to protect the natural ecology of the place; and various ethnic interests that feel they have a stake in who really discovered America. But all such a summary really tells you is that Mr. Trillin has created a wonderful vehicle for poking fun at everything from smalltown politics to the American business ethic to the uproar surrounding Alex Haley's Roots. Not why the novel is funny.

title: House Panel, Ignoring President, Votes to Continue Nuclear Project
description: WASHINGTON. May 11 (AP)A House committee, brushing aside President Carter's recommendation to end work on a Federal breeder nuclear reactor project at Clinch River, Tenn., voted instead today to continue the project.

title: Washington & Business
description: Legislation to bring foreign banks operating in the United States under Federal supervision is again being sought by the Federal Reserve Board. The chances for passage are favorable, according to the legislative analysts. Page D3.

title: New York Area Coal Comeback Looms as U.S. Tells 7 Plants to Convert
description: Coal, abandoned as an energy source in the New York metropolitan area a decade ago as too costly and environmentally unsound, may soon be making a comeback.

title: In Tears, Another Quarry Reaches the End of the Line
description: It had the feel of an old movie.

title: BAN PROPOSED BY '79 ON SPRAYCAN GASES
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Three Federal agencies proposed today that spray can gases that deplete the earth's protective ozone should be phased out and banned within two years.

title: Home Repair Q & A
description: Q. Many of the flagstones have comeloose on our outdoor steps and cement). What is the best way to get the stones to adhere in their original positions?Dr. H. D. S., Larchmont, N.Y.

title: ABC Raises News Budget
description: ELTON H. RULE, president of the American Broadcasting Companies Inc., said the corporation would increase the aparating budget for ABC News at least 25 percent this year in an effort to strengthen it.

title: Neighbors of Kennedy Airport Deplore Decision to Allow the Concorde to Land
description: Residents of communities near Kennedy International Airport reacted angrily yesterday to the decision of a Federal judge to allow the Concorde to use the airport.

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT
description: THERE is a knack or perhaps an art to placing plants around a house to landscape it attractively. One of the main reasons new homeowners find themselves in a quandary about landscape design is that so much of the site planning and planting has already been done for them.

title: Bacteria Use Changes Product Cancer Tests
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Scientists working here with colonies of tiny bacteria in little laboratory dishes are brewing a revolution in the ways that chemical and pharmaceutical companies test their new products for cancer risks.

title: Closing of Gimbel's Buying Office And Shift to Outside One Expected
description: Gimbel Brothers Inc., which recently changed the managements of two major store divisions, is expected to announce this morning the discontinuance of its decadesold corporate buying office, and the shift of that function to an independent office, the Mutual Buying Syndicate.

title: Andy's Automat
description: ARE YOU ready for the AndyMat? Andy Warhol is going into the fastfood business, and Camphell's Soup isn't on the menu. Mr. Warhol, a 20thcentury manchild, loves junk food and so does his friend Geoffrey Leeds, the boywonder entrepreneur who brought the London Bridge and the Queen Mary to the United States. He also gave New York the discos Shepherd's. L'Interdit and Escadrile.

title: Badillo Would Put Poverty Help In New York Into One Big Basket
description: Representative Herman Badillo, concededly considering a race against the other candidates for Mayor, called yesterday for replacing all New York City's antipoverty programs with a single massive youth training and construction program.

title: Coors Brewery Agrees in U.S. Court Not to Discriminate in Employment
description: DENVER, May 11 (AP)Although not admitting past bias toward blacks, MexicanAmericans and women, the Adolph Coors Company has signed an agreement in Federal court promising not to discriminate in its hiring practices in the future.

title: HELSINKI CABINET QUITS; MAJORITY COALITION DUE
description: HELSINKI, Finland, May 11 (UPI)The threeparty minority Government of Prime Minister Martti Miettunen resigned today to clear the way for the appointment of a majority coalition before President Urho Kekkonen leaves next Tuesday for a 12day official visit to the Soviet Union.

title: Speaking and Writing English Good
description: Walter Lippman said, almost 50 years ago: While we insist that every American be educated, there is nothing in particular that an educated man must know. If this statement was at all valid in 1928, it is triply today. If we want a further generation of illiterates to enter the college and university, all we need to do is continue our present practices in many elementary and secondary schools. Please the students by giving them plenty of exciting courses; make sure they get no continuity by giving hits and pieces of term courses which hear no relation to one another, and make sure that we don't kill their individuality by grading too harshly or insisting on complete sentences.

title: JUDGE URGES CUTBACK ON TOLLS FOR BRIDGES LINKING CITY, JERSEY
description: In a wideranging decision that could strike at the heart of the financial operations of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, an administrative law judge appointed by the Federal Highway Commission recommended yesterday that tolls be rolled back to $1 on all four Port Authority bridges linking New York and New Jersey.

title: Court Confines Jets to Shea Stadium
description: In a decision filled with emotional language, State Supreme Court Justice Harold Baer ruled yesterday that the New York Jets may not play home games anyplace but Shea Stadiumthis year, or for the six other years remaining on their lease with the city.

title: Plan Set for New York City Loan
description: New York City and the municipal employee pension systems reached agreement yesterday on how the pension funds would make their next $1 billion in loans to the city, removing the possibility of yet another fiscal crisis next week.

title: Proposed Nominee for Chairman Of Federal Bank Board Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, May 11A coalition of public affairs lobbying groups declared today that the man President Carter apparently has selected to be chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board should not be nominated because of his deep involvement in the industry.

title: Post Office Will Sue A.M.A. for $1 Million
description: CHICAGO, May 11 (AP)The United States Postal Service, saying that the American Medical Association had underpaid for postage, will sue the association for more than $1 million this week, the A.M.A. says.

title: BILLS RATE TOPS 5%; FED SLOWS THE RISE
description: Shortterm interest rates rose yesterday and threemonth Treasury bill rates climbed above 5 percent for the first time since Oct. 1. The Federal Reserve pumped some temporary reserves into the banking system when the interest rate on overnight loans moved up to 5 percent, and the action slowed the rate rise. In the newissue market, the BankAmerica Corporation's $200 million issue yielding 8.35 percent and the Port of Portland's $84 million of taxexempt bonds yielding up to 5.80 percent all sold out quickly.

title: Shy Dawn Takes $52,650 Vagrancy
description: Shy Dawn, a 6yearold campaigner who has jokingly been described as mare who has served long and well enough to deserve a gold watch, scored her third stakes triumph of the year yesterday. The daughter of Grey Dawn II, owned by Jacques D. Wimpfheimer, was the winner of the $52,650 Vagrancy at Aqueduct. Made the $3.60for$2 choice by the crowd of 16,154, Shy Dawn scored by threequarters of a length.

title: Leonard Silk
description: The naming of unemployment as the No. I problem facing the major industrial democracies at last weekend's economic summit conference caught the headlines, but what did it signify? Until President Carter left for London, his economic policy had undergone a pronounced shift to the right. The President appeared to be taking his cue from his conservative advisersBert Lance, the budget director, and Arthur F, Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in showing greater concern about inflation than unemployment.

title: Designer Turns To Home
description: THEY ALL WANT to be homebodies: Yves St. Laurent, Pierre Cardin, Missoni, Bill Blass, Kasper, Halston. They're designing sheets and towels as fast as their highfashion designer names can he printed on fabric. Halston's new carpet designs are just being introduced. And now Mary McFadden, whose meteoric, fouryear rise to fame has made her clothes and jewelry status symbols for the very rich, has entered the world of home furnishings.

title: TV: Enter Spirited Poldark
description: POLDARK, the new Masterpiece Theater series public television, faces the unsettling, and unfair, possibility of being punished by neglect for presuming to fill the electronic shoes of the recently departed and beloved Upstairs, Downstairs. That would be unfortunate, for both viewers and the 16part series, which has been the British Broadcasting Corporation's biggest dramatic hit in England since the The Forsyte Saga. The first episode, which was unveiled last Sunday at 9 P.M., will be repeated on Channel 13 tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: Carter's Proposal to Raise Social Security Taxes Could Put Fiscal Strain on State and Local Governments
description: WASHINGTON, May 11If enacted by Congress, President Carter's proposal to increase Social Security taxes paid by employers could cause new fiscal stress for state and local governments, including New York City.

title: NATO Answers Challenge, but Cost Could Be High
description: LONDON, May 14The North Atlantic Alliance's agreeement today to prepare its forces for the changed defense needs of the next decade was seen as a success for President Carter, and a promise of headaches to come for many member governments.

title: News Summary
description: Assurances to Israel of America's special relationship and promises of needed arms and advanced technology were made by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance after talking with Israel's Foreign Minister, Yigal Alton, at the United States Embassy in London. Mr. Vance said American suggestions for Middle East solution would he made to the parties involved and there would be no attempt to impose a solution. Israeli confidence in the policy of the United States was said to have been restored. [Page A1, Columns 12.]

title: Color TV Talks to Reopen
description: TOKYO May 11 (Reuters)Japan and the United States will reopen talks next week on restrictions on Japanese color TV exports to the United States after failing to reach agreement in London last weekend, Miroru Masuda, Vice Minister of Trade, said here.

title: Legislators Say Abortion Study Invades Privacy
description: ALBANY, May 11The New York State Health Department has been conducting a federally financed study of the effects of abortion involving 48,000 women, without their knowledge, in what two state legislators charged today was a massive invasion of privacy.

title: U.S., Using Sterile Flies, Opens AllOut War on the Screwworm
description: MISSION, Tex., May 6In the busy operations room, Gil Rodriquez made a lastminute check of his flying mutes, the weather and his targets. Seconds later he was out on the flight line, climbing into the cockpit of a converted C15 twinengine transport and starting its engines.

title: Portrait of a Great Patron
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y. LILA BELL ACHESON WALLACE sips her martinis these days from an exquisite Egyptian gold cup. It's 4,000 years old, she said, fingering the lotus leaves etched On the sides of the glittering goblet. Seated there on a settee in her sundappled living rooman airy setting, abundant with flowers and French antiquesshe raised the vessel, a gift from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Egyptian Government, and gazed appreciatively at it.

title: A Preemptive Strike?
description: WASHINGTON, May 11Israel and its supporters have been engaged in curious campaign here. They have been warning that a new arms sales policy now under consideration by President Carter would, as one story put it, limit Israel's ability to receive modern weapons from the United States. Congress, moved by the alarms, seems likely to attach to the foreign aid bill language commending arms supplies to Israel.

title: West Europe's Press Lauds Cartex
description: LONDON, May 11 (AP)Major West European newspapers were high in their editorial praise today for President Carter and his role here in the international meetings of recent days. Two said he evoked the character of John F. Kennedy.

title: Film: House by Lake Sinks in Blood
Yankees Lose in Seattle
description: In their first appearance in Seattle's Kingdome, the Yankees were beaten, 52, by the Mariners, who ended a sevengame losing streak. Details, Page D16.

title: Padres Double Mets' Troubles By 63 and 43
description: Surrounded by untold miseries and only 7,518 cash customers, the fussing and feuding New York Mets got hack to baseball last night at Shea Stadium and promptly took two more lumps by losing a doubleheader to the San Diego Padres.

title: CRUDE STOCKS SET RECORD FOR THE 2D STRAIGHT WEEK
description: Inventories of crude oil for the week ended May 6 reached record highs for the second week in a row, with supplies at 306.7 million barrels, up from the 300.5 million barrels in the previous week, the American Petroleum Institute reported today.

title: Albany Votes a 4Year Extension Of City and Upstate Rent Control
description: ALBANY, May 11The Legislature gave formal approval today to a fouryear extension of rent stabilization in New York City and its suburbs and of rent control in upstate areas where it is in force.

title: A Man Is Fatally Stabbed In Dense Times Sq. Area; Police Seize 2 Suspects
description: A man in his mid20's was stabbed fatally on a street corner off Times Square yesterday afternoon in a confrontation with another man and a woman. Transit policemen seized two suspects after a brief chase.

title: Press institute Director Elected
description: Peter M. Macdonald, the president of Harris Enterprises and the publisher of nine newspapers in Kansas, Iowa and California, has been elected to the board of directors of the American Press Institute. Mr. Macdonald will serve a threeyear term beginning July 1, succeeding John A. Scott, president of the Frank E. Gannett Newspaper Foundation. Selected along with Mr. Macdonald at the group's annual meeting in San Francisco on April 24 were 17 members of the board, all reelected.

title: Home Beat
description: Can you top this? Just when you thought there wasn't another big name left to design sheets, along comes the popularpriced Pacific Home Products, a division of Wamsutta Mills, with a name designer to outdo all name designers.

title: Historic Home Tour
description: To honor National Preservation Week, the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, located at 421 East 61st Street, will join in the closing weekend festivities and open its doors to the public on Saturday, May 14, from noon to 4 P.M. (The museum is normally open weekdays but not Saturdays.)

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary of Joan Crawford in The Times yesterday incorrectly gave the address of her New York apartment. She lived at 150 East 69th Street.

title: PUBLIC IS FOUND OPPOSED TO UNION SHOP, 63 TO 31%
description: There continues to be strong opposition to the union shopa longtime fixture on organized labor's legislative agendait was reported yesterday in the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Sewage Dumping in Ocean Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI)Ignoring a warning that some cities might have to dump their sewage in the streets, the House Merchant Marine Committee voted 22 to 12 today to hart the dumping of sewage into the oceans after Dec. 31, 1981.

title: Record Budget for Arts Gains
description: WASHINGTON, May 11The highest budgets ever for the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities $98 million and $96 million respectively for the regular grants programs of each agencyhave been approved by the House Appropriations Subcommittee for Interior and Related Agencies.

title: 76ers' Box Score
description: HOUSTON (118)

title: Dollar Is Stronger In European Trade; Gold Holds Steady
description: LONDON. May 11 (AP)The dollar closed stronger against most European currencies on foreign exchange markets today. The price of gold held steady.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Personal Beauty
description: ONE CAN IMAGINE, back in the dim day of prehistory, a caveman returning home from a days hunting to find his mate wearing a layer of dried mud on her face.

title: Coal Comeback Looms as U.S. Tells 7 New YorkArea Plants to Convert
description: Coal, abandoned as an energy source in the New York metropolitan area a decade ago as too costly and environmentally unsound, may soon be making a comeback.

title: Notes on People
description: ACROSS THE land yesterday, an estimated 250,000 voices sang out in celebration of the 89th birthday of Irving Berlin, the legendary composer of popular songs. Mr. Berlin was in seclusion at his home in Livingston Manor, N. Y., but a spokesman said he was in pretty good health for a man his age and he's alertsometimes too alert.

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT WIDENS WITH MIDEAST AND AFRICA
description: WASHINGTON, May 11 (Reuters)The United States' trade deficit with the Middle East and North Africa has widened this year, largely because of a turnaround in the balance of trade with oilproducing Iran, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Tax Abatement Approved for Vertical Tennis Club To Be Built in New York, First Such Facility in U.S.
description: New York City, where most people live and work stacked one above another in multistoried buildings, will soon be the first city in the country where people can play tennis the same way.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: HOUSE PANEL CHIDED OVER KOREA INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, May 11A substantial number of representatives, most of them freshmen or secondterm members, demanded today that the House ethics committee step up its investigation into the Korean scandal.

title: Atlantic Alliance Backing Carter On Closer Link in Arms Production
description: LONDON, May 11The North Atlantic Treaty Organization today embraced President Carter's proposals for strengthening the alliance, according to a communiqu ending a twoday conference here.

title: Vance Pledge to Allon on Mideast Said to Restore Israeli Confidence
description: LONDON, May 11Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance renewed America's commitment to a special relationship with Israel today and promised that the Israelis would continue to receive the arms they need, together with advanced technology.

title: Elegance Never Made It Through Our Door
description: THE DAY we put the readymade slipcover on our couch we knew: House Beautiful would never beat a path to our door. House Beautiful is where others hang their hat. If we owned a hat it would never find the right place the peg would fall off, the shelf would smell of yesterday's chicken soup, the rack would be less rack and more ruin.

title: Yeo Concerned on Hidden Curbs
description: Edwin H. Yeo 3d, the chairman of the asset and liability management committee of the First National Bank of Chicago, expressed concern yesterday that we not drift in the direction of a type of hidden price control.

title: Stage: Vieux Carre By Williams Is Haunting
description: MEMORIES of memories. Echoes of echoes. A portrait no, not a portrait, a glimpseof an artist as a young man. The laying of ghosts. The recollection of old rain on older roofs, of different streets and different ways. Tennessee Williams's new play, Vieux Carre, which opened at the St. James Theater last night, is a journey into the past, an excursion into an interior, that perhaps once existed, or perhaps once did not.

title: The Power and the Pity
description: During his visit to London, President Carter took occasion to speak out for a dead poet whose work admires, but made a point of not speaking out for living writers who have been silenced by authoritarian regimes.

title: SALVADORAN OFFICIAL SLAIN BY KIDNAPPERS
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 11 (AP)Foreign Minister Mauricio Borgonovo, kidnapped three weeks ago, was found shot to death last night and a leftist group said today that he had been executed in a revolutionary war to establish socialism.

title: Bergen Asks Rejection of Utility's RateRise Request
description: NEWARK, May 11Residents of affluent north Bergen County communities served by the Rockland Electric Company today urged the Public Utilities Commission to deny a $7.9 million rate increase requested by the utility, or to reduce it to the bare minimum required to provide reliable and lowcost electric service.

title: ARAMCO CHIEF SAYS SAUDIS PLAN TO RAISE CAPABILITIES ON OIL
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, May 11Saudi Arabia plans to increase its ability to produce oil by nearly 50 percent between now and 1982, in part to help keep world oil prices down and in part to meet increasing demand, Frank Jungers. chairman of the Arabian American Oil Company, which produces virtually all Saudi oil said today.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEXT TIME you're asking yourself questions, you will undoubtedly ask yourself what the following objects have in common: bowie knives and buttonhooks, trivets and toy banks, beer cans and butter molds, Playbills and paperweights, watch fobs and war posters. I'm happy to provide the answer so that all of us can get on to more important questions, such as How high the moon? and Why me?

title: PORT AUTHORITY'S BAN ON TESTS OF CONCORDE IS VOIDED BY U.S. JUDGE
description: A Federal judge, citing the primacy of Federal rules, held yesterday the ban on Concorde flights to Kennedy International Airportimposed a year ago pending a study of the effect of the supersonic airliner's operations on other citieswas illegal.

title: Deaths
description: ALFORDDonald C., of Norfolk, Conn., died March 11. Husband of Catherine, father of Donald C., 3d, F. S. Jerome, James L. and Linda Alford Sahl, son of Mrs. Henry S. Redmond. Also survived by three grandchildren. Memorial services Saturday, May 14, 11:30 A.M., Church of the Transfiguration, Norfolk, Conn.

title: A NEW INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORDER1
description: A currently faddish, if acrimonious, acronym is NIEONew International Economic Order. It may seem faintly totalitarian or conspiratorial, but has become the accepted way to describe what is badly needed, and, as of now, unattainable.

title: Black Boycott of Event Discounted by Canada
description: LONDON, May 11 (UPI)Canada is optimistic it can avoid a boycott of next summer's Commonwealth Games at Edmonton by black nations, External Affairs Minister Don Jamieson said today.

title: Professors' Association Criticizes Way City University Cut Its Staffs
description: The American Association of University Professors accused the City University yesterday of disregarding the need for a reasonable period of notice for those faculty members who faced retrenchment last year and deplored the univer sit's overall handling of 1,000 dismissals.

title: American International Net Gains 22.7% to $29 Million in Quarter
description: American International Group Inc., a holding company with a wide variety of insurance operations here, in Canada and internationally, reported yesterday firstquarter net income rose 22.7 percent to a record $29 million, or 92 cents a share, from $23.7 million, or 75 cents a share for the initial three months last year.

title: Disks: Bach to Big Band Jazz
description: Here's a real oddity, one that might appeal to fanciers of Walter Carlos's, Isao Tomita's or Ward Swingle's arrangements of Bach. But this time the arrangements have been done by a composer of stature. Piano versions of orchestral worksin this instance, for piano four handswere common until about 50 years ago, when the evolution of the phonograph record obviated the need for such homemusic substitutes. Reger himself, for all the bombast of some of his music, was in at least part of his heart a classicist, and he responded to the logical purity of this music from deep within.

title: Grow Your Own Tea
description: PROBABLY AT NO TIME since its coining has the slogan Drink tea and see been more popular. And if tea prices are beginning to tag along on coffee's meteoric rise, there is an alternative to the case: Grow your own.

title: 25 Japanese Coal Miners Killed
description: WETSU, Japan, Thursday, May 12 (Reuters)Twentyfive coal miners were killed, and eight injured after a gas explosion yesterday at a colliery in the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido, the police said. The blast ripped through a mine of the Mitsui Mining Company shortly after noon.

title: Nestle Plans to Move Its Offices To Harrison or Out of New York
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 11The Nestle Company, whose national headquarters have been here for 25 years, said today that it would seek authority to build a $25 million headquarters in the adjoining Westchester Count Community of Harrison, and that if it failed to ge the needed zoning amendment it would leave New York State altogether.

title: J. EDGAR MURDOCK, JUDGE, SERVED ON U.S. TAX COURT
description: J. Edgar Murdock, a retired Chief Judge of the United States Tax Court, died May 2 in Denver, while visiting one of his daughters. He was 82 years old and a resident of Washington, D.C.

title: No Major Movement, Vance Reports
description: MADRID, May 11 Secretary of State Vance said during his flight here from London today that he had brought Foreign Minister Allon up to date with what I thought were some signs of movement in some of the core areas.

title: A Jazz Bassist Goes Up Front
description: When a bass player forms a jazz quartet, you would scarcely expect him to hire another bassist for his group. But that is what Ron Carter did when, a year ago, he organized his own quartet, which will be heard tonight at Avery Fisher Hall along with Marlena Shaw, the singer, and Bob James's orchestra.

title: Egypt Receives Pledge of Only Slight Increase in Aid
description: PARIS, May 12Egypt, a country hardpressed economically, received a pledge of continued but only slightly increased aid today at a meeting of its Western and Arab supporters.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Management
description: Advice for executives seeking to improve their companies Images in the investment community is discussed by a rating agency officer. Page D3.

title: About Real Estate
description: Our commitment to home ownership is unswerving, the Urban Home Ownership Corporation proclaimed in a report it issued recently on what it called the lessons to be learned in eight years of experience in the urban housing field.

title: Cardinal Cooke Is 1977 Winner Of Award for Interracial Justice
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke has been selected by the Catholic Interracial Council of New York as the 1977 recipient of the John LaFarge Memorial Award for Interracial Justice.

title: Callaghan Defends Choice of Jay
description: LONDON, May 12Prime Minister James Callaghan confidently parried a volley of questions in the House of Commons this afternoon about the appointment of his soninlaw, Peter Jay, as Britain's Ambassador to Washington.

title: Restaurants
description: AS DIFFICULT AS IT IS to find good food at moderate prices in restaurants, it is even more of a problem to find it in pleasant and attractive surroundings. All too often, budget restaurants are so seedy and dismal that eating there takes on the aspect of a punishment, as though one is expected to suffer simply because he or she is not spending $25 a person for a meal. The two restaurants described here are bright and cheerful exceptions to that rule, each offering decent to very good threecourse meals for under $10. And because both dish up generous portions, that may be one course more than most people will want.

title: Accord Set in ArmoredCar Strike
description: A tentative agreement in a nineweekold strike of armoredcarservice drivers against three major concerns was announced late last night by Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board.

title: Screen: Spain Is the Star
description: LUIS (Jos Luis Lopez Vazquez) is an unmarried, middle-aged, Barcelona businessman. He's soft-spoken and has the manner of someone who keeps to the background. Perhaps he's self-conscious about his lack of hair and about the oval face that recalls the faces of clowns who are meant to seem most comic when they are most sad, though Luis is not a comic character. He's self-contained and intelligent, the sort of man, you feel, who has made a satisfactory adjustment to life by scaling down his dreams to fit an overnight bag.At the beginning of Carlos Saura's fine, sorrowful and poignant Spanish film, "Cousin Anglica," Luis is taking the bones of his long-dead mother from Barcelona to her family's crypt in southern Spain, where Luis grew up with his Falangist relatives while his father was fighting for the Republican cause."Cousin Anglica," which opened yesterday at the D.W. Griffith Theater, is a voyage into the past quite unlike any other I've ever seen in a movie, both because Spain's recent history is so particular and because of Mr. Saura's way of always dealing with memory so that it becomes an extension of the immediate present."Cousin Anglica" is not simply about Luis's childhood before and during the civil war. It's about Luis's recollections of his childhood as he renews contacts with his family, especially with his cousin Anglica, the sweet, pigtailed little girl he once loved and who has grown into a handsome, rather ordinary woman whose disappointments frighten him.Mr. Saura doesn't use conventional flashbacks, which are as isolated from time and feeling as postcard pictures are removed from a tourist's actual experiences. When Luis recalls scenes from his childhood, he walks into them as the middle-aged man he is, a theatrical device that works in films much more effectively than I might have imagined.En route once again to his relatives, the tearful Luis is comforted by his mother and father. There is nothing exceptional about this scene except that when we see the middle-age, cardigan-wearing Luis being soothed by parents younger than he is we are suddenly presented not only with a memory of the past but with everything that's accrued in the intervening yearswith fear, anger and humiliation, but, also with the sense of loss that has haunted his maturity.The older Luis sits in his schoolroom listening to a priest tell a horror story about a little classmate, killed in an air raid, who may or may not be eternally damned depending on whether or not the boy had "given in to temptation" the morning he was killed. No wonder Luis never married.The recollected scenes of tentative courtship between Luis and the young Anglica, played by a beautiful, dark-haired actress named Mara Clara Fernandez are both intensely moving and slightly perverse, being simultaneously a remembrance of not-quite-forgotten intimacies and a description of where Luis is now, a contemporary Spaniard whose scars remain raw, if unseen. He's a Humbert Humbert with no will to act, without even a fantasy life.Jos Luis Lopez Vazquez is super as Luis, apparently cheerful, self-contained and settled, though forever disconnected from the kind of family life he remembers with such mixed feelings.Spain, though, is the real subject of the film, and at the time it was released there  1974  "Cousin Anglica" caused quite a stir with its references to the war, Spanish Catholicism and the possible nobility of at least some members of the Republican cause. Even if it's difficult for someone not familiar with the subtleties of Spanish life to get all of these references, the movie is extraordinarily compelling, an invitation into a world until recently closed, but whose vitality has remained undiminished.

title: Tips on Tickets
description: Tickets for the concert with Ron Carter's Quartet, Marlena Shaw and Bob James's Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall, tonight at 8 P.M. are $7.50, $8 and $8.50. They may be obtained at the Avery Fisher Hall box office (TR 42424) or by calling Ticketron (9779020) or on credit card charge by calling Centercharge (8746770).

title: Rail TonMileage Gains 4.5%
description: WASHINGTON, May 12The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.4 billion tonmiles, 4.5 percent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 474,933 cars, 0.4 percent above last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. Reported intercity truck tonnage was 5.6 percent above last year.

title: Consolidated Rail
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP)The Consolidated Rail Corporation today reported a net loss of $207.6 million for the first quarter of this year. Revenues were $770.4 million for the period.

title: Leaps and Boundaries For Israel's Georgians
description: It was my dream to have a dance company in Israel, Ilya Namtalashvili said. But since I lived all my life in Soviet Georgia, I also wanted to show who we are as Georgian Jews. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., the Georgian Dancers of Israel, formed in 1972 by Mr. Namtalashvili in Tel Aviv, makes its New York debut at the Felt Forum. The 40member ensemble will also perform Sunday at 1 P.M. and 5 P.M.

title: BOND PRICES STEADY IN A QUIET SESSION
description: Prices in the Government, taxexempt and corporate credit markets moved slightly higher yesterday in a trading session that took the latest money supply figures in stride. It was, one municipal underwriter said, sort of a hohum Thursday. Most everyone had been expecting a decline in the money supply and this contrbiuted to a generally firm tone in the market. After 4 P.M. the Federal Reserve reported that the nation's basic money supply in the week ended May 4 declined $1.6 billion. This matched approximately some of the forecasts.

title: CARTER BRUSHES OFF LIBERALS CRITICISM; DEFENDS HIS POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 President Carter brushed aside today recent criticism of his domestic policies by liberal Democrats, describing them as people who are always hard to please and defending his programs and his goal of a balanced budget as consistent with the Democratic Party's traditions.

title: Canada and China in Pas de Deux
description: OTTAWA. May 12If the Shanghai Ballet company now performing in Canada is a frankly political expression by China through a cultural medium, the Canadian Government's sponsorship of the monthlong tour is no less politically motivated.

title: P.S.A.L.'s Shoestring Is Wearing Thin
description: Two years ago the Public Schools Athletic Leage had a 50 percent budget cut. Now th program is beginning to bleed. The city's youngsters are losing the coaching, the opportunity and the equipment needed to develop their athletic skills.

title: PEAKHOUR CHARGES ON BRIDGES WEIGHED
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that, following the recommendations of a Federal administrative judge, it was studying the feasability of charging higher bridge tolls during peak commuter hours.

title: Jamaica Partly Devalues Its Dollar To Help Sagging Tourist Industry
description: Jamaica has partly devalued its dollar by 37 percent in an effort to help its ailing tourist business and obtain hard currency.

title: FRED MULLER JR., 61, A CONTAINER EXPERT
description: Fred Muller Jr., one of the leaders in the development of international standards for the construction and handling of shipping containers, died Tuesday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 61 years old and a resident of Florham Park, N.J.

title: QuarterHorse Opening Snarled by Computers
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., May 12 (UPI)What Pompano Park billed as new era of spaceage betting to open its quarterhorse season last night turned into computerdriven confusion that cost the track an estimated $70,000 in bets.

title: MONEY GROWTH EBBS IN 1ST WEEK OF MAY
description: The torrid pace of monetary expansion cooled a bit during the first week of May, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday. Following the very rapid expansion in the month of April, the, money supply, on both principle definitions, declined in the week ended May 4.

description: Mayor Beame yesterday announced the approval of an agreement between the New York State Urban Development Corporation and a private developer for the construction of a 200,000squarefoot shopping mall in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Carter Defends Continuing Investigation and Possible Prosecution of F.B.I. Agents
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 President Carter said today that while he wished to avoid prejudging any Federal Bureau of Investigation agents who participated in allegedly illegal breakins in New York, he believed that if a crime is committed [and they're determined to be guilty, they should be punished.

title: Shapp Told to Return Vote Funds
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania was ordered by the Federal Election Commission today to return nearly $300,000 in public subsidies given to his brief 1976 Presidential campaign on the ground that his claim of eligibility for the money was party false.

title: James C. Windham, 63, Chairman And Top Executive Officer of Pabst
description: James C. Windham, chairman and chief executive officer of the Pabst Brewing Company of Milwaukee and a civic leader, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at the Noxubee General Hospital. Macon. Miss. He was 63 years old and lived in Macon.

title: Food Outlook Bolsters Fight Against Inflation
description: WASHINGTON  One of the chief sources of the inflationary push in recent months has been the sharp rise in food costs. Fortunately, however, this key area now seems likely to provide early relief. This would mean good news

title: Surplus Is Expected At Meadows Track
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 12Exuberant officials of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority said today that income from the Meadowlands Race Track was exceeding projections, and that they expected $5.2 million in surplus earnings would be given to the state at the end of the year.

title: Manikin Helping Students In Heart Disease Diagnosis
description: WASHINTON, May 12The patient was normal at the outset but within 20 minutes had developed clear signs of five serious types of heart disease.

title: Gil Evans, Still Setting Trends, Is Having a Jazzy 65th Birthday
description: Gil Evans, the arranger and band leader who has been in the forefront of jazz for some 30 years, is celebrating his 65th birthday tonight at 8 P.M. by giving a concert at St. George's Church, 209 East 16th Street (Stuyveant Square).

title: Opposition Grows As SST Operators Plan Jet Test Runs
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., May 12 (UPI)A threemilelong oil slick was spotted over the living coral reefs making up the John Pennekamp Underwater State Park today, but it dissipated quickly and officials said it caused no damage. A Coast Guard spokesman said that the origin of the spill was not known.

title: Enterprise Heading East For Yachting Cup Trials
description: SAN DIEGO, May 12 (UPI)Enterprise, the 12Meter racing yacht, is being transported to New York by truck to begin June trials for the America's Cup challenge off Newport, R. I., in September.

title: Art: Two Who Paint By Their Own Lights
description: FORTY YEARS AGO, when it was still very much a minority position for a serious American painter to take up abstraction, Giorgio Cavallon and Balcomb Greene were founding members of the American Abstract Artists group.Mr. Greene was, indeed, the group's first chairman. Since that time, these painters have pursued very different courses. Mr. Cavallon, though his work has come a long way since the 1930's, has remained dedicated to the abstract mode, and is now indeed one of our best abstract painters. Mr. Greene, on the other hand, is known today primarily as a painter of romantic, almost dreamlike, seascapes and cityscapes in which certain elements of fantasy, memory and symbolism are combined with the specifications of direct observation.

title: ANNE BLAINE HARRISON
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Anne Blaine Harrison, a public education advocate and philanthropist, died today of cancer at the Washington Hospital Center. She was 58 years old.

title: The Truth in Hopper's Art
description: ONE of the great repositories of American life in its most distinctive and least contaminated form is the art of Edward Hopper. Not merely is he fundamental to the history of American painting, but he is also fundamental to the history of American it lived his

title: BARRY ASHBEE DIES; PLAYED FOR FLYERS
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12Barry Ashbee, a former allstar defenseman whose playing career with the Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League was ended by an eye injury in 1974, died today of leukemia. He was 37 years old.

title: Nixon Talk Reflects Fascination With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, May 12Richard M. Nixon's interview tonight was useful, not only for its insights into his personal relationships with Henry A. Kissinger, Mao Tsetung and Leonid I. Brezhnev, among others, but also for the candid and constant reminder of how heavily he relied upon the Soviet connection in formulating foreign policy. This second broadcast conversation with David Frost produced no major historical revelations and surprisingly few disclosures. What Mr. Nixon said seemed consistent with the known record, though ardent supporters of Mr. Kissinger might argue with the former President's portrait of his adviser.

title: PARENTS/CHILDREN
description: A 15yearold who recently had her braces removed, after two years during Which her teeth were bound in metal and forced into rectitude, flashed what he described as her Farah Fawcett smile and said she had never minded wearing the braces.

title: Mary Farren Jones, 69, Retired After Long Career as an Actress
description: Mary Farren Jones, who retired in 1966 after a long career as an actress, died Monday in Norwalk, k Conn.) hospital after a lengthy illness. She was 69 years old and died at 47 Chestnut Hill Road, Norwalk.

title: Philadelphia Transit Fares to Rise
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP)Starting Sunday it will cost 45 cents, instead of 35, to ride a bus, trolley or subway in Philadelphia. Officials of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority said that the new rates would raise an estimated $11 million a year, enough to pay for a new contract covering 5,000 drivers, maintenance workers and cashiers.

title: A Food Critic's Favorites on the Street
description: Behind the temporary dazzlement of food stalls and displays set up for the weekend food fiesta that is the Ninth Avenue Festival dwell numerous permanent installations devoted to selling products that lure and satisfy gastronomes the year round. Personal favorites follow below.

title: Investigation of the Sex Industry Begun by New York State and City
description: New York State and City officials disclosed yesterday that they had begun a joint investigation of organizedcrime involvement in the Manhattan sex industry, including the alleged takeover of bars and the recruitment of teenaged boys and girls for prostitution.

title: Barnes & Noble to Open New Store
description: Barnes & Noble announced yesterday that it would open a major new bookstore at 600 Fifth Avenue, between 48th and 49th Streets, in Rockefeller Center in July.

description: A BOULEZ FINALE

title: Ford Raises His 1977 Sales Forecast     On U.S.Made Vehicles to 15 Million
description: DETROIT, May 12 Henry Ford 2d predicted today that 15 million cars and truckseasily the highest number everwould he sold in the United States this year.

title: Federal Suit Filed by 52 Persons Charging New Haven Wiretapping
description: NEW HAVEN, May 12A group of 52 lawyers, doctors, students, journalists, antiwar activists and former Black Panthers filed suit in United States District Court here today, charging that they had been the victims of a campaign of wiretapping, breakins and dirty tricks by members of the New Haven Police Department, the state police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Nixon Says Russians Seek World Control
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)Richard M. Nixon says the Communists still seek worldwide domination, not just a Communist Russia.

title: FirstQuarter Profits Up 9%, Survey Shows
description: Net profits in the first quarter for over 1,700 companies totaled $17 billion, up an average of 9 percent over the yearearlier period, but down 3 percent from the 1976 fourthquarter total of $17,5 billion, according a survey released today by Citibank.

title: Dual Listing for Southwest Airlines
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that Southwest Airlines would become its eighth dually listed stockone listed on both the Amex and the New York Stock Exchange. It said the company would shortly list its stock on the Big Board, but would also continue to be listed on the Amex. Other dually listed Issue are Varo, Dutch Boy, Frigitronics, GearheartOwens, Sambo's Restaurants, the AMC Corporation and Grow Chemicals.

title: A Lottery Is Planned to Fill 1,100 Summer Park Jobs
description: A lottery will be held this month to fill in a fair and equitable manner 1,100 Parks Department summer jobs, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

title: Schmidt's Allies and Foes in Bonn Concur on His Success in London
description: BONN, May 12Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has come back from his London meetings with President Carter with a widely acknowledged personal and diplomatic triumph, something he needed badly on his domestic political front. Even his political opposition concedes that on the really important matters, Mr. Schmidt scored.

title: Rutherford Snaps Mark On Indy Lap of 200.624
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (AP)Johnny Rutherford turned in a lateafternoon run of 200.624 miles an hour today. the fastest lap in the history of the 68yearold Indianapolis Motor Speedway.

title: DOLLAR WEAKENS IN EUROPEAN TRADE
description: LONDON, May 12 (AP)The dollar fell against the strongest European currencies on foreign exchange markets today. The price of gold also dropped.

title: Canadiens Win, Need 1 Victory
description: BOSTON, May 12The storm of vio lence forecast for tonight's third game of the National Hockey League's championship series blew over quickly, letting the Boston Bruins and the Montreal Canadiens go ahead and play 60 minutes of pure if unexciting hockey.

title: Art: Beckmann In Bold Relief
description: THERE WILL ALWAYS, I suppose, be people who dislike Max Beckmann's paintings, though they are probably less numerous today than they once were. Beckmann, whose dates are 18841950. was a strong and imperious talent, and he took a big view of his calling as an artist. He populated his paintings with sharply defined personalities and eloquent symbols. He was an acute social observer and gifted in the creation of pictorial allegory. He had a large experience of the worldnot only of his native Germany, but all of Europe (which he knew as a free artist and as a political refugee) and even America, where lie lived out his last years after World War IIand he wanted his art to reflect that experience.

title: Bethlehem and 2 Others Join Rise In Steel Prices by 6% for June 19
description: The nation's No. 2 steel producer, the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, along with the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation and the Kaiser Steel Corporation got on the bandwagon yesterday by announcing 6 percent price increases, effective June 19, for the steel that goes into automobiles, appliances, machinery and tools.

title: Cheap Mexican Labor Attracts U.S. Companies to the Border
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., May 9The 35 women who sort and box shrimp at TexMex Cold Storage Inc. are quick with their hands. With the help of machines, they can grade and package for freezing about 6,000 pounds of shrimp an hour. Their base pay is $2.30 an hour; their takehome pay: $2.12 an hour.

title: S.E.C. Sues, Charging Debt Fraud in Louisiana
description: WASHINGTON,May 12 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit today charging that an insurance holding company, three members of a prominent Louisiana family and seven other defendants violated antifraud laws.

title: FORD CUTTING PRODUCTION AT 2 SMALLCAR PLANTS
description: DETROIT, May 12  While overall American auto production is reaching a fouryear high, the Ford Motor Company said today that it was cutting production at two smallcar plants this month.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 12The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners ordered today that gas and electric companies in the state put into effect an optional financing plan for home insulation, which includes loans of up to $500.

title: The Bronx as a Character In 'The Ginger Man
description: In many Englishspeaking realms. J. P. Donleavy is known as the author of the muchpraised The Ginger Man and other novels, and as an elegant American expatriate who is lord of a manor in central Ireland.

title: Sale of $2 Million in Stolen Bonds And Art Is Laid to Two L.I. Men
description: A sixmonth investigation in which police sergeant posing as a gobetween, said he had bought stolen works of art and securities worth more than $2 million ended yesterday with the arrest of two Lone Island men.

title: Turner Barred as Manager But Sees Team Triumph, 61
description: PITTSBURGH,May 12Ted Turner had to relinquish, at least temporarily, his position of acting manager of the Atlanta Braves yesterday when the National League president, Charles (Chub) Feeney, ordered him back into the stands.

title: People and Business
description: Harry J. Gray, chairmanpresident of the United Technologies Corporation, was America's highest paid executive in 1976, earning $1.66 million in salary and benefits.

title: Jury Bids C.I.A. Pay 3 in Mail Case
description: The first trial of charges that the Central Intelligence Agency had invaded the privacy of citizens by secretly opening their mail ended yesterday with an advisory jury recommending cash reimbursement ranging from $2,500 to $10,000.

title: Notes on People
description: Rachele Mussolini, the Italian dictator's widow, has lost a 30year struggle for the return of property confiscated after World War II. Mrs. Mussolini, now 86 years old, maintained that farms and other real estate she owned independently of her husband were unjustly sequestered along with Mussolini's possessions in 1946. Through the years a succession of courts rejected the widow's claims, and finally the case landed in the Italian Supreme Court in 1968. It took that court nine years to conclude that the confiscation decree applied equally to the slain dictator and his wife.

title: First Woman Rector Is Appointed To Serve in an Episcopal Church
description: An upstate woman who was baptized a Roman Catholic is scheduled to become the first member of her sex to be placed in charge of an Episcopal parish.

title: A Punch You Felt in the Toenails
description: After Pete Rademacher dismantled the Soviet heavyweight, Lev Moukhina, to win the 1956 Olympic championship, he was asked whether his opponent had landed even one punch. Pete gave that a long moment's thought. I think I may have brushed off a jab, he said. That's how it was with Ken Norton Wednesday. He brushed off the tentative jabs Duane Bobick aimed at his mustache when they met in midring. Then he brushed off Duane Bobick as a contender for the heavyweight championship of the world.

title: Elsa Redmond Wed To Charles Spencer
description: Elsa Marion Redmond and Charles Sidney Spencer, graduate students in anthropology, were married yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Dr. John Baiz of Pittsburgh, a cousin of the bride, and the Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay, rector of St. Bartholomew's, performed the ceremony.

title: Goodman Opens Race; Expects 4 In Fall Election
description: Insisting that he could unequivocally, positively and absolutely be elected Mayor of New York without the Liberal Party's support that he once called crucial, State Senator Roy M. Goodman announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination yesterday.

title: Look Who's Dancing With Twyla
description: For one brief moment of glory, 147 novice performerssome celebrated, some just folkswill dance with Twyla Tharp at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this weekend, when the iconoclastic young choreographer offers her ballet Half the One Hundreds.

title: Jazz: Polish and Polished
description: Adam Makowicz, a Polish jazz pianist known well enough in Europe to have been voted top European jazz pianist of 1977 in a poll conducted by the International Jazz Federation, is making his American debut at the Cookery, University Place at eighth Street, where he will be playing for the next three months.

title: Dance: Ailey's Cuban Encore
description: ONE OF THE MORE interesting aspects of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater's gala at the City Center on May 4 was the appearance of two dancers of the National Ballet of Cuba, Maria Elena Llorente and Lazao Carreno. They were so wellreceived that they extended their stay and have given additional performances with the company.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Net Up 54.6% In 1st Quarter to $716 Million
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of companies reported yesterday a 54.6 percent rise in firstquarter net income to $716 million from $463 million in the initial three months last year. This reflected the improvement in several sectors of business, a $53 million lower currency translation loss ($93 million against $146 million) and earnings inflation resulting from the decline in the value of the pound, the company said.

title: World News Briefs

title: House, Approving Aid Bill, Reaffirms Ban on Trade With Cuba and Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, May 12 (UPI)The House of Representatives today reaffirmed its opposition to United States trade with Cuba and Vietnam while approving a $1.7 billion foreign aid bill that ends outdated restrictions against food aid to other nations trading with them.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Most New Jersey residents say there is no need for a state income tax, according to the most recent poll by the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers University. description: The State Comptroller's office yesterday criticized central administrators for the Board of Education for permitting conditions that may have jeopardized the safety of children in some of New York City's public schools.

description: ALBANY, May 12Governor Carey today proposed a statewide energy conservation program designed to reduce energy consumption by 7.3 percent in the next three years.

title: COURT FREES HUNTS TO ACT ON MAY SOYBEAN DELIVERY
description: CHICAGO, May 12 (Reuters)The Hunt family of Texas oil millionaires today won another round in its battle with the Federal Government over alleged attempts to corner the soybean market.
