description: British Football

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: NAVY MEN ARE TRIED FOR LAND SALE FRAUD
description: SAN DIEGO, May 13A Federal court jury has begun hearing evidence of fraudulent sales of desert wasteland allegedly promoted by a group of Annapolis graduates who employed young Navy officers to solicit buyers aboard ships and at shore bases.

title: Trudeau Cautions France
description: PARIS. May 13 (Reuters)  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that France should have nothing to do with the Quebec issue and added that he was convinced the French Government would do nothing that would interfere in Canadian internal affairs.

title: Commuter Flights Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)An application to run commuter flights to Boston and Washington from Morristown Airport in Hanover, N.J., has been denied by the Civil Aeronautics Board. In a decision released yesterday, the C.A.B. noted that the flights, proposed by Colonial Airlines, would duplicate the service provided at Newark International Airport by Eastern Airlines, which objected to the application.

title: Ballet: Aurora
description: The dead audience is a severe trial to a performing artist. Comedians have the option of approaching the footlights and asking rhetorically, Are. you out there? but such simple directness is denied a ballerina who has to press ahead with what is essentially a oneway conversation. Yoko Morishita, who danced Aurora Thursday evening, did well despite the handicap in American Ballet Theater's production of The Sleeping Beauty, and was graciously partnered by Fernando Bujones.

title: BHUTTO ANNOUNCES A VOTE ON HIS RULE
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 13Prime Minister Zulkifar Ali Bhutto announced today a referendum to decide whether he should retain power in the aftermath of two months of rioting against his rule in which some 260 persons have been killed.

title: Connors Gains W.C.T. Final
description: DALLAS, May 13 (UPI)Jimmy Connors shook off a lethargic start at Moody Coliseum tonight and won all the key points to sweep aside Eddie Dibhs, 64, 75, 61, and advance to the final of the World Championship of Tennis.

title: Money
description: Friday, May 13, 1977

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Osborn Elliott. the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, charged that the State Environmental Quality Review Act, which is to take effect June could delay and seriously hurt the city's economicdevelopment program.

title: World Health Unit Uncovers No Proof Of Saccharin Peril
description: GENEVA, May 13 (UPI)The World Health Organization, in a carefully worded and inconclusive report, said today that studies made so far had failed to provide any proof that saccharin increased the risk of cancer of the bladder.

title: Carter Signs Bills for Public Works And the Creation of a Million Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, May 13  President Carter signed today a pair of bills that Administration officials said would create more than a million jobs, primarily for construction workers and young people.

title: Upstate Scientist Is Trying to Breed a Tomato That Can Stand the Cold
description: GENEVA, N.Y.Snow had fallen and the temperature had dropped to 27 degrees that October night in 1972. So when Dick Robinson went out to the field the next morning, he was more than a little surprised to see a few live tomato plants among the hundreds that had been killed by the frost.

title: Sadat Hints a New Development In Relations With Soviet Union
description: CAIRO, May 13President Anwar elSadat toned down today his longstanding controversy with the Soviet Union and hinted that a positive event in the relations between the two countries is imminent.

title: O. R. M'NEEL
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.,May 13(AP)O. R. McNeel, one of a dozen surviving builders of Charle' Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis, died at Desert Hospital yesterday of lung cancer. He was 79 years old.

title: La Pasionaria Returns Home to Spain After 38 Years
description: MADRID, May 13Dolores Ibarruri, a living Communist legend from the Spanish Civil War, today slipped back into her homeland after 38 years in exile.

title: New York Muting Image of Its Mt. Everest
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.This region's renowned Mount Marcy, long used by state officials as an advertising symbol to lure more tourists to remote hiking trails, is losing its cachet as the premier attraction of the Adirondack wilderness.

title: Mexico Reinstating Editor Ousted by Former Regime
description: MEXICO CITY. May 13Mexico's new Government has decided to return control of the newspaper Excelsior to the liberal editor and journalists who were ousted from their posts last July through the intervention of former President Luis Echeverria Alvarez.

title: Tackling the Immigration Mess
description: HOUSTON, May 13  Ninetyseven years ago a peasant man from Linares, Mexico, left his home one day and walked into the United States. At the border, he paid a guard either a nickel or a halfdollar, his family is not sure which, to cross. In those days. it was that simple to enter the United States from Linares, and begin a new life. Today that man's grandson, Leonel Castillo, was sworn in by Attorney General Griffin B. Bell as the new Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization. His friends say that taking the job amounts to committing political suicide; one of Mr. Castillo's most pressin gtasks will be to try to curtail the floodtide of people, mostly Mexicans like his grandfather, who are entering the United States illegally.

title: In Knee Socks and Thrift Clothes, Design Students Claim Their Prizes
description: The only woman in the room wearing Kevin Emard's design was his mother, who has been following the fashion advice of her 20yearold son for several years.

title: Mattern Wins Golf Title; Manhattan Team First
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.,May 13Kerry Mattern, a 21yearold senior at Glassboro State College in New Jersey, won the individual title in the 28th annual Metropolitan Golf Association intercollegiate championships today with a fouroverpar 38, 3775 on the windy Rutgers Golf Course. He beat Dave Stevenson of Montclair State by one shot when Stevenson took a bogey 6 on the 18th hole.

title: Carter Denies He Believes Jews Are Guilty of the Death of Jesus
description: WASHINGTON, May 13In response to a letter from a Lutheran pastor, President Carter has declared that he regards antiSemitism as unChristian and does not believe that the Jewish people are guilty of the death of Jesus.

title: TEST GRADES ARE LOW IN SIX LARGEST CITIES
description: TRENTON, May 13 (UPI)The State Education Department released statistics today that showed that more than half of the 10thgrade public school students in the state's six largest cities failed reading and mathematics tests.

description: An official of the American Jewish Committee yesterday attributed the apparent growth and success of Jews for Jesus groups to the inability of many rabbis to talk to young people about spiritual values of Judaism.

title: U.S. Is Pursuing New Ways to Produce Nuclear Energy
description: SALZBURG, Austria, May 13In a comprehensive reassessment of ways to harness the atom, a wide range of untried methods are to be explored in a United States program as a consequence of President Carter's new energy policy.

description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 13The Carter Administration may be reconciled to putting aside for the time being a socalled comprehensive proposal for limiting strategic arms and to accepting a more modest plan similar to one proposed by the Soviet Union, according to indications given today to reporters traveling with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance.

title: Whose Fault Is No New NoFault?
description: Experience under New York's nofault auto insurance law, enacted in 1973, shows the need for modifications. In the light of rising premiums, such modifications should be politically popular. There are bills now before the Legisature to make necessary reforms but none of them seem to be moving, and there is now fear that nothing will happen before the Legislature adjourns next month. Why?

description: CHICAGOCharles Lang, the fictional hero of David Mamet's new play, The Water Engine, is a lowly punchpress operator and amateur tinkerer. In his home workshop he manages to remove the H from H.O andeureka!he invents an engine that uses plain distilled water as fuel. The effects could have been revolutionary were it not for a small matter of Big Business.

title: A Confession's Trustworthiness, It Is Argued, Isn't Enough
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.A shocking crime, Justice Felix Frankfurter once observed, puts law to its severest test. As good an illustration as any is the recent case of Brewer v. Williams.

title: AGENCY BLOCKS INCREASE IN DOMESTIC AIR FARES
description: WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) The civil Aeronautics Board today suspended a 2 percent increase in domestic passenger fares that would have become effective Sunday on some airlines.

title: U.S. Is Reassessing Its Strategy For Meeting Soviet Nuclear Strike

description: Sandra Jean Dugan and Robert Norman Redella, both of Atlanta, were married yesterday in Westfield, N. J. Canon Richard Hardman, assisted by the Rev. Michael Desmond, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Striped Bass Appearing
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.Having returned home to Martha's Vineyard a short time ago from a Virginia encounter with my first bluefish of the season, I learned that the spring run of striped bass had appeared off the Vineyard's South Shore.

title: Mini Roses Deserve A Place In the Sun
description: Miniature roses have everything going for them. They are dainty, the flowers are the same colors, textures and shapes as the large hybrid teas and they are rugged. Yet the little roses grow under two feet tall.

title: Library Aide Assails Beame Plan For Workers on Federal Payroll
description: A senior official of the New York Public Library said last week that Mayor Beame's plan to give the libraries 200 workers paid with Federal funds rather than 80 professional librarians would result in further cuts in library services next year.

title: Vice Adm. Charles Rosendahl Dies; Airship Pioneer
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14Vice Adm. Charles E. Rosendahl, a pioneer in the development of lighterthanair craft, died at the Philadelphia Naval Hospital today after a brief illness. He lived in Toms River, N.J., and would have been 85 years old tomorrow.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: This classified ad is presently running in a numismatic periodical: METCA (Merchant Token Collectors Association) is back! Membership will be $7.50 a year. Mail check or money order to METCA, 1416 Third Avenue, Seattle, Wash.98101.

title: Lawyer Suggested as Judge
description: WASHINGTON, May 13Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, recommended today the appointment of Joseph Adinolfi Jr., a lawyer in Hartford, to he a judge in the Federal District Court in Connecticut. He submitted the recommendation to Attorney General Griffin Bell for consideration by President Carter. Mr. Adinolfi, 52 years old, is a former Corporation Counsel for the city of Hartford and was Democratic candidate for Mayor of Hartford in 1969.

title: Zaire Asserts War Is Virtually Over; Tells of Push West
description: KASAJI, Zaire, May 14 (Reuters)The Zaire Army asserted today that its nineweek war with rebels in the southern copperproducing province of Shaba was virtually over. A military spokesman said that Government troops were practically unopposed as they pushed west towards the Angolan border after capturing this strategic town from the insurgents.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BRONXVILLEThe Tempest. Today and Thursday through Sunday. The Loft Film and Theater Center, 84 Kraft Ave. $3. Students and the elderly, $1.50. 7932610.

title: Jazz: A Master
description: Lightnin Hopkins, the blues singer and guitarist from Texas, made one of his infrequent New York appearances Friday evening at the Palladium. Although he was not on stage for very longa little over 30 minutesMr. Hopkins turned in a superb performance.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Last night Pierre Boufez conducted the last of the 197677 subscription concerts of the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. When he put down his baton, he not only concluded the season. He ended his sixyear tenure as music director of the orchestra. Off he goes to Paris, where he will start work as director of the Institut de Recherche et de Coordination Acoustique/Musique. He leaves New York quietly, and has said that he will give no interviews. He has made but one comment: I go because something else is there to be done and for no other reason. Translation: I am leaving on my own volition, not because I have been fired.

title: Spaniard Opposing Ali Is Hardly a Fearsome Name
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 14Alfredo Evangelista, whoever he is, does not train by pounding left hooks into veal cutlets and he does not have a pet turtle. The challenger for Muhammad Ali's world heavyweight boxing title Monday night is not Rocky Balboa, the Italian Stallion of movie fame.

title: DINING OUT
description: ANICE little restaurant where the food generally wellprepared and a threecourse meal runs about $15 is good to have in any area. L'Aventura, in Plainview, under the present management since the beginning of the year, is just such a place.

title: Building, Construction and Leasing Rules Compel Energy Waste in New York
description: A complex web of buildingcode rules, construction standards, leasing practices and regulatory requirements have combined to compel energy waste in the operation of large buildings in the New York metropolitan area.

title: Orantes Gains Final
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, May 14 (UPI)Paolo Bertolucci of Italy defeated Buster Mottram of Britain, 63, 62, in the semifinals of the West German tennis championships today. Mottram had upset Guillermo Vilas of Argentina in the precedinp round.

title: Recording Rock Live
description: just a few years ago, live recordings of pop performers were mostly a matter of innocent exploitation. If 10 trillion kids wanted to see the Rolling Stones, then a commercially satisfying number of them would buy a live LP. It didn't much matter that what you actually heard on disk was a ragged performance overlayed with steadystate screaming. It was a way to keep the teenage cash flowing in between studio albums.

title: White Sox 182 Victors As Spencer Bats In 8
description: The Federal Government's space program may be in limbo, but the earthlings who play major league baseball seem to have inaugurated their own moon shots.

title: Martha GrahamStill Charting the Graph of the Heart
description: She is not the mother of us all, but she is certainly a titanic figure to anyone who cares about dance and theater in America. She is, of course, Martha Graham. Hers is a name usually followed by the words, legendary moderndance pioneer and genius. President Ford, Japanesestyle, called her a national treasure when she became the first dancer to receive the Medal of Freedom.

title: Victoriana
description: Like so many other things Victorian, the shawl is being revived. But today's shawl isn't draped on the grand piano  it is worn over everything from a sundress to an evening gown. A shawl does provide some protection from the air conditioner's blast, but its real function today is more decorative than practical It adds a bit of glamour and romance when flung casually over a shoulder. This summer's shawls are really oversize squares of cotton, crepe de chine, or then wool They're meant to be folded into triangles and worn as shown here on actresssinger Andrea Macovicci... with a sense of drama and a touch of fun.

title: The Counter Market Is Alive and Well
description: Picking winners in the stock market has been extremely difficult for most individual investors for nearly a decade, and many have decided that the market has little appeal nowadays as a place to put their savings.

title: Cynthia M. Knapik Is Bride
description: Cynthia M. Knapik, daughter of Mr. And Mrs. Edward A. Knapik of Uxbridge, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Frank R. Curtis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Curtis Jr. of Valley Stream, L.I. Uxbridge Town Clerk Ruth Davis performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents. The bride is an account executive with Emett & Chandler New York Inc., insurance brokers. Her husband is a member of Rembar, Wolf & Curtis, a law firm in New York.

title: EXGOVERNOR OF SAMOA TO SERVE UNTIL ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)H. Rex Lee, a career Federal official, is coming out of retirement to serve temporarily as Governor of American Samoa, a position he held from 1961 to 1967.

title: Suspension, Injuries Weaken Cosmos
description: All of a sudden the Cosmos find themselves short of defenders for today's encounter with the Fort Lauderdale Strikers at Giants Stadium. In the first seven games, of which the Cosmos won four, Coach Gordon Bradley had the luxury of choosing his starters on defense from a large contingent, but for today's game he may have to settle for less than his secondbest choices of defenders. Although there are plenty of them in the North American Soccer League.

title: Ruddy Duck Finishes First
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., May 14 (AP) Ruddy Duck beat Rubles Image by six lengths in finishing first today in the featured $4,200 eighth race at Finger Lakes Race Track. Reasonable Willie was third in the sevenhorse field. The victor paid $4.60, $3.40 and $2.80.

title: SCANDAL AND ARRESTS EMBROIL ARGENTINAI
description: BUENOS AIRES, May 12Argentina is in turmoil over revelations of business scandals and over a morality campaign by rightwingers in which a former president has been arrested.

title: INTO THE ARMS OF THE LAW:
description: Carla Blair, in window at top, throwing her 13monthold daughter, Danielle, into the outstretched arms of Gordon Johnson, F.B.I. agent, in Youngstown, Ohio, yesterday. Mrs. Blair's son, Isaac, 4, was caught by agent at left. The woman and her children were seized as hostages by a bank robber who later surrendered.

title: Canadiens Oust Bruins, 21, For 2d Straight Cup Sweep
description: BOSTON, May 14An overtime goal by Jacques Lemaire tonight not only gave the Montreal Canadiens a 21 victory over the Boston Bruins, the championship of the National Hockey League and the Stanley Cup, but also may have proved what people have been saying all along: The Canadiens are the best hockey team in the world.

title: Jean Ruth Eskind Bride Of Dr. Kenneth J. Kral
description: Jean Ruth Eskind, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold G. Eskind of Louisville, Ky., was married at noon yesterday to Dr. Kenneth John Kral, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kral of New Hyde Park, L.I. The Rev. Robert Reid performed the ceremony in the First Unitarian Church of Louisville.

title: The Rise of the SinglePerson Household
description: TO some it would seem that Gary Gerth lost his mind about two years back. That's when the 34yearold blond bachelor relinquished a banking career, apartment at Park Avenue and &3d Street in New York City and a healthy social life for a job with the administration of the Town of Hempstead and a twostory bungalow in a Long Island community where the most exciting event one recent spring evening was the arrival of the icecream man.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Evans Captures Lead In National Kayaking
description: JAMAICA, Vt., May 14Eric Evans, the 27yearold eighttime national champion, from Mountain View, Calif., had a clean first run today and took the lead in the men's kayak class of the national whitewater championships and team trials here.

title: THAT WAS THE LIFE
description: EVERY spring, while George P. Hunt reigned as managing editor of Life magazine, we who worked there would get all dressed up and troop over to the Plaza Hotel to find our place cards at what was called the Hunt Ball. Food and speeches were extravagant. Hunt, a Marine veteran, one year exhorted us to take the high ground! He meant it, just as Henry R. Luce had when he decreed that our mission was to see life, to see the world, to eyewitness great events. No wonder we weren't much for sitting around the office, or anywhere else, when we could go out swashbuckling. If we didn't leap tall buildings with a single bound, we hired someone else to leap them for us, and never mind what it cost or whom it inconvenienced. Our 40 million readers would forgive us, and so might our friends, if we still had any outside the office. We shared what Dora Jane Hamblin, in That Was the Life, calls a casual arrogance.

title: Topics
description: Bad Call

title: In Defense of the Educational System
description: DR. GUSTAVO A. MELLANDER, president of Passaic County Community College, issued a clarion call (Opinion Page, April 17) for a return to basics in education. At the risk of being classified among those who are contemptuous of Lincoln, motherhood and dogs, 1 would like to defend parts of the current educational system, even to the point of stating that the teaching of the three R's may not be the primary concern of our schools. (1 think 1 hear cries of Heresy! emanating from Passaic.)

title: CHARLES E. GORDON
description: Charles E. Gordon, a retired sales executive for the Oxford Paper Company, died Friday at Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing. Queens, after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Greece Working For the Revival Of Its Provinces
description: ALEXANDROUPOLIS, Greece Twentysix miles east of this provincial capital, a bridge spans the sluggish brown waters of the Hevros River. In the middle of the bridge, two lines are painted across the pavement only inches apart, one red and one blue.

description: As everybody knows, there are at least two sides to every issue. At Princeton University, the two sides are putting out every issue of the campus newspaper.

title: Thoroughbred Racing
description: Aqueduct closes on Saturday and Forego, the 7yearold gelding voted Horse of the Year the last three years, is slated to make his first start of the year. The feature is the $50,000 added Roseben Handicap at seven furlongs for 3yearolds and up. Forego's main rivals are expected to be Quiet Little Table, Gentle King, Full Out and Soy Numero Uno. Tomorrow's feature is the $35,000 added Comely at seven furlongs for 3yearold fillies.

title: SELECTION: The Oxford Book of Literary Anecdotes.
description: It is said that upon his presenting some poems to the Queen she ordered him a gratuity of one hundred pounds, but the Lord Treasurer Burleigh objecting to it, said with some scorn of the poet, of whose merit he was totally ignorant, What, all this for a song? The Queen replied, Then give him what is reason. Spenser for some time waited, but had the mortification to find himself disappointed of Her Majesty's bounty, Upon this he took a proper opportunity to present a paper to Queen Elizabeth, in which he reminded her of the order she had given, in the following lines:

title: Mary Hartman, The Writer, Is a Professor
description: PEOPLE tend to misinterpret it right off the bat and say, Oh, you're feminist writing about women who murderyou must be saying it's a feminist thing to do,  declares Mary S. Hartman, author of Victorian MurderessesA True History of Thirteen Respectable French and English Women Accused of Unspeakable Crimes (Schocken Books, $15).

description: President Carter has returned from his first overseas diplomatic journey able to report modest successmostly because his goals were also modestin his conference with leaders of six other important industrial nations in London.

description: MEXICO CITY, May 14The editors of the newspaper Excelsior said today that a report in The New York Times suggesting that the Government planned to replace them with journalists ousted from the paper last year was fantasy and far from truth and reality.

description: A suspect in the killing of an offduty police officer Thursday night in Brooklyn surrendered, the police reported.

title: FEDERAL LAW URGED TO AID STATE INMATES
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The American Bar Association has urged the enactment of Federal legislation to protect the rights of inmates in state institutions.

title: Jefferson Davis's Pipe Recovered
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that it had recovered Confederate President Jefferson Davis's meerschaum pipe and case, which were stolen in Virginia. The antiques were taken from a display at Casement Museum at Fort Monroe, Va., six days ago and turned up here in the hands of a private individual, the agency said. No arrests have been made.

title: Christopher Fisher Weds Missy Edson
description: Mary Amizetta Edson and Christopher Alan Fisher were married yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Denver by the Very Rev. Herbert M. Barrall.

title: What's Doing in
description: THE PLAIN FOLKThe Pennsylvania Dutch Country is a rolling, richly fertile rectangle in the southeastern part of the state, bounded roughly by Philadelphia's northern suburbs, Allentown, Harrisburg and York. Tourists are interested mainly in the area just east of Lancaster and northeastward from Lancaster to Reading, where the principal attraction is not the beauty of the countryside but the human sceneryspecifically, the plain folk. The conservative Mennonites and their even more conservative offshoot sect. the Amish, believe in preserving life as it was when their forefathers came to America early in the 18th century. They have prospered in agriculture, but they shun tractors and electricity and refuse to own automobiles, radios or television sets. Instead, they cling to the horse and buggy, the horsedrawn plow, the kerosene lamp, the oneioom schoolhouse, austere dress and a rigid code of behavior. They don't like to be photographed and they avoid tourists, but they aye extremely visible around Lancaster except on Sunday mornings, when they are in church. The name Dutch is a misnomer: most of the plain folk are descended from Germans or Swiss. They originally called themselves. Deutsch, but the AngloAmericans incorrectly translated it as Dutch.

title: Memorial Services
description: COSTERCharles Henry. A memorial service for Charles Henry Coster, who died April 3, in Florence, Italy, will be held in the Chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave, and 60th St., New York City, on Tuesday, May 17, at 11 A.M. The service will be conducted by the Very Reverend Sturgis Lee Riddle, D.D. In ??e? of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to the American Red Cross ?t Greater New York.

title: FISHING
description: THE most plentiful fish around the Island this week appear to be whiting and mackerel off the South Shore, mackerel in Long Island Sound and cod and pollock off Block Island. But if you've already filled your freezer with these, there is a mixed bag of winter fish beginning to move offshore and summer fish heading in. The choice runs from weakfish, striped bass and fluke to flounder, blackfish and porgies.

title: In California
description: ST. HELENA, Calif.A new growing season has begun and the vines are turning green here in the Napa Valley, a bucolic region 60 miles north of San Francisco where some $200 million of wine, including some of the world's finest, is produced each year.

title: ART
description: THERE was much  more brouhaha and raucous fanfare  over the Bicentennial celebrations in the visual arts than there was memorable substance. Now that the clamor has died down and the applause of selfcongratulation has subsided, we have had a chance to take stock of what was produced for America's birthday in the way of exhibitions, publications and other events, and we have found that there wasn't too much.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Anna Quindlen is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: None but the Braves
description: Now that Ted Turner has closed out his career as manager of the Braves, it should be said that he was not the worst field leader Atlanta ever had, although Bowie Kuhn was not aware of this when he decided Turner's lack of familiarity with game operations could make a travesty of the sport. In their only game with their owner moonlighting in uniform, the Braves absorbed their 17th defeat in a row, giving the boss a winning percentage of .000 but Ken Silvestri's record was even worse. Back in 1967 Ken replaced Billy Hitchcock with three games remaining, and the Braves lost all three. And when it came to familiarity with game operations, well, 1967 was Silvestri's 29th yerf in baseball and in his time he had been a catcher, outfielder, first baseman, second baseman, shortstop, coach and minor league manager.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: 9 Robert Nisbet reviews Utopia and Revolution

title: Darrell Royal Receives Award
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 14 (AP)Darrell Royal, former football coach for the University of Texas, received the Robert R. Neyland Memorial Award last night. The award, named for a Tennessee coach, is presented annually by the Knoxville Quarterback Club to a coach who has made a major contribution to collegiate football.

title: Betrayed by Adults
description: A Family Gathering is a tight, unpretentious novel about the little crumbling disorders and disentanglements of nieces, nephews, uncles and aunts. Bailey Wright, a middleaged engineer who has just lost his job, leaves Richmond, Va., with his wife and his 12yearold son for a twomonth stay in his late father's country house. His niece is getting married. The house is occupied by his older brother, Brody's wife and Brody's daughter Bonnie, the bridetobe.

title: What Was Good for the Railroads...
description: ONCE again Dee Brown is telling us one of the great American stories in his new book, this time the story of how the railroads crossed North America in the 1860's and 70's and changed everything for everybody. Just about everybody we've ever heard of in the second half of the 19th century had some connection with the railroads. Abe Lincoln in 1858 was the lawyer for the first rail line to cross the Mississippi, defending them in an action brought by Mississippi steamboat interests who wanted the corn, pork, wheat and timber of the Midwest to continue traveling south In boats to St. Louis, Memphis and New Orleans, instead of heading east in trains to Chicago and New York; Buffalo Bill Cody shot buffalo to feed the Irishmen laying track; Lieut. Col, George Armstrong Custer was sent west to clear Indians out of the path of the Kansas Pacific Railroad; James A. Garfield, later President of the United States, briefly, was caught with his hand in the till of Credit Mobilier, the outfit that was milking the Union Pacific of its profits.

title: Gadfly on Jobless Fraud
description: O NE YEAR AGO Robert Mollozzi set out alone, full of good intentions and some wideeyed innocence, to show the State Department of Labor the error and ineptness of its ways. The Labor Department had him arrested for his trouble.

title: Down to Brighton: A Day in Prinny's Playground
description: One firstclass ticket to Brighton, said I to the ticket seller at London's Victoria Station. His mustache twitched ever so slightly. We both knew it was folly to go first class to Brighton, one hour south of London.

title: Canadians Score in Crew Races
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., May 14The Western sprint rowing championships marked by the absence of most of the Pacific8 Colleges, ended this morning after two days of competition. The Pac8 crews will stage their own conference title races next weekend.

title: Design
description: The romance of Victorian times is in the air. Perhaps it's nostalgia, a desire to return to the solidity of that timespan when America was secure, selfsatisfied and growing. Whatever the reason, the Victorian influence is making a strong impression on interior and furniture design and fashion. It's the taste for anything with lace and eyelet that can range from blouses and sundresses to lacefilled bedrooms. The newest accessories to wear are shawls and antique Victorian jewelry. It's the vogue for pretty floral prints and a softtinted palette in wallpaper and fabric designs. Decorators who have made their names devising cool, modern interiors are now leaning toward fabriccovered wails and cozier rooms filled with furniture and bricabrac. And the massive, ornate furniture that was commonplace at the turn of the century, has now been revived in an impressive way by American furniture manufacturers who supply the entire country. Here, and on following pages, is a report on how some of this Victorian influence is being evidenced today.

title: Giaimo: Capitol Budget Maker
description: ON THE WALL behind the clutter of papers and budget reports on his desk there is splendid symbol of the RenaisIt's a large sketch of the Duomo, the famous Florentine cathedral, a gift the sketch, that isfrom the Mayor of Florence.

title: City Culture Chief Plans an Arts Festival
description: Martin E. Segal, an investment banker who has another fulltime career as New York City's unpaid chairman of the Commission for Cultural Affairs, a position in which he functions as financial guide, nursemaid, mediator, protector and booster of arts and letters as they affect the city (he thinks there is no way in which they don't), met the other day with Dr. William Schuman, board chairman of the Norlin Foundation. The two men approved an announcement saying that there will be an International Festival of the Arts in New York in 1979.

title: Renee Richards Fails Sex Test For Rome Open
description: ROME, May 14 (AP)  Dr. Renee Richards failed a sex test today and was declared ineligible to play in the women's division of the Italian tennis open, which starts tomorrow.

title: Homosexuality And the Suburbs
description: IT may not sound like an unusual suburban dinner party: two couples, a few odd singles, good food and wine, an artistically furnished apartment on a quiet White Plains street. But there was this difference: the couples were all men and the talk was of homosexual life in the suburbs.

title: MUSIC
description: HAVE you ever wondered why amateur orchestras usually sound like, well, amateur orchestras, while avocational fine and rehearsal timecan mount performances rivaling professional ensembles? I remember thinking about that when sang with the N.Y.U. Glee Club several centuries ago: half the fellows couldn't read music and the other half had nonvoices like mine, a dubious mix that nonetheless sparked some marvelous results.

description: Illustrated. 63 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $7.95. (Ages 9 to 13)

description: ATLANTA, May 14The textile industry, whipsawed by a growing flood of cheap foreign imports, a powerful union organizational drive and relentless pressure from the Federal Government to spend billions on new safety equipment, is entering one of the most critical economic periods in its recent history.

title: WAGE INCREMENTS RULED VOID IF PACT EXPIRES
description: ALBANY (AP)Public employers may cancel agreedupon salary increments if negotiations on a new contract reach an impasse when an old pact expires, the state's highest court ruled.

title: Won't Fool Wins by Head
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 14 (AP) Aisco Stable's Won't Fool, half of the oddson favored entry trained by Jimmy Croll Jr., captured the $25,000 Cavalcade Handicap today, beating Moody Jolley's Nearly On Time by a head. Ali Oop, the other half of the entry, took third place in the sevenfurlong race at Atlantic City.

title: U.S. Considering New Strategies In Its Policies Toward South Africa
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, May 13The United States is reviewing a series of possible strategiessome symbolic and some punitivethat would signal to South Africa just how strongly the Carter Administration is committed to fostering significant change in racial policies.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, MAY 15, 1977

title: ENCOUNTER
description: I staggered off the boat, an old car ferry called the Marine Coaster. The crossing from Labrador to northern Newfoundland had been rough and I was barely able to mount my bicycle and head off up the narrow dirt road toward the town of St. Anthony.

title: La Pasionaria Returns
description: Dolores Ibarruri, the Communist leader whose inspiring oratory during the Spanish Civil War won her the nickname 'La Pasionaria, has returned to Spain after 38 years of exile in the Soviet Union; and many of the 2,000 Spaniards living in the Soviet Union will probably follow. Mrs. Ibarruri returns as the nominal president of the recently legalized Spanish Communist Party, and Soviet officials hope she can exert some proMoscow influence on the party's policies. Santiago Carrillo, the party's secretarygeneral, has followed a more independent course in the past. Spanish Communist leaders say they expect to use Mrs. Ibarruri extensively in the upcoming election campaign. Mrs. Ibarruri, now 82, symbolized for many the Republican cause during the Spanish Civil War. It was she who coined the phrase, in a broadcast in 1936, It is better to die on your feet than to live on your knees.

title: Katherine Inez Hall Married to Albert G. Lauber 3d
description: Katherine Inez Hall, who will graduate in January from the Yale Law School, was married yesterday afternoon in New Haven to Albert George Lauber 3d, who will receive a law degree from Yale tomorrow.

title: PuffPuff Potatoes
description: There is one dish in the French repertory that, mum than most, seems to fire the imagination and capture the fancy of nonproffessional  pommes soufflees or souffle potatoes, those crisp, hollow, zeppelinshaped oddities served hot from the kitchen.

title: Janet Watrous Is Bride of Upstate Editor
description: Janet Couper Watrous, will become assistant minister of the Tabernacle United Methodist Church in Binghamton to Robert Charles Kochersberger Jr., assistant city editor of The Evening Press there.

title: Summer Tenants: Horror and Chutzpah
description: NO Dogs. No children. No heterosexual singles. No homosexual singles. No parties. With all these prohibitions, it's a wonder that anyone but an 80yearold celibate transvestite with a parakeet manages to rent a house for the summer on Long Island Sound, but people do, although in everdecreasing numbers, as homes on the Sound lose ground and prestige to Cape Cod and the Hamptons.

description: Two events last weekthe dedication of a new sightseeing boat and the addition of a new vessel to the port's cruise ship rosterbuoyed hopes for local and offshore passenger ship activities. On Thursday, the new sightseeing boat Miss Freedom, a 135foot, 450passenger craft was dedicated in brief ceremonies at West 43d Street, home base of the Circle Line. The new $750,000 boat will offer service from the Battery and from Jersey City to the Statue of Liberty National Monument's Ellis Island section, the site of the American Museum of Immigration.

description: ICAME to Iona at the age of 56 with the same fears, lack of knowledge of the workings of a college and doubts about my future as any highschool graduate of lesser years. Younger students have no monopoly on concerns about the unknown.

description: This colt is amazing, says Johnny Adams, the former jockey who trains horses on the West Coast. He does things so easy, it's phenomenal.

title: New Rochelle Tests Sunpower
description: NEW ROCHELLE'S $4.5 million public library and cultural center, now under construction as the centerpiece of an ambitious downtown redevelopment project, may serve an even wider purpose in a few years. Last week it was selected by a Federal agency as one of three libraries around the nation to test the feasibility of solar energy as an alternative heating and cooling source.

title: Patching Up Social Security
description: The Social Security system is well on its way to going broke. Payments to beneficiaries have exceeded revenues since 1975, and this year the deficit may reach $5.6 billion. According to recent estimates, reserves set aside to pay disability claims will be exhausted in two years; reserves for old age retirement will be gone in six.

title: Chicago Gets Chagall Windows
description: CHICAGO, May 14The America Windows, Marc Chagall's tribute to the American Bicentennial and to the late Mayor Richard J. Daley, will be dedicated tomorrow afternoon at the Art Institute of Chicago.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE Traveler's Rest reflects an era when eating out was a planahead family treat. The building that now houses the restaurant in Millwood, N.Y., is only about six years old, but it adjoins the original inn, which goes back at least to the turn of the century and perhaps many years before that. It has two rooms on the main floor and two on a lower level. All four look out on a garden at the rear where ducks stroll through a manicured garden with a manmade stream meandering through it. In the middle distance is a waterfall surrounded by evergreens aglow with twinkling lights. It's all of piece, right down to the golden oldies from the 1930's and 90's wafting gently through the sound system.

title: Woman Officer Hailed After Texas Drug Raid
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 14 (UPI)Six months ago Lucille Franckowiak abandoned her friends, started dressing in grimy clothes, poked her arm daily with needles to give the appearance of a Junkie and bought narcotics.

description: LONDON, May 14 (AP)  Barbara Moore, a Russianborn health enthusiast who was the first woman to make a 3,000mile marathon walk from San Francisco to New York. died in a London hospital yesterday. She was 73 years old.

title: The Parlous State Of the Arts In Great Britain
description: LONDON Sotheby's has at last stopped biting its nails about Mentmore. After two years of quiet dickering and several months of excited debate, the British Government refused to buy the exRothschild, neoJacobean mansion and its vast collection of furniture and art, and the result is that an extraordinary quantity of objects will now be sold in what the auction firm, acting for Lord Rosebery, the present owner of the mansion, calls the sale of the century. It will be held from May 18 to 27.

title: victoriana
description: The late Vickirian furniture styles that are about to sweep America are rich in nostalgia and beastly chic. Indeed, the revival is pervasive in the collections of the nation's mass furniture producers that were shown recently in High point, N. C., furniture that will surface in stores from July through late summer. Many of these reproductions are exact copies of yesterday's favorifetthe weighty wonders that spelled solidly and respectability in homes of the gaslight on lions paw bases, and so much more: rolltop desks, brass beds, fainting couches and hall racks. The revival actually dates to the 1960's, when buffs of the style

description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 14The hurt is still there for Steve Williams but it stirs from the heart, not his legs.

title: Henn, Leading From Start, Takes Long Motorboat Race
description: MIAMI, May 14Preston Henn triumphed in a wild and woolly, Bacardi Trophy motorboat race that started here today. The race was delayed for 2 hours because of weather conditions. When it did start at 12:30 P.M., 14 open boats took the starter's flag. On their way out to Bimini on the first leg of the race, five of the starters broke down.

description: This time John D. MacDonald is trying to tell us something: Don't louse up the landscape, don't tamper with the environment, don't let hustlers by any respectable name take over our fragile natural resources. He's not a message writer, not even in Condominium, but a novelist foremost. Never. theless, MacDonald has strong feelings about the despoliation of the countryside and country.

title: Letters
description: Norma Rosen's article on abortion (Between Guilt ancl Gratification: Abortion Doctors Reveal Their Feelings, April 17) was most object There are, however, a few points that need to be expanded. In the piece, Dr. Howard Diamond states that the righttolifers don't give a damn, and he's right. He doesn't mention that they are against sex education and contraception (except the unreliable natural kind) and that they approve of the death penally. Dr. William Rashhaurn brings up the problem of teenagers who wait until the second trimester to have an abortion. These young women need sex education and easily accessible family planning sarvices.

J., 62, 62, in the opening round of the $3,000 Prince Eastern hardcourt tennis championships today.

All three sports somehow became involved in a lengthy State Department of Environmental Conservation proceeding in Hastings that has resuited in something of a loss for tennis, definite gain for fishing and uncertain outcome for some who love to take to the Hudson in boats.

title: Car Owners Sense Threat to FreeWheeling Life
description: ST. CLAIR SHORES, Mich. May 13Wally Jarema talks about his first car almost as if it were his first love. It was a 1953 Ford with a Chevy grille and Oldsmobile taillights and two glasspack mufflers that let the 1956 V8 engine roar right out. As a teenager, he installed those custom features himself, including the engine, and he lowered the car's back end in the style of the late 1950's.

title: FOOD
description: SOME people will go to extraordinary lengths to please their palates. Take Dahmen Brown, for example. Living in New York after 20 years in California, he discovered to his dismay that fresh tortillas were unobtainable here. I thought he was kidding, said his partner, Mary Gallagher, but I began making calls and sure enough, no fresh tortillas in New York.
