description: May 15, 1977/The New York Times Book Review

title: Rizzo Faces Test of Leadership In Voting Tuesdayin Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, whose political obituary has been prematurely written several times, is staking a significant part of his career in public service on the citywide primary election Tuesday.

title: When the Poor Nations Meet the Rich, They May Get Mostly Promises
description: LONDONThe rich industrial countries of the world, having successfully concluded their London conference, will have cause for relief when they move back to Paris at. the end of the month sit down with poorer nations for the final session of the Conference on International Economic Cooperation.

title: STAMPS
description: Even the most bureaucratic of institutions, and the United States Postal Service does not have to take a back seat to any on that score, is able to feel the stirrings of the seasonand so there is coming out a quartet of stamps for butterflies, because they are pretty and because it is spring.

title: Readiness Class Gets High Marks
description: IN KINDERGARTEN Jonathan was reading thirdgrade books, but he had trouble using scissors and crayons and pencils. His ability to control his muscles was far below that of most children his age.

title: Rumanian Gymnasts Quit Women's Meet in Dispute
description: PRAGUE, May 14 (AP)The Rumanian Gymnastics Federation withdrew its team from the European women's gymnastics championships today, alleging biased refereeing.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: JUST when it appeared that spring had finally arrived to spread its warmth and nurture the nation's agriculture and shrubbery, the weather man became a spoilsport and deposited some unseasonal coldair blasts, hail and even snow last week in some eastern sectors of the country. And something analagous happened in the business world.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bill on Challenging Judges Is Stalled in the Assembly
description: ALBANY, May 14After a spirited debate full of personal insults and verbal attacks, the Assembly Judiciary Committee refused this week to report out a controversial bill that would give a lawyer for either side of a case the right to reject the assigned judge and request another one.

title: William P. Fletcher And Mary Johnson Set August Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Johnson of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellen Johnson, to William Preston Fletcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Leland Fletcher Jr. of Pittsford, N.Y. The wedding is planned for August.

title: The London Art Market Arrives
description: When the British colonized America, revolutionary things happened. Now the British are at it again, this time in the art world, and a minirevogution is expected to ensue with New York nosing out London as the preeminent capital of the art and antiques market.

title: LETTERS TO THE NEW IERSEY EDITOR
description: How happy, and surprised, I was to come across Michael Goodwin's article, Still Missing, Still Hope (New Jersey Weekly, May 1).

title: The Cleverest Young Man Is Named
description: The appointment of Peter Jay, the soninlaw of Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain, as the new British Ambassador to Washington, has been criticized by members of both of Britain's major political parties. The appointment was called blatant naked nepotism and indefensible favoritism, and newspapers generally favorable to Mr. Callaghan's Government questioned Mr. Jay's qualifications for the job. Mr. Jay, 43 years old and the economics editor The Times of London, is considered highly competent; fact, a newspaper profile of him last year called him the cleverest young man in England. But his lack of diplomatic experience and his relationship to the Prime Minister make the appointment vulnerable. Mr. Callaghan will have defend the appointment before Parliament, but it does not need formal Parliamentary approval.

title: Preholiday Exams Due at Rutgers
description: WE'RE really going to have exams before Christmas next year? a Rutgers freshman said last week. That's fantastic, he added happily. He voiced sentiment heard often recently among the State University's undergraduates, after a perennial student lobbying effort on the New Brunswick campus paid off, and Rutgers scheduled next year's fallterm final examinations before the Christmas vacation.

title: Revson Foundation Revived
description: In his day, and a long day it was, Charles R. Revson, the harddriving, irascible and controversial founder of the Revlon cosmetics empire, liked giving money away almost as much as he liked making it.

title: Of Rats and Men
description: The F.D.A. wants to ban saccharin because it causes cancer in rats. But are rats like humans?

title: Music in Review
description: Add to the roster of accomplished young harpsichordists the name of Lucille Gruber. Miss Gruber, a New Yorker who has spent much of her playing career in Boston and Cleveland, displayed considerable facility in dealing with works abounding in technical and musical difficulties, and that made her recital in Alice Tully Hall last Sunday night continually worth paying attention to. Performing on a softvoiced Herz instrument dated 1971, Miss Gruber manipulated its two manuals adroitly and made sensitive use of its restricted registration.

title: Mary Miller Married To Sinclair Hatch
description: Mary Wendell VanderPoel Miller of Oyster Bay, L. I., was married there yesterday afternoon to Sinclair Hatch of New York and Setauket, L. I. The Rev. Robert Hollett and Canon Paul Wancura of the Caroline Church of Brookhaven (Episcopal) officiated in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: State Aide Scores Foes Of Nestle Headquarters In Westchester County
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 14John S. Dyson, the State Commissioner of Commerce, has branded residents of Purchase who oppose a Nestl headquarters in their area, which has many private estates, as a few fat cats whose stand would have made the most arrogant of the robber barons blush with shame.

title: GARDENING
description: WORD has got around that some tardy gardeners have not planted anything in their vegetable patch. On with it! This week is the deadline for setting out lettuce and pea seed, cabbage and broccoli plants and onion sets. At least catchup planters will be on schedule with their provident neighbors who are getting ready to set out melons, corn, beans, tomatoes, peppers, eggplants and squash by the end of the month.

title: Carol Martin Married To Richard A. Bellino
description: Carol Ann Martin of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Blair Martin of Norristown, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon in New York to Richard A. Bellino, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Bellino of Newburgh, N. Y. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony in St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: The Democrats Favor ElectionDay Registering, Republicans Oppose It
description: WASHINGTONWhen successive waves of immigration began to fill expanding American cities with the poor, 19thcentury political reformers moved to insure the sanctity of elections by requiring prior registration. In earlier days, pollwatchers had known all the residents of their village or neighborhood precinct, and only an occasional stranger was challenged. Only a system of limiting the franchise to those who had earlier identified themselves as eligible could protect honest citizens against bosses efforts to buy the votes of masses of potentially corruptible newly arrived citizensor so the argument went.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY HOMES that have oilfired hot water heat in this area get their domestic hot water (for bathing and washing) from a coil that is inside the same boiler that creates heat for the house

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Baseball
description: The Mets conclude their series against the Los Angeles Doagers with a 2:05 P.M. game today in Shea Stadium, After a day off tomorrow, the Mets resume at Shea with 8:05 P.M. games Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday nights against the San Francisco Giants. The Yankees open a fivegame series against the Baltimore Orioles with 8 o'clock games on Thursday and Friday in Yankee Stadium, followed by a 2 o'clock game Saturday and a doubleheader Sunday against the Orioles beginning at 1 P.M.

title: Apples Beat Lobsters, 2619; Ruffels's Service Prevails
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., May 14Although Martina Navratilova scored her first women's singles victory over Billie Jean King following three losses in World Team Tennis competition, the New York Apples topped the Boston Lobsters, 2619, tonight at Nassau Coliseum and put the brakes on Boston's runaway start.

title: Gaelic Football and Hurling
description: Today is one of the biggest of the season at Gaelic Park, 240th Street and Broadway in the Bronx. It marks the final United States stop for the 1977 allIreland champions in both sports. At 2:30 P.M., Cork, the allIreland hurling champion, takes on a contingent of Irish AllStars and at 4 o'clock, Dublin, the allIreland football champion, plays another allIrish allstar team.

title: A Time for Energy
description: THE TIMING would appear to be nearperfect. The President's dramatic program has heightened public awareness of the of the crisis. The winter's hardships gave evidence that the 1973 embargo was but a harbinger.

title: South African Trip Is Off For Field Hockey Team
description: It was after 8 o'clock Thursday night when the president of Ursinus College had finally made his decision. All last week, he had not been sure if he had the authority to influence the outcome of the matter and had doubted that he did. Even Richard Richter's tone had changed as he read the lengthy prepared statement over the phone from his office in Collegeville, Pa. Only five days before, he had discussed the possibilities more freely, and now he would only read the words aloud and decline to comment further. I will say nothing else, this is my statement, he repeated in response to various questions.

title: Can He Make the Jaws of Outer Space?
description: Los ANGELES He drives the obligatory Mercedes with a telephone, only the car is leased. He lives in a chalet perched on the side of a canyon, but it's small and modest. And when he comes strolling in for lunch at L'Ermitage, a posh little place on La Cienega Boulevard, no one recognizes him, perhaps because he looks more like a schoolboy in his Prince Valiant hairdo, aviator glasses, brown suede jacket and Levis than he does a multimillionaire movie mogul.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY HOMES that have oilfired hot water heat in this area get their domestic hot water (for bathing and washing) from a coil that is inside the same boiler that creates heat for the house.

title: A New Cultural Alliance
description: On May 24, when the Stuttgart Ballet opens in Washington, the curtain will rise not only on a premier dance company but on a new, unprecedented partnership. The Stuttgart is imported, presented and managed by an unlikely pair of impresarios: the Metropolitan Opera and the Kennedy Center. Without this new management venture, spokesmen suggest, Americans might never again see major European cultural attractions in this country on a regular basis. Moreover, the MetKennedy Center collaboration promises to further bolster the position of dance in the United States. It may also stimulate a new interest in vocal and choral music as the two partners weigh the possibilities of recitals, operettas, even musical comedies.

title: Bell Plan on Release Of Information Gets Variety of Responses
description: WASHINGTON, May 14Federal officials have given varied responses to a recent letter from Attorney General Griffin B. Bell in which he warned that the Justice Department would defend them for withholding Government information only when disclosing the information would be demonstrably harmful.

title: Rhodesian Priest Faces Charges
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 14 (Reuters)A Roman Catholic priest is facing charges of failing to report the presence of black nationalist guerrillas in his parish, the Bishop of Wankie, Ignatius Prieto, said today. He told reporters that Father Maximus Gumbo from Karangwe mission near the border with Zambia, will appear In magistrate's court on May 23.

title: Realty News
description: The Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association is expanding its facilities on the East Side in midtown by about 40 percent.

title: NEW JIIRSIVY
description: WEIGHT LOSS GUARANTEED THE ULTIMATE DIET FAMOUSTRAYLOR METHOD FASTING SPECIAL DIETS FRICE MEDICAL EXAM FREE DAILY MASSAGE TENNIS Limited To 40 People SETON INN SPA Lakewood Golf Course New Jersey (212) WO 24380 (201) 3637733

title: Concorde's New Chance to Lose Money
description: After being lost in the political clouds for a year, the joint BritishFrench supersonic Concorde may finally be permitted to land at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Lemaire Sparkles in His Own Right After Being in Shadow of Linemates
description: BOSTON, May 14Jacques Lemaire had found a quiet, cool corner in a trainer's room, away from the hubbub and the champagne geysers with which the Montreal Canadiens tonight were celebrating their second consecutive Stanley Cup championship.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Grass clippings are an excellent mulch between vegetable rows ;use lightly and scratch into the surface of the soil. . . Use paper collars made of milk cartons when setting out tomato, pepper, eggplant and melon seedlings to protect them from cutworms which hide near the surface of the soil. . . . Benomyl, folpet or ferbam used every two weeks will keep rose black spot under control. . . Snap heads off faded tulips so seed pods do not form; allow foliage of all bulbs to ripen and renew bulbs forming next spring's flowers.

title: To the Class Of 77 With Love
description: OXFORD, Ohio, May 14This year's college graduates are supposed to be the luckiest class since the last World War. They are not being battered now by the cynicism and pessimism of recent years. In some ways they have advantages: no military draft, no conventions, Gods, priests, teachers or even parents standing in their waynothing but Freedom.

title: Sweet Smells of Food Festival Lure Thousands to 9th Ave.
description: I can't eat nothin', said John Jones. I'm on a diet.

title: Mixed Use: As an Idea It's Enticing, But Does It Work In Dollars?; Mixed Use: Enticing, But Does It Work?
description: To many planners, diversity is the key to urban vital ity, and the key to diversity is the mixeduse building.

title: CRIME
description: An air of disillusion hovers over Mel Arrighi's TURKISH WHITE (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $7.95). On one level it is a chase novel, in which a young American and his girlfriend, hired to run a carload of opium from Istanbul to Marseilles, discover they are being followed. The young man is clever and resourceful, and manages to ditch his pursuers; but they are never far behind, and at the end there is a confrontation.

title: Dance: Agglomeration by Tharp
description: The charm of some works by, say, Miro, are partly that you could imagine creating them yourself. Their simplicity is childlike. A scribble, a scrabble, a dash. A flick of color. A beetlelike shape. Yes anyone could do it. Perhaps.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IVE gone for two months averaging $25 or $30 a week. And then all of a sudden you have a $2,000 day, and then everybody _ ys: That's the business oueht to be in.'

title: Success as a Narcotics King
description: IN SOME ways, his life story sounds like that of a contemporary Horatio Alger. Born to povertystricken parents in rural North Carolina, he left the South to find his fortune in the urban North. Eventually, he moved into Newark's crowded Central Ward.

title: Home Style
description: Lock the barn door before the horse is stolen, of course. But how to protect the barn itself? In Pennsylvania recently thieves made off with an 80footlong side of a 100yearold barn. And that is just one larcenous tale.

title: Dog Shows Alfresco
description: THE dogwood is out in Connecticut. So are the dogs. In Recreation Park, at the junction of Routes 6 and 14 in Willimantic, the Windham Kennel Club is staging its 33d annual fixture today. It marks the start of an outdoor dogshow season in Connecticut that lasts until the end of September, with a dozen events to be held across the state.

title: NEW YORK CITY URGED TO BUILD DRILL RIGS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14New York should cash in on the coming boom in offshore oil development by constructing drilling platforms and superstructures approaching the size of the Chrysler Building.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY HOMES that have oilfired hot water heat in this area get their domestic hot water (for bathing and washing) from a coil that is inside the same boiler that creates heat for the house.

title: In Memoriam
description: AMSTERDAMGary. With deep ????? tion I recall my dear brother, who Passed away, May 18, 1966. Irving.

title: Bridal in Greenwich Held for Ann Martin And Barry Ridings
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Ann Kennedy Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Roland Martin Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married to Barry William Ridings, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester W. Ridings of Cedar Grove, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel Walker, assisted by the Rev. Peter Roberge, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: PARISAfter the season's final schuss through the spring corn, his pullovers packed away in mothballs and his Rossignols banished to a remote corner of the closet, how does a skier stay fit until the next winter's first snowfall?

title: Deborah Mott Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Mott of Hewlett Bay Park and Ocean Beach, Fire Island, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Anne Mott, to Gary P. Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Taylor of West Islip and Atlantique, Fire Island, L.I. Miss Mott, an alumna of Middlebury College, received a master's degree from Teachers College of Columbia Univerity. Her fianc, graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, is a realestate appraiser with Rogers & Taylor Inc. of Bay Shore, L.I. The couple will be married June 11.

title: IN AMERICA
description: RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex. Until recently, the eyes of Texas were never upon you if you lived in Starr County. What slight distinction Starr could claim was a matter of a few statistics. No other county in the state had a higher proportion of MexicanAmericans (more than 97 percent), or persons living below the poverty line (nearly 75 percent), or residents ??grating annually from their homes in search of labor (at least 30 percent). Figures like that don't add up to influence in Texas. A remote border county with a population of fewer than 20,000, Starr seemed destined to be ignored. But Starr isn't being ignored any longer. It has been discovered, all because someone finally came up with a statistic that could slick in the mind. Between 10 percent and 35 percent of Starr's population, it was said, has a stake in the booming mar?uana traffic across the Rio Grande.

title: Coast Guard Academy Crew Takes 3d Straight Vail Cup
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 14The United States Coast Guard Academy's computer crew, unbeaten the last two years in smallcollege, eightOared racing, won the varsity heavyweight championship for the third straight season in a close finish today in the 39th Dad Vail Regatta.

title: Artful Industry
description: IT COULD be Santa Claus's workshop two days before Christmas. The room is crammed with tools, halffinished projects, and the inevitable sawdust. The workers are in dustrious, cooperative, and diminutive, if not exactly elfin. They are students at the Helen Keller Middle School of Easton, a public school for grades six through eight, and they are experts in the art of woodworking.

title: New Economics Series Is Strictly Galbraithian
description: And now . . . heeere's Johnny! John Kenneth Galbraith, economist, teacher, writer, editor, art historian, novelist, adviser to Presidents, has turned his attention to television.

title: Questions/Answers
description: Questions/Answers

title: Hope for Young Cancer Patients
description: KEITH EVANS'S parents learned last January that their son had a malignant stomach tumor and that, fol lowing surgery, he would need to undergo chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

title: Miss Fales Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Fales of Pompano Beach, Fla., and West Tisbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Haliburton Fales, to Reinke Johann Duhme, son of Heide Duhme of Forst Gut Hermanshorst, Mnster, West Germany, and Hans Duhme.

title: He Meets Mondale This Week;Points of Agreement May Be Limited
description: JOHANNESBURGPrime Minister John B. Vorster does not indulge potential adversaries, however powerful, with diplomatic evasions. As you will learn, I am a very blunt man, he told an American last year. How blunt, Vice President Mondale is likely to discover this week, when he meets the South African leader in Vienna for two days of talks.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: ON June 24, 1976, amid great fuss and fury, a Government worker on a beach in Fairhaven lifted a sixounce shampoo bottle from a swath of materials where the water meets the land. According to the label, the barnacledfilled bottle had been purchased on Aug. 2, 1972, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Mr. Shapp Is Asked to Return Subsidy
description: Mr. Shapp Is Asked to Return Subsidy

title: Redding Takes a Stand
description: FOR a town to streamline a turnpike bridge over a stretch of Conrail tracks should be straightforward matter of a little planning, with some solid engineering, and plenty of concrete.

title: Putting Together a Car Pool That Works
description: IT'S 7 A.M. on a Friday and the Poundford Riders get out of their own cars and board the big, green Chevy van. These Pound Ridge and Bedford commuters have a car pool that works.

title: A Troubled Prima Donna Tries For a Comeback
description: Is it too late for Anna Moffo? Is her voice shot? Is opera's most glamorous diva going to become a hasbeen at 41? Anna's voice has been there all the time, her teacher Beverley Johnson reports calmly. It's just that somebody along the way forgot to tell her that you can't run a RollsRoyce without gas in it.

title: Montclair State Stressing the Arts
description: IN April 1975, Ralph Dungan, the state's Commissioner of Higher Education, designated the art facilities at Montclair State College as an official State Center for the Arts. Montclair thus joined Rutgers as an actively sponsored art center.

title: LEFTRIGHT DIVISION WIDENS IN PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, May 11Posters with three little girls stuffing carnations into the barrels of automatic rifles have recently appeared along the walls of Lisbon, with the slogan resistance and liberation.

title: The Beast That Put Somers on the Map
description: THE huge beast appeared without warning in their midst, spreading fear, awe and wonder among the people of Westchester. The time was early in the 19th century. The huge beast was an elephant called Old Bet. She had just become the property of an ambitious farmer named Hachaliah Bailey. And as farmer and elephant trudged through Westchester from Sing Sing to his place in Somers, the American circus was being born.

title: Regal Rumor Triumphs
description: CHICAGO, May 14 (AP)  Regal Rumor, the favorite, owned by Albert M. Stall of New Orleans, took the lead at the top of the strech today and under a whipping ride by Larry Snyder won the $34,100 Galafete Handicap by five lengths at Hawthorne. Kittyluck finished second and Mickey's Gal was third before a crowd of 17,663. Regal Rumor paid $3.80, $2.40 and $2.10. Kittyluck returned $3.40 and $3 and Mickey's Gal $4.

title: Pop: Comeback
description: There was an irony in Carly Simon's official return to live performing Friday night at the Other End after a fiveyear retirement. More than her songs, more than her singing and even more than her excellent band, what was impressive was her complete, seemingly confident command of the stage.

title: Intriguing Intrigue
description: JOHN CROSBY, formerly the arch and witty television critic of The New York Herald Tribune before it folded, here writes like a man alternately convinced and embarrassed by his own plot and charactersin doing so he surely anticipates his readers. The Company of Friends, Crosby's third novel, concerns a 45yearold retired concert pianist named Sascha Nagy, who is recruited by a former Anthard classmates and lifelong friend into performing small favors for the C.I.A. Also involved is his

title: Linda Anne Pizzitola, Buyer, Engaged to Edward H. Ruby
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Pizzitola of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Anne Pizzitola, to Edward Henry Ruby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Ruby of South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Real's Origins a Public Opinion Survey
description: Real started with a series of opinion surveys conducted for. Reynolds between 1971 and 1973 by the polling firm. of Yankelovich, Skelly & White Inc. The consumer's preference was switching to natural productswhether health foods or natural cosmeticsthe survey found. Reynolds eager to translate this shift in taste into a new cigarette began the most extensive testing process that any of its products had ever undergone.

title: Robert H. Levy, Lawyer, at 42; Was With the Legal Aid Society
description: Robert H. Levy, an attorney in charge of the law advisory bureau of the Legal Aid Society, died of a brain tumor Friday at his home, 142 East 16th Street. He was 42 years old.

title: South A frican Visit By Young Remains A Matter of Doubt
description: LISBON, May 14A spokesman for Andrew Young, United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that Mr. Young's announced plans to visit South Africa remained a matter of doubt and negotiation.

title: Bouncy Rendition of Cajun Music
description: Not all popular music in New York takes place under flossy recordcompany sponsorship. Friday night at the Church of Our Lady of Peace, 237 East 62d Street, the Louisiana Aces appeared under the auspices of the New York Pinewoods Folk Music Club, and the place was packed.

title: Ohio Legion Rejects Youth as Noncitizen
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 14 (AP)A popular high school honor student who was a unanimous choice to attend the American Legion's Boys State has been rejected by the sponsors because he is not an American citizen.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: The three sisters will not be leaving for Moscow tonight. They'll be dispersing, after this evening's performance of Chekhov's play, for Hollywood, Broadway, and points between, having done heroic duty in a very brief repertory season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Actually, I don't know where Rosemary Harris, Ellen Burstyn and Tovah Feldshuh are going, not to mention all the other far more than able actors who have been appearing in Frank Dunlop's production of The Three Sisters, but I know where they've been. Home. Home is where you go when you don't want to be with strangers for a while, where you go for the immediate sympathy and unquestioning support of your own kind.

title: 2D FIGURE IN SPY CASE CONVICTED ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, May 14 (AP)Andrew Daulton Lee, a 25yearold cabinetmaker accused of selling United States intelligence secrets to the Soviet Union, was convicted today on eight counts of conspiracy and espionage.

title: Summit Conferences All Move In NowFamiliar Rhythms
description: WASHINGTONSummit conferences, whether conducted between two national leaders or among seven, whether the principal topic is to be military, political, economic or all three, have a remarkable similarity in rhythm and structure, and last week's conference in London was no exception.

title: No Place for a Single?
description: THE phenomenon of suburban single is just one more example of Westchester's growing independence from New York City. And yet, because of New York's attraction to the young, defining a suburban single is done in terms of negation. A Westchester single is a person who did not grow up in the city, and who does not seek to satisfy his needs there. Most importantly, it is a frame of mind. it is desire to remain outside the grasp of the great monster to the south.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Louis H. Engel Jr.'s piece in your Westchester Weekly section of April 24 (So You Want to Be a Supervisor?) eloquently conveys his frustrations as the new (since 1975) Supervisor of the Town of Ossining. In the course of doing so, however, he takes several hard swings at my office. Almost any local official across the state would recognize them as both misdirected and wide of the mark, but many of your readers may not be aware of the facts.

title: Can the Genie Be Put Back in the Bottle?;
description: LONDONThe most important result of the London summits was intangibleJimmy Carter's emergence as leader of the West. Not much could be done about key tangible problemsunemployment and energy  in the exchanges on economic, political and military matters.

title: Golf
description: Laura Baugh, Carol Mann, Jane Blalock, Jan Stephenson, Kathy Whitworth and Pat Bradley, the defending champion, are some of the top women golfers expected to participate in the 1977 Ladies Professional Golfers Association $77,000 CocaCola Classic at Forsgate Country Club in Jamesburg, N.J., Friday through Sunday.

title: Nazi Hunter Accuses 2 Funds Of Aiding Accused War Criminals
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the Nazi hunter, said yesterday that two foundations had been organized in the United States to raise defense funds for accused Nazi war criminals.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: MY strongest reaction to Jules Feiffer's new novel is to wonder why he wrote it. We have to remind ourselves, every now and then, that a novel is a transaction between author and reader, and I'm tempted to ask Mr. Feiffer: What did I do to deserve this?

title: TRENTON NOTEBOOK
description: APROPOS of the old song, Will You Love Me in December as You Did in May?, will the people of New Jersey love casino gambling in June as much as they did last November?

title: Public Reaction to 90Proof Scotch
description: The bar chart below seems to have struck a nerve among connoisseurs of Scotch whisky. It shows the results of chilling a jigger of Scotch (1.7 fluid ?unces with six oneinch ice cubes. This simple experiment was conducted with Scotch of three different proofs So, 86.8 and 90 (Famous Grouse). If proof is cosidered a measure of freshness 90proof famous Grouse has a 8 minute advantage over 86.8Proof Scotchand in 8 minute advantage over 80Proof Scotch. ( Because it takes that much longer to dilute to 45 Proof.)

title: Littlenecks, Big Hopes
description: POINT LOOKOUT

title: Citizens Group Keeps Helping New York City
description: Although New York City's fiscal crisis has eased, individuals, companies and foundations are continuing to give time and money to help the city do what it no longer can afford to do, according to a report made to Mayor Beame.

title: Hospital Agency Faces Changes
description: SIGNIFICANT CHANGES in the way the state regulates hospitals and staterun health institutions are expected to be brought about by legislation passed by the General Assembly and now before the Governor, and by a lawsuit originally brought against the Hospital and Health Care Commission by 31 of the 35 community hospitals in the state.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 10 A.M. (Channel 4) Here and Now: Former Representative Bella S. Abzug.

title: After a Suit in Court, There's a Job on Deck
description: SAN FRANCISCOSay deckhand and most people envision a burly seaman, grizzled by time and the sea.

title: TV VIEW
description: There is always that one allencapsulating moment. In the first installment of The Nixon Interviews with David Frost, it came at the very end of the 90 minutes, when Frost, exhausted, said, I feel we've . . . been through a life almost, rather than an interview, and we thank you. Richard M. Nixon started to smile hesitantly, turned suspicious, dropped the smile, changed his mind again and put on a broad and mirthless grin leftover from the days of political campaigning. Like many in his audience, the former President wasn't sure whether to feel complimented or insulted. Whether to express gratitude or anger. He and Frost had indeed delivered a program with extraordinary impact, but the fact that a disgraced President could earn a reported $1 million for information and explanations rightfully due the country, without conditions of any sort, raises serious questions about the contemporary crafts of marketing and communications. The weary might merely sigh, once again, only in America.

title: Leonard Gets Unanimous Verdict For Second Victory as Pro Boxer
description: BALTIMORE, May 14 (AP)Sugar Ray Leonard, the former Olympic champion, won every round and pounded out a unanimous decision over Willie (Fireball) Rodriguez in a sixround junior welterweight bout today.

title: Talk With Roger Angell
description: ROGER ANGELL does his daily work in a corner office of The New Yorker, where if the magazine had titles (which it does not) he would be listed as the senior fiction editor. At first glance the office suggests the quarters of a serious literary personagethe manuscript boxes, the framed photographs of authors (V. S. Pritchett, Frank Sullivan and E. B. White, who is Angell's stepfather); a decorous vacation pursuit is suggested by a photograph of the editor's sailboat running before the wind across a Maine harbor. But there are indications of another intereston the wall a little Steinberg drawing of a pitcher, a photograph of Jim Palmer, the Baltimore ace, pegged to a cork bulletin board, along with a baseball card showing the likeness of Art Nehf, an oldtime Giant pitcher. There is a row of baseball reference books, and on a bookshelf sits a lone baseball  not autographed, as one might expect, or even, as it turns out, a memento from a game. It is just an ordinary baseballperhaps there for contemplation or for picking up on occasion to feel its splendid texture.

title: Study Says Hunger Is Crowing Problem Across the South of Asia
description: MANILA, May 14Maria Salcedo, pale and wiry at 48, strolled listlessly around the parched vegetable plot in the town of Novaliches, an hour's drive from here. She and her children cultivate the halfacre less for the meager crop it yields than to protect their right to stay.

title: Dard of Thanks
description: MILLERThe family of the late Linda Miller gratefully acknowledges your kind expressions of sympathy.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: THERE is to my sense no work of literary, or of any other, art, that any human being is under the smallest positive obligation to like,  wrote Henry James in The Future of the Novel. There is no womanno matter of what lovelinessin the presence of whom it is anything but a man's unchallengeably own affair that he is in love or out of it. It is not a question of manners; vast is the margin ieft to individual freedom.... The power of the novel as a literary form, he continues, comes from its recognition and response to this truthits infinite variety. The novel can never be at the end of its tether until it loses the sense of what it can do.

title: Banks Tighten Credit Ratings To Identify Overseas Risks
description: BOSTONJames P. Thornblade, an economist at the First National Bank of Boston, occasionally undertakes a mission that has become increasingly common for intenational bankers: a country risk evaluation trip.

description: TodayWindham County K.C. 33d show and obedience trial, Recreation Park, Junction Route 6 and 14, Willimantic, Conn.; 1,802 dogs: to 7 P.M.

description: A good longshot bet to win the Indianapolis 500 on May 29? How about Duane (Pancho) Carter Jr. in the new and radical Jorgensen Eagle built by the Dan Gurney team? Carter is one of the young lions of the United States

title: THE WHITE HOUSE PRESS CLUB
description: 11 A.M. Photo Opportunity of the White House Tree House. 10:55 pickup at the West Wing Press Room. Notice on the White House press room bulletin board, April 12, 1977.

title: A Model Ship Builder
description: SHIPPING buffs take their avocation seriously, and probably none more so than Frank P. Eldridge, who is one of the country's foremost amateur builders of ship models.

title: Connecticut /This Week
description: HARTFORDConnecticut Academy of Fine Arts, exhibition of sculpture, graphics, painting. Through June 26 at Wadsworth Atheneum. Information 2782670.

title: PREMINGER
description: HOLLYWOOD in the 1940's was an exercise in the concentration of power. The moguls made the movies. They chose the story ideas (often remakes of past successes), hired the screen writers (identified as the present writer, to distinguish him from all those who follow him), cast contract players or bartered for stars on loanout from other studios and anointed favorite house directors. Actors, writers and directors ricocheted from one film to another. The right of final cut belonged to the head of production, and art was accidental.

title: HELLO, DOGGY!
description: The dressing room was disappointingly typical: the naked lights around the mirrors, the openingnight telegrams beginning to curl at the edges, the discarded gift wrappings thrown carelessly on the dressing table, and that obligatory concommitant of the starmaker machinery, pills. Big pills, in a plastic bottle. They were Pet Tabs. Underneath the makeup lights, a Hartz jumbo dog dish, orange, Sandy rose from a prone position in the center of the room, sniffed the air, and then sat down and extended a paw. He is suspicious of groupies. Arf, went Sandy, as one always knew he would. His foot pads were inky. He had recently been giving autographs.

title: Questions Remain In Apparent Suicide OF Virginia Woman
description: MANASSAS, Va., May 14The apparent suicide of a socially prominent woman who was the estranged wife of one of the country's leading corporate entrepreneurs, Thomas Mellon Evans, has diStUrbed the calm of Virginia's hunt country, just west of the nation's capital.

title: Beame Unit Opposed on Proposal To Alter Bargaining Procedures
description: The Board of Collective Bargaining, in an outspoken report yesterday, criticized proposals of Mayor Beame's advisory panel on personnel for revamping the city's collectivebargaining agencies and procedures.

title: AWOL Soldier Becomes Focus Of Controversy over Unionizing
description: A 19yearold AWOL soldier, who said he had abandoned his Army unit in Germany because he had been denied adequate medical attention and had been shunted into an inappropriate duty assignment, has turned himself in at Fort Dix, N.J. He acted with the aid of an organization that believes his problems are representative of thousands who would benefit from unionization of the armed forces.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: MY friend Iry phoned the other day to tell me that he was running for Governor. Of what? I asked. Our state, said Irv. Our state, I replied, is constant depression. Ha, ha, said Irv. Funny. I mean New Jersey.

title: $40 Million For a Real Smoke
description: For almost four years fewer than 50 persons within the organization were in on the project codenamed RL. Documents referring to RL were stamped SECRET or EYES ONLY, and were distributed on a needtoknow basis.

title: Bert B. Don Is Victor
description: BOSTON, May 14 (AP)Monarch Stable's Bert B. Don led all the way today in winning the featured $6,000 allowance race before a crowd of 9,820 at Suffolk Downs. Ridden by Timothy Haire, Bert B. Don covered one mile and 70 yards in 1:41 , hitting the finish 4 lengths ahead of Demon Flight. Fast Smile was third.

title: Banker's Books Pay Off
description: ASHORT letter about clams in an Illinois river, scrawled in 1908 by a 9yearold boy who spelled his topic dames, sold for A series of 30 letters to his parents, written during 192028 by that same boy, who had moved from clamming to journalism and novels, sold for $65,000.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Now he's Hollywood Joe instead of Broadway Joe, but Joe Namath never needed a nickname. All he's ever needed was a challenge. That's when he was at his best with the New York Jets before the team disintegrated around him. Now he has a new challenge  leading the Los Angeles Rams to victory in Super Bowl XII at the Superdome next season. Qualifying for it won't be enough. Qualifying for the playsoffs won't be enough. Joe Namath has to lead the Rams to the Super Bowl championship or he will be considered a flop. But he's been challenged before.

title: LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: It is a pleasure to be receiving Connecticut Weekly in the state's northwest corner, and I don't want to appear ungrateful by nitpicking. However, in Walter D. Wetherell's interesting article on Hitting the Appalachian Trail [April 3], the elevations are slightly mixed.

title: MARIJUANA SMOKERS HOLD VILLAGE RALLY
description: There was something in the air besides springtime yesterday as several thousand marijuana enthusiasts and the merely curious gathered for a peaceful smokein in Washington Square Park.

title: Keeping Up With Father Knows Best
description: They were the family we wanted to be part of, if only we could have somehow stuffed ourselves into the 12inch television screen.

title: STERN PLAN TO GUARD PRIVACY IS EXPECTED
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The Privacy Protection Study Commission, in a final report to be released early next month, is expected to recommend severe restrictions on the Government's right to confidential information about an individual without that individual being's informed.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE younger kids are moving about the neighborhood on weekend mornings, wearing baseball caps and toting bats bigger than they are, with enormous gloves dangling from the bats. You don't see them lolling about anymore. When they are in the vicinity, they peg balls at one another and speak earnestly about what positions they play, and they gabble about standings.

title: JOHN C. COUNCIL
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 14 (AP)John C. Council, fomer publisher and chairman of the editorial board of The Tampa Tribune and The Tampa Times, was found drowned in a canal near his home today. A Tampa police official said that Mr. Council, who was 74 years old and nearly blind, apparently wandered into his backyard, stumbled into the canal and drowned accidentally.

title: ART
description: GARDEN CITY WILLIAM BLAKE, whose books and illustrations are the subject of an exhibition at Ade1phi University's Swirbul Library Gallery, is somewhat of a cult figure among our contemporaries. We have particularly appreciated his mystical visions and lyrical imagination, viewing them as celebrations of poetic license, freedom of thought and the beauties of ideas emanating from the inner recesses of the mind. His work was indeed a visual and literary anticipation of much that was to come in our

title: CENTURY'SWORST SHORTAGE OF WATER FEARED IN WEST
description: WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)The parched Western states will probably suffer the most severe summer water shortage so far in this century, the Agriculture Department said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times last Sunday incorrectly identified a Bronx community board that managed to reopen three libraries with leftover budget funds. The board is No. 11, in the Pelham Parkway, Allerton Avenue and Morrison Park communities. Its vice chairman is Ruth Bernstein.

title: Cynthia J. Plaisted Bride of Steven Potter
description: The Center Church OntheGreen (Congregational) in New Haven was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Cynthia Jane Plaisted, daughter of Mr and Mrs. William Eugene Plaisted of Whittier, Calif., to Steven Brandreth Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Winslow Potter of Woodbury, Conn.

description: Included in all copies distributed in New York City and the suburban area.

description: To the Editor:

title: Untermeyer Remembers
description: BEGIN at the beginning, says Louis Untermeyer, the 91yearold poet, anthologist, humorist and writer of light verse. He is in his favorite armchair in the living room of his house on Great Hill Road in Newtown, and he anticipates the interviewer's questions.

description: ?usan Bernhard and Donald Collins, graduates of Boston University, were married in Rye, N.Y., yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop, minister of the Presbyterian Church there, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. David B. Magee.

title: SMALLPDX EPIDEMIC REPORTED IN SOMALIA
description: The World Health Organization's pro gram to wipe out smallpox around the world has been seriously hampered by an explosive epidemic of the viral disease in the East Africa country of Somalia in recent weeks.

title: Linda Rachel Fieldman Bride of David Robbins
description: Linda Rachel Fieldman, daughter of Harriet Levine Fieldman of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., was married last evening to David Edward Robbins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Robbins of Westbury, L.I. Rabbi David Arzt performed the ceremony at Shaarei ShalomSouth Baldwin Jewish Center.

title: JOHN B. BIDDLE
description: HUNTINGTON, Pa., May 14 (UPI)John B. Biddle, publisher of The Huntingdon Daily News and president of Huntingdon Broadcasters Inc., died today after a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: $1.2 Million From Estate Gives Area Residents Food for Dreams
description: BOSTON TOWNSHIP, Ohio, May 14 It's been a month of Sundays or more, as people here might say, since there was any interest in improving the old town hall in this community of 1,500 in southeastern Ohio. But in recent weeks there has been talk about building a new one altogether.

title: Bar Chief Backs Prepaid Legal Help
description: PREPAID legal services, as proposed in a bill introduced in the Legislature, have the unqualified endorsement of the New Jersey Bar Association, Donald R. Conway, president of the organization, indicated in an interview in his Hackensack offices.

title: Leonard P. Kline Jr. To Wed Diana Shand
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Gray of Baltimore have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gray's daughter, Diana Jackson Shand, to Leonard Patton Kline Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kline of New York and Kansas City. The wedding is planned for July 30.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: WHEN our house was. being built in Chatham Township, friends would ask, Is part of a development? The yes practically choked me. Nobody likes to feel that he lives in an assemblyline dwelling stamped out of pattern like your kids sneakers.

title: GARDENING
description: TARDY gardeners who have not yet planted vegetable gardensthis week is the deadline for cabbage, broccoli plants, onion and lettucemight turn their tardiness to advantage by being adventurous and trying plant companioning. The theory is that some vegetables grow better when planted next to each other. This sort of horticulture is not new, and those who are convinced follow it faithfully every year.

title: Fordharn Hall to Induct Andrejco, Cheverko
description: Joe Andrejco and George Cheverko, the touchdown twins of Fordham football in the 1940's, will he among 18 persons inducted into Fordham University's Hall of Fame tonight.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: M EET me at the Katonah diner at 8 o'clock, Ed Giobbi instructed. Eli and I have coffee there after I jog. I skidded up to the diner just as Edward Giobbi, painter, sculptor, builder, landscape artist and chef, was finishing his threemile trek at the start of one of his normal days.

title: LessDeveloped Country Loans Pose Questions For Regulators
description: American banks have been lending huge sums of money abroad to satisfy the credit demands of underdeveloped countries, but now the pressures are mounting to force a slowdown in an effort to insure against a crisis in the world banking system.

title: Corporate America Giving More to the Arts
description: Corporate America reached into its wallet last year and presented the arts in this country with the biggest cash present yet.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: BOSTON Of all the American choreographers, for some strange reason, Agnes de Mille is the most difficult to assess. In the first place she is one of the few senior classical American choreographers of stature to be Americanborn. Balanchine and Tudor had their roots in Europe, and choreographers such as Eugene Loring have produced too little to be regarded as significant. Choreographers of promiseone thinks of Michael Kidd's brief excursion with On Stagewere diverted to Broadway, and certain younger choreographers such as Eliot Feld and Gerald Arpino, have made their contributions only in recent years. No, of all the true redwhiteandblue American choreographers, there are only two in captivityJerome Robbins and Agnes de Mille.

title: Back Bay Update
description: This week, after two decades in eclipse, a distinguished 1871 Back Bay mansion, the Endicott House, will be reintroduced to society, in particular to the Victorian Society in America, convening in Boston. The cognoscenti will talk of Snell & Gregerson, architects, whose meticulous detailing and opulent attitude toward space characterize this peerless house.

title: Record Prices at Auction
description: Athletes and auctioneers are fanatical about records and announce each new one enthusiastically. Following are some of the standing records covering everything from the corkscrew (Christie's recently eclipsed Sotheby's $368 record on that] to Old Master paintings.

title: Jersey City Policeman Convicted Of Stealing Army Reserve Boat
description: NEWARK, May 13(AP)A former Jersey City policeman has been convicted of stealing a 62foot boat from the United States Army Reserve center in Jersey City and selling it for $7,000.

title: LIBBIE RICE
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 14 (AP)The state's first woman boxing and wrestling inspector, 21yearold Libbie Rice, died yesterday in a fire in her north Austin apartment. Miss Rice was a secretary for the State Board of Labor and Standards and a parttime inspector for the board's wrestling and boxing division. Her job was to certify that all participants were properly licensed and to doublecheck gate receipts.

title: Visiting Washington?
description: A Hotel Suite for the Price of a Single Room!

title: Out of Essex On Old 97
description: WITH A PUFF of white smoke, two short whistle blasts and a rousing all aboard, Old 97, a 53yearold locomotive, is again chugging out Essex for the run up the west bank of Connecticut River on one of the state's most notable excursion trips.

title: Mets Given a PepTalk By Owners, Then Lose, 54
description: The chief owners of the New York IN/lets addressed the team in an extraordinary lockerroom meeting yesterday to reaffirm their confidence in both the bosses and players, and to denounce all the rumors of owner dissension.

The last two should be startecLindoors in containers, but potted plants of both are usually available in New Jersey plant centers (although they may not be color labeled).

title: Music: Boulez as Modern as Ever
description: It was appropriate that Pierre Boulez's nexttolast concert as music director of the New York Philhamronic should be a Prospective Encounter. The series of programs of this kind were started by him as a way of bringing new music and sympathetic audiences together. The settings were largely in the Greenwich Village area; informality in dress was the rule for performers as well as audience; composers talked about their music.

title: G.E, WARNS OF HALT IN MAKING REACTORS
description: WASHINGTON, May 14The General Electric Company has told the Federal Government that if legal and policy restrictions on nuclear technology continue it will eventually stop manufacturing nuclear reactors.

title: Mets to Recall Series Gems
description: The Mets will stage their 16th annual OldTimers Day program at Shea Stadium on Saturday, July 16, with Memorable Moments of World Series History as the theme. Ceremonies and a short game will precede a regularly schedule contest between the Mets and Pittsburgh Pirates. The ceremonies are scheduled to begin at 2:45 P.M.

title: Opportunity Knocks for the Trail Blazers
description: PORTLAND, Ore., May 14'We have an opportunistic team, said Coach Jack Ramsay in listing the assets of the Portland Trail Blazers after they qualified for the National Basketball Association playoff final by eliminating the Los Angeles Lakers last night.

description: Just when the thought is circulating that after more than a century of horse shows in the United States there could be nothing new, there is indeed a new idea.

title: The LowKey World of Sunapee
description: A century ago the arrival of warm weather in the Northeast set an affluent breed of city folk in Boston and New York to packing huge trunks and traveling by train to New Hampshire for the summer. They would check into one or another big resort hotel, sign up for the meal plan and stay put until fall.

title: Ossining's New Route to a Diploma
description: A30yearold Westchester County man, whose job teaching and giving emergency medical care requires a minimum of some college training, talked nervously this month about the fear of losing his job and the shame he would feel if someone were to find out that he had never graduated from high school.

title: Carey Urges Bill To Aid Localities On interest Rates
description: ALBANY, May 14Governor Carey has proposed legislation to enable local governments to take advantage of the currently relatively low interest rates by refunding bond issues that were sold at higher prevailing rates during the last seven years.

description: Robin Winthrop Crawford of Washington was married yesterday afternoon to Paul Louis Perito, senior partner in the Washington law firm of Perito, Duerk & Carlson.
