title: Of Style and Substance
description: WASHINGTONThe most revealing document being circulated around Washington today is the Initial Working Paper on Political Strategy written at Mr. Carter's request last December by pollster Patrick H. Caddell.

title: 5 Nations Vow Continued Support For Central Treaty Organization
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 15 (UPI)The United States, Britain, Iran, Pakistan and Turkey today pledged continued support for the Central Treaty Organization and the security of an area stretching from the eastern Mediterranean to the Arabian Sea.

title: Referendum Plan One of Bhutto's Biggest Gambles
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, May 15With his dramatic offer to test his personal popularity in a national rferendum, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto seems to be making one of the biggest gambles of his long political career.

title: New York to Study '79 Arts Fete
description: The Norlin Foundation has granted New York City $25,000 to study whether the city could sponsor a proposed International Festival of the Arts in 1979, according, to Martin E. Segal, chairman of the Commission for Cultural Affairs. He said the study would be completed in six to nine months. The festival was proposed by the Norlin Foundation. The foundation was established in 1975 by the Norlin Corporation, an international musical instrument company, based in New York.

title: DISSIDENT CZECH WRITER LOSES HIS HOME IN PRAGUE
description: VIENNA, May 11Pavel Kohout, the Czech playwright and human rights advocate, has lost a fourmonth battle to hold on to his home in Prague. With his wife, Jelenaa, he has moved to a village, Sazava. 80 miles southeast of the capital.

title: Aqueduct Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: SST Demonstrators Tie Up Roads AtKennedy Airport at Peak Period
description: Hundreds of slowmoving cars protesting the proposed landings of the British and French Concorde jetliner stopped traffic on the main circle road at Kennedy International Airport for two miles starting about 6 o'clock last night.

title: Soviet Union Silent On Chance of Gains In New Arms Talks
description: MOSCOW, May 15On the eve of the SovietAmerican talks scheduled this week in Geneva, the Soviet Union is maintaining its low profile on prospects for progress toward a new agreement limiting strategic nuclear weapons.

title: Kathryn Rose Pasmantier Wed to Gordon C. Oliver
description: The marriage of Kathryn Rose Pasmantier to Gordon Colin Oliver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin Alister Oliver of Newport, Wales, took place yesterday in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Alfred Landesberg performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Pasmantier.

title: Nearby Yachting Results
description: AT PELHAM MANOR, N.Y.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)  Although the United States is the largest contributor to the United Nations and its affiliated organizations, 13 percent of their professional employees are Americans, Congressional reports said today.

title: Ninth Ave. Fizzes With Sausages, Tacos, Rock Music and Bicarbonate
description: Two men standing in line for a hot sausage sandwich yesterday at the International Food Festival on 9th Avenue finally got to the head of the line, still in good spirits. One of them, Frank, turned to the others in line and said in the conversational tones of a carney barker: My friend here has an ulcer. Ladies and gentlemen, you are looking at a man who is flirting with death.

title: Results of Eastern Rowing
description: AT PRINCETON, N.J. EASTERN SPRINTS

title: Next President of U.A.W. Plans to Alter Its Politics
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15This Wednesday, barring accident or miracle, the United Automobile Workers, a major liberal force in American labor and politics for a generation, will elect Douglas A. Fraser as its new president.

title: Chess:
description: The most onesided of the quarterfinal candidates matchesthe first stage of the elimination series to select a challenger for the world champion, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Unionwas the victory of Lajos Portisch of Hungary over Bent Larsen of Denmark. Portisch won five games, while Larsen won two, with three games resulting in draws.

title: Jersey Nuclear Plant to Start Operations in 3 Weeks
description: HANCOCK'S BRIDGE, N.J., May 15On a sandy spit of land called Artificial Island that elbows into the Delaware River just west of here, the first unit of one of the world's largest nuclear generating plants will go into operation in about three weeks.

title: Florida Obtains Delay in Sale Of 5 JaiAlai Frontons to Bally
description: MIAMI, May 15 (AP)Florida officials have obtained a courtordered delay in the proposed sale of five jaialai frontons to a slotmachine manufacturer.

title: Foreigners in Moscow Upset by Big Rent Increases
description: MOSCOW, May 15Like a rich landlord who owns all the apartments in town, the Soviet Government has suddenly demanded huge rent increases from foreign residents, some up to 125 percent, and has told a complaining tenant, We dictate the prices, not you.

title: Missouri Investors Face Coop Losses
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 15 (UPI)Missouri investors may lose millions of dollars in the wake of the sudden collapse of the Progressive Farmers Association, a farm cooperative linked by Federal and state investigators to fraudulent coops in 10 other states in the South and Middle West.

title: HERBERT WILCOX, 85 FILM DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Herbert Wilcox, the film director and producer who was at times England's most successful film producer, died yesterday in his London home after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: Publicity Drive Is Urged for Schools
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., May 15A campaign to give New York City's school system a better public image received a mixed reception from the system's supervisors and administrators attending their 14th annual union convention here this weekend.

title: Brewster Is Nostalgic As He Leaves Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, May 15After leading Yale through 14 tumultuous years, Kingman Brewster Jr. today ended his presidency of the university.

title: Golf
description: AT FORT WORTH

title: Gimmicks Mar Bronx Opera's Fra Diavolo
description: The Bronx Opera has brought so many fine productions to Hunter College in Manhattan over the last several years that perhaps one can forgive the company for doing less than justice to Daniel Francois Auber's Fra Diavolo at the Hunter Playhouse last weekend.

title: Coping With the Invisible Immigrants
description: Illegal alien: The words bring to mind a lonely wader in the Rio Grande, night flight from the sirens of the border patrol, stoop work in the lettuce fields. But reality has outdistanced the image. Ten percent of the population of Mexico is now in the United States unlawfully. Illegal aliens also fly from South America and the Caribbean to metropolitan airports. Pakistanis with Commonwealth passports arrive by ferry in Detroit. In New York City there may be as many as 350,000 illicit entrants from the Dominican Republic alone. The statistics are necessarily sketchy, but estimates of the total run from six to ten million, somewhere near the number of Americans unemployed  though unemployment would not vanish if the illegals all went home. Most of these immigrants work for substandard wages at jobs American workers usually disdain, but more than a million work at semiskilled pay levels.

title: Polish Church Is Consecrated, Ending Battle
description: NOWA HUTA, Poland, May 15 (Reuters)Tens of thousands of Roman Catholics stood in the rain as the first church in this postwar industrial town was consecrated today, 17 years after clashes over lack of religious facilities.

title: Robert M. Hutchins, Long a Leader In Educational Change, Dies at 78
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., May 15Robert Maynard Hutchins, founder and president of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions, died last night at Cottage Hospital. He was 78 years old. He underwent surgery in March for treatment of a kidney ailment.

title: James Jones Hailed by Friends At a Memorial Service on L.I.
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., May 15The novelist James Jones was recalled here today as a writer in the American grain who knew his worth better than his critics did and as a tender and complicated human being beneath a rough exterior.

title: Law Graduates From Harvard Prospered More 50 Years Ago
description: Are Harvardtrained lawyers doing better today than their counterparts of 50 years ago? Probably not.

title: Israel's Labor Party Facing a Tough Test In Voting Tomorrow
description: JERUSALEM, May 15The governing Labor Party, Israel's major political entity since the country was founded and one beset in recent months by scandals, suicide and internecine battles, faces its toughest election test on Tuesday.

title: NIXON DEFENDS CAMPAIGN AGAINST WAR DISSENTERS
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, in his third television interview with David Frost, contends that his campaign against dissent, including the creation of enemies lists and the White House plumbers unit, was necessary to strengthen his diplomatic hand in the Vietnam war, Newsweek magazine reported yesterday.

title: Nearby Horse Shows
description: AT FARMINGTON, CONN. CHILDREN'S SERVICES

title: FOOD EXPERTS ASSERT WHEAT SUPPLIES END FAMINE FEAR FOR NOW
description: WASHINGTON, May 15For the first time in five years, the world is entering its primary growing season without fear that crop failures may generate a food crisis for any broad section of the globe.

title: Two Stars Bait a Better Mouse trap
description: David London, who is in the painting and contracting business, wasn't intimidated by all those swells in black tie. He stood on the sidewalk in front of the Broadway Theater, dressed in jeans and a sweat shirt, and hollered out desperately.

title: Evans, Miss Campbell Win U.S. Kayak Slalom Titles
description: JAMAICA, Vt., May 15Eric Evans, a 27yearold competitor from Fountain View, Calif., won the national kayak slalom title today for the eighth year in a row. He ran the 30gate, quartermile whitewater course on the West River twice without touching a gatepole. Jean Campbell, of Norwich, Vt., the favorite in her class won the national women's kayak title with one clean run of four during the twoday United States Whitewater Slalom Championships and team trials for kayaks and covered canoes.

title: Coffee Concert Draws Crowds To Its New Home at the Beacon
description: The Coffee Concerts moved from Tully Hall to a new home Saturday, the Beacon Theater on upper Broadway, and a large crowd of lateafternoon concertgoers turned out for the event. Keeping its informal tone and format intact, the program consisted of about an hour's worth of chamber music, followed by coffee, doughnuts and a chat with the artists in the lobby.

title: Josephine A. Lynch Wed to Todd Slotkin
description: Josephine Ann Lynch daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Joseph Lynch of Andover, N.Y., was married yesterday to Todd James Slotkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Slotkin of Holly, Mich., and Palm Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed in the Old President's House on the campus of Cornell University by Rabbi R. C. Hertz of Temple Beth El in Birmingham, Mich.

title: Beaten Soldier Dies in Oklahoma After Life Support Is Turned Off
description: LAWTON, Okla., May 15 (AP)A Fort Sill soldier died at an Oklahoma City hospital after his life support machine was disconnected, the authorities announced yesterday.

title: DRUG CENTER'S CAMP STIRS NEIGHBORS' IRE
description: PATERSON, May 13Damon House, a residential drug rehabilitation center founded here in 1970, with a second facility in New Brunswick that opened five years later, is like most organizations of its kind. It is constantly in need of almost everything: more money, more staff, more jobs, but, perhaps most of all, more community acceptance, especially outside of its immediate precincts.

title: OPTIMISM PREVAILS IN CREDIT MARKETS DESPITE FED POLICY
description: The Federal Reserve has been tightening the credit reins, and major banks last Friday raised their prime rates for the first time in almost a year, yet the credit markets are surprisingly optimistic about the outlook for the next several months.

title: HART, SUPPORTING CARTER, DISAGREES WITH M'GOVERN
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP)Senator Gary Hart, who managed Senator George McGovern's 1972 Presidential campaign, said today that he did not agree with Mr. McGovern's criticism of President Carter.

title: Ali, Foe Look Soft for Title Bout
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 15Muhammad Ali will return to the ring tomorrow night at about the sane weight he left it almost eight months ago, but he will be eight important months older.

title: Five Aboard Helicopter Are Killed In Crash With Plane at Air Show
description: BIGGIN HILL, England, May 15 (AP)As thousands of spectators watched, a ??iplane collided with a helicopter carrying sightseers at an air show today, killing the five persons aboard the helicopter, local authorities said.

title: White House Studies Curb on Profits to ExOfficials
description: WASHINGTON, May 15White Heous officials have discussed the possibility of finding ways to discourage profitable book contracts for departing Administration officials, including a requirement that all royalties for a period of years go to the Government rather than the author.

title: PYOTR V. DEMENTYEV DIES; LED SOVIET AIR INDUSTRY
description: MOSCOW, May 15 (UPI)Pyotr V. Dementyev, the Aviation Industry Minister, who is credited with leading the Soviet Union into the age of jet and supersonis aircraft, died yesterday at the age of 70, national television and the Tass press agency said today.

title: Rutgers Takes Met. Track Title
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 15Give a group of good track and field athletes the proper conditions and chances are they will produce exciting results.

title: Ali's Scouting Report on Rocky
description: LANDOVER, Md., May 15About half an hour before today's weighin, Alfredo Evangelista, husky and with a heavy chin that will tempt Muhammad Ali's patience, moved through the boxing types that had gathered in the otherwise empty Capital Centre for the noon ritual. That him, somebody said, that's the fighter. Nearby a lady stared in disbelief. That's the fighter? she said. I thought that was a rock star, I thought he was looking for his guitar. Sometime tomorrow night Alfredo Evangelista is expected to he looking for his equilibrium. Alfredo Evangelista is what is known in boxing as an opponent, meaning a poor soul who has virtually no chance to win, a Rocky in real life. Imported from Spain despite having been outpointed by Lorenzo Zanon of Italy in his last bout, Alfredo Evangelista is also an offering, meaning the 22yearold lamb who will be sacrificed so that Muhammad Ali and the promoter, Don King, and the ABC television network, can provide primetime violence for perhaps 40 million viewers. Don't blame Ali; he fights everybody, he's entitled to a tuneup. Don't blame the promoters; they simply put the show together. If anybody is to blame, it's those, perhaps including yourself, who turn on your TV sets. What you see is what you deserve.

title: A Real Dream Job: Starring in Show While Fast Asleep
description: The hours are terrible but the money's good, considering the nature of the work: to sleep, perchance to dream.

title: U.S. Officials Hopeful on Mideast, But Their Optimism Is Guarded
description: WASHINGTON, May 15The Carter Administration, after three months of exploring the prospects for a Middle East peace settlement, has detected enough favorable signs to keep its diplomatic efforts alive but not enough to warrant much optimism yet that a solution to the Arab  Israeli dispute can be easily achieved.

title: SOVIET SAID TO PROPOSE AFRICAN CONFEDERATION
description: BEIRUT, May 15 (Reuters)The Soviet Union has pledged military and economic backing for a proposed confederation of states and territories in the strategic horn of Africa, according to an Arabiclanguage news magazine received here today.

title: Georgian Dancers of Israel in Lively Debut
description: The Georgian Dancers of Israel, a company of migrs from Soviet Georgia that gave its first performance in 1973, made its local debut Saturday night at the Felt Forum.

title: TV: Alexander, Effective Story of Male Hustler
description: Like love and marriage in any compendium of popular clichs, sex and violence seem to have settled into a state of eternal coupling, especially in discussions about television. Although violence has been exploited shamelessly, sex has been a relatively scarce commodity in the medium. But now that violent programming is being widely criticized, most significantly by advertisers, there are signs that sex is being prepared for the big sell, wrapped in promises of adult candor and mature content.

title: Dissident Stockholders Begin to Get Somewhere at Last
description: For two decades church and social service groups, seriousminded advocates of reform, and gadflies who rush from meeting to meeting have sought a greater role in shaping corporate standards and policy.

title: Oakland Newspaper Is Sold by Knowland For $15.8 Million
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 15 (UPI)The Oakland Tribune, a 103yearold newspaper operated by the Knowland family since 1915, is being sold to Combined Communications Corporation, an Arizonabased conglomerate, for $15.8 million in stock and cash.

title: Jane Blalock Rallies to Victory
description: BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP)Jane Blalock overtook Sylvia Bertolaccini with a fiveunder par 68 today and scored a threestroke victory in the Greater Baltimore Classic, a Ladies Professional Golf Association event.

title: Two Antarctic Vignettes
description: Scene One: Argentine Islands Station, British Antarctic Survey, the Antarctic Peninsula.

title: Rockets Win By Erasing Deficit of 17
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 15  Julius Erving's firsthalf show fizzled to a nearstandstill in the second half today. The Philadelphia 76ers' inside game, one of their strengths, was almost nonexistent in the fourth quarter. The Houston Rockets' defense toughened, and the 76ers faded.

title: Commodities
description: An examination of the futures prices in the soybean complex finds beans, meal and oil all heading upward. The advance, which has upset spreads, reflects market factors such as the shortage of anchovies off Peru and lower peanut oil supplies here. Page 46.

title: School's Offer Rescues Library Devoted to Women's Rights
description: LONDONThe Fawcett Society, a women's rights organization that was born during Britain's suffrage battle of the late 19th century, has won another battle.

title: Books of the Times
description: It did not take long for the Myth of the English to be forged. As Samuel Hynes reminds us in The Auden Generation: Literature and Politics in England in the 1930's: Only months after the Nazi invasion of Poland, W.H. Auden in his poem September 1, 1939 referred to the period as a low dishonest decade.... The following spring Virginia Woolf dismissed the entire generation of writers as incapable of giving us great poems, great plays, great novels. By then the Myth had congealed, according to Professor Hynes, and could be summarized in the following set of propositions.

title: Crenshaw's Rally Takes Golf by Shot
description: FORT WORTH, May 15 (AP)Ben Crenshaw made up a fivestroke deficit in only six holes, swept past the leader, John Schroreder, with a 31 on the back nine and scored a onestroke victory today in the $200.000 Colonial National invitation golf tournament.

title: Foreign Investing Bolsters Industry in Northeast
description: Foreign investment, particularly by Canadian companies, has become an important source of new industry and jobs for parts of New York State, New Jersey and other declining areas of the Northeast.

title: 'Looking Up,' Sober Tale Of a Family's Ambitions
description: As the first feature-film producing effort of Linda Yellen and Karen Rosenberg, "Looking Up" bears a stamp of maturity not normally associated with a pair of 27-year-olds. Their dramatization of the relationships of members of a middle-class New York Jewish family leaves the nagging impression of a dizzying succession of people caught up in a variety of troubles. But, despite its disturbing realties, "Looking Up," which had its premiere yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater, projects its sincerity with heartfelt emotion and a seemingly autobiographical remembrance of things present and past.In essence, Jonathan Platnick's script focuses on three generations of the family, particularly on Rose Lander, her two sisters, their husbands, children and their grandparents. More directly, it concentrates on their anxiety-ridden, largely unsuccessful drives for the better (i.e. richer) life in such authentic surroundings as, say, Washington Heights or Forest Hills.Practically all of the clan is involved in a frantic dash for the golden end of the rainbow while planning a diamond anniversary party for the grandparents. Rose is desperately striving for the fast-food franchise that will free her husband, Manny, from his failing seltzer business as she worries about her daughters and grandchildren, copes with grandma's geriatric fantasies, constantly shops and works part time in an envious cousin's luncheonette.Her sister, Libby, is also defeated as her plans for her daughter's marriage to a rich suitor are shattered when her husband is indicted in a real estate flim-flam. It also happens that Rose's married daughter has turned into a pill-popping psychiatric case. And Rose also discovers that her husband had sired Libby's child."Looking Up," however, does live up to its title when the sisters join to face the future bravely as they gather at that party in one of those pseudo-elegant palaces where you can get a swan sculptured out of chicken liver with the hors d'oeuvres. "We'll do the best we can," says Becky the spinster sister, if we can just hold on."Despite the plot's soap-opera overtones, Miss Yellen, who directed with an eye for visual movement and character delineation, and the large castmostly drawn from local stage and television ranksmanage to avoid many of the sudsy banalities of the genre.Some of the roles are too broadly played, but quite a few of the principals score with natural portrayals. Marilyn Chris is a truly impressive and poignant figure as the undaunted Rose, either as a canny supermarket shopper or as the tigerish leader of her brood. Jacqueline Brookes is properly self-reliant as the realist Becky; Naomi Riseman is fine as the bumbling grandma, as are a serious Dick Shawn as Rose's inadequate, if devoted, husband and Doris Belack and Neva Small, as the beleaguered Libby and her problematic daughter.Many of the parts of "Looking Up" are greater than the whole, but its sobering, specialized drama rings as true as its real street scenes."Looking Up" received a PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") rating probably because of some explicit dialogue and a near-nude scene, neither of which should be especially traumatic for young viewers.

title: Law,FastestGrowing Profession, May Find Prosperity Precarious
description: In the last 10 years, the law has become the country's fastestgrowing profession, with many lawyers prospering as never before. Indeed, several thousand lawyers earn more than $100,000 a year.

title: Sally Victor, 83, a Hat Designer With Many Firsts in Fashions
description: Sally Victor, who once described her principal business objective as designing pretty hats that make women look prettier, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital after a short illness. She was 83 years old and lived at 35 East 75th Street.

title: Horton's 3 Homers Spark Rangers in a 73 Triumph
description: On April 12 the Detroit Tigers decided that there weren't many hits left in the bat of 33yearold Willie Horton, who had slugged 262 home runs for the Tigers since 1963, when he entered the major leagues. They traded him to the Texas Rangers for Steve Foucault, a relief pitcher. They may have been premature in deciding Horton was on the way down.

title: Advertising
description: A dozen executives of advertising agencies, questioned about the new network television season, didn't agree on everything. That would be asking too much. But they did agree that the violence issue is dead, that comedy the new wave, that ABC will remain dominant and that prices for commercial time are (a) outrageous, (b) out of sight and (c) unreal.

title: Great Depth Set the Canadiens Apart in Their Championship Season
description: BOSTON, May 15As parties of players vied in the Canadiens' dressing room last night to hold the champagnefilled Stanley Cup and quaff from the wide lip of the silver chalice, Murray Wilson commented on the rite of adoration.

title: Porsches Finish 1, 2, 3
description: SILVERSTONE, England, May 15 (AP)Jochen Mass of West Germany and Jacky Ickx of Belgium won the World Championship of MAKES sixhour endurance race today in a Porsche. John Fitzpatrick of Britain and his French teammate, Bob Wollek, finished second, also in a Porsche. Third was the Porsche of Rolf Stommelen of West Germany and Toine Hezemans of the Netherlands.

title: Carroll's AllStars Take Hurling. Lose in Football
description: Carroll's AllStars defeated Cork in hurling and lost to Dublin in Gaelic football yesterday before a crowd of about 8,000 at Gaelic Park in the Bronx.

title: Suit Sheds Some Light on Mystery of Vesco's Yacht
description: MIAMI, May 15Late in the afternoon of July 9, 1975, a 137foot luxury yacht hastily left her mooring in Dania north of here and sailed Into the Atlantic.

title: Greece Halts Night Flights
description: ATHENS, May 15 (Reuters)Greek civil aviation authorities decided today to suspend all night flights in and out of Athens and other airports during a strike by about 700 civilian employees, an airport spokesman said here. The spokesman said that starting tomorrow the international airports of Athens, Rhodes, Corfu and Salonika would be open only from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Fassbinder, in 'Jail Bait,' Explores Danger of Women Through Girl, 14
description: "Jail Bait" is the intentionally slangy English rendering of the original German title of Rainer Werner Fassbinder's 1972 German film, "Wildwechsel" (literally, "Wild Game"), a melodrama that mixes the tacky with the sublime in much the same way that its soundtrack switches back and forth between early 1960's-sounding pop records full of loudly proclaimed laments for that week's lost love, and the music of Beethoven."Jail Bait," which opened yesterday at the New Yorker as part of the theater's continuing Fassbinder festival, is Mr. Fassbinder's "La Peau Douce," a close-up examination of the sort of event that might make a two-or three-paragraph item in the local newspaper.In "La Peau Douce," Franois Truffaut found evidence of poetic misalliance in a banal murder story. Mr. Fassbinder finds fury in the shape of a mindless Erinyes who destroys because she's peeved. "Jail Bait" touches on a number of other things, but misogyny is the dominant theme. Beware, it says. The danger presented by women is not symbolicit's real, lethal and wanton and, in this case, it's named Hanni.Hanni (Eva Mattes) is an astonishingly well-developed 14-year-old, as full-breasted and round-hipped as a Rubens model with a fondness for ice cream and Cokes. She wears her hair in braids, frolics unselfconsciously with her truck-driver father and would appear to be the perfect child in a household where no room is without its crucifix or picture of Jesus, Mary or one of the saints.One day after school Hanni allows herself to be picked up by Franz (Harry Baer), the sort of 19-year-old who has been told too often that he looks like James Dean. Harry wears his well pomaded hair in an artfully teased pompadour, favors studded jeans and drives a motorcycle. That afternoon in a haybarn, Franz deflowers Hanni with a good deal less fuss than he'd anticipated. When he mentions this, she shrugs and points out that if it hadn't been him, it would have had to be someone else. "Why are you getting dressed?" he says. "Why not?" is the reply. "There's nothing else to do.""Jail Bait" is "The Blue Angel" without the hysterics of Jannings and the mystery of Dietrich. It's a tragedy for the soft-drink, fast-food, drive-in generationcryptic and almost as cold as Hanni, who, having once been responsible for Franz's being sent to jail (for impairing the morals of a minor), immediately takes up with him again on his release.Franz, of course, is no great brain, though he swaggers as he thinks a man should. As written, and as played (gently) by Mr. Baer he's no match for the rapacious Hanni. When she suggests that their only recourse is to murder her father, he finally agrees. He tells himselfperhaps vaguely remembering a movie he's seenthat "it's men's work."From this outline you might think that "Jail Bait" is less political than such other Fassbinder films as "Mother Kusters Goes to Heaven," "Fox," "The Bitter Tears of Petra Von Kant" and "Ali," but its quite as concerned as those films with the uses of power and the quality of life in bisected, postwar Germany.It's also obsessed with a particularly adolescent fantasy about the difference between men and women. At one point Hanni, a role played by Miss Mattes with staggering self-assurance, kids Franz about the possibility of her father's catching them and castrating the younger man. "Then," she says, "you'd be just like me."When Hanni's father first learns of his daughter's seduction, he cries out for the death penalty, which, Hanni's mother notes, has been abolished since the fall of the Nazis. "That," says the father, "was a regime. Now all we have is a government." He's the kind of fellow who says he doesn't believe in murdering Jews but adds. "Better to gas 100,000 Jews than to have a pig like that messing around with my daughter.""Jail Bait," though it is beautifully and, intelligently controlled, is not an easy film to like. It certainly doesn't lift the spirits in any conventional way. It does contain moments of real pathosunusual in a Fassbinder film  in those scenes involving Hanni's mother, a role acted with desperate sadness by Ruth Drexel. However, the film's fascination lies not in any particular character or event but in the meanness of the total drama that Mr. Fassbinder sets before us. It's as blunt and simply drawn as a cartoon. The times, he says, deserve no more.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Despite a cautionary report by an American Psychiatric Association task force almost two years ago, the psychohiktory industry is still alive and churning. Its newest product, Nixon vs. Nixon, by Dr. David Abrahamsen, a psychoanalyst, is the third such probing that the former President has endured, and coming up from other psychohistorians is, of course, Jimmy Carter.

title: FOOD EXPERTS ASSERT WHEAT SUPPLIES END FAMINE FEAR FOR NOW
description: WASHINGTON, May 15For the first time in five years, the world is entering its primary growing season without fear that crop failures may generate a food crisis for any broad section of the globe.

title: Cuban Emigres in New Orleans Picket a Liner Bound for Havana
description: NEW ORLEANS, May 15The Cubans walked peacefully and sadly under a bright sun today in Spanish Plaza, near the ship passenger terminalmen and women, young and old, scientists and philosophers, laborers and students.

title: Mondale and Young Meet in Lisbon on Africa Policies
description: LISBON, May 15Vice President Mon dale and Andrew Young, the United States representative at the United Nations, met here today to coordinate action on what their aides described as a very complicated set of diplomatic operations.

title: Teachers Fight Local Evaluations
description: HIGHTSTOWN, May 15 (UPI)The New Jersey Education Association is fighting a proposal by the Assembly Education Committee to create local boards with the power to discipline tenured teachers.

title: Colborn's Royal Effort Produces a NoHitter
description: KANSAS CITY, May 15 (AP)For a few fleeting seconds last night, after he entered the dressing room and before the writers and players mobbed him, Jim Colborn stood silently and stared at his right hand.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Brown Arrives in Brussels to Spur NATO Allies to Increase Spending
description: BRUSSELS, May 15Defense Secretary Harold Brown arrived tonight in Brussels where he and European defense ministers are to focus discussions this week on American efforts toward a sharp increase in military spending by the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Failure of MitchellLama Sales Threatens City's Debt Repayments,
description: A key element of New York City's plan to pay back $1 billion in shortterm debtsthe sale of MitchellLama housing mortgageshas run into difficulty, and not a single mortgage has been sold since Mayor Beame announced the debtrepayment Dian two months ago.

title: Israeli Diplomat Opposes Sending American Troops To Fight in the Mideast
description: Israel's chief representative in the United Nations said yesterday that the special relationship between his nation and the United States, reaffirmed last week by President Carter, should preclude any guarantees that would involve United States troops in fighting in the Middle East.

title: Raid in Japan Brings an End To Detergents
description: KAMISHIMA, Japan  Aroused fishermen have taken the naw into their hands and seized every box and bottle of synthetic detergent and most tubes of toothpaste and shampoo from every house on this offshore island in the Pacific. They believe that detergents pollute the sea and kill the fish and abalone from which they earn their livelihood.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Court's Trials and Tribulations
description: A vestpocket crime wave seems to have hit the Criminal Courts Building. Typewriters have been disappearing from the offices and a court officer had to be rushed to a hospital recently after he was struck on the head by an addict he found in a stairwell injecting heroin into his arm.

title: Rendezvous in Vienna
description: WASHINGTON  Wilter Mondale has confounded the cynics and taken on Zeal responsibility as Vice President but he has had no task remotely as important, or as daunting, as the one he will undertake in Vienna this Thursday. He meets Prime Minister Vorster of South Africa for a day of talks, perhaps two if things go well.

title: A Real Dream Job: Starring in Show While Fast Asleep
description: The hours are terrible but the money's good, considering the nature of the work: to sleep, perchance to dream.

title: Drive to Save Mrs. Roosevelt's ValKill Pressed
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.Eleanor Roosevelt, who added luster to the Roosevelt name as First Lady and later as delegate to the United Nations, is about to be celebrated again in her own right, thanks to the efforts of a lot of Republicans in this upstate town of 20,000 on the Hudson.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, May 15 (UPI)The police in big cities now use firearms with more restraint hut still need clear direclives to shoot only in selfdefense or in defense of others, the Police Foundation said today.

title: Twin Goals for Coal
description: Since 1972 the price of coal has gone from $7.66 a ton to $20, and if President Carter's energy plan goes into effect, the coal companies should do even better. So it appears gratuitousone might almost say shamelessfor the coal industry to renew its campaign against strip mine controls as environmental brinkmanship. Carl Bagge, president of the National Coal Association, goes so far as to predict a collision between the President's energy plan and his determination to protect the environment. Obviously any sound strip mine law will add to the cost of production. But the costs will almost surely be passed along to the customer, who should by rights be made aware of the environmental price of his energy consumption.

title: Nordiques Down Jets, 61
description: QUEBEC. May 15 (UPI)Steve Sutherland's two goals sparked the Quebec Nordiques to a 61 victory over the Winnipeg Jets tonight. The team's World Hockey Association playoff final is tied at one game each.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Commodities
description: Although soybeans are by far the most actively traded commodity and their prices affect every consumer, what traders are actually buying and selling are the meal and oil made from the bean.

title: Harvard Varsity Crew Captures Sprint Title With Penn Second
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 15Another winning streak began today for Harvard varsity crew.

title: New York Area Energy Use Dips
description: The average individual consumption of energy in the New YorkNew JerseyConnecticut region has declined by 4 percent since 1970, while consumption in the country as a whole has increased 1 percent.

title: Shoe Quota Accord Reached in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, May 15American and Taiwanese officials have reached a preliminary agreement on a plan to cut down Taiwanese exports of shoes to the United States.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SCREEN SUMMITS Many movie buffs consider Alec Guinness's deft portrayal of eight characters in the British comedy, Kind Hearts and Coronets (1949) one of the actor's film peaks. The colorful gallery  all eliminated by the inheritanceminded killerhero, Dennis Price ranges from a doddering admiral (canceled out by an exploding cake) to a Victorian suffragist whose balloon is furtively punctured by an arrow (and Lady Agatha went down in Berkley Square).

description: MONS, Belgium, May 13At the age of 26 the North Atiantic Alliance is once again studying ways to improve the readiness of its forces.

description: MIAMI, May 15 (UPI)Customs agents seized 30,000 pounds of coffee beans yesterday in a routine inspection of containerized cargo aboard the passenger ship Starward.

title: Miss Fisher Has Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Tracy Fisher, daughter of Mrs. Elizabeth Vernon Fisher of Lancaster, Pa., and J. Robert Fisher of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Alan Norman. He is the son of Mrs. Russell Ellis of Philadelphia and Arnold Norman of Yardley. Pa.

title: Editor of Principal Black Newspaper in South Africa Has Become Influential Critic of Apartheid System
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 15During the roundup of black leaders that accompavied the antiGovernment upheaval here last year, the addition of a new name to the list rarely attracted much attention. But when the police briefly seized Percy Qoboza, editor of The World, the country's principal black newspaper, it made frontpage newsin some cases headlinesacross the nation.

title: Around the Nation
description: BALTIMORE, May 15 (UPI)At least three persons died and 30 were injured today when a fire raged out of control for four hours in a fourstory downtown hotel occupied by transients and elderly persons.

title: 5Hitter Paces Angels Ailing Munson Is Out
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., May 15Frank Tanana's fivehit pitching and some opportune Angel hits were too much for the Yankees today as they lost to the California Angels, 82.

title: Barbara Rosenthal Is Bride
description: Barbara Rosenthal, a producer for NVNBCTV's NewsCenter 4, was married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations to Milton E. Haynes, a reporter for The Associated Press. The Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, the chaplain, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rosenthal of South Orange, N.J. Her husband, son of Sara Haynes of Oroville, Calif., and the late Thaddeus Haynes, is coauthor with Representative Herman Badillo of A Bill of No Rights: Attica and the American Prison System.

title: News Summary
description: MONDAY, MAY 16, 1977

title: Yonkers
description: ENTRIES

title: Lily von Ballmoos Excels at Piano
description: Sometimes  not very often, but sometimesmusical events that don't seem to promise much end up delivering a good deal, after all. Take the piano recital scheduled for 5:45 P.M. Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall by somebody named Lily von Ballmoos. Miss Ballmoos's flyer arrived with absolutely no information as to who she was, and 5:45 is hardly the most auspicious of hours.

title: Creamer/FSR Gets Stouffer's Food Line
description: Creamer/FSR has picked up the advertising assignment for all of Stouffer's food products. Donald E. Creamer, chairman of the agency, says the billings are over $7 million a year, the largest account he has ever helped to land. A fitting way to mark his 10th anniversary as head of the Company.

title: Rock: Mink De Ville at CBGB
description: CBGB's used to be a place where young New York rock bands played. It's still that, but now it's also where bands that have record contracts want to showcase themselves for special engagements. Mink DeVille, with its first album just out on Capitol, is a case in point. The band comes from New York and has been together a couple of years, but its run last weekend at the Bowery club, was almost like a formal debut.

title: Dance: Singular Merrill Ashley
description: Question: What is a cult ballerina? Answer: Well, the answer is more difficult than the question, as answers so often are. However, let us say that it is a ballerina, or senior dancer, whose reputation with the ballet fans, and probably his or her professional colleagues, stands higher than it does with the general public. The very appearance of a cult dancer in a leading role, particularly in a debut, brings out a special audience of balletomanes, and the dancer receives a singular kind of ovation.

title: Track and Field
description: AT WHITE PLAINS MET. INTERCOLLEGIATE TRACK EVENTS

description: WASHINGTON, May 15Is President Carter trying to stick a countercyclical camel's nose into the Social Security tent?

description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: School Integration in Chicago, Delayed for More Than a Decade, May Soon Become Issue Before the Courts
description: CHICAGO, May 15More than a decade ago, when Chicago's schools were predominantly white, the city and its Board of Education began a long process of delay in integrating the schools, and the process has continued to this day.

description: EHobson, Stein, Jutze. DPBoston Seattle 1. LOBBoston ID, Selttle 6. 2BCReynolds, Stanton, Stein. HRFisk (6), RuJones (6). SBEvans, Dillard, Burleson 2.

title: Jersey Nuclear Plant on Delaware Slated to Start Up in Three Weeks
description: HANCOCK'S BRIDGE, N.J., May 15On a sandy spit of land called Artificial Island that elbows into the Delaware River just west of here, the first unit of one of the world's largest nuclear generating plants will go into operation in about three Weeks.

title: Bridge
description: ARUBA, Netherlands Antilles, May 15 Venezuela won a convincing victory over Mexico here yesterday to take the Central American and Caribbean team championship, the first such title off cally recognized by the World Bridge Federation.

title: Yarborough Triumphs Again
description: DOVER, Del., May 15 (AP)Cale Yarborough overcame a pair of penalty pit stops to remove loose equipment today and won the MasonDixon 500 stock car race.

title: Connors Beats Stockton for W.C.T. Title
description: DALLAS, May 15Always looking for new worlds to conquer, Jimmy Connors found another one here this week the finals of the World Championship Tennis circuit.

title: Rutherford Posts Fastest Time on 2d Day of Indy Qualifying
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 15Johnny Rutherford, who lost a $20,000 gamble yesterday trying to win the pole for the Indianapolis 500 meter race, qualified his car today at the thin edge of 200 miles an hour.

title: Childers Wins 5Mile Run
description: Tom Childers of the Florida Track Club scored a 400yard victory over Tony Colon of the New York Athletic Club yesterday in the third annual Bronx Historical Society fivemile race at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. Childers won in 25 minutes 14 seconds in a field of 275. The Weaver of Fordham University was third in 26:09.

title: Customers (and Music) Integrated at Brooklyn Nightclub
description: Most nightclubs in New York cater to a particular crowd. Not Smucker's. Situated at the corner of Schermerhorn Street and Flatbush Avenue, near the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Smucker's draws a stylish, happily integrated audience that its owner estimates at about 50 percent black, 25 percent white and 25 percent Latin, with some variations, depending on who's playing.

title: Local Talent In Punk Rock Shows Its Stuff
description: The Elgin Theater, Eighth Avenue and 20th Street, began showcasing local rock bands last week, and by Saturday night shows were running smoothly, with minimal setup time between groups. The theater could become a comfortable place to play and listen to rock, with its large stage and intimate atmosphere, but one suspects that the promoters will have to book bands that are more interesting and more popular than those that played on Saturday if the operation is to continue.

title: Mrs. Abzug Endorsed for Mayor By the New Democratic Coalition
description: After a fiery speech in which she promised to lead a fight for more Federal help for New York City, former Representative Bella S. Abzug won the mayoral designation yesterday of the Democratic Party's reform faction.

title: Islam and Conservatism Pervade Pakistan Turmoil
description: WAGAH, PakistanThirty years ago, with the monsoon late and the punishing sun baking the Punjab plain, this village became one of uncounted way stations as perhaps 10 million Hindus, Sikhs and Moslems on the Indian subcontinent fled their homes. The Islamic nation of Pakistan was painfully born. British India was riven.

title: Seaver Angry as Mets Lose, 43; Yankees Halted, 82, by Tanana
description: Weary after having been victimized again by a nonproductive Met attack, Tom Seaver lashed out at a management that had not provided the club with a consistent hitter. The attack came after the New Yorkers had dropped a 12inning, 43 decision to the Dodgers yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: The Standings
description: Monday, May 16, 1977

title: 2 NAVAJO LEADERS ON TRIAL FOR FRAUD
description: PHOENIX, May 15The Navajo tribal chairman, Peter MacDonald, is standing trial in Federal District Court here on six counts of mail fraud and one count of income tax evasion.

title: HERBERT WILCOX, 85 FILM DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Herbert Wilcox, the film director and producer who was at times England's most successful film producer, died yesterday in his London home after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: MEASLES OUTBREAKS FUEL VACCINE DEBATE
description: LOS ANGELES, May 15  Fourteen years after the introduction of vaccines to provide immunity against measles, the disease continues to spread through the nation in outbreaks of epidemic proportions.

title: Rose Kirschenbaum Is Married to Peter Lewis
description: The marriage of Rose Eve Kirschenbaum, daughter of State Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Irving Kirschenbaum of New York and Harrison, N.Y., to Peter A. W. Lewis of Carmel, Calif., took place last evening at the Plaza. The bridegroom is a son of Charles Lewis of Johannesburg, South Africa, and Mrs. Leo Brady of New York. Rabbi Saul J. Teplitz performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Norton D. Shargel and Cantor Bernard Dienstag.

title: Leonard Silk
description: Painful as it will he to whoever winds up paying the bills, a huge increase in taxes (or cut in benefits) is inescapable if the Social Security trust funds are to be kept from being wiped out and thrown into the red within the next five years. As the accompanying table shows that the combined trust funds to cover Old Age and Survivors Insurance and Disability Insurance, which now amount to $41 billion, will fall to zero in 1982 if present payroll tax and Social Security benefit schedules continue unchanged.

title: Seton Hall Wins, 124, And Takes League Title
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 15Seton Hall won its fifth straight Metropolitan Conference baseball championship by defeating C. W. Post, 124, today. The Pirates ended the league season with a 133 wonlost record and Post with a 124 mark,

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: In a recent column, the joys of a Provencal sandwich known as pan bania were outlined briefly and a recipe was offered for the dish, which is essentially a marvelous salad nicoise served in a sliced bun.

title: Israel Reports a Tank With Armor That Can Withstand Any Arab Shell
description: TEL AVIV, May 15 (Reuters)Israel has produced a revolutionary frontengined tank with armor capable of withstanding any Mel! in the Arab arsenal, Israeli newspapers said today.

title: Market Place
description: In late 1974, when raw sugar was bringing more than 60 cents a pound in the spot market, the major processors were riding high. Most of them raised their dividends substantially. And one producer, the Holly Sugar Corporation, was so awash in profits that it repaid all its debt.

title: Finnish Pilot, Down at Sea, Says Her Rescue Came as a Surprise
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 15 (Reuters) A 34yearold Finnish woman pilot, plucked from the icy North Atlantic by an American military helicopter yesterday after ditching her singleengine plane, today said she was surprised that she had survived.

title: MEASLES OUTBREAKS FUEL VACCINE DEBATE
