description: EVERY MORNING, Lowell Nesbitt swims in his indoor pool surrounded by his oversized paintings of flowers, underneath his fourstoryhigh skylight, walks up two floors to work out on his trapeze and then starts painting. And he thanks God that the harassment of the renovation is finally over.

title: House Bars Cut in Lunch Program For New York, but Adds Controls
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The House today narrowly rejected amendments to cut New York State's share of the fraudscarred, free summer feeding program for needy children, and then voted, 393 to 19, to extend the program for two more years with tighter controls.

title: YOUNG SEES A TACTIC IN RHODESIAN FORAY
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, May 18Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, said here that a hot pursuit incursion into Botswana by Rhodesian troops yesterday had been an attempt to widen the conflict in the forlorn hope of enticing Western support for the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

title: CARTER ENERGY PLAN CALLED REGRESSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, May 18In another criticism of President Carter's economic policies from liberals, a consumer group representing 34 unions, farm groups ana power cooperatives denounced Mr. Carter's energy policy today.

title: 4 Burned as a Cruiser Explodes Off Port Jefferson Harbor Dock
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., May 18 (UPI) Four persons were burned when their 28foot cabin cruiser exploded today about 100 feet off the Town of Brookhaven dock in Port Jefferson Harbor, police reported. Two of the victims, Charles Schalkhan, 33 years old, of Carmel, N.Y., and Wendy Mulder, 19, of Stone Gate, Peekskill, N.Y., were taken to Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson and later taken by helicopter to the special burn unit in the Nassau County Medical Center In East Meadow.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The St. Joe Zinc Company, a subsidiary of the St. Joe Minerals Corporation, joined other major zinc producers in cutting prices 3 cents a pound. The new prices, effective immediately, include: prime western and high grade, 34 cents a pound; controlled lead, 34.25 cents and continuous galvanizing and highgrade plus aluminum, 34.50 cents a pound.

title: Connecticut's Assembly Approves Revised Budget of $1.915 Billion
description: HARTFORD, May 18The Connecticut General Assembly today adopted a $1.915 billion budget providing modest cuts in business taxes, a new sliding scale for the state tax on dividends and a spending package $40 million larger than Gov. Ella T. Grasso had wanted.

title: Assembly Speaker Vows a Push For New Department of Energy
description: TRENTON, May 18A new state government agency to be known as the Department of Energy could be operating well before next winter, the Assembly Speaker, William J. Hamilton Jr., said today.

title: Market Place
description: The Reserve Oil and Gas Company put to rest yesterday rumors that the company was about to merge by saying, in response to a New York Stock Exchange request, that Reserve had not been approached regarding a merger.

title: U.S. Study Supports Korea Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, May 18A Congressional study asserts that American ground forces can be withdrawn from South Korea without jeopardizing the military balance or with it the political and strategic stability of the nationally divided peninsula.

title: Letters
description: Here's to Hers

title: Key Question: What Is Reserve's Aim on the Funds Rate?
description: WASHINGTONWhenever the Federal Reserve System's top policymaking body, the 12man Federal Open Market Committee, meets  as it did on last Tuesdayscores of stockbrokers, bond dealers, investment counselors, economists, bankers and other members of the clan of Fedwatchers seek to penetrate the mystery of what happened behind closed doors in the central bank's headquarters building here on Constitution Avenue. The secrecy is not total, though, since the Fed does not so much leak as exude information in vaporous form.

title: Dispute Cuts S.A.S. Flights
description: COPENHAGEN, May 18 (Reuters)Lastminute attempts to negotiate a wage settlement with Danish cabin crews failed to prevent a total shutdown of the Scannavian Airlines System's international flights today. An S.A.S. spokesman said all international services had to be cut.

title: Eskimos of 4 Lands Plan to Meet in Alaska to Form an Organization
description: OTTAWA, May 14Canadian Eskimos will meet with ethnic kin from Alaska, Greenland and possibly Siberia next month in Barrow, Alaska, to form the first international organization of the indigenous inhabitants of the Arctic, the Eskimo Brotherhood of Canada has announced.

title: Use Leashes, Owners Told
description: About eight million people and one million dogs, including a rapidly growing population of strays, inhabit New York City. Abandonment is a major problem and while some 600,000 dogs have owners, approximately only 282,000 are licensed. Although the city has existing leash and litter laws, irresponsible dog owners continue to turn their often unmanageable and unlicensed dogs loose on the streets and in the parks. The situation is so critical that mothers in the East Village have banded together to keep dogs out of the public sandboxes provided for their children.

title: H.E.W. Chief Issues Orders To Tighten Contract Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)Joseph A. Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that he was tightening his department's procurement policies to eliminate waste, abuse and mismanagement in the awarding of grants and contracts that cost taxpayers $7 billion a year.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 18Virginia Long, formerly the state's Consumer Affairs Director, was sworn in today as New Jersey's Banking Commissioner and said she hoped to make the multibillion  dollar  a  year banking industry more responsive to the state's needs.

title: As I Was Saying. . .
description: We have been reduced to general, civicminded, goodnatured volunteer publicpark cleaning and protection as a substitute for trained, equipped and courtsupported policing and expert fifthburial and removal.

title: The Standings
description: Thursday, May 19, 1977

title: Robber Takes Cab, Bank for a Ride
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 18Anton Nigosian had a small problem today at the end of a cab ride from Manhattan to his home here. The fare on the meter read $15.05, and Mr. Nigosian told the cabby he could not pay it. Off they went to a local bank for the money.

title: Uncollecting Paperweights
description: PAUL HOLLISTER has knownand felt passionately aboutpaperweights most of his life.

title: Pravda Assails Carter Again on His Domestic Policies
description: MOSCOW, May 18The Communist Party newspaper Pravda published a broad indictment of President Carter today, accusing him of giving the American people sermons instead of concrete action during his first 100 days in office.

title: Growing a City Watermelon
description: Does it pay to grow watermelon on a city terrace? Economically. no. Horticulturally, yes. A city gardener can succeed with them, and it's satisfying to see melons thriving in such an unlikely settings. By all means, grow watermelons on the terrace, on the roof, on the balcony...

title: Bridge:
description: Chess players often became experts when in their teens, but in bridge it used to be a different story.

title: Stolen Car With Police in Pursuit Hits and Kills a Woman in Bronx
description: A GOyearold Bronx woman was killed last night when she was stuck by a stolen car being pursued by a police car on the Grand Concourse at Morris Avenue.

title: Beame Joins Race: I Want to Finish the Job
description: Undaunted by fiscal problems, poor poll ratings, Governor Carry's opposition, four Democratic opponentswith more to comeand his own implied pledge to serve only one term. Mayor Beame announced his candidacy for a second term yesterday.

title: GARDENING: IN AND OUT
description: AMERICANS abroad often seek the solace of culinary familiarity when suffering from culture shock. If this urge besets them in Europe, one delicacy from home they rarely find, unlike other staples of the American larder, is watermelon. Turkey is now available throughout Europe although it is often smoked. Corn, which until recently was considered suitable only for pigs on the Continent, now is served to people. But watermelon is simply not eaten there.

title: Cairo Fears Political Uncertainty
description: CAIRO, May 18Egyptian Government sources expressed concern today that the election outcome in Israel would mean a long period of political uncertainty that would delay progress toward an ArabIsraeli peace settlement.

title: New York City's Precinct Patrol Force Has Shrunk By 3,305 Officers in Two Years of Budget Problems
description: New York City's precinct patrol force, which the Police Department regards as its first line of defense against crime, has been cut by 3,305 officers in the two years of the city's budget crisis, a review of police data has established.

title: True Nobility Is Exempt From Fear
description: The ball Ed Kranepool knocked out of sight, a man said to the Duke of Montefusco yesterday, that was a good pitch, fastball low and away. Jerry Koosman's first home run in nine years, that was an act of God.

title: Deaths
description: AGAPITOJennie M., formerly Jennie Sant, beloved wife of the late Patsy Agapite, loving mother of Flank. Re. posing at Braille Funeral Home until Fri. until 9:30. Independent GG train, Bedford Ave. Station.

title: Home Calendar
description: Stendig, Inc/B & B America Warehouse, 1105 Metropolitan Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Coffee Up by Limit, Despite Brazil's Reassurances
description: Most coffee futures prices again rose the daily limit of 6 cents a pound yesterday, despite reports by Brazilian authorities that recent cold and wind damage to coffee bushes there was insignificant.

title: Women's Five Upgraded
description: ATLANTA, May 18 (AP)The Board of Trustees of the Georgia Tech Athletic Association announced today that women's basketball would become a varsity sport next season after operating as a club sport for three years.

title: Kennedy Urges Withholding of Aid That Could Spur Violence in Ulster
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy called on Amercians last night to help work for peace in Northern Ireland, saying that we cannot turn aside our eyes when Ireland weeps.

title: Big Board Lists 25 Billion Shares
description: The total number of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange was listed past the 25 billion mark yesterday when the American Express Company listd almost 75 million common shares. The list of issues on the Big Board first encompassed one billion shares in 1929, 10 billion in 1965, 20 billion in 1973 and 24 billion last September.

title: Sinatra & Martin, Rock Stars
description: FRANK SINATRA and Dean Martin brought their show to the Westchester Premier Theater on Tuesday for a weeklong run. Both men still radiate tremendous presence; the popping of flashbulbs when each came on stage created an almost blinding strobe effect. And both are still masters of the relaxed, improvisational timing that Mr. Sinatra learned from Louis Armstrong, Billie Holiday and Bing Crosby and established as the dominant approach in American popular singing.

title: Soccer Cup to Juventus
description: BILBAO, Spain, May 18 (UPI)Juventus of Italy won the Union of European Football Associations Cup tonight despite a 21 loss to Athletic Bilbao in the second leg. Juventus captured the championship because of the away goal scored that decided the title after a 22 aggregate based on Juventus' 10 victory May 4.

title: Robber Takes Cab, Bank for a Ride
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., May 18Anton Nigosian had a small problem today at the end of a cab ride from Manhattan to his home here. The fare on the meter read $15.05, and Mr. Nigosian told the cabby he could not pay it. Off they went to a local bank for the money.

title: ARABS SAY THE VOTE IS A BLOW TO PEACE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. May 18Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization today assessed the Likud bloc's victory in yesterday's Israeli elections as a serious setback to efforts for a Middle East settlement.

title: U.S. Warns That Failure To Reach Ocean Accord Imperils Maritime Rights
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Carter Administration warned today that failure to make reasonable progress toward an international sea law at negotiations resuming Monday in New York could set back the project for years and jeopardize maritime freedoms around the world.

title: Home Repair Q & A
description: Q.The concrete floor in the basemeat of our 70yearold house has a number of hairline cracks that normally are no problem. However, after a heavy rain, water seeped in through these cracks. After several days the floor dried and there has been no further problem. We want to store things art the floor and are afraid of a recurrence. Is there any paint or coating the can apply that will keep the water out in the future? C.G.R., Summit. N.J.

title: Hyndman Advances in Golf
description: PINEHURST, N.C., May 18 (AP)Bill Hyndman, who is 61 years old, struggled 37 holes in stifling 90degree heat today to win two matches and advance to the quarterfinals of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming

title: G.O.P. in Albany Senate Approves Bill Cutting Welfare by 7 Percent
description: ALBANY, May 18The Republican majority in the New York State Senate, in a move to embarrass Governor Carey and his Democratic allies in the Legislature, today passed a bill that would cut back welfare benefits for 1.4 million people by an average of 7 percent in each of the next two years.

title: ALBERT O'B. ANDREWS, 65, RETIRED FOUNDATION AIDE
description: Albert O'Beirne Andrews, who retired last year as a vice president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation here, died Tuesday in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital after a short illness. He lived at Belden Hill, Wilton, Conn., and was 65 years old.

title: 6,800 Columbia Graduates Get Degrees at Exercises
description: One of the honorarydegree recipients kissed the university president gratefully, a bearded philosopher noted for a historical study of skepticism chewed gum throughout the long citation of his achievements, and students mockingly chanted socialized medicine, socialized medicine as the dean of medicine crossed the platform. The dean grinned at the students.

title: Topics
description: Window Dressing

title: White Voters Approve SelfGovernment Plan For SouthWest Africa
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, May 18 (Reuters)Whites in SouthWest Africa have voted overwhelmingly in favor of a multiracial interim government to lead the territory to independence from South African rule.

title: Sound
description: IF YOUR stereo system is more than about four years old, you can probably upgrade the sound just by changing the cartridge, or pickup, as it is sometimes called. Cartridge design has much improved recently, and nearly all of today's better models attain performance levels noticeably better than what was common only a short time ago.

title: Croquet Aces Begin Play in Central Park
description: Catherine Tankoos picked up her new croquet mallet while on a birthday trip to England last week and practiced there with G. Nigel Aspinall, the Jack Nicklaus of the game. Robert Liberman's cleated moccasins were made in Italy for racecar drivers, but purchased by Liberman for running around the ruins in Turkey and for croquet matches. John Young Jr.'s deep tan was acquired in Bermuda, where he plays frequently on his resort hotel's two courts.

title: At Your Service: Mounting Needlepoint
description: E Everyone is doing needlepoint. Some do it to keep from smoking or eating or worry ing. Others do it to pass time on the beach creatively. Newlyweds start rugs together and the nonprocrastinators among us make holiday gifts. But what to do with all the pillow and tennisracket covers, the wallhangings and bell pulls, those samplers and picture frames, once they are completed.?

title: Quarter Horses Set For Debut Tonight
description: YAPHANK, L. I., May 18It resembles an Old West boom town rather than El Dorado, with dust flying high, the air filled with noises of hammering, drilling and sawing, and rugged men swearing over the delay.

title: For Parr, a Long Trail to Starting Gate
description: YAPHANK, L. I., May 18A year ago local people who drove past the gaping hulk of the Parr Meadows grandstand on the Long Island Expressway and asked about it were told the track would never open.

title: DEMOCRATIC REGULAR PICKED IN PITTSBURGH
description: PITTSBURGH, May 18Thomas J. Foerster, an Allegheny County Commissioner, won the Democratic Party nomination for Mayor yesterday by a 15,000vote margin. The victory made it virtually certain that he would head the city administration for four years starting in January.

title: News Summary
description: Israel's election stunned both the Labor Party, whose support crumbled after 29 years in power, and the Likud bloc, now the nations largest party in Parliament, where it has always been in opposition. It seems certain to obtain 41 of the 120 seats to 33 for Labor, which saw its own defeat as a protest against scandals and divisions rather than as an affirmation of the ideals of the hawkish Likud. [Page 1, Col. 6.]

title: Vote Causes Concern on Future Policies
description: JERUSALEM. May 18The emergence of Likud as Israel's major political party is causing concern at both the foreign and domestic levels. At the foreign level, there are those who feel that Likud's longenunciated hawkish posture against returning to the Arabs the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip, captured by Israel during the 1967 war, may have a seriously constricting effect on efforts to renew ArabIsraeli peace negotiations.

title: Misuse of Corporate Jets by Executives Is Drawing More Fire
description: In the aftermath of Watergate, the private corporate jetlong taken for granted as a sleek, exclusive, and prestigious executive perquisiteis increasingly under fire.

title: Perry Third to Win 100 in Both Leagues
description: Gaylord Perry, the 38yearold rightbander for the Texas Rangers, beat the Detroit Tigers, 63, last night in Arlington, Tex., and became the third pitcher in major league history to win at least 100 games in both the American and National Leagues.

title: Setback Is Seen in Plans for Geneva Conference
description: GENEVA. May 18The surprising outcome of the Israeli elections has, at the minimum, further set back the Carter Administration's timetable for reconvening a Geneva conference on the Middle East, American officials declared today. But beyond the procedural problems, which would have been difficult to surmount even if Shimon Peres and the Labor Party had been returned to power, much more profound and farreaching difficulties may have arisen.

title: Cabaret: Styne's Rainbow
description: JULE STYNE, the composer of such Broadway musicals as Gypsy, Funny Girl and Subways Are for Sleeping and a long list of movie songs of an earlier era, who sang and played halfahundred of them during a twoweek run at the Rainbow Grill last January, is back at the Grill with a second helping of his songs, only a few of which are repeated from his first appearance.

title: Oakland Elects First Black Mayor
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 18By a narrow margin of 5,715, voters here yesterday elected their first black mayor and ended years of City Hall dominance by moderate white Republicans and their supporters in the business community.

title: An Optimistic Stock Market Notches Broad Advance
description: Basking in a newfound optimism, the stock market scored a broad advance yesterday, moving higher for the fourth consecutive session.

title: Amendment Snags House Action on Easing Hatch Act
description: Washington, May 18The House of Representatives adjourned abruptly tonight after seven hours of debate without voting final approval of President Carter's proposal to free most Federal employees from current restrictions on political activity.

title: South Africa, Amid Furor, Exiles Wife of Imprisoned Black Leader
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 19The South African Government has provoked a fresh storm over its practice of banning political opponents by exiling a black woman, Winnie Mandela, from her modest but comfortable home in the black area of Soweto to a threeroom house In a black area 200 miles away where she has no friends or family ties.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES>

title: John S. McNamara, 69, Adman And ExHerald Tribune Reporter
description: John S. McNamara, a retired account executive for the J. Walter Thompson advertising company and a former reporter for the old New York Herald Tribune, died Tuesday in Lisbon, Portugal, where he was on vacation. He was 69 years old.

title: Beanie Accused of Using U.S. Funds for Housing To Help Balance Budget
description: Mayor Beame was accused yesterday by elected officials of subverting $150 million in Federal community development funds to achieve a balanced budget instead of using the money to rehabilitate the city's housing stock.

title: Panel Weighs Stronger Pornography Curbs
description: In another attempt to salvage its original pornographycontrol proposal, the New York City Planning Commission held a hearing yesterday on two amendments to a zoning resolution that would sharply curtail pornography in all five boroughs.

title: Notes on People
description: THE MAN named last month to be temporary guardian for the aging and ailing comedian Groucho Marx says he wants out of the assignment. It's becoming an immense responsibility and I just don't want to devote my life to that, said Nat Perrin, a longtime friend of the 86yearold Mr. Marx. Mr. Perrin, who is 72, said in Santa Monica, Calif., that he has told the court that appointed him that he wants to be relieved by the end of July. What most rankles him, he said, is serving as traffic manager between the rivals to be named Mr. Marx's permanent guardian. Arthur Marx, the comedian's son, and Erin Fleming, Mr. Marx's woman companion of many years. Mr. Marx, who underwent hip replacement surgery earlier this year, needs roundtheclock medical attention.

title: MOSCOW, Publishers Seek Pact
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 18Independent of the Federal Government, American book publishers are trying to hammer out a protocol with the Soviet Union that is designed to extend the right of freedom to write, publish and communicate in both directions under the Helsinki Accords.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: MODIBO KEITA DIES; FIRST MALI PRESIDENT
description: BAMAKO, Mali, May 19 (Agence FrancePresse)Modibo Keita, the first President of Mali, who was deposed in a 1968 military coup, died Monday at a hospital here and was buried today. He was 61 years old.

title: Mother Slips Out The Front Door
description: FIVE OR SIX years ago, at a time in my life when I was blanketed with babies and pathetically willing to label anyone tall enough to ring the doorbell a babysitter, I contracted with a 10yearold girl co come to the house every Saturday morning to watch the children. I can't recall what I planned to do with the several hours of free timeoften I would dash out to the car and sit inside reading a magazine with the doors lockedbut the arrangement was, in any event, shortlived.

title: CubanAmericans Get Into Havana
description: HAVANA, May 18Four Cubanborn Americans from the Middle West who had come here on a cruise ship from New Orleans hoping to visit relatives they had not seen for many years, were finally permitted to leave the ship late last night by reluctant Cuban authorities.

title: An Early Revolutionary
description: Mr. Keita, a leader of the first generation of African revolutionaries, was President of Mali in its first eight years of independence. Junior officers ousted him because of a swing to the Communists and because of the hardpressed economy of the landlockeddesert country.

title: Letter From Home
description: NEW HAVEN I HAVE JUST landed at LaGuardia Field. Or rather, my plane has. The flight from Chicago to New York700 mileshas taken an hour and a half. Now I am waiting for the airport limousine that will take two hours to get me home to Connecticut.

title: Quebec Survey indicates a Third Of Population Backs Independence
description: MONTREAL, May 15A survey of attitudes in Quebec, commissioned by The Toronto Star, indicates that close to a third of the population approves independence of Canada, a higher proportion than had been estimated up to now.

title: Tanner, Vilas, Ramirez Upset In Italian Open
description: ROME, May 18 (UPI)Seven favorites; including Guillermo Vitas of Argentina, Raul Ramirez of Mexico and Roscoe Tanner of the United States, were upset today in the $150,000 Italian open tennis championships.

title: Crocker London Unit Gets Surprise in Mail
description: LONDON, May 18 (UPI)In today's mail at the Crocker National Bank's ranch here there were $3 million worth of its banking certificates. It was a surprise, and relief. The certificates had been lost on a suburban train Monday afternoon by a messenger.

title: Senate Gets Carter Bill to Curb Foreign Intelligence Wiretapping
description: WASHINGTON. May 18Legislation was introduced in the Senate today to require a judicial warrant for electronic eavesdropping on American citizens or resident aliens in foreign intelligence and national security investigations.

description: JERUSALEM, May 18The emergence of Likud as Israel's major political party is causing concern at both the foreign and domestic levels. At the foreign level, there are those who feel that Likud's longenunciated hawkish posture against returning to the Arabs the West Bank of the Jordan and the Gaza Strip, captured by Israel during the 1967 war, may have a seriously constricting effect on efforts to renew ArabIsraeli peace negotiations.

title: Clerks' Union Calls Strike at Aqueduct
description: The parimutuel clerk's union announced yesterday it would strike Aqueduct after the ninth race today. The strike, if carried out, could close the race track for the final two days of its meet and it could be carried over to Belmont Park, which is scheduled to open Monday.

description: Summertime, and the living is easy. But it's even easier if you laze in a chaise.

title: Drought Hindering Rafting By Tourists in Grand Canyon
description: GRAND CANYON, Ariz., May 17The Western drought is leaving its mark on the region's most awesome natural creation, the Grand Canyon.

title: EAST GERMAN NOTES ECONOMIC PRESSURE
description: EAST BERLIN, May 18Erich Honecker, the East German leader, has acknowledged that his country is having trouble coping with price increases on imports from both East and West. Addressing a labor union congress here yesterday, he called for greater labor productivity.

title: Dance: A Gypsy Mood
description: A and gives a flashing and soul steals over George Balanchine and gives a flashing and soul ful throb to one or another of his ballets. Cortege Hangrois has a Romany beat as well as the more classical cadences, and Sara Leland appeared fully in control of the accelerated tempos Tuesday evening at the State Theater. She appeared in the part for the first time and was partnered by Bart Cook.

description: Theater

title: INTELLIGENCE ABUSES CURBED, PANEL SAYS
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Senate's Select Committee on Intelligence said today that it believed the nation's intelligence agencies were now fully accountable to the President and Congress, but it said that strict legislative charters would be needed to insure against a repetition of the widespread abuses of the past.

title: Gulf Oil to List Stock in Switzerland
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced that it is in the process of listing its common stock for trading on the Zurich, Basel and Geneva stock exchanges in Switzerland, The company's stock is currently traded on the New York and Toronto stock exchanges.

title: UPSET STUNS ISRAELIS; SPECULATION INTENSE ON COALITION CABINET
description: JERUSALEM, May 18The outcome of the Israeli general election yesterday has stunned members of both the Labor Party, who saw the political ground they had held so long crumble under them, and the Likud, who after 29 years as the gadfly opposition were suddenly the nation's leading political party.

title: Books of The Times
description: IN AN UNFRIENDLY, MOOD, Robert Lowell wrote to the editor of Commentary magazine: On the great day, when she meets her Maker, John Stuart Mill on his right hand and Diderot on his left, they will say, Liberalism gave you a standard; what have you done for liberalism? Diana Trilling replied: Well, rationalist that I am, this particular confrontation has not been much of a concern to me; nevertheless, To Mill I shall say that I did my best to see the truth, and to Diderot I shall say that I did my best to look beneath the appearance of things, especially the things which announce themselves as virtues. And surely it is not impossible that I'll get by.

title: People in Business
description: Robert J. Birnbaum, an executive vice president of the American Stock Exchange, is considering a bid from the Chicago Board Options Exchange to assume a top post there, according to Wall Street sources. Mr. Birnbaum, one of three Amex executive vice presidents, is responsible for trading and markets and was instrumental in establishing the exchange's options program.

title: Allied Stores and Dayton Net Up; Federated Chain Reports Decline
description: Three leading department store chains reported yesterday firstquarter earnings results, with two showing increases and one a decline.

title: Income in April For Individuals Rose Almost 1%
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)Personal income increased by seventenths of 1 per cent in April as the economy returned to its normal growth pattern following a severe winter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Beame Joins Race: I Want to Finish the Job
description: Undaunted by fiscal problems, poor poll ratings, Governor Carey's opposition, four Democratic opponentswith more to comeand his own implied pledge to serve only one term, Mayor Beame announced his candidacy for a second term yesterday.

title: Lowell Gets Medal
description: ROBERT LOWELL, the poet, was given the $10,000 Nation al Medal for Literature yester day in the 37th annual award and induction ceremony of the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. The event was held in the AcademyInstitute Auditorium at 633 West 155th Street.

title: Beame's New Team Stressing Business and Management Skill
description: Squinting in the sun on the lawn at Gracie Mansion, Mayor Beame looked out yesterday on an array of friends and associates who had been with him in his campaign for mayor in 1973.

title: Policies Unaffected, Washington Says
description: WASHINGTON, May 18White House and State Department spokesmen said today that the unexpected election outcome in Israel would have no effect on the Administration's efforts to advance peace in the Middle East.

title: Let Us Begin
description: WASHINGTON, May 18A couple of years ago, in the elevator of Jerusalem's King David Hotel, I mentioned to a bellman that I was on my way to meet Menahem Begin, leader of the hardline Likud Party.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONThe $4 billion publicworks program, signed into being last Friday by President Carter, is similar to many such projects over the years except that it is bigger than most at least twice as large as the President wanted.

title: Commerce Agency Asks U.S. Aid for Sugar and TV Because of Import Injury
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)The Commerce Department recommended today that the sugar growing and processing and the television manufacturing industries be made eligible for special aid because they have been injured by imports.

title: N.B.A.'s Finalists in Rapid Rise
description: F. Eugene Dixon, who inherited much of his wealth, and Larry Weinberg, who grew up in Brooklyn and made his money in real estate, have their teams in the National Basketball Association championship round. Dixon is the owner of the Philadelphia 76ers and Weinberg of the Portland Trail Blazers. They are among the league's newer owners. Dixon purchased the 76ers toward the end of last season, and although Weinberg has had a share of the Trail Blazers since they came into the league as an expansion team for the 197071 season, he has been the majority owner for only a year and half.

title: Mishap Bars Satellite Launching
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 18 (UPI) A motor attached to the first stage of a Delta rocket fell off and damaged the machine today, forcing an indefinite postponement of the June 16 launching of an orbital test satellite owned by the European Space Agency. No one was on the launching pad at the time and there were no injuries.

title: Cornell Victor in N.C.A.A. Lacrosse
description: ITHACA, N. Y., May 18Cornell broke open a tight game with five goals late in the third period and scored a 1713 victory over Massachusetts in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate lacrosse tournament today.

title: Data General's New Minicomputers Spur Competition
description: Competition in the rapidly expanding minicomputer industry intensified this week with an introduction by the Data General Corporation of Westboro, Mass., of a line of small computers designed for multiterminal operation. Purchase prices for the new line are said to be about 20 percent below competing models.

title: Books: Heroin Trade
description: PLEASANT AVENUE is a cal de sac avenue that runs from 114th to 120th Street east of First Avenue in Manhattan in the blocks above 116th Street lived the Italian bosses of the heroin trade in this countryOld Worldrooted Mustache Petes, who imported the stuff, saw that it was cut and bagged, and sold it to the wholesalers and middlemen, who in turn cut it further for street sales to addicts.

title: GENERICDRUGS LAW IS BACKED IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY May 18The State Assembly approved with surprisingly little dissent today a bill that would encourage physicians to prescribe drugs by generic rather than brand name. The bill would require physicians to include the generic name of the drug on every prescription they write. but would allow them to specify a brand if they felt it was necessary.

title: Lamont Sues on Mail Opening
description: Corliss Lamont, 75yearold writer, has filed suit in Federal, District Court in Brooklyn seeking $300,000 in damages because the Central Intelligence Agency allegedly had opened his mail illegally. He charged that at least 300 of his letters were opened over a 15year period steal.ing in 1957. Most, he said, involved correspondence with a former teacher of economics et Columbia University, Vladimir Kazakevich, who had returned to Moscow to live.

title: Design Notebook
description: THE Landmarks Preservation Commission last week wrote the final official chapter in the long and curious saga of 18 West 11th Street, where a distinguished Greek Revival house was blown up by radicals making explosives in 1970. It has approved the controversial design by architect Hugh Hardy for a new house to be built on the site.

title: Mondale Meets Vorster in Vienna On Southern African Issues Today
description: VIENNA, May 18Vice President Mondale will begin a long day of discussions here tomorrow with Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa amid indications that they view the racial and political problems of southern Africa from such different perspectives that significant progress may be difficult to achieve.

title: States Debate Offshore Boundaries in Dispute Over Oil
description: ATLANTA, May 18Fearful of losing what they feel is their fair share of revenue from offshore oil, a number of states along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts have begun squabbling among themselves over how to project their boundaries out to sea.

title: Ban Looms for Cruguet
description: Jean Cruguet's mount was disqualified for interference in the sixth race at Aqueduct yesterday but the incident will not cost the French jockey the mount on favored Seattle Slew in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.

title: Retail Test in BedfordStuyvesant Could Lead to a Department Store
description: This morning, an experiment in selfreliance and business skills will begin in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: Ripping Out the Label That Says Made in Sicily
description: Most Americans take for granted that the heart of organized crime is a secret criminal conspiracy of Sicilian origins that is variously called the Mafia or Cosa Nostra. Belief in the Mafia, once derided, has grown steadily over the last few decades until today it is a journalist's clich, and the cornerstone of public policy against organized crime. We repudiate that approach.

title: The Race for Governor
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, May 17Senator Raymond H. Bateman has begun counting the days until the end of his longest and grueling political campaign.

title: CAREY NAMES 2 WOMEN TO APPELLATE DIVISION
description: ALBANY, May 18Governor Carey named two women today to serve as justices in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Courtthe first women ever to sit in that court. The two, Ann T. Mikoll and M. Dolores Denman, are both justices of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Justice Mikoll will serve in the Third Department of the Appellate Division in Albany and Justice Denman will serve in the Fourth Department in Rochester.

title: Home Beat
description: There is no place you can read a magazine in this house, said Tharon Musser, the prominent theatrical lighting designer, except at the drawing board.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NOW'S THE TIME Auction enthusiasts and followers of WNET/ Channel 13 have until next Tuesday to inspect more than 300 items that will be up for telephone bidding on June 5 in the station's televised Art & Antiques Day Auction, an annual benefit event. The public is invited to scan the merchandise earlyan array of paintings, porcelain, silver, carpets, prints, photographs, sculpture and furnitureat the Galleria, 115 East 57th Street (between Park and Lexington Avenues).

title: Everyday Use of Solar Energy Growing in Japanese Households
description: NUMAZU JapanToki Imamura took a very hot bath here recently thanks to the sun of a few days before.

title: G.O.P. Conservative Wins the House Seat Vacated by Adams
description: SEATTLE, May 18In a stunning upset, State Senator Jack Cunningham, a conservative Republican, yesterday defeated Marvin Durning, a liberal Democrat, for the Seventh District Congressional seat formerly held by Transportation Secretary Brock Adams.

title: Kahane Is Defeated in Campaign For Seat in Israeli Parliament
description: TEL AVIV, May 18 (AP)Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the militant Jewish Defense League in the United States, was defeated in his bid for a parliamentary seat in Israel's national election.

title: Accountant, Heal Thyself
description: Although accounting enjoys little of the glamour of medicine and law, accountants do have this in common with physicians and lawyers: They are very much under attack these days. In a recent Senate report, for example, Senator Metcalf deplored the alarming lack of independence and lack of dedication to public protection shown by the large accounting firms....A Los Angeles Federal judge recently approved a settlement in the Equity Funding insurance scandal of $60.5 million, twothirds of which will be paid by accounting firms that inadequately audited the financial statements. And the revelations about hundreds of questionable American corporation payments abroad have raised questions as to why they were overlooked by auditors.

title: Personal Beauty
description: THOSE blissful vacation days lie ahead, and one dreams of lolling on an Aegean beach, or viewing the Taj Mahal or wandering around Paris boutiques. But getting there means choosing what to pack, particularly if the trip is overseas, miles away from Bloomingdale's or the corner drugstore. Decisions, decisions.

title: Sale of French Furniture at English Palace Sets a Record
description: MENTMORE, England, May 18Buyers from Europe, the Middle East and the United States spent more than S2.9 million for 287 florid pieces of French furniture today as the sale of the century began at Mentmore Towers, a Rothschild palace in Buckinghamshire.

title: Matlack 20 Victor Over Giants
description: The Mets, who haven't overcome too many or too much recently, especially adversity, outlasted the rain and the San Franciso Giants last night.

title: Plan to Restrict Saccharin Debated
description: WASHINGTON, May 18The Food and Drug Administration today opened two days of public hearings into its proposal to limit the use of saccharin, but what had been billed as a mass outpouring of protest against the agency's plan failed to materialize.

title: People in Sports
description: Worried about his pitching arm after losing two games in a row, Jim Palmer, the Baltimore Orioles' ace righthander, stopped off in Los Angeles for a checkup with the famed orthopedist, Dr. Robert Kerlan. Dr. Kerlan told him that his arm was in good shape and he should continue pitching as he has all season

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MAY 19, 1977

title: Wave Hill Courses
description: LITTLE voyages of discovery can he taken over the next few months in a tranquil garden in Riverdale, the Bronx. The summer program at the Wave Hill Center for Environmental Studies, 249th Street and Independence Avenue, explores the heavens and the insect world, delves into the past for a weaving technique that predates Christianity, swings to the Orient for a lesson in basketry and finds within the city limits wild greens and vegetables to give a lift to summer menus.

title: U.A.W. PICKS FRASER FOR WOODCOCK POST
description: LOS ANGELES, May 18Douglas A. Fraser, who immigrated from Scotland at the age of 6, went to work in a Detroit auto plant at 18 and grew up with the union, was elected president of the United Automobile Workers today.

title: Apples Are Victors Over Nets by 2722
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, May 18 (AP)Billie Jean King and Virginia Wade led the New York Apples to a 2722 World Team Tennis victory over the Cleveland Nets tonight.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Wednesday, May 18, 1977

title: Cost of a New Home Is Now Put at $52,300
description: WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)The cost of a new singlefamily home rose 5.3 percent in the first quarter of this year, bringing the average price to $52,300, the Department of Commerce said today.

title: 'Cria!' Film on Childhood
description: CHILDHOOD CAN BE a most terrifying time. One must constantly observe the proscriptions of a primitive system of cause and effect that can be questioned only by the reckless or the ignorant. Squash a spider and it will rain. Step on a crack, break your mother's back. Sleep in the light of a new moon and you may never wake up. There is power in the knowledge of these things, as well as awful responsibility. One must be vigilant. One has to be alert for signs.Such a child is Ana (Ana Torrent), the 9-year-old heroine of Carlos Saura's beautifully acted, haunting Spanish movie, "Cria!" about a childhood so packed with trauma that one can scarcely believe that this acutely sensitive child will ever grow up to be the apparently composed, articulate woman that Geraldine Chaplin plays.In his 1973 film, "Cousin Angelica," which opened here last week, Mr. Saura looked back on a Civil War childhood from the position of a middle-aged man forever stuck on the dead-center of his memories. "Cria!" is more ambitious but, without the focal point of a strongly defined present, it lacks the cumulative impact of the earlier movie.Its dreamlike reality is fragile. As it cuts among three time periodsAna at 9, Ana a few years earlier at the time of the death of her mother (also played by Miss Chaplin), and snippets of the grown-up Anaone begins to wonder whether the movie is much more than an outline for another movie. One wants more than mood and memory, though that may be asking for more than Mr. Saura ever intended.He's quoted as having said he conceived "Cria!" after seeing Miss Torrent in Victor Erice's "The Spirit of the Beehive," which is easily understood. This extraordinary little girl, with large dark eyes and the grave manner of someone who has been given the secrets of the universe, is childhod not as it ever was, but as adults remember it.The childhood that Mr. Saura imposes on Ana is enough to have crushed even someone who's gone through a successful Freudian analysis, much less someone of Ana's age and temperament. She watches her mother diepainfullyof cancer and blames her philandering father. Using a substance that her mother has told her is poison (but actually may be no more than bicarbonate of soda), Ana doses her father's glass of milk and shoulders the responsibility of his death while he's in the act of making love to his best friend's wife.It's one thing, I suspect, for a child like Ana to fantasize about murder and even to accept responsibility for a murder obtained through charms or prayers, but it's quite another kind of drama when you have a little girl running around and believing that she's knocking off people with poison. Mr. Saura stacks the cards against Ana. Unlike her two sisters, she has an uncanny knack for walking into rooms at the wrong time. She's more than vigilant. She's emotionally accident-prone.Though "Cria!" seems arbitrarily and artificially structured, individual sequences are remarkably fineAna's attempts to make contact with her mute, paralyzed grandmother, her longing memories of her mother's combing her hair, her matter-of-fact questioning of the maid about what a woman's breasts look like, and a scene in which Ana and her two sisters become giddy and dance rock to a rock recording."Cria!" is a movie of marvelous moments and two superb performances, by Miss Torrent and by Miss Chaplin, who has never before in a film that I've seen so thoroughly realized herself as an actress. She's awfully good in the otherwise messy "Welcome to L.A.," but she's excellent in "Cria!""Cria!" which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a sequence in which Ana comes upon Freud's primal scene (most delicately suggested), something that may well terrify more adults than children who see the movie.

title: Florida Securities Firm's Suit Against 21 Customers Charges That They Reneged on Ginnie Mae Accounts
description: A littleknown Ft. Lauderdale, Fla., securities firm that closed last week has filed suit, against 21 of its customerssmall country banks, savings and loan associations, credit unions and otherscontending that they put it out of business by walking away from contracts to purchase Government securities. The firm is Winters Government Securities Inc.

title: Blue Shield Acts to Curb Payment On Procedures of Doubtful Value
description: The national Blue Shield Association recommended yesterday that its individual plans stop routine payments for 28 surgical and diagnostic procedures considered outmoded or unnecessary but that currently cost subscribers $27.4 million a year.

title: Galletta Captures L.I. Open by Shot
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., May 18Mal Galletta Jr. has been chasing the Long Island open golf championship for 15 years. He finally won it today by just one stroke as he posted a threeoverpar 213 for the 54hole tournament at the St. George's Golf and Country Club.

title: BuiltIn Vacuums: A Convenient Luxury
description: ALONG PLASTIC hose plugs into what looks like an electrical outlet covered by a flap. It vacuums carpets, floors and upholstery. But instead of being sucked into a cumbersome canister that trundles along behind, the dirt flows through polyvinyl chloride tubing in the walls and ends up in a bucket in the basement or the garage.

title: YIELDS MOVE DOWN ON TOPRATED BONDS
description: Yields on longterm topquality taxexempt bondslike the yields on tripleA corporate bonds earlier this weekmoved lower yesterday as North Carolina sold a $55 million issue in what was regarded as the most significant financing in this sector of the credit markets this week. While longterm bond yields dropped, however, interest rates on shortterm Government and agency securities rose to their highest levels since last September.

title: No Victors in Israel
description: As luck and Israeli democracy would have it, the politics of the Middle East are now dangerously out of synch. Just as the Arab governments were at least listening to the proposition that the return of their occupied territories would require their genuine acceptance of Israel, the first try at forming a new Israeli Government has fallen to Menahem Begin, the leader of a rightwing coalition whose dominant faction would not surrender the West Bank even for total peace. When asked about the occupied lands yesterday, Mr. Begin insisted that they were not occupied but liberated. That is a formula for disaster, for Israel and Israel's relations with the United States.

title: Sex Ratings Set Off M.I.T. Furor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 18Recently published research by two Massachusetts Institute of Technology women undergraduates has resulted in possible disciplinary proceedings against the women and a campus newspaper and brought controversy to the noted scientific school.

title: Show People to Aid Theater Club Monday
description: Broadway show people will appear in a musical entertainment at the University Club, I West 54th Street, next Monday for the benefit of the Manhattan Theater Club, the nonprofit Off Broadway group. Admission to the club's 300seat basement theater will be $50, entitling the patron to view the show and have cocktails and dinner.

title: About New York
description: It was two days before the formal opening of his father's reelection campaign, and Buddy Beame kept a rabbi waiting. H:s father would have disapproved.

title: TaubmanAllen Tops Mobil Bid for Irvine
description: The TaubmanAllenIrvine group made a bid yesterday of $337.4 million, or $40.10 a share, for the 8.1 million shares of the Irvine Company. The group's latest offer topped that of the Mobil Corporation on Wednesday of $336.6 million, or $40 a share.

title: New London Is Planning A Celebration for Those In Times Sailboat Regatta
description: A threeday celebration with welcoming bands, street festivals, craft shows and presentation of trophies and awards is being prepared at New London, Conn. for participants in the overnight race of sailing vessels sponsored by The New York Times July 7.

title: Carter Admits He Erred With Congress, but Says Cooperation Now Prevails
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI)President Carter said today that he and the Democratic Congress were now marching in step for the country's good and cited tremendous, tangible proof in approval of his nrograms.

title: Lindy Planned for Everything Except His Role as a Hero
description: The tall, lean aviator with the boyish grin was known by many namesLindy, Lucky Lindy, the Lone Eagle, the Flying Kidbut, to his friends at the little airfields around the country, he was Slim. And it was as Slim that Charles A. Lindbergh took off from Roosevelt Field 50 years ago today and headed his frail, singleengine airplane out over Lone Island Sound.

title: Children Foil Trap for Extortionist
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the New York City police tried to foil an extortionist, who was threatening to blow up a bank yesterday, but their efforts were foiled in turn by children.

title: A Scientist's Rabies Baffling Colleagues
description: ALBANY, May 19A State Health Department scientist who has spent five years developing an oral vaccine for rabies has become the first victim of the disease in New York State since 1953 and the first victim ever reported in medical literature to have contracted rabies after receiving an effective course of immunization.

title: United Press International
description: United Press International

title: ROBERT WAGNER JR. WINS ENDORSEMENT
description: City Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr. won the endorsement of the New Democratic Coalition in his race for the Manhattan Borough Presidency last night.

title: Music: Michael Dadap, Guitarist
description: Although Michael Dadap's recital Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall had many poetic moments, on the whole the young Philippineborn guitarist was frustrated by technical hurdles that obscured his interpretive gifts.

title: A Cup of Coffee at the Interrogation
description: To refuse to reply to polite questions is contrary to good upbringing. Moreover, good relations between two conversation partners can be harmed by such behavior, often irretrievably.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: Below 42d Street

title: Lindbergh's Story: Luck Isn't Enough
description: PARIS, Nlay 22.Well, here I am in the hands of American Ambassador Herrick. From what I have seen of it, I am sure I am going to like Paris.

title: Jazz: Charlie Rouse's Tenor Sax
description: Charlie Rouse played tenor saxophone with Thelonious Monk's quartets throughout the 1960's, and although he never rose to the spectacular heights attained by Sonny Rollins and John Coltrane, his predecessors in the band, his work was always warm and accomplished.

title: Advertising
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., May 19Most of the nation's top advertising agency executives were first complimented, then challenged, here today by Eugene A. Cafiero, president of the Chrysler Corporation. He told them to use their skills to alter the way this country is going and to enhance the gross national purpose.

title: Agency Blames Engineer for Connecticut Rail Crash
description: STAMFORD, Conn. May 19The National Transportation Safety Board, in its final report on the train crash in New Canaan last summer that killed two passengers and injured 30 others, today laid the bulk of the blame for the crash on the engineer in charge of one of the trains involved.

title: Doubts on the Issue of Dividend Taxation
description: For many years the nation's business and financial leaders have pressed efforts to convince Washington that the longstanding American policy of double taxation on corporate dividends was inequitable and should be abolished. Since other types of income are not penalized at the national level, they made the point that the duplicated tax on stock dividends involved a clear inequity. Philosophically, there has been no lessening in the drive toward that objective. Ironically, however, as the feedback from the capital indicates that the business pleas are finally getting a sympathetic hearing in the White House and the Congress, many prominent business executives are becoming more aware of the complexities of the problem. And they are having sonic reservations about the price they might have to pay to achieve the goal.

title: Strike Cancels Racing at Aqueduct
description: There will be no racing at Aqueduct today. The Independent Association of Mutuel Employees, whose 600 members sell and cash betting tickets at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga, the New York area's three major thoroughbred tracks, forced the closing by striking last night.

description: ??? ??? Yugoslavia, ??? Sabina Simmons, ??? 64, 62; Maria ??? ??? ??? Doornor, ??? 62, 63; Janet ??? La Jolla, ??? ??? Mary Carrillo, New York, 46, 64, 63; ??? Colver City, ???

title: Carter Summons General in Korea Over Criticism of Withdrawal Plan
description: WASHINGTON. May 19  President Carte today called to Washington a highranking United States Army general in South Korea who had questioned the President's plans to withdraw American troops from that nation.

title: The Standings
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a reference to a speech by Representative Morris K, Udall before the American Association of Publishers that appeared in The Times on May 18 said that he abused his audience. The word should have been amused.

title: Bridge
description: The bridge activity on the 5:24 P.M. Grand CentraltoStamford commuter train, where the object is to race through at least 15 deals in 55 minutes was even more feverish than usual Wednesday night.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: Article 8  No Title

title: An OffDuty Officer Seizes Suspect
description: An offduty housing police officer was driving along Gun Hill Road in the Bronx yesterday afternoon when he saw a young man with money flying out of his pockets run from a bank with the manager in pursuit.

title: Where Banks Borrow, but Don't Lend
description: New York appears to be subjecting itself to a perverse kind of economic imperialism. According to a recent report of the State Banking Department, mutual savings banks, which take in billions in this state, invest startling amounts in other states. In 1975, 73 percent of the assets of these New York banks were invested in mortgages on outofstate property. For New York City banks, the outflow was even worse85 percent. For Brooklyn alone, it was still worse: 89 percent of local deposits ended up outside Brooklynand even the 11 percent invested there was concentrated on the southern fringe.

title: Dow Declines by 5.43 in Response To Money Rates and Credit Fears
description: Stock prices turned weaker yesterday afternoon in response to higher moneymarket rates and investor fears that the Federal Reserve might be tightening its credit policy by another notch.

title: Bill on Medical Misconduct Passes Albany Assembly
description: ALBANY, May 19The Assembly gave unanimous approval today to a bill requiring doctors and other health professionals to report any instances of medical misconduct they observe to the State Office of Professional Medical Conduct.

title: Aramco Estimates $100 Million Losses From Oilfield Fire
description: The ArabianAmerican Oil Company estimated yesterday that losses from a fire last week at its Abgaig oil field in Saudi Arabia would amount to $100 million.

title: Sven Simon/Katherine Young
description: Sven Simon/Katherine Young HESS AT 83: Rare photo of Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy, was smuggled out of Spandau prison in Berlin some days ago. Pictures of Mr. Hess, sole prisoner at Spandau, are banned by the four nations that have guarded Mr. Hess for 31 years since life sentence was imposed.

title: Market Place
description: Dreaddisease insurance policies are not in the best financial interests of the individual, an insurance stock analyst said the other day, thus putting himself in the camp of insurance departments of many states, including New York. The insurance departments view general health and accident insurance as a more economic vehicle.

title: Ballet: Glitter by Frolich
description: JEANPIERRE FROLICH is beginning to make something of a career out of New York City Ballet's Bournonville Divertissements. He drew attention to himself with a series of effortless leaps and a clear sharp batterie at the beginning of the Ballabile last season, when the ballet was first presented, and now has added the concluding Pas de Sept as well. T8he glittering little ballet made its first appearance of the spring season Wednesday evening at State Theater, looking brighter than ever.

title: Week's Auto Production to Ease
description: DETROIT, May 19The United States auto industry is planning heavy overtime this week at plants making larger cars but total output will drop slightly because of shutdowns of smallcar plants.

title: Reserve Report
description: WEDNESDAY FIGURES

title: Jersey Concerns Barred From Boycotting Israel
description: TRENTON, May 19Governor Byrne signed into law today a bill that prohibits New Jersey companies from joining an Arab boycott of Israel. The Governor says the new law reinforces the state's position of opposing any form of discrimination.

title: A Scientist's Rabies Baffling Colleagues
description: ALBANY, May 19A State Health Department scientist who has spent five years developing an oral vaccine for rabies has become the first victim of the disease in New York State since 1953 and the first victim ever reported in medical literature to have contracted rabies after receiving an effective course of immunization.

title: Helicopter Service Linking 3 Airports Is About to Resume
description: New York Airways helicopter flights between the three major airports in the New York metropolitan area will resume by this weekend following inspections ordered by the Federal Government as a result of Monday's fatal accident atop the 59story Pan Am Building in midtown Manhattan.

title: Art People
description: DAVID HOCKNEY, England's bestknown contribution to the current art scene, is more pleased than not with his David Hockney, the hefty instant journal he wroteor rather tapedthat's just been published by Harry N. Abrams Inc. ($27.50). A candid, reflective and sometimes spicy book that has sold 18,000 copies in six months in England, it also illustrates virtually the entire output of paintings and prints (though not drawings) done by the flaxenhaired Yorkshireman since his days as a cutup at the Royal College of Art in the early 1960's.

title: RATE RISES SHARPLY FOR FEDERAL FUNDS
description: Shortterm interest rates moved sharply higher yesterday as the Federal funds ratethe basic interest rate in the money I marketclimbed and the Federal Reserve did nothing to stop its rise. Late in the afternoon, the central bank disclosed a small decrease in the nation's basic money supply, and that was unexpected enough to touch off a modest recovery in the Treasury bond market but only a hintof a rebound in the corporate bond market.

title: The Flight to Paris: Storm and Fatigue
description: The tall, lean aviator with the boyish grin was known by many namesLindy, Lucky Lindy, the Lone Eagle. the Flying Kidbut, to his friends at the little airfields around the country, he was Slim. And it was as Slim that Charles A. Lindbergh took off from Roosevelt Field 50 years ago today and headed his frail, singleengine airplane out over Long Island Sound.

title: Waldheim Is Doubtful on a Mideast Parley This Year
description: GENEVA, May 19Secretary General Kurt Waldheim of the United Nations said at a news conference today that the outcome of the Israeli elections would probably preclude a Middle East peace parley this year.

title: Grenades Kill Rhodesian Black

To some it seemed slumberingly mysterious, to others a wastelandits scattered city hospitals and abandoned asylums isolated by a moat from the feverish, golden shore of Manhattan's Upper East Side.

description: DURING HER 41 YEARS of life, Della Reese has done almost everything in show businesssung in nightclubs, recorded hit records, made a movie, appeared in a television serieseverything, that is, except star in a Broadway show. Well, Broadway has finally beckoned. Miss Reese will start rehearsals in November for an allblack musical called The Last Minstrel Show, in which she will play Black Sally, the head of a troupe of boys in a minstrel show, circa 1926, that is about to break up in Cincinnati after a 25year run.

Tomorrow at 2 o'clock, there is a Gilbert and Sullivan matinee, sung by a vocal quintet. description: WASHINGTON, May 19Former President Gerald R. Ford made another political visit to the capital today, but he studiously avoided nearly every opportunity for partisan attack on President Carter, his Administration or the Democratic Congress.

title: Donald Ousts Hyndman in Golf
description: PINEHURST, N. C., May 19 (UPI)Michael Donald, 21 years old, overcame 90degree temperatures and the experience of his veteran opponent today and defeated 61yearold Bill Hyndman, 1 up, in the quarterfinals of the 77th North and South amateur golf championship.

title: Management
description: In 1975, Governor Carey suspended the computerrun state lottery temporarily and dismissed the staff of more than 300 persons, including the data processors. The reason given was flaws in the computer system.

title: Lifting the Veil of Silence From a Musical Enigma
description: What does Michael Habermann have that is shared by no other pianist in the world? The answer is the blessings of Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji for public presentation of his keyboard pieces the first such approval bestowed by the composer in some 40 years. Accordingly, Mr. Habermann will not only play Haydn, Liszt and Chopin at his Carnegie Recital Hall debut Sunday afternoon, but will also give the first authorized American performances of four works by this most enigmatic and, from all accounts, extraordinary.

title: Asserts U.S. Role Was Prolonged by Doves
description: WASHINGTON. May 19Former President Richard M. Nixon, likening himself to a latterday Lincoln engaged in an ideological civil war, said in a television interview broadcast tonight that he had been obliged to act forcefully against dissident Americans in order to extricate the nation from the Vietnam War.

title: Carter Names Representative
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois was designated by President Carter today to be his representative at an International technical fair next month In Poznan, Poland.

title: Screen: Vampire In Fassbinderland
description: TENDERNESS of the Wolves," which opened yesterday at the Jean Renoir Cinema, follows "Jail Bait" as the second movie this week to come out of the Rainer Werner Fassbinder film factory, where, it seems, they make movies in their lunch breaks while making movies."Tenderness of the Wolves" was produced in 1973 by Mr. Fassbinder and directed by Ulli Lommel, the actor who was most recently seen as the wife's lover in "Chinese Roulette" and will be seen again soon in another Fassbinder film, "Effie Briest," when it opens as part of the Fassbinder festival at the New Yorker Theater. This sudden surfacing within a short time of so many films directed by Mr. Fassbinder, or associated with him, carries with it both rewards and punishments.The situation would be intolerable were the young German director and his colleagues less talented, but it's difficult in any case. Just because one admires them, one tends to expect each new film to be something of a revelation, and when it isn't, one is inclined to draw back a bit, to re-examine earlier reactions, to find fault.People with such gifts aren't allowed to have fun, which is pretty much what "Tenderness of the Wolves" seems to be doing, though if you are familiar with the Fassbinder mode, the fun is of a particularly chilly sort."Tenderness of the Wolves," written by Kurt Raab, who also plays the leading role, is the gospel according to Mr. Fassbinder about Peter Kurten, the Dsseldorf mass murderer whose crimes inspired Fritz Lang's 1931 classic, "M."Kurten, here named Haarmann and played by Mr. Raab, lives in an unidentified German city in the late 1940's. A sneak thief, forger and occasional fence, Haarmann has as his principal source of income dealings in blackmarket meat, which may or may not be leftovers from his victims, mostly destitute young men whom he takes home to fondle and then to drink. Haarmann, you see, is a vampire.Mr. Lommel regards the activities of Haarmann as he moves about the citypicking up his victims, acting as a police informer, attending convivial dinners at the neighborhood pub (with the main course usually supplied by him)with a deadly cool that, in the Fassbinder troupe, passes for humor.Haarmann's neighbors treat him as a harmless eccentric with a taste for boys. True, he's something of a sightgag, with his totally bald head, odd clothes and manic expression, but as any one of the local hookers or pimps or black marketeers would say, nobody's perfect. Only one person, an irritable, nosey woman (Margit Carstensen), who lives just downstairs, has the courage of her suspicions when she starts counting the number of young men who go upstairs and the number of brown paper parcels that come down."Tenderness of the Wolves" may be about the least erotic vampire movie ever made, which is, I suspect, the intention of Mr. Lommel and his associates. The movie deals in sleazinessphysical and emotionalof such intensity that second-rateness becomes virtually the subject of the film as well as its style. This is not to say the film is sloppy.It is beautifully and enthusiastically performed and it doesn't contain a single superfluous or redundant camera movement. Like Mr. Fassbinder's own early films, "Tenderness of the Wolves" is cryptic, tough-talking and swaggering in the manner of someone who means to shock his elders. Like the early Warhol work, "Tenderness of the Wolves" seems to be sending up everyone and everything, but, unlike the Warhol movies, it takes filmmakingthe possibilities of the disciplinewith complete seriousness, which becomes the redeeming factor in Fassbinder films, even when the subjects are off-putting.In addition to Mr. Raab, an exceedingly witty actor, and Miss Carstensen, the Fassbinder regulars who appear in the film include Brigitte Mira as the tough, cheery proprietor of the local pub, Ingrid Caven as a hard-luck hooker and Mr. Fassbinder as a smalltime crook. Wearing a loud pin-stripe suit and seeming to be 100 pounds heavier than usual, Mr. Fassbinder scowls through his scenes as if he thought of himself as a young Orson Welles. He may well begifted, arrogant and indefatigable.

title: Restaurants
description: As ENTICING AS IT MAY SEEM to drive out to the country for a pleasant and leisurely dinner, one of the big drawbacks to such an outing has been the paucity of really good country restaurants an hour or so away from New York. One enduring and delightful exception for the last 30 years is La Crmaillre in Banksville. N.Y., near the Connecticut border.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO SAID TO GAIN ON ARMS
description: GENEVA, May 19Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union were reported today to have made progress toward breaking a deadlock in negotiations for a treaty to limit longrange offensive nuclear weapons systems.

title: Spring Guide to Flea Markets
description: THE FLEA MARKEthat eloquent testimonial to the idea that everything, no matter how flawed, frayed or foolish, has valueis back again for its long season in the sun.

title: Universal Leaf Decision Ordered Reconsidered
description: The Federal Appeals Court in Richmond, Va. ordered a lower court to reconsider its denial of the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company's request for a preliminary injunction restraining the Congoleurn Corporation from taking over Universal Leaf.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises 4.4%
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.7 billion tonmiles, up 4.4 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 485,993 cars, a rise of 1.5 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage rose 5.7 percent from a year ago.

title: SoHo Is a SoHappening
description: It's Artists Day in SoHo tomorrow, a day when scores of independent artists show their experimental work in a rare display of solidarity. It is also a day when the public can confront the artists on their own territory in as free an exchange as gallerygoers and artists are ever likely to have.

title: CONGRESS ECONOMIST CAUTIOUS ON OUTLOOK
description: WASHINGTON, May 19In a speech today, Alice M. Rivlin, Congress's chief staff economist, sounded a cautious note on the economy's prospects and warned that the unemployment rate might soon begin edging upward.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a reference to a speech by Representative Morris K. Udall before the American Association of Publishers that appeared in The Times on May 18 said that he abused his audience. The word should have been amused.

title: Residents of Ocean County Urged to Conserve Water
description: TOMS RIVER, May 19A heavy downpour last night and cooler temperatures today have eased a water crisis in six Ocean County communities. However, the 90,000 residents in the area have been urged to conserve water voluntarily or face mandatory water restrictions.

title: Books: A Midwife to Poetry
description: Unlike other scholars, who in taking on a subject also become its partisan, Mrs. Williams remains cool and critical. That she has a great affection for Harriet Monroe and a respect for her achievement is evident throughout. But she is not blind to her weaknesses and her benevolences. And she is much aware of her editorial shortcomings, qualities that alienated Eliot and Yeats among others.

title: Schneider, St. John's, Wins IC4A Decathlon
description: Trailing until the nexttolastevent, Joe Schneider of St. John's exceeded by 18 feet his careerbest throw in the javelin and won the IC4A decathlon title yesterday at Franklin Field in Philadelphia.

description: HOUSTON, May 19'Look, we're not running out of oil. That's not the consideration. We're not going to run out in your lifetime or mine. I don't know when the transition period is as to when we will no longer have as much oil as we want, to use in any form that we want.

description: TOKYO, May 19 (AP)  The dollar States dollar was little changed today against currencies in Europe, where many markets were closed for the annual Ascension Day holiday.
