description: VIENNA, May 19United States consular officers who are stationed in the Sovietbloc countries met here this week to discuss the human rights situation in their areas, refugee problems and related topics.

title: Pacific Exchange Defeats Proposal.
description: LOS ANGELES, May 19 (AP)The Pacific Stock Exchange narrowly defeated a proposal today to consolidate its Los Angeles and San Francisco operations. The P.S.E., the nation's third largest exchange after the New York and Amerir can, has been incurring losses that could approach $600,000 this year, according to its President, G. Robert Ackerman. Consolidation had been favored by some members as a means of cutting costs and thus reducing operating losses.

title: 3 Break Meet Records In Women's Track Trials
description: LOS ANGELES, May 19 (UPI)Patty van Wolvelaere, a hurdler from the University of Southern California; Jane Haist, a discus thrower from Canada and the University of Tennessee, and Deborah Pearson, a middledistance runner from El Paso, Texas, broke meet records in today's trials of the women's collegiate field championships at Drake Stadium here.

title: Drama: Joyce's Exiles Back
description: JAMES JOYCE considered his only play, Exileswritten in 1915 between Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man and lilyssesas three catandmouse acts. Seeeing it in revival at the Circle Repertory Company, where it opened last night, one can accept the author's description and also understand the attraction that the play has for Harold Pinter, who staged it in London several seasons ago. There is a beguiling air of mystery and domestic menace as these people seduce and betray one another intellectually as well as emotionally.

title: Future of Aviation Is Clouded by ShortTerm Problems
description: The Lindbergh anniversary today finds the aviation community contemplating the future of global air travel with an uncharacteristic degree of caution for the short term. But it has lost little of its visionary, anythingispossible outlook about the long pull.

title: Exchange Puts Off Action On Plan for Amex Merger
description: In a surprise development, the board of directors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday deferred action on a proposed merger with the American Stock Exchange and requested a thorough review of the affiliation plan.

title: U.S. Safety Agency Being Revised To Focus on Major Work Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Ray Marshall, Secretary of Labor, announced today that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration will focus virtually all of its efforts in the future on the most serious hazards for workers and attempt to gradually eliminate nitpicking regulations.

title: FOUR CHILDREN DIE IN SOMERVILLE BLAZE
description: SOMERVILLE. May 19Four children were burned to death early today when a fire destroyed the top floor of a small twostory home here that had no electrical and gas service because of nonpayment of bills and was apparently lighted by candles.

title: Music: Chopinist
description: WITOLD MALCUZYNSKI cannot be said to have a monopoly on the music of Chopin, nor, in all honesty, can he be said to play it with as much grace and insight as some other pianists. But no one could deny that this Polishborn performer who studied with Paderewski has done a lot of Chopinplaying in the course of his career. Indeed, this year marks the 40th anniversary of Mr. Malcuzynski's winning of the International Chopin Competition in Warsaw.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, May 19 (AP)A Police clampdown blocked a radicalleft protest rally here today, but student extremists caused violence in Padua and a bombing halted Milan's subway.

title: Out of Doors
description: THERE'S NOTHING, of course, quite like the great out of doors, yet hikers, campers, backpackers, canoeists, cyclists and mountaineers often find that planning weekend and vacation outings can be almost as much fun as the trips themselves.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 19Governor Byrne signed into law today a bill that prohibits New Jersey companies from joining an Arab boycott of Israel. The Governor says the new law reinforces the state's position of opposing any form of discrimination.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Holiday Inn of Fort Lee has followed a discriminatory policy by restricting black persons to rooms on the second floor, a hearing examiner for the State Division of Civil Rights said.

title: Israel: Second Thoughts
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The reaction to the Israeli election here has naturally been a little jumpy, but after the first official hiccup, the most thoughtful people have begun to take a more philosophic view.

title: Soybean and Meal Prices Drop; Most Coffee Futures Climb Again
description: Soybeans, coffee and cocoa futures continued to occupy the limelight in the commodities markets yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Frank E. Taplin, a former president of the Cleveland Orchestra and of the Cleveland Institute of Music, was elected president and chief executive officer of the Metropolitan Opera yesterday. He succeeds William Rockefeller, who was elected board chairman. Mr. Taplin, an amateur pianist, is a Yale Law School graduate and was a Rhodes scholar at Oxford in 1939. He has practiced law and engaged in several business, civic and cultural activities in Cleveland, New York, and elsewhere; was the first president of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and has served as board chairman of the Marlboro School of Music and Sarah Lawrence College. The new Met president, who is 61 years old, is married to the former Margaret Eaton and they have six children. Although he is an excellent pianist, his friends say, he limits his playing to small chamber groups for his own pleasure.

title: Plan Urged for Saccharin Sales
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)Saccharin and all products containing saccharin should be classified as nonprescription drugs. a move that would permit individuals to continue using the artificial sweetener, the Food and Drug Administration was told today.

title: MAYOR OF HOUSTON DENOUNCES SLAYING
description: HOUSTON, May 19Mayor Fred Hofheinz, expressing dismay at the recent alleged murder of a MexicanAmerican prisoner by a Houston police officer, said that he had concluded that there was an attitude in this city that is an illness that encouraged the police to act with the knowledge that they could depend upon the support of the community for whatever they may do, whether it is against the law or not.

description: BASEBALL

title: NEW YORK FIGHTS L.I. TO GET ADOPTION DATA
description: An investigation by the Manhattan Dis trict Attorney's office into an alleged nationwide black market in babies operated by New York lawyers is developing into a confrontation between the District Attorney and two suburban courts.

title: Huston Remains Silent on Comment by Nixon
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (AP)Thomas C. Huston. who formulated the socalled Huston plan for spying on domestic dissidents, refused to comment today on President Nixon's assertion that illegal acts are not illegal when ordered by a President.

title: CURB ON JOBLESS PAY IS VOTED IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD, May 19The Connecticut House of Representatives gave final legislative approval today to two bills that would deny unemployment compensation to people who quit their jobs or weredismissed for cause.

title: Screen: Burt Reynolds Plays King Of Road in Motor Mayhem Tale
description: WHENEVER the weather starts to turn warm and Americans begin to take to the roads and drive-ins again, the Hollywood assembly line disgorges another series of movies that employ cars as stars.In the case of the latest example, "Smokey and the Bandit," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, the advertising and publicity would have it that the principal performers are Burt Reynolds, Sally Field, Jackie Gleason and Jerry Reed.But that is misleading. This is a movie for audiences capable of slavering over a Pontiac Trans Am, 18-wheel tractor-trailer rigs, dismembered police cruisers and motorcycles. It is also for moviegoers likely to use one hand to pound arm rests with sheer zest of a race against time involving 400 cases of Coors beer and the other hand to smite thighs with glee at what happens when a couple of good old boys and a passel of pursuing redneck sheriffs and state troopers match alleged wits.And just in the event that there is somebody out there incapable of recognizing the difference between a 6.6 liter Trans Am and a Hudson Terraplane or a new Peterbilt rig and a decrepit Reo truck, there is sufficient use of C.B. radios to let everyone know that while "Smokey and the Bandit" may not be a very original motor-mayhem movie, it is at least a new one.Mr. Reynolds, playing Bandit, a driver of legendary skill, takes on an $80,000 bet that requires him to race 1,800 miles from Georgia to Texas and back in a span of 28 hours, returning with the aforementioned beer. Bandit commandeers his friend Cledus (Jerry Reed) to drive his rig while he takes the wheel of the Trans Am to act as the blocker, or diversionary force, when Smokeythe lawturns up.All proceeds smoothly until the homebound trip, when Bandit picks up a runaway bride-to-be (Sally Field), touching off interstate pursuit by her prospective father-in-law, an outraged Texas sheriff named Buford T. Justice (Jackie Gleason), who is accompanied by the bridegroom-to-be, his hulking nincompoop of a son (Mike Henry).With Mr. Reynolds playing it cool and Mr. Gleason doing his burns and investing the film with a certain raunchy humor, the rest is up to the vehicles. And they don't do anything that hasn't been seen before.The movie carries a PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") rating. Despite its regional settings and characters, "Smokey and the Bandit" abounds with scatology, profanity and obscenity neither uncommon to the streets of New York nor unknown to most of its inhabitants from the age of 2 onward, or unspoken by most of them at one time or another.

title: LEGISLATOR OPPOSES DAM IN HIS DISTRICT
description: ANDERSON, S.C., May 19Representative Butler Derrick became a political rarity today.

title: News Summary
description: Broad measures restricting future sales of American weapons abroad were announced by President Carter. who observed that the United States had specific responsibilities as the world's largest arms seller. Arms sales will be cut back after this year, the development of advanced weapons systems solely for export has been banned, and the United States has been barred from serving as the first supplier of advanced weapons to nations seeking them, [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Lou Adler's Kidnapper Sentenced
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., May 19 (UPI) Zoltan Laslow Kakash, 39 years old, was sentenced yesterday to life in prison for kidnaping Lou Adler, the pop music figure and recording executive. Mr. Adler, president of Ode Records and discoverer of The Mamas and The Papas and other groups, was taken from his Malibu home at gunpoint and held until a $25,000 ransom was paid last September.

title: Group of Anticancer Drugs Found Likely to Raise Risk Of Other Forms of Cancer
description: DENVER. May 19 (AP)Patients treated with a widely used family of anticancer drugs run a higher risk of later developing a second form of cancer apparently caused by the treatment, says a major new study.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: CHICAGO, May 19Directors of the Xerox Corporation voted today to raise the quarterly dividend to 40 cents share from 30 cents, payable July to holders of record June 3.

title: Todd of Mets Tops Giants, 43, In First Start
description: A pitcher who was given a 10 percent chance to live 2 years ago because of cancer found the San Francisco Giants comparatively easy last night and hurled the Mets to a 43 victory at Shea Stadium.

title: Gottfried, Gerulaitis Advance to Rome Quarterfinals
description: ROME, May 19 (AP)Brian Gottfried beat Nicola Spear of Yugoslavia, 63, 63, and Vitas Gerulaitis defeated Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia, 64, 63, today, leading an American advance into the quarterfinals of the Italian open tennis tournament.

title: Gold
description: Selected world gold Prices Thuesday. London: morning fixing $146.80 of 0,10; afternoon fixing $146.85 off 0.05, Parls: afternoon fixing Closed.

title: George Washington Wins Borough Track Meet
description: George Washington won five events and took the team title with 46 points yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League's Manhattan Borough track and field championships at Randall's Island. Music and Art was second with 46 and Stuyvesant was third with 38.

title: CHECKER'S TOP POST RESUMED BY MARKIN
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., May 19David R. Markin the president of the Checker Motors Corporation, has resumed the title of chief executive officer left vacant after the death early this month of Edward N. Cole and said the company is proceeding optimistically on Mr. Cole's plans to build a small, lightweight and economical taxi out of the Volkswagen Rabbit.

title: Lindbergh's Story: Luck Isn't Enough
description: PARIS, May 22.Well, here I am in the hands of American Ambassador Herrick. From what I have seen of it, I am sure I am eoine to like Paris.

title: ExEnvoy to Chile Sues I .T .T., Geneen
description: Edward M. Korry. former United States ambassador to Chile. sued the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation yesterday for $4.6 million for damaging his reputation by allegedly implicating him in Central Intelligence Agency efforts to thwart the election of Salvador Allende. the United Press lnternational reported.

title: New Museum Recreates Wimbledon's Past

Chaiken, president of the 375,000member International Ladies Garment Workers Union, announced yesterday that the union, in conjunction with the New York Skirt and Sportswear Association, would begin to sew a combination union on sportwear association label into all sportswear made by union members here.

title: Music's His Ticket
description: With some orchestras you have a good chemistry. With others you have a bad chemistry. It is not something that can he explained. It's just a fact. I have a good chemistry with the American Symphony, and I have a special affection for it. I think it is a fine orchestra, with good potential, and New York deserves a second orchestra.

title: He Calls 73 Pledge of Aid to Hanoi Invalid
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Richard M. Nixon told Prime Minister Pham Van Dong on Feb. 1, 1973, that the United States would furnish North Vietnam with up to $4.75 billion in postwar reconstruction and other kinds of aid without any political conditions.

title: Art: Chagall Shines In 90Candle Show
description: THIRTYSIX YEARS ago, on the eve of United States entry into World War II, Marc Chagall arrived in New York as a refugee albeit an illustrious onefrom the German occupation of France. Miraculously (as it seemed under the conditions of the time), he was able to bring with him some of his finest paintings, and these were very shortly made the basis of an exhibition at the Pierre Matisse Gallery in the fall of 1941. That was the real beginning of America's long love affair with Chagall and his workan affair that continues to prosper as the artist, who returned to his home in France after the war, prepares observe his 90th birthday July 7.

title: They Give Old Music New Life
description: Five musical detectives sat in a semicircle and looked for further clues. I think it's very forceful, da lada da da, said Sheila Schonbrun, a soprano who, like most of her colleagues, was once a member of the New York Pro Musica.

title: Turner Penalty Upheld
description: ATLANTA, May 19 (AP)A Federal judge upheld today Bowie Kuhn's decision to suspend the Atlanta Braves owner, Ted Turner, for one year, but voided the baseball commissioner's action in eliminating the team's firstround draft choice in next month's amateur draft.

title: Union Oil Agrees to Molycorp Deal
description: Announcing a definitive agreement to acquire the common shares of Molycorp Inc. of White Plains, the Union Oil Company of California said yesterday that it would issue between 4 million and 4.2 mllion shares of its stock to effect the taxfree acquisition. Union Oil closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 54, off  for the day. At this price the value of 4 million shares would total $217 million, and the value of 4.2 milllion shares would be $227 million.

title: Fidrych Impressive In Exhibition Test
description: CINCINNATI, May 19 (UPI)Mark Fidrych, tuning up for his first regularseason start next week, pitched impressively for seven innings tonight in the Detroit Tigers 41 exhibition victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Lloyd Gains Quarterfinals
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19Topseeded Bill Lloyd of Australia led the field into the quarterfinals of the $3,000 Prince Eastern hard court tennis championships tonight by beating Steve Siegel of Teaneck, N.J., 63, 75, at the Roosevelt Field Tennis Club.

title: Cagney Released From Hospital
description: LOS ANGELES. May 19 (UPI) James Cagney was released from Good Samaritan Hospital today in good condition. He had been in the hospital two weeks after suffering a minor stroke and today returned to his canyon home for secluded recuperation.

title: Short Interest Up On the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose to record 29.9 million shares by increasing 2.1 million shares in the month ended May 13. The short interest on May 14. 1976, totaled 24.8 million shares.

title: Art: Rooms With A View to the Past
description: THE HARD NEWS from the Metropolitan Museum is that after a 14month closure the Wrightsman Galleries will be open again as of 10 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Running From the Issues in New Jersey
description: New Jersey has all the familiar and serious problems of an older industrial state: high unemployment, crime, pollution, decaying cities and a poor school system. But as the June 7 gubernatorial primaries approach, the candidates are not saying much about those problems. Instead, they remain obsessed with the unpopular state income tax. That tax was not only necessary but mandated by the State Supreme Court. It expires in June 1978, and while it may be modified, no candidate can responsibly promise a different source of needed revenues within six months of his arrival in office. The energies of the candidates would be far better spent persuading the voters that the tax is both fair and necessary, and educating them on the real issues.

title: Busting Brokers Beaks Charitably
description: The man who works the floor of the New York Stock Exchange for Oppenheimer & Company had a blueblack shiner under his left eye and it gave him a baleful mien he shuffled in to slot the options trader for F. D. Cohn of the American Exchange. The latter held him off with a jab and circled away.

title: VANCE AND GROMYKO SAID TO GAIN ON ARMS
description: GENEVA, May 19Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union were reported today to have made progress toward breaking a deadlock in negotiations for a treaty to limit longrange offensive nuclear weapons systems.

title: Asserts U.S. Role Was Prolonged by Doves
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Former President Richard M. Nixon, likening himself to a latterday Lincoln engaged in an ideological civil war, said in a television interview broadcast tonight that he had been obliged to act forcefully against dissident Americans in order to extricate the nation from the Vietnam War.

title: Ford Assailant Loses Plea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 19 (AP)Federal District Judge Samuel Conti refused yesterday to set aside Sara Jane Moore's life term and allow her to withdraw her guilty plea of attempting to assassinate President Ford Sept. 22, 1975. He said he had no doubt that Mrs, Moore. 47 years old, was competent when she entered the plea in connection with firing a pistol at the President outside the St. Francis Hotel here. A bystander deflected the gun and the shot missed.

title: BROAD CARTER POLICY WILL RESTRICT SALES OF WEAPONS ABROAD
description: WASHINGTON. May 19  President Carter, citing the responsibilities borne by the United States as the world's largest arms dealer, announced broad measures today to restrict sales of weapons abroad.

description: WASHINGTON, May 19Richard M. Nixon said tonight that the films he watched in solitude as President had made him neither a militarist nor a literary giant.

title: Republican U.S. Attorney Refuses To Quit to Open Job for Democrat
description: DETROIT, May 19Philip Van Dam, a Republican appointed 11 months ago as United States Attorney for the Southern District of Michigan, has refused a request by the Justice Department that he resign to make way for a successor designated by the Democratic Party.

title: A DowntoEarth Union Chief
description: LOS ANGELES, May 19Douglas A. Fraser has never forgotten what he calls the cruelty and the corruption endured by auto workers in the mostly Polish neighborhood in Detroit where he lived as a youth after his Scottish parents moved there from Glasgow.

title: Film Forum: 1930's Visions
description: The passage of time inevitably has relegated The River and The City to the comparative anonymity of archives or to all too infrequent exposure on college, museum and public television circuits. But the Film Forum's current assemblage of these noted documentaries, coupled with the even rarer short, Pie in the Sky, is vivid proof that their highly spirited style is still forcefully unusual and effective even if the subject matter has become slightly quaint with age.

title: Tape Recorder Gives A Clue to Its Owner
description: As Detectives Timothy McCarthy and James Restivo questioned 31yearold Vincent Caputo in the Forest Hills, Queens, station house yesterday about an alleged parole violation, they could not help noticing the tape recorder he had with him.

description: Mavor Beame is expected to appoint ???rian Logan, a black, socially prominent ???rights fundraiser, as chairman a the New York City Commission on Human Kights.

title: Music: New at the Prom
description: AN ANNUAL SPRING rite has been the transformation of Avery Fisher Hall into a semiinformal auditorium in which some of the patrons can listen to the New York Philharmonic's Promenades while drinking champagne or softer beverages. This year marked the first time that the new Fisher Hall, completely revamped last summer, has undergone such alteration.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Nixon About Domestic Effects of Indochina War
description: WASHINGTON, May 19The following are excerpts from a transcript provided by David Frost of the televised portions of his interview with former President Richard M. Nixon about the war in Southeast Asia and its domestic consequences:

title: Antiques
description: MAJOR turnofthecentury posters, and revelations about them, continue to surfacefully 20 years since the great revival of interest in Art Nouveau began. This, at any rate, seems one of the inescapable conclusions to be drawn from two new poster shows on the period. Beyond Art Nouveau, at the ReinholdBrown Gallery, 25 East 78th Street (through June 28), is unquestionably the more provocative of the two. Most of its 25 posters are rare, and a few are extraordinary. Furthermore, the show suggests that Charles Rennie Mackintosh and his colleagues in the group known as the Glasgow Four, as well as the Beggarstaffs, two British artists, were largely responsible for the post1900 Cubistoriented and rectilinear poster style.

title: Kenya Bans Hunting of Big Game In Effort to Conserve Its Wildlife
description: ?? Kenya, May 10The Governmert banned biggame hunting today in an ?? to ?? the dwindling wildlife that is the basis for much of this East African country's $80millionayear tourist industry.

description: Parks Commissioner Martin Lang, a longtime civil servant and a top Beame admnistration troubleshooter, said yesterday that he had informed the Mayor that he would retire shortly.

title: Fannie Mae Stockholders Told Bill Seeks to Reduce Property Rights
description: WASHINGTON, May 19Stockholders of the giant Federal National Mortgage Association, which acts as a sort of central bank for the housing market, were told here, today that a bill in the Senate that would increase Government influence over the company represents an illegal attempt to deprive them of their property rights.

title: The Pop Life
description: ASIDE FROM THE MUSIC, there is little that provokes so much emotion in the average popmusic fan as the issue of how tickets for popular concerts are sold. After every ticket sale for major New York concertsnearly all of which are at Madison Square Gardenthis office receives anguished protests. People couldn't get tickets. They couldn't get tickets close up even though they were first in line. The box office, they complain, siphoned off the best tickets for VIP's or scalpers. And on into the night.

title: Ethiopian Campaign to End Terrorism Takes a Heavy Toll
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, May 17One month ago Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, the strongman of Ethiopia's military Government, stirred a rally of 200,000 people in Revolution Square with a theatrical but vivid pledge.

title: U.S. POLICY IN AFRICA DEFENDED BY YOUNG
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, May 19Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, today appealed for black African understanding of new United States policies on this continent and urged a course of negotiations and economic pressures to bring about majority rule in whitedominated southern Africa.

title: Ballet: Grownup Nutcracker
description: THE MOST interesting thing about Mikhail Baryshnikov's new pruduction of The Nutcracker is quite simply how new it is. The production was given its gala New York premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night, and it amply confirmed the good impression it made when American Ballet Theater first presented it at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, in Washington, last Christmas. It is outstandingly beautiful and original, quite one of the best productions of The Nutcracker extant, a triumph for the company and its new young choreographer, here making his first attempt at staging a ballet.

title: Art: The Worlds Of Carol Anthony
description: CAROL ANTHONY, at the Monique Knowlton Gallery, 41 East 71st Street, makes figure sculptures that, though not life size, are nonetheless quite big enough for us to feel them as presences on a scale roughly comparable to our own. They are dressed up in real clothes carefully shrunk for the occasion, and sometimes they come with complete environments (or parts of environments). This puts them closer to characters in a novel than to orthodox sculptures, which must make their impact by stance and gesture aione. Miss Anthony operates at both extremes of our human span. She is good with very old men, and she is good with girls who have yet to come to terms with life. She is good at how people look when they are all by themselves, and she is also good (see The Trustees and Parlor Maids, the Secret) at how they look when they are hatching some kind of plot together. The demeanor is right, the costumes are right, and there is just enough of a finely perceived vulnerability about her figures to stop them from getting too cute.

title: Democrats Boo Carey at Dinner
description: Governor Carey was booed and Mayor Beamethe man the Governor is trying to eject from his jobwas cheered at a Democratic political dinner last night. The cheers sounded, too, for Deputy Mayor John E. Zuccotti, the honored guest, when he said that Mr. Beanie should be continued in office.

title: State's Liberal Party Gives Cuomo Its Endorsement in Mayor's Race
description: Bowing to the wishes of Governor Carey, the Liberal Party last night overwhelmingly endorsed Mario M. Cuomo for Mayor of New York City. In accepting the nomination, the 44yearold Secretary of State declared that he would be responsive to no President, no king, no leader, no Governor.

title: Carter to Vacation on Island
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)President Carter will take a sixday Memorial Day vacation beginning May 26 at St. Simon's Island, a resort off the coast of Georgia. It will be his longest vacation since taking office. Rex Granum, White House deputy press secretary, told reporters today that Mr. Carter and his wife would stay at Musgrove Plantation, where Mr. Carter took time off twice from transition planning between his election and his inauguration.

title: Long Island to Open Celebration
description: The celebration of Lindbergh's epochal flight will begin today with the flight of the sister ship of the Spirit of St. Louis, a Ryan Brougham that was purchased recently by the Friends of the Nassau County Museum for S75,000. The sister ship has been restored by volunteers and private companies, particularly Grumman Aviation in Bethpage, L.I.

title: Oil Heiress Is Buried In Ferrari in Texas
description: SAN ANTONIO, May 19 (UPI)A construction crew and two cement trucks today buried Sandra Illene West as she wisheddressed in her lace nightgown seated in the driver's seat of her blue 1964 Ferrari sports car.

title: Publishing: Notes From Bermuda
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda ONE MAJOR REPORT and one somewhat minor position paper were presented at the annual meeting of the Association of American Publishers in Bermuda this week. The first was a 103page document called The Accidental Profession, about the need to educate and train people in book publishing. The second was a onepage paper, prepared for the Internal Revenue Service, titled Statement of Foreign Convention Attendance and subtitled, Hours Devoted to Business Activity.

title: Coffee Consumption In U.S. Declines 17%
description: WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)Each American drank nearly 17 percent less coffee in the first three months of this year than in the first quarter of 1976, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: An Israeli Benefit: Bonds and Bikinis
description: The government may change, but the Israeli fashion show goes on. Yesterday, for the 23d year, styles from the country's leading designers were assembled and paraded by volunteer models, who have made their names in other fields.

description: BALTIMORE, May 19Seattle Slew continues in the starring role, but the supporting cast for Act Two of racing's annual Triple Crown drama will be largely a new one.

Normally a program that contains the Bartok Sonata for Two Pianos and Percussion would not be considered a gentle offering: the piece can sound wild. But not on this occasion.

description: WESTFIELDIrving Tanzer won't say how old he is, but he remembers the Lower East Side of Manhattan when the Young Men's Hebrew Association was a place where you went to become an American.

title: Books of The Times
description: IFEAR THAT the mournful fellow on the radio who plugs Gamblers Anonymous is not going to be pleased this morning. Because the authors of these two books do not concur with the Moroccan proverb that A hundred drunkards are better than one gambler. Indeed Mario Puzo, in his richly illustrated Inside Las Vegas, places gambling up there on the top shelf with mother's milk, although George Bernard Shaw put Mr. Puzo's case more succinctly when he wrote in Maxim for Revolutionists: The roulette table pays nobody except him who keeps it. Nevertheless a passion for gaming is common, though passion for keeping roulette tables is unknown. (Please note that Shaw writes passion there; the keepers of the tables at Caesar's Palace are known for their business acumen, not their passion.) As for the authors of The Big Player, Ken Uston and his Boswell, Roger Rapoport, you will understand their affection for gambling the instant you read their subtitle: How a Team of Blackjack Players Made a Million Dollars.

title: PAYOFF OF $60 MILLION CHARGED TO LEYLAND IN A BID FOR EXPORTS
description: LONDON. May 19The giant British Leyland Company, the stateowned automobile maker, was alleged today to be handing out massive bribes to obtain export orders and the Government promptly ordered an investigation into the charges.

The baseball team at the Bronx school is unbeaten in 11 Public Schools Athletic League games. The star pitcher is David Steinberg, the starting quarterback in football. Today the wrestling team goes for its fourth P.S.A.L. title in five years. The team leaders are Ron Bradley and David Cruz, both starters and stars on the football team.

After 16 years with five teams in the National Football League, the quarterback announced his retirement yesterday from the Giants. He starts work this summer as an apprenticerecruitment coordinator at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company.

description: Judge John J. Dooling Jr. of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn visited two Queens high schools yesterday to see for himself how students were affected by a segregatedand an integratededucation.

description: SAN SALVADOR, May 19 (Reuters)At least seven persons were killed in a gun battle between troops and leftists near here today.

title: Strike Cancels Racing at Aqueduct
description: There will be no racing at Aqueduct today. The Independent Association of Mutuel Employees, whose 600 members sell and cash betting tickets at. Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga, the New York area's three major thoroughbred tracks, forced the closing by striking last night.

title: STAVISKY DENOUNCES PROCEDURE ON TESTS
description: The New York City Board of Education, which during 12 years purchased nearly $65 million worth of reading tests from the publishing company of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich without the required competitive bidding, also awarded the lucrative business without the protections of a written contract, Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky, Democrat of Queens, charged yesterday.

title: At the Movies
description: IN THE LATE SHOW Art Carney played a limping, nearly deaf detective who refuses to go into a hospital with his bleeding ulcers, having endured the unsalutary agonies of the surgeon's blade in his younger, more trusting days. In his next movie, Mr. Carney won't have to fret about medical malpractice, because he will play the nutty chief surgeon of a topsyturvy hospital in Howard Zieff's comedy House Calls. He will be coupled once again with Walter Matthauthe other half of Broadway's Odd Couple'and joined by Glenda Jackson, playing a divorced woman dedicated to the pursuit of connubial happiness with the widower Matthau.

title: 4 Sugar Refiners Enter Pleas of No Contest
description: Four major industrial sugar refining companies pleaded nolo contendere yesterday to charges that they had conspired to fix the prices of industrial cane sugar in violation of antitrust law.

title: Levitas and Schanberg Are Named to New Posts As Editors at The Times
description: The appointment of Mitchel Levitas as editor of The New York Times Sunday Week in Review was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor. Mr. Levitas, 47 years old, has been metropolitan editor since April 1976.

title: Hughston M. McBain, 75, Dies; ExPresident of Marshall Field
description: CHICAGO, May 19 (AP)Hughston M. McBain, former president and chairman of Marshall Field & Company, died today of cancer in Whitefish Bay, Wis. He was 75 years old.

title: MACY EARNINGS RISE SHARPLY IN QUARTER
description: R. H. Macy & Company Inc.. reported yesterday a sharp rebound in earnings in the April quarter, reflecting improved merchandising results, effective control of expenses and revival of consumer purchasing.

title: SomaliEthiopian Reconciliation Said to Fail at Aden Summit Talk
description: CAIRO, May 19 (Reuters)The heads of state of Somalia, Cuba. Ethiopia and Southern Yemen held a summit meeting in Aden last month but failed to settle differences between Somalia and Ethiopia, President Siad Barre of Somalia said in an interview published here today.

title: 2 Sentenced to. Life Terms In Churchill Attack
description: MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, May 20 (UPI)Two men were sentenced today to life imprisonment for a shooting attack on the vacation home of Lady Sarah SpencerChurchill Roubanis, a distant relative of the late Sir Winston Churchill.

title: AGE UNFAIRNESS LAID TO AMERICAN MOTORS
description: WASHINGTON, May 20. (AP)The Labor Department filed a suit against the American Motors Corporation today, accusing the automobile maker of discriminating against its employees on the basis of age.

title: A New York Program
description: The green decals signifying discounts for the elderly are on the windows of places of business in all of New York City's five boroughs. There are at least 3,000 and every sort of place is representedtheaters, restaurants, sports events, beauty shops, pet stores, filling stations.

title: STEADY BEEF SUPPLY LIKELY AFTER RAINS
description: CHICAGO, May 20With the modest improvement in range conditions in many sections of the High Plains states, the selling off of cattle herds was slowing this week and the longterm chances for a steady supply of beef in the supermarkets Was greatly improved.

title: Hallberg, Donald Gain NorthSouth Golf Final
description: PINEHURST, N.C., May 20 (AP)Eighteenyearold Gary Hallberg overcame the putting heroics of Mike Holland and won a 23hole North and South amateur golf tournament semifinal match today.

title: RABIES SHOTS ORDERED FOR 7 IN UPSTATE CASE
description: ALBANY, May 20 (UPI)Doctors said today that seven persons would have to get painful antirabies shots because they were exposed to a state microbiologist who contracted the disease in a case that made medical history.

title: BRAZIL PLACES A LIMIT ON EXPORTING OF COFFEE
description: BRASILIA, May 20 (UPI)Brazil announced today a limitation on coffee exports designed to insure domestic supply.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: COOL QUARTERS Two new jazz lairs are definitely worth investigating these Saturday evenings, one downtown, the other on upper Broadway, in the Columbia University neighborhood.

title: Rosalind Berle Wigderson, 64, Actress Sister of Milton Berle
description: Rosalind Berle Wigderson, Milton Berle's sister, who created his costumes in the early years of his career and occasionally appeared in sketches with him, died in Los Angeles Thursday. Born in Brooklyn, she was 64 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: For the first time since his brother moved in, Billy Carter has finally slept in the White House, in the famous Lincoln bed, to be exact. He had no report on the bed's relative comfort, but of the White House itself he said, I got lost. Its too damn big. The President's younger brother was in Washington for the White House Photographers Association dinner, where he appeared to be some 15 pounds slimmer. Asked whether he had got that way by quitting beerdrinking, Mr. Carter, whose fondness for beer is almost legendary. looked incredulous. I've cut out eating, he said.

title: Kahn Resigns as Director Of Shakespeare Theater
description: Michael Kahn has resigned as the artistic director of the American Shakesspeare Theater in Stratford, Conn. Mr. Kahn's resignation comes three months after Konrad Matthaei, president of the 22yearold theater, announced the cancellation, for financial reasons, of the company's 1977 spring and summer season.

title: New Opera Theater Offering Work of Argent() and Ullmann
description: The second bill of Ian Strasfogel's New Opera Theaterwhich opened Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and continues there through tomorrow afternoonis certainly a venturesome one. It consists of the first performances of Dominick Argento's A Water Bird Talk and the first East Coast performances of Viktor Ullniann's The Emperor of Atlantis.

title: Idaho Fears Clash on Indian Fishing Rights
description: RIGGINS, Idaho, May 20Tension mounting between Nez Perce Indians and the white population of this small mountain town over Indian fishing rights for salmon.

title: Britain's New National Theater Complex Is Scene Of a Controversy Over Costs, Grandeur and Role
description: LONDONBritain's new National Theatre, a complex of gray projections and terraces on the south bank of the Thames, looks something like an aircraft carrier, but its delicately angled facade makes it an elegant and buoyant one.

title: College Results
description: MEN'S BASEBALL

title: DAVID R. BRANDON
description: David R. Brandon, who retired in 1958 as a brigadier general of the Seventh Regiment, New York National Guard, died suddenly Tuesday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L.I. He lived at 1A Vista Way, Port Washington, L.I., and was 79 years old.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Agriculture U.S.A. 6:20(5)News

title: its a Standout SitDown Sale
description: Prague chairs! Prague chairs! they shouted as the doors swung open at yesterday morning and 200 impatient shoppers surged into Stendig's Brooklyn warehouse to buy modern furniture classics at bargain prices.

title: Yanks Rout Palmer but Orioles. Come Back and Triumph by 65
description: When Thurman Munson was finished hitting and having his right hand cut up and when Reggie Jackson was finished grinning at Jim Palmer and when Palmer was finished gesturing at everyone and everything, the Baltimore Orioles owned a 65 victory over the Yankees last night at Yankee Stadium.

title: RESULTS
description: FIRST$9,500, pace, mile

title: Nicklaus's Golf Course Teaches Pros a Lesson
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 20This is the kind of golf course that Jack built: It is attracting more attention in the Memorial Tournament than the players. And the players' reaction to the Muirfield Village Golf Club ranges from love to terror.

title: CORONA MAN IS STABBED TO DEATH IN HIS YARD
description: A 50yearold Queens resident was stabbed to death last night in the rear yard of his Corona, Queens, home during what may have been an attempted robbery or a dispute, the police reported.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Philip Alampi, State Secretary of Agriculture, conceded that he was the cabinet officer who sent his state car and driver to run personal errands. Dr. Oscar B. Sussman, the director of Consumer Health Services who is involved in a bureaucratic dispute with Mr. Alampi, made the charges but did not name the official.

title: Arizona Legalizes Laetrile
description: PHOENIX, May 20 (AP)A measure legalizing in Arizona the manufacture and sale of the controversial substance laetrile was signed into law today by Gov. Raul H. Castro. The law takes effect immediately. The substance has been banned from interstate commerce by the Food and Drug Administration. which contends that it has not been proved effective against cancer.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET AGREE ON A FORMULA TO END ARMS PACT IMPASSE
description: GENEVA, May 20Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko concluded three days of talks with an agreement on a formula for ending the impasse in the negotiations to limit strategic arms, United States officals said tonight.

title: Woman, 24, Raped in Central Park
description: A 24yearold Bronx woman who was out for a walk with a male friend and her 5yearold son last night in Central Park was raped by two men impersonating plainclothes police officers, the police reported.

title: Honor Graduate, at 15, the Youngest Ever at City U.
description: A little less than a month from now, when Brooklyn College holds its commencement exercises, Eric C. Jablow will get his Bachelor of Science degree and thereby become, at 15, the youngest graduate in the City University's 130year history. And he will do so summa cum laude, having earned an A in every course except thirdyear French and bowling.

title: St. John's Ousts Knights From E.C.A.C. Tourney
description: PRINCETON, N.J., May 20St. John's University defeated Fairleigh Dickinson, 60, and eliminated the Knights from the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference District two baseball playoffs today. Richard Hille, St. John's pitcher, gave up five hits.

title: Miss Graham And St. Joan Light Stage
description: There were so many people in the Martha Graham Dance Company praying on stage Thursday night that one wondered if the LuntFontanne Theater had been turned into a church.

title: The TopForty Samaritans
description: As Arlen tells the story, he had wandered into Central Park last Sunday to look at grass. A lifelong resident of New York, he had seen very little grass, except for the hallucinogenic variety peddled clandestinely in the Times Square subway station.

title: SST's Operators Plan to Test It At Kennedy Airport by May 31
description: Operators of the Concorde supersonic airliner discicsed in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday that they intended to bring the plane to Keneedy Intenational Airport on its first test, or proving, flight by May 31. But, the plan could be upset by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit following a hearing to be held next Tuesday.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 20 (AP) Herbert Fineman, Speaker of the Pennsylvania House, was convicted tonight, of two counts of obstructing justice for causing destruction of evidence in the Government's investigation of influencepeddling in admissions to medical schools.

title: News Summary
description: The United States would be forced to take diplomatic steps against South Africa, Vice President Mondale warned Prime Minister John Vorster at their meeting in Vienna, if he did not start a progressive transformation of his country's white supremacist policies. Mr. Vorster, however, remained adamant in his refusal to make any changes in South Africa's status quo. [ Page 1, Column. 1. ]

title: First Manned Space Shuttle Flight On a 747 Is Delayed Two Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (UPI)The first manned flight of the new space shuttle rocket plane on the back of a 747 jumbojet in California has been delayed two weeks to June 9 because of ground test problems, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported today.

title: Man Convicted in Slaying
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., May 20 (AP)A Newark man was found guilty yesterday of beating to death the 22monthold son of a woman friend in her Asbury Park apartment last Nov. 22. A Monmouth County jury convicted the man, Eddie Thomas a 31yearold truck driver, of seconddegree murder in the slaying of Troy Singleton, who died from brain hemorrhaging six days after being taken to Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune.

title: Mr. Nixon Impeached
description: By Richard Nixon's own testimony the dictates of the Constitution, which he had publicly sworn to defend, had no compelling meaning. It was he, Richard Nixon, who derived from the Presidency the inherent power, like the civirie right of absolute monarchs, to determine which of tlie Constitution's commands to obey. Referring to burglaries, illegal wiretaps and other breaches of the law committed with his sanction and in his name, Mr. Nixon said: ?When the President does it, that means that it is not illegal.

title: Israelis Upset by Begin's Support Of Settlements on the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM. May 20 Menahem Begin's remarks yesterday that he favoured the creation of more Jewish settlements on the Israelioccupied Arab lands of the West Bank of the Jordan River have caused a stir here.

title: Cadet Dies After a Boxing Bout
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 20A firstyear cadet at the United States Military Academy, Richard C. Mull of South Euclid, Ohio, died today in Vassar Hospital, Poughkeepsie, of a brain hemorrhage suffered in a boxing match on Tuesday.

title: Saudi Arabia's April Output Listed
description: JIDDAH, Saudi Arabia, May 20 (AP)Saudi Arabia produced 9.47 million barrels of crude oil a day in April, the Oil Ministry has announced.

title: Seattle Slew Preakness Standout
description: BALTIMORE, May 20Back in Europe, says Seattle Slew's jockey, I'm an American when I get beat. When I win, I'm French.

title: 12TH INSTITUTE HELD BY NAACP LEGAL FUND
description: Thirty years ago, Mary E. Moore was a plaintiff in a suit against a school board involving equal salaries for black teachers.

title: In Defense of Canadian SealHunting
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland,  The sealing ships were back from the ice fields. Hundreds of Newfoundlanders sat down to their annual feed of flipper pie. The antisealhunting crusaders and their press agents were gone. And out in the Atlantic, 300,000 to 500,000 young seals had shed their white coats and were diving for fish.

title: Ford Renews Criticism of Carter And Defends the Pardon of Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Gerald R. Ford went a long way today toward resuming his intermittent political offensive against the Carter Administration and again defended his pardon of former President Richard M. Nixon.

title: Golf
description: AT GARDEN CITY G.C. TRAVIS MEMORIAL The Qualifiers

title: N.A.A.C.P. Drops Houston Aides And Orders Chapter Reorganized
description: HOUSTON, May 19The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, saying it has uncovered serious inadequacies in the administration of its Houston affiliate, has relieved the group's local leaders of their responsibilities and has begun a reorganization of the 11 branch offices that make up the Houston chapter.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: The rise was eighttenths of 1 percent in the Labor Department's index last month as against gains of sixtenths in March, 1 percent in February and eighttenths in January, which works out to an annual rate of 9.6 percent thus far in 1977. The department reported that the index for April stood at 179.6 based on the 1967 average of 100, so that goods costing $100 in 1967 would be priced at $179.60 in April.

title: Organized Crime Reported Aiming At Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 20Law enforcement authorities say that they are accumulating increasing evidence that organized crime is trying to capitalize on the gambling casinos due to open here.

title: 1,000 Poles Attend Mass For Dissident Student
description: WARSAW, May 20 (Reuters)More than 1,000 Poles attended a requiem mass tonight for a dissident student who died mysteriously two weeks ago in Cracow.

title: ALBANY UNITS IN RIFT OVER ATTICA INCIDENT
description: ALBANY, May 20The two agencies with responsibility for the state's prison system have traded sharp attacks over their respective handling of investigations of a violent outbreak at the Attica Correctional Facility last July.

title: TaubmanAlien Group Is Winner Of Irvine as It Tops Mobil's Offer
description: LOS ANGELES, May 20An investment group financed by money from New York, Detroit, Los Angeles, San Francisco and the hunt country of Virginia outbid the Mobil Corporation and was today declared the winner in the long battle for the landrich Irvine Company.

title: The Race for Governor
description: MAPLEWOOD, May 19Assemblyman Thomas FL Kean of Livingston believes his chances of becoming Governor of New Jersey and the future of the Republican party in the state depend on the same thingopening up the party to greater participation by minorities, young voters and women.

title: Aviad Yaffa, Director General Of 2 International Zionist Groups
description: TEL AVIV, May 19  Aviad Yaffa, director general of the World Zionist Organization and its executive arm, the Jewish Agency for Israel, died Thursday, three months after he assumed the two posts. He was 54.

title: In Memorium
description: GREGORYAnnie H. May 21, 1949. In ever loving memory of our ??? mother. Clarence, Remand and Lewis.

title: Environmentalists Say Carter Has a Strong Team
description: WASHINGTON, May 201f policy is poople. President Carter's key environmental appointments show that he is apporently planning to keep his campaign commitment to give a high national priority to preserving and enhancing the environment.

title: Mets and Seaver Fall to Reds, 62
description: CINCINNATI, May 20The New York Mets, beginning a road trip of 90 innings, stumbled over the Cincinnati Reds leadoff hitter at Riverfront Stadium tonight by making two errors, and never recovered.

title: Odd Process in Wilmington, N. C.
description: The refusal of a North Carolina Superior Court Judge, George M. Fountain, to grant a new trial to the ten people convicted of arson and conspiracy in 1971 for the burning of a Wilmington grocery store, is even more astonishing than the facts elicited at his hearing. Judge Fountain explained from the bench that he was deciding not the defendants guilt or innocence but only whether their constitutional rights had been violated. That definition of his task is sound, but his conclusion is breathtaking.

title: Durable Goods Orders Down by 0.5% in April, First Drop in 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)New factory orders for durable goods dropped 0.5 percent in April, the first decline in three months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Thousands Cheer the Memory of Lindbergh's Feat
description: While crowds cheered an act of courage performed 50 years earlier, the widow and daughter of Charles A. Lindbergh said yesterday that they hoped he would also be remembered for his concern for the world's environment.

title: World Team Tennis
description: THURSDAY NIGHT'S MATCHES

title: $400 Million Is Offered to N.F.L. For Games on ClosedCircuit TV
description: A West Coast promoter who proposes to link 500 theaters and auditoriums into a national closedcircuit television network is attempting to outbid the commercial networks for professional football rights by offering the National Football League $400 million for fiveyear rights to the Super Bowl and championship playoff games.

title: Benny Carter Is Superb at Club
description: When Benny Carter appeared at Michael's Pub one year ago, It was a jazz event, the first time that the most influential alto saxophonist prior to Charlie Parker had played a New York nightclub engagement in 34 years. His performances then were somewhat colored by the tensions and anticipations of reacquaintance.

title: Prices Increase in Britain
description: LONDON, May 20 (UPI)Britain's inflation has accelerated to its highest level for a year, according to government figures released today. The latest retail price index showed the annual rate of inflation rose to 17.5 percent in April from 16.7 percent in March. The April figure was the highest since the same month in 1976. There was a monthly increase in prices of 2.6 percent in April, an increase that has not been exceeded in a single month since May 1975.

title: Letters it
description: Secretary of State Vance in an address to the University of Georgia Law School (news story May 1) attempted to define the direction and scope of President Carter's human rights policy. He made a valiant, but futile effort. As a matter of fact, his failure was preordained. Even a spokesman of Vance's expertise cannot make rhetorical sense out of an illconceived, spasmodically applied foreign policy program. However, one statement made by Vance was especially noteworthy. It expressed a thought that, if actually adopted by President Carter, might provide the requisite basic guidance for his otherwise unguided political missile labeled human rights. Vance stated: In pursuing a human rights policy, we must always keep in mind the limits of our power and wisdom.

title: Nordiques Win, 42, Tie Series With Jets at 22
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 21(AP) Serge Bernier scored two goals tonight to lead the Quebec Nordiques to a 42 victory over the Winnipeg Jets, lying their World Hockey Association finalround playoff series at two games apiece. The fourofsevengame series shifts to Quebec Sunday night.

title: M. Ralph Kaufman, Chief Psychiatrist For Mount Sinai
description: Dr. M. Ralph Kaufman, Mount Sinai Hospital's first director of psychiatry and its psychiatristinchief, died yesterday at the hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 1170 Fifth Avenue.

title: Ronald Francis Kozusko Weds Kathleen C. Cogan
description: Kathleen Constance Cogan, a socialwork supervisor at the New York Foundling Hospital, was married yesterday to Ronald Francis Kozusko, an assistant vice president of communications for the National Arthritis Foundation.

title: 2 Held in Arizona in Death of Wealthy Indiana Widow
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 20 (AP)The last two persons sought in the murder and multimilliondollar robbery of a reclusive widow were arrested today in Arizona after trying to pay cash for a $35,000 motor home, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON A Washington physicist received a patent this week for what he describes as a safe, economical coal mining method in which a coal seam is disintegrated by a jet of hot oil under pressure. The coaloil slurry can be transported by pipeline to a remote location for further processing or possibly for use as fuel.

title: Legislators Reject Gov. Grasso's Plea For 3% Budget Cut
description: HARTFORD, May 20Six Democratic leaders of the Connecticut General Assembly today rejected an appeal from Gov. Ella T. Grasso that they make an acrosstheboard cut of 3 percent in the S1.915 billion budget the General Assembly approved two days ago.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: SAN CARLOS, Callf.Irwin Williams, 162 pounds, Oakland, knocked out Vinconto Medina, 159, Tucson, Ariz., 3 rounds; Leonel Valencla, 124, Redwood City, Calit., and Rene Silva, 125, Los Angoles, fouaht to a to chnical draw.

title: Very Special Guests at the Beames'
description: Seventy members of Congress from all over the United States, with their wives, children and some grandchildren, breakfasted with Mayor and Mrs. Beame yesterday on the lawn of Gracie Mansion.

title: School Results
description: BOYS BASEBALL

title: Six Horses of Another Color
description: BALTIMORE, May 20Sometimes it seems that in American racing excitement begins and ends with the Kentucky Derby, and then year after year that turns out to be dead wrong. The Derby is only the beginning, as circumstances surrounding tomorrow's 102d Preakness demonstrate beyond dispute. Though the Derby is the only race old ladies in Wisconsin ever hear about, in the continuing competition for supremacy among the 3yearolds, it merely begins the process of separating the men from the boys. Of the 15 that started at Churchill Downs May 7, only three are trying again at,PimlicoSeattle Sports Slew, the undefeated; Run Dusty Run, who of was second in Kentucky, and Sir Sir, the The Times stuff that dreams are made on. (He has opposed Seattle Slew twice and lost by a total of 29 lengths.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The review of Carol Anthony's sculpture s how in yesterday's Times gave an incorrect address for the Monique Knowlton Gallery. The correct address is 19 East 71st Street. The show runs through June 4.

title: Giscard Party Gives Self New Name
description: PARIS, May 20The Independent Republican Party of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing transformed itself into new political organization today in the hope of improving its prospects in the elections due next spring.

title: CARL E. ATKINS
description: Carl E. Atkins, who retired last year as director of research for the Wagner Electric Corporation, Parsippany, N.J., died Wednesday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, N.J. He lived at 38 Ardsley Road, Montclair, and was 66 years old.

title: MONDALE DELIVERS WARNING TO VORSTER ON RACIAL POLICIES
description: VIENNA, May 20Vice President Mondale said today that he had warned Prime Minister John Vorster that unless he undertook a progressive transformation of South Africa's white supremacist policies leading to full political and social equality for the black majority, the United States would be forced to undertake diplomatic steps against that nation.

title: Sports Today
description: Third day or the Indianapolis 500 time trials. (The Hawaiian Masters surfing championship and European Ladies gymnastic championships will also be shown. Time trials will resume at P.M. following coverage of the Preakness Stakes at 5 P.M.) (TelevisionChannel 7, 4 P.M.)

title: New York Offers Tax Concessions If Amex Will Agree to Stay in City
description: Competing against attractive invitations from both New Jersey and Connecticut, New York City yesterday offered a wide variety of tax concessions to the American Stock Exchange plus an offer to float a bond issue to finance the cost of a new home for the Amex in lower Manhattan.

title: U.S. and Japan Sign Pact  On Cut for Color TV Sets
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The United States and Japan signed today an agreement that will substantially cut back the present level of shipments of Japanese color television sets to this country. Robert S. Strauss, President Carter's special representative for trade negotiations, denied at a White House briefing that the threeyear pact would be either protectionist or inflationary.

title: No Curbs Are Seen in Israel's Trade
description: JERUSALEM, May 20Israel is not curbing its growing commercial and trade links with South Africa, in the view of a number of Israeli officials and members of the foreign diplomatic community based here.

title: About New York
description: In his bare cubicle down from City Hall, the bureaucrat confessed his personal goals for this year: To write home about the Islamic and Egyptian collections at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to master the city's budget process and understand this thing called a mayoral race, and to read more history books about Hannibal.

Mr. Vorster, however, remained adamant in his refusal to make any changes in South Africa's status quo. [Page 1, Column. 1.]

title: Life Good and Not So Good in Remote Australian Mine Area
description: KARRATHA, AustraliaIt may be the best deal in the world$26 a week for a new, fully furnished, airconditioned threebedroom house, plus all you can eat in the local restaurant. There's sunshine all year round, a free 18hole golf course, an Olympicsize swimming pool, sailing on the weekends and a 10 percent rebate on income tax just for living here.

title: Vietnam Refugees Reach Manila
description: MANILA, May 20 (Reuters)Thirtyfive people who fled from Vietnam in a motor boat drifted into coastal waters northwest of here Wednesday after a sevenday voyage across the South China Sea, the police reported today. The refugees, including a university professor, a priest and students, were to undergo interrogation before any decision was made on their future, military sources said.

title: Carter's Political Bills Imperiled By Lagging Congressional Support
description: WASHINGTON, May 20The ambitious political bills that President Carter sent to Capitol Hill two months ago are running into trouble in a way that is embarrassing for the Democratic Congressional leadership and its labour allies but not necessarily fatal to the program.

title: Koreans Push Bahrain Dock Job
description: MANAMA, Bahrain (AP)Under signs reading New Heart. New Determination, 1,600 South Kercans are working with tight discipline to complete a major, Middle Eastern construction project ahead of schedule.

title: Court Rejects U.S. Order for BOC To Divest Itself of Airco Interest
description: BOC bought the interest in 1973 for about $80 million, paying $20 a share for 4 million shares. Both companies are in the business of manufacturing industrial gases, a small percentage of which are used in the medical field.

title: Indonesia Forgoes A 5% Oil Price Rise
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 20 (AP)indonesia has decided to forgo the 5 percent oil price increase scheduled by 1 members of the Organization of Petrolium Exporting Countries on July I, Mining Minister Mohammad Sadli said today.

title: General Returns From South Korea to Face Carter
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, the United States Army officer in Korea who criticized President Carter's plan to withdraw ground troops from South Korea, returned home tonight for a facetoface meeting with Mr. Carter.

title: Bank Trust Units Favor the Oils In 1st Quarter but Stepup Selling
description: Bank trust departments made oil shares the favorite additions to their stock portfolios in the first quarter of 1977. At the same time, these large money managers stepped up their selling activity sharply during the threemonth period, during which the Dow Jones industrials opened at 1,004 and closed at 919.

title: The City Council, at Large
description: There is restlessness in the ranks of the New York City Council. Members feel that they are accomplishing less than they promised, as usual. The disappointment is keener this year because some of the 1975 amendments to the City Charter envisioned larger responsibilities. In the words of Henry Stern, one of Manhattan's two councilmen at large and one of the more restless ones, the Council has been incredibly laggard even in establishing the office of budgetary review which the new Charter requires. It took the leadership 17 months to designate a director. He has not yet been confirmed.

title: Greece Looks to Its Mines To Aid Exports, Employment
description: SALONIKA, GreeceGreece is making a vigorous effort to find and exploit new sources of mineral wealth to strengthen its economy and prepare for eventual membership in the European Economic Community.

title: We Are Still Killing the Indians
description: A child is crying. And there are very few who hear. The sound comes from an American home in Arizona. And the Dakotas. Alaska. And New York State.

title: Negligence Lawyer Given a Year in Jail For Keeping Claims
description: A negligence attorney who pocketed more than $150,000 in settlements he had won for some 150 clients in the last few years was sentenced to a year in jail yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

description: Horses listed in order of Dolt positisns Letter dasignates OTB listing.

title: U. N. Conference Trying To Formulate Compromise On Southern Africa Plan
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, May 20Delegate to a special United Nations conference nere worked into the night in an attempt to frame a strategy on SouthWest Africa and Rhodesia that would draw the widest possible support.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.8% IN APRIL, SPURRED BY 1.5% RISE FOR FOOD
description: WASHINGTON, May 20Higher food prices led to another big increase in the Consumer Price Index in April, the Government reported today. But Administration economists said they expected the surge in food prices to taper off in the second half of the year and that the general rate of price increases would be more moderate.

title: Japanese Shipbuilding Orders
description: TOKYO, May 20 (Reuters)Japanese shipbuilders, under fire from Western Europe for taking a major share of a shrinking market, today reported their worst month for overseas orders in two years. The Japan Ship Exporters Association said only 10 ships, totaling 151,300 tons, were ordered last month, compared with 32 ships totalling 811,950 tons ordered in March.

title: First of 230 New Railroad Cars Delivered for Lines in Jersey
description: TRENTON. May 20 (UPI)New Jersey has received the first of 230 railroad passenger cars.

title: Rebecca Penneys Proves to Be WellSchooled Pianist
description: It is not hard to admire Rebecca Penneys, who gave a piano recital on Thursday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. Although slim and willowy, she has wrists like buggy whips and fingers that can do just about anything she demands. Anybody who is able to buzz through the double octaves of Diszt's Funerailles and the most florid pages of his Dante Sonata the way Miss Penneys did on this occasion must be treated with the respect due a wellschooled technician. That said, however, it must he added that the recital also contained a good deal of unremarkable musicmaking.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 20Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, told shareholders today that he expected the company's earnings would increase sharply this year because of increased revenues from North Sea oil.

title: Organized Crime Reported Aiming At Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 20Law enforcement authorities say that they are accumulating increasing evidence that organized crime is trying to capitalize on the gambling casinos due to open here.

title: A War Resister, Ending 8 Years of Frustration, Returns Home to Benefit From Amnesty Program
description: TACOMA, Wash, May 19The long, fearful years of waiting are over for Richard C. Moore 3d.

title: MONDALE, IN MEETING WITH VORSTER,WARNS OF DIPLOMATIC STEPS
description: VIENNA, May 20Vice President Mondale said today that he had warned Prime Minister John Vorster that unless he undertook a progressive transformation of South Africa's white supremacist policies leading to full political and social equality for the black majority, the United States would be forced to undertake diplomatic steps against that nation.

title: Unanswered Questions Cited
description: The domestic color television industry generally applauded the agreement signed yesterday that limits Japanese color TV exports.

title: Stalking a Man Called Son of Sam, the 44Caliber Killer
description: Tracking down a major killer is more like a chess game than the car chases, stakeouts and shootouts that characterize so many TV nonce series.

title: Greenwich Residents Lock Doors After 2 Attacks by Rapist in Week
description: Residents of a fiveblock area in Old Greenwich, Conn., are locking their doors and windows and leaving their dogs out at night, fearful that a rapistburglar who struck twice at middleaged women within the last week will return.

title: People in Sports
description: Speculation that Randy Smith would be traded by the Buffalo Braves or become a free agent has ended. The seasoned guard, who had been playing out his option, signed a twoyear contract with the National Basketball Association team yesterday.

title: State Ban on Clamming in Suffolk Is Stayed by Court Until June 1
description: A state ban on clamming in 2,000 allegedly polluted acres of Suffolk County waters was stayed only hours after it went into effect yesterday. Commercial clammers, who did not go out at dawn yesterdayalthough poachers didwere given a reprieve at least until June 1 as Justice Lawrence J. Bracken of State Supreme Court signed the stay.

title: Gannett Visiting Professor Named
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., May 20 (AP)John Hohenberg, a journalism professor who administered the Pulitzer prizes for 23 years, has been named Gannett Visiting Professor at the University of Kansas. Mr. Hohenberg taught at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism for 25 years.

title: FOOD UP NEARLY 2% IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Food prices, which typically decline in April, rose by almost 2 percent in the New York metropolitan area last month, according to Herbert Bienstock, regional commissioner of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: RepairItYourself Renewal Reviving Downtown Albany
description: ALBANY, May 20A decision by the Historic Albany Foundation to rehabilitate the most dilapidated structure we could find on Capitol Hill as a new headquarters for itself has drawn attention to an ambitious, selfhelp urbanrenewal effort that has begun to reverse the tide of decay in downtown Albany.

title: General Hershey Dead at 83
description: ANGOLA, Ind., May 20Gen Lewis Blaine Hershey, who supervised the draft of 14.5 million Americans in three wars before retiring as the oldest military man on active duty, died today while on a visit to his home town of Angola in northeastern Indiana. He was 83 years old.

title: Cunhal Gives Up a Position
description: LISBON, May 20 (Reuters)The leader of Portugal's Communist Party, Alvaro Cunhal, is giving up his scat in Parliament to devote more time to his duties as the party's secretary general, the Lisbon radio said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The formation of a citizens committee to promote the old Brooklyn Navy Yard as a base for offshore exploration for oil and gas was announced by the Brooklyn Educational and Cultural Alliance. New jobs are needed in Brooklyn to sustain its cultural institutions, said Howard B. Hornstein, executive director of the alliance, explaining why, it was sponsoring an economic development effort.

title: Kidnapping of Basque Industrialist Heightens Tension
description: MADRID, May 20Urban guerrillas disguised as nurses kidnapped a wealthy rightwing Basque industrialist from his home on the outskirts of Bilbao this morning, heightening tension in the troubled Basque provinces 26 days before general elections are to be held throughout Spain.

title: Soybean and Grain Futures Weaken
description: Rains in most of this country's growing areas as well as reports that the Soviet Union's spring planting was ahead of last years helped send prices of soybean and grain futures down again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Five Worlds Without End
description: VIENNAPresent custom likes to divide the earth we inhabit into five geopolitical segments: a first world comprising Western industrializedlands; a second world including all varieties of Communist rule; a third world of poor underdeveloped countries; a fourth world of rich, developing nations like Iran, and a fifth world of isolated oddmenout like Israel, South Africa and Taiwan.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMMeta. Sister of Recha Abraham and Adele Trier. Services were held May 19, 1977 at The Riverside.

title: General Became a Symbol
description: His name, like that of the late J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal, Bureau of Investigation, was virtually synonymous with the organization he headed for more than a generation. General Hershey helped to set up the Selective Service System before World War II, became a key figure as its director in the mobilization of the United States against the armies of Japan and Germany and kept running it until 1970, when he stepped down at the age of 76. In those three decades, he presided over the induction of 14,620,096 soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines, by the count of the Selective Service System.

title: Carter Nominates Energy Aide
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP)President Carter announced today that he wasnominating Robert R. Nordhaus, counsel of the House Commerce Committee, to be assistant administrator of the Federal Energy Administration for regulatory programs. Mr. Nordhaus, 40 years old, has been a Congressional employee since his graduation from Yale Law School in 1963.

title: A LatterDay Pilot Departs for France
description: While the country celebrated by putting airplanes into the sky in dozens of locales, one lone pilot pointed his singleengine plane toward the east and took off at precisely 7:52 A.M. yesterday on Long Island, headed for France.

title: Books of The Times
description: From Kaufman and Hart in Once in a Lifetime to Erica Jong's latest, the indignities suffered by writers in Hollywood have been chronicled in great detail with either hilarity or bitter intipathy. Now Hollywoodin the senses of film capital and state of mindno longer exists. All those movies written by people who were called sellouts in their day are studied in film courses and a small wave of revisionism is lapping the intellectual shores. Movies are still by and large in the hands of the bankers and money men, but writing them, even if for a quick buck, is no longer regarded as Faustian bargain.

title: Couples Get One Last Chance In Conciliation Court on Coast
description: LOS ANGELESWhen husbands and wivesembittered and estranged by finapcial problems, conflicting philosophies of child rearing or their attitudes toward inlawscontemplate an end to marriage, there is little judges and lawyers can do in most cities to resolve their differences.

title: David E. Scoll, a Lawyer, 71; Hamilton Associates Partner
description: David E. Scoll, a partner in the New York law firm of Hamilton Associates, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 7.1 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y:

title: Monmouth Park Opens Today
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., May 20Monmouth Park's thoroughbred season opens tomorrow for 92 racing days through Labor Day, Sept. 5.

title: Text of a Statement By Carter on Flight
description: WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP]Following is the text of a statement President Carter issued today to mark the anniversary of Charles A. Lindbergh's flight from New York to Paris:

title: Spanish Communist Is Injured
description: CIUDAD REAL, Spain, May 20 (Reuters) A Communist labor leader, Marcelino Cam.oho, was seriously hurt in a car crash near here today, the police said. Mr. Camacho, 59yearold leader of the Workers Commissions trade union, was traveling to a political meeting when his car collided with another car.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: The rise was eighttenths of 1 percent in the Labour Department's index last month as against gains of sixtenths in March, 1 percent in February and eighttenths in January, which works out to an annual rate of 9.6 percent thus far in 1977. The department reported that the index for April stood at 179.6 based on the 1967 average of 100, so that goods costing $100 in 1967 would be priced at $179.60 in April.

title: WORKERS END STRIKE AT JEWISH AGENCIES
description: Employees of 22 Jewish agencies, including Y.M. and Y.W.H.A.'s and centers for the elderly, voted yesterday to accept a pay raise while other, still striking, members of the same union held a rally near City Hall.

title: The Golden Buckeye: Store Discounts Ease the Burden on Ohio's Elderly
description: COLUMBUS, OhioLike most of this state's million citizens age 65 and over, Kathleen Hoke, a 72yearold retired secretary, has developed a knock for making her small retirement income stretch a long way.

title: Borne by Foxes, Rabies Creeps West and South Through Europe
description: GENEVA, May 20The spacious gardens of Schloss Hellbrun near Salzburg, Austria, are aglow with sweeping floral displays, interspersed with reflecting pools and statuary against a backdrop of alpine scenery.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The Board Of Public Utility Commissioners voted ycsterday to restrict a utility's authority to shut off service to customers who are delinquent on their bills.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The review of Carol Anthony's sculpture show in yesterday's Times gave an incorrect address for the Monique Knowlton Gallery. The correct address is 19 East 71st Street. The show runs through June 4.

description: LONDON, May 20 (AP)A British Leyland executive told a newspaper today he forged a letter about payoffs allegedly made by the stateowned auto company to win overseas contracts, but still insisted a slush fund existed.

description: GENEVA, May 20Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko concluded three days of talks with an agreement on a formula for ending the impasse in the negotiations to limit strategic arms, United States officals said tonight.

Although she is best known as the lead singer and arranger for the Sweet Inspirations, who sang behind Aretha Franklin, Elvis Presley and other stars, her background is in Newark's fine choirs and gospel groups.
