Kearney, the former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who is under indictment on charges of obstructing justice, illegal wiretaps and mail openings, asked the Government yesterday to produce evidence that the radical Weatherman outfit was a national security threat justifying the use of warrantless wire interception and mail openings.

The 71yearold Blenheim Hotel, half of the old MarlboroughBlenheim on the famous Boardwalk, is far along toward being declared a historic structure. It is also being refurbished to accomodate gambling casinos.

Ebert, the president and director of the Marine Biological Laboratories at Woods Hole, Mass., has been named president of the Carnegie Institution of Washington. Mr, Ebert, who will take office July 1, 1978, will succeed Dr. Philip H. Aberson, who has served as president since 1971.

title: Topics
description: Mayor Beame is reported to be considering Mrs. Marian Logan to head the city's Human Rights Commission. The vacancy was created by, the selection of Eleanor Holmes Norton to head the Federal Equal Opportunity Commission. Mrs. Logan's appointment would be a mistake. That job, as Mrs. Norton demonstrated, requires analytical skills, broad knowledge of public policy, deftness at public affairs and a detailed knowledge of the increasingly technical field of civil rights. Mrs. Logan has been a notable and constructive citizen of this community and a supporter of civil rights causes around the country. But there is noth ing in her background to indicate that she has, the required abilities, Her selection would only cast doubt on the Mayor's commitment to the commission's work.

Shaw was timed at 16 minutes 5.61 seconds.

title: Power Shortage in India

Government officials said the main reasons for the power shortage were the low water level at the Bakhra Dam and hydroelectric plant in the Punjab and the failure of some thermal power units.

It is scored, appropriately enough, for eight winds plus piano and lasts about 15 minutes.

title: Belmont Is Closed Today; Horsemen Back OTB Card
description: The mutuel clerks strike will shut down New York thoroughbred racing again today. The horsemen gave their approval yesterday to race on Monday at Belmont Park for offtrackbetting purposes, even if no fans are in the stands, but a highly placed source said he believed the track plans to remain closed for a few more days.

description: Shareholders of four mutual funds operated by Investors Overseas Services, the oncegigantic financial complex, were awarded yesterday almost $124 million frozen by securities regulators in Canada.

title: Ali's Latest Victory Is 'The Greatest'
description: "The Greatest," the screen biography of Muhammad Ali, a.k.a. Cassius Clay, is a charming curio of a sort Hollywood doesn't seem to make much any more. It's a movie about a real-life personality who plays himself in reconstructions of those events that brought him to success's pinnacle, which, in turn, prompted movie producers to want to make this movie about him.As serious fiction, it's product merchandising such as T-shirts, bumper stickers and personality posters. Yet once you get beyond the embarrassingly simple-minded introductory sequences, "The Greatest" is winning entertainment. I suspect this is because Muhammad Ali, unlike Audie Murphy ("Beyond Glory") and Douglas (Wrong Way) Corrigan ("The Flying Irishman"), to name two others who replayed their lives in film, has spent the last 15 or 20 years shaping a public personality big enough to fill a movie screen. "The Greatest," which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, glosses over a lot of rocky material and smoothes the rough edges of one of the most fascinating careers in boxing history, but this, too, is the way of such movies. One of the pleasures of "The Greatest" is in not getting bogged down in details not easily explained by a piety.The film, written by Ring Lardner Jr. and directed by Tom Gries (who died shortly after the completion of producton), is old-fashioned, upbeat movie-making with a marvelous personality at its center. You might call Muhammad Ali a natural actor, but that would be to deny his wit, sensibility, drive, ability, enthusiasm, poise and common sense, all of which are the conscious achievements of an ambitious man who has known exactly what he has wanted for a long time.Part of the fun of watching "The Greatest" is in being in on another Ali victory, and in being aware that he himself has such a clear perspective of what he has been up to in defining his career as much through public relations as determination, belief and talent. The film itself is an extension of that public-relations sense. It opens with the young Cassius Claynicely played by Phillip (Chip) McAllister  returning home to Louisville from Rome with an Olympic medal to face obligatory discrimination, thus to acquire the inspiration to go on to his success as a professional fighter.At the point he turns pro, Muhammad Ali takes over his own role in what amounts to a rsum of the published facts of his lifehis friendship with Malcolm X and conversion to the Muslim religion, his successes in the ring and then ostracism after he refused induction into the Army, followed by his victory before the Supreme Court and his victory over George Foreman in the title fight in Zaire.The fight sequences (actual footage) are cannily placed within the film to build to the climatic bout with Foreman. The facts of the champ's private life are treated much in the manner of a "Dick and Jane" story, but so ingenuously that it's difficult to complain about the disappearance of Malcolm X (James Earl Jones) without comment halfway through the movie, or about the apparent elimination of one entire first marriage.I say apparent because I don't know that much about the champ's love life. I wouldn't have realized that Annazette Chase, who plays the Muslim girl he marries in the film, was not his first wife without having read the program notes in which her role is described as that of "Ali's controversial second wife, Belinda." Why she is controversial is not explained by the film. Could it be because she has since been replaced?The huge supporting cast includes a lot of fine actors doing little more than bits, though Robert Duvall stands out as one of Ali's earlier backers and Roger E. Mosley is very funny as Sonny Liston in the film's most uproarious sequence when Ali sets out to insult the humorless Liston into a title bout. Ernest Borgnine and John Marley are staunch as, respectively, the champ's trainer, Angelo Dundee, and his doctor, Ferdie Pacheco."The Greatest," though, is entirely Muhammad Ali's. His presence dominates the screen and turns a rather ordinary, one-in-a-million success story into a first-rate piece of popular Americana."The Greatest," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some vulgar language, but is otherwise as nicely mannered as a high-school play.

When they first opened their shopVoltaire's, three miles North of New Milford on Route 7that part of Connecticut was considered antique country and neighbors wondered how an establishment with emphasis on the contemporary could survive. title: L.I. Fishermen Attack Plan on PCB
description: RIVERHEAD, LI., May 20Fishermen and political leaders in Suffolk County are alarmed over a Federal move to lower the legal limit of PCB pollutants in fish caught off Suffolk's East End and are seeking ways to delay the proposed ruling or to keep it. from going into effect.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: ALTHOUGH James Herriot wrote two bestselling books about his experiences as a veterinarian among the quaint folk and cranky animals of Yorkshire, he's still a rural veterinarian. As he recently wrote his publisher, St. Martin's Press: Maybe I am crazy, but I just want to go on vetting and turning out a book now and again. still regard myself as a veterinarian who scribbles in his time.

title: Reynolds Price's play, Early Dark, will be published in July.
description: Reynolds Price's play, Early Dark, will be published in July.

title: 4 Suspects Seized in Bronx Chase
description: Four armed men who the police said took $2,300 in cash and $980 in food istamps from a poultrymarket operator were arrested last night following an extended chase by the police through the West Bronx and an exchange of gunfire.

title: The Emergency That Wasn't
description: HICKSVILLE THERE were no ice storms and no hurricanes in April, but the Long Island Lighting Company was acting as if there were. For one week last month, the utility went into its emergency operating procedure. The company took executives out of conferences, lawyers out of court, secretaries out of offices and braced for an emereencv that wasn't.

title: Letters: HairRaising Ride to a Hairdresser
description: To the Editor: Iris Ihde Frey's article, Shampoos for the Peripatetic (Travel Section, May 8), reminded me of an experience I had a number of years ago in Marrakesh, Morocco.

title: Soccer Standings
description: Dallas 2, Connecticut 0. Fort Lauderdale 2, Rochester 1, San Jose 1, Seattle 0. Washington 1, St. Louis 0.

title: The Best Blues For a Flower Border
description: Gardeners often bewail the fact that there are so few blue flowers for the garden. While it is true that there are comparatively few true blues, cobalt blues or ceruleans, there are many others in the blue spectrum in tones of mauve, lavenderblue, violet blue and purple. We treasure blue flowers in our garden for they tend to cool, soften and tone down strong, bright colors and Elda flaring is author of The Complete Book of Growing Plants From Seed. create shadowy effects to convey a sense of space or distance.

title: New York City Announces a Plan To Hire 300 Unemployed Artists
description: The Beame Administration announced yesterday that New York City, as part of a program of economic and cultural revitalization, would channel Federal Tunds to provide at least 300 jobs this summer for unemployed artists.

title: Ecology, Theology and Nuclear Power
description: On its face, the endless controversy over the proposed nuclear power plant at Seabrook, N. H., seems to typify the rising national tension between energy and environment. The private utility sponsors contend the plant is essential to meet New England's predicted electricity needs. Opponents argue that the plant would seriously alter the coastal environment (perhaps, some think, even attracting sharks). The controversy has already generated five years of hearings and reports. Early this month, 2,000 demonstrators descended on the site and their mass arrests drew national attention. Next Monday, hearings reopen before the Nuclear Regulatory Agency.

title: A. R. Mehran, Lucinda Kew Have Bridal
description: The marriage of Lucinda Watson Kew, a granddaughter of the late Thomas J. Watson, founder of the International Business Machines Corporation, to Alexander R. Mehran, an assistant treasurer of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, took place yesterday at the Round Hill Cornmunity Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Remembering the Matriarch Of Modern Dance
description: Every period recreates Isadora Duncan in its own image of freedom. A hundred years from her birth (on May 27) she is, more than ever, a Vivid example of the human capacity for breaking through restraints. She was not only a great dancer, and a social force, but a person who, seizing life with both hands, profoundly stirred the public's imagination. In fact, the legend of Isadoraher extravagant lifehas almost obscured her to us as an artist.

title: INTERVIEW
description: FEW things anger Santa DeGrosse, basically a patient woman, but insensitivity toward mental illness is one of them. If someone calls for help, you don't tell them to call back in six weeks, she said in a recent interview. If you can't take time to give someone who is desperate little hope, you don't belong in this business.

title: Where Grand Jury Means One Person
description: Available. Abraham Goldstein, Sterling Professor of Law at Yale, said single grand jurors raise questions about whether a sitting judge should be carrying out an investigation.

title: Hester Eggert, C. D. Weeden Are Married
description: Hester Harrington Eggert and Charles Douglas Weeden of New York were married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Arthur Hargate. He was assisted by the Right Rev. Frederic C. Lawrence, retired Suffragan Bishop of Massachusetts and greatuncle of the bride.

title: TONY AWARD NOMINATIONS!
description: Best Book, Musical: Vinnette Carroll Best Director, Musical: Vinnette Carroll Best Featured Actress, Musical: Delores Hall Best Choreographer: Talley Beatty.

title: V.S. Pritchett Himself
description: WE live in an age when a book called Modern Men of Letters would be as thin as Great Chinese Comedians or Famous Women Composers; and yet there are exceptions. The finished copies of his biography of Turgenev had just arrived; his essay on Gabriel Garcia Mtuquez was in the current issue of the New Statesman; the previous night the usually punctual ten o'clock news started 15 minutes late allow extra time for the TV adaptation of his story Blind Love, and that morning The London Times had described him in a review as truly venerable.

title: Mile Mark Equaled By Shadyside Trixie
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., May 21 Shadyside Trixie tied the Meadowlands track record for a mile tonight as he upset Oil Burner, a 25 favorite, and won the $35,000 Rivaltime Pace before 26,2255 fans.

title: Crash Course on Insurance
description: CRASH. The car behind me in the rushhour traffic slammed into my 11trunk. It rammed my car into the trunk of the car in front. We had both stopped at a red light. Confusion and daze. No injuries.

title: Pamela Cotter, Agent of Bank, Becomes Bride
description: In Our Lady Star of the Sea Roman Catholic Chapel on Governors Island at noon yesterday, Pamela Mary Cotter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Cotter of Cherry Hill, N.J., became the bride of William Andrew Cordingley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cordingley of Great Falls, Mont.

title: Marie Spring Dollison Is Wed
description: Marie Spring Dollison and Dean Allen Schlief were married yesterday at the home of the bride's father, George, Wheelock Spring Jr., in Goochland, Va. The bride, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a daughter also of the late Mrs. Spring. Mr. Schlief is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion R. Schlief of Detroit. His first marriage also ended in divorce.

title: GOVERNOR RACE GRIPS VIRGINIA DEMOCRATS
description: RICHMOND, May 21Gubernatorial politics in Virginia is a theater of combat viewed far more gravely than mere Presidential campaigns.

title: London, Catskills, Paris
description: JUDITH BURNLEY is an elegant writer, and The Wife is a truly intelligent book. Whether works as a novelrather than as a sketch, or long storyis debatable. It's the bare bones, with all the filler left this works to perfection because it deals mainly with ideas, moods and impressions, all rendered in lean, haunting prose. The characters, on the other hand, suffer from such a highly reduced presentation. They are almost invisible, except as the types they are meant to represent: Adam, the driven, ambitious husband; Zack, the prototypic academicianlover; Jonathan, husbandofthefriend, onenight (afternoon, actually) stand and, incidentally, father of the baby. In the center: Sarah Cornish, the young, privileged, journalistwife with a partially raised consciousness, from whose point of view the story is told.

title: Aemorial Seroices
description: MARTIIBANEZDr. Fellx. A fifth anniversary Memorial Mass in loving memory of Dr. Fellx Martilbanez will be offered at Saint Patrick's Cathedral at 10 A.M. on May 24th, 1917.

title: Round 1: The Budget
description: THE political sniping between Yonkers mayoral candidates began rapidly last week after the City Manager, Vincent R. Castaldo, proposed a $147,516,586 budget for the city. The proposal represents a nearly $14 million increase over last year's budget and will mean a 5.3 percent in realestate taxes. A property owner who last year paid $1,302 in taxes on property assessed at $15,000 wouldpeople were in a delicate financial condition, and he added: pay $1,372 in the coming fiscal year if the budget is adopted as is.

title: Ade1phi University Establishes School of Banking
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., May 21A new School of Banking and Money Management has been established at Ade1phi University here, Dr. Timothy W. Costello, Adelphi's president, has announced.

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Continuing last week's dissertation on Merchant's tokens, also known as store cards, the accompanying photograph shows another extraordinary piece that will interest many collectors.

title: Cotton Tradiffg Comes to Asia
description: HONG KONG  Traders in raw cotton futures are looking forward to a following of their new commodity exchange the first in Asiaby the actual spinners and weavers of the fiber in Hong Kong and throughout the Far East. Until now the only cotton futures market has been in New York.

title: Wald, Foe of War, Retires at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 21 (AP)To the beat of a bongo and the cheers of students, the Nobel Prizewinning biologist George Wald, an outspoken critic of the Vietnam War, retired from Harvard University. Dr. Wald, 70 years old, was given the bongo and a standing ovation after his last lecture yesterday.

title: L.I. Man's Ordeal in Mexican Drug Case Puts Focus on Behavior of U.S. Agents
description: MEXICO CITYEarly one morning little over five years ago, Cristina Diaz rolled over and nudged her husband, Raphael, as he slept in their tiny room at the Posada del Rey, a Cuernavaca hotel about 60 miles south of here. She was, she told him, about to give birth to their first child.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: In June 1963, President John F. Kennedy declared at American University. that the United States does not propose to conduct nuclear tests in the atmosphere so long as other states do not do so. President Kennedy's bold move broke the deadlock in the negotiaton with Russia for a limited nuclear test ban, and a treaty was agreed to within a few weeks.

title: The Botherer of Politicians Fights On
description: Jane S. Kelley has been bothering politicians and a lot of other people for a long time, with the result that New York State now has permanent personal registration, the county penitentiary has a system for education for shortterm prisoners and many suburban communities have adult schools modeled on the 11old program in Scarsdale.

title: Monmouth
description: FIRST$5,000, cl. 4YO and up, 6f.

title: Literary View
description: His prose blends rapture with lucidity; passion for scientific fact with an intensely sensuous reception of nature's details. The butterfly's pale yellow wings are adorned with little eyes encircled with the finest blue and crimson  a very brilliant rosary. The quill feathers of the sixfoothigh savanna crane, when in flight, creak as the joints or working of a vessel in a tempestuous sea. The language is at times recklessly personal. The goldfish's head is covered with a salads of an ultramarine blue. In a letter to Emerson a half century after the publication of the Travels, Thomas Carlyle would praise Bartram's style. for its wondrous kind of floundering eloquence.

title: Numbers Have Sharply Increased in the 70's
description: One of every 10 couples of childbearing age in the world now uses sterilization as a familyplanning method. Once regarded as an extreme and undesirable form of birth control, voluntary sterilization has become the contraceptive phenomenon of the 1970's. The trend is nowhere more evident than in the United States, where In 1973 the National Survey of Family Growth showed that nearly one four married couples using contraception relied on sterilization. The record numlier of sterilization performed since then suggests that this figure may now have grown to one in three.

title: Born to Please
description: VIVIEN LEIGH was a tragic heroine, chosen, blessed and abandoned by the gods. Obstinately throughout her life, she tried to control and defy her destiny; and to read her story is be inspired with pity and terror.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY homeowners do not realize that they can have running water around the outside of their houses without much difficulty. Using widely available and 11handle flexible plastic pipe, any 11yourselfer can install extra outdoor faucets, a utility sink on his patio or terrace, a backyard shower or a drinking fountain. Or he can run water lines to supply permanently installed lawn sprinklers, eliminating the need to drag wet hoses around several times a week.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: WASHINGTONLike their counterparts in the private sector, Government economic officials have been carefully scrutinizing the major economic indicators for April reported so far and have concluded they depict not only a rather strong overall tone in current business activity but also generally favorable prospects for the rest of the year.

title: Next Step on School Financing
description: IN 1954, the Supreme Court's landmark decision banning racial segregation in the schools shook American education to its roots by requiring, in effect, that no one be denied equal educational opportunity because of race.

title: United Press International HIGHJUMPER: Robin Yount of the Brewers leaping to avoid George Scott of Red Sox after completing double play at Boston Friday night. The Brewers won, 157.
description: United Press International HIGHJUMPER: Robin Yount of the Brewers leaping to avoid George Scott of Red Sox after completing double play at Boston Friday night. The Brewers won, 157.

title: President to Ask Broader System Of U.S. Alliances
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  President Carter has concluded that the system of Western alliances established after World War II under American leadership no loneer suffices to meet the challenge of international conditions. He intends to propose a broader international system in a sneech tomorrow.

title: PARKING METERS HURT BUSINESS, SAYS GOLDIN
description: New York City's parkingmeter system is threatening the existence of small businesses, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

title: Dublin To Galway
description: After bicycling for 38 miles we really appreciated Mrs. McCormack's hospitality. She took us into her living room and offered a bath in the large oldfashioned bathroom. She even commiserated with me over my scratched ankle and general exhaustion.

title: Hanoi Publishes Nixon 73 Letter About $3 Billion in Postwar Aid
description: HANOI, Vietnam, May 21 (Agence FrancePresse)The Foreign Ministry tonight made public a letter in which former President Richard M. Nixon told Prime Minister Pham Van Dong of projected $3.25 billion in postwar reconstruction aid.

title: FINANCIAL PROBLEMS HIT BENNETT COLLEGE
description: School in Millbrook, N.Y., Petitions for Financial Reorganization Despite Wealthy Alumnae.

title: The Case That Will Not Die
description: They were put to death in the electric chair at Charlestown Prison at midnight on the 23rd of August, 1927, a desolate dark midnight, a night for perpetual remembrance and mourning. So writes Katherine Anne Porter in her toughminded yet moving reminiscence, in the Atlantic Monthly, of the unsuccessful campaign to save Sacco and Vanzetti. That night, a good shoemaker and a poor fish peddler, as Bartolomeo Vanzetti described Nicola Sacco and himself, were executed for the 1920 murder of a paymaster and a guard in South Braintree, Mass. Their case, the overriding liberal and radical cause of the time has never died.

title: DINING OUT
description: IF you dine at a normal hour, you may have trouble setting foot in Poseidon I in Little Neck, Queensat least until a proposed expansion into the adjacent store is completed. The entry is tiny, with space for a few standees, leaving a scant passageway for departing patrons.

title: Those Old Oaken Barrels
description: THOSE fellows with the folksy names and the rural Kentucky and Tennessee addresses who reluctantly part with their 11silk bourbon whisky have a byproduct that is proving something of a bonanza for an enterprising Putnam County executive of a lumbersupply chain.

title: MATERNITY PAY LIMIT OF 8 WEEKS BACKED 2BY ALBANY LEADERS
description: ALBANY, May 21Leaders of both houses of the New York Legislature have agreed to an eightweek limit on disability benefits that pregnant women may claim from their employers under the Workmen's Compensation Law.

title: ART
description: IN a retrospective exhibition of Giorgio Cavallon's paintings at the Neuberger Museum of the State University College at Purchase, there are two worlts that startle for their conspicuous difference: They are the only examples in a show of 65 entries that do not have any discernible white in them. One, done in the late 1930's, is a mosaic of many colors, some bright and others mild and soft, but no white. Another, painted in 1963, pays homage to a spectrum of bronze.

title: Pick up your free House Color Coordinator today at:
description: Pick up your free House Color Coordinator today at:

title: If You Go
description: Ixtapa presently has two hotels. The rates for El Presidente Las Palmas are $42 to $45 double, $36 to $37.50 single, European plan. For modified American plan, add $11.25 per person. At the Aristos, double rooms are $36, singles $32.50, European plan. For M.A.P., add $12 per person.

title: Deregulation's Foggy Future
description: WASHINGTONLike two planes about to land on the same airstrip at the same time, two great forces of governmental policy seem to be on a collision course.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Several months ago this column discussed early pianos and their role in the music of Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven. It is a problem very much on the minds of literate musicians today. For those three composers wrote piano music for an instrufe ment that was a long way from today's modern concert grand. They heard a different sound in their ears; they were accustomed to a different kind of piano action; and Limy wrote accordingly. Thus no piano today, unless it is a replica of the fortepianothe instrument used before the romantics came alongcan give a true idea of piano music throueh Beethoven.

title: Richmond To Boston
description: Every bicycle tour has its psychological (as well as topographical) ups and downs. Psychologically, this onealong the full length of the East Coast Bicycle Trail, which winds some 860 miles between Richmond, Va., and Bostonwas mostly ups. The weather was excellent, and headwinds, a cyclist's nightmare, were never a problem. The only serious mechanical trouble was a broken rear gearchangerwhich occurred two level miles from a bike shop. I experienced no harassment from motorists, and I had to spray only four menacing dogs with my can of Halt, a nontoxic irritant.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Thirty seconds. It flashes on the little screen, an interruption in a morning quiz show or an afternoon soap opera. A pretty little blonde girl, the picture of innocence, is having tea with her do'l to the accompaniment of soft music and the dulcet patter of an announcer. Suddenly the camera's vision shifts to reveal that the doll's arm has been twisted off. The child's face is distorted now and she's screaming hateful epithets at the toy. Finally there's a large view of a glistening paperback cover featuring a doll with a severed arm while the announcer sonorously declares that innocence dies so easily, evil lives again and again  and again. It's all over in just half a minute and the tube is back to its routine of quiz shows and soap opera.

title: Navy Aide Wins Award for Invention
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (UPI)President Carter has presented a cash award to Lawrence I. Guzick, assistant director of aircraft carriers for the Navy, for saving the taxpayers $10.5 million with his invention of a steam trap device. Mr. Guzick, a Brooklyn native, received a $25,000 award last week.

title: His Name, But Hers to Keep
description: CHICAGO, May 21 (UPI)A judge here has ruled that a divorced or widowed woman who remarries does not have to give up the last name of her first husband.

title: Hoagy Carmichael Weds Actress
description: PALM DESERT, Calif., May 21 (UPI)Hoagy Carmichael, 77 years old, the com poser, was married yesterday to Wanda McKay, 52, an actress, ending a 15year courtship, friends said.

title: A Correction
description: In the letters section of the Westchester Weekly for May 15, Raymond J. Langley was wrongly identified. He is vice president for academic affairs at Manhattanville College.

title: Who Cares Whose Name Goes on Top? Everybody!
description: Merman and Martin wanted it that way. That was the explanation I received to my query about the unique billing of the stars names in an advertisement that appeared in this section of The Times last Feb. 27. The advertisement heralded the first appearance together on Broadway of Ethel Merman and Mary Martin (or should it be Mary Martin and Ethel Merman?), in a benefit performance for the Friends of the Theater and Music Collection of the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: William Humphrey's memoir, Farther Off From Heaven7

title: Carter Disciplines Gen. Singlaub, Who Attacked His Policy on Korea
description: WASHINGTON, May 21  President Carter today ordered the reassignment of a general who publicly criticized his plan to withdraw United Slates troops from South Korea.

title: Subway Murder
description: One of the more puzzling New York City subway crimes occurred the evening of Feb. 1, 1975, when a 25yearold mother of three children was pushed to instant death under an onrushing train by a man who apparently was a total stranger to her. A transit policeman arrested John R. Heiberg, 43, after witnesses in the Brooklyn IND station had pursued the suspect.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE recommendation began: It's a great place to go if you suddenly decide you don't feel like cooking. Praise went on from there, but that first thought was still the key. It the restaurant turned out to be as good and as inexpensive as promised, we knew we'd be on to something many busy suburbanites were looking for.

title: Korean Dissidents in Washington Report Threats by Seoul's Agents
description: WASHINGTON, May 21The South Korean Central Intelligence Agency appears to have resumed a campaign of threats against Korean residents of the United States who are critical of President Park Chung Hee's Government.

title: Food
description: One of the most unforgettable discussions we ever engaged in took place while mussel gathering one gray day on Duxbury Bay in Massachusetts with C. Graham Hurlburt, who in addition to being director of administrative services at Harvard University is also an expert on the edible blue mussel and experiments in its cultivation. The thing that really intrigued us was the gentleman's comparison of mussels and Tbone steaks. The protein content of mussels and steak is, he informed us, practically the same. Steak, however, has four times more calories than mussels and 18 times more fat. How, we've been pondering ever since, can anything so positively nutritious be so positively delectable. Here is a sampling of recipes using that eminently edible, eminently delicious and eminently nutritious blus mussel.

title: NEW YORK PRISONS CURB OPPOSITESEX GUARDS
description: Male guards will no longer stripfrisk female inmates, according to new rules of New York State's Correctional Services Department made public on Thursday.

title: Engagements
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee M. Landis of Glen Rock, N.I. announce the engagement of their daughter, Tina Patricia to Barry Jay Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Levine of Silver Springs, Maryland.

title: Maryland IC4A Victor; McLean Outruns Belger
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21  Tom McLean won another oneonone duel today, but it was on a track, not a playground.

title: Patricia Ann McKegney Is Married to Philip C. Dunn
description: Patricia Ann McKegney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Osborne McKegney of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Westhampton, L.T., was married yesterday afternoon to Philip Campbell Dunn, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Franklyn Dunn of Middletown. Conn.

title: Hallberg Wins NorthSouth
description: PINEHURST, N.C., May 21Gary Hallberg. playing with skill far beyond his 18 years, shot threeunderpar golf over 33 holes today and beat Mike Donald, 5 and 3, in the final of the North and South amateur golf tournament.

title: Horse Shows
description: Medal ClassJeanette Spivak, Gladstone, N.J. Maclay TrophyMissy Ellemon, Mendham, N.J.

title: Profs to Share Profits
description: HEMPSTEAD IN what may be the first labor agreement of its kind in American higher education, Hofstra University and its faculty members are now operating under a contract that, among other things, will reward teachers for increases in the school's enrollment.

title: A Peculiar Institution
description: IN NEW LONDON, the state is now reinvestigating the 11run death of a young man named Kevin Showalter, a crime that some have charged was covered up to protect locally prominent person.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: Today  Eastern Metropolitan Racing Association twohour enduro race at Bridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit; practice at 1 P.M.; race at 2:30.

title: GARDENING
description: MY FAVORITE New Jersey garden is really a series of gardens. It is Skylands, once owned by Clarence M. Lewis, a wealthy horticulturist and plant collector lie brought in rare plants from all over the world and, with his staff of 50 or more experts, created a collection of fantastic gardens on a 1,300acre estate in the peaceful hills of Passaic County.

title: Hershey Services on Wednesday
description: WASHINGTON (AP)Funeral services will be held Wednesday for Lewis B. Hershey, the fourstar general who supervised the drafting of 14 million Americans in three wars. After services at Fort Myer, Va., Memorial Chapel, General Hershey will be buried in Arlington National Cemetery. The general died yesterday at the age of 83.

title: Lynne Anne Stanton, Richard B. Boardman Set July 23 Wedding
description: Lynne Anne Stanton, a teacher in Newton, Mass., and Richard Browning Boardman, director of development at the Groton (Mass.) School, plan to be married July 23 in St. John's Chapel at Groton.

title: Mara Kenney Married to William B. Petersen
description: Jean Marie Kenney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kenney of New York and Spring Lake, N.J., was married at noon yesterday to William Blaine Petersen, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Petersen of Littleton, Colo. Msgr. John Grimes performed the ceremony in St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake.

title: Bittersweet Moment Nears at Briarcliff
description: BRIARCLIFF COLLEGE'S last graduating class will be receiving its diplomas this week while faculty members and their lawyers are in Albany, seeking to convince the State Board of Regents that the sale to Pace University requires investigation.

title: Liquor Authority Head Stops Discotheque's Music
description: The head of the State Liquor Authority, Michael Roth, conducted a sort of oneman raid early yesterday and had one of the newest and most popular discothques in the city, Studio 54, closed for selling liquor without a license.

title: Edward Hoagland is an essayist and novelist who was recently in the Sudan for The New Yorker.
description: Edward Hoagland is an essayist and novelist who was recently in the Sudan for The New Yorker.

title: JOHN GRIERSON, AUTHOR AND AVIATION PIONEER
description: John Grierson, a British aviation pioneer and author, died after a stroke Friday night at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He had been visiting the United States in connection with celebrations commemorating the transAtlantic flight of Charles A. Lindbergh.

title: New Jersey/This Week;THEATER
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East Orange Endgame. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through June 18). $3.90$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90 ; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: Mr. Carter and His Aides Seem Determined to Take Away the Mystery
description: WASHINGTONPeriodically in this century there have been reforms of the tax system, reforms that always seemed in the end to make tax forms more complicated, tax loopholes more varied and tax lawyers more wealthy. The tax system, like Mount Everest, is a challenge by its very presence. Reform was thus understandably high among the campaign promises of President Carter, who called the tax system a disgrace to the human race and promised to simplify it, to make it fairer and to focus it more purposefully on producing economic growth and jobs.

title: Temps: The Help That's Here to Stay
description: What do the Easter Bunny, a typist, a gas station attendant and Santa Claus have in common? They are all likely to be temporary workers.

title: Elizabeth Gary Becomes Bride
description: Elizabeth Hitch Gary, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edson Gary of South Norwalk, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Nicholas Sible Young of New York, son of Woodbury Lew Young of Bradenton, Fla., and the late Mrs. Youne.

title: Princeton to See Two Sleeping Beauties
description: DANCING the role of the en chanted Princess Aurora, Karen Russo, a 11old South Brunswick High School student, will age 200 years next Saturday. She will awaken not once, but twice, from 100year naps as the star of a double performance of The Sleeping Beauty.

title: Michigan Wins Tennis Title
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 21 (AP)Michigan captured its 10th consecutive Big Ten tennis title today with 70 points. Indiana was a distant second with 40.

title: English Cocker Spaniel Named Best of 1,750 Dogs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 21Ch. Buff Tip of Broomleaf, a red English cocker spaniel owned by Mrs. Collier Platt of Syosset, L.I., was the best of 1,750 dogs tonight at the 71st allbreed show staged by the Ladies Kennel Association of America at Hofstra University.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY homeowners do not realize that they can have running water around the outside of their houses without much difficulty. Using widely available and 11handle flexible plastic pipe, any 11yourselfer can install extra outdoor faucets, a utility sink on his patio or terrace, a backyard shower or a drinking fountain. Or he can run water lines to supply permanently installed lawn sprinklers, eliminating the need to drag wet hoses around several times a week.

title: Nancy Rath Bride Of Robert A.Nigro, An Investment Aide
description: Nancy Prosser Rath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Stearns Rath of New York and Litchfield, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Lawrence A. Nigro of Yardley, Pa., the Rev. Cannon Earl S. Estabrook performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield.

title: The Horse Next Door
description: GILBERT BERGEN, supervisor of Connetquot River State Park, waxes philosophic: As one old Englishman said, The outside of a horse is good for the inside of a man.

title: Quest for Intrepid Funds Reaches Critical Stage
description: Intrepid's chances of competing again this summer for the honor of defending the America's Cup for a record third time are still alive. The emergence last week of a prospect who has promised a substantial contribution sustained the hopes of Gerry Driscoll, the San Diego skipper in charge of Intrepid, to bring the 10yearold 12Meter yacht East to Newport, R.I., for the trial races this summer.

title: Meadowlands
description: FIRST$11,000, pace, mile.

title: A Shrine to a Craftsman
description: THE tang of wood smoke wafts from the copper hood over the fireplace. Thick wooden beams stretch low above the 1160foot living room. A stylized S arches up the banister. The little balcony off the master bedroom overlooks the pond, the curving path and the flowering shrubs.

title: FOOD
description: GERI Harrington plants root vegetables in her gently sloping garden in Wilton, harvests bushels of them and turns them into dishes that range from soups to desserts. Summer Garden, Winter Kitchen (Atheneum, 1976 $9.95) tells how. At one time she thought of calling her book something like Roots. I guess I missed the boat on that one, she said.

title: Nails Differ in More Than Tust Their Size
description: When a home handyman or handywoman goes in to a local hardware store or lumberyard to buy some nails, the only selection he or she nail required for the job at hand, and possibly deciding what type of head the nails should have (common nails with conventional head, or finishing nails which have practically no head).

title: POLL SHOWS ENERGY PLAN HASN'T INJURED PRESIDENT
description: Contrary to his predictions, public reaction to President Carter's proposed energy plan has not caused his popularity to drop according to the Gallup Poll.

title: West German Football
description: Bayern Munich 2, Borussia Moonchengladbech 2.

title: A New Work by Miss McIntyre, Journey to Forever, a Bad Trip
description: The numbing monotony of Dianne McIntyre's dance concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday was relieved only on those infrequent occasions in which distinguished music was used as accompaniment. For the most part, unhappily, Miss McIntyre relied on group compositions prepared by Ahmed Abdullah Babafumi Akunyun, Doug Hammond and Mustafa Abdul Rahim.

title: Lieut. Patricia Anderson Wed to Paul Nugent Jr.
description: First Lieut. Patricia Mary Elizabeth Anderson, Army Nurse Corps, was married yesterday noon to Paul Michael Nugent Jr., who is entering his third year at the Columbus School of Law of the Catholic University of America.

title: The Nation
description: Richard Nixon has uncontritely offered a justfication for the conduct that led to the article of impeachment charging him with abuse of Presidential power. Mr. Nixon contended, in another of his televised interviews, that his efforts to spy upon domestic dissidents were necessary to end the war in Vietnam and that such acts were inherently legal when ordered by a President.

title: Jane Edwards Married To Gordon Walker Jr.
description: Jane Spenser Edwards and Gordon Beverley Moore Walker Jr., doctoral candidates at the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Bradford Hastings, rector of Christ Episcopal Church there. The garden ceremony took place at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walker.

title: Parisians Build For Mothers And the Aged
description: PARISWhat sells like hotcakes in a market where building costs are high and credit hard to get? In Paris, the answer seems to be a new sort of luxurious housing.

title: FILM VIEW
description: At the start of the next century it may well be possible to look back on these years of the 1970's and identify this very particular periodif not as the turning point from the Old Movie to the New, then as the time when New Movies began to supplement Old in such number that it wasn't always easy to tell them apart. The situation is disorienting. To experience some current movies is to go scubadiving in murky water. Which way is up?

title: Tracy C. Freeman Is Married
description: Tracy Clark Freeman, daughter of Mr. ano Mrs. Harry Bolt Freeman Jr. of New York, was married yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church to Stephen Lee Baldwin, son of Melvin James Baldwin of Lookout Mountain, Tenn., and the late Mrs. Baldwin. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Knickerbocker Club.

title: Annaud: From TV Commercials to Oscar
description: LONDON Since winning his Academy Award for the best foreignlanguage film of 1976, JeanJacques Annaud has enjoyed telling people that before Black and White in Color, the longest movie he had ever directed ran for all of 36 seconds. In fact, he exaggerates. When pressed, he will admit he once made one that lasted a full three minutes.

title: Sarah Whitehead Bride

The Rev. Peter Jacobs performed the ceremony in Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Chrystine W. Jones Married to Kempf Hogan
description: Chrystine Wellman Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Jones of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married there yesterday evening to Kempf Hogan, son of Mrs. Romani G. Hogan of Birmingham, Mich. and Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Hogan.

title: Cornell, Hopkins in Lacrosse Final
description: ITHACA, N.Y., May 21The defending champion, Cornell, tuned up for next Saturday's championship game with Johns Hopkins by beating Navy, 226, today in National Collegiate Atliletic Association Division One lacrosse playoff action.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: IT was not a state of affairs to be lovingly documented by our mainstream Puritan tradition, which feared nature as Satan's ally and believed that God dwelled exclusively in town: The forests resounded for hundreds of miles with the converse of wild turkeys, 15pound trout abounded in our streams alongside the 11long brown spotted garr; the eightfoot wing span of the savanna crane shadowed our marshes, and the great softshelled tortoise, 30 pounds in weight, lumbered in our ponds. Tigers, bears and great bald eagles still preyed in the areas of our Southeast presently named Georgia, Florida, the Carolinas.

title: Seattle Slew Captures 102d Preakness by 1 Lengths
description: BALTIMORE, May 21  Leaving others to decide whether he's a great horse or just a very good one, undefeated Seattle Slew gave a record crowd of 77,346 at Pimlico at least a partial clue today while winning the eighth race of his illustrious career.

title: Morristown's Brady Bunch
description: The partition split the entrance hall and ran up the stairs to the landing, where the steps branch right and left. It stopped right against the middle of the Tiffany window. We removed the partition first thing.

title: Manchester United Beats Liverpool in Final, 2 to 1
description: WEMBLEY, England, May 21 (UPI)Manchester United, runnerup in 1976, destroyed Liverpool's triple title dream today by defeating the oddson favorite, 21, in the English Football Association Cup final before a capacity crowd of 100,000 at Wembley Stadium.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THESE are uncertain times, when the old established order of the household seems to be vanishing in a blizzard of morning goodbyes. The husband says goodbye and heads for the office. The children say goodbye and head for school. The wife says goodbye as she heads to her job. That is the unsettling thing. Wives often have work of their own and there is no one to say goodbye to in many homes.

description: Newgate Callendar conducts the Book Review's Crime column.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: MANY homeowners do not realize that they can have running water around the outside of their houses without much difficulty. Using widely available and 11handle flexible plastic pipe, any 11yourselfer can install extra outdoor faucets, a utility sink on his patio or terrace, a backyard shower or a drinking fountain. Or he can run water lines to supply permanently installed lawn sprinklers, eliminating the need to drag wet hoses around several times a week.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: EVERY year at this time, an endangered species comes out of its winter hiding in search of things green. You will see them on the best golf courses in New Jersey.

title: Neil Diamond Charges Dropped
description: LOS ANGELES, May 21 (UPI)MariJuana possession charges against Neil Diamond, the singer, were dropped yesterday. A Municipal Court judge ruled the Mr. Diamond had successfully come plated a sixmonth drug education program, as ordered, and the charges were dismissed. Sheriff's deputies found an ounce of marijuana in the singer's home last June.

title: Africa Document Rejected by West
description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, May 21 (Reuters)A United Nations conference on southern Africa ended here today with Western nations refusing to endorse parts of documents containing sweeping measures to isolate white minority governments and persuade them to accept majority rule.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: SOMETIMES there are only a few bemused tourists in the gallery, and maybe just a couple of dozen Congressmen on the floor, when something big is going on in the House of Representatives.

description: Linda Ann Schwartzsteln, who expects to receive an LL.M. degree in taxation this June from the New York University Graduate School of Law, and Lee Martin Goodwin, a lawyer with Miller & Chevalier, Washington law firm, will be married in June.

title: School Financing: Search for Equity
description: LAST MONTH, the Connecticut Supreme Court ruled that the system of financing public schools in the stategargely through local property taxes was unconstitutional because it denied equal educational opportunities to children in poorer communities. The landmark rulingHorton v. Meskilldid not suggest an ternative system, nor did it set a deadline for a system to replace local financing of education.

description: In some respects Margaret Stehlin's current home resembles the 10room house where she lived until four years ago. The spacious living room is furnished with the same thick carpet and large sofa. In the yard, the retired woman keeps a garden, much as she always did.

title: GARDENING
description: T HERE is one rule in the garden that is above all others: You must give to nature more than you take. Obey it, and the earth will provide you in glorious abundance. These words of Alan Chadwick, a horticultural teacher, were the theme of an extraordinary workshop held recently at the Connecticut Audubon Society in Fairfield.

title: Common Market Tries to Narrow a Multitude of Technical Specifications
description: In eight of the nine Common Market countries, tractors are allowed to travel on public roads at speeds faster than 25 kilometers an hour. But in West Germany they are not. Executives at Ford Tractor Operations, Europe, estimate that this small difference in national laws adds $345,000 a year to the company's European manufacturing costs. And a British machinery manufacturer complains that his company must be able to turn out products that can meet any of 3 million different European government specifications.

title: Floridians Gain in Drive to Force FillingIn of Canal 48 Miles Long
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 21Florida environmentalists, who in 1971 stopped the construction of the Cross Florida Barge Canal, are mounting a campaign to dismantle another project of the Army Corps of Engineers, a 48mile canal along the Kissimmee River in central Florida.

title: BRIDGE
description: The 1977 world team championship in Manila is still six months away but it promises to be a most dramatic contest. For the first time in four years the United States will have two teams, one to represent the North American zpne and one as a result of the American victory in Monte Carlo a year ago. But the team that won on that occasion has split up.

description: Beatrice Buckler, the founding editor of Working Woman magazine, has resigned her positionending an acrimonious fight for control of the magazine between her and J. Jay Frankel, the financial promoter who helped start the publication last year.

title: Woosnam Foresees Bigger Big Time
description: Phil Woosnam, the commissioner of the North American Soccer League, has high aspirations for soccer and the N.A.S.L. In a recent interview he said, I am totally confident that soccer will be the biggest sport in this country and that the United States will be the world center of soccer. Woosnam, in his ninth year of directing the fortunes of a league that went from 17 teams to five and is now back up to 19 franchises, predicted that the N.A.S.L. would grow to 32 teams by 1985 and that each franchise would have a value equal to that of a comparable franchise in the National Football League.

description: ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP)Al Hrabosky, St. Louis pitcher, was suspended indefinitely today by the Cardinals manager, Vern Rapp, in what the tempestuous reliever termed a personality conflict.

title: ART
description: IN a retrospective exhibition of Giorgio Cavallon's paintings at the Neuberger Museum of the State University College at Purchase, there are two works that startle for their conspicuous difference: They are the only examples in a show of 65 entries that do not have any discernible white in them. One, done in the late 1930's, is a mosaic of many colors, some bright and others mild and soft, but no white. Another, painted in 1963, pays homage to a spectrum of bronze.

description: Fearful of being punished economically because of their success in selling color television sets in America, Japanese TV makers agreed last week to sharply reduce their shipments for three years.

(1appointed psychiatrists get up to $75 an hour, and many parents bring in their own psychiatrists and pediatricians to testify.)

title: At 55, Activism Is Still Her Motto
description: DR. EMILY ALMAN has no time for old age. She plans, in fact, to skip it. My new sense of total immortality, Dr. Alman said in a recent interview, tells me that I'm going to have to settle for an instant onehour old age right before life ends.

title: Oral History Is Beyond The Stage Of Talking
description: What memories that man carries to oblivion, and how absolutely they are lost, the late historian Allan Nevins of Columbia University used to say to himself when he read the obituaries of famous men. And so, in 1938, he proposed the creation of a project to obtain from the lips and papers of living Americans who have led significant lives a fuller record of their participation in the political, ecoAomic and cultural life of the last 60 years.

description: TWO special legislative committees have undertaken to find out how government works, but one problem they should look at, but probably will not, is the way some state employees treat the public.

title: CARLOS LACERDA, 63, BRAZILIAN POLITICIAN
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21 (Reuters)Carlos. Lacerda. a writer and publisher and one of Brazil's most influential politicians between 1954 and 1968, died in a hospital here today of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: What is so particularly painful about Tennessee Williams's Vieux Carr is that, if you listen carefully enough to penetrate the appalling stage direction that has been imposed upon it, and if you disregard totally the monstrously shabby physical design that is supposed to represent a rooming house in New Orleans, and ifbeyond these things you are willing to tolerate the aimlessness of the playwright's own structure, you can hear his voice.

description: To the Editor: It is churlish indeed for an author to protest to an editor who has placed his book at the top of Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy list. But the listing was alphabetical, and if I am a churl, so be it.

description: Lizbeth Tate Binks and Dr. Robert Kimball Kritzler were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Robert Dresser in St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford. Conn.

Ferrer 3d, who is an associate with the New York law firm of Battle, Fowler, Lidstone, Jaffin, Pierce & Kheel, were married yesterday in the Noroton (Conn.) Presbyterian Church by, the Rev. Edward Danks.

title: The Begin Factor
description: Thirty years of Labor Party domination of politics and power in Israel have come abruptly and surprisingly to an end with a national election that puts the Israeli Government in the hands of the Likud, an ultraconservative bloc of parties, and its strident leader, Menahem Begin. With that change come inevitable and profound effects on all of the Middle East, and on the chances for meaningful negotiations leading to peace talks.

title: Obstacles for Television
description: ABC Sports, televising its first Preakness had to use engineering supervisors and other management people as a result of a continuing strike by technicians. The strikers, limited by court injunction to pickets at one gate, made no effort to interfere with the national telecast.

title: What's Doing in RIO DE JANEIRO
description: OVERVIEWFor some years now, Rio de Janeiro has witnessed a relative decline in political and economic importance. The capital has been moved more than 600 miles inland to Brasilia, and with it has gone the power, influencemongering and juicy political gossipBrazilians call it fofocathat Rio once monopolized. Siio Paulo has emerged as a far more important industrial, commercial and financial center, and even a lesser city like Belo. Horizonte appears to be expanding rapidly. Yet Rio remains the country's pleasure capitalas the place where most affluent Brazilians would live if they could, A gigantic and continuing real estate boom has transformed its skyline. Copacabana, once considered a suburb, has no room for new buildings and could easily be mistaken for the downtown area. Virtually no private houses remain in Ipanema; the spanking new luxury apartments there are among the most expensive in the worldsome of them selling for $1,000,000 or more. In general, the city has moved southward along the Atlantic coast. cast Ccpscablna, Ipanema and Leblon, through and around the junglecovered mountains, and on to vast stetches of oncesecluded beach. Many, if not most, of the residents of the new condominium communities have moved to Rio in recent years after making their fortunes elsewhere. The Cariocasas the Rio natives call themselvesare now a minority. But the newer residents quickly take on the Carioca personality: the capacity to linger endlessly at the bar or on the beach; the ability to project a carefree image even when they are, in fact, working hard.

title: Margo Field Is Bride Of Scott A. Rogers 3d
description: Margo Moore Field, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Field of Weston and Annisquam, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Scott Arthur Rogers 3d, sort of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Somewhere behind the shoulder of everyone who writes about art there stands the intimidating figure of John Ruskin. How much he wrote, and how well he wrote! How early (at the age of 16) did he fix upon J.M.W. Turner, the painter whom destiny called upon him to defend, and with what a prodigious eloquence did he set about it! How vast was his audience, and how devoted! People would work for Ruskin, and stint for Ruskin, and all but starve for Ruskin, in ways for which our own era has no parallel.

title: Hagen's Legacy: Humor, Great Golf
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 21He was witty practical joker, he addressed princes as Kid, and for his fellow golf professionals he forced open the doors of clubhouses.

description: Cincinnati 8, New York 7 (twi.)

title: Decent Men in Trouble
description: WHEN Elmore Leonard's FiftyTwo Pickup appeared in 1974, it had some critics talking in terms of Raymond Chandler and Ross Macdonald. Swag in 1976 indicated that Leonard's first book was no mere accident. A new and important writer of mystery fiction had arrived. Now comes Unknown Man No. 89, and it maintains the high standard Leonard has set for himself.

title: Automobile Insurance: The Fault With NoFault
description: THE article, What Price Car Insurance? by Ronald W. Spevack (May 1), is the sort of thing that breeds public misin formation. Mr. Spevack states that the proponents of the 1973 New Jersey nofault automobile insurance legislation intended to alleviate all problems related to automobile insurance.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: The worderful exhibition of some of the contents of Tutanldiamun's tomb will be traveling about the United States until 1979. In Washington, D.C. the waiting time at the National Gallery was about four hours, and there is every reason to expect it will be the same in the five other cities it will visit. My suggestion, if you plan to see it, is to provide yourself with the three available books on the subject and begin your study of the contents of the 3,200year old tomb in the Nile Valley of the Kings as you inch your way toward the gallery.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: ELMSFORDCamelot. Tuesday to Suhday (through July 17). Opens at 6:15 P.M., dinner at 7 P.M., show at 8:30 P.M. Sundays one. hour earlier. Special concerts on Mondays. An Evening Dinner Theater, 11 Clearbrook Rd. $15.50 to $17.50. Reservations. 5922222.

title: Overplanting Brightens a Groundcover
description: There are ways to add color to a garden in spite of extensive groundcover. My solution is overplanting. The results have brought bloom to areas where no flowers would grow. Maintenance is easy once the basic soil preparation is accomplished.

title: Homecountry, East Texas
description: THE classic laments of man are older than the cavesPain, Hunger. Death and Solitude. But 20thcentury America has invented what seems a new cryMy parents didn't love meand the cry has preempted a very wide band on our psychic airwaves, not only because we believe to describe a credible and deplorable deprivation but also because we accept it as universal alibi: Since my parents didn't love me, how can I be expected to love you? Or to brush my teeth? Or pull up my socks and acknowledge that an external world exists and requires my competence? Is there anyone alive in middleclass America who has not at least once joined some mate in a gratifying bath of tears comprehension at the mutual discovery that all our woes are assessable to themparents who weaned us on the gruel of neglect? How odd by comparison to notice that only one of the Ten Commandments concerns parents and children, that it exhorts children to honor their parents (not vice versa) in the hope of long life on the land God gives; and that almost none of the world's literature before Dickens sounds the child's complaint.

title: EnglewoodDisputed Parkland
description: THE sweet sounds of This Land Is Your Land floated over the Blackberry Meadow a couple of Sundays ago as Cathie Ruppi, trail guide, and her guitar led a crowd of 50 or so on a folksing nature walk through Flat Rock Brook Park in Englewood.

title: A Mix of Art, Politics and Sex
description: WRILE it is of course impossible to discuss the literature of the 30's, whether in England or the United States, apart from the literary movement of the left in that decade, an unavowed bias in relation to the radical politics of that time is likely to result in mystifying sympathies or animosities, strange omissions, disturbing emphases. In the case of Samuel Hynes's book, it even helps to account for the fact that the promise of its title and subtitle isn't fulfilled.

title: But the CollectiveSecurity Principle Is Intact
description: TEHERAN, IranOf all his diplomatic travels this month, the visit by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance to the headquarters of the Central Treaty Organization seemed the least significant. Why did Mr. Vance fly thousands of miles to attend meetings of what amounts to a diplomatic artifact, a relic of the ice age of the early cold war?

title: Land Of the Lobster
description: There's a reason why several generations of artists have favored the southern coast of Maine for their summer work. The reason becomes clear with just one stroll along the Marginal Way, in the coastal, village of Ogunquit, a milelong paved path that follows a jagged route in and out of high, dense bushes, affording a series of splendid aerial views of the rocky shoreline and the gleaming Atlantic.

If the restaurant turned out to be as good and as inexpensive as promised, we knew we'd be on to something many busy suburbanites were looking for.

title: Gottfried Trails Gerulaitis as Match Is Called
description: ROME, May 21 (AP)Antonino Zugarelli of Italy beat Phil Dent of Australia, 6.4, 57, 64, 62, in the semifinals of the $150,000 Italian open tennis championships today. The claycourt match took nearly four hours.
