description: Kathleen McCahey and Larry Allan Lechner plan to be married in Chicago on July 3d. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. James B. McCahey Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Vail, Colo.

title: Call Brings Ride for
description: IT ISN'T often, perhaps, that a 1975 Buick station wagon with 27,000 miles and a temperamental transmission is considered a godsend, but to the participants of CallARide, a free transportation service for elderly Greenwich residents, the word couldn't be more appropriate.

title: John Lahr has just completed the biography the English playwright Joe Orton, Prick Up Your Ears.
description: John Lahr has just completed the biography the English playwright Joe Orton, Prick Up Your Ears.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: One unanticipated consequence of the recent growth of interest in old photographs deserves to be noted: It has sent librarians searching through their stacks to see what treasures might be hidden there. The library at Princeton University recently displayed a selection of photo graphically illustrated books gathered from its various divisions. Now The New York Public Library has mounted a similar exhibition organized by Julia van Haaften of the Department of Art and Architecture and entitled Original Sun Pictures. It will be on view in the main lobby of the Library's main building at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street through July 30.

title: Checking Out Freud's Ideas
description: FREUD is generally recognized as a genius who, more than any other psychological theorist, has altered 20thcentury man's conception of himself. Yet, most of his hypotheses were advanced on slender evidence and put forward such a way that their confirmation or refutation has proved difficult. This has led such eminent figures as Karl Popper and Peter Medawar to dismiss the whole psychoanalytic structure as nugatory, on the grounds that, unlike hypotheses in the hard sciences, psychoanalytic theories cannot be disproven.

title: CRIME
description: Last September, Simon Brett's Cast in Order of Disappearance was published. It was an engaging British import about show business and a veteran actor who solves a murder. His name was Charles Paris, and he returns in SO MUCH BLOOD (Scribner's, $6.95). This time he is giving a oneman show at the Edinburgh Festival, and while he is kibitzing during a rehearsal an actor is stabbed by a stage.

title: Port Chester: Scandal in Air?
description: FOR the last several months, a Federal grand jury has been hearing evidence on conditions in Port Chester, and there is some speculation around town that a major corruption scandal is about to burst on the scene.

title: Best Sellers
description: FICTION

title: If You Go
description: If you are traveling with children, pack games, puzzles and books, as well as soft animals to sleep with and other personal necessities. took one fat paperback book for myself, which I swapped for other books and magazines along the way. Preaddressed postcards and their notebooks also kept the girls busy.

title: If You Worry About Yanks and Knicks, You Forget to Worry About Big Things
description: Thanks in large part to the courts, arbitrators and negotiations between owners and players' unions, concepts and relationships long associated with sports by the American public have been radically altered. But despite this wellpublicized sports revolution, essentially little has changed. Sport Is still being used as an opiate for the people in many nations.

title: Poseidon I
description: 25308 Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, Queens. (212) 2299506, (212) 3212091.

title: Major League Averages
description: National League

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: As a New Rochelle City Councilman and as a longtime proponent of clean water policies, I must address the article on the Army Corps of Engineers' dredging issue that appeared on April 17.

title: The F.B.I., Yes
description: WHITE PLAINS, N. Y.  For the last few years, some of our most valued and honored institutions have come under escalating and unrelenting attacks. These include the Central Intelligence Agency and Federal Bureau of Investigation. I believe the magnitude and the intensity of the attacks are unfair and unwarranted, particularly those against the F.B.I.

title: WhiteWater High
description: White water is the phrase riverrunners use for rapids and turbulences that set the adrenaline zinging. The bigger, the better. You can sample it in thrilling snippets on certain Appalachian streams the Youghiogheny or the Chat tooga, on which the movie Deliverance was shot. You can race against hundreds of Northeasterners through difficult rapids, slalom courses and blobs of ice in Massachusetts Westfield River, swollen and foreboding. But for really bigleague white water, you must go West, young person, to the Tuolumne, the Colorado.

title: Virgin Islands Begin 3d Attempt To Write Their Own Constitution
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., May 21Final approval has been given to legislation enabling the United States Virgin Islands to write a constitution.

title: Can (or Should) Rock Music Appeal to Adult Sensibilities?
description: The following is an edited transcript of a symposium on the future of rock music and its relation to an adult audience. The symposium was held at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles. In alphabetical order, the panelists were Stan Cornyn, executive vice president of the Warner Brothers record company and widely regarded as a leading industry pundit; Ray Davies, the leader of the Kinks, a British band that was a huge success with teenagers in the 1960's and has more recently explored various aspects of rock theater; Bill Graham, the concert promoter who once ran the Fillmore theaters in San Francisco and New York; Linda Ronstadt, the countryrockpop singer who is one of today's most popular performers, and Tina Turner, the hardrocking soul singer who has recently enjoyed success in Las Vegas and suburban theaters. John Rockwell of The Times was moderator.

title: Article 21  No Title
description: Sheila Ballantyne is a novelist and short story writer. Her story, Perpetual Care, appears In Prize Stories 1977The O. Henry Awards.

title: Yankees ReCords
description: BATTING

title: Lewis Street Chowder House
description: Lewis Street, Greenwich, Conn. (203) 19827

title: Cuello Knocks Out Burnett in the 9th for Title
description: MONTE CARLO, May 21 (AP)Miguel Cuello of Argentina survived an early knockdown and knocked out Jesse Burnett of Los Angeles in the ninth round today, winning the vacant World Boxing Commission lightheavyweight title.

title: Lacrosse
description: FINAL IVY LEAGUE

title: On the Same Side This Time
description: TWO usual political sparring partnersSuffolk County Executive John V. N. Klein and Floyd S. Linton, Presiding Officer of the County Legislaturetraded friendly gibes last week as they were honored by the Smith Haven Ministries, the ecumenical socialwelfare agency.

title: Young, in South Africa, Asks Change
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 21Andrew Young, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, came to an uneasy South Africa today to tell its business leaders that they held the key to social change in this country, a change he said would he necessary to stave off economic deterioration of this country.

title: Article 25  No Title
description: Article 25 No Title

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: Baltimore 4, New York 3 (12 inn.).

title: Efficiency Goal Of New Chief Of Civil RPrtIiPA
description: WASHINGTON, May 21Yes, said Alan K. Campbell, the new chairman of the Civil Service Commission, the days of the pink slip are past, and callers from the executive branch or Capitol Hill will be supplied with no more information about Civil Service jobs than anyone else is.

title: Letters FollowUp: An Exchange Among Nobel Laureates
description: The following exchange of correspondence was initiated by two letters published in The Times on Oct. 24, 1976, shortly after the public announcement of the award to me of the 1976 Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences. Each letter was signed by two Nobel laureates: one by George Wald and Linus Pauiing, the other by David Daltimore and S. E. Luria. Both letters objected to my selection for the award on the ground of my alleged involvement with the Chilean junta. My reply of Jan. 18, 1977, was addressed to each of the four men individually. Wald and Pouting have never replied. Baltimore and Luria did on Feb. 18, 1977, but they have not replied to my response of March 14, 1977.Milton Friedman.

title: MUSIC
description: WHEN the Boston Musica Viva performs in Westport Saturday night, the concert will cap a fascinating daylong experiment in, educational entertainment concocted by the Westport Friends of Music to close out their 20th anniversary season.

title: 365 Rehired Officers Sworn In
description: Mayor Beame swore in 365 police officers who were rehired with funds from the Federal Comprehensive Employment. Training Act at a Police Headquarters ceremony last week.

title: SELECTION
description: NOW, when I try to call to mind my father's father, I can see him clearly enough, but the background surrounding him is vague, or rather, composite, made up of the many places he stayed on over the years. For it is not a memory of my father's homeplace, the old family farmstead, that I have. The family owned no such place. My grandparents moved just about every other fall, going from one farm to another almost as often as we moved from house to house in town. My father's father was a sharecropper. He would contract with a landowner to farm on shares, fiftyfifty, by the year. When his disappointing crop was gathered, they would pack their few belongings in the wagon and hitch the team to it and move a few miles, always in a radius around the tiny settlement of Lone Star, to another place which, next fall, would prove just as unyielding. To the end, going blind with cataracts and feeling his way with his feet in the furrows, my grandfather clung to his dream of gathering a good enough crop for a couple of years in succession to make a down payment on a place of his own and work for himself. Instead, the gathering of his crop and its sale, the one time of the year when he held cash money in his hand, often left him in debt to the owner of the crossroads store for what he had advanced them to keep alive on.

title: A New Kind of Song in the Cabarets
description: Although what is currently being called cabaret has been proliferating around town for several years, the recording industry has paid relatively little attention to it. A primary problem may be that the term cabaret can only be vaguely defined.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Striper Angling
description: POPOLOPEN BROOK, N.Y.Popolopen Gorge was still deep in earlymorning shadow when we entered it from the Hudson River in our canoe and began casting plugs for striped bass.

title: A Crook'sEye View of the Caper
description: THIS is a good book. The story is absorbing and the characters persist after the book is over. It is, of course, the story of the 1950 Brink's robbery in Boston, wherein seven men wearing Halloween masksand carrying handguns walked into the Brink's counting room at the Mirth Terminal Garage and stole about $2,700,000. They got away with it, sort of, until Jan. 6, 1956 when Specs O'Keefe, with 11 days left until the statute of limitations ran out, sat down in Hampden County Jail with two F.B.I. agents and told all.

title: John Gardiner Layng And Amanda Barney Set October Bridal
description: Amanda Barney, an account executive with Firestone Associates, a public relations concern, and John Gardiner Layng, a bond trader with Wood Gundy Inc., a Canadian investment organization in New York will be married in October.

title: RIGHTEOUSNESS DOWN THE YEARS
description: America's foreign ventures have a way of turning into crusades. Right, clockwise: an 1869 cartoon preceding seizure of the Philippines and expulsion of Spain from Cuba: a World War I poster promoting war bonds: a 1968 poster exemplifying the equally American penchant for righteousness turned against ourselves: a painting by Thomas Hart Benton damning the Axis powers during World War II, when the line between good and evil was clearly drawn. These days, says the author of this article, the line is not that clear.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Right now, it is pure Piranesi. The interior of the very large, very expensive, and potentially very beautiful new East Building of the National Gallery in Washington, scheduled to open in the summer of 1978 and still literally under wraps to outsiders and most of the profession, is a place of un finished, soaring spaces, dense scaffolding and balconies and bridges leading to mysterious destinations in murky halflight. Even the escalators seem surreal.

title: What Price Rehabilitation?
description: THE IMPENDING demolition in August of six small 19thcentury buildings on South Main Street in Norwalkone of them bear ing a rare castiron facadehas sparked a controversy that is becoming more and more common in American cities: Should slum areas be upgraded by wholesale razing and new construction? Or should the neighborhood integrity be preserved by rehabilitation of existing structures?

title: Christine Haynes Wed To Christopher Myers
description: Christine Louise Haynes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Evans Haynes of Irvington, N. Y., was married yesterday noon to Christopher Andrew Myers, son of Donald O. Myers of Chicago and Ethel B. Myers of Marina Del Rey, Calif.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Tral question becomes who is the better parent. Time in court should be spent finding out what the best interests of the child are and which parent can better serve them.

title: Path of 1939 Ordeal Retraced
description: MOUNT KATAHDIN, Me.. May 21 Donn C. Fendler was 12 years old when he became lost on this milehigh mountain in Baxter State Park in northern Maine.

title: Television This Week
description: 11:30 A.M. (2) FACE THE NATION. Secretary of Defense Harold Brown is the scheduled guest.

title: News Summary
description: Major differences are still holding up the conclusion of new Soviet American strategic arms accord despite agreement on a new formula to break the deadlock in negotiations. The delay was acknowledged by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko at the end of their threeday meeting in Geneva. Mr. Vance's remarks on the meeting were far more positive than Mr. Gromyko's, but it was clear that no breakthrough had been achieved and that further detailed.talks still have to be held. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: R. A. Montgomery Weds Miss MacKenzie
description: Marilyn Rita Mackenzie and Robert Allen Montgomery of New York were married yesterday afternoon in Leland, Mich. The Very Rev. Thomas Stoll, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Leland Community Church.

title: Beating Student Boredom
description: ERICH FROMM identified boredom as the insidious cause of catastrophes ranging from drug addiction to violence. Bertrand Russell said that at least half the sins of mankind are caused by the fear of it.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE HOUSE has adopted a tentative Federal spending ceiling of $480.9 billion for the next fiscal year. The limit includes a projected deficit of $64.65 billion The nation's money supply (cash plus checkingaccount balances) fell $400 Million in the latest week to $321.2 billion The O ganization of Economic Cooperation and Development will set up a study group on trade and pricing of the international steel industry to ease protectionism pressure from the American steel industry.

title: Lucinda Almy Is Married
description: Lucinda Turner Almy and Ronald Harvey Clingenpeel were married yesterday in the chapel of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. S. Hughes Garvin, who was assisted by the Rev. Edwin Cromey. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Almy of Mendham, N. J. Her husband is a son of Mrs. L. I. Clingenpeel of Valentine, Neb., and the late Mr. Clingenpeel. The bride gradu. ated from Hollins College. Her hesband, a graduate of the University of Nebraska, is studying at the General Theological Seminary.

title: DINING OUT
description: WHEN Spanish restaurants began to proliferate in this area a few years back, almost anything they did was welcome. After so many years of mediocre food northern New Jersey restaurants, the Spanish, with their unfamiliar style of cooking, enthusiastic service and reasonable prices, were an exciting find.

title: Uniquack Explains It All
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  After watching Secretary of State Cy Vance compromising with the Russians on arms control in Geneva, Vice President Fritz Mondale lecturing Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa in Vienna, the State Department condemning Cuba's African army but trying to establisb diplomatic relations with Havana, we dusted off our old electronic truthdetector, Uniquack, and pleaded for an explanation.

title: Letters
description: Nowhere in his article (College of Hard Knocks: My Life as a Garbageman, May 1) does John R. Coleman discuss the fact that it Costs twice as much to pick up a ton of garbage in New York as it does in many other American cities. The reason is that sanmen have contracts that enable them to retire at half pay after 20 years, among other golden goodies. With overtime, a guy can get out after 20 years in his early 40's with $8,000 or $9,000 a year for the rest of his life. Wouldn't it be a helluva lot cheaper to hire private companies, which seem to do adequate jobs for a lot less, or to pay more per man but less on pensions?

title: Events Today
description: GALA SPRING FESTIVAL: Art show, lea market, plans craits and rctecnments 11 A.M. lo 5 P.M.; Riverdale Neighborhood House, 5521 Mosholu Avenue, Riveroale.

title: After 14 Months, a Vote on the Books
description: LEVITTOWN MORE than a year after the small Island Trees School District here gained national prominencesome say notorietyfor banning nine books from its library shelves, the book issue refuses to go away.

title: TV VIEW
description: There are three new miniseries in television town, all of them playing outside the commercial networks and each of them reflecting different production arrangements. Poldark, the new 16episode tale on public TV's Masterpiece Theater (Sundays at 9 on Channel 12). is an import from the British Broadcasting Corporation. Hard Times, a fourpart public TV production (Wednesdays at 8) is a coproduction of WNET/13 and Granada TV, a commercial organization in England. And Testimony of Two Men, six hours based on the novel by Taylor Caldwell (Mondays at 8 on WPIX/ Channel 11), represents the first major production of a new syndicated effort called Operation Prime Time. If any general conclusion can be wrenched from generous samplings of the batch, it's that the British still seem to do these things better. Experience is an indispensable asset.

title: Reds Send Alcala to Expos
description: MONTREAL, May 21 (UPI) The Montreal Expos today acquired Santo Alcala, righthanded pitcher, from the Cincinnati Reds for a player or players to be named later. The 24yearold Alcala, from the Dominican Republic, has been a starter with the Red where he had an 114 wonlost record and 4.70 earned run average last year.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The article on suburban garbage disposal, Landfill in the Suburbs: Who Wants It Next Door? [April 24] should have noted the passage last fall of a significant new Federal law, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976.

title: Mets Big Con on Gary Matthews
description: In the New York Mets attempt to justify the failure to sign any free, agents, the front office has been professing for six months that it made Gary Matthews, the outfielder now batting 370 for the Atlanta Braves, an excellent offer. But according to both Gary Matthews and his agent, Ed Keating, the Mets never pursued him aggressively. The best the Mets did was mention a vague package somewhere between $1 million and $1.2 million that was nearly $600,000 short of the fiveyear contract Gary Matthews signed.

title: Making Big Leaps In the Dance Field
description: SUDDENLY things are falling into place for Lynne Taylor. Thirteen years after she came east from Denver in search of that proverbial fame and fortune, the dancerchoreographer, who lives here with her husband, Mike Corbett, a musician and record producer, has hit her stride.

title: MUSIC
description: CHANNELING a portion of local tax revenues to benefit the arts is still a matter of heated controversy in many parts of the state, but the Town of Greenburgh has been quietly making it happen for dozen years now, via the Greenburgh Arts and Culture Committee.

title: Dividing a Job Feast
description: THERE was more than a little symbolism as officials gathered last week in the County Office Building in White Plains to announce jubilantly how the latest piece of Federal pie was about to be divided locally. The building itself is a former W.P.A. monument and the programs under discussion last week bore strong resemblance to those in the old Federal works nroiect.

title: Australia, After U.S. Talks, Hopes to Export Uranium
description: PERTH, Australia, May 16With the return of Australia's Deputy Prime Minister from Washington this week, the LiberalCountry Party Government appears more confident that it can finally surmount a bitter controversy that has long held up the mining and export of the country's large uranium reserves.

title: Political Post Time In Yonkers
description: WHILE harnessrace horses are deserting Yonkers in droves for New Jersey's Meadowlands Race Track, the city's politicians are entering the starting gate for what promises to be a cliffhanging mayoralty race in the fall.

title: Elaine Dundy is the author of The Dud Avocado. The Old Man and Me and The Injured Party.
description: Elaine Dundy is the author of The Dud Avocado. The Old Man and Me and The Injured Party.

title: GARDENING
description: IF enjoying one's own garden may be rated highly among life's pleasures, then visiting another's garden cannot be far behind. This is particularly true when the garden is on the North Shore of Suffolk Coupty, where the trees and hills seem a bit greener and the air fresher, and the sounds one hears are more apt to be the songs of birds than the cacaphony of the Long Island Expressway.

title: Diana Vinade Ronan Is Married To Alan Grant Quasha, Lawyer
description: Diana Vinad Ronan, daughter of Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and Mrs. Ronan of New York, was married yesterday morning to Alan Granat Quasha, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Howard Quasha of Manila.

title: Pennsylvania Speaker Quits After Conviction
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 21 (AP)Herbert Fineman said today he was resigning the position of House Speaker and his membership in the Pennsylvania House of Representatives because of his conviction on charges of obstructing a Federal investigation of alleged influence peddling in medical school admissions.

title: Better Avis Than Fuqua
description: Fuqua Industries Inc. is not a household name. Consumers may attend Fuqua's movie houses, play with Its sporting goods and trim their lawns with its power mowers without knowing the company.

title: Tuck Higgins Weds Elizabeth S. Gentile
description: Elizabeth Steele Gentile, coordinator of the emergency alcohol service of the Howard Mental Health Services in Burlington, Vt., was married yesterday afternoon to Tuck Pfeiffer Higgins, associate director of the United Way of Chittenden County, Vt. The Rev. David Heim performed the Protestant ceremony at Edson Hill Manor, in Stowe, Vt.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)More than half the world's couples of childbearing age have no protection against unplanned pregnancy even though international spending on family planning has doubled since 1970, according to a new population study.

title: A State Border Is a State of Mind
description: CONSIDER for a moment the curious predicament of Susan Ranscht, Sandra Haines and Nancy Ames, who may cross the ConnecticutNew York border dozens of times in a given day. The three housemates live on a little less than an acre, most of which is in Ridgefield, Conn., but a third of which is in Lewisboro. The state line passes right down their driveway, between their house, in Connecticut, and their garage, in New York.

title: Book Review May 22, 1977
description: ADISTURBING visitor arrives at a country house, there's a walk in the garden, a debate at lunch, a lady of the house talks with a peasant, there's a lovers tetetete, a declaration of love in which a man is caught between two loves then farewells between two people, thoughts of the young man alone In outline it seems slight. But what we are conscious of is the outer watchful timeless silence of Russia. The words of comedy are grave in their undertone and around the people we feel the sparkle or the stare of Nature which is as indifferent to them as it is to the passing of time itself.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Troubles over arms control and fishing boats have dominated SovietAmerican relations since the Carter Adniinistration came in, while the subject of SovietAmerican trade has almost faded from view. Yet trade is one area where the Administration can and should move quickly to restore vitality.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: As a British citizen occupying a relatively senior position in the line management of a United States corporation and having previously been a director of a large British company, I differ from Eric Moonman's opinions in The Ineptitude of British Managers (May 1). His view that the style of British management is a fundamental fault recognizes an effect rather than cause.

title: Do Writers Stay Home?
description: TO live is to see, and traveling sometimes speeds up the process. In Khartoum this winter unexpectedly one evening I ran into an old acquaintance in the hotel lobby, really a sort of classmate, though I was at Harvard when he was at Yale. Now in his mid40's, he was to set off at five o'clock the next morning to visit the Eritrean guerrillas in northern Ethiopia, just as I was about to entrain in the opposite direction to the Darfur desert to see the camelriding Kababish nomads near the Libyan borderwriting assignments for different organizations we both turned out to have sought, indeed. He had a bullfrog in his throat and had only just recuperated from a serious operation, so that, although I can't vouch for how I looked, he was wan and puckery. I had been into Eritrea very briefly myselfthe guerrillas are begging for publicitybut the last American reporter who had undertaken the full trek had lost 17 pounds during the experience, according to the U.S.I.S. man based in Khartoum. The last British newspaperman had wound up being seized as a hostage himself. We knew that wasn't going to happen to him, but our grins over our drinks were appropriately ambivalent and middleaged.

title: REV. DEXTER L. HANLEY,  S.J. ; AUTHORITY ON LABOR LAW
description: The Rev. Dexter L. Hanley, S.J, former president of the University of Scranton, an authority on labor law, died Friday in Scranton, Pa., after a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: In the Name of Social Reform
description: MEXICO CITYWith the political route to realization of their aims obstructed by militarydominated regimes that resist change, advocates of social reform in the largely impoverished and overcrowded republics of Central America are once again turning to violence.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE Founotani triggering device sounds like some new playground gimmick for children, or maybe something that would get Perry Mason involved in a new detective adventure.

title: OBSERVERS PREDICT BEAMEABZUG RACE
description: With most of the entrants set, the contest for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of New York Citywhich is usually tantamount to electionis, as of now, essentially a twoway race with several other mayoral hopefuls trying to make it three way.

title: Matinee Today at 3 P.M.
description: Based on volpone by Ben Jonson Directed by ARTHUR PENN Also starring JACK GILFORD BOB DISHY GRETCHEN WYLER JOHN RAMSEY JAMES GALLERY BETH AUSTIN JOHN HEFFERNAN and HECTOR EUZONDO as Able Production Designed and Lighted by Costumes by GEORGE JENKINS ALBERT WOLSKY

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Michael Maccoby
description: William James (18421910), philosopher, psychologist and Henry's brother, might have been startled to know that he had a little to do with Michael Maccoby (1933 ), resident fellow of the Institute for Policy Studies In Washington. director of the Harvard Maccoby. Project on Technology, Work and Character, and author of The Gamesman. So, too, did the early Prophets and Christians, Aristotle, Spinoza, Marx, Erich Fromm, Abraham Maslow and David Riesman. The demands of instant journalism and picaresque Judgment lump them together because stone of them ever said: Love that corporation. Rather, they talked of individualism and humanism.

title: 288 TO BE SWORN IN AS SCHOOL OFFICIALS
description: Members of Local Boards Chosen on May 3 in New York City to Take Posts by June 30

title: Missy Cary Is Married To David McLuer Laird
description: Margaret Rhodes Cary, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis Frothingham Cary of Greenfield, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to David McLuer Laird, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry M. Laird of Attleboro, Mass. The Rev. Stephen D. Howard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Cary home.

title: A Spectacular Bass Performance
description: The Institute for Advanced Musical Studies was founded in Montreux, Switzerland, in 1973 and is now moving to the University of Southern California. To celebrate this rather radical dislocation, the institute has chosen to stage two concerts inof all placesNew York. The first took place Wednesday and was favorably received; the second was Friday night, again at Carnegie Recital Hall. This one had its ups and downs; the highest up was Gary Karr.

title: Fromm Gains Final
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 21Eric Fromm, 19yearold Columbia star, beat firstseeded Bill Lloyd, 26, 63, 64, in the semifinals of the $3,000 Prince Eastern hardcourt tennis championships today at the Roosevelt Field Tennis Club.

title: POLITICS
description: WHAT is it that Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean found at home, Senator Raymond H.Bateman had to look all the state for, Congressman Robert A. Roe borrowed by the basketful and Governor Byrne got from his Cabinet?

title: Jazz: Diverse Tacks via Chicago
description: Chicago's Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a 10yearold cooperative organization, has contributed a new and influential thrust to contemporary jazz. Usually, when one thinks of A.A.C.M. music, the approach of Anthony Braxton or the Art Ensemble of Chicago come to mind, an approach that involves the use of an unusual number and variety of instruments and of disciplined compositional structures that frame and direct improvisations.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market closed slightly higher last week after selling pressure on Thursday and Friday wiped out most of the gains achieved earlier in the week.

title: Seattle Slew Wins Preakness
description: Undefeated Seattle Slew, ridden by Jean Cruguet, scored his eighth victory yesterday, winning the 102d running of the $191,100 Preakness Stakes at Pimlico in Baltimore. Seattle Slew finished a length and a half ahead of Iron Constitution, covering 13/16 miles in 1:542/5. He paid $2.80 for $2 to win. Details in Section 5.

title: Tito, at Talks With Mondale, Attacks U.S. on Rights
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 21Vice President Mondale met today with President Tito who, in an unmistakable reference to President Carter's humanrights policy, politely but firmly said that he would not be lectured on the subject of civil rights in Yugoslavia.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: NOT so very long ago, Herbert Gold's novel, Fathers, was favorably reviewed on the front page of this Book Review. In another piece in these pages, a critic suggested that if John Donne had grown up in Cleveland, Ohio, in the 20th century he Might have written a book like Mr. Gold's Therefore Be Bold. While still in his 40's, Gold had published perhaps a hundred short stories and as many articles, most of them knowledgeable, polished and promising. He was considered by many a writer to watch, one of the possible heirs apparent of the BelloWMalamud generation.

title: Theresa Helen McCahill Bride of Walter Abrams
description: Theresa Helen McCahill, who today receives a master's degree in social work from Adelphi University, was married yesterday afternoon to Walter John Abrams, a junior executive in operations for Macy's Herald Square.

title: Helping Children Live
description: ICAN'T make a date for Monday, that's piano, said a child negotiating an afternoon schedule, and Tuesday I have divorce, but Wednesday is O.K.

title: Le Tombeau de Couperin Given With Elegance by the City Ballet
description: Of all the ballets to Ravel that were featured in the New York City Ballet's Ravel Festivalthank heavens we were never offered a work called Ravellianaof two years ago, one of the most enduring has proved to be what was surely the simplest. This is George Balanchine's Le Tombeau de Couperin, and it made its first appearance of the season at the New York State Theater on Friday night.

title: Family Plots: Homely History Amid Sprawl
description: Peter Ambrogi of Westwood, N.J., recently discovered a grave on his vacation retreat in the Catskill mountains, and he and his wife, Loretta, think that's just great.

title: Author's Query
description: I am researching a book about Franz Kafka's friend, Dr. Robed Klopstock, and would appreciate hearing from anyone having letters or related material.

title: Borderline Cases

For the past few years, the carrot crop has been abundant and delicious but the carrots have always had a mass of tiny white hairy roots suggesting whiskers. title: Battle for Free Agents: Reminder of A.F.L. Era
description: The battle for free agents within the National Football League is now coming to a close after a month of mild chicanery that reminded many of the war in the 1960's when the N.F.L. teams were competing savagely with the American Football League for players.ln those years, up to the N.F.L.A.F.L. merger pact of 1966, kidnapping and babysitting of players was not uncommon, the idea being to hide the athletes so that other coaches and scouts could not find them. There were. several instances of babysitting Othis year during and after the draft of May 3 and 4 as the 28 teams vied for the best of the free agents, those who had not been drafted. The personnel directors regarded this as fun and games.

title: A Hiroshima Maiden Conquers Bitterness

That's when 1impresario Gian Carlo Menotti will open the first American version of his renowned Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds, an annual summer event in Spoleto, Italy. For the 12day run of Spoleto Festival U.S.A., some 600 actors, dancers, singers, instrumentalists and backstage helpers will perform more than 100 events (opera; theater; dance; jazz, symphonic and choral concerts; recitals; art and film shows) at various Charleston locations and nearby island resorts.

title: Brian Holtby, Law Student, Weds Virginia Clare White

title: Aboard the Old Westchester
description: IN 1926 I was hired, at the age of 18, on the Westchester as a station agent. The southern terminal of the railroad, known formally as the New York, Westchester & Boston Railway Company, was at the Harlem River at 133d Street and Willis Avenue. The railroad operated on two tracks of the New Haven system to West Farms Junction, then became four tracks to Mount Vernon. At the Columbus Avenue Junction it became two tracks to White Plains and two tracks to Mamaroneck. Later the line moved on to Harrison, Rve and, finally, Port Chester.

Designers Bob Patino and Vincent Wolf were asked: What could they dothat anyone could doto personalize the house, if only temporarily, working with the existing furniture? They would have to use more flair than cash, since summer rentals already mean a hefty outlay to most people.

Miss Flynn and Miss Zech were among eight women who participated with their fellow cadets. Parade took less than one hour and drew few spectators.

description: WASHINGTON, May 21The Carter Administration has decided not to try to hold the Reserve Mining Company to July 7 deadline for ending its dumping of potentially hazardous ore wastes into Lake Superior, Government officials disclosed today.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThirty months ago at the World Food Conference in Rome there was an international undertaking to establish a system of food security to prevent recurrence of the kind of shortages that were then causing millions of people to starve.

title: Last Week's Rejection of Marijuana Bill Was a Surprise
description: During the early 1970's, when it seemed social troubles could be solved simply by spending money on them, New York City's drug abuse programs were the most innovative in the country. But changes In attitudes toward drug addicts and shortages of money have produced significant cutbacks in drug abuse therapy and questions about the prospects for the future. In lean times, the public prefers spending what money there is on basic services such as sanitation and fire and police protection. Also, because of a continued rise in property crime rates and a city addict population that has reached 125,000, the public perception is that rehabilitative programs do not work and severe punitive measures are necessary.

title: Jersey Leads U.S. In Flood Insurance
description: NEW JERSEY municipalities, plagued by periodic flooding since the turn of the century, lead the nation in participat ing in the Federal insurance program set up in 1968 to provide subsidies for rebuilding damaged homes, industries and community facilities.

In implementing these goals, President Woodrow Wilson soon landed the Marines at Veracruz, Mexico.

description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 21If Jack Nicklaus wants to protect his celebrated Memorial tournament from being won by an unknown upstart, he may have to win it himself.

title: Radio Station Copter Pilot Killed
description: DALLAS, May 21 (AP)A pilot was killed yesterday when a Dallas radio station's helicopter crashed after making morning traffic reports to listeners. The pilot was identified as Elliot Cohn, an employee of the Helix Transport Inc. No other persons were aboard when it crashed. A spokesman for station KVIL said that Mr. Cohn had let a traffic reporter, Suzy Humphreys, out of the craft just minutes before it went down.

title: How the Species Get That Way
description: CAN a discipline so vast and so heterogeneous as modern biology be epitomized in fewer than 200 pages? No biologists could be better qualified for such an audacious challenge than P. B. and J. S. Medawarfor their combination of scientific excellence, broad vision and fine writing represents a rare intersection indeed. Peter Medawar won the Nobel Prize in 1960 for his work on the vexatious question of why our bodies reject tissues implanted from other individuals. In more general works, he has probed as widely as The Future of Man (1960) and into the basic methods of science in The Art of the Soluble (1967).

title: Notes: Rules Eased On Overseas Luggage
description: The weight of baggage carried by Americans flying overseas is going to be less of a burden. Most international airlines have agreed to implement from June 1 a checked baggage allowance system based on the size of a passenger's luggage. Restrictions on dimensions, rather than weight, have been the governing factor on American domestic flights for years. The reason: On today's jet plpnes the weight of the cargo is less of a problem than the space it occupies. The effect of the new regulations, international airline officials estimate, will be to increase the amount of belongings a passenger can take along free by about 10 percent. Some countries, however, including the South American nations and Mexico, will continue to apply the weight system: 44 pounds per person in economy class and 66 pounds in first class.

description: St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Joanne Adele Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Chapman of Short Hills, to Edwin A. Einert Jr. of Carle Place, LI, son of Mr. and Mrs. Einert of Boynton Beach, Fla. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray, director of administration for the Archdiocese of Newark, performed the ceremony.

There, pick up U.S. 1 to Ogunquit. (Coming from New York, to shortcut past Boston, use I495, which connects the Massachusetts Turnpike with the New Hampshire Turnp'Ke.)
description: Both Greyhound and Trailways offer several buses daily, making the trip from New York to Ogunquit in seven or eight hours, at a roundtrip cost of about $45. Some hotels arrange to have a car meet flights into Boston's Logan Airport.

title: Report on Attica Uprising Points To Beating of Inmate as a Cause
description: An investigation committee of the New York State Commission on Corrections has concluded that a riot by inmates in Cellblock D in the prison at Attica last July, was precipitated by the beating of an inmate by five guards.

description: A program of particular interest will mark the finale for the American Symphony Orchestra which reaches the end of its season this afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The program includes Stravinsky's Symphony of Psalms and Ravel's Daphnis and Chloe, both with the 175voice New York Choral Society; and, tucked in between, the American premiere of William Walton's Varii Capricci, a transcription of his Five Bagatelles for guitar composed in 1971 and reworked in 1976 for the Royal Festival Hall's jubilee celebration in London. Sergiu Commissiona, of the New York Choral Society, will be guest conductor. (See Music)

description: GORDON W. BURROWS, the Assemblyman and Republican candidate for Westchester County Executive, confessed the other day that it was a humbling thing to find out after all my years in politics that I am not a household word.

description: In the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday morning, Jean Rosemary Spencer, daughter of Mrs. Anthony Spieczny of Bound Brook, N.J., and the late Mr. Spieczny, was married to Victor Amend Lemaitre, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Victor Edward Lemaitre of Lima, Peru. The Rev. Alanson Houghton performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Lawrence Prast. The bride, who uses the name Spencer prcfessinnally, is a real??? broker with Whitbread Nolan in New York. Her husbnnd is business manager of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Opposite Concepts
description: VIENNA  The two concrete achievements of the Vienna negotiation between United States Vice President Mondale and South African Prime Minister Vorster were: significant agreement on truly democratic elections in Rhodesia and independence of that state in 1978 under the name of Zimbabwe; plus identification of the nature of problems still impeding similar freedom for SouthWest Africa (Namibia).Americans and black South Africans. The former, once slaves, had given up their original roots and embraced a wholly new culture; he for one always saw them as Americans, quite like their white brothers.

title: Energy Crisis Is Expected to Alter Building Design
description: Back in 1974, in the midst of the fuel shortages that followed the Arab oil ernbargo, energy experts were predicting solar collector on every roof, a windmill in every backyard and a quick end to the era of the glassenclosed tower.

title: Sailors Haven
description: AT THE TIME I joined, Indian Harbor had the reputation of being one of the two hardest clubs to get into in Greenwich the other was Round Hill, said Joan Caldwell. More than 20 years later nothing much has changed. Miss Caldwell, a 1generation member of the club, was among the first Corinthian members (nonvoting, 24 to 34 y ears of age) to be admitted in a careful effort to expand the club's economic base.

title: Flaw in the Energy Program?
description: NEW JERSEY'S Legislature has acknowledged the need for a state energy agency to help formulate a longoverdue energy policy. Generally, the proposed enabling legislation moves in the right direction. But there is a serious flaw: The proposed Energy Advisory Council would be completely dominated by industry's representatives.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Boris Strugatsky is an astrophysicist. His brother Arkady has translated Japanese classics into Russian. According to the jacket copy, the Strugatskys are the most popular writers of science fiction in the Soviet Union, which says something for the perspicacity of Russian s.f. fans. Roadside Picnic (the first of two short novels in this volume) is not easy reading, but it is well worth the effort. The theme is one that Frederik Pohl made good use of (in quite different fashion) in his recent Gateway. If we ever encounter extraterrestrial intelligences, we are likely to find them ??? ???

title: Motorists Delayed by Elephants
description: HAINES CITY, Fla., May 21 (UPI)stopped briefly Tuesday so 23 elephants could lumber across the highway to be weighed at a truck stop scale. The elephants, performers at Circus World, are weighed once a year to help determine their health and growth based on their gain or loss of weight, according to Bill Woodcock, superintendent of elephants at the theme park.

title: Right An Again
description: Baltimore, May 21Tommy Ennis. best of a splendid lot of sign painters from Charleston. W.Va., scurried up a bright red ladder on top of the doll house that stands in the winner's circle at Pimlico, slapped black and yellow paint on a weather vane fashioned like mounted race horse and scurried down in 1 minute 56 seconds this Sports afternoon, a Preakness record. Skeptics tended to scoff at the clocking. They said no wonder Tommy could get the job done that fast, he was so sure Seattle Slew would win that he didn't cumber himself with any paint except in the colors Jean Cruguet was wearing aboard the unbeaten favorite. While Ennis swung his brush, 77,346 witnesses  the greatest crowd ever funneled into this 107yearold cavalry postwere rending their haberdashery and bawling approval of the winner's eighth victory in eight races. Once again, the best 3yearold colts in America had askd him th question, once again Slew had come up with the answer, and now he was twothirds of the way along toward possession of the American Triple Crown. I think he will run the mile and a half of the Belmont the same way he's been running these races, said Billy Turner, the trainer, making the best forecast he could about the final contest in the classic trilogy. The Belmont comes on June 11, striking mutuel clerks permitting. The strike in New York has complicated Turner's immediate plans. In ordinary circumstances he would van the horse to the home barn at Belmont Park tomorrow, but lie said he didn't risk him through a picket line and might decide to stay in Baltimore a little longer.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Timothy J. Mclnerney's excellent article [Reverse Tactics on the Zoning. Issue, April 10] introduces the concept of inclusionary zoning. In response to those who question whether housing advocates wish to overcrowd our suburbs and bring environmental chaos, the concept of inclusionary zoning suggests that we can limit our total growth while assuring that our communities will still include a healthy mixture of incomes and races.

title: Fashion
description: End of May, brink of summer suddenly it's 11beach time and you've only got last year's leftovers in your closet. Don't panic. There are lots of easy ways to acquire this year's in look: soft, loose, seductive. A big blouson top can lead a double life under the sun and shawl, a decorative flower, some the moon. A you comfortab slivers of 1and all at a low dais can add a dash of romance to any costume. From the fanpleated skirt and strapless sundress to the secondskin onepiece bathing suit, this year's beachwear is both cool and sexy. On these pages are a dozen items to launch ly and stylishly into summer, costaround $300 for the Iot We slide quickly down between our Scylla and Charybdis, the sleeper and the opposite rock. We sweep past the big hole. At the bottom Jim swings the boat to meet the first wave. It towers over us. It crashes down. The Stanislaus swamps. But Jim seems to know what he is doing. Certainly we will push through. Then we turn over, rolling from starboard to port. I am sitting on the port side and the boat comes down on me like a lid. And it is dark. Amid foam, boat and bodies I start to work my way out and am struck on the back of the headby an oar, l guess. The blow is nothing compared with the confusion I feel. Then I am free, clinging to the overturned boat. But I am on the downstream side; Lore, as wideeyed and blond as Carol Channing, is next to me. We work our way around the boat. The life jacket holds me in an unaccustomed position. It is hard to swim. But now I have a chance to look around. All hands accounted for, as we sweep and bob along in the rushing water. It feels warm and rather pleasant. So this is what it is like to turn over in a big rapid. Nothing to it, I think.
