title: Elliot Bernstein, Writer for TV, Magazines, Was 41 Years Old
description: Elliot Bernstein, who wrote magazine articles and scripts for television, died of a heart attack yesterday at his summer home in Cutchogue, L.I. He was 41 years old and lived at 333 Pearl Street in Manhattan.

title: Continental Soldiers, Sky Diving, Dancers Enliven Oakland's 75th
description: OAKLAND, May 22 A lone skydiver parachuted from a plane 2,500 feet Shove the recreation fields of this westernmost borough of Bergen County today, and descended into the middle of thousands of cheering people gathered for the 75th anniversary of the bdrough's incorporation.

title: Chess:
description: On the level of candidates for the world championship, it can be a tricky business playing to an opponent's weakness. Either he will be very good at covering it up or he will discover that he is by no means as weak in the area of his weakness as he is supposed to be.

title: Harlem River Oil Spill Traced to a Basement
description: After searching the sewers of the South Bronx for several hours last night, sanitation workers found the source of the oil that had been spilling into the Harlem River near East 135th Street at a rate of up to 40 gallons a Minute yesterday afternoon.

title: CASINO DEVELOPERS PROCEEDING SLOWLY
description: ATLANTIC CITYEven if the Atlantic City casino gambling bill pending tin the New Jersey Legislature becomes law within the next month, only one casino is tonsidered to have a chance of opening this year, and it may be two to five years before the resort city has enough casinos to become a rival of Las Vegas.

title: Heablirgk Has Transformed Notre Dame in His 25 Years
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 22 President Carter's host here, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, has a record in human rights that makes Mr. Carter look something like a Jimmycomelately.

title: Events Today
description: WE ALL LOVED EACH OTHER SO MUCH, an Italia, film with English subtitles; directed by Ettore Scala; starring Vittorio Gassman, than Manfredi and Stefania Sandrelli, at the Beekman Tneater.

title: School Board and Aged Battle for Site in Corona
description: The site for a proposed school in Corona, Queens, a sixyear battleground between homeowners and the Lindsay administration, is the center of another dispute this time with serious implications fonthe mayoral race.

title: The Riga/Yalta Knot
description: BOSTON  The uncertain steps in the uncertain strategicarmslimitations talks process should remind us that despite the rise of the global economic issues, the Soviet Union continues to pose the single most important problem for American foreign policyjust as it has for more than three decades. And, while the current debate over our relations with the Soviet. Union may seem to focus on the number and throwweight of missiles, it is also about more fundamental questions: What kind of state do we face in the Soviet Union? What its intentions and capabilities?

title: Mr. Vorster and Mrs. Mandela
description: Few nations remain as patient as the United States with the racism and repression in South Africa. What drives the American conscience, and its current emissaries on South African businessVice President Mondale and Ambassador Andrew YoungIs the hope that peaceful ways can still be found to let whites and blacks share political power and the country's abundant wealth. That hope, though, grows dimmer every day only because the regime of Prime Minister Vorster persists in denying it.

title: Young, in Johannesburg, Urges Boycott by Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 22Andrew Young suggested today that South African blacks mount an economic boycott against apartheid and said that it would be hypocritical of the United States, born in a revolution, to condemn violence by blacks seeking freedom from white minority regimes here and in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa.

title: 8 Escapees From Matteawan Still at Large
description: Eight mentally ill prison inmates, four of them convicted killers, remained at large last night from the Dutchess County facility from which they escaped Friday night, the state police said.

title: WEAK CAR FUME BILL HELD HEALTH THREAT
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  Proposals for weaker controls on automobile exhaust fumes that may be adopted in the House of Representatives this week would pose a continued threat to public health, according to an analysis just prepared by three Federal agencies.

title: A Double Life: Secretary by Day and a Magazine Editor by Moonlight
description: Louise Reynolds doesn't much like being a secretary, but at least her salary lets her do what she wants to do in the evenings and on weekends: publish her own little magazine.

title: Fortune to Publish Every Other Week
description: Fortune magazine has announced officially that it will change to a publishing schedule of every other week beginning next January.

title: Meadowlands
description: (C)ConventIonal sulky. All others modified. *Also eligible.

title: Deaths
description: ABRAHAMSAdele, beloved wife of Joe, dear mother of Michael and Martin, devoted sister of Mildred Davidson and Mack Gray. Services were held Sunday, May 22, 1977.

title: Dance: At Lincoln Center the Accent Is, on the Leningrad School
description: Dance at Lincoln Center last weekend came in two distinct varieties but all of it was classical and most of itone way or the otherstemmed indirectly from the Leningrad Choreographic School. To be more precise, one way was via Mikhail Baryshnikov and his new production of The Nutcracker for American Ballet Theater, and the other way was via George Balanchine (a Soviet graduate of a somewhat ekrlier vintage) and his own New York City Ballet.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Six firemen and a police officer were injured during a twoalarm fire at. a delicatessen at 11905 Jamaica Avenue in Richmond Hill, Queens. Officials said the fire had apparently been set by burglars attempting to enter the store, near the corner of Lefferts Boulevard.

title: Measles Trend Seen In Metropolitan Area
description: Using a map to plot the advance, Dr. Thomas C. Abruzzo watched this year as measles and rubella (German measles) broke out in every community in Nassau County.

title: Andrea Leslie Port Wed To Robert Kahn, Lawyer
description: Andrea Leslie Port, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Port of Hallandale, Fla., was married yesterday to Robert Myron Kahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ade Kahn of Woodmere, L. I. The ceremony was performed in the Summit by Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman of the Central Synagogue.

title: Our Bach Ensemble Performs Four Works
description: Alice Tully Hall was nearly full at midnight, Saturday for an allBach Our Bach concert featuring the third orchestral suite and the concertos for oboe d'amore in A, oboe and violin in C minor, and harpsichord in D.

title: Legacy Is Lost in House Deal, Life on Stray Shot
description: A 78yearold woman shot to death in the Inwood section of Manhattan on May 14, spent the last four years of her life in poverty while she tried to recover $74,000 she had given a friend to build a house, according to court records. The friend's son built the house, but took title to in his own name, the records say.

title: Critic Says Pentagon Lost Track Of $20 Billion in Defense Work
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  The Defense Department has lost track of where more than $20 billion of its procurement money is being spent this year, Representative Michael J. Harrington, chairman of a NortheastMiddle West Congressional coalition, charged today.

title: Nicklaus Leads by Two As a Storm Halts Golf
description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 22 The rain falls on rich and poor alike, even on Jack Nicklaus and his golf tournament. In fact, completion of the closing round of the Memorial Tournament had to be postponed tonight because of rain, lightning and flood conditions.

title: Questions and Answers About the Need for Immunization
description: WASHINGTON  Recent outbreaks of measles have underscored the Federal Government's campaign to persuade Americans that they need vaccination against important infectious diseases. Following are questions on immunization and answers reflecting Government recommendations and other experts opinions:

title: The Standings
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Marine Scientists Say Coastal Waters Are Healthy
description: HIGHLANDS, May 22 New Jersey's coastal waters, which have endured fish kills, black water, the rottenegg smell of decay and fish that might contain toxic chemicals, appear to be healthy again.

title: Market Place
description: Measured by the bluechip Dow Jones industrial average, which is down 7 percent this year, the stock market's performance of late has been less than spectacular.

title: Defense Chief Backs Korea Plan, Says the Military Must Support It
description: WASHINGTON, May 22Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said today that the withdrawal of American ground troops from South Korea would not endanger the security of that nation, and made it plain that any military officer who publicly challenged the policy would be punished.

title: Saburo Eda, at 69; Japanese Socialist Had Set Campaign
description: TOKYO, May 22 (Reuters)  Saburo Eda, long a leader of Japan's major political opposition group, the Japan Socialist Party, died yesterday in a Tokyo hospital from acute hepatitis. He was 69 years old.

title: The Authority of the Port Authority
description: As the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey prepares for the replacement of its retiring chairman, William J. Ronan, and for the arrival of a new executive director, it has been hit by three legal decisions. Two were mere jabs; the third, a haymaker. Unless it can shake off the effects of that last blow, the authority might as well prepare to take the count.

title: WARRENE.COX,EXPERT ONANTIQUEPORCELAIN
description: Warren E. Cox, a longtime antiques dealer and an authority on porcelain and.pottery, died yesterday in his, apartment at 201 East 37th Street in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and had been ill for several years.

title: 6 Advising Mutual Fund Earn $300,000 Each
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 For years, professional money managers have commented among themselves, not without envy, about the very high salaries paid to those who run the group of mutual funds that includes the Massachusetts Investors Trust.

title: Whitworth Is ThreeStroke Victor at Forsgate
description: JAMESBURG, N.J., May 22 Kathy Whitworth, who has taken more money to the bank tnan any other competitor in the history of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, will make another of those journeys tomorrow morning. This time it will be with the $11,500 she won today for finishing first in the $77,000 CocaCola Classic at Forsgate Country Club.

title: Modernization Leaves Turkes Culture in Disorder and Its People Seeking an Identity
description: ANKARA, Turkey, May 22As the son of a tribal chief, Sentaor Kamran Man is widely respected in eastern Turkey. On a recent campaign trip, he was approached by a young student and questioned closely about politics and government.

title: Frank C. Osmers Is Dead at 69, A Bergen Congressman 17 Years
description: Frank C. Osmers, a former Representative from New Jersey's Ninth Congres sional District, died Saturday at his home in Tenafly; N.J. He was 69 years old.

title: Rifle Group Ousts Most Leaders In Move to Bolster Stand on Guns
description: CINCINNATI, May 22 In one of the most farreaching shakeups in the 107year history of the National Rifle Association, voting members of the organization ousted today most of their top elected and paid officials.

title: Town in the Philippines Inspires UNICEF Delegates
description: MORONG, Philippines, May 20Delegates attending the meeting of the United Nations Children's Fund in Manila visited this town of 23,000 people today and marveled at improvised street lamps and potted vegetables adorning window sills.

title: Deaths
description: GORDONRabbi Harold H. We mourn the passing of Rabbi Harold H. Gordon, Executive Vice President of the New York Board of Rabbis and Secretary of the International Synagogue at Kennedy Airport. He was the spiritual architect of the Synagogue. His vision and devotion to the creation of our institution were indispensable elements in Its creation. His Inspiration led us to wider areas of service not only for the 5,000 Jewish employees at the airport but to the hundreds of thousands who came to the Synagogue for prayer before leaving on their tourney to Israel and other countries of the world. May his soul rest in Peace.

title: Income Tax Issue Haunts Byrne In Battle for Party Nomination
description: Governor Byrne can be seen on television these days conceding that he made a mistake four years ago in failing to see the need for a state income tax and asking the voters to forgive him and give him credit for making tough decisions when they cast their ballots in the primary election for Governor of New Jersey on June 7.

title: In Wisconsin, Easing of Laws Leads to Open Use
description: MIDDLETON, Wis., May 16The debate over decriminalization of marijuana in this town of 12,000 people officially ended some time ago, but feelings on the subject still run deep.

title: 1,600 Students Receive Diplomas At Fairleigh Dickinson in Teaneck
description: TEANECK, May 22 If 1 were a girl I would cry, Leroy J. Thomas saic as he waved vigorously to get the at tention of his son at Fairleigh Dickin son University's commencement exercises for 1,600 students here today.

title: Federal Agency Expects To Clear Sewage Funds For New York by Sept. 30
description: ALBANY. May 22  The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has revised its earlier, more pessimistic projections, and now says it should be able to meet a Sept. 30 deadline for approving all the funds allotted to New York State for sewagetreatment projects, the state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner said today.

title: Key U.N. Resolutions On Peace in Mideast
description: The two United Nations resolutions referred to today by President Carter in his address at Notre Dame provided the framework for negotiations on the Middle East.

title: Willough by Breaks Ahkle
description: BOSTON, May 22 (UPI) Jim Willoughby, a Boston Red Sox relief pitcher, broke his right ankle today after slipping on the outfield grass during pregame drills. He will he lost to the team for six weeks.

title: Todd Wins in 11th of Second Game, 43
description: CINCINNATI, May 22The New York Mets gave up pregame batting practice today. Then in the first game of the doubleheader with the Cincinnati Reds, they gave up pitching, fielding and winning in that order and lost, 81. But by outlasting the Reds, 4.3, in 11 innings in the second game at Riverfront Stadium, they salvaged one of the four games of the series here, though they still fell back into the National League East cellar.

title: CARTER SAYS FAILURE ON THE MIDEAST NOW COULD BE DISASTROUS
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 22President Carter said today that it was now a propitious time for a settlement in the Middle East and warned that failure to act could be disastrous not only for the Middle East but perhaps for the international political and economic order as well.

title: Around the Nation
description: MIAMI, May 22 (AP)  The Florida Power and Light Company, the state's largest power company, whose blackout cut service to three million customers last week, has had more major power failures than any other utility in the country, Federal officials say.

title: Tons of Bad Shrimp Treated in Mexico And Shipped to U. S.
description: HOUSTON, May 22Seafood salvage buyers, using a Mexican sanctuary, are recycling into the United States large volumes of foreign shrimp and other frozen ocean products that Federal food inspectors rejected as spoiled or contaminated.

title: Smoking of Marijuana Wins Wider Acceptance
description: WASHINGTON, May 22 There are those who consider Mississippi socially backward, but something startling happened there the other day: The Mississippi Legislature voted to end criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana for personal use.

title: Music: Stories
description: To describe Charles Aznavour as a singer or a songwriter, or both, is to overlook the basic theatricality of his performance. On Saturday evening, the first of his two appearances at Carnegie Hall (he also performed there last night), Mr. Aznavour began the process of capturing his audience by simply, walking on stagebusinesslike, matteroffact, no flourishesand letting the audience briefly absorb his lean, intense face, punctuated by penetrating eyes under black, emphatic eyebrows.

title: Remember The Future
description: BOSTON, May 22Suddenly we were back in the emotions of Vietnam. There on the screen was. Richard Nixon, refusing to bug out, rejecting the easy political past, acclaiming the invasion of Cambodia as one of the most effective operations of the warand refusing to notice that the patient had died.

title: Shih Tsu judged Best at L.I.Sho.
description: IMMYSTEAD, L.I., May 22Sunshine, a 12 12pound Shih Tsu owned by Victor Joris, the fashion designer, was judged best in show over 1,600 dogs tonight at the 75th Long Island Kennel Clubevent on the Hofstra University camnus.

title: Interest Rates Expected to Go Up Even More as Result of Fed Action
description: The bond market late last week dropped sharplymoving down in price and toward higher interest rates  as traders and investors became convinced that the Federal Reserve had tightened its hold on credit another notch after its policysetting Open Market Committee met on Tuesday. Credit As a result, the consensus Markets among money market economists seemed to be that interest rates are headed still higher.

title: 7 Catholic Bishops Say San Salvador Persecutes Church
description: SAN SALVADOR, May 22The Roman Catholic bishops of El Salvador accused the conservative military Government of this Central American republic today of persecution of the church in the name of antiCommunism.

title: Text of President's Commencement Address at Notre Dame on Foreign Policy
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 22 (AP)Following is the text of the commencement address delivered by President Carter at Notre Dame University today:

title: PRICE RISE IN STEEL UNDER STUDY IN U.S. ON ANTITRUST BASIS
description: WASHINGTON, May 22  John H. Shenefield, the Justice Department's acting antitrust chief, says his staff is taking a close look at recent steel price increases and the public statements by steel executives that preceded them.

title: Manoir Is a Thin Opera but Entertaining
description: Al Carmines's continuing love affair with the plays and poems of Gertrude Stein has produced five operas since 1963, and the latest of them, A Manoir, has been on view at the Judson Memorial Church since April 22 (the final performance takes place tonight).

title: Obituary 6  No Title
description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY SE TELEPHONED TO OXFORD 5.3311 UNTIL 6.;10 P.M. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 0.00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY: NEW JERSEY (201) MARKET 3.1900; WESTCHESTER CO. AND NORTHERN NEW YORK STATE COUNTIES (DIN) WHITE PLAINS 03300: NASSAU CO (SIG) 74 /0500; SUFFOLK Co. (518)8691800, CONNECTICUT (203) 345.7707.

title: Business Leaders Skeptical Of Carter's Realizing Aims
description: Charles L. Schultze, President Carter's plainspoken chief economic adviser, ran into considerable skepticism in,y+Tashington last week from a distinguished business audience when he sought to lay out the Administration's touryear goals ana say how Mr. Carter meant to achieve them. At a symposium sponsored by the Committee for Economic Development, Mr. Schultze laid out these objectives for 1981:

title: Nixon Said to Affirm He W eighed Watergate Pardons
description: In the closing days of his Presidency, Richard M. Nixon considered granting pardons to everyone involved in the Watergate scandal, Newsweek magazine reeorted yesterday.

title: Seattle Slew Discourages Rivals for Belmont Stakes
description: BALTIMORE, May 22Seattle Slew, undefeated and by now unquestioned, left the Pimlico Race Course by van today along with most of the horses he overpowered in the 102d Preakness and headed for the final test in racing's Triple Crown: the Belmont Stakes in New York.

title: ALICE HOLCOMB
description: Alice Holcomb, an artist who gave show at the Barzansky Gallery here in 1962, died last Saturday in Sarasota, Fla., where she had been living. She was 70 years old and a resident also of Rockport, Mass., where she had served on the governing board of the Rockport Art Association.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ROYAL VIKING SEA (Royal Viking Line). Leff Horta May 18; due 1 P.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Olympic Buildings and Hopes Rising in Lake Placid
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y.  One gift shop on Main Street here already has received two orders for an Official Olympic executive silverplated paperweight at $150 each. Tshirts, stickers and other souvenirs are selling well in other stores.

title: Give Henry the Chair
description: There is no place at Columbia for Henry Kissinger, cries that university's student newspaper. The issue is whether this university respects the moral values it purports to represent  a Columbia appointment would reward and legitimize Kissinger's policies. His actions have shown him unfit to teach here, and Columbia should not hire him.

title: Turnout Increases in Car Protest Against Concorde
description: Demonstrators against landings of the BritishFrench Concorde supersonic jet brought out more carsbut caused less disruptionat Kennedy International AirreIrt vpqtardav than the week before.

title: Nordiques 83 Winners, Lead W.H.A. Finals, 32
description: QUEBEC, May 22 (AP) Real Cloutier, Christian Bordeleau and Paulin Bordeleau scored two goals apiece to day, leading the Quebec*Nordiqiles to an 8.3 rout of the Winnipeg JetS. The triumph gave the Nordiques a 32 lead in the fourofsevengame; World Hockey Association final playoffs:

title: Music: Variety
description: Sergiu C.omissiona chose to conduct four nicely contrasted works for his guest appearance with the American Symphony in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, the final concert of the orchestra's season. Although the music mild not have been more varied, the pieces had one common denominatorthey were all very much concerned with sonority and provided a real test of an orchestra's virtuosity.

title: Airliner Returns to Kennedy With 159 Following Bomb Threal
description: Several passengers reportedly received skinned knees and other minor injuries last night during an emergency evacuation of an American Airlines DCI0 that returned to Kennedy International Airport a few minues after it took off because of a telephoned bomb threat.

title: Thousands Honor Martin Luther King jr. in Fifth Avenue Parade
description: Thousands marched along Fifth Avenue yesterday in a jubilant tribute of pageantry and song in the 10th annual Martin Luther King Jr. memorial parade.

title: pr. D. M. Libby Weds Dr. Nancy Kemeny
description: Dr. Nancy E. Kemeny, an assistant professor in the department of medicine at Cornell University, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel M. Libby, a resident in internal medicine at the New York Hospital. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mrs. George Haynel in North Manursing Island, Rye, N.Y., by Rabbi Jerome Davidson of Great Neck, L. I.

title: World News Briefs
description: Task of Moroccan Troops In Zaire Said to Be Over

title: Chicago Jury to Probe Pornography and Prostitution Involving Boys
description: CHICAGO, May 22 A special Cook County grand jury will soon start hearing evidence about widespread pornography and prostitution involving boys. The United States Attorney for the Chicago area began investigating allegations of such practices last week.

title: Fire Chief Gets Wish For a Stylish Funeral
description: PEEKSKILL, May 21 Nine years ago C. Kennard Robinson, who was involved in this area's volunteer fire departments for 47 years, confided to a friend that when I go I want to leave this life in style.

title: Tinker People
description: Until a few years ago, people just happened. As a result, most of them were hodgepodges, like London and Rome, which also just happened.

title: Saudi Crown Prince in Washington For Talks With Carter on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia arrived today to begin talks with President Carter on the prospects of a Middle East settlement.

title: Essex Country Club Hits 90 Still Up to Par
description: ORANGE, May 23The Essex County Country Club turned 90 years old today, and it hardly showed its age.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: Fire in Small Ontario Town Contained by 500 Firemen After Burning 60 Buildings
description: COBALT, Canada, May 23 (AP)A windwhipped fire that apparently started in an abandoned store swept through this small Ontario mining town today anddestroyed 60 buildings, authorities reported.

title: 11.1% Profits Rise Posted By Associated Dry Goods In Its Fiscal First Quarter
description: The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, a leading department store chain that includes the Lord & Taylor stores, reported yesterday for the first fiscal quarter ended April 30, net earnings of $2.4 million, equal to 17 cents a share.

title: Should Homosexuals Be Teachers?
description: The controversy generated by an ordinance in Dade County, Florida, that bans discrimination in employinent, housing and public accommodations because of affectional or sexual preference, has touched a national nerve. As an effort to repeal the ordinance moves toward a June 7 vote, emotions are high. Supporters of repeal, including church groups, are campaigning on the slogan, Save our children from homosexual influence'; its opponents, bringing together advocates homosexual rights from around the country, call for Justice for an oparessed minority.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, May 23 (AP)A commission headed by Leonid I. Brezhnev today approved the draft of a new Soviet Constitution and ordered that it be published for nationwide discussion, the Soviet press agency Tass announced.

title: Mercedes Appeal Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)The Supreme Court today let stand a lower court's ruling that could subject MercedesBenz dealers in the United States to damage claims by up to 300,000 Mercedes owners.

title: Coop City Gas and Electric Lines Endangered by Shifts in Landfill
description: Shifting nf the filledin marshland on whch Coop City was built has led to serious structural defects at the huge housing complex in the northeast Bronx. Officials now say the shifting may also have been responsible for gas leaks and for the shearing off of an electrical cable Iasi December that resulted in a loss of power in part of the 15,000family development.

title: Around the Nation
description: DETROIT, May 23Defense attorneys for two Filipino nurses charged with murdering patients at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor, won court approval today to question a psychiatrist about possible confessions made to him by a former nursing supervisor, Betty Jakim.

title: Roots Grew Out of His African, Courlander Charges in Haley Suit
description: Harold Courlander, author of the 1967 novel The African, and Crown Publishers, which issued the book, have filed lawsuit for copyright infringement in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York against Alex Haley, author of Roots, and his publisher. Doubleday & Company.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VOICES OF EXPERIENCE How Do You Become a Writer? Some words of wisdom and practical experience on that subject are available from two who should know, in a free lecture program at 1. P.M. in th junior auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum. One speaker is Pauline Bloom, writer and teacher of writing. The other is Dr. Isaac Asimov, scientist and author of more than 150 books of wide variety.

title: Blue Shield Curb to Be Pressed
description: CHICAGO, May 23 (AP)The Blue Shield Association's plan to stop routine payment of bills for questionable procedures will require three to nine months to implement, a spokesman said today.

title: Looks Like the MasonDixon Line Was Erased
description: NASHVILLEBeing a Southerner in this euphoric first stage of the Carter Presidency is an instructive experience. There we were, riding along in the back of the national bus; now, suddenly, were driving. Southerners are being courted, feted and listened to. Within a matter of months, weve moved from stoop labor on the back 40 to tea and cookies in the parlor.

title: Burlington Plans Rise In Its Capital Outlays
description: Burlington Northern Inc. plans capital outlays about $2.2 billion in the five years ending in 1981. This would compare with $800 million spent over the last five years. The company explained in a preliminary prospectus for a twomillionshare offering of convertible preferred stock that it expected $1.1 billion to $1.3 billion of the total funds needed for the next five years would come from external sources. It said that about 75 percent would come from equipment obligations and leases, 20 percent from sale of longterm debt and equity securities and 5 percent from bank revolving credits and term loans.

title: About New York
description: For one brief, shining moment we had a Committee to Elect Crazy Pete Robinson Mayor,

title: 14 White House Fellows Announced by President; 1,334 Had Sought the Posts
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)President Carter announced today the appointment of the 14 White House Fellows for 197778, the 13th group since the creation of the program.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS OBSCENITY CONVICTION
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)The Supreme Court ruled today that individuals are subject to the Federal ban on sending obscenity through the mail even though the state where they are acting has more Permissive standards.

title: Carter's Opposition to Tennessee Breeder Reactor Is Reasserted Before House Panel Vote
description: WASHINGTON, May 23In a counterthrust at pronuclear forces in Congress, the White House reaffirmed today that President Carter opposed construction of the Clinch River breeder reactor at Oak Ridge, Term.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Tho New York Times/William E. Sauro

title: ExKansas Player Critical
description: TUSTIN, Calif., May 23 (AP)Danny Knight, a former University of Kansas basketball center, remained in critical condition in a coma today. He was injured when he fell down a flight of stairs at his home on Friday.

title: Music: Nygaard's Rarities Rouse
description: Jens Nygaard, who seems to have staked out all music as his province, appeared as conductor last night with the Westchester Chamber Orchestra. Not thit conducting is a strange role for him; he has had considerable experience before an orchestra. But he could just as well have turned up as pianist and, indeed; he did play a bit last nightor lecturer, or historian, or as the head of a choral group, or as propagandist for unknown music of the past and present.

title: South Africa Attacks Young
description: CAPE TOWN, South Africa, May 23 (AP)South Africa said today that Andrew Young had broken the terms of the agreement under which he was allowed to visit. Mr. Young was admitted at the weekend on condition he refrained from making controversial statements, said Interior Minister Connie P. Mulder. He said Mr. Young had failed to keep the bargain, and the Government was taking the matter in a serious light.

title: Ballet to Honor Magallanes
description: Next Tuesday's performance by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater will be dedicated to the memory of Nicholas Magallanes, a principal dancer of the company, who died on May 1. Two Balanchine ballets in which Mr. Magallanes created major roles, La Valse and Episodes, will be performed. His family and colleagues are expected to attend. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 A.M. that day at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, 249 West 48th Street.

title: Moluccans Long Under Alien Rule
description: About 40,000 South iMoluccans live in the Netherlands a heritage from the Dutch colonial past.

title: New York City to Pay $675,000 To Mother Who Lost Both Legs
description: A Manhattan mother of five has received a $675,000 settlement frdm New York City in her lawsuit that contended she has lost both legs because of a pothole.

title: United Brands to Move Its Offices To New York Within 18 Months
description: BOSTON, May 23 (AP)United Brands Company plans to move its executive headquarters to the New York City area within 18 months, the concern announced today.

title: ECONOMISTS DIVIDED ON NEW TAX CREDIT FOR CREATING JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The new jobs credit part, of the tax bill signed into law by President Carter today has the economics profession divided over its likely accomplishments.

title: Appeal. Reinstates Murder Conviction Invalidated in 1975
description: The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reversed yesterday a State Supreme Court justice and reinstated the murder conviction of a cab driver who, it was charged, had killed a man to whom he had lost $1,000 in a card game.

description: To the Editor:

title: Radio
description: Music

title: After TwoYear Stalemate, U.S. and Soviet Now Have Agreed on New Blueprint for Arms Negotiations
description: WASHINGTON, May 23After having argued for more than two years over just what they had agreed upon in Vladivostok, the United States and the Soviet Union last week in Geneva drew up a new blueprint for curbing their

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has given the International Business Machines Corporation letters of intent covering orders for 85 of the new model 3033 central processors. If consummated, this would be one of the largest nongovernmental orders ever placed for computers.

title: 7 Rape Victims Identify Youth They All Feared to See Again
description: The young woman came haltingly into the room where the detectives and lawyers awaited her. She was instructed to approach the oneway window and to keep silent until she had viewed all six men in the lineup. One of them, she was told, might be the man who had attacked her.

title: F.C.&B. to Acquire AitkinKynett Shop

description: Ethel Barrymore Colt, actress, singer and daughter of the late Ethel Barrymore a member of the ninth generation of the famous familydied Sunday at her home at 333 East 68th Street. She was 65 years old.

description: The first concerted effort to sever all United States sports competitions with South Africa has been formed, with next month's Federation Cup women's tennis matches in Britain an early target, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: Airport Worker Says Protest Led to Ouster
description: A leader of demonstrations against landings of the Concorde supersonic plane at Kennedy International Airport said yesterday that he had made hardship appeal against the dismissal of an airport worker who took part in Sunday's protest against the BritishFrench craft.

title: EFFECT OF CASINOS ON HOUSING IS SCORED
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 23A study completed today reports a systematic effort by landlords to evict Hispanic, poor and elderly residents from Atlantic City tenements to raze buildings and sell property at rates inflated by the expected arrival of casino gambling.

description: President Carter has clearly indicated that he will seek ways to reduce the soaring costs of health care in this nation, and hospitals reportedly are already feeling the squeeze.

description: ALBANY, May 23Governor Carey announced today that the state would supply 10,000 elderly residents of Rochester with citizens band radios as a pilot project to help them protect themselves against crime.

title: President Selects Oceanographer as Head of NASA
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)President Carter selected a physicistoceanographer today to head the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. He said that he would nominate Robert A. Frosch, 49 year,A old, associate director for applied oceanography at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution,. to head the space agency.

title: In Memoriam
description: HOLLANDERPaul. RememberIm the birthday of my heart's best treasure.

title: Maria Leach Dies at 85, Editor Of Major Works, Covering Folklore
description: Maria Leach, the editor of The Dictionary of Folklore, Mythology and Legend, a twovolume work published in 1949 and 1950, died in a hospital near her home in Barrington, Nova Scotia, Sunday, after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

title: OFFICERS AT ATTICA THREATEN TO STRIKE
description: Correction officers at Attica said yesterday that they might strike rather than answer questions in another investigation or incidents that resulted in a riot at the maximumsecurity facility last July.

title: Angola Said to Oust 2 High Aides For Criticism of President Neto

title: French Unions Joining In General Strike Today Over Government Policy
description: PARIS, May 23 (AP)France faces general strike tomorrow that the Government says could cost the country $1.2 billion, or 0.5 percent of its total output for the year.

title: $34 BILLION TAX CUT SIGNED BY PRESIDENT; RETURNS SIMPLIFIED
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  President Carter signed into law today a bill designed to save lowincome and middleincome taxpayers more than $5 billion this year as part of a $34.2 billion Federal Lax cut spread over the next 28 months.

title: Censored Brazilian Humorist Keeps His Public Laughing
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, May 23Millor Ferriandes is Brazil's best playwright, one of its finest painters, certainly among its most published authors, and undoubtedly its best humorist.

title: Protecting Trade Against Protectionism
description: if President Carter really means to head off protectionism in trade, he will have to change his strategy. At the moment, he is avoiding confrontation with American industries that seek shelter from foreign competition, preferring to blunt their demands by negotiating temporary import controls. But the failure of the recently announced import quota for Japanese color television ides to satisfy the appetite of some American competitors suggests that the President's best hope lies in fuller public campaign for free trade.

title: Kuwait's Oil Output Up in April
description: KUWAIT, May 23 (UPI)Kuwaiti oil production in April averaged 1.7 million barrels a day, the Government said today. In 1976 Kuwaiti production averaged 2.1 million barrels a day.

title: Begin, Winner of Israeli Election, Is Hospitalized With Chest Pains
description: JERUSALEM, May 23Menahem Begin the head of the rightwing Likud political bloc and the man slated to be Israel's next. Prime Minister, was taken to a hospital early today suffering from chest pains.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Carter Must Decide Soon on Rumania's Trade Status
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  President Carter will have to decide shortly whether to continue granting normal trading privileges to Communistruled Rumania in the face of growing reservations in Congress about Rumania's human rights Practices.

title: AbdulJabbar Is Chosen M.V. P. for a Fifth Time
description: Bill Walton is good, but Kareem AbdulJabbar is the best. All one needs to do is ask the players of the National Basketball Association, who vote annually to select the league's most valuable. By a vote of 159 to 29, anflounced yesterday, they About chose AbdulJabbar, the towering center of the Los Pro Angeles Lakers, over WalBasketball toil, the key to the Portland Trail Blazers reaching the championship round against the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: France Protests Detention of Six By Polisario Rebels in the Sahara
description: PARIS, May 23Foreign Minister Louis de Guiringaud today protested an announcement to the effect that six Frenchmen recently captured in Mauretania by the socalled Polisario movement are mercenaries.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: In Washington today, hearings resume before the Metcalf subcommittee inquiring into the accounting profession. Today's sar witness before the Senate group is to be Harvey Kapnick, chairman of Arthur Andersen & Company and a mover and shaker within the accounting world.

title: BANKRUPT GEORGIA BANK IS REOPENED FOR BUSINESS
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., May 23 (UPI)The First Augusta Bank and Trust, which was declared bankrupt on Friday opened for business today after being acquired by the First National Bank of Atlanta.

title: President Warned by House Democrats Against a Water Projects Veto
description: WASHINGTON, May 23House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. indicated today that he had warned. President Carter that if he vetoed water projects appropriations measures he would set off a serious confrontation with Congress.

title: SAN FRANCISCO VOTE TO TEST NEW MAYOR
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 23Mayor George Moscone asked some of the most powerful figures in the city today to help him diffuse some of their power in the interest of stability and democracy.

title: 100,000 Jobs May Go To Welfare Mothers
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)Labor Department officials predicted today that nearly 100,000 of the Government's 400,000 new public service jobs would go to welfare mothers.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Carter Considering a GI. Bill for Youths in Federal Job Programs
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Carter Administration is contemplating a G.I. Bill for disadvantaged young adults who work in Federal job programs.

title: Ford Introduces Fiesta, 42MileaGallon Minicar
description: NAPA, Calif., May 23The Ford Motor Company, despite the shutdown of three domestic smallcar plants, today unveiled the American version of its new Europeanbuilt Fiesta minicar amid growing hopes of good sales prospects for small cars this fall.

title: Chester J. Deutsch, 52, an Officer Of Connecticut Balcing Company
description: Chester J. Deutsch, senior vice president for finance and administration of Arnold Bakers Inc., died of cancer Sunday at his home, 29 Lawrence Hill Road, Stamford. Conn. He was 52 years old.

title: Mondale, Home, T ells Of Accord on Africa
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)Vice President Mondale, returning in high spirits from his European mission, said today that the United States and Britain were in complete agreement on how to achieve black majority rule in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: An upstate witness is scheduled to testify as hearings resume today in the Metcalf subcommittee's inquiry into the accounting profession. He is Harvey Kapniol:, chairman of Arthur Anderson & Company. Page 51.

title: Edison High Triumphs In Queens Track Meet
description: Edison scored 43 points to take the title yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League's Queens track and field championships at Randalls Island. Andrew Jackson was second at 251/2 points, and Van Buren and John Bowne tied for third at 23.

description: The heart may go out to Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, who lost his job in South Korea for denouncing President Carter's new policy there. But the mind must applaud the President.

description: At a time of rising demands for an overhaul of the welfare system, fiscal experts working for Mayor Beame and Governor Carey have concluded that national payment standards and other elements of socalled welfare reform are not necessarily in the interests of New York State or New York City.

description: WESTPORT, Conn., May 23The dogwood trees in the center divider of the Merritt Parkway did not put on their usual spring show this year, and the mountain laurels look limp. .

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Theodore Rosenberg, a 50yearold lawyer from Brooklyn, has been indicted again on charges of grand larceny in connection with an alleged scheme to get a light sentence for Giovanni Reyes, a man charged with murder in 1973.

title: World Bank's Borrowing in Year To June 30 Is Put at $4.1 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, May 23(AP) The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) announced today that its borrowing program for the current fiscal year, which ends June 30, was a record of $4.1 billion.

description: WHITE PLAINS, May 23The Town Club of Scarsdale, which has been described as an organization that is really a branch of the village government, wa upheld in its menonly policy today by Federal judge.

description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)  Jack Cunningham, who scored an upset Republican victory to succeed Transportation Secretary Brock Adams in the House, was sworn in today as Washington State's newest Representative.

title: FORMER PROSECUTOR CONVICTED IN BRIBERY
description: Norman D. Archer, a former chief of the indictment bureau in the Queens District Attorney's office was convicted last night of sharing in a $15,000 bribe to fix a criminal case.

title: PRESIDENT PLEDGES TO HELP HANDICAPPED
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  President Carter was cheered by several thousand handicapped Americans tonight as he promised to work forcefully to end discrimination against them

description: DUBLIN, Ohio, May 23Jack Nicklaus went through the formality of playing three holes this morning to complete the victory in the Memorial Tournament he actually had locked up yesterday before rain and lightning deferred the finish.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Anglers Are Surveyed on Needs
description: New York State is about to start a survey of resident and nonresident freshwater anglers to determine their habits, favorite fish and amount they spend annually in pursuit of their sport.

description: Films

title: Cauthen Breaks Arm and Rib in Spill at Belmont
description: Steve Cauthen, the teenager whose unmatched fivemonth winning spree had made him the country's leading jockey, was thrown and trampled in threehorse mishap at Belmont race track yesterday. He suffered a concussion, broken arm and broken rib and had to be hospitalized.

title: Life of Privacy Panel Extended
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)  The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation extending the life of the Privacy Protection Study Commission for three months. The commission, due to expire July 10, was created in 1974. The House vote was 387 to 3. The Senate passed an identical bill May 9.

title: Quog Music Theater Twin Bill Limns City Life Then and Now
description: Whether by design or accident, the theme of young women alone and adrift in the big city pervades the stage pieces on a double bill presented by the Quog Music Theater in the Hotel Ansonia's AMDA Theater this week (there will be performances nightly through Sunday and a matinee on Sunday).

title: Robert Preston, in Scott's Role, Proves Sly Fox of Another Hue
description: By common consent, George C. Scott is a hard act to follow. Indeed there are times when he is a hard act to share a bill withand the redoubtable Mr. Scott in comedy, with his shark's grin, flaring eyes and a lack of the histrionic inhibitions he plays on like a harp, is like a fire engine on an urgent summons to hell. How do you replace him?

title: Japan's Motor Vehicle Output Down
description: TOKYO, May 23 (Reuters)Motor Vehicle production in Japan fell6.3 percent last month to 703,050, the automobile Manufacturers Association said today. The figure was down from March's record 750,120 cars and trucks, but still 3 percent above the 683,250 vehicles manufactured in April 1976. The April figures included 448,270 cars, 250.340 trucks and 4,440 buses, the association said.

title: A Possible Leash on the French Left
description: OXFORD, EnglandWhat difference will it make to France when, as is generally expected, the CommunistSocialist coalition gains power in the general election scheduled for 1978?

title: $34 BILLION TAX CUT SIGNED BY PRESIDENT; RETURNS SIMPLIFIED
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  President Carter signed into law today a bill designed to save lowincome and middleincome taxpayers more than $5 billion this year as part of a $34.2 billion Federal tax cut spread over the next 28 months.

title: Big Ben Grinds to Temporary Halt
description: LONDON, May 23 (AP)Big Ben, the clotk atop the House of Commons that takes its name from a bell in the clock tower, stopped at 9:25 A.M. today. An engineer climbed.,316 feet to the clock chamber, and by 11:30 A.M. the clock was working again. He said that all needed was a drop of oil on a tight bearing. Last summer, the clock was out of action for 22 days.

title: U.S. Rock Group Ends First Tour of Soviet
description: MOSCOW, May 23 (AP)The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band today completed the first Soviet tour by an American rock group with a concert in Moscow.

title: Squad Cars Turn Into Classrooms As Professors Study Life in Bronx
description: Two black children, frightened and apparently homeless, pressed closely against a wall inside a Bronx police station, wideeyed at the noise and commotion as the officers changed their tours of duty.

title: Recital: Habermann Plays Sorabji Piano Works
description: Kaikhosru Shapurji Sorabji is a halfIndian composer, the son of a Parsi father and a SpanishSicilian mother, and something of a mystery man to this generation. Mr. Sorabji, who has lived most of his life in England, is now 84, at which patriarchal age he has withdrawn a 37yearold ban on the performance of his works. One of them enjoys immortality by being listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the longest nonrepetitive piano piece (a 252page, threehour score weighing four pounds).

title: City Orders Flushing Airport Safety Study
description: Mayor Beame yesterday ordered a study of operations and safety at the cityowned Flushing Airport in Queens. Civil Air Patrol plane that had just taken off from the airport crashed into a private home Sunday, killing a 16yearold boy who was aboard.

title: H.E.W. to Eliminate Federal Form For College Students Seeking Aid
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that it was eliminating a Federal form widely used by college students applying for Government financial assistance.

title: Carter News Parley Slated for Thursday
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)President Carter will hold a news conference at 10:30 A.M. Thursday before leaving Washington on a sixday trip to Georgia the White House press secretary, Jody Powell, announced today. The conference will be his eighth since becoming President.

title: Dave Anderson
description: WEST HAVEN, Conn.Yesterday should have been the one day in the year when Maurice Podoloff knew that basketball remembered him. In its New York offices the National Basketball Association announced that Kareem AbdulJabber again had been voted the Podoloff Cup as the league's most valuable player. But for Maurice Podoloff, all the days

title: STEEL OUTPUT UP IN WEEK TO HIGHEST LEVEL OF YEAR
description: Steel production for the week ended May 21 continued its upward trend and reached 2.8 million tons, its highest weekly level of the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yegerday. This was a gain of 0.2 percent over the preceding week and represented _ the seventh consecutive weekly increase. At its present level of production, the industry is utilizing S8.5 percent of its total available capability.

title: E.P.A. STARTS AN INQUIRY INTO A FARM INSECTICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 ( Reuters)The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had started a public investigation into possible dangers of Toxaphene, one of the most widely used farm insecticides.

title: New Italian Film 'We All Loved...' Paced by Outrage and High Spirits
description: "We All Loved Each Other So Much" is the forgettably awkward title of Ettore Scola's wise, reflective Italian comedy that examines 30 years of recent Italian social history in terms of the friendship of three men and the one woman each man has loved at one time or another. It's the sort of thing for which European film makers, especially Italian, have a special feeling, while Americans have none whatsoever, if only because American producers are made uneasy by movies that are about friendship and that attempt to cover so much time."We All Loved Each Other So Much," which opened yesterday at the Beekman, is full of fondness, rue, outrage and high spirits. It is alsosurprising for an Italian filmpacked with the kind of movie references that French filmmakers like, and it is dedicated to the late Vittorio DeSica, whose "Bicycle Thief" plays a prominent part in the picture.The three men, who have become friends as leftist partisans near the end of the Nazi occupation of Italy, are Giovanni, a lawyer (Vittorio Gassman). Antonio (Nino Manfredi), who begins his postwar career as a hospital orderly (and remains one for the rest of his life, and Nico (Stefano Satta Flores), a politically committed movie nut who doesn't hesitate to abandon his wife and child to go off to Rome after a disagreement over the merits of "The Bicycle Thief."The woman who moves in and out of their lives is Luciana (Stefania Sandrelli), an aspiring actress, the high point of whose career (and one of the high points of the film) comes when she is cast as an extra in "La Dolce Vita." The scene that Mr. Scola recreates is the preparation for Anita Ekberg's walk through the Trevi fountain, complete with Marcello Mastrcianni actually sitting on the sidelines as Federico Fellini directs (and receives a tribute from a policeman who says, "I've always admired your films, Mr. Rossellini").The film's principal storyline has to do with the decline and fall of the lawyer, Giovanni, into successful opportunism, a role that Mr. Gassman has played before, but which he does with immense gallantry and humor as he goes from youth to middle-age. Also extremely good are Aldo Fabrizi, as the crooked industrialist who becomes Giovanni's father-in-law, and Giovanna Ralli as the fat, bird-brained rich girl whom Giovanni marries and transforms into a chic, bored woman who comes to identify herselffatallywith the women in Antonioni movies.Mr. Scola, who has been represented here both as a writer ("Il Sorpasso") and director ("Made in Italy," "The Pizza Triangle," among others), employs a comic style that is effective for being loose, allowing him to introduce real people as themselves, to parody "Strange Interlude's" spoken interior thoughts, to go from slapstick to satire and then to drama of genuine feelings.At its best, the film combines a number of different emotions at once, as when the film-obsessed Nico attempts to teach Luciana the fundamentals of Sergei Eisenstein's theory of montage on Rome's Spanish Steps, all the while seducing her.Though the film is very funny at moments, the dominant mood is a sense of loss, but even here the film makes its point in a backhanded way. "We wanted to change the world, but the world changed us," says Antonio, the aging hospital orderly. Yet Mr. Scola recognizes this as the windy clich of someone given to self-dramatization. After 30 years the three friends are more worn, more tired, more experienced than they were as young men, but neither the world nor time has changed them in any essential ways. That's the bitter truth.

title: People in Sports
description: Al Hrabosky's twoday suspension was lifted yesterday after the pitcher and his attorney had met with Manager Vernon Rapp and General Manager Bing Devine of the St. Louis Cardinals. Hrabosky, known as the Mad Hungarian because of his fierce competitiveness, was suspended for insubordination after he refused to talk to Rapp in the manager's office before last Saturday's game. Although he had been feuding with Rapp since spring training over the manager's cleanshaven edict, which forced him to shave his flowing mustache, Hrabosky said he had not caused the present rift.

title: Sperry Plans to Buy Varian Data Machines
description: The Sperry Rand Corporation and Varian Associates of Palo Alto, Calif., announced the signing of an agreement by which Sperry intends to purchase for cash Varian Data Machines, a subsidiary of Varian that produces minicomputers in Irvine, Calif. Last year Varian Data and its affiliates had revenues of about $40 million. While no figures were given, industry sources estimated the transaction would have value of about $25 million, depending on certain contingency arrangements.

title: BEE BUDGETS FATE RESTING WITH BANKS
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, which is in the final stage of considering Mayor Beame's proposed 197778 budget, said yesterday that the budget could not be approved unless the city got a firm assurance from the banks that they would defer loan paymentsdue them.

title: Chain Store Sales in April Up 10.4% From 76 Level; Gain Is Lowest in 7 Months
description: Sales of the nation's criatn organizations in April rose by 10.4 percent over the yearearlier level, according to a compilation prepared by Chain Store Age magazine. For the first four months of the year, chain sates increased by 11.6 percent compared to the corresponding period of 1976.

title: Advertising
description: How would you like to be introduced to a medium with an advertising cost per thousand as low as 3V2 cents that reaches 81.7 percent of all adult males and 72.2 percent of all adult females and that has a better advertising message recall than the average fourcolor magazine nage?

title: Basque Guerrillas Say They Hold Kidnapped Spanish Industrialist
description: MADRID, May 23 (Reuters)Basque nationalist guerrillas announced today that they were the kidnappers of a leading industrialist whose abduction three days ago was seen as an attempt to raise tension at the start of Spain's election campaign.

title: Dow Drops 13.40 to 917.06; Loss Is 24.85 for 3 Days
description: Reflecting inflation and interestrate worries, stock prices fell sharply yesterday across the board.

title: S.E.C. SAYS TYPESETTER IMPROPERLY USED DATA
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a typesetter for a New York financial printer with using advance information picked up on his job to make a $28,000 profit in the stock market.

title: Presidential Yacht Acquired
description: PORTSMOUTH, R.I., May 23 (UPI)The former Presidential yacht Sequoia was officially awarded today to a Rhode Island businessman, Thomas Aquinas Malloy, who plans to make it an historical tourist attraction. The Defense Department's ship sales office gave Mr. Malloy ownership after he signed art agreement not to make any significant changes on the 104foot luxury cruiser, which was used by Presidents from Herbert C. Hoover to Gerald R. Ford.

title: Catering to the Cowboy in Us All
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  It had to happen. First came Sears to rival the local dry goods store. Then came Safeway to rival the local grocery, Herman's in sporting goods, Sam Goody's in records. Now  a toot on the bull horn, please  comes Sheplers, a supermarket of Western wear.

title: Profits Off Sharply For Member Firms
description: Profits of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange dropped sharply in the first quarter, as tradingg volume, and therefore commission income, sagged. Net earnings amounted to $34.7 million, compared with $215.1 million in the first quarter of 1976 and $111.5 million in last year's fourth quarter.

title: Sharif Khan Triumphs In Racquets Tourney
description: SPRING GLEN, N.Y., May 23Sharif Khan of Pakistan, now a squash racquets leaching professional in Toronto, took the S15,000 first prize in the first world ricquets toullriment today at the Homowack Ludes.

title: A RETIRED VICE ADMIRAL HEADS RIFLE ASSOCIATION
description: CINCINNATI, May 23 (UPI) Members of the National Rifle Association who over the weekend ousted four top officials of their organization today elected Lloyd Mustin, retired Navy vice adm., to head the 1.2 million member organ! zation.

title: High Court Rejects Uranium Data Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI)The Supreme Court today refused to block temporarily the Federal Trade Commission from giving Congress data on uranium reserves, which the Exxon Corporation and two other companies say would disclose their trade secrets. Two lower Federal courts had rejected the companies interim plea to block the disclosure, and a United States District Court here dismissed the entire suit. The United States Appeals Court still has before a company request for a 10day notice before the commission turns over any material.

title: ASIAN EXTREMISTS SEIZE 161 HOSTAGES IN THE NETHERLANDS
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 23 Asian extremists living in the Netherlands seized an elementary school and hijacked a train today in this northern agricultural area, taking 161 hostages.

title: 100 Mutual Stations to Carry NebelJones Night Talk Show
description: The allnight talk and interview program with Long John Nebel and Candy Jones on radio station WMCA will be distributed coast to coast by the Mutual Broadcasting System, beginning next Monday. Approximately 100 stations of the Mutual network will carry the broadcasts, running from midnight to 5:30 A.M., Mondays through Saturdays. WMCA, the originating station, will also continue to carry a Sunday night broadcast that will not go out over the network.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros

title: Kaunda Says Vorster Is Using Smith
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, May 23President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia said today that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith of Rhodesia had three times been kept from resigning by pressure from South Africa.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Connecticut Senate Votes Consolidation Of 200 State Units
description: HARTFORD, May 23The Connecticut Senate approved a plan today to merge more than 200 agencies, boards and commissions of state government into 23 departments reporting directly to the Governor.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The New York Times/Paul Hosefros

title: TV: Key to the Universe Surveys Modern Physics
description: For those who, like myself, classify simple electricity and the operation of ordinary appliances (such as a television set) in a category that might be called modern magic, physics remains a science demanding extraordinary faith.

title: Fall Lines Full of the Bloused Look
description: The fashion lexicon for fall is full of such code words as voluminous, soft and easy. They describe the general drift of the new clothes. A specific way this effect is achieved is through blous!ng.

title: High Court Rules States Can Enter Into Agency Shop Labor Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Supreme Court ruled today that state and local governments could enter into agency shop agreements with labor unions under which a union is the exclusive agent for the employees and all employees must contribute to the union whether or not they are union members.

title: Bonn Denies It Was Connected With Disappearance of Uranium
description: BONN, May 23 (UPI)West Germany denied today it was connected with the disappearance of 200 tons of uranium that is reported to have been shipped to Israel.

title: Dibbs Triumphs Easily At Start of French Open
description: PARIS, May 23 (Reuters)America's Eddie Dibbs and Argentina's Guillermo Vitas work opening matches in straight sets today at the $300,000 French open tennis championships.

title: O'Neill Concerned at Possibility That Carter May Reappoint Burns
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Congressional leaders are concerned that President Carter intends to reappoint Arthur F. Burns as the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. suggested today.

title: ALBANY BARS A HALT IN ABORTIONS STUDY
description: ALBANY, May 23The State Health Department today rejected requests by two legislators that it halt a study on the health effects of abortion until it notified the 48.000 women involved.

title: Jersey Senate Passes Casino Bill; Assembly Action Slated Thursday
description: TRENTON, May 23The State Senate approved today a 98page bill for the regulation of casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: ALICE HOLCOMB
description: Alice Holcomb, an artist who gave show at the Barzansky Gallery here in 1962, died last Saturday in Sarasota, Fla., where she had been living. She was 70 years old and a resident also of Rockport, Mass., where she had served on the governing board of the Rockport Art Association.

title: SAFETY INSPECTIONS HELD CONSTITUTIONAL AFFRONT
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)An Idaho man who refused to allow Federal safety inspectors into his place of business told a Congressional panel today that the safety inspections were a premeditated affront to the Fourth Amendment.

title: 2 Specialist Firms on Big Board Lose Registrations
description: Two specialist firms on the New York Stock Exchange that operate as a single unit lost their registration as a specialist in the common stock of a listed company because of violations of regulations, the exchange announced yesterday.

title: GATT to Investigate Higher U.S. Duty on Japanese Electronic Goods
description: GENEVA, May 23An international trade group, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, said today that it would investigate whether additional duties imposed by a United States Customs Court against Japanese electronic imports contravened the organization's fairtrade rules.

title: Fire Damages Newark Hotel
description: NEWARK, May 23 (UPI)  Several dozen resident; of the Renzell Hotel in downtown Newark were forced to evacuate today by a predawn fire that broke out on the top floor of the hotel. The police and fire officials said that the blaze, on the fourth floor of the oncefashionable brick hotel on Broad Street, apparently was caused by poor wiring or a guest smoking in bed.

title: Scientists Report Using Bacteria To Produce the Gene for Insulin
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Scientists in California reported today that bacteria bred in laboratories have been engineered to make the gene for insulin, a developmeat that could provide a virtually limitless supply of the vital hormone and have an important impact on the treatment and understanding of diabetes.

title: Judge May Bar Consumer Unit On Ban of Tris
description: Federal District Court Judge Robert F. Chapman said last night that he intended if possible to issue an order today that would temporarily enjoin the Consumer Product Safety Commission from enforcing its controversial ban on the use of the flameretardant chemical Tris

title: SUPREME COURT BARS PLEA BY EHRLICHMAN, HALDEMAN, MITCHELL
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Supreme Court refused today to hear the appeals of John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman from their COIINiclions in the Watergate coverup case.

title: Soviet Military Aide in India
description: NEW DELHI, May 23 (Reuters)Deputy Defense Minister Ivan G. Pavlovsky of the Soviet Union arrived here today for a fiveday visit to consolidate military links between the two countries. His visit comes less than a month after Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko arrived here to discuss the continuance of strong ties with the new Indian Government.

title: DoughnutShaped Tank to Aid in Study of Ocean Fish
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 23  An unusual, doughnutshaped aquarium, the first in this country designed to hold schools of fastswimming ocean fish, has been displayed at the California Academy of Sciences. It may soon house a great white shark the species denicted in the film Jaws.

title: AACM Band Covers Wide Range
description: WKCRFM, the campus radio station of Columbia University, presented the last of four concerts devoted to the new jazz of Chicago's AACMthe Association for the Advancement of Creative Musiciansat the Wollman Auditorium on Sunday night. As with earlier events in the series, attendance was disappointing, but spirits were high, and Sunday's program was particularly auspicious because it introduced the AACM big band to New York.

title: Extension Is Sought For the Exchange Of Chevrolet Engine
description: Saying there has been confusion and dealer resistance, State Attorney General Louis Lefkowitz asked a court yesterday to extend a June 1 settlement deadline for 5,000 consumers who got Chevrolet engines when they bought higherpriced General Motors cars.

title: Bergen to Be Site for School for the Handicapped
description: HACKENSACK, May 23The first of five regional day schools for the state's severely physically impaired and multihandicapped children is to be built In Bergen County under legislation signed today by Governor Byrne.

title: Italian Premier Visiting Greece
description: ATHENS, May 23 (Reuters)Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti arrived here today from Rome for a twoday official visit and talks with Prime Minister Constantine Caramanlis on international and bilateral issues. The talks are expected to center on Greece's application for full membership in the European Common Market.

title: HOMER S. BROWN
description: PITTSBURGH, May 23  Homer S. Brown, a retired Allegheny County Com mon Pleas Court judge and a formes Pennsylvania state legislator, died yes terday. He was 79 years old.

title: TRADE PACTS CONCLUDED BY JAPAN AND CANADA
description: TOKYO, May 23 (Reuters)Japan and China concluded trade contracts worth a record $370 million during a monthlong biannual spring trade fair that ended last week in Canton, a Japanese trade official said today.

title: Breeden Stars in Japan
description: TOKYO, May 23 (AP)Hal Breeden, a former player for the Montreal Expos, hit two home runs today, leading the Hanshin Tigers to a 5.2 victory over the Yakult Swallows, Breeden has 15 homers this season.

title: National Cancer Institute Weighs The First Human Tests of Laetrile
description: The National Cancer Institute is considering the first human tests of the highly controversial drug laetrile, the institute's acting director said yesterday.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: JOHN MILTON LACEY
description: John Milton Lacey, special agent in charge of the office of investigation, United States Customs for the Treasury Department in Newark, died Saturday in Jersey City Medical Center of injuries received in an automobile accident. He was 47 years old and lived at 1792 Watchung Avenue, Plainfield, N.J.

title: A Million New Income Tax Refunds Foreseen
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.. May 23 (AP)More than a million Americans may be able to get Federal income tax refunds under a provision in the tax bill President Carter signed today, the head of a nationwide tax preparation service said.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: WASHINGTONA banking official here, peering out a window toward the Capitol recently, made an interesting, though perhaps understated, comment on some legislation expected to be considered by Congress soon. It will oro

title: DR. JOHN W. MATTHEWS
description: Dr. John W. Matthews, a research physicist for the International Business Machines Corporation, died Friday at Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. He was 45 years old and lived in Ossining. N.Y.

title: Moynihan's Brother Working for Saudis
description: Michael W. Moynihan, the younger brother of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Is directing the public relations for the visit of Saudi Arabian leaders to Washington this week.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 21Angelo Bruno, reputed head of organized crime in the Philadelphia area, agreed today to testify before the State Commission of Investigation to avoid going back to prison for contempt of court.

title: Study Scores Effects on Housing Of Proposed Atlantic City Casinos
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 23A study completed today reports a systematic effort by landlords to evict Hispanic, poor and elderly residents from Atlantic City tenements to raze buildings and sell property at rates inflated by the expected arrival of casino gambling.

title: Satellite Warning System Launched
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., May 23 (UPI) An Atlas Agena rocket fired a spy satellite into space at 2:13 P.M. today, to provide what sources said would be an early warning system that could detect missile attack. The satellite was also reported to be part of a series to monitor rocket tests in the Soviet Union and China.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: Sanjay Gandhi Still a Major Topic in India, but Now the Talk Is of Jail
description: NEW DELHI, May 23Two wellknown politicians were sitting in a rose garden here the other evening, discussing what has become one of the hottest topics of late.

title: May Coffee Contract Is Closed Out
description: After gyrating wildly during its lifetime, the May coffee contract went off the board yesterday at the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange on an upbeat note. Prices had ranged from a high of $3,375 a pound to a low of $1.525.

title: John Duncan Miller, Correspondent Of The Times Of London in the U.S.
description: LONDON, May 23 (AP)John Duncan Miller, Washington correspondent of The Times of London from 1947 to 1954, is dead at the age of 75, The Times said today. He died on Friday in Lewes, Sussex.

title: The New York Times/Paul Hosofros Robbie Ftorek with Gordie Howe Trophy for most valuable player in W.H.A. Howes Choose Whalers Over N.H.L. Bruins
description: The stubborn World Hockey Association, ever hopeful of consolidation with the National Hockey League, strengthened its image yesterday and scored a psychological victory over its rival with the announcement that Gordie Howe and his sons Mark and Marty had signed a multimillion dollar contract to play for the New England Whalers.

title: Bridge:
description: While six unbeaten teams rested last night, several topranked groups in the Resinger knockout championships at the New York Hilton Hotel were fighting to survive.

title: 100 Border Patrolmen Rushed to California
description: HOUSTON, May 23One hundred border patrolmen are being temporarily sent to southern California to help stern flood of illegal aliens entering the country and to reduce widespread violence along the Mexican border near Tijuana, Leonel J. Castillo, Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said here today.

title: Fluor Unit Awarded Contract
description: The Fluor Corporation said at Los Angeles that its British subsidiary, the Manchester division 4of Fluor Ltd., had been awarded a $219 million contract for design, engineering and procurement of two chemical plants at Wilhelmshaven, West Germany. The contract was awarded by Imperial Chemical Industries of London and involves a caustic chlorine plant and a vinyl chloride monomer plant.

title: Busing Foes Protest in Boston
description: BOSTON, May 23 (AP)Antibusing demonstrators marched here yesterday to protest courtordered desegregation. The turnout, estimated variously at 700 to 2,000, was cited by rally spokesman as a sign of the depth of opposition to forced busing. Among the demonstrators were 22 marchers from Louisville, Ky., a city also under court order to desegregate, who had traveled to Boston for what they termed the Second Boston Tea Party.

title: F.A.A. Survey Hints a Gain in Approval for Concorde
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Flights of the Concorde supersonic airliner in the vicinity of Dulles International Airport near here are facing declining opposition, according to a Government agency.

title: Notes on People
description: The annual Ladies Home Journal WoMen of the year awards were presented last night in Ford's Theater in Washington. The nine distinguished women cited were Marian Anderson, the retired contralto; Elizabeth Drew, the Washingtonbased writer; Liz Carpenter, former press secretary to Lady Bird Johnson, who was on hand to present Mrs. Carpenter's award; Ruth C. Clusen, president of the League of Women Voters; Elisabeth KiiblerRoss, the psychiatrist and author of On Death and Dying'; Margaret McNamara, founder of the Reading is Fundamental program; Gloria Scott, president of the Girl Scouts; Sheila Young, winner of three speed skating medals in the 1976 Winter Olympics, and Addle L. Wyatt, an international vice president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen union. Journal readers nominated the women, whowere chosen by a jury of women leaders.

title: ALVIN R. GUYLER
description: Alvin R. Guyler, who retired in 1971 as executive director of the Veterans Administratibn for the Pittsburgh area, died Sunday. He lived in Wilkes,Barre, Pa., and was 75 years old.

title: LEVITT OPPOSES AID BY STATE TO BLOCK CORPORATE EXODUS
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., May 23Comptroller Arthur Levitt said today he opposed using New York State's credit for loans or guarantees to keep corporations from leaving the state. The comptroller also said, the time was ripe to adopt state constitutional amendment that would bar any new public programs backed by the state's moral obligations to make good if the projects go sour.

title: Nassau Ordered by Court To Complete Assessment At Full Values by 1980
description: The Board of Assessors of Nassau County was ordered yesterday to cornptete by May 1, 1980, new assessment bats at full value for all property in the County.:

title: Gemini Continues NewRealism Trend
description: One of the most impressive aspects of the last theater seasonwhich I think has been the finest, on the whole, of the last decadehas been the emergence of a number of new American playwrights. What is also interesting about these playwrights is that, by and large, they have been working realistically. They are a long way away from, say John Guare, Sam Shepard, Lanford Wilson, or even Israel Horovitz and Leonard Melfi. It is perhaps significant that David Rabe's most recent play, Streamers, the last of his Vietnam trilogy, is also his most realistic.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Some 350 striking Newark cab drivers reached agreement yesterday with city officials to end their weeklong strike staged to demand improved working conditions and to protest the loss of their business. Lewis Smith, the president of the Newark Taxi Drivers Association, said the union reached agreement to end the strike following a meeting with William Walls, the City Business Administrator, who represented Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, and other city officials,

title: FORMER PROSECUTOR CONVICTED IN BRIBERY
description: Norman D. At cher, a former chief of the indictment bureau in the Queens District Attorney's office, was convicted last night of sharing in a $15,000 bribe to fix a criminal case.

title: Rifle Group's New Leader
description: CINCINNATI, May 23It was easy to tell most of the 1,100 voting members of the National Rifle Association of America were more than happy with their selection yesterday of Harlon Bronson Carter, 63 years old, as their executive vice president.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MAY 24, 1977

title: Environmental Message Seen as an Indication of Carter's Commitment and a Push for Advisory Panel
