description: LOS ANGELES, May 23  Amohgseveral noteworthy features of President Carter's environmental., message: in Con, gress today, perhaps the most significant is simply that it was promulgated:At is the first formal. Presidential affirmation

title: Carey Given Delay on Bridge Tolls
description: Efforts to reach a compromise on court ordered bridge tolls were disclosed yesterday to a Federal judge who had ordered Governor Carey to comply with timetable for establishing them on bridges over the East River and Harlem River.

title: PeugeotCitroen
description: PSA PeugeotCitroen, the French automotive group, reported from Paris )/esterday that consolidated net earnings last year totaled the equivalent of $282,660 on sales of $7.1 million. There are no comparative figures available as Peugeot S.A. and Citroen S.A. merged last year. The company said it would propose to shareholders the distribution of a 10franc dividend for 1976.

title: Yerevan Rock Audiences Find Nitty Gritty Dirt Band Far Out
description: YEREVAN, U.S.S.R.  The Nitty Gritty Dirt Band from Aspen, Colo, was hard into some tough 100decibel rock, and a lot of the Soviet kids were out of their seats and in the aisles, writhing and grinding and dancing themselves into that special sort of rockconcert frenzy that is Made in the U.S.A.

title: Atom Plants Produce Much Less Than Projected, Researchers Say
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  A research organization has reported that American nuclear plants last year generated 57.5 percent of the electricity they were designed to produce, two percentage points less than in the years through 1975 and well below the 70 to 80 percent expected by the industry and the Government.

title: The Program
description: MUSIC WITH JENS NYGAARD. Westchester Chamber Orchestra, Jens Nygaard, conductor and pianist. At Alice Tully Hall.

title: Dollar is Mixed As Pound Slips
description: LONDON, May 23 (AP)The price of gold fell in both London and Zurich today while the dollar was mixed in Europe.

title: 3.Train Crash in South Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, May 23 (AP) A crash involving three trains killed an engineer and injured 75 people today at a station in the eastern suburbs of Pretoria, officials said.They said that one train had crashed into a second that was stopped at the station, driving it into the third train. The police said that none of the injured people was in serious condition.

title: Books of The Times
description: The French started it and the Americans finished it, I seem to recall parent telling me long ago when I asked how the Panama Canal came to be. The reply was true enough as far as it went, but safer reading David McCullough's latest historical extravaganza, The Path Between the Seas: The Creation of the Panama Canal, 18701914, it strikes me as about like saving Ham

title: Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: DRIVERS IN HONOLULU BACK UNION MERGER
description: HONOLULU. May 23A merger of Hawaii's 6,000 teamsters with 23,000 members of their union in Alaska has cleared its first major hurdle here after drivers for the cityfinanced bus system unanimously approved the merger of Locals 996 and 959.

title: Justices Reject Balkanization of Fishing, Upholding Federal Laws Over a Virginia Curb
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Supreme Court ruled today against what it described as the possible balkanization cf commercial fishing in United States coastal waters, holding that Federal laws preempt a Virginia statute prohibiting the catching of menhaden in Virginia's waters by nonresidents.

title: Magnum/Marc Rlboud A desalination plant in Saudi Arabia. Many Middle Eastern countries are spending lavishly for plants to make fresh water. 20 Desalination Plants To Cost Saudis 15 Billion
description: JIDDAH, Saudi ArabiaYou can do almost anything you want, with oil, it is often said here, except drink it.

title: Nancy Festival, at 15, Shows Chaos, Bright Spots and Age
description: NANCY, FranceFor an avantgarde theater festival to celebrate a 15th anniversary may not be a contradiction in terms; but it probably tempts fate.

title: Harvard Medical Group Questions Cost and Value of Much Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, May 23Four Harvard medical professors said today that many of the 25 million operations performed on Americans each year were of questionable surgical value, and that their cost was adding substantially to health care costs.

title: Bill Approved in Trentoh
description: TRENTON, May 23The StateSenate approired today a 98page bill for the regulation of casino gambling in Atlantic City.

title: Australian Cowboys Ride Planes, But Quality of Life Is Still Pioneer
description: FOSSIL DOWNS STATION. Australia, It's roundup time on this dusty cattle ranch in Australia's remote and virtually uninhabited northwest.

title: Agriculture CallIn Set Today
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP)Scores of farmers and consumers are expected to tell their problems tomorrow to Bob Bergland, Secretary of Agriculture, senior members of his staff and more than dozen members of Congress through tollfree telephone callin, sponsored by the Agriculture Council of America.

title: The Standings
description: Tuesday, May 24, 1977

title: BRITISH PAPER SUED OVER LEYLAND STORY
description: LONDON, May 23 (Reuters)A major British newspaper is being sued for defamation over its allegations that the giant stateowned British Leyland Motor Corporation paid huge bribes to make sales abroad.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: People and Business
description: The prime rate of major domestic banks is expected to increase this week to 63/4 percent from 6 percent, according to William C. Bigelow, a vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank in charge of international money market operations.

title: Drought Victim Aid Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON. May 23 (UPI)President Carter signed a bill today providing $175 million in emergency loans and grants for persons suffering from the drought in the West. The effects of the drought are just beginning to he expressed, he said. They're going to get much worse. The new law lets the Commerce Department provide funds for digging new wells, repairing and upgradingaquaduct systems, transporting emergency water supplies and promoting conservation.

title: Issue and Debate
description: A year ago Muhammad All fought someone named Richard Dunn in Munich, and, to the great delight of NBC, 65 million watched on television in the United States. In Montreal last year five Americans won Olympic gold medals in boxing, and ABC earned golden ratings.

title: 13 Missing in Iranian Floods
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 23 (AP)Iranian newspapers said that 13 persons, mostly children, were missing today in Khurramabad after heavy rains caused flooding in the area. Khurramabad is about 230 miles southwest of Tehran.

title: Red Sox Top Yankees, 43; Game Quiet
description: The Yankees and the Boston Red Sox played a baseball game at Yankee Stadium last night the way the Yankees and Boston Red Sox are expected to play a baseball game when they play each other  intensely, ferociously, dramatically, skillfully.

title: ASIAN EXTREMISTS SEIZE 161 HOSTAGES IN THE NETHERLANDS
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 23Asian extremists living in the Netherlands seized an elementary school anc hijacked a train today in this northerr agricultural area, taking 161 hostages.

title: PRESIDENT IS PRAISED ON ENVIRONMENT AIM
description: WASHINGTON, May 23  President Carter's environmental message, submitted to Congress today, represents the sharpest shift in national policy on envirolunental matters since Theodore Roosevelt, according to the chairman of the White House's Council on Environmental Quality.

title: SUPREME COURT BARS PLEA BY EHRLICHMAN, HALDEMAN, MITCHELL
description: WASHINGTON, May 23The Supreme Court refused today to hear the appeals of John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John D. Ehrlichman from thefr convictions in the Watergate coverup case.

title: Who Is Minding the Deep Seabed?
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.  The United Nations Law of the Sea Conference, which resumed yesterday, was almost on the rocks when it recessed last September, but now the 156 countries seem poised for hard work and pragmatic compromise.

title: BROOKLYN GANG HELD AS KIDNAPPERS OF 2
description: Brooklyn police officers brandishing pistols in a 6 A.M. raid yesterday, captured what they said was a gang that had used teenaged girls as bait to entrap two victims beside a shadowy park.

title: 150 Nations Try Again To Complete Sea Pact
description: UNITED NATIONS. N.Y., May 23Negotiations to complete a Treaty on the Law of the Sea opened here today with warnings that failure to reach agreement could lead to anarchy on the seas.

title: Tass Commentator, Echoing Gromyko, Blames U.S. on Arms
description: MOSCOW, May 23The official press agency Tass said today that there was still a long distance to be covered before a new SovietAmerican agreement limiting strategic weapons could be concluded.

title: ALBANY NEARS DELAY OF ENVIRONMENT ACT
description: ALBANY, May 23The Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to postpone implementation of the state's twoyearold Environmental Quality Review Act as applies to many major construction proieets.

title: Walther Buys Way Into Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 23 (AP)Salt Walther, who had been bumped from the starting field and had not been able to get enough speed out his backup car, today bought hi, way into the lineup for Sunday' s Indianapolis 500.

title: Stubblefield Has Ace, Tops Open Qualifiers
description: DEAL, N.J., May 23 (AP)Mike Stubblefield of Rockaway River topped off his leading effort today in New Jersey qualifying for the United States Open golf tournament with a holeinone on the 170yard final hole at the Deal Country Club.

title: Taking Aim at Arms Sales
description: President Carter's new guidelines to curb arms sales abroad amount to a statement of intentions, and as such they are admirable. Though less strong than some had hoped, they are clear in purpose and direction. But it will be a year or more before anyone can know whether they will, in fact, reduce American arms sales significantly.

title: PODGORNY IS OUSTED BY SOVIET POLITBURO IN A SURPRISE MOVE
description: MOSCOW, May 24President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union wai dropped from the Communist Party's ruling Politburo today in a Krenilin move that is expected to spell the end of hie political career.

title: Suit Charges Citibank With Selling of Data Time At Ruinously Low Prices
description: An association representing companies that sell computing services sued yesterday in Federal district court in New York City to restrain Citibank from selling timeshared data processing on the bank's computers at what the association termed ruinously low prices.

title: TRUCKLOAD OF COINS HIJACKED IN QUEENS
description: But $65,000 Shipment Is Recovered laterSuspect Is Arrested

title: Spain's Election Campaign Begins
description: SEVILLE, Spain, May 24Spain's first open election campaign in four decades officially began today, with at least quarter of the electorate apparently undecided on how to vote on June 15.

title: Mrs. Carter, at a Hearing, Opposes Sending Mentally Ill to Institutions
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24Rosalynn Carter, presiding at the first public hearing of the President's Commission on Mental Health, said today that she was generally opposed to placing mentally ill persons in institutions.

title: 4Set Victory For Solomon In France
description: PARIS, May 2 (AP)Harold Solomon came back from illness today and survived his first match in the $300,000 French open tennis championships on the slow clay of Roland Garros Stadium.

title: Matlack Is Loser
description: PITTSBURGH, May 24On paper, it looked easy. Jon Matlack, starting for the Mets tonight and working on two consecutive shutouts, and Jerry Reuss, pitching for the Pittsburgh Pirates, without a victory after five defeats.

title: Marcel BleusteinBlanchet on the future of advertising in Europe.
description: Q: The second rebirth of Public's as you have often called it, and especially the acquisition of Intermarco and Fattier appear to have again taken Publicis in new directions. What is the philosophy behind the new group?

title: Most Join France's 24Hour Strike
description: PARIS, May 24Most of France's five million organized workers went on a 24hour general strike today in protest against the Government's austerity program.

title: Avoiding the Worst in Argentina
description: Things are getting so bad in Argentina that the regime, which the United States so rightly chastised only three months ago, now urgently needs some American help to block the fascist movement stirring in the wings.

title: Senate Passes 5Year Farm Bill Exceeding Carter's Support Level
description: WASHINGTON. May 24 Brushing aside warnings of a possible Presidential Veto, the Senate tonight passed a fiveyear farm bill setting grain price supports well above levels recommended by the Carter Administration. But the Senate adopted an Administration proposal that foodstamp recipients no longer be required to pay cash for a portion of their stamps. The bill was passed by a vote of 69 to 18.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: Lawrence Van Gelder

title: Deere's Net for Quarter Up 9.7%
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest manufacturer of farm equipment and a leading maker of light construction machinery, reported yesterday a profit gain of 9.7 percent for the latest quarter and of 1.9 percent for the six months ended April 30.

title: Leonard Opdycke, Was Professor Of Fine Arts at Harvard University
description: Leonard Opdycke, associate professor of fine arts emeritus at Harvard University, died last Friday at his home in Boston. He was 82 years old.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: A woman standing on a balcony at the 250yearold Dock Street Theater the background, is the steeple of St. Philip's Episcopal Chuich.

title: At the Center of Power Since 1963
description: Nikolai Viktorovich Podgorny, once named by Nikita S. Khrushchev as possible successor, was born 74 years ago in Karlovka, the Ukraine. . . After eight years in engineering jobs at sugarbeet refineries, became a deputy commisar of Ukrainian food industry. . . Named party chief of Kharkov Province in 1950 and of the entire Ukrain in 1957 . . . Moved into higher echelons of the party on the basis of ties with Khrushchev, becoming alternate member of the ruling Politburo in 1958 and full voting member in 1960... Transferred to center of power structure in 1963 when he moved from Ukrainian party leadership to the post of a national party secretary. . . After ouster of Khrushchev in 1964, joined Leonid I. Brezhnev and Aleksei N. Kosygin in top levels of Soviet leadership and was appointed Presidentformal title is Chairman of Presidium of. Supreme Soviet. . .Has represented the Soviet Union on foreign journeys, most recently to Africa. . . Is understood to have a wife, two daughters and a son.

title: Tree and Plant Hail Teacher For Cultivating Young Minds
description: TEANECK, May 24All 456 children at the Longfellow School were given a halfhour off from class this morning to sit on the front lawn under the maple trees for a party in honor of Grace Hoehn, who is retiring next month after 41 years, a thirdgrade teacher.

title: Technology
description: A new type of television signal, designed to minimize the socalled ghosts or multiple images, that afflict millions of American television screens, is about to be tested commercially.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Unit to Aid Arts Teaching
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  David Rockefeller Jr. today announced the formation of a private nonprofit organization to be called Arts, Education and Americans Inc. to promote the teaching of the arts in schools.

title: TWO SAID TO LEAD IN RACE TO HEAD NEW YORK G.O.P.
description: Two upstate New York Assemblymen, Gary A. Lee of Ithaca and James L. Emery of Genesco, are considered the frontrunners for the Republican state chairmanship to succeed Richard M. Rosenbaum, county party leaders said Yesterday.

title: Carter to Make Dive In Nuclear Submarine
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)Jimmy Carter, the retired submarine officer, will return to the sea Friday, boarding the nuclear submarine Los, Angeles at Cape Canaveral, Fla., for a dive in the Atlantic Ocean. The President will fly to Florida from Georgia, where he is planning to spend the Memorial Day weekend at St. Simons Island.

title: Orioles
description: Good news about Baltimore's Jim Palmer is bad news for American League batters. The visiting Milwaukee Brewers suffered last night because Palmer's arm is all right again. The threetime Cy Young Award winner fired a sevenhitter at them to win 21 pitching duel from Jerry Augustine. It was Palmer's first triumph since May 8.

title: Arafat Wants Dialogue With U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 24Yasir Arafat has announced that the Palestine Liberation Organization would like to start a dialogue with the United States Government.

title: MILITARY AID FUNDS APPROVED Ft HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The House today voted to authorize $3.2 billion in foreign military assistance in the year beginning Oct. 1. Included would be $100 million for blackruled countries of south??? Africa.

title: Nonlawyers Given Disciplinary Role By Bar Association
description: in a move to bolster the credibility of the legal profession, nonlawyers will take part in the disciplining of errant lawyers in Manhattan and the Bronx starting next fall.

title: Writers and Newspapers In Arizona Crime Series Are Sued for $17 Million
description: TUCSON, Ariz., May 24 (AP)Investigative Reporters and Editors Inc., several newspapers and 40 reporters and editors were accused today in a $17 million lawsuit of defaming Peter Licavoli Jr. in series of articles on organized crime Arizona.

title: Aluminum Labor Accord Advances Goal of Lifetime Income Security
description: The United Steelworkers of America took another long step yesterday toward establishing a pattern of lifetime income security for industrial workers. In contracts negotiated in Miami Beach with the country's three largest aluminum producers, the union won pay guarantees that went well beyond those provided in the pioneering pact it reached last month with the Big 10 of the basic steel industry.

title: Letters
description: Mail Preference Service

title: FORD SCORES CARTER ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) President Carter's suggestion that general tax revenues might be needed for the Social Security System is one of the most dangerous and shortsighted policies I can imagine, former President Gerald R. Ford said today.

title: SAUDI PRINCE PRAISES CARTER FOR BACKING PALESTINE HOMELAND
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia praised President Carter today for supporting the idea of a Palestinian homeland and said he was optimistic that the United States would use its tremendous moral and material power to bring about a Middle East settlement that includes a solution of the Palestinian question.

title: 28 Held in Italy As Kidnappers Become Bolder
description: ROME, May 24After Roberto Giansanti left his father's jewelry store last week, he drove to his apartment house nearby and into the underground garage. Three men and a woman seized him, dragged him into another car and drove off.

title: Business Outlays Set To Combat Pollution
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (UPI)The nation's business community plans to spend $7.5 billion this year an new plant and equipment to combat air, water and solid waste pollution, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Foreign Investments in Japan Fall
description: TOKYO, May 24 (UPI)Foreign investments in Japanese securities and bonds showed a net loss of $37 million in April the Finance Ministry announced today. The ministry said the acquisition of Japanese securities by foreign investors totaled $202.8 milloin against sales of $246.9 million. The purchases of bonds by foreign investors totaled $133.4 million compared with sales of $126.3 million.

title: Barbecue Grills for a Range of Tastes
description: The choice of a barbecue grill is dictated by personal taste, financial resources and the number to be catered for. If, as do most city dwellers, you decide to stick with charcoal, the range is wide, all the way from a $6.99 hibachi at Korvettes up to $1,295 for a stainless steel grill at Hammacher Schlemmer that looks big enough to cook for an army and actually serves 70 or 80.

title: Springs Mills Wins Tris Court Ruling.
description: A Federal judge yesterday held that the Consumer Pi'ociuct Safety Commission had violated its own rulemaking procedures in banning Tris the flameretardant chemical.

title: The Long Trek Where?
description: VIENNA  Behind the japanned screen of courtesy which masked the colloquy on southern Africa's future between Vice President Mondale and Prime Minister Vorster, there raged potentially explosive disagreement. Just before they flew homeward at the start of this week, South Africans began to talk bluntly, even menacingly, about the split's implications.

title: Advertising
description: John Destler, who spent 11 of his 45 years as an international advertising executive, has been named president and chief operating officer of Wunderman, Ricotta & Kline, the country's largest direct marketing specialty agency. Lester Wunderman, 56, who has been president of the agency since its founding in 1958, has become its first chairman and remains chief executive officer.

title: Trudeau's Liberals Gain Commons Seat In ByElection Tests
description: MONTREAL, May 24Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeat and his Liberal Party gained a seat in the House of Commons today after winning five out of six byelections.

title: Byrne Seeks to Halt CasinoInspired Ouster of Poor
description: TRENTON, May 24Governor Byrne today directed state and Atlantic City officials to find ways to stop the forced exodus of the poor and elderly residents of Atlantic City to make room for gambling casino hotels or facilities to serve the patrons of such hotels.

title: Child'sWorld
description: Seeing the Unseen

title: About Real Estate
description: What New York City needs, according to Fred Manocherian, is a good country club. Several, in fact.

title: Richard P. Diehl Is Dead at 55; Ad Executive of CarrafielloDiehl
description: Richard P. Diehl, executive vice president of CarrafielloDiehl & Associates inc., an advertising agency in IrvingtononHudson, N. Y., died Monday of a heart attack in his home in Englewood Cliffs, N. J. He was 55 years old.

title: Senator Long, as Head of Finance Panel, Holds Key to Carter's Legislative Program
description: WASHINGTON, May 24'There was this little boy, and his father wanted to see how smart he was, so, he asked him how much was two and two, And the boy answered, Daddy, that depends on whether we're buying or selling.

title: ]SOUTH AFRICAN HINTS AT CHANGE IN SYSTEM
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 24A leader of the reform wing in the South African Cabinet suggested today, for the first time in public, that the 10 million blacks living outside their tribal homelands could gain, representation in a new national political system that would supersede the existing Parliament, in which all political power is held by whites.

title: Meadowlands Pace To Happy Attraction
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 24 Happy Attraction, a 231 chance driven by Buddy Gilmour, held on tonight to score a head victory in the $48,000 final of the First Edition pacing series at the Meadowlands.

title: People in Sports
description: Brad Park, the former Ranger defenseman who was among the Boston Bruins recently swept by the Montreal Canadiens in the fourgame Stanley Cup finals, said yesterday that his team merely had run out of games in the National Hockey League series.

title: How the Cookbooks May Be Obtained
description: The Asphodel Cook Box can be ordered from the Pelican Publishing Company, 630 Burdette Street, Gretna, La. 70053, for $12.50 plus 60 cents postage. The file box is available in antique red, blue, green or gold.

title: Ohio Sanctions United Technologies Bid for Babcock
description: The Ohio Commerce Department said yesterday that the United Technologies Corporation could proceed with its proposed tender offer for shares of Babcock & Wilcox Inc. The decision now goes to the Ohio's securities commissioner.

title: Nuclear Expert Says Poor Controls On Materials Hold Potential Danger
description: WASHINGTON, May 24A Government security expert has cautioned President Carter that ineffective controls over nuclear materials pose a serious potential hazard to the public health and national security.

title: Summer and Food: Feasting al Fresco
description: FOOD enthusiasts whose passion is dining out of doors care little for fine definitions of seasons. They do not reckon their pleasure from the vernal equinox or the swallows of Capistrano. Fie on calendars and bird watchers: Warm weather stimulates al fresco appetites and, with the arrival of Memorial Day next Monday, epicurean minds are irresistibly drawn to thoughts of charcoalgrilled foods and other delights of feasting in sunlight and shade.

title: Dance: Gifted Crop
description: IT WAS the Russian impresario Serge Diaghilev who once, with ironic exaggeration, claimed that he was interested only in dancers when they were either very young or very old. Well, one can see the point, although there is perhaps a happy middle ground. Yet it is curious that at an age when a violinist would still be as regarded 23 young and promising, a dancer is preparing to hang up his or her shoes, and the growing artistry that has gone into them. Meanwhile we can enjoy the very young dancerwhere artistry has scarcely developed, and each step, though carefully garnered through long training, is still all but new.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: WE SHALL TURN now to matters propriety and deportment, and to questions that whistle through conversations whenever etiquette is discussed. The questions may not seem burning, but over the years they have agitated people sufficiently so that they cannot simply be dismissed. The first question is, how long should you serve your guests drinks before you sit them down to dinner; the second question is, how is a guest to know when it is time for him leave a dinner party and go home?

title: Students and Faculty Show Unrest At Rhode Island School of Design
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 24The detached style of its new president and questions concerning control of its talented and creative faculty have produced a flareup of student and faculty unrest at the Rhode Island School of Design in the closing days of the academic year.

title: LOU GORDON, COMMENTATOR ON TELEVISION IN DETROIT
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., May 24Lou Gordon, a television commentator, died in his sleep today of apparent heart failure. He was 60 years old.

title: Labor Leaders Upset Over Ruling Against Strikers' Jobless Benefits
description: Union leaders were angry and upset by the decision yesterday by a Federal judge that it was unconstitutional to pay strikers unemployment benefits after seven weeks off the job.

title: Power of Its Pocket Calculators Increased by Texas Instruments
description: In a move designed to sharply expand the computing power of programmable pocket calculators, Texas Instruments Inc. yesterday demonstrated calculators with clipin libraries of up to 5,000 program steps, or distinct instructions.

title: Georgian Is Held for Questioning In Slaying of Heiress in Indiana
description: ATLANTA Wednesday, May 25 (AP)A 53yearold Georgia woman sought for questioning in the robbery and slaying of Marjorie Jackson, an Indianapolis heiress, was arrested Tuesday night at a camping park 25 miles northwest of here, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Carter's Legislative Compromise
description: WASHINGTONWhen Jimmy Carter was elected President, the two new Democratic leaders in the CongressSenator Robert Byrd of West Virginia and Speaker Tip O'Neill of Massachusettshad one major question: Would Carter really negotiate with them in private on a legislative program, or try to work around them by appealing over their heads to the people.

title: Rock Concerts in Central Park Will Be Continued This Summer
description: The annual rock concerts in Central Park, which had been threatened by the withdrawal of the Schaefer Beer Company from their sponsorship, will be continued this summer with underwriting from the Dr Pepper Company, Mayor Beame announced yesterday.

title: CUOMO GETS $90,000 INMAYORAL CAMPAIGN
description: Mario M. Cuomo reported yesterday that he had raised $90,000 for his mayoral campaignbelow the sixfigure sum with which he had hoped to create an impression of momentum but, according to his manager, a decent beginning for the young campaign.

title: Last Street Play Is Gang's Nostalgia
description: OFF STAGE, voices sing in hearty, footstomping unison, We're the Mighty Gents!, a martial air of memory to the roughest, meanest gang in Newark. On stage, Frankie, the leader of the Gents, now descended into mediocrity, takes a drink and confides in us. He talks about his failed dreams, thwarted pride and rising sense of desperation. The play is Richard Wesley's The Last Street Play (at the Manhattan Theater Club), an eloquent threnody to lost, spent youth.

title: Film: Journey to the Altar
description: NOTHING IN THE WAY of heightened perception, lateflowering appreciation or guiltladen hindsight has come along in the last 37 years to give rise to revisionist theories about Edgar G. Ulmer's Americaner Shadchen (American Matchmaker), the Yiddish film that opened yesterday for a run through Sunday at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Revision of Supply Of Soybeans Lifts Prices of Futures
description: Following a Government revision downward of soybean stocks in this country, prices of the beans, soybean meal and oil futures climbed their daily limits yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans futures rose 30 cents a bushel as meal increased $10 a ton and oil gained 1 cent a pound.

title: Velasquez Also Set to Return Sooner Than Estimated
description: With the odds boards blank again, much of the speculation between races yesterday at betless Belmont Park involved celebrity jockeys and horses who weren't competing.

title: People and Business
description: The nation's fourth largest automobile company, the American Motors Corporation, yesterday designated Gerald C. Meyers, 48, as president and chief operating officer. He had been executive vice president since 1975 and succeeds William V. Luneburg, who reached the compulsory retirement age of 65 on Sunday.

title: A Consolidation of Some Services In 2 New York Hospitals Weighed
description: The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation and New York Medical CollegeFlower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals have initiated negotiations aimed at achieving what would be the city's first consolidation of pediatric and obstetric services offered by a private, voluntary hospital and a municipal institution.

title: U. S: GETTING READY FOR BELGRADE TALK
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 President Carter will name a delegation next week to participate in the Belgrade conference of EastWest cooperation and will instruct it to hit hard on human rights issues, officials said today.

title: Tests Fail to Show Drug In One of Alleged Victims Of 2 Ann Arbor Nurses
description: DETROIT, May 24Tests by a prominent toxicology laboratory showed that there was no Pavulon in the liver bile or blood of a man allegedly murdered with the muscleparalyzing drug while a patient at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Ann Arbor.

title: State Bankers Ask Uniformity in Rates
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.. May 24Commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations should all pay the same interest rates on interestbearing checking accounts if Congress authorizes them, the New York State Bankers Association rornmmended here today.

title: DUTCH WON'T BARGAIN TILL PUPILS ARE FREE
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 24The terrorists holding move than 160 hostages made their demands known today, but the Dutch Government said it would not talk about them until the children among the hostaees were set free.

title: Private Lives
description: WE ENDED UP the evening arguing. This usually happens. It happens because she is fiercely intelligent and there are matters, not all of them trivai, on which we disagree. It also happens because she is fiercely beautiful  beauty like tightened bow, said Yeats, who then added: Was there another Troy for her to burn?'and arguing with her is a way of flirting, a form of courtly love. I cannot, really, bring her a rose in my teeth, or wag my tail, and so instead. I shake my head and quibble.

title: The Race for Governor
description: EAST ORANGE, May 23Representative James J. Florio has decided it is even more dangerous politically to tax people's credibility than their pocketbooks and is basing his campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination on town meetings dsigned to give his views on state issues a complete airing.

title: Little Leaguer Killed
description: LEMONT, 111., May 24 (AP)A Little League baseball player collapsed and died last night after having been struck in the chest by a pitched ball. He was Tom Steck Jr., 8 years old.

title: P.E.N. to Elect Howard President Today
description: The American branch of P.E.N., the International Association of Poets, Playwrights, Editors, Essayists and Novelists, will elect new officers at its annual meeting today in New York.

title: Sub Hunts for Reservoir Victims
description: LEBANON, N.J., May 24While subdued relatives looked on, a small orangeandwhite research submarine slipped into the chill waters of the Round Valley Reservoir today to begin a search for at least six victims of separate drowning incidents.

title: Letters
description: Middle East: After the Israeli Elections

title: Market Place
description: Uncertainty has a depressing effect on securities prices, and in view of the many uncertainties concerning Mesabi Trust it is perhaps not surprising that certificates of this mining property offer a premium dividend return at current New York Stock Exchange prices.

title: M. A. C. AND CITY GAIN HIGHER BONDS RATING
description: In still another sign of improvement in the perception of New York City's finances, Moody's Investor's Service yesterday upgraded its credit rating for both city bonds and Municipal AssiStance Corporation bondsits first such move since it lowered the ratings during the height of the fiscal crisis in 1975 and last year.

title: SAUDI PRINCE PRAISES CARTER FOR BACKING PALESTINE HOMELAND
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia praised President Carter today for supporting the idea of a Palestinian homeland and said he was optimistic that the United States would use its tremendous moral and material power to bring about a Middle East settlement that includes a solution of the Palestinian ouestion.

title: Owners of the Mayaguez Settle With 6 ExCrewmen Seized in 75
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 24 (AP)A $258,000 settlement has been reached in behalf of six former crew members of the merchant ship Mayaguez, which was seized by Cambodia in 1975.

title: Deaths
description: ABRONSLouis W. The Board of DI ecturs and Stall of Henry Sti eel Settlement extend their ueepest sum Ipartly to Heroeit L. Abrons, CNIIMIOr at the Board and Richard S. Abrons, treasurer and all other members o, the family et Louis W. Abrons, Mr. Abrons was a devsled benefactor of the Settlement and principal done of the Louis Abrons Arts For Living UMW'. His contributions shall be reflected in the future work of the SMIPACM, May his famity derive, from JOHN MORNING, President Henry Street Settlement BERTRAM M. BECK, Executive Director

title: Television
description: 8:00 P.M. Good Times (R) (2)

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: SOME OF THE BEST and most quickly made dishes of the Italian kitchen particularly those kitchens that specialize in cooking in the style of Naples are those with pizzaiola..These sauces have a tomato base, which has been reduced considerably, and olive oil and a touch of garlic. Plus one indispensable ingredient, oregano. Beef quickly cookedgrilled panfriedadapts itself well to a pizzaiola sauce, but I prefer pork chops. The recipe here includes a variation on the basic saucethe use of mushrooms and green peppers. On the day the recipe was made, both ingredients happened to be lying in the refrigerator with no other immediate destination.

title: Of Restaurants, Dentists and Lorgnettes
description: Sometime within the next month, Le Premier is scheduled to open and although you'll be able to dine there, with enough cash, you'll be just an ordinary customer unless you plunk down $500 in advance. Then you become a preferred patron.

title: Sugar: Villain In Disguise?
description: SUGAR PROPONENTS call it quick energy, opponents say it's empty calories. But to the average American, who consumes a third of pound of it each day, sugar is mostly an irresistibly goad taste. Human societies have long equated sweetness with goodnesssweet mystery of life, sweet smell of success, sweetheartand that enhances the attraction.

title: All About: Passports
description: WITH VISIONS of distant paradises dancing in their heads and chiefly with woeful looking photographs clutched in their hands, nearly 3 million Americans will turn to the State Department this year to apply for vassnorts.

title: The Inconstant Mr. Carter
description: The honeymoon is fading. Twothirds of the public (and threefourths of Democrats) continue to approve of President Carter's performance. But Senator McGovern assails the new Democratic Administration for practicing Republican economics. Governor Carey, Senator Kennedy and others publicly question the sincerity of the President's commitment to promised social reforms. Commentators uneasily appraise his goal of a balanced Federal budget (and Jody Powell's characterizing him as tight as a tick) and ask whether the Carter vision is the inspiring one of a leaderor the pinched one of a mere manager.

title: Best Buy
description: WITH THE first big holiday weekend of the warm weather season at hand, New Yorkers don't have to head for the amusement parks if they want a rollercoaster ride.

title: Books of TheTimes
description: WHY DOES the legend of the child prodigy hold such hypnotic fascination for the human race? Surely it must be that we need desperately to believe in miracles, to believe that the 2 times 2 of our lives need not necessarily add up to 4, to believe that we are not inevitably the product of all our yesterdays. To read his own account, by now a legend entwined in myth, of Yehudi Menuhin's New York debut with orchestra at the age of 11 is to experience a twinge of recognition: Here stood the seraphic child in the temple of music discoursing on the mysteries of the Beethoven Violin Concerto while the scribes and pharisees sat confounded.

title: WILLIAM DAVIS
description: William Davis, supervisor of the department of general services at The New York Times since 1953. died Monday in the Nassau County Medical Center, East Meadow, L. I., after being taken ill in his home, 231 Grand Street, Westbury, L. J. His age was 64. Mr. Davis, who joined The Times in 1945, is survived by his wife, the former Lorraine Patterson, and a daughter, Joyce Brown.

title: Arabs Setting Up Own Monetary Fund
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, May 22The Arabs have added yet another financial institution their growing arraythe latest venture designed to emulate the wellknown International Monetary Fund.

title: U.S. Sees Stronger Brezhnev Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 24American officials said today that the ouster of Nikolai V. Podgorny was probably a prelude to further strengthening of, Leonid Brezhnev's role.

title: Reuss Alleges Fed Minutes Disclose Questionable Acts
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Henry S. Reuss, chairman of the House Banking Committee, charged today that confidential minutes of the Federal Reserve's 12 district banks disclose questionable activities by the Reserve System and a pattern of disdain for public accountability.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Sentence in $2 Robbery

title: POLICE IN NEW YORK TO GET MORE DECOYS
description: The New York City Police Department is planning to reinforce substantially its anticrime squad, whose members act as decoy victims or are assigned to highcrime areas in civilian clothes.

title: U.S. JUDGE OVERTURNS JOBLESS PAYMENTS IN NEW YORK STRIKES
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the payment of unemployment benefits to strikersa practice in New York State for 40 yearswas unconstitutional, bemuse it put the state on the side of strikers and conflicted with Federal laws.

title: World News Briefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 24 (AP) Syria agreed today to a sixmonth extension cf the mandate of she United Nations buffer force between Israeli and Syrian trocps, clearing the way for Security Council action to keep the force on the Golan Heights through November.

title: Placid Dutch Town Is Swept by Fear and Prejudice
description: BOVENSMILDE, the Netherlands, May 24The.Soulh Moluccans who kidnapped 105 Dutch school children and five of their teachers here yesterday morning shattered the middleclass calin Of this suburban settlement of ordered brick houses along a canal. Old wounds n; Dutch societyracial prejudice, rear and the strains of colonialismwere opened and some townspeople believe they will take years to heal again,

title: Carter Asks Approval of U.N. Pact
description: WASHINGTON, May 24President Carter asked the Senate today to ratify the United Nation's 1948 genocide convention on grounds that it would be a significent enhancement to the nation's human rights commitments. Ratificption has been held up by the Senate, partly by opponents who say it could be used by other nations to interfere in minority rights problems in the United States.

title: THE EXPERT SHOPPER
description: No COOK, no matter how skillId or wily, can overcome tho handicap of poor ingredients. And just as it behooves any craftsman to know his materials, it is up to the cook to know how to judge the quality of the foods he buys. In the midst of all the purple prose written about the glories of gastronomy, few hard facts about basic ingredients are explained. The place to go for such knowledge is to the experts, people in the business of buying and selling those foods, and to whom knowing intrinsic quality is vital.

title: The New York Times/Neal Boertel
description: NTH BIRTHDAY OF BROOKLYN BRIDGE MARKED: A unicyclist taking part in parade from City Hall across the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday as the span became 94 years old. After the parade, Mayor Beanie received a plaque from Paul Roebling, the greatgreatgrandson of the bridge's designer.

title: Cosmos Will Sign Beckenbauer For 4 Years, $2.8 Million Today
description: Franz Beckenbauer, Europe's premier soccer player in 1976, will sign a fouryear contract for a reported $2.8 million with the Cosmos today. The signing will take place at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan and not in Bermuda, where Pele signed part of his sixyear, $4.7 million contract in 1975 for tax purposes.

title: Puterbaugh Back in Indy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 (AP)Bill Puterbaugh was reinstated today driver of car No. 16 for Sunday's Indianapolis 500, after Salt Walther had stepped aside.

title: 28 Held in Italy As Kidnappers Become Bolder
description: ROME, May 24After Roberto Gian santi left his father's jewelry store last week he drove to his apartment house nearby and into the underground garage. Three men and a woman seized him, dragged him into another car and drove off.

title: Alfred Schild
description: Alfred Schild, a Univerisity of Texas physicist who pioneered many advances in the interpretation, verification and application of Einsten's theories of relativity, died yesterday in Downers Grove, Ill. He was 55 years old.

title: Arbitrators and Whooping Cranes
description: Some of the elder statesmen around here may recognize the name, Peter Seitz. Back in the feudal age of 1975 when baseball players were owned outright by their employDrs, Peter Seitz decided that the contracts of two pitchers named Andy Messersmith and have McNally meant what they said. For this heresy, he was instantly dismissed impartial chairman of baseball's Grievance Arbitration Panel. Incidentally, John Gaherin, who had the dirty job of telling the arbitrator to get lost, is approaching retirement and baseball has hired not one but three or four headhunting firms to find a successor to handle labor relations. One headhunter, even one company of headhunters won't do because they have to find somebody smart enough to hold his own with Marvin Milier at the bargaining table. At any rate, not long ago The Chronicle of the National Academy of Arbitrators pinned Peter Seitz to the wall and wrenched the following interview from him:

title: CALLAGHAN ATTACKS NEWSPAPER'S CHARGE OF LEYLAND BRIBERY SMEAR, PRIME MINISTER SAYS Car Company Analyst Who Forged Key Letter in Case and His Wife Are Held Without Bail
description: LONDON, May 24Prime Minister James Callaghan bitterly attacked The Daily Mail of London in the House of Commons today, saying the newspaper's allegations thit stateowned British Leyland was entangled in a web of bribery amounted to a contemptible display of political spite.

title: Post Offices For Passports
description: Following is a list of post offices in the Metropolitan area at which you can apply for a passport:

title: HAMPTON HAWES
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (UPI)Hamp ton Hawes, wellknown jazz pianist, diec Sunday of a massive cerebral hemorrhage at the Veterans Hospital. He was 48 years old.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 25, 1977

title: Senate in Hartford Apparently Blocks Bottle Bill for 1977
description: HARTFORD. May 24The muchdebated and muchlobbied bill that would ban fliptop cans and require that deposits be paid on beer and softdrink bottles in Connecticut appeared today to have been blocked for another year.

title: Coffee Airlift From Uganda to a Thirsty Market Is Flying a Route to Instant Riches
description: ENTEBBE, Uganda, May 22Capt. Rocky Boroughf lifted off at Entebbe Airport, pulling the stick effortlessly with a hefty tattooed forearm. Gino Bagley, the copilot, leaned over and radioed the Entebbe flight controller. He read out the flight plan and then added the obligatory: Will not fly over city of Kampala. Will not fly over statehouse.

title: INCH BY INCH, a crew of engineers started raising the west reproach span of the Union Avenue Bridge on the Passaic River at Route 21 yesterday. The span
DISCOVERIES
description: Enid Nemy

title: DEFUNCT BANK'S RECORDS SUBPOENAED BY U.S. JURY
description: NORWICH, Conn., May 25 (AP)All books and records of the now defunct Monroe Bank nad Trust Co. have been subpoenaed by a Federal grand jury, according to a published report.

title: Okker Player of Week
description: LOS ANGELES, May 24 (AP)Tom Okker of the Golden Gators was named World Team Tennis player of the week today. He was undefeated in singles and led his team back into Western Division contention.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: State Jobless Rate Is Up, But Labor Force Rises

title: A. H. Raskin
description: The handle at all the parimutuel windows and offtrack betting parlors from Rockingham Park to Santa Anita is small change alongside the money that switches hands whenever the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics flashes a new monthly number on unemployment or inflation. Julius Shiskin, whose post as Commissioner of Labor Statistics makes him chief monitor of these magic numbers, estimates that $25 billion to $30 billion a i year rides on their fluctuations. This includes a billiondollar increase in private payrolls covered by costofliving escalator clauses every time the Consumer Price Index goes up by 1 percent

title: Dolphins
description: MIAMI, May 24 (AP)Two players for the Miami Dolphins, Don Reese and Randy Crowder, entered innocent pleas today to charges of selling more than a pound of cocaine to Miami undercover police agents last month. Circuit Court Judge Joseph Durant Jr set a tentative June 27 trial date for the two National Football League players.

title: Life in a Drought: Disruption Reigns
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: PODGORNY IS OUSTED BY SOVIET POLITBURO IN A SURPRISE MOVE
description: MOSCOW, May 24President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union was dropped from the Communist Party's ruling Politburo today in a Kremlin move that is expected to spell the end of his political career.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Tuesday, May 24, 1977

title: $2 Million Normally. Wagered at Races Not Bet Off track
description: Racing continued as unusual yesterday at Belmont Park with no bettifig at the strikeaffected track and $2 million missing.

title: Plantation Cooking: Sweet Excesses
description: BATON ROUGE, LA.

title: Bobby Hull Paces Jets
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba, May 24 (AP) Bobby Hull scored three goals tonight, leading the Winnipeg Jets to 123 romp over the Quebec Nordiques that tied the final of the World Hockey Association playoffs at three games apiece.

title: About Education
description: New York City's public school system, as seen through the eyes of a group of British educators, is an institution desperately constrained by the provisions of the contract between the city and the teachers union.

title: Nixon Says Ouster Of Agnew Became An Early Certainty
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)Richard M. Nixon says that, when he learned in 1973 about the investigations involving Spiro T. Agnew, there wasn't any question that he was, frankly, going to get it.

title: 4Run 7th Wins, 65
description: The Yankees, with a dramatic fourrun, seventhinning rally, overcame the Boston Red Sox, the enemy from without tonight after Manager Billy Martin, with a brief pregame meeting, tried to subdue Reggie Jackson, a potential enemy from within.

title: Spoleto Arts Feitival Opens. Today in Charleston, Reflecting a Revival of the City's Cultural Legacy
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., May 24There was a time, back in the 1700's and early 1800's, when Charleston was one of the three or four most important cities in the United States, a port of immense wealth and artistic energy.

title: Careers
description: The trend toward more corporate help in retirement planning for employees received a determined nudge on Monday from the 18monthold National Center for Career Life Planning, an offshoot of the American Management Associations.

title: Some of Yale's captains
description: American college women putt, run, swing, lob,, shoot, slam, dive, dribble, win and lose for their alma maters with more clout and in greater numbers than ever before.

title: Meadowlands
description: Houses listed in order of post pos???

title: SALES OF U.S. CARS OFF 52% IN MIDMAY
description: DETROIT, May 24American newcar sales declined 5.2 percent in the May 1120 period from the same period a year ago, the industry said today. Auto analysts reported some indecision on the part of buyers and attributed it to energy worries.

title: Carter Rebuffed on Aircraft Carriers by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Carter Administration, seeking to build smaller aircraft carriers and end the construction of expensive, Nimitzclass, nuclearpowered ships, was rebuffed today by the House Armed Services Committee.

title: Placid Dutch Town Is Sweet by Fear and Prejudice
description: BOVENSMILDE, the Netherlands. May 24The South Moluccans who kidnapped 105 Dutch school children and five of their teachers here yesterday morning shattered the middleclass calm of this suburban settlement of ordered brick houses along a canal. Old wounds o Dutch societyracial prejudice, fear and the strains of colonialismwere opened and some townspeople believe they will take years to heal again.

title: PARKS AGENCY HOLDS LOTTERIES FOR JOBS
description: Coleen Servis kneiv the odds were against her: Only 1,100 jobs were available and 12,000 people were applying for them.

title: Maguire Scores F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP)Representative Andrew Maguire, Democrat of Bergen County, told the seven Federal Communications Commissioners that their treatment of New ersey was shocking, The F.C.C. chairman, Richard E. Wiley; rejected the charge. Mr. Maguire accused the comfnissioners of a Milquetoast approach in refusing to assign New Jersey at least one VHF television channel and described as a tepid solution the commission's directive to New York and Philadelphia television stations to com mit themselves to covering events of interest to New Jersey viewers.

title: TV: Cause Celebre
description: THE PEOPLE vs. Inez Garcia, on Channel 13 at 10 this evening, is a theatrical production stitched together by Rena Down from the records of a real trial. On March 19, 1974, Inez Garcia killed Miguel Jimenez in Soledad, Calif. By her own admission she failed to kill Luis Castillo, who became a principal prosecution witness. Mrs. Garcia was tried that September in Monterey, Calif., and the trial attracted widespread publicity as a significant statement on both rape and sexist/racist justice.

title: B.B.King: From Beale
description: NEW HAVEN O NE OF THE 14 PERSONS awarded honorary degrees at Yale University's 276th commencement last week left school after the 10th grade to pick cot:ton, plow with mules, and drive tractor on a plantation in the Missigsippi Delta. As an adolescent he took up the guitar and began playing blues, one of the few occupations open to black people in the Delta that promised deliverance from a lifetime of manual labor. He moved to Memphis when he was 18, and three years later It job with WDIA, the first blackoperated radio station in the country

title: Seeing the Bodies
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  Seven years ago, on May 14, 1970, a crowd of Mississippi police officers fired over 200 rounds of buckshot, regular bullets, and 3006 armorpiercing ammunition into a girl's dormitory at Jackson State College in Mississippi, wounding a dozen students and killing two. Last year, begining with the June 16 Soweto demonstration, the South African Government killed over 500 schoolchildren and wounded hundreds more.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 500 Pounds of Marijuana Seized
description: Two men were arrested and 500 to 700 pounds of marijuana were seized Monday evening in a raid on a Staten Island apartment believed to be a way station for a smuggling ring, the police said. The marlJuana, with a street value of $30,000, was Iseized as it was about to be moved to another location for distribution in the New York City area, the police said. Thomas Clancy, 28 years old, and John Bersaney, 24, both of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, were charged with possession of drugs and of an automatic pistol allegedly found in the apartment in the Oakwood section.

title: The Standings
description: Wednesday, May 25, 1977

title: U. S. DEFENSE PLEDGE TO SEOUL REASSERTED
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 24Under Secretary of State Philip C. Habib and Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, arrived here today tor consultations with President Park Chung Hee on the planned withdrawal of American ground troops from Korea over the next five years.

title: PBS Sets Schedule
description: The Public Broadcasting Service yesterday revealed to its affiliates the blueprint for its fall program schedule. It will be highlighted by a nightly cultural interview show headed by Dick Cavett, a Monday night movie and a new adult dramatic series, The Best of Families, produced by the Children's Television Workshop.

title: The Amazing Expectationless Man
description: CARMEL, Calif.There once was a man named Henry Blivit who was so determined to abide by the President's plea for all citizens to lower their expectations that he decided to rid himself of all his possessions, his theory being that if you didn't own anything you'd be less apt to need or expect anything.

title: Ga. Tech Quits Tourney
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., May 24 (UPI)Georgia Tech has dropped out of the NorthSouth college basketball doubleheaders, reportedly over a dispute over the school's share of receipts from the event. Athletic officials at North Carolina and North Carolina State, hosts for the tournament, said today a replacement had not been found for the Yellow Jackets. Furman is the fourth participant.

title: Patent Office Asks Inquiry Into Paying Of Clerical Workers
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Patent Office has called in the Federal Bureau of Investigation to inquire into reports that some of its clerical workers have been taking payments from outsiders to expedite the delivery of documents.

title: Sudanese President Asks Young for Military Aid As a Friend of the U.S.
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, May 24 (AP)President Gaafar alNimeiry, who expelled Soviet military advisers and some embassy personnel last week, told Andrew Young, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, today that his nation needed American military equipment.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MANPOWER The public is invited to hear two major American novelists, John Cheever and E. L. Doctorow, reading from their works tonight at 7:30 on the fourth floor at the Queens College Union Building at the Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard in Flushing. The appearances of Mr. Cheever, highly praised for his new Falconer, and Mr. Doctorow, author of the bestselling Ragtime, are for benefit event for WBAIFM, one of the very few local stations regularly broadcasting readings of poetry, fiction and drama, as well as interviews with artists and authors. Because of debts, the nonprofit, listenersponsored outlet is threatened with closing down.

title: GOLD DROPS BELOW $146 ON EUROPEAN MARKETS
description: LONDON, May 24 (AP)Gold prices fell below $146 an ounce on European bullion markets today for the first time in more than a month, and the dollar had a narrowly mixed day on currency exchanges

title: Japanse Seek U.S. Accord
description: TOKYO, May 24 (UPI)Following tne recent agreement to limit Japan's export of color television sets to the United States, the Japanese steel industry will shortly urge the Government to start negotiations with the United States for similar accord, steelmakers said today.

title: U.S.JUDGE OVERTURNS JOBLESS PAYMENTS IN NEW YORK STRIKES
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the payment of unemployment benefits to strikersa practice in New York State for 40 yearswas unconstitutional, because it put the state on the side of strikers and conflicted with Federal laws.

title: Israeli Promises Caution on Gaza And West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, May 24Aides to Menahem Begin, the hospitalized Likud leader, circulated a statement on his behalf today pledging that as Prime Minister he would not unilaterally move to make the Wet Bank and the Gaza Strip a formal part of Israel.

title: U.S. Prison Inmates Tutor Visitors
description: Every week 4yearold Gena Candy plays with brightly colored toys, watches Sesame Street and sometimes has a spelling lessonat the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City. She is one of 50 children who do just that while their parents visit inmates in the shortterm Federal correctional facility on Park Row. It is all part of a new prison daycare program sponsored by the Federal Bureau of Prisons and the Children's Television Workshop.

title: M. A. C. AND CITY GAIN HIGHER BONDS RATING
description: In still another sign of improvement in the perception of New York City's finances, Moody's Investor's Service yesterday upgraded its credit rating for both city bonds and Municipal Assistance Corporation bondsits first such move since it lowered the ratings during the height of the fiscal crisis in 1975 and last year.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, MAY 25, 1977

title: Chess:
description: The single most flagrant error in the quarterfinal candidates match in Rotterdam between the Hungarian grandmaster Lajos Portisch and the Danish grandmaster Bent Larsen came in the sixth game when Larsen, overlooking a simple pin, dropped a pawn.

title: Issue and. Debate
description: WASHINGTON, May 24  When President Carter asked Conress just two months ago to create a national system of Election Day voter registration the initial response was broadly favorable. Democrats were almost uniformly supportive, and national Republican leaders comments ranged from lukewarm to enthusiastic.

title: Topics
description: Test, Trade, Torque and Tribute

title: Solar Energy Tested as Way To Reduce Cost Of Irrigation In Southwest
description: GILA BEND, Ariz., May 23Under the searing sun of central Arizona, a strange crop occupies one section on the Gila River River Ranch, surrounded by fields of cotton and alfalfa.

title: 148 NEW JUDGESHIPS APPROVED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, May 24The Senate passed tonight a bill to create 148 new Federal judgeships, which would ease the burden on the judiciary and provide patronage for Senate Democrats and President Carter.

title: DUTCH WON'T BARGAIN TILL PUPILS ARE FREE
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 24The terrorists holding more than 160 hostages made their demands known today, but the Dutch Government said it would not talk about them until the children among the hostages were set free.

title: Bridge
description: The Swiss team final at the New York Hilton Hotel Monday night proved to be a triumph for anybody whose name happened to be Becker. With 18 teams fighting to survive in the Reisinger knockout team championship, the two qualifying positions went to groups headed, by Jim Becker and Michael Becker, both of New York.

title: Inquiry Weighs Effect of Japan On Steel Trade
description: WASHINGTON, May 24At the request of two key Congressmen, the International Trade Commission, an independent factfinding body reporting to the executive and legislative branches, has started an investigation into production and distribution of basic steel in the Western states.

title: KENNEDY BACKS CURB ON HOSPITALS
description: WASHINGTON, May 24Like a trial lawyer in defense of his client, Senator Edward M. Kennedy tried today to prove in a public forum the case for the Carter Administration's proposal to limit the rise in hospital costs.

title: Around the Nation
description: SUMATRA, Fla., May 24 (AP)A forest fire started by a lightning bolt raged out of control today at the southern edge: of the Apalachicola National Forest in the Florida Panhandle.

title: Dow, Vexed by Inflation, Mideast And Prime, Sags to 16Month Low
description: The Dow Jones industrial average sank yesterday to a 16month low amid inflation jitters, tension in the Middle East and the possibility of another uptick in the crime lending rate on Friday.

title: Beame Proposes New Business Tax Cuts as Lure
description: New business tax reductions that would permit New York City to attract companies to move here were proposed yesterday by Mayor Beame.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Grumman American Aviation Corporation of Savannah, Ga., a subsidiary of the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, Li., said yesterday it would not continue to develop a Gulfstream3 executive jet aircraft at this time because development costs would exceed the original estimates and because future environmental requirements could not now be determined.

title: Solar Energy Tested as Way To Reduce Cost Of Irrigation In Southwest
description: GILA BEND, Ariz., May 23Under the searing sun of central Arizona, a strange crop occupies one section on the Gila River River Ranch, surrounded by fields of cotton and alfalfa. . .

title: Carey Urges New Watchdog Of State Boxing
description: ALBANY, May 24Governor Carey asked the Legislature today to abolish the State Athletic Commission, transferring its functions to the Secretary of State and, in effect, eliminating the job of James A. Farley Jr., the beleaguered chairman of the commission.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Tuesday, May 24, 1977

title: Notes on People
description: THE WHITE HOUSE and Senate Majority Leader Robert C. Byrd are engaged in a game that might be called Chandelier, Chandelier, Who's Got the Chandelier?

title: U.S. Court Delays Until June 1 Any Concorde Flights to Kennedy
description: A stay barring the start of Concorde test flights to Kennedy International Airport was extended yesterday to June 1 by the United States Court of Appeals 1 for the Second Circuit.

title: Albany Senate Passes Court Bill But Its Enactment Is Still Distant
description: ALBANY, May 24The State Senate today gave second passage to the proposed courtreorganization amendment to the State Constitution. But it did so, as expected, in a manner different from the Assembly, giving both houses the appearance of favoring reorganization but leaving them far apart on a final approval.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: American Publishers Make Appeal to Soviet Leaders Over a Jailed Dissident
description: in an unusual effort to achieve the release from jail of a Soviet human rights activist, American book publishers have appealed directly to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader, and Roman A. Rudenko, Soviet prosecutor general, emphasizing their interest in the case under the Helsinki accords and their concern for future relations in the book field.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed in order of post pos??? Letter cesignates OTB listing

title: Advertising is the first common language of Europe..
description: A candid interview with Marcel BleusteinBlanchet, creator of French commercial radio, foundet and chairman of the $400 million. Publicis group, today, the leading network of European advertising agencies.

title: Music: Pentaphonic Winds
description: W HEN IT COMES to making up concert programs, woodwind quintets do not have the easiest time of it. The repertory, while extensive, is not heavy with popular masterworks of the kind that a string quartet can draw upon so freely. Moreover, because wind instruments in the past could be played more easily in some keys than in others, the typical windquintet program can fall into a monotonous contest between E flat and B flat.

title: Aluminum Labor Accord Advances Goal of Lifetime Income Security
description: The United Steelworkers of America took another long step yesterday toward establishing a pattern of lifetime income security for industrial workers. In contracts negotiated in Miami Beach with the country's three largest aluminum producers, the union won pay guarantees that went well beyond those provided in the pioneering pact it reached last month with the Big 10 of the basic steel indus try.

title: Wine Talk
description: WE HAD a merlot fad, we almost had a petite sirah fad and cabernet sauvignon is always a bit faddish, but there is one red wine grape that is constantly popular with the true California wine enthusiasts: the zinfandel.

title: Powell, Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 24Marvin Powell, the Jets No. 1 draft choice, is supposed to be a good listener. But he misunderstood today's question.

title: Gerulaitis Rises to Top From New York Courts
description: He was marked for stardom as a precocious youngster, when his father taught him the fundamentals of tennis. Then a few other coaches refined his game, and finally he came under the disciplined tutelage of Harry Hopman, the Old Fox, who saw things in him that others had not seen.

title: Israeli Promises Caution on Gaza And West Bank
description: JERUSALEM Iytay 24Aides to Mena; hem Begin, the hospitalized Likud leader; circulated a statement on his behalf today pledging that as Prime Minister he would not unilaterally move to make the West Bank and the Gaza Strip a formal part of Israel.

title: CAREY PUSHES FUNDS TO AID CONSTRUCTION
description: ALBANY, May 24Governor Carey today listed nearly a score of major construction projects across New York State that he said would be brought to fruition if the Legislature and the voters approved a $750 million economicdevelopment bond issue this year.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, May 24The New Jersey State Commissioner of Insurance, James J. Sheeran, joined a Federal official and three Insurance Commissioners from other states today in sharply criticizing the nation's automobile insurance practices and vowing to cooperate in ending what they said were widespread abuses.

title: Belmont Racing
description: RESULTS

title: Sub Hunts for Reservoir Victims
description: LEBANON, N.J., May 24While subdued relatives looked on, a small orangeandwhite research submarine slipped into the chill waters of the Round Valley Reservoir today to begin a search for at least six victims of separate drowning incidents.

title: For 50 Years, Crawford Fan
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: City, U.S.T.A. Reach Accord To Shift Open
description: The city has reached agreement with the United States Tennis Association for developing a major tennis facility at Flushing Meadow Park in Queens.

title: TV:Rape, Alcohol Explored
description: IT'S THE TIME of year when television, loosening the competitive ties that bind schedules, can become slightly silly. Tonight, for example, New Yorkers can ponder two rather odd half hours: The Rape Victims on WABC/Channel 7 at 9, and Under the Influence, a showandtell lecture on drunken driving, on WOR/ Channel 9 at 10. Last Tuesday, on NBC, the entire nation had access to Suzy Visits, the latest entry in the people/ celebrity/gossip sweepstakes.

title: Carter Is Reassured by Saudi Prince on Oil Embargo
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 President Carter said today that he had been assured by Crown Prince Fand of Saudi Arabia that there would be no oil embargo against the United States to force concessions from Israel.

title: Watergate Special Prosecution Force Will Disband Next Month
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)The Watergate special prosecution force announced today that it would cease operations next month after four years of dealing with the scandals that drove Richard M. Nixon from the White House and sent some of his top aides to jail.

title: Thomas B. Reston Sworn In
description: WASHINGTON, May 25Thomas B. Reston was sworn in today as Deputy AsSistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs. Mr. Reston, son of the New York Times, columnist, James B. Reston, had previously served on President Carter's transition planning group and on the CarterMondale Policy Planning Committee, during the campaign.

title: New York Parks Face a TouchandGo Summer...
description: In Central Park, the oncegreen lawn of the Sheep Meadow is wearing away, gradually becoming a dust bowl with overuse. At the Bethesda Fountain, drugs are sold routinely, and the Duck Pond each night becomes a receptacle for beer and soda cans.

title: Beckenbauer Gives Cosmos a New Range
description: With the signing of Franz Beckenhauer yesterday, the Cosmos possess the two players who have dominated the world of soccer the last 20 years.

title: The Charles River Gang Returns
description: WASHINGTONSenator Ted Kennedy, champing at the bit part he has been assigned during a Democratic Administration, has begun his campaign for a far more impressive role in the play of American power.

title: New Milford Nursing Home Plan Opposed by Residents Near Site
description: NEW MILFORD, May 25A plan to build a 240bed nursing home on 71/, acres of farm land here has touched off resentment and opposition by residents of the secluded homes surrounding the plot. expressed pleisure that the proposed facility would ease the county's shortage of nursing home beds for the indigent elderly, the homeowners say the facility would destroy the tranquility of their wooded neighborhood, lead to property devaluations, and bring more traffic onto the busy main street of their crowded little town on the east bank of the Hackensack.River just north of Route 4.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MAY 26, 1977

title: BEAME GETS SET BACK ON CONVENTION PLAN
description: Mayor Beame's plans for a new convention center were dealt a serious setback yesterday when the Board of Estimate announced that it was opposed to spending $6.5 million for design, as the Mayor had requested.

title: Film: Animals on the Rampage
description: DAY OF THE ANIMALS," which opened yesterday at Loews State II, the UA East Side and RKO 86th Street Twin I theaters, is "The Birds" recycled by an equal-opportunity employer with an eye more on shock than suspense.So when the participants in a trek of fools into the Western high country come under attack, they have more than talons and beaks to fear. Wolves, mountain lions, bears and packs of dogs are stalking and savaging them, as well as the birds; and in more civilized areas, rats run amok and poisonous snakes slither in sinuous multitudes in abandoned cars and trucks.Why all this unseemly behavior? Well, "Day of the Animals" is a movie speculating about what could happen if the ozone layer protecting the earth were diminished because of mankind's use of aerosol sprays. And it decides that this would give rise to a mutant virus that would turn animals into mankillers.Naturally, we are told, this phenomenon would manifest itself initially in the high country, where Steve Buckner (Christopher George) and Daniel Santee (Michael Ansara) are leading a no-weapons, no-food wilderness tour. Among the participants are a megalomaniacal advertising executive, a television newswoman, a science professor, a divorced mother and her son, a football player dying of cancer and a couple trying to patch up their marriage."Day of the Animals" offers pretty scenery, and some repulsive animal attacks. Despite its putative concern for the environment, it is calculated more to incite terror than to inspire restraint.This film has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"). Animal and human savagery, the latter in the form of an attempted rape, are apparently the reasons.

title: Marshall Rawle, 69, an ExPartner Of Investment Capital Company,
description: Marshall Rawle, who recently retired as the managing partner of Payson & Trask, an investment capital concern in New York City, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. Mr. Rawle, who lived at 172 Long Neck Point Road in Noroton, Conn., was 69 years old.

title: LABOR PARTY SCORES GAINS IN DUTCH VOTE
description: THE HAGUE, May 25 (AP)Prime Minister Joop M. den Uy1's Labor Party scored major gains in the Dutch general election today and seemed likely to continue as the base for a leftofcenter coalition.

title: 9 Killed by Fire at a West Side Bathhouse
description: Nine men were killed and 10 were injured yesterday in an earlymorning fire that destroyed a Manhattan bathhouse that catered to homosexuals.

title: U.S. DROPS BACKING ON BILL GIVING TRIBE $177 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)In a last minute switch that an official said he believed had been dictated by President Carter's budget office, the Interior Department abandoned today its support of a bill to pay Oklahoma Indian tribes $177 million for the bed of the Arkansas River.

title: State Relief Looms for Trotters Today,* Press Gives Ailing Cauthen Little Relief; Albany Moves to Avert Harness Strike, But Belmont Dispute Goes Into Sixth Day
description: Horse racing, the sport of picket lines and threatened strikes, made some ground on three labor fronts in the state of New York yesterday.

title: Republic Steel's Debt DOwnrated by S.&P.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation has lowered its rating on the debt issues of the Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel maker, to A2 from Al, the highest rate possible.

title: CALIFANO OUTLINES WELFARE AID LINKED TO JOB REQUIREMENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The Carter Administration announced today that, under the revised welfare system it plans to propose to Congress, hundreds of thousands of people now on relief would be required to accept jobs or lose a good part of their public assistance.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Despite the Season, It's a Big Year for Fur
description: HOW CAN anyone think of a fur coat when the temperature is in the 80's? Well, about 300 customers in their summer dresses pushed their way into Saks Fifth Avenue yesterday and got ecstatic over lynx and mink and sable and oversized raccoon and coyote.

title: This YearThe Quintessential Quilting Bee
description: HERE HAS all the velvet gone? It seems like only yesterday that velvet was the upholstery fabric most in demand. Now, everywhere you sit it's quilted, quilted, quilted.

title: Design Notebook
description: BY NOW almost everyone knows that Christie's, the London auction house, has expanded and begun auctions in New York, if only because Christie's competitor, Sotheby Parke Bernet, has gotten nervous and embarked on what looks like a tripling of its advertising. Christie's has settled in specially remodeled space in Delmonico's Hotel at 502 Park Avenue, the tower at the corner of 59th Street that also houses Regine's the discotheque. Christie's has taken much of the second floor, including Delmonico's former ballroom, now its salesroom.

title: CALIFANO OUTLINES WELFARE AID LINKED TO JOB REQUIREMENT
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The Carter Administration announced today that, under the revised welfare system it plans to propose to Congress, hundreds of thousands of people now on relief would be required to accept jobs or lose a good part of their public assistance.

title: Advertising
description: The recently released consumer study commissioned by Sentry Insurance will have a major impact on Government regulatory agencies and on advertising, in the view of one astute observer

title: Jazz: Phil Woods 5
description: Phil Woods, who has been a consistently interesting jazz saxophone soloist for the last two decades, while he played, for the most part, with pickup groups, is now leading a quintet that functions as an ensemble rather than merely a backdrop for his solos.

title: Otherwise Engaged Wins Critics Award
description: HE NEW YORK Drama Critics Circle yesterday voted the British comedy Otherwise Engaged the but play of the 197677 season. Amer:can Buffalo was named thd best American play and Annie the best musical.

title: TRADE WITH JAPAN STRESSED BY BYRNE
description: WEST ORANGE, May 25New Jersey and Japan wooed each other today in promoting business between the natioa's most industrialized state and its best overseas trading customer.

title: Top 100 BlackOwned Companies Report 24.2% Gain in Revenues
description: Total revenues for the 100 largest blackowned companies, as listed by the business magazine, Black Enterprise, rose 24.2 percent last year to $775.2 million from $623.9 million in 1975. The 1975 figure had marked the first revenue decline in the four years that the magazine had made the survey.

title: Housing for Disabled Supported
