description: WASHINGTON, May 25Patricia Roberts Harris, Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, announced today the creation of a new office of independent living.

title: Jazz: African Beat
description: CLIFFORD THORNTON, who is leading a jazz quintet at Ali's Alley, 77 Greene Street, through Saturday night, has been grappling during the last few years with an intriguing musical problem. Through traveling and performing in Africa and coming in contact with African musicians while he taught at Wesleyan University, Mr. Thornton became interested in the polyrhythmic complexity of traditional African music.

title: Fire in L J.R.R. Cable Holds Up Commuters
description: A fire in the main cable of a Long Island Rail Road switch substation east of Jamaica halted 16 trains last night and delayed several thousand commuters some more than two hours.

title: Nixon Saw Cuba and Chile Enclosing Latin America
description: WASHINGTON. May 25Former President Richard M. Nixon regarded the Cuba of Fidel Castro and the Marxist Government of Salvador Allende Gossens in Chile as the slices of a Red sandwich that could eventually have enclosed all of Latin America in Communism.

title: 2,000 to Rebuild Carrier Saratoga
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP)The Navy announced plans today in Washington to have the aircraft carrier Saratoga rebuilt at the Philadelphia Navy Yard. Navy officials said that the project was expected to emloy 2,000 workers over two years. Some $380 million has been allocated to modernize the Saratoga, Forrestal, Ranger and Independence.

title: Deaths
description: Bratip

title: $61,000 Libel Award Against Times And Audubon Official Overturned
description: A $61,000 libel award against The New York Times and an official of the National Audubon Society was thrown out yesterday by a Federal appeals court that stressed the right of the press to report serious charges involving public figures.

title: U.S.Considering Aid Concessions To Poor Nations
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The United States is prepared to make significant concessions in commodity stabilization, foreign aid and special assistance to the poorest countries to bring the Conference on International Economic Cooperation, the socalled NorthSouth dialogue between rich and poor countries to a positive conclusion, American officials said today.

title: Senate Unit Votes, 9 to 8, to Disclose Intelligence Total
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The Senate's Select Committee on Intelligence voted 9 to 8 today to recommend to the full Senate that it disclose publicly the amount of money appropriated for the intelligence community in 1978.

title: Who Will Be the Next Head of Federal Reserve Board?; Leonard Silk
description: Who will be the next chairman of the Federal Reserve Board? The question once would have seemed important only to the more sophisticated members of the financial community. But recent nationwide survey by U.S. News

title: GARDENING_
description: Espalier (pronounced ispalyah) derived from the French, and means shoulder or support. As a horticultural technique, it dates back to the medieval period when people lived in walled towns. To make the greatest use of garden space, fruit trees were trained to grow flat along garden walls. The practice reached its height in the gardens at. Versailles, and was introduced to America by the English settlers. Samples of the Colonial style can he Seen in the to dens of Mount Vernon and Wift:,msburg.

title: Size of Marijuana Seizure Cut
description: KEY LARGO, Fla., May 25 (AP)Monroe County deputies say that the marijua= na seized from three fishing boats in the Florida Keys weighed 20.8 tons, less than half the original estimated 50 tons. Since the seizure of the boats Monday in an obscure canal, the authorities have arrested 11 men.

title: ...And It Almost Didn't Get to the Screen
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: Peru Bridge Collapse Kills 9
description: LIMA, Peru, May 25 (Reuters)Nine workers were drowned when a bridge they were building on the Maranon River, 260 miles east, of Lima, wns swept away by swirling wntrrs, neerording In reparls reaching herr today.

title: Jockey Is Swamped Leaving Hospital for Month Rest
description: Described by his mother as real good now, Steve Cauthen paid the price of being a national celebrity yesterday during a tumultuous departure from Long Island Jewish Hospital.

title: Books of The Times
description: YOU MAY very well think, as did, that nothing remains to be written about the American phase of the Vietnam War. Indeed there is not much in Philip Caputo's A Rumor of Warfrom his accounts of atrocties committed, to the frustration he expresses over the lack of setpiece battlesthat hasn't been referred to in a general way in the literature on the war. Nevertheless.

title: 50 CUBAN ADVISERS REPORTED TRAINING TROOPS IN ETHIOPIA
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The State Department said today it had received reports that about 50 Cuban military advisers had arrived in Ethiopia. In addition, the department said there were unverified reports that several hundred Cuban troops were being sent.

title: Jazz: Nod to Nostalgia
description: HE SIGN advertising Nostalgia Night"outside the Red Blazer Too at Third Avenue and 88th Street on Monday evening did not really suggest what could be heard inside. Neither camp, sentimentality nor banality, which are too often the handmaidens of musical nostalgia, were in evidence in the performance by Gary Lawrence and His Sizzling Syncopaters, a 10piece band that works with the pop and jazz materials of the 1920's and 30's.

title: ALBANY BILL HEATS SUNDAY TRADE ISSUE
description: The issue of doing business on Sunday which had cooled after most of New York's largest retailers joined in keeping stores open on Sundays, is beginning to heat up again under the threat of a new bill that would reinstate Sunday blue laws.

title: Jersey's Pledge For Amex Now At $63 Million
description: TRENTON, May 25Culminating a twoyear campaign to attract the American Stock Exchange to New Jersey, Governor Byrne said today that the state was prepared to spend as much as $631 million to construct a 33story skyscraper to house the Amex in Jersey City.

title: Beame Asks Million For Accused Agency
description: Mayor Beanie is asking the Board of Estimate to approve $1 million in Federal job funds today for an agency under investigation for suspect bidding practices and other alleged irregularities in the lunch program it sponsored last summer. The agency, the B'nai Torah Institute of Brooklyn, is the subject of investigations by the United States Departments of Justice, Agriculture and Labor, Last March, it was also cited by Representative Elizabeth Holtzman, Democrat of Brooklyn, for serious abuses in connection with the operation of a Federal summer job program.

title: Podgorny, Seen Slipping From Presidency, Fails To Sign African Message
description: MOSCOW, May 25 (Reuters)President Nikolai V. Podgorny, abruptly dropped yesterday from the Communist Party's ruling Politburo, today appeared to be easing out of the public view in a probable prelude to his removal as head of state.

title: Yanks Win, Then Lose To Rangers
description: If the Yankees haven't bolted away from the rest of their division the way they were supposed to, they at least can claim a big lead in number of clubhouse meetings held or contemplated.

title: ExLeasing Official Convicted of Taking Gratuity of $3,000
description: Michael R. Palumbo, the former director of leasing for New York City, who had handled transactions committing the city to pay $87 million a year in rents, was convicted yesterday of having accepted a gratuity of $3,000 from a real estate agent.

title: PRESIDENT PLANNING WIDER ROLE FOR T.V.A.
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  President Carter has told a group of senators representing the seven states directly served by the Tennessee Valley Authority that he plans to expand the Federal agency's responsibilities for energy research and development.

title: Brixton
description: IN THE BRIXTON RECOVERY, Jack Gilhooley shows a genial recording eye for his protagonists: an ambitious West Indian woman in a London slum and the white American boxer she befriends.

title: Carter's Island Retreat Great Place
description: ST. SIMONS, Ga., May 25For Dwight D. Eisenhower, it was Gettysburg, Pa.; for John F. Kennedy, Hyannis Port, Mass.; for Lyndon B. Johnson, the LBJ Ranch on the Pedernales in Texas.

title: Senate Approves Nominations Of 11 New U.S. Ambassadors
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (Reuters)The Senate today, approved without dissent or objection President Carter's nominations of 11 ambassadors.

title: Price of Gold Continues To Show Drop in London; Dollar Off Around Europe
description: LONDON, May 25 (AP)The price of gold continued to fall in London today while the dollar closed lower around Europe, especially against the pound.

title: Higher Moody's Ratings Bolster M.A.C. Bonds and a Jersey Issue
description: The financial fortunes of the Northeast improved yesterday as Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds jumped sharply in price in response to their upgrading Tuesday by Moody's Investors Service and as New Jersey sold a $50 million

title: JOHN MAXON, 60, OFFICIAL OF CHICAGO ART INSTITUTE
description: John Maxon, vice president for collections and exhibitions at the Chicago Art Institute, collapsed and died while dining with friends and colleagues in Chicago on Tuesday evening. He was 60 years old.

title: Around the Nation Coast Guard to Assign Women to Sea Duty
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., May 25 (AP)The Coast Guard's allmale ships will soon take women crew members aboard on permanentduty status, Brock Adams, the Secretary of Transportation, said today.

description: For periods ended April 30 unless other1 wise Indicated. (N) Indicates stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange. (A) American Stock Exchange and (0) OvertheCounter

description: Thursday, May 26. 1977

title: Mexican Expert Says U. S. Moves to Deal With Illegal Migration Would Invite Disastrous Consequences
description: MEXICO CITY, May 25Mexico's leading expert on illegal migration to the United States has sharply criticized the Carter Administration's plans for dealing with the problem and has warned that its myopic policy could bring disastrous consequences for both the United States and Mexico.

title: YEVGENIYA GINZBURG, 71; SOVIET DISSIDENT AUTHOR
description: MOSCOW, May 25 (Reuters)Yevgeniya Ginzburg, author of the Stalin labor camp autobiography Into the Whirlwind, died today in Moscow. She was 71.

title: Israel Accuses Egypt of Violating Accord on Forces Near the Canal
description: TEL AVIV, May 25 (AP)Israel claimed today that Egypt had violated the interim Sinai agreement by moving extra missiles and troops into the limitedforces zone separating the two armies near the Suez Canal.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PEKING, May 25 (Reuters)China lifted a 10yearold ban on Shakespeare today and announced that it would publish a new Chinese language edition of his works.

title: New York Fetes Its 200th Year At Albany Party
description: ALBANY. May 25Charles McGuire, a young man who works in the Senate document room at the State Capitol, was standing on State Street shortly before noon today, minding his own business, when what should appear but a 325pound cheese in the back of horsedrawn wagon.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Spying Is Spying Is Spying Is Spying
description: WASHINGTONClarence Kelley, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, often boasts that he has reduced F.B.I. intelligence investigations from 21,000 to 621. This is, we think, a bit like the man who takes credit for now beating his wife only once a day rather than four times. The F.B.I. should not infiltrate and investigate any lawful political group simply because it believes its members may violate the law sometime in the future.

title: Oosterhuis, 2 Others Lead British P.G.A. With 69's
description: SANDWICH, England, May 25 (AP)Peter Oosterhuis of Britain, Severiano Ballesteros of Spain and Andreis Oosthuizen of South Africa fashioned oneunderpar 69's today and shared the firstround lead of the $85.000 British Professional Golfers Association championship on windswept Royal St. George's.

title: Avis Shifts 85 Aides to Manhattan From Garden City to Cut Travel
description: Too many Avis Inc. executives are spending too much time in cars driving between the comany's headquarters in Garden City, L.I., and business appointments in New York City, and so the company is going to move them to New York.

title: Louisiana Houses: The Talk of the Town
description: HOUSE PROUD is a phrase that comes to mind often and felicitously as one travels through Louisiana, especially in the areas around New Orleans and Baton Rouge. Before too long, a visitor who expresses an interest in old architecture, antique furniture and interior decorating will be whisked off to see at least one house that will be, has been, or is being reclaimed from ruin.

title: Islanders Fear Reprisals by the Indonesians
description: AMBON, Molucca Islands, May 25Those terrorists in Holland are stupid, a Moluccan student said, grinding a fist into his palm.

title: Topics
description: Tired and Fired

title: The Ultimate Tent: A Pitch for Permanence
description: NOW THAT building a house is dramatically expensive and real estate prices are zooming, the possibility of building vacation house is vanishing for many Americans. That summer shack, beach house, or mountain log cabin may soon be replaced by a livein tent.

title: FORD ASKS MICHIGAN TO HELP HIS MUSEUM
description: LANSING, Mich., May 25Former President Gerald R. Ford returned to Michigan to lobby legislators today for funds to build a museum in his honor in Grand Rapids, where he grew up. He asked for $3 million.

title: NonQuebec French Ask for Rights,
description: OTTAWA, May 25French Canadians who live in Englishspeaking provinces, and who reject an independent Frenchspeaking Quebec as a solution to their identity problems, announced a program today to defend their separate linguistic and cultural character by political pressure.

title: Jet Slides Off Runway in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)An Eastern Air Lines 727 had an engine failure while taking off from Washington's National Airport this morning and slid off the end of a rainslick runway when the pilot aborted the flight, a spokesman for the airline said. There were no injuries to any of the 53 persons aboard the flight, which had originated in Raleigh, N.C., and was on its way to Boston.

title: Louisiana Governor Ordered To Testify on Korean Influence
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI)Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Lottisian and his wife have been ordered to testify in the House Ethics Committee's investigation into alleged South Korean bribery of Congressmen, it was learned today.

title: The Race for Governor
description: TRENTON, May 25  At campaign rallies, Representative Robert A. Roe often asks: Why should a Democratic Congressman, who has eight years of seniority and is chairman of the powerful Economic Development Subcommittee of the House Public Works Committee, want to give up a relatively safe Congressional seat to be Governor of the State of New Jersey?

title: At Your Service: Termite Trouble
description: IT IS EARLY evening on a weekday night and the telephone rings. Is this the lady of the house? Our termite inspectors will be on your block tomorrow, and we'd be happy to arange for a free inspection. You are located in a red alert area, you know:

title: Home Beat
description: LAST YEAR. shects. This year, sheets and carpeting. Next year, perhaps, furniture. Halston, the fashion designer, is up to his white suit iacket in home furnishJugs, and it's just the beginning.

title: The NoImpact Impact Statement
description: Two years ago, Congress passed legislation requiring the executive branch to submit an armscontrol impact statement every time it seeks funds for an important new weapon system. The process was designed to force both branches to think hard, before deploying a new weapon, about whether it would help preserve international stability. The national security agencies have completed their second annual review and, for the second time, their analyses are so deliberately superficial as to be worthless.

title: New Bond Issues
description: Wednesday, May 25, 1977

title: Beirut Showing Signs of Recovery From Wounds of War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 25Nothing can take the place of Beirut, the Lebanese kept telling themselves during the 19 months of devastating civil war that destroyed the heart of the capital, severely damaged the Lebanese economy and is estimated to have taken 60,000 lives.

title: U.S. GENERAL IS INVITED TO VISIT FINLAND IN JUNE
description: WASHINGTON. May 25Gen. George S. Brown, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will visit Helsinki, Finland, from June 13 to 16 at the invitation of the Finnish defense forces, the Department of Defense announced today.

title: Speer Urges World Talks On Steel Industry Policy
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, called yesterday on the governments of all steel producing nations to begin negotiations to establish what he called a worldwide fair trade policy.

title: JEANNE WASHBURN ROSE
description: Jeanne Washburn Rose, who had been active in civic affairs in North Shore Long Island communities, died Tuesday at St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L.I. She was 58 years old and a resident of Port Washington. L.I.

title: General Foods Quarter Profits Rose 14.4% Above Level for 1976
description: The General Foods Corporation, a major producer of packaged foods and groceries and a leader in coffee production, reported yesterday a 14.4 percent profit gain for the quarter and an 18 percent rise for the fiscal year ended April 2. Both periods covered one week less than in fiscal 1976.

title: Airmorial rruim
description: JACKSONRobert V. A Memorial Servico will be held at 11 A.M. in the Williams Institutional C.M.E. Church, 2225 7th Ave., N. Y. C., on Saturday, May 28, 1977. He was an interior designer wellknown for his extraordinary displays. He was an excellent host and much loved by his friends as a social entertainer. Mr. Jackson, who resided at 135 W. 96th St., died Sunday, May 22, as a result of an accident.

title: Police Isolate Moluccans of the Dutch Town Struck by Terrorists
description: BOVENSMILDE, the Netherlands, May 25The national police have sealed off the north quarter of Bovensmilde, where 750 native Moluccans live apart from theicwhite neighbors.

title: Iran Is Shaken by Earthquake
description: TEHERAN, Iran, May 25 (AP)A quake shook Teheran today but there were no reports of casualties or damage. The epicenter was about 35 miles southwest of the capital.

description: The Denver Nuggets unloaded their highpriced second front line yesterday in a threeteam sixplayer trade.

description: A group of 21 fifthgraders, steeled by the ups and downs of a mythical company that they had set up and invested in three weeks ago, went down to meet some real Wall Street experts on their own ground yesterday.

title: Arabs
description: DETROIT, May 25A year ago, the Bank of the Commonwealth's big problem was raising $10 million of new capital that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation required as the price for keeping the bank open.

title: Bring Back the 5Cent Deposit
description: Should every can and bottle of soda and beer carry a 5cent deposit against its return? It seems like a small question until you hear the arguments pro and con; large stakes ride on the answer. A bill to require the nickel deposit seems headed for a vote in the New York State Senate this week and the Assembly soon after. Oregon, South Dakota, Vermont and all Federal installations have had a deposit system for some time; Connecticut appears close to adopting one; the voters of Michigan and Maine approved of deposits last fall, while the voters of Massachusetts and Colorado demurred. The issue boils down to whether consumers can be induced to return their drink containersto the benefit of the environment, the energy supply and the stock of natural resourcesor whether the dislocations in a major industry and the ingrained habits of consumers would merely raise everyone's costs and cause as much social harm as good.

title: Dale Littman in Piano Debut
description: DALE LITTMAN, a New Yorker with a master's degree from the Jullliard School who teaches at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., gave her first local recital on Tuesday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The pianist played what used to be considered an orthodox program: a Bach prelude and fugue (in F sharp minor from Book If of The WellTempered Clavier), three short Brahms pieces, a Beethoven sonata (Op. 109 in E), a Schumann sonata (Op. 22 in G minor), Bartok's Rumanian Folk Dances and Liszt's Hungarian Rhapsody No. 8.

title: Armored Truck Found, Cash Gone
description: PHOENIX, May 25 (AP)An armored truck that disappeared yesterday on bank run with about $300,000 in cash was found abandoned today. Most of the money and the two guards assigned to the truck, owned by Purolator Security Inc., were missing.

title: Twins Outhit Red Sox, 3519, in a Sweep
description: Has the baseball been juiced up? Or is the manufacturing process better than usual? Judge for yourself.

title: IRISH GENERAL ELECTIONS ARE SCHEDULED FOR JUNE 16
description: DUBLIN. May 25 (Reuters)Prime Minister Liam Cosgrave tonight called general election for June 16, and launched a threeweek election campaign for a second term for an Irish coalition government.

title: Letters
description: In response to Mr. Zinsser's Letter From Home column [April 28], we, as college students, feel the need to support his observations on the limited concerns of the majority of our peers. It is not their intellectual curiosity or capability which is lacking, but that they channel their energies to achieve one specific goal. In doing so, they neglect other essential aspects of their education which would consummate their development as wellrounded individuals. Who would deny that spending seven days a week, 12 hours a day, in the library is a narrow existenceone which leaves little time for the acquisition of knowledge in areas other than in graded courses? Is that not defeating the purpose of a liberal education?

title: Letter From Home
description: It began on Sunday morning when Kingman Brewster Jr., gave his last baccalaureate address to Yale's seniors after 14 years as president. ]t ended on Monday afternoon when he was sworn in as Ambassador to the Court of St. James's and, like all the other new graduates, went home to pack. But much happened in between.

description: WASHINGTON, May 25Richard M. Nixon, professing regret that he was unable to clear his name through the agony of a trial, said in another interview televised tonight that his life had become almost unbearable after he resigned the Presidency in disgrace.

description: Beset by chronic financial problems, the Rockefeller University is seeking to sell a group of apartment buildings owns adjacent to its York Avenue campus.

description: In Central Park, the oncegreen lawn of the Sheep Meadow is wearing away, gradually becoming a dust bowl with overuse. At the Bethesda Fountain, drugs are sold routinely, and the Duck Pond each night becomes a receptacle for beer and soda cans.

title: Blumenthal Backs Wider Role for Yen
description: TOKYO, May 25 (UPI)Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that it was natural and normal for the Japanese yen to play a wider role in the international economy because it was an internationally strong currency.

title: Welfare for Farmers
description: Over White House objections the Senate passed a farm bill this week raising price supports for most grain crops. It is a bad bill that would reverse the trend toward less Government involvement in agriculture and increase the cost of farm products to both consumers and the Treasury.

title: THE SOLDIER who was superintendent of the United States Military Academy during West Point's worst cheating scandal in its history, Lieut. Gen. Sidney B. Berry, yesterday was given the major command of a 50,000man Army Corps in West Germany. The Defense Depart
description: trent said General Berry will command V Corps, which is made up of two infantry and armored divisions and an armored cavalry regiment. It's considered a choice assignment in Army circles.

title: Joseph Spivak, 65, Chief Geologist For the Mobil Oil Corporation
description: Joseph Spivak, chief geologist for the Mobil Oil Corporation, died Thursday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and a resident of Stamford, Conn.

title: Hers
description: W HEN I FIRST met Glinda, she was a customer's woman on Wall Street. That was shortly before she went into designing sheets, dishes and small leather goods. We lost track for a time, during which I heard she had either opened a seafcod restaurant or become a sex therapist, or both.

title: Earn Those Pinstripes, Reggie
description: Dave Anderson

title: The Banality of Evil
description: BOSTON, May 25Six hours of Richard Nixon reminiscing on television have deepened one's feeling of awe for the American constitutional system. It had to be a system of amazing strength and resilience to bring country through nearly six years of such a person as President. There can have been few such devastating pieces of selfexposure in political history: the fantasies, the contempt for law, the selfconfessed paranoia, the obliviousness to responsibility for human suffering and death. And the banality of the man, the level of his reasoning: Trying to justify American intervention in Chile, he said an Italian businessman had told him that a leftwing election victory in Chile would turn all of Latin America into a Red sandwich.

title: Big Board and Amex Issue Reports Of Changes in Stock by Insiders
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies.

title: Cartir Pledge Kept On Atom Fuel Plant In Portsmouth, Ohio
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  President Carter decided today that he could not go back entirely on a campaign promise to Ohioans to place a new $4.4 billion nuclear fuel enrichment plant in Portsmouth, in the depressed southern part of the state, even though the cost of the project might be several hundred million dollars less if it were built in Oak Ridge, Tenn.

description: GENEVA, May 20To test the intrinsic limits on weather forecasting and lay the basis for an understanding of climate change, one of the most extensive international scientific experiments in history is being organized.

title: Publisher Loses First of Two Suits to Untangle a Hughes Connection
description: SAN FRANCISCO. May 25A recent Federal court decision here and one awaited from a state court in Elko, Nev., may finally resolve the tangled relationship of Howard Hughes and Hank Greenspun, as well as determine the future of The Las Vegas Sun, Mr. Greenspun's newspaper.

title: NEW & USEFUL
description: When the Living Is Easy June has almost happened, which means that those who have summer cottages will soon be repairing to them. And if you're not one of those people who do everything in jig time and live ever after in perfect surroundings, you're probably still adding furnishings. There are numbers of things in stores now that will add zest to a summer place, or fill in some missing category. Take china, for example. Something simple and inexpensive is usually what's wanted for rural diningbut with a little style. No problem. The Pottery Barn, 117 East 59th Street, has stoneware from Poland that would look fine on a country dining table. There are two styles in the Barclay patternsimple shapes in an offwhite tone. One set is just plain white, at $9 for a fivepiece place setting (dinner plate, salad plate, bowl and a low, rounded cup and saucer); the other style simply adds a blue band around the edge and is $10.50 for the basic setting. The inexpensive china at Design Research, 53 East 57th Street, comes from France. Bistro is available in allwhite, or white with a blue rim or a darkbrown rim. The fivepiece place setting, with deep dinner plate, salad plate, bowl, cup and saucer, is $6.70 for the white, $10.50 for the ones with banding. Another French earthenware set, white with a wide blue rim and little dots around the edge, has a charming peasant look. A fourpiece place setting (dinner, salad, bowl and mug) is $10, and it would do well in the city too, luncheon set.

title: W. R. Grace to Study Saudi Methanol Unit
description: W. R. Grace & Company, with Japanese and Saudi Arabian concerns, will study the feasibility of building in Saudi Arabia a plant capable of producing 2,000 tons of methanol a day, the Mitsubishi Gas Chemical Company of Japan said. Methanol is used in producing synthetic resins.

title: Environmental Body Cautioning Australia on Mining of Uranium

title: Wales Fire. Kills 4 Children
description: NEWPORT, Wales, May 25 (Reuters)Four sisters, all under the age of 8, died today when fire destroyed their house in this South Wales town. The police said the girls mother escaped with a fifth daughter, 8 years old, by leaping from a bedroom window.

title: MANDATE UNLIKELY IN TURKISH ELECTION

description: WASHINGTON, May 25  President Carter plans to announce tomorrow that he is considering vetoing three pieces of legislation that he considers inflationary, White House aides said, thereby placing himself in direct confrontation with Congress.

L., Staten Island, N.Y.

No motive for the killing was immediately known.

Lefkowitz, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to perjury in connection with her testimony before a grand jury investigating corruption and official misconduct in the Attorney General's office.

title: Dayan Likely as Foreign Minister
description: TEL AVIV, May 23Former Defense Minister Moshe Dayan, a Labor Party member who is opposed to giving up territory on the occupied West Bank, agreed in principle tonight to serve as Foreign Minister in a coalition Government to be headed by Menahem Begin.

title: ...But London's Hyde Park Remains a Refuge of Stability
description: LONDON, May 25Hyde Park is to London what Central Park is to New York City. It is the outdoor gathering place for the rich, the poor, blacks and whites; a quarter of a million people go there every day. But unlike Central Park, Hyde Park is almost free of crime, rowdyism and noise.

title: Park Said to Yield Reluctantly to U.S. Korea Plait
description: SEOUL, South Korea, May 25President Park Chung Hee, with evident reluctance, was reported today to have accepted as inevitable the withdrawal of American ground forces and urged the United States to take compensatory measures along with the withdrawal, which is to be completed gradually over four to five years.

title: Excerpts From Nixon Interview on Agnew Chile and His Decision to Resign
description: WASHINGTON, May 25Following are excerpts from the fourth televised conversation between former President Richard M. Nixon and David Frost, as transcribed by Mr. Frost and televised tonight:

title: W. L. Damian Pitcaithly, Episcopalian Priest, 68, Founder of Drug Center
description: The Rev. W. L. Damian Pitcaithly, an early exponent of drugfree treatment for narcotics addicts in New York City, died Tuesday at his home in Middletown, Conn. He was 68, years old and, although formally retired, had remained active as a counselor.

title: 4 States Sign Delaware Water Pact
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 25The Delaware River Basin Commission unanimously approved today a program requiring New York City to release up to 31 billion gallons more water annually from its three big reservoirs in the Catskill Mountains.

title: 'Star Wars' A Trip to a Far Galaxy That's Fun and Funny.
description: "STAR WARS," George Lucas's first film since his terrifically successful "American Grafiti," is the movie that the teen-agers in "American Graffiti" would have broken their necks to see. It's also the movie that's going to entertain a lot of contemporary folk who have a soft spot for the virtually ritualized manners of comic-book adventure."Star Wars," which opened yesterday at the Astor Plaza, Orpheum and other theaters, is the most elaborate, most expensive, most beautiful movie serial ever made. It's both an apotheosis of "Flash Gordon" serials and a witty critique that makes associations with a variety of literature that is nothing if not eclectic: "Quo Vadis?", "Buck Rogers," "Ivanhoe," "Superman," "The Wizard of Oz," "The Gospel According to St. Matthew," the legend of King Arthur and the knights of the Round Table.All of these works, of course, had earlier left their marks on the kind of science-fiction comic strips that Mr. Lucas, the writer as well as director of "Star Wars," here remembers with affection of such cheerfulness that he avoids facetiousness. The way definitely not to approach "Star Wars," though, is to expect a film of cosmic implications or to footnote it with so many references that one anticipates it as if it were a literary duty. It's fun and funny.The time, according to the opening credit card, is "a long time ago" and the setting "a galaxy far far away," which gives Mr. Lucas and his associates total freedom to come up with their own landscapes, housing, vehicles, weapons, religion, politics  all of which are variations on the familiar.When the film opens, dark times have fallen upon the galactal empire once ruled, we are given to believe, from a kind of space-age Camelot. Against these evil tyrants there is, in progress, a rebellion led by a certain Princess Leia Organa, a pretty round-faced young woman of old-fashioned pluck who, before you can catch your breath, has been captured by the guardians of the empire. Their object is to retrieve some secret plans that can be the empire's undoing.That's about all the plot that anyone of voting age should be required to keep track of. The story of "Star Wars" could be written on the head of a pin and still leave room for the Bible. It is, rather, a breathless succession of escapes, pursuits, dangerous missions, unexpected encounters, with each one ending in some kind of defeat until the final one.These adventures involve, among others, an ever-optimistic young man named Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill), who is innocent without being nave; Han Solo (Harrison Ford), a free-booting freelance, space-ship captain who goes where he can make the most money, and an old mystic named Ben Kenobi (Alec Guinness), one of the last of the Old Guard, a fellow in possession of what's called "the force," a mixture of what appears to be ESP and early Christian faith.Accompanying these three as they set out to liberate the princess and restore justice to the empire are a pair of Laurel-and-Hardyish robots. The thin one, who looks like a sort of brass woodman, talks in the polished phrases of a valet ("I'm adroit but I'm not very knowledgeable"), while the squat one, shaped like a portable washing machine, who is the one with the knowledge, simply squeaks and blinks his lights. They are the year's best new comedy team.In opposition to these good guys are the imperial forces led by someone called the Grand Moff Tarkin (Peter Cushing) and his executive assistant, Lord Darth Vader (David Prowse), a former student of Ben Kenobi who elected to leave heaven sometime before to join the evil ones.The true stars of "Star Wars" are John Barry, who was responsible for the production design, and the people who were responsible for the incredible special effectsspace ships, explosions of stars, space battles, hand-to-hand combat with what appear to be lethal neon swords. I have a particular fondness for the look of the interior of a gigantic satellite called the Death Star, a place full of the kind of waste space one finds today only in old Fifth Avenue mansions and public libraries.There's also a very funny sequence in a low-life bar on a remote planet, a frontierlike establishment where they serve customers who look like turtles, apes, pythons and various amalgams of same, but draw the line at robots. Says the bartender piously: "We don't serve their kind here."It's difficult to judge the performances in a film like this. I suspect that much of the time the actors had to perform with special effects that were later added in the laboratory. Yet everyone treats his material with the proper combination of solemnity and good humor that avoids condescension. One of Mr. Lucas's particular achievements is the manner in which he is able to recall the tackiness of the old comic strips and serials he loves without making a movie that is, itself, tacky. "Star Wars" is good enough to convince the most skeptical 8-year-old sci-fi buff, who is the toughest critic."Star Wars," which has been rated PG "Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a lot of explosive action, and not a bit of truly disturbing violence.

title: Carter Discharges a U.S. Attorney
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)President Carter dismissed Philip Van Dam as the United States Attorney in Detroit Itoday after he had refused the Adminis tration's request for his resignation.

title: LOGAN T. JOHNSTON OF ARMCO STEEL DIES
description: Farmer President and Chairman Initiated Major Modernization and Expansion Program

title: Union Ruling Is Affecting Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)Employ ees of businesses owned by foreign governments operating in the United States are entitled for the first time to union representation, the National Labor Relations Board ruled today.

title: Veeck Leaves Quietly To Scout in Cuba
description: MILWAUKEE, May 25 (UPI)Bill

title: Carey to Request StopGap Aid For WorstOff Housing Projects
description: ALBANY, May 25The Carey administration has decided against making any sweeping proposals this year to salvage the state's faltering middleincome housing program. Instead, it will ask the Legislature to appropriate $18 million as a stopgap solution to keep 10 of the worstoff projects from having to dip into required reserve funds to pay for needed repairs.

title: Matching Payments With Income
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has tried to build maximum flexibility into its pilot program on graduatedpayment mortgages.

title: NEW BOUNDARIESI When More Is Not Attainable
description: COVENTRY, England  President Carter said it, and in his Inaugural Address: More is not necessarily better. He struck a chord with the growing disenchantment that Americans, along with other citizens of the world's materially rich societies, have been experiencing toward the old god of economic growth. But this questioning of economic growth is typjcally vague and often confused  and this doubtless explains the imprecision of the President's allusion.

title: DECLINE IS PREDICTED IN WORLD WHEAT CROP
description: LONDON, May 25 (AP)The International Wheat Council has tentatively forecast the 1977 world wheat crop at between 390 million and 410 million tons, down from a record of 417 million tons in 1976.

title: Gen. Hershey Buried at Arlington With a Joint Services Ceremony
description: ARLINGTON, Va., May 25 (AP)Gen. Lewis Blaine Hershey, the Selective Service chief who called 14.5 million draftees to service in three wars, was buried today with high honors in Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Even Opulence Sparks Hyperbole in Brokers
description: The creativity or realestate brokers when it comes time to take to the typewriter and compose advertising has always been a source of amazement. By now, even the least sophisticated reader is aware that oldworld charm means that the plaster is cracking and cozy means that one is best advised to sleen standing un. One would think that this hyperbole would lessen when it comes to more elaborate apartments of the sort that could never be called cozy or cute or that perfect piedaterre, since the big places presumably have virtues of their own that are attractive enough when described in matteroffact terms. But curiously, opulent real estate seems to stimulate the creative juices of the copywriters. A recent perusal of the real estate ads suggests that the eagerness of brokers to prove themselves as prose stylists has only increased with the recent upturn in the coop market.

title: Detroit School Bus Drivers Go Out
description: DETROIT, May 25 (AP)About 25,000 elementary and middlegrade students had to get to school on their own today as 300 public school bus drivers stayed off the job in a contract dispute. School spokesmen said that the drivers, members of the teamsters union, set up picket lines at the two school bus terminals. High school students were not affected because they ride public transportation.

title: Bridge:
description: The Reisinger knockout team championship, which began its semifinal stage at the Cavendish Club here last night, attracts nearly all the strongest players in the metropolitan area, and the list of winners in almost half century includes many world champions.

title: Thomas L. Daniels Is Dead at 84; ExHead of ArcherDanielsMidland
description: Thomas Leonard Daniels, former president and board chairman of the ArcherDanielsMidland Company, Minneapolis, died Monday in St. Paul. He was 84 years old.

title: Dance: Graham's Double Duet
description: ATRUISM is something that is sufficiently true in the first place to make it a truism in the second place. Even clichs did not get that way by accident. It is, admittedly, a truism to suggest that any choreographer who sets up shop to provide the sum total substance of his or her repertory had better have pretty large stock in trade. Had better bein a wordversatile. That Martha Graham most certainly is.

title: Catherine T. Hunt Is Married to Thomas C. Lindsay
description: Catherine Turner Hunt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lucas Hunt of Brinxville, N. Y., was married there yesterday at her parents home to Theinas Christopher Lindsay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lindsay of the Btonx. Judge Lucille Polk Buell of the Westchester County Family Court performed the ceremony.

title: Sound
description: THIS ARTICLE has been inspired by the recent experience of my friend Fitz, who had gone to a discount house in Queens to buy some stereo components I had recommended. Instead of supplying him with the equipment specificany asked for, the salesman disparaged his choice, and after lecturing Fitz in dense jargon to the point of utter confusion, the salesman finally suggested a quite different sound system, assuring Fitz he'd be a lot happier that way. Fitz said he would think about it, went to the nearest phone booth and called me up to ask my opinion.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk reports that the question of who will be the next chairman of the Federal Reserve System is entangled in the evolving struggle between a relatively conservative President and a liberal Democratic Congress. Page D3.

title: Creditors Charge a Plan For Reorganizing Pennsy Could Shortchange Them
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP)  The bankrupt reorganization plan of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company was attacked in Federal court today by lawyers for creditors who conend they are being shortchanged.

title: RedsDodgers Sold Out
description: CINCINNATI, May 25 (UPI)The Cincinnati Reds announced today that the Reds:Los Angeles Dodgers doubleheader here on Sunday, June 26, is sellout at 51,963seat Riverfront Stadium. Reds officials said o the best of their knowledge it is the earliest regular season game sellout, excluding opening day, in the club's history.

title: About Newyork
description: There is a public high school in this city with a principal who says he has no studentdiscipline problems, a man who has fashioned a haven for himself from palette and brushes that he takes up a few doors from his office when he needs to retreat from bureaucracy to stilllife.

title: ISA NAKAYAMA
description: TOKUSHIMA, Japan, May 25 (Reuters) Isa Nakayama, reputed to be Japan's oldest woman at 108, died here today of hepatitis, relatives said.

title: AntiApartheid Protests Likely For Wimbledon
description: Wimbledon's 100th birthday celebration may become the scene of largescale demonstrations against apartheid if South African players are allowed to participate in the tournament.

title: Open Interest
description: Wedncsdar, Mar 25, 1977

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State's Services Corporation, which had been under fire from the Legislature and educational officials for delayed payments of Regents scholarship and Tuition Assistance Program checks, said in Albany that payments had gone out to 424,531 students and that the vast majority of the remaining 20,000 should be decided and paid by June 30.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Orlando, Fla.James Salerno, 156 pounds, outoolnted Tlger Hall, 1521/2, 4 rounds. Sacramenls, Calf Pete Romany, 148, Sacramento, outpoIntod Abel Cordoba, 150, Los Angeles, 10.

title: Cash Prices
description: Wednesday, May 25, 1977

title: Mets to Try Still Another Lineup Shift
description: Having watched his team descend to a 715 wonlost record so far in May, Joe Frazier of the Mets is trying some radical lineupshifting to close out the unmerry month on a positive note.

title: Smoke Kills 100YearOld Man
description: MATTOON, Ill., May 25 (AP)Charles William Eaton celebrated his 100th birthday yesterday and died today in his smokefilled rural home in the village of Paradise near Mattoon, in east central Illinois. The authorities said Mr. Eaton suffocated from smoke pouring from coalburning cook stove in which he was disposing of trash. Neighbors saw the smoke and summoned help.

title: A Journalism Award To Journalists in Jail
description: The faculty of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism broke with tradition and awarded the 1977 Columbia Journalism Award yesterday to imprisoned journalists around the world, declaring that it is their absence that prompts us to give them the prize.

title: 9 Killed by Fire at a West Side Bathhouse
description: Nine men were killed and 10 were injured yesterday in an earlymorning fire that destroyed a Manhattan bathhouse that catered to homosexuals.

title: How to Put More Bite Into Jaws
description: HE IS A BRAINY Harvard graduate who went from directing classics in the theater to making films that are praised for being human, such as Bang the Drum Slowly. She is an actress who specializes in serious, meaty, women's roles, such as Rennie in the film End of the Road and Tennessee Williams characters on stage.

title: 50 CUBAN ADVISERS REPORTED TRAINING TROOPS IN ETHIOPIA
description: WASHINGTON, May 25The State Department said today it had received reports that about 50 Cuban military advisers had arrived in Ethiopia. In addition, the department said there were unverified reports that several hundred Cuban troops were being sent.

title: Louis W. Abrons, 89, a Builder Prominent in the 20's and 30's
description: Louis W. Abrons, a builder prominent during the 1920's and 30's, died Tuesday at Memorial Hospital, Hollywood, Fla. He was S9 years old and a resident of Golden Beach, Fla.

title: ABC, CBS to Televise Carter's News Parley
description: The CBS and ABC television net, works and their local stations, Channels 2 and 7, will provide live coverage of President Carter's news conference at 10:30 A.M. today. The conference will be rebroadcast on Channel 13 at 7 P.M.

title: Ballet: A Delectable Quartet
description: IT'S AN EVENING of pure dancing, my companion at the State Theater remarked. And so it was. By turns witty, nostalgic, tender, romantic and passionate, the New York City Ballet was doing what it does bestpure dancing. Tuesday evening featured a delectable quartet of ballets fashioned by its resident choreographers George Balanchine and Jerome Robbins.

title: On Disks: The Past Revived
description: Besides making available on disks American music being written today, Composers Recordings, Inc. (CRI) occasionally backtracks to issue American music of the past. It is a splendid

title: Ban on Shakespeare Removed by Chinese
Steak n Shake Chain To Go to Grey/North
description: Steak n Shake, which says it is the oldest of the nation's hamburger chains, is switching its S2.5 million account to Grey/ North, Chicago, from BurtonCampbell, Atlanta. Grey/North is part of Grey Advertising.

title: Albany Bill Sets Special Penalties For Violent Crimes Against Aged
description: ALBANY, May 25Bipartisan agreement was reached today on compromise legislation that would set special penalties for crimes of violence against anyone 65 years of age or older.

title: DR. ABRAHAM SEGAL, 66; AN EDUCATOR AND AUTHOR
description: Dr. Abraham Segal, who retired in 1975 as director of the education department of the Union of American Hebrew Congregationsthe organization of 720 Reform synagogues in the United States and Canadadied Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 9059 56th Avenue, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 66 years old.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, May 25 (Reuters)A Federal Trade Commission judge has ruled that an agreement between the Brunswick Corporation and the Yamaha Motor Company to build outboard boat motors is not anticompetitive, the F.T.C.said today.

title: DEMOCRATS NOMINATE DELBELLO FOR 2D TERM
description: WHITE PLAINS, May 25Alfred B DelBello, the first Democrat to be elected Westchester County Executive, was nominated for a second fouryear term at a party convention here tonight.

title: Stein Assails City Housing Agency
description: Assemblyman Andrew 3. Stein and a group of Yorkville tenant leaders charged that the city's Housing and Development Administration had allowed a landlord to let a four.block area deteriorate so that a nursinghome owner could expand his operations.

title: W. R. Grace Plans To Buy Pic N Pay
description: W. R. Grace & Company announced an agreement in principle to acquire Pic N Pay, a 348unit chain of selfservice shoe stores and leased departments, through an exchange of one share of Grace for every 2.3 shares of Pic N Pay common stock. Pic .N Pay would continue to operate under its present management.

title: Lightning Causes Five New Fires In Florida's Apalachicola Forest
description: SUMATRA, Fla., May 26 (AP)Lightning strikes ignited five new fires in Apalachicola National Forest today, diverting some of the crews that had contained a 7,000acre blaze burning since Monday.

title: South Africa Gives Only Scant Support To Votes for Blacks
description: JOHANNESBURG, May 26Support appears to be building within South Africa's ruling National Party for constitutional changes that would offer political power to the 2.4 million people of mixed race and the 700,000 Indians, but there has so far been scant highlevel backing for a proposal that the reforms be widened to include blacks living outside the rural homelandsareas set aside for blacks.

title: BONN PLANS DISPOSAL OF NUCLEAR WASTES
description: SALZBURG, AustriaWest Germany is preparing to build the world's first fully integrated fuel cycle park atop a geologic formation in which it would deposit all the most radioactive wastes generated by German nuclear plants for the next several generations.

title: Dow Up by 4.83 for 908.07 Close, But Stock Drops Outpace Gains
description: The stock market, showing its best gains in the final halfhour of trading, staged a mild rally yesterday after a fiveday selling spree that carried the Dow Jones industrial average to a 16month low.

title: Carter Defends Plan to Reduce Forces in Korea
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  President Carter, emphasizing the staunch commitment of the United States to. South Korea,, defended the Administration's plan to withdraw American ground troops there and expressed confidence today that it was strong enough to repel attack.

title: VICTIM OF KIDNAPPING IS FOUND SHOT DEAD
description: A 25yearold Ulster County man was arrested last night and charged with the kidnapping of a wealthy 30yearold woman whose body was found in a shallow grave, dead of several gunshot wounds.

title: Retail Store Sales Increase 11%
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The Department of Commerce reported today that total, retail store sales last week were about $13.76 billion, up 11 percent from the yearearlier level of $12.38 billion. Department store sales were an estimated $1.39 billion, up 16 percent from last year's $1.18 billion.

title: Fluke, Flounder, Weakfish Plentiful Off Long Island
description: AREA AFishing has not been good in this area in recent days, but a few flounder ranging from 4 to 15 pounds have been caught with smelts, clams, minnows, spearing and bloodworms. A few largesized striped bass have also been taken at the Ocean City bridge and in Barnegat Bay Inlet near jetties. Bluefish of more than 10 pounds have been caught in waters about eight miles off Seaside park and Avalon.

title: Meadowlands
description: Meadowlands Results

title: Yonkers Racing
description: Horses listed In order of post oosifions Letter designates 0113 listing

title: Lockheed Puts Payments at $38 Million
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation raised to a possible $38 million yesterday the total of bribes and other questionable payments that were made overseas to win aircraft and other contracts between 1970 and 1975. The previous figure had been at least $25 million.

title: SUGAR MEETING IN GENEVA UNABLE TO DRAFT A PACT
description: GENEVA, May 26Major sugar consumer and producer countries failed today after a sixweek effort to draft an international pact to stabilize the price and availability of the commodity.

title: Kupec Has Surgery
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 26 (AP)The quarterback for the University of North Carolina, Matt Kupeck of Syosset, L. I., underwent surgery in New York for removal of a benign cyst from hist left adrenal gland, the university announced today. He is expected to be ready to play football in the fall.

title: New Face: Joanna Gleason
description: It's the kind of rock em, sock em number that Broadway hopefuls construct for themselves in their fondest fantasies about success upon the wicked stage, and Joanna Gleason makes the most of it. A few minutes into I Love My Wife, the Cy ColemanMichael Stewart musical that is playing to appreciative crowds at the Barrymore, Miss Gleason steps demurely into the spotlight and sizzles through a remarkably torrid strip teaseremarkable in view of the fact that she removes only her hat, coat and eyeglasses.

title: Teacher Sues Over Social Security
description: A 55yearold Queens schoolteacher who voluntarily subscribed to Social Security under a contract worked out between the Federal Government and New York City 20 years ago has filed suit in Federal Court in Brooklyn to get out.

title: Carter Defends Plan to Reduce Forces in Korea
description: WASHINGTON. May 25  President Carter, emphasizing the staunch commitment of the United States to Sow) Korea, defended the Administration's plan to withdraw American ground troops there and expressed confidence today that it was strong enough to repel attack.

title: Gain in Productivity Revised to 4.7 Percent
description: WASHINGTON, May 26 (Reuters)The productivity gain in the private business sector was revised upward to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.7 percent in the first quarter from the 3.2 percent originally reported, the Labor Department said.

title: Colombia Curbs Its Currency, Cuts Coffee Export Prices
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, May 26 (UPI)The Colombian Government, unable to slow the 17 percent rate of inflation this year, today implemented a new strict foreign currency exchange policy and lowered its minimum price for coffee exports.

title: President Stresses Welfare Limit Despite Warning
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  President Carter reaffirmed today his determination not to increase Federal spending for welfare programs, despite a warning from Cabinet members that such a limitation might jeopardize politically his plan to revise the nation's welfare system.

title: Arthur Chalk, Founded the Oldest Airline
description: MIAMI, May 26 (AP)Arthur Chalk, the founder of the world's oldest airline, Chalk's International Airline Inc., died today. He was 88 years old.

title: Pennsylvania Reconsidering Wiretaps as Crime Rises
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 26The apparent flourishing of organized crime and official corruption in the state is increasing pressure on the Pennsylvania legislature to give more power, including the restoration of eavesdropping and wiretapping rights, to law enforcement agencies.

title: Plane Crash in Maine Kills3
description: PATTEN, Me., May 26 (AP)A light plane crashed today in a remote wooded area, killing all three persons aboard. The state police said that the singleengine Cessna 172, on the way from New Hampshire to Easton, went down near Black Cat Pond, about 25 miles north of Patten.

title: Advertising
description: For his United States debut as the star of a television advertising campaign James Coburn; the actor, was given the simplest script in years. In each of the three spots he delivers only two words: Schlitz Light.

title: 24Hour Police Substation Opens at Times Square
description: A new 24hour, twoman police substation in the Times Square area was heralded amid a flurry of speechmaking yesterday by a host of city officials including Mayor Beame and Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd.

title: Food Guide To Stores And Dining
description: FEW AREAS OF THE CITY offer so varied and interesting an array of high quality foods as Greenwich Villagenot the least of the considerable advantages that have kept me a resident for tile last 32 years. And though old Village hands may justifiably mourn the passing of favorites (Gatti & Ruggiero for pastry, the Eighth Street Delicatessen for pastrami and sturgeon, Mandaro's for mozzarella and the Jumble Shop for ouietiv relaxed homecooked American meals), this section remains one of our last strongholds of momandpop specialty food markets and small, pleasantly casual and individualistic restaurants whose owners are always on the premises.

title: Soybeans Are Mixed on Reports of Brazil Export Rise
description: With reports .that soybean exports by Brazil were running at twice the rile of those from the 1976 harvest futures prices of that commodity closed mixed yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Brazil is outranked as a soybean exporter only by the United States.

title: Cornell Downs St. John's With 3 Runs in 12th, 107
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 26 (AP) Cornell scored three runs in the top of the 12th inning today and defeated St. John's, 107, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Northeast regional openinground baseball game.

title: HOUSE VOTE DELAYS AND ALSO WEAKENS CURB ON AUTO FUMES
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The House of Representatives passed today a bill to amend the Clean Air Act of 1970 after first adopting a provision that would further delay and permanently weaken controls on automobile exhaust fumes that constitute a potential health hazard.

title: New York City and Major Banks Close to Accord on M.A.C. Bonds
description: New York City and its major commercial banks were reported close to agreement yesterday on an intricate legal formula clearing the way for a bank stretch in the maturity dates of Municipal Assistance Corporation bondsa step that would yield $250 million vital to Mayor Beame's proposed budget.

title: Parents/Children
description: You ask them what they do for fun, a psychiatrist who is studying persistently sad children said. And they answer: Nothing.

title: JOHN T. DAVOL
description: John T. Davol, a financial consultant, was stricken Wednesday aboard an inbound flight from London, and was pronounced dead on arrival at Kennedy International Airport. He was 34 years old and a resident of Atlanta.

title: Cards Set Back Phils, 43, With a Rally in 10th Inning
description: While the Pittsburgh Pirates breeze along in first place in the National League's Eastern Division, the battle continues between the St. Louis Cardinals and the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Notes on People
description: The New York Times/Chester Hleeins Jr.

title: GOJKO RUZICIC
description: Gojko Ruzicic, a retired professor of SerboCroatian language and literature at Columbia University, died yesterday in Jewish Memorial Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 240 Nagle Avenue.

title: family/style
description: Bloomingdale's and Revlon decided to throw a bash the other night to encourage black fashion designers. They called it The Black ExpressionA Statement of Style and it turned out successful beyond their wildest dreams.

title: Heat Defeats Polar Expedition
description: LONDON, May 26 (Reuters)A British North Pole expedition of four men and two women has withdrawn from the polar ice cap because of exceptionally hot weather after coming within 170 miles of the pole, its organizers said today. They said the expedition had to be abandoned because of the unusually early ice breakup, caused by record high temperatures for May.

title: JEAN MENARD
description: OTTAWA, May 26(AP)Jean Menard, a University of Ottawa professor ofFrench literature and author of several Frenchlanguage books and poems, died today after a brief illness. He was 47 years old.

title: Dance: Graham's Errand
description: In the mid1940's, when the world, at least the modern dance world, was jealously guarding its roles against interlopers, Martha Graham had begun to share her roles with members of her company. It was a small but significant beginning, which now has spread to other companies and positively flowered within Miss Graham's. Thus Peggy Lyman made a splendid first appearance as the central figure of Errand Into the Maze, Wednesday evening at the LuntFontanne Theater.

title: BEAN OFFERS FUNDS FOR FULL SCHOOL DAY
description: To restore a full school day in September, Mayor Beame is prepared to grant the Board of Education at least $10 million extra, an amount that is less than the board wants but more than it is likely to get from the City Council and the Board of Estimate, city officials said yesterday.

title: Build the Convention Center
description: New York City needs no adversaries out there; it grows its own. Some of them sit with great power on the Board of Estimate and estimate our city ever deeper into trouble.

title: At Home:
description: AMBON, South Moluccas, May 26Three times in the last 20 years the authorities here have sent policemen to arrest a man living in a small home on a side street.

title: Tentative Pact With Bennett May Save Briarcliff College
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 26Briarcliff College may live after all. It received a reprieve today, a few hours before the graduating class was preparing for what was expected to be the final commencement of the 75  year  old women's college.

title: People in Sports
description: Tony Dorsett and the Cowboys agreed to terms yesterday, and the Reisman Trophy winner from Pitt received the greatest money package ever given a Dallas player.

title: Two Others Accepted Towering Challenge
description: Like mountains, deserts, the sea and other tall buildings, the World Trade Center, seems to become, from time to time, irresistible to daredevils. Its twin towers have been walked across, parachuted from and, now, climbed.

title: Captors Release Dutch Children; Adults Still Held
description: ASSEN, The Netherlands, Friday, May 27South Moluccan terrorists today released all the children they had held hostage in the Boldensmilde school near here.

title: Pepsico and Pizza Hut To Start Negotiations
description: Pepsico Inc. announced it would begin negotiations with Piza Hut Inc. regarding a possible merger by means of an exchange of stock.

title: Restaurants
description: LONG DISTINGUISHED by the diversity, originality and modest prices of its restaurants, Greenwich Village has in recent years been the breeding ground for a new sort of eating place: the small, storefront caferestaurant with a limited menu of carefully turned out specialties. One of the earliest pioneers of this form, and by now the classic example, is Trattoria da Alfredo on Bank and Hudson Streets. Few proprietors of subsequent store

title: Jersey Adopts CasinoControl Bill
description: TRENTON, May 26The State Assembly completed today legislative approval of casino gambling in Atlantic City, opening the way to the first legal gaming casinos in the East before the end of the year. The Assembly passed the Casino Control Act by a rollcall vote of 43 to 26, two more votes than necessary for passage, after attempts to amend the measure failed. Governor Byrne is expected to sign the bill next Thursday in Atlantic City.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: ESMARK EARNINGS SHOW 22.8% DECLINE
description: Esmark Inc. holding company for Swift & Company, the world's largest meat packer, reported yesterday earnings declines of 22.8 percent for the second fiscal quarter and 25.3 percent for the halfyear ended with April. The lower results were attributed mainly to continued weakness of the Swift subsidiary, most other operations were well ahead of last year according to Robert W. Reneker, chairman.

title: Metropolitan Baedeker
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., a village long known for its harbor, is fast becoming a village known for its village. Centuryold homes have been restored, the oncedelayed shopping area has been revitalized, a funeral parlor has been turned into an elegant restaurant and a car dealerShip divided up into a row of fine shops and boutiques.

title: Americans End Seoul Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, May 27Under Secretary of State Philip C. Habib and Gen. George S. Brown, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, left for Japan today after three days of talks with the South Korean Government on the planned withdrawal of American ground forces.

title: MarijuanaPenalty Compromise Proposed in Albany
description: ALBANY, May 26Three Democratic Assemblymenall elected with Conservative Party endorsementsintroduced a bill today that would retain criminal penalties for possession of small amounts of marijuana but would insure that no first offender went to jail.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: BRONX

title: Canada Announces Further Cut In Its Oil Exports to the U.S.
description: OTTAWA, May 26The Canadian Government announced today a further reduction of 10 percent in exports of crude oil to the United States, effective July 1.

title: Music: Sylvia Syrns Concert
description: Sylvia Syms could scarcely have asked for anything more at her Town Hall concert on Wednesday evening. She was in excellent voicestrong, full, completely responsive to even her most gentle nuances. She had, miracle of miracles, a sound system that projected her voice cleanly, clearly and naturally. She looked gorgeously sunny and cerrulean in a loose, flowing powderblue goWn. And she had a large adoring audience that applauded eagerly at even her slightest cue.

title: Davison W. Grant Weds Barbara K. Cavanagh
description: Barbara Kirk Cavanagh and Davison Winchell Grant, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in Grace Episcopal Church. The rector, the Rev. Christopher F. Allison, performed the ceremony.

title: Screen: OneArmed Samurai
description: IF MEMORY and records serve, the work of Seiijiro Uchikawa, the directorwriter, had not surfaced here before the arrival yes terday of TangeSazen, the latest. offering in the Regency Theater's Japanese film series. More than anything else, it indicates that the prolific Nipponese movie industry is not suffering from any dearth of directors or Samurai sagas.

title: Art People
description: IT DOESN'T HAVE quite the dimensions of the Mark Rothko case, but a court battle is in progress over the ownership of paintings by the late Arnold Friedman (18721946), an artist little known to the public but much praised by leading critics.

title: Dollar Drain Laid to Illegal Aliens Estimated in the Billions Annually
description: HOUSTON, May 26Every day at post offices, telegraph offices and border crossing points throughout the United States, millions of dollars disappear from the nation's economy. The money is earned by undocumented workers, or illegal aliens, and sent home to needy families in countries around the world.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Federal Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr. has dismissed a criminal indictment against Litton Industries for allegedly filing a false claim with the Navy in May 1972 for $37 million in connection with a contract to build three nuclear submarines.

title: Tyrone Everett, Boxer, Dies of Bullet Wounds
description: Tyrone Everett, a boxing contender who had recurring dreams of a championship belt and premonitions of danger, was shot and killed yesterday in Philadelphia.

title: Art: Sculpture That's KingSize
description: O N A FINE spring afternoon one of the best places to be is the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y. You may not picnic, and you may not play games, but you can walk as you wish on hundreds of acres of spectacular country. Green hills abound; centenarian forests grow ever more majestic; deer, fox and raccoon add a fourfooted garnish.

title: About Real Estate
description: This is just crazy! said Mrs. Anne Rudell. If they don't stop this they won't have a district to represent.

title: Seales Stops Gardner In 4th, Retains Title
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, May 26 (AP)Ray Seales knocked out Tony Gardner in the fourth round last night and retained his North American middleweight boxing title. Scales controlled the fight from the opening bell, finally finishing Gardner at 2 minutes 28 seconds of the fourth round of the scheduled 15round fight. Scales also sent Gardner to the canvas in the third round, opening a cut over his right eye.

title: Around the Nation
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 26 (AP)The number of black pupils living in normally allwhite neighborhoods in the Louisville suburbs has increased 63 percent since a courtordered busing program began, according to a study issued today.

title: Bridge:
description: While a handful of experts focused their attention on the final of the Reisinger knockout team championship, 1,200 players will be looking for successes in the Eastern regional championships beginning today at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Newspaper Publishers in Baltimore Agree to Bar PriceFixing Accords
description: BALTIMORE, May 26Publishers of Baltimore's daily newspapers agreed today, in settlement of a state civil antitrust suit, to a 10year injunction against any agreement to fix retail or wholesale prices of the papers and to rebate an estimated $187,000 to subscribers in restitution for simultaneous price increases instituted in August 1975.

title: Sparks Resigns His Posts at Ailing Cook Industries
description: Cook Industries Inc., one of the Big Six commodity trading houses and a leading grain exporter, said yesterday that Willard R. Sparks, senior executive vice president and thirdranking officer of the company, had resigned. Mr. Sparks, 39 years old, also resigned as director of the company's agriproducts group.

title: Van Nostrand, Levine in Final
description: ROSLYN, L.I., May 26King Van Nostrand of Brightwaters, L.I., and Robert Levine of Mount Vernon reached the final of the Long Island men's 35year division tennis championship tonight at the Tower Tennis Club. Van Nostrand defeated George Gill of Rumson, N.J., 60, 62, and Levine beat Peter DeLamas of Rumson, 64, 6.1. 61.

title: Elkan Naumburg's Gift Plays On
description: In 1905, Central Park was a genuinely bucolic spot, boasting among other things, a flock of 70 ewes, a ram, a sheep dog named Jack and a shepherd named James Conway. That year Elkan Naumburg decided that the park would be a good place to provide New Yorkers with some free music, and he sponsored a concert by a symphony orchestra in an octagonal, pagodashape bandstand, around which the audience sat.

title: TRADING OF STOCKS ON OPTIONS BOARD IN CHICAGO PLANNED
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange announced plans yesterday to begin trading stocks in addition to its present options trading program.

title: The New York Times/Chester Merlins
description: NEW CANCER LABORATORY DEDICATED: Mayor Beatne, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Vice President Mondale at dedication here yesterday of the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center's new Schwartz laboratory building. Center plans to begin controversial genetic experiments. Page D12.

title: The Race for Governor
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, May 25Joseph A. Hoffman walked to the microphone at a dinner dance this evening and said, When I started my campaign for Governor I was 6 feet 2 inches tall.

title: Amex Elects New President
description: As expected, Robert J. Birnbaum, 49 years old, was elected president of the American Stock Exchange yesterday by Amex's board of governors. Paul Kolton, the American Exchange chairman, announced that Mr. Birnbaum would be assuming his new position immediately.

title: Fred J. Zeitz Is Dead at 81; Was Chairman of Martin's
description: Fred J. Zeitz, chairman of the board and a principal owner of Martin's, an apparel store with headquarters in Brooklyn, died yesterday at his home. He was 81 years old.

title: Climber Conquers 110Story Tower
description: Using equipment he designed and built himself and tested in secret at night, a 27yearold toymaker and mountain climber from Queens scaled the South Tower of the World Trade Center yesterday morningto the delight of thousand of pedestrians who watched his threeandahalfhour effort.

title: TEXTRON TO INVEST IN ALLIED CHEMICAL
description: Textron Inc., a conglomerate based in Providence, R. I., said yesterday it had reached a tentative understanding with Solvay et Cie. of Brussels to acquire 2.7 million shares of the Allied Chemical Corporation, which is owned by Solvay.

title: Mexico's Conservatives Regaining Strength Since Lopez Took Office
description: MEXICO CITY  Five months after President Jose L6pez Portillo took office, conservative forces in Mexico appear to have recovered much of the ground lost during the reformist administration of his predecessor, Luis Echeverria Alvarez.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Stores closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 14, unchanged for the day.

title: Spoleto Comes To Charleston
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., May 26The 20th anniversary of the famous Spoleto Festival in Italy also sees the introduction of the first Spoleto Festival in the United States. When Gian Carlo Menotti founded the Spoleto Festival, he subtitled it Festival of Two Worlds, but it remained that in name only. He always had wanted the festival to operate in the United States as well as in Italy, however, and several years ago a task force began looking around this country.

title: Broadway
description: YES, THERE ARE legitimate theaters north of 52d Street, and the newest one is in Waltham, Mass. It is the Spingold, which has been on the grounds of Brandeis University since it was built in 1962, but has never been used as a house for Broadway shows. Now, however, three impresariosNorman Stephens, Walter Pierce and Arthur MacKenzieare moving into the Spingold to book touring attractions and to produce shows of their own. Sweet Adeline. nroduced by The Goadspeed Opera House in Haddam, Conn., will come to the Spingold on June 23 and stay there until July 17, and then Shaw's Too True to Be Good, with Jean Marsh, Jack Gwillim and Katherine Houghton, will be there from July 19 through Aug. 14. Goodspeed's Hit The Deck will arrive for a week in August, and then after that The Utter Glory of Morrissey Hall will have its premiere. Sometime this fall it will be on Broadway.

title: A Bill for Bill Collectors
description: Professional bill collectors cannot, in the nature of things, expect to win popularity contests, but they are hardly required to set new records for obnoxious behavior. The excesses of some collectors are among the most common consumer complaints to the Federal Trade Commission and have deservedly attracted the attention of Congress. The House has already passed a measure designed to keep collectors within the bounds of civilized behavior, and similar legislation is now before the Senate.

title: Begin's Choice of Dayan Disrupting Coalition Talks
description: JERUSALEM, May 26  Menahem Begin's choice of Moshe Dayan to be foreign minister in a government led by Mr. Begin's Likud Party caused a disruption in coalition talks between Likud and another political party today and produced a furious reaction in Mr. Dayan's Labor Party.

title: Commodity Price Index Declines 2.9 From the WeekEarlier Level
Las Vegas Group Seeks Sites
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 26Caesars World Inc. of Los Angeles was reported today to be completing negotations to lease two Boardwalk properties for a new casino hotel. Such a purchase would be the first of Atlantic City property by owners of a Las Vegas casino hotel since Nevada adopted a law last week permit Ling companies holding Nevada casino licenses to conduct gambling businesses in other states.

title: Antiques
description: BLEECKER STREET, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, is a sevenblock stretch, 1,500 feet long, that offers more antiques shops20and a greater variety of vintage wares than anywhere else in town.

title: West German Trade Surplus Fell 47 Million to $1.24 Billion in April
description: FRANKFURT, May 26 (Reuters)West Germany released today figures that showed a continued large trade surplus last month.

title: Publishing: Prize Change
description: THE NATIONAL Book Awards program is changing hands again. After two unhappy years of marriage, the administration of the program is being divorced from the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters. Instead, the Association of American Publishers will go it alone, assuming responsibility for administration, financing and selection of the panelists who vote for the winners in poetry, fiction and major nnnfiction categories.

title: Carter Aides Question Amnesty Plan for Illegal Aliens
description: WASHINGTON, May 26The Carter Administration, which is drafting a new immigration policy, is reported to be having second thoughts about a proposal that would grant sonic form of amnesty to many of the estimated six million to eight million illegal aliens now in the United States.

title: Transcript of the Carter News Conference on Domestic and Foreign Matters
description: Good morning.

title: YOUNG ENDS HIS TRIP ON A DISSONANT NOTE
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  Andrew Young flew back today from a trip to Africa and .Britain, in the last 24 hours of which he managed to enrage the Swedes, the., Russians, the British, the Borough of Queens and almost certainly the State Department.

title: Goheen Takes His Post in India
