description: RESULTS

title: 102 Yachts Start Block Island Race
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 27A foul. a nearcollision, and a daring starboard tack maneuver that did not quite come off, were the exciting elements of the start at dusk today of the Storm Trysail Club's annual race to Block Island and back.

title: Handicapped Pupils Salute a Special Friend
description: Pupils at Public School 199, many in wheelchairs or on crutches, and all in ethnic costumes, presented a program of songs from around the world yesterday and then chatten with a new friend who made them laugh a lotthe violinist, Itzhak Perlman.

title: Girding to Battle Federal Hydra
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 It's like looking at one of those 17thcentury books about sea monsters, said W. Harrison WeIlford. You see all those marvelous shapes that you really didnt imagine existed in quite those forms.

title: Deaths
description: HEF,MANBelle. Beloved wile of Ed ward Julius, devoted mower of Int Doctors Wenn and 3C011. Deal sister of IIIIIe Hartman. services Ihe Riversice, i6 Si. & Amsieruart Ave. sun at 10:30 A.M.

title: So That the Alaskan Treasure
description: WASHINGTONAlaska's stunning fjords, majestic mountains, virgin forests, Arctic tundra and fascinating wildlife are a national treasure. But, for some, the word treasure has another meaning: Alaska also evokes the image of the raw frontiera wilderness ripe for exploitation.

title: Cherry Hill's Aid Possible
description: ATLANTIC CITY, May 27Gerard; Kauper, executive director of the Atlantic City Convention Bureau, said today thgt hotels in Cherry Hill 50 miles away might be requested to help house some of the, conventions seeking to come to the resort. in 1978 and 1979.

title: People and Business
description: Christopher IL Parrott, 34, the No. 2 man in the troubled AgriProducts division of Cook Industries Inc., Memphis, resigned yesterday. He was the second highranking vice president to leave the company in as many days. Willard R. Sparks, 39, senior executive vice president and head of the AgriProducts division, resigned Thursday.

title: FUNDING IS DROPPED IN SENATE PRIMARIES
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (UPI)The Senate Rules Committee voted today to remove primary election campaigns from a bill extending public financing to Senate elections and lowered the amount of campaign money each candidate could spend. It also voted to allow specified Senate aides to solicit campaign contributions.

title: Notes on People
description: The National Security Agency, whose secret budget is said to be the largest of any United States intelligence agency, will be headed by Vice Adm. Bobby R. Inman, the White House has announced. The N.S.A. is the intelligence organization that runs the Government's communications and code monitoring systems. Its new chief, now second in command at the Defense Intelligence Agency, will succeed Lieut. Gen. Lew Allen, who is being promoted to general and taking over the Air Force Systems Command. Admiral Inman, 46yearold Texan, is the second Navy admiral to be given a major intelligence post by President Carter. The first was Adm. Stansfield Turner, who is direcof the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Township Wins U.S. Aid

title: DUTCH PSYCHIATRISTS PRESS TALKS TO FREE 60 ADULT HOSTAGES
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, May 27A team of psychiatrists continued negotiating today with South Moluccan terrorists who have freed 105 children and a teacher from a village school but are still holding 60 hostages there and in a commuter train they seized Monday.

title: Meadowlands
description: ENTRIES

title: 44,207 Bird
description: DETROIT, May 27Mark Fidrych, The Bird of baseball and the biggest draw in the big leagues, returned to the public stage tonight as lie had left it before his operationtalking to the ball and himself, pacing around the pitcher's mound, smoothing the dirt on hands and knees, and prompting 44,207 cheering fans to raise the roof of Tiger Stadium.

title: G.M. Said to Be Studying a Halt ToDivisional Names on Engines
description: DETROIT, May 27After years of allowing its five car divisions to place their brand names on engines inside their cars, the General Motors Corporation has decided in principle to drop the practice starting with its 1978 model cars, several knowledgeable persons within the company said today.

title: OUSTER OF PODGORNY PART OF A RESHUFFLE
description: MOSCOW, May 27The unexpected ouster of President Nikolai V. Podgorny from the Communist Party's governing Politburo several days ago has been accompanied by several other enigmatic personnel shifts that suggest only that the political authority of the party chief, Leonid I. Brezhnev, is stronger than ever.

title: People in Sports
description: The best fight in boxing continue to be among the matchmakers. For example, Bob Arum of Top Rank has signed Ken Norton to fight Jimmy Young in a battle for the No. 1 contender's position in the heavyweight division. Arum _ also has signed Earnie Shavers to fight Muhammad All for the heavyweight title. But Madison Square Garden has  reportedly signed All to fight Shavers and Young's manager, Jack Levin, who would rather have his man fight the champion directly without going through Norton, says he is as confused as anyone.

title: Live Beef Cattle Futures Mixed; Old Crop Soybean Prices Plunge
description: Future prices of live beef cattle cosea mixed while those of feeder cattle finished up and those of live hogs closed mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday.

title: ExCBS News Chief Tells of Sharing Information. With C.I.A.
description: Sig Mickelson, who was president of CBS News in the 1950's, said yesterday that his organization had cooperated with the Central Intelligence Agency to the extent of sharing information under implied instructions from William S. Paley, chairman of CBS Inc.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY. MAY 27. 1977

title: ALBANY PANEL HEARS TESTIMONY ON TESTS
description: Klegislative committee looking into tne New York City school system's testing protedures heard a former school district testing and research official testify yesterday that a few months after he left his post he sold testing and evaluation materials to his former school district.

title: Starrett City Energy Plan Sought
description: Mayor Beame announced yesterday that; the city and other parties were seeking a Federal grant of $1.2 million to establish a major energyconservation program to reduce electricity use at Starrett City, in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. The grant, he said, would be used for a feasibility study and preliminary design to use methane gas from a landfill and sewagetreatment plant near the Starrett housing development.

title: Cleveland Busing Order Delayed
description: CLEVELAND, May 27 (AP)A Federal district judge today delayed a busing order scheduled to become effective as part of a city school desegregation program this fall. The judge gave school officials more time to work out a plan to avoid unnecessary disruption.

title: Fly
description: Mayor Beame yesterday accepted $1.10 to settle the city's $250,000 suit against George H. Willig, the Queens mountain climber who, on Thursday, became New York's newest folk hero by scaling the 1,350foot South Tower of the World Trade Center.

title: Markets Closed Monday
description: Banks in New York New Jersey and ConnectiCut will be closed Monday in observance of Memorial Day. All United States security and commodity exchanges will also, be closed Monday.

title: Letters: On Illegal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Homosexual Sailor Loses Fight With Navy:
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)  A Federal district judge refused today to order the Navy to reinstate a former officer who acknowleged committing homosexual acts while in the service.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, MAY 28, 1977

title: Dance: Historically Appropriate
description: Few things in ballet could be more historically appropriate than American Ballet Theater's staging a small Fokine Festival in the midst of its longestever season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Yet, as politicians (to say nothing of historians) have discovered in the past, what is historically appropriate may well he realistically risky.

title: Crangle Is Accused Of Drunken Driving
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Softening the Spills
description: Skateboarding developsand requiresbalance and coordination, and riders under 13 years old may simply lack the development necessary for trick riding. But even experts inevitably take spills, so safety equipment is essential: a helmet (the motorcycle or football variety is O.K.) will minimize head injuries; knee and elbow pads (basketball type), and a pair of ordinary gloves will do the same for sprains and scrapes.

title: Newsstand Prices of The Times Increased in Eastern Long Island
description: Beginning today, the newsstand price of The New York Times on the eastern end of Long Island is being raised to 25 cencs on weekdays. Tomorrow, the newsstand price of The Times Sunday issue will be raised to $1 in the same area.

title: New Yorkers Are on the Go For Holiday
description: Spurred by memories of a bitter winter and lured by the promise of nearperfect weather, millions of New Yorkers and their suburban neighbors took to the road yesterday for the Memorial Day weekend, the first long holiday of the summer season.

title: New Park Service Chiefs Named
description: WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP)Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus is naming two National Park Service career employees with experience in urban parks to direct the service, a spokesman said today.

title: Stan Kenton's Condition Stable
description: READING. Pa., May 27 (AP)Stan Kenton, the bandleader, remained hospitaiized in serious but stable condition today. He underwent surgery at Reading Hospital earlier this week to relieve pressure from a blood clot. Mr. Kenton fractured his skull Sunday night when he fell in the parking lot of the hotel where he and his b?nd were practicing.

title: Chicago Yields in Battle With U.S. Over Integration of Its Teachers
description: Er CHICAGO, May 27After nearly eight years of Federal pressure, the Board of Education has agreed to integrate Chicapublic school teachers in apparent compliance with. Federal guidelines.

title: Betting Resumes at BelmontWhile Strike by Clerks Continues
description: With a security force of 200 Pinkertons and policemen standing guard, ontrack wagering began yesterday at strikebound Belmont Park after four days of betless racing.

title: Officials Hopeful at New Track
description: YAPHANK, L.I., May 27Parr Meadows, which last night concluded its first full week as a quarterhorse racing plant, has not been knocking them dead at the turnstiles. Track officials, however, insist livelier times lie ahead. Despite ideal weather only 2,065 turned out for last night's regular ninerace program.

title: Pride of Carlisle Wins Again

title: ART VIEWHILTON KRAMER
description: The career of GaspardFelix Tournachon, known as Nadar, is one of those 19thcentury extravagances that never fail to hold us in thrall. Even in a period and a placeParis in the heyday of Hugo and Baudelaire and Manet and the Impressionists where genius seemed to abound and the rhythm time and energy for prodigious feats of accomplishment and no less prodigious feats of delinquency, the record of Nadar's activities is sometimes a little too crowded to be believed. And in his case, our wonder is compounded by the fact that Nadar was so nimble in skipping from one activity to another, and yet in the end was able to leave behind such a solid accomplishment.

title: Ibsen's Master Builder
description: After Brand and Peer Gynt Ibsen never again wrote any play in verse, nor, with one exception, Emperor and Galilean, a play almost totally unknown to the general public and never intended for the stage, did he aspire to the heights of worlddrama, plays of much more than contemporary scope. As Solness says of his great churches, People don't want that. So Ibsen, alive to his time the three later decades of the 19th centurylike Sol, ness, took to making homes for people to live in, practical plays, social plays: A Doll's House and the others. It cannot be said that Ibsen regretted the change, but The Master Builder gives evidence that he wished to rise above the domestic level and once again to climb the pinnacles of poetic power and universal import.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEWPAUL GOLDBERGER
description: Funhouses, with their shrinking rooms and moving walls, have always done a better job of forcing us to think about the nature of architectural space than most serious buildings do, and it is hard not to think that this was in the minds of architects Hugh Hardy, Malcolm Holzman and Norman Pfeiffer when they designed the new Brooklyn Children's Museum. For the museum, set in Brower Park in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, is a sort of learned funhousea collection of educational exhibitions housed in a wildly exuberant structure that is itself the best exhibition of all. The building is a madly active array of tubes big enough to walk through, neon lights, brightlypainted pipes, kiosks, greenhouses and bridges. It is all put together with the skill of a fine composition, but the architecture never nets in the way of the fun.

title: Trade Secrets of a Waitress

For I have been chewed out by Hartsdale residents sporting tennis whites, bossed by Scarsdale children, harassed, poked and mangled by bands of youths from various county high schools, and shunned by adults arriving to snack after a show at the Premier Theater.

The major participation and spectator sports are of the 19th Century and the 20th Century concoctions, such as Roller Derby, do not seem to make a deep dent. And It is not because the games are so good they fulfill all needs.

title: ExGovernor Denies A Kickback Remark Ascribed to Agnew

title: MUSIC VIEW HAROLD C. SCHONBERG
description: Few inventions have given as much pleasure to the human race as the phonograph, which Thomas Alva Edison invented 100 years ago. It was in July, 1877, that Edison wrote in his notebook about an experiment with diaphragm having an embossing point and held against paraffin paper moving rapidly . . . A short time laterthe exact date is unknown he scribbled out a sketch on which he wrote KruesiMake this. John Kruesi was one of Edison's mechanics. Kruesi made it. Edison put tinfoil around the cylinder, turned the crank and recited into the mouthpiece the first stanza Mary had a little lamb. The gadget worked. Said Edison, many years later: 1 was never so taken aback in my life.

title: The World's Richest Iron Mountain

Since then so much more ore has been found that geologists have had to revise their estimates up to one billion tons for this mountain alone.

title: CRIME

In addition to good writing and fluent storytelling, The Alvarez Journal had an unusual type as its heroa Chicano cop, working out of Denver, with the unlikely name of Gabriel Wager. He was smart, honest and efficient, and it is pleasant to report that Wager carries on his good work in The Farnsworth Score.

title: The Programs Might Constitute a Lesson on the Seductiveness of Power
Trade With U.S. Is Enormous
description: DHAHRAN, Saudi ArabiaThe relationship between the United States and Saudi Arabia is most often perceived in simplistic images of tankers carrying oil west and billions of precious American dollars just as surely flowing east. But fortunately for the United States, those petrodollars are not resting Saudi coffers nor are they being used to buy out Western companies, as was the popular fear a few years ago. Instead, they are, for the most part being churned back into the world economy in general and into the United States economy in particular.

Singlaub dared in a newspaper interview to criticize President Carter's plan for withdrawing troops from South Korea, he was summoned to the White House, reprimanded and relieved his command in Korea. After the House Armed Services Committee defied Mr. Carter last week by refusing to provide design funds for a smaller aircraft carrier, the President decided to go on a submarine cruise wth the man who influenced the committee to balk on the issue, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover. Such are the varied ways that dissent may expressed by the military and either tolerated or punished by civilian suneriors.

title: Amber Light on the Minibus
description: THE CASE against the minibus is not really against the minibus, but against the proliferation of small and inefficient bus trans portation systems. These purport to provide certain benefits but in reality simply waste our resources and may disrupt, and even help to dehumanize, our economic, social, shopping and recreational lives.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: From Fawcett  Publishing empires sometimes start in the most unlikely places. Consider, for example, the footlocker filled with barrackroom jokes a captain brought home with him from World War I. In 1920 ,while working on the night desk of The Minneapolis Tribune, William H. Fawcett sorted out his cache, then persuaded a printer to produce some of it as a pamphlet called Captain Billy's WhizBang. ( A whizbang was one of the smallcaliber shells that disturbed the peace of frontline soldiers during the war to make the world safe fon democracy. The jokes, considered quite risque at the time, wouldn't cause anyone's maiden aunt to blush nowadays.)

title: It's Not Unusual for Kidneys to Be Rushed From Country to Country
description: Last February, a kidney from a Russian teenager who had been killed in an automobile accident in Moscow was flown to New York HospitalCornell Medical Center where doctors transplanted it into Jose Serrano, a Brooklyn construction worker. Now, Mr. Serrano's new kidney allows him to urinate normally and there is no need for him to undergo the dialysis, or artificial kidney treatments that had been cleansing his blood of natural wastes three times a week for a year.

Now it is up to the House to adopt the improved reform.

No matter Sports that Donna is only 15 years old, an elfin 5 feet and 90 pounds, she is the United States Gymnastics Federation women's champion, a title she won in April. And with that achievement comes responsibiliy.

title: Paul's Fate

Our writers seem to be cradled in one school after another; they go from college to graduate assistantships to posts in creative writing. It's either teach or die, as most writers cannot support themselves from the bounty of their own work. So we have stirred up a generation of institutional freaks: writers who write about being teachers and writers at colleges and writing schools.

title: If the Hatch Act Is Repealed, They'll Be Able to Do More Than Just Vote
description: WASHINGTONDuring the First Congress, in 1791, the House of Representatives defeated a proposal to limit political.activity by Federal inspectors of distilled spirits because, the Annals of Congress relates this clause will muzzle the mouths of free men and take away their use of their reason. Today an echo of that argument is being sounded in the Ninetyfifth Congress by those who expect, in a few weeks, to free a considerably larger body of Federal employees from restrictions, first imposed almost 40 years ago, unon their participation in political campaigns.

title: FISHING
description: THE vast schools of bluefish that arrived off Margate and Atlantic City last week should now begin offering good action north to Sandy Hook. Along with the abundance of whiting and ling and the early start of fluke fishing, the arrival of the bluefish in force bodes well for the summer.

title: A Change in Commissioners
description: The New York State Boird of Regents has chosen Gordon M. Ambach to be the new State Education Commissioner. Mr. Ambach has been the deputy to Ewald B. Nyquist, ousted by the Regents six months ago. The choice was a surprise, inasmuch as Mr. Ambach has been closely associated with Mr. Nyquist's policies. Mr. Nyquist's ouster last fall came after a bitter fight between conservative and liberal regents. Since then, three conservative regents have been replag.ed, which may have paved the way for Mr. Ambach's selection.

description: SOMEWHERE between the fusty scientists who stay in their ivory towers and a public so eager to understand natural mysteries that it accepts answers lacking evidence stands Carl Sagan, a 42yearold professor of astronomy and space sciences at Cornell University who is also a regular on the Johnny Carson show.

title: The Region
description: A New York State law providing unemployment payments to strikers beginning in the eighth week of a walkout has been invalidated by a Federal judge, who said the law put the state on the side of strikers, encouraged long walkouts and conflicted with Federal laws. On the face of it, the decision seems to be an important victory for business and industry in New York and a setback for labor.

title: Today's Indy 500 a Race Of Stars and of Novelties
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 28It is de rigueur to rank A.J. Foyt as the favorite in the Indianapolis 500 auto race. But in the 61st running of the race tomorrow on Indianapolis Motor Speedway of Super Tex is just about swallowed up in an array of strong competitors.

title: SCRANTON AREA WINS SUMMER JOB FIGHT
description: SCRANTON, Pa., May 28Lackawanna County, a collection of 40 municipalities with a combined population of 234,000 and an unemployment rate of 10 percent, has won a concession from the Labor Department that will permit the county to give some federally funded summer jobs to youths from middleincome families.

title: CHESS ROBERT BYRNF.
description: In the case of bishops of opposite color, if the bishops are the only pieces on the board, and if there are no positional weaknesses, an additional pawn will generally not be sufficient to win. Moreover, drawn positions can arise even when the superior side has a twopawn advantage.

Lawrece Parker of Pound Ridge, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Douglas Morrill.

title: One Man's Library a Lodestone for Savants

Outside on Route 1, where gasoline stations jostle one another for business, there is the screech and bellow of traffic.

title: Ambassador Young at Home
description: We do not know whether the Russians, the Swedes, the British, the people of Queens or the diplomats Foggy Bottom can take it, but Andrew Young's almost jolly campaign to make racism a subject fit for table talk is in the highest interest of our country. His performance is also fast creating a tradition among our ambassadors to the United Nations. Like his predecessor, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Mr. Young is given to colorful speech that often obscures meaning and offends conventional diplomacy. He is, admittedly, an acquired taste whose great value shines through only if his purpose is rescued from some of his glib remarks. But he worth the effort.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Depressed by growing fears of inflationary pressure and a new increase in the prima rate by at least half of the 20 biggest banks in the country, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 31.63 points last week.

title: Memoirs for Memorial Day

Our fee was the opportunity to live like the head of a multimillion dollar corporation for five days, which proved to be very lavishly indeed. title: Mondale and Young, in Different Ways, Are Saying the Same Things
description: WASHINGTONVice President Mondale's talks in Vienna this month with South African Prime Minister John Vorster were a curious sort of success. Mr. Mondale, acting as an authoritative spokesman for the Carter Administration, may not have succeeded in doing much more than making himself clear. But, to the extent he did so, he considerably advanced United States policy in a dangerous corner of the world. As the Vice President repeatedly stressed, he did not go to Vienna to negotiate with the formidable and dour South African leader but to convey to Mr. Vorster a new policy towards Mr. Vorster's white minority government.

title: Carter Enunciated a New, but Somewhat Used, Foreign Policy

And the reason was to affix his own stamp on the Administration's approach to the rest of the world. In keeping both with graduation and earlyAdministration rhetoric, the speech was general rather than specific, thematic rather than precise. It was marred by , some inconsistencies, but nevertheless it was obviously intended as a cornerstone against which future words and deeds can be measured.

He played in the N.H.L. for 16 seasons.

title: Portable Vise, Cellar Pump and Other New Products for the Home Handyman
description: The versatile Bench Buddy vise pictured here is designed so that it can clamp onto any table, counter, bench or other flat surfaceor it can be attached to the top of a workbench or drill press base. Made of aluminum, but fitted with hardened steel jaws which are replaceable, the vise is ideal for apartment dwellers who don't have room for a regular bench and vise, as well as for home handymen who often find need for a second vise that can be carried to the job. It can either rest on top of the bench or table, or project out in front, and it can be quickly locked into 45degree, 90degree or 180degree positions. Featuring instantaneous jaw settings, the vise has a maximum opening of four inches, with jaws that are four inches wide. Made by Coastal Abrasive & Tool Company, Trumbull, Conn. 06611, it sells for about $40.

title: Personal Doings
description: THIS is the most awful book. It's so bad that it radiates a kind of embarrassing innocence, like a Victorian parlorset or anything that solemnly expresses the most ridiculous pretensions of its time. If you like fringed lampshades or 19thcentury sex manuals, you'll love Sita. The people in charge of these things should make sure to bury a copy in the New Mexico desert for the delight of future generations.

title: What's Doing in CHICAGO
description: SECOND CITYFor the first time in 21 years, Chicago is without Richard J. Daley at its helm. Democratic politicians are chipping away at each other behind the scenes with much more vehemence than they used to dare. But the nation's Second City still worksor at least that part of it most visitors see. For as former Senator Paul Douglas often said, Chicago is a town with a Queen Anne Front and a Mary Anne Back. Along the 24 miles of Chicago's East Sidethe clean and wellkept shores of Lake Michiganthere remain some of the most appealing and eyecatching urban sections in the United States. But ten blocks west, Chicago becomes a smallscale, bluecollar city of modest two and fourfamily apartments, and beyond them are some of the nation's worst slums. It is a husky, vibrant community, and still poet Carl Sandburg's City of the Big Shoulders, the nation's Freight Handler, the Tool maker, Stacker of Wheat. (The grain dealers put on one of the liveliest shows in town every weekday from 9:30 A.M. to 1:15 P.M. at the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading can be watched free from the visitors gallery.) Except for a needless and foolhardy step into the slums, a traveler will find Chicago after dark safer than many large cities and certainly more alive, along its lakefront, than most of them.

title: Two Wounded Drivers Crash On Way to Hospital, Both Die
description: ATHENS, Ga., May 28 (AP)Two persons dying of gunshot wounds lost a race to the hospital early today when their cars crashed on a northeast Georgia highway, the authorities said.

title: Legal Gambling, a Big Gamble
description: Each year, residents of New York, New Jersey and Conneticut bet almost $5 billion with their state governments, on horse races and lotteries, and, in Connecticut, on dog races and jai alai. Casino gambling soon will be available in Atlantic City, N.J. With all those enterprises, the three states now take in about. $500 million a year in gambling revenues, and Governor Byrne has estimated that the casinos in New Jersey will yield an additional $50 million a year.

title: Why Production in Region Lags
description: Although most of the country is experiencing a resurgence in singlefamily home construction, several factors appear to have combined to moderate the pickup in residential construction in the metropolitan area.

title: Ideas &
description: In Summary

title: U. of California, Hayward, Captures Track Title
description: Hie university or uantornia, Hayward, captured the Division II track and field championships of the National. Collegiate Athletic. Association at Fargo, N.D., yesterday. The University of California, Irvine, the defending champion, was second.

title: Video Portraits of AvantGarde Composers
description: Proclamations about schools and stylistic categories among composers are generally greeted with suspicion, and rightly so. The Frenchboth the artists themselves and their critical endpropagandistshave been especially eager to accompany any artistic endeavor with a broadside of polemics, sharply defining and isolating the new movement from its antecedents and surroundings. When you look at the work rationally, however, all sorts of indebtedness to the past and affinities with the become observable.

title: Bittersweet Weekend for Bill Walton and Mark Fidrych
description: Some people call it growing up.

title: POLITICS
description: THE BLUE Laws, as the restrictions on Sunday shopping have come to be known, have two distinct seasonal moves in Connecticut: down and out of sight under the heavy pressure of Christmas shopping, and up again when summer approaches and shopkeepers, like the people who work for them, begin to think once more of the traditional day of rest.

title: PROSECUTOR IN OHIO IS SUED BY A DOCTOR
description: CINCINNATI, May 28The Cincinnati Academy of Medicine has asked The Cincinnati Bar Association to investigate on behalf of Dr. Bertold Pembaur the conduct of the office of the Hamilton County Prosecutor.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: ExKent Official Dies
description: KENT, Conn., May 28 (UPI)Manuel Nadal, the athletic director emeritus of Kent School, died in a fire in his home on the campus last night. He was 80 years old.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: THEATER

title: Others Have Doubts
description: WASHINGTONIf President Carter's energy program the moral equivalent of war, his environmental message to Congress last week was the moral equivalent of guns and butter.

title: Separate Trips, Common Aims About Africa
description: Two high emissaries of the Carter Administration, Vice President Mondale and Andrew Young, chief delegate to the United Nations, have returned from extended journeys to explain Washington's Africa policy to the parties directly involved. The directness of both Mr. Mondale and Mr. Young left no doubt as to what Washington wantsa deliberate but speedy transition to black majority ruleeven if some observers suspected that Mr. Young wanted more speed and less deliberation.

title: JOSEPH GREENFIELD
description: Joseph Greenfield, who headed his own accounting firm, died Friday at Caledonian Hospital .)f a heart ailment. He was 76 years old and lived at 283 East Fifth Street in Brooklyn.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores, supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This analysis is based on reports from representative wholesalers and chains with more than 10,000 outlets in the United States.

title: A Provocative Moral Voice
description: THIS is the book Lillian Hellman's publishers refused to print unaltered, and so it comes trailing clouds of scandal. A new collection of essays by Diana Trilling ought to be read with dispassionate care, but I'm afraid that this is not the mood in which We Must March My Darlings will renerally be received. Some will be ready to denounce or defend Trilling's views of our politics and culture even before they read them; others will be hoping for a peek into the private quarrels of eminen! persons. One would regret this situation were it not so evident that she means many of these writings to be controversial, that the offenses they give are deliberate and principled assaults on what she sees as a profoundly disoriented cultural condition.

title: To Many, Having Fun Means Taking a Risk
description: LOS ANGELES, May 28When Gcorge H. Willig scaled the 110story South Tower of to World Trade Center in Nlanhattan this week, he was cheered nol only by those watching on the streets below but also by countles,s other Americans who are finding joy and excitement by risking their lives.

title: Mistra's Mysteries
description: On the floor of the Metropolis, the largest church in Mistra, a doubleheaded eagle is carved into a marble slab. This watchful bird was the symbol of the Byzantine empire, and on this spot in southern Greece, Constantine Paleaologus was crowned emperor in 1449 after the death of his brother, John. If he had looked up at the frescoes covering the ceiling of the sanctuary, Constantine would have seen a remarkable portrait of the angel of judgment, reading from a large scroll. A sad and hesitant figure, the angel seems to be saying, I hate to be the one to tell you this.

title: THOMAS ROBINS JR., COMPANY CHAIRMAN
description: Thomas Robins Jr., an industrialist who played a prominent role in the development of the syntheticrubber industry during World War II, died Thursday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 80 Years old.

title: KATHERINE VAIL MARSTERS
description: Katherine Vail Marsters, one of the founders of Bennington College in Bennington, Vt., and for many years the head of the Morris County Visiting Nurses and Tuberculosis Association in Morristown, N. .1., died Friday at Bellevue Hospital. She was 95 years old and lived at 117 East 72d Street.

title: `Our Town
description: Afew years before he died on Dec. 7,1975, I began a series of discussions with Thornton Wilder about Our Town, its relevance to contemporary society and why it was important to bring it to the attention of the American people at this time through the medium of television. Tomorrow evening at 9, when NBC presents a twohour production of the Pulitzer Prizewinning play, with a cast that includes Hal Holbrook, Ned Beatty, Barbara Bel Geddes, Sada Thompson, Ronnie Cox, Charlotte Rae, John Houseman, Glynis O'Connor and Robby Ben

title: HOUSE INTELLIGENCE UNIT EXPECTED TO BE FORMED
description: WASHINGTON, May 28Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, is expected to form a House intelligence committee soon, possibly as early as July, Congressional staff officials said today.

title: 24 French Bulldogs Set For Show. in Plainfield
description: Around the turn of the century, French bulldogs were the canine darlings of the aristocracy, and it wasn't unusual to find 50 to 100 at show. Maids even carried them on velvet pillows into the show area and

title: Albany Examiner Approves Nuclear Power Plant for Lake Ontario
description: ALBANY, May 28Approval for a $1.3 billion nuclearpower plant to be built at Sterling, N.Y., on the shores of Lake Ontario, has been recommended by an examiner for the State Board of Electric Generating Siting and the Environment.

title: Bergen's Pro Arte Chorale
description: THE Bergen Countybased Pro Arte Chorale will round out its 13th season Friday evening, when it will fill Ridgewood's Our Lady of Mount Cannel Church with the music of Handel and Haydn.

title: Jan Attwood Becomes Bride Of R.S. du Pont
description: Jan Attwood and Richard S. du Pont were married yesterday on Block Island, R. I., at the summer home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Attwood, also of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Anthony G. Pappas of the Harbor Baptist Church on Block Island performed the ceremony.

title: Carter's Extended Family Puts a Southern Tradition to Work
description: WASHINGTON, May 28When Chip Carter was 12 years old and his brother Jack was 16, they would speed across the flat, baked landscape of southern Georgia in a car loaded down with campaign posters. Their father, Jimmy Carter, would be at the wheel.

title: Booksellers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 28This year's gathering of the American Booksellers Assocation differs markedly from previous meetings. It is being referred to as the first Pacific A. B. A. for reasons that reach beyond its locale beside the Golden (lath Bridge.

title: Franais for Being Cartesian?
description: too willing to sell without a word spoken.

title: Pekingese Is Judged Best Of 1,530 Monmouth Entries
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., May 28Kay Jeffords of New York enjoyed sidebyside successes today at the Monmouth County Kennel Club's all breed show at Wolf Hill Farm and the neighboring Monmouth Park race track. Her Pekingese, Ch. Quilkin The Stringman walked off with the top award at the dog show over 1,529 competitors and her horse, Donald Young, ran second in the sixth race at Monmouth.

title: It's More Than Hooky
description: ROBERT L. BONN, in his article The Crime of Truancy: Who's Responsible? [Opinion Page, April 3], poses this question and then goes about telling us of the process of bringing the absentee child before the courts. He suggests that possibly we should not extend these efforts and finally states that perhaps we should not compel youths who do not want to be in school to attend.

title: Letters
description: jailhouse blues

title: Saccharin: Time to Stop?
description: AMERICANS are now engaged in a loud protest over the impending ban on saccharin, the sole remaining artificial sweetener on the market. It is puzzling to note that, upon the publication of experiments indicating that large amounts of saccharin cause bladder cancer among rats, our major reaction is to hoard and consume as much of the sweetener as possible. Has anyone actually stopped using this food ingredient since its harmful effects were revealed?

title: Bonnie Maynard Married to Robert Stapleton
description: Bonnie S, Maynard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, Horace S. Maynard 3d of Troy, Mich., and Robert J. Stapleton were married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church in Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Edward E. Craxton performed the ceremony.

title: Owens Schoolboy Mark For Ohio Is Broken
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 28 (AP)The 34yearold Ohio state high school longjump record of Jesse Owens was wiped out today by a senior from Middletown, Ohio.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Not surprisingly, consumers have sharply protested what they see as an unreasonable application of Government authority to force accepted products like saccharin and others from the marketplace without due consideration of benefits as well as risks.

title: Music: Solomon &
description: An obvious and often cited distinction between opera and other forms of musical theater is that in opera the music is never interrupted by stretches of spoken dialogue. By a second, more subtle criterion, in a successful opera the music must embrace and amplify the drama at critical points of conflict and transitionthere must, in other words, be more than a linked succession of static pieces in which exciting twists of the plot fall where the musical fabric is thinnest and least supportive.

title: Bruce Bliven, 87, Former Editor Of New Republic, Dies at Stanford
description: Bruce Bliven, former editor of The New Republic, author and champion of liberalism, died Friday at the Stanford Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 87 years old and had been recovering from a broken hip suffered in a fall on the lawn of his home on the Stanford University campus..

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: THEY won't be strutting about in Butler tomorrow, Memorial Day, but that doesn't bother the town. As a matter of fact, Butler would just as soon not have just another Memorial Day parade, so it is saving its volunteer fire companies, the promise of a guest appearance by the Goodyear blimp, the oldest fireman in the State of New Jersey and, of course, the town's Wooden Fireman for next Sunday, when Butler's will be the only parade around here.

title: Beame Cabinet Appears United For Campaign
description: To his supporters, one of Mayor Beanie's strong suits in his reelection campaign is the management team he has recruited to City Hall in the last year and a half. To his critics, the same team serves as a symbol of Mr.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE EMPEROR OF ICECREAM, by Brian Moore. (Penguin, $1.95.) The comingofage of a gangling young buck named Gavin Burke under the stress of the German bombardment of Belfast during World War II. This 1965 novel, now returned to print, is probably Brian Moore's best after The Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne (Little, Brown, $2.25). It is remarkable for the skill with which it combines youthful subject matter and mature craftsmanship.

title: Christine Cort Shattuck Wed to Richaxd Stenhuis
description: At the Landgrove (Vt.) Community Church yesterday, Christina Cort Shattuck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Francis Shattuck Jr. of Darien, Conn., and Landgrove, was married to Richard Hendrik Stenhuis of Zwolle, the Netherlands. He is the son of Mrs. H. StenhuisBleeker and the late Jan Stenhuis of Groningen, the Netherlands. The Rev. Edward 0. Miller, former rector of St. George's Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: London Daily Mail Sued for Libel
description: LONDON, May 28 (AP)Britain's Industry Secretary, Elie Varley, says he is suing The London Daily Mail and its editor, David English, for libel following the newspaper's allegations about Governmentsanctioned bribery by the staterun British Leyland car company. A Leyland executive, Graham Barton, the source of the newspaper's charges, is being held by police on charges he forged a letter implying official support of bribes to win foreign contracts for automaker.

title: ONE CRITIC'S FICTION
description: Matthiessen, Innes, Jones

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW GENETHORNTON
description: The pictures of lovely ladies in elegant dress that the fashion photographer Deborah Turbeville currently showing at the Sonnabend Gallery (420 West Broadway, through June 11) are not the kind that mother used to admire in Vogue.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: HEAVYDUTY, industrialtype vacuum cleaners have become increasingly popular additions to many home work shops, especially since some are quite reasonable in price.

title: The Schools: Worse Every Year
description: THE PUBLIC schools of Westchester are often praised as the finest in the country. Yet, the Pupil Evaluation Performance test given by the New York State Education Department shows more than 17 percent of the students are below average in reading and math, not only in cities such as Yonkers, New Rochelle and White Plains, but also in good communities such as Bedford, Somers and North Salem.

title: Coming of Age in the Sixties
description: THE most characteristic literature of our agewhether it bills itself as fiction, faction, nonfiction or even poetryconsists of a kind of hearing witness: bearing witness to history seen through the prism of personal experience, to personality formed in the crucible of society. We have become so hooked on this kind of personal testimony that we tend to mistrust fantasy, fairy tale and myth, and to ask of our writers: Did you do it? Were you really there? As if only a yes answer could validate their books, could make them worth reading.

title: East Meets West, With Some Fancy Footwork
description: OTTAWAAn army of Chinese is advancing on foot through Canada, taking one meal a day from the Occident and two from the Orient, and washing them down with CocaCola, Fanta, Tsingtao beer, jasminescented tea and gallons of hot water.

title: 4 Campers Die in Plane Crash
description: EVANSVILLE, Wis., May 28 (UPI)Four more returning from a camping trip in Minnesota were killed yesterday in the crash of their small plane in a cornfield. They were identified as Richlard Hepler, 39 years old, Jerry Roberts, :34. and John Harris, 65, all of Charleston. W. Va., and Raymond Trip, of Ashland, Ky.

title: Negative Climate for School Equity
description: WE ARE ENTERING a critical period for public education in Connecticut. On April 18, the Connecticut Supreme Court, by a vote of 4 to 1, ruled that the state's system of financing public education was unconstitutional.

title: Pound Ridge And Its Inventor
description: HIRAM HALLE was a wealthy bachelor, an inventor and businessman ; Pound Ridge was a deteriorating farming community. They met in 1928 and their lives became inextricably interwoven. The man is dead now, but the place lives on as the town that Halle built.

title: Indian Brawl Is Now Just Fun
description: HEMPSTEAD TOM POSTELL cradled the ball with his stick in his right hand, hiding it behind his body from the defenseman as he ran in back of the opposing team's goal. Ball, back, left, shouted the opposing goalkeeper, telling his defense how the play was evolving. Man coming around . . get him out of there! Postell fired the ball into the crease area in front of the goal.

title: Emilie Ornstein Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Franklin H. Ornstein of Lido Beach, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Emilie Ornstein, to Bruce Watzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Watzman of Pittsburgh,

title: Bill Would Widen Prepaid Legal Aid
description: THERE are, according to prevailing expert opinion, two economic classes reasonably assured of decent legal representation: The rich and the Door.

title: TV VIEW
description: in the bizarre arena of show business and sports, the undisputed crown for hypocrisy belongs to boxing. The fight business has always attracted colorful characters. In the context of a Damon Runyon story, they produce indulgent chuckles. During the periodic scandals that infect the business, they become objects moral indignation. The latest round involves ABC Sports and something called the United States Boxing Championships, tournament promoted by Don King, who is nothing if not colorful. A former convict and numbers racketeer, he worked himself into some major heavyweight fights, several starring Muhammed Ali, and within a couple of years became boxing's most successful promotor. Sporting heavy gold jewelry  and the biggest cigars this side of Fidel Castro, King was picked up by the pressprint and electronicas a flamboyant personality worth a slew of feature stories. Even in boxing, success assures surface respectability.

title: Au Revoir to a Pupil Exchange
description: IT was the last day of the student exchange program between Wheatley High School in Old Westbury and its French counterpart, the Lycee Victor Duruy in Paris. Of course there was the obligatory farewell party at Wheatley. School officials and class officers talked about the value of such programs, the French students were presented with Wheatley Tshirts, and a rock band played.

title: The ShoreExperts Forecast Cleaner Water
description: ABOUT 10 days ago, the research ship Xiphias returned to her port at Sandy Hook from a cruise south of Ambrose Light with another bit of encouring news, for marine biologists and scientists apprehengive about another huge algae bloom off the New Jersey Shore this summer.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONIn the 15th century people were troubled by the lack of conformity between movement in the heavens and Ptolemy's Earthcentered model of the universe.

title: News Summary
description: Dutch officials are growing increasingly concerned about the health of the remaining hostages being held by South Moluccan extremists. Some of the 106 schoolchildren who were released when an infection swept through their school were said to have symptoms of meningitis. 7A .pediatrician said that whatever the disease was, it was, still spreading. The South Moluccan captors . who remained in the school with four teachers after the children's release asked for antibiotics. [1:56.]

title: My Day in a Police Lineup
description: WE are at the 23d Police Precinct house, 164 East 102d Street in Manhattan, for a community meeting. The teama group of high school students and teachers from the subutbs that is studying the pleasures and problems of city lifehas assembled to cover the evening's proceedings.

title: An Alternative Voice Is Changing
description: THE University of Bridgeport has reversed its initial decision to abolish its popular FM radio station, WPKN, and turn over the license to a group wanting to form the first National Public Radio affiliate in the state.

title: Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 28Back in the Boston suburbs 15 years ago. Richie Hebner and Skip Lockwood were the stars of their Little League teams. Even then, he threw hard, Hebner recalled.

description: ART

title: Chapter Four
description: The concluding acts in the long legal drama produced by the Watergate scandal have now been played. Three of the main characters, John N. Mitchell, H. R. Haldeman and John Ehrlichman, have lost the appeal of their convictions; the special prosecutor's office has decided to close; and the central figure, former President Richard M. Nixon, has given his explanation of the circumstances surrounding his acceptance of a pardon.

title: Miss Tang, Pharmacist, Wed To William Loh, Researcher
description: The couple are 1976 graduates or the University of Michigan, from which Mr. Loh also received an M.S. degree.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE UNITED STATES registered a record trade deficit in April, the Commerce Department reported. Imports totaled $12,6 billion and exports $10 billion. Oil imports alone came to $3.68 billion, down $407.8 million from March. . . . Meanwhile, West Germany reported a trade surplus of $1.25 billion in April.... Citibank raised its prime lending rate from 6 percent to 6 percent, and Chase Manhattan Bank followed suit. Many other large banks held at 6 percent, however.

description: They have always been the happy warriors of sportsmiling, wideeyed, casual. They talked of their art in terms of joy, not torture, and made friends wherever they comoeted.

title: Summaries of Catholic High School Title Track Meet
THEATER
description: THE Hartford Stage Company's production of George Bernard Shaw's Candida, which runs through June 12, is an historic one. It marks the end of the H.S.C.'s 14season, 88play run in a drugstore warehouse. A few blocks away on Church Street the new theaterlong wanted, long awaitedis already rising.

title: FISHING
description: BIG striped bass moving north from the Chesapeake Bay hit off Montauk a few days ago and should offer fine action now. Hudson River bass, fanning eastward along the North Shore; also should provide good catches for experienced fishermen.

title: Journalism Weds Fiction in Washington
description: NO BOOK should be judged by its cover; some not even by their opening chapters. The first chapter of Playing for Keeps in Washington is a long and gossipy account of life The Washington Post, less likely to irritate intrigue Katherine Graham than to make her shrug. Go on to chapter two, though, because Laurence Learner turns out to be a quite remarkable writer. What he has done is to marry journalism with the short story and, stylistically at least, the marriage works. Learner's research Is extensive, his characters

title: The Blue Collars: 62,000 Strong
description: IT'S not all whitecollar executives rushing for commuter trains to New York City. Nor is it all garden clubs and houses with manicured towns. Westchester is also a manufacturing community, with 62,000 hourlyv,iatrie employees working in a variety of factories at skilled and unskilled jobs, darning from the minimum wage up to 17 or &ft an hour. Some people think you have to be Lich to live in Westchester, that you've got to own a plantation with horses, Says Frank Pirone, a section manager fpr Mount Vernon's Kulka Electric Corporation, makers of electrical equipMent.

title: A New Head for the Gun Lobby
description: A leadership shootout in the National Rine ASSOClatinn has shaken one of the country's more effective lobbying organizations. In an internal political upheaval, many officials of the association, which has staunchly opposed gun control laws, were replaced by members of a dissident faction that advocates even stronger opposition. The dissidents suceeded in electing Lloyd Mustin, a retired Navy admiral, as president, and Harlon B. Carter, a retired Immigration Service official, as executive vice president, and in capturing the association's other top offices. The organization Is generally credited with having obstructed several attempts recent years to enact stricter Federal gun control laws, primarily by mobilizing constituents of key Congressmen write letters and call in person to express opposition. The dissidents, however, contended that association officials were relaxing their vigilance. At the convention last week, the dissidents asserted that the officials had interfered with the antigun control activities of the association's lobbying

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: ACTORS CAFETHEATER, 263 Central Avenue, East OrangeEndgame. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M. (through June 18). $3.90$5.50; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90 ; group rates. (201) 6751881.

title: European filmmakers are able to explore childhood successfully while Americans deal largely in distortions. (Vincent Canby)
FOOD
description: French Meals to Take Home

title: SUNY Picks a Music Man
description: THE appointment last week of Michael P. Hammond, dean of music and acting dean of dance at the New York State University College at Purchase, as the college's second president brings to the helm a man who has been a student of Ravi Shankar, a conductor of symphonies and choirs, a researcher in neuroanatomy, a philosopher, a resident on a Menominee Indian reservation, a man who by his description has a voracious appetite for learning.

title: H.U.D.Will Accept Unmarried Couples For Public Housing
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP)The Government is opening public housing to unmarried couples living together and to homosexual couples if they can show stable family relationship.

title: Writers to Honor Rozelle
description: Pete Rozelle, a former program editor of the Los Angeles Rams, will be honored by the New York chapter of the Professional Football Writers Association at its annual dinner in New York June 6 at the Americana Hotel.

title: Wood, Field &
description: The proposed Federal regulations that would lower the tolerances of polychlorinated biphenyls (P.C.B.'s) permitted in foods involved in interstate commerce would clearly hurt the commercial fishing industry.

title: Carla Hall Sets Bridal for July
description: Carla Hall and BenAmi Friedman of New York plan to be married July 4 in Greenwich, Conn., where Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hall of Greenwich, parents of the bridetobe, have announced the enffaaement.

title: Passport Chief, 72, Told to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, May 28 (UPI)Frances G. Knight, the controversial head of the United States Passport Office for 22 years, has been told by her State Department superiors that she must retire on July 31, it was disclosed today.

title: Notes: New Stadiums, Forts, Ghost Towns
description: America's Bicentennial year has left a concretein both senses of the word legacy. According to the United States Travel Service, which recently compiled a list of projects completed in 1976, there are at least 28 new major tourist attractions in the country, ranging from the National Air and Space Museum of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C., to restored ghost towns and newly built sports complexes.

title: Terror in The Netherlands
description: Once again, the desperate ambitions of the movement seeking independence from Indonesia for the South Moluccan Islands have intruded violently on the normally tranquil countryside of the Netherlands. South Moluccan terrorists seized a Dutch elementary school and hijacked a train, along with 161 hostages, to try to force the Dutch Government to help them in their struggle. The fact that there were many children among the hostages, even though they were later released, added to growing Dutch anger with the Moluccans.

title: Lefkowitz Aide Pleads Guilty
description: Vera Bocco, the former personal secretary to Louis Lefkowitz, the New York State Attorney General, has pleaded guilty to perjury in connection with a grand jury investigation of Mr. Lefkowitz's office. She has agreed to cooperate with the Manhattan District Attorney in the continuing investigation, which centers on allegations that members of Mr. Lefkowitz's staff promised consultant work to accountants who contributed to Mr. Lefkowitz's 1970 and 1974 reelection campaigns. Two other members of Mr. Lefkowitz's staff have been indicted.

title: Young Guides: The New Sleepy Hollow Legends
description: PATTY CAPPAZELLI peers into the oven of the woodburning stove to check the progress of her apple turnovers. She is wearing a simple wool houseservant's dress and a lace cap. But some days she dons the elegant hoop skirt and a tight bodice with bone stays of a proper 24yearold woman of the 19th century. As an interpreterguide at Sunnyside, the Hudson River home of Washington Irving in Tarrytown, Miss Cappazelli combines a gracious romanticism and makebelieve with the hard work of transforming history into something more than a collect ion of lovely objects.

title: Crumbling Statues of Ancient Kings Put on Sale by British Government
description: LONDON (AP)St. George minus a hand and part of his dragon, a headless Saxon king and 17 other crumbling stone figures from the British Houses of Parliament are on sale.

title: Liz Ducas, a Teacher, Sets Bridal for Aug. 20
description: Jean Weir Ducas of Pawling, N. Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Ann Ducas, to Simon Bonham of London, son of Sir Antony and Lady Bonhani of Citencester. England.

title: SAME AIDES BUOYED BY A U.S. TAX RULING
description: A major roadblock in New York City.'s plan to pay off $1 billion in debts has been removed, city officials say, by Federal tax ruling that is expected to permit the city to sell more than $100 million worth of its housing mortgages.

title: Tiger Fans Hail Loser
description: DETROIT, May 28Baseball's love affair with The Bird was hotter than ever today. But for Mark Fidrych, welcomed back by 44,207 cheering fans and once more the man of the hour, this was a bittersweet weekend: The Detroit Tigers made him sell his favorite motorcycle.

title: Investors Turning a Profit in the Housing Market
description: For most people a house is a home. But for a growing number a house has become a lucrative form of investment or hedge against inflation, particularly in recent years.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: JOAN LEE FAUST

title: BRIDGE ALAN TRUSCOTT
description: One of the most intriguing mysteries in the world of international bridge for many years past has been the status of bridge in Russia. In sharp contrast to Poland, where bridge has a mass following, Russian officialdom actively discourages it, a surprising attitude for a country that has chess as its national game.

title: AGREEMENT REACHED TO ISSUE $250 MILLION OF NEW M.A.C. BONDS
description: An agreement has been reached between New York City, the Municipal Assistance Corporation and the city's major municipal unions for a new $250 million public offering of M.A.C. bonds next month.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: BEGIN DEFERS ACTION ON DAYAN NOMINATION
description: JERUSALEM, May 29Menahem Begin thwarted a potential revolt in the Likud bloc today over his choice of Moshe Dayan as Foreign Minister. At the same time, Mr. Begin temporarily deferred action on the nomination of Mr. Dayan, whom he still supports, in an effort to placate a new political party that Likud hopes will help it form a broadbased majority coalition government.

title: Survivor Says Victims Were Caught Because the Flames Spread Rapidly
description: SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 29Ralph Graves believes he is alive and well today because he agreed to exchange tables last night in the cabaret at the Beverly Hills Supper Club.

title: Proxmire Suggests Eliminating Allowances for Top Officers
description: WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, proposed today that personal allowances for highranking generals and admirals be eliminated.

title: Dark Is Padres' Pilot
description: SAN DIEGO, May 29 (UPI)Alvin Dark was named today to pilot the San Diego Padres, who dismissed John McNamara last night.

title: Shanghai Ballet, in Toronto, Offers Choreography Adapted to Ideology
description: TORONTO, May 28Yes, it is ballet, but so different, ideologically and in some ways even technically, from our own that perhaps we should find a new name for it. I am referring, almost of course, to the performances of the Shanghai Ballet, which closed its Toronto season at the O'Keefe Center tonight with the second of two performances of a variety program. The remainder of the week's engagement had been devoted to what is described as a modern revolutionary dance drama and is called The WhiteHaired Girl.

title: Letters: On Carter's Energy Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: HolidayCrowd Bookings Sweep Atlantic City as Weather Cools
description: As cool weather took over yesterday from steamy heat, New Jerseyans mlocked to countryside and shore and to Memorial Day weekend events.

title: Bronx and Brooklyn Gain Fastest In Survey of Per Capita Income
description: The per capita income of the Bronx and Brooklyn appears to be catching up toalthough it is still a long way behind that of the rest of New York City and New York State.

title: Manuel D. Nadal, Was Director Of Athletics at the Kent School
description: Manuel Davett Nadal, athletic director emeritus and assistant to the dean of the Kent School for Boys in Kent, Conn., died Friday in a fire that engulfed his home on the campus. He was 80 years old.

title: AirQualityMonitoring System For New York Called Unhealthy
description: The oneword description of the day's air quality in New York Citygood, acceptable, unacceptable or unhealthyis not as reliable as it used to be. The monitoring system that is the basis of those forecasts, once called the best in the country, has deteriorated sharply.

title: New Product of General Foods: The Physically Fit Employee
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y.  Sweat rolls down the face of Alex Merolli, a 30yearold employee in the productevaluation department at the General Foods Corporation. The morning is rising into 80degree temperatures as Mr. Merolli dashes off through the underbrush to a sign reading, SIDE VAULT OVER BAR, THEN RETURN UNDERNEATH.

title: Growth of Debt and G.N.P. Both of Concern to Burns
description: When the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries sent the price of oil skyrocketing in 197374, the oilproducing states replaced the major industrial countries, led by the United States, as the principal suppliers of international capital. The OPEC nations had a cumulative surplus on current account of $11 billion during the three years of 197073. As the accompanying chart shows, that surplus soared to $142 billion in 1976. And according to projections by the economists at Citibank, the OPEC surplus will reach $270 billion in 1985. Three small Arab countriesSaudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirateswill by then have a cumulative hoard of investable capital totaling $320 billion, a sum that boggles the mind.

title: Emergency Services in U.S. Found Uneven
description: By the end of this holiday weekend, ambulances will have been called upon to rescue some 20,000 persons seriously injured in motor vehicle accidents and another 40,000 who suffered other urgent, possibly lifethreatening injuries or illnesses.

title: Couple, to Be New Caretakers for L.I. Birthplace Of Walt Whitman, Know Their Gardens and Poetry
description: WEST HILLS, L.I, May 29A horticulturist and a librarian will soon move into the birthplace of Walt Whitman here to serve as the caretakers of the landmark farmhouse.

title: Goddard Lieberson, Who Fostered LP's at Columbia Records, Dies
description: Goddard Lieberson, president of Columbia Records for 19 years, who introduced longplaying records to the American public, died of cancer early yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 66 years old.

title: Bridge
description: After a week of play that began with 67 teams, the Reisinger knockout team championship ended in the early hours of Saturday morning in a victory for team led by Alan Greenberg of New York. With Peter Weichsel, Alan Sontag, Jim Cayne and Matt Granovetter, Greenberg's team won the 64deal final by 39 international match points.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: A Victim, Clinically Dead, Is Revived by Paramedics From a New York Hospital
description: One person saved by skilled ambulance attendants was a New Yorker who collapsed in the 10th floor hallway of the Municipal Building. When the paramedic team from the BeekmanDowntown Hospital, one of four such teams in New York City, arrived, a doctor told them, Stop hurrying, the man is dead. He has no pulse.

title: 2 Comedians Credited With Calming Crowd
description: SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 29 (UPI)A survivor of the fire in the Beverly Hills Supper Club today credited Jim Teeter and Jim McDonald, comedians, with saving lots of lives, including my own, by staying on stage when the audience began to panic.

title: NorthSouth Talks Nearing an End
description: PARIS, May 29Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance arrived here today in a bid to improve relations between the rich and poor nations of the world by successfully winding up the 18month Conference on International Economic Cooperation, informally referred to as the northSmith talks.

title: Susan Frier Is Married To Greg Danilow, Lawyer
description: Susan Frier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Frier of Woodmere, L.I., was married at the Harmonie Club yesterday to Greg Danilow, son of Mrs. Norman W. Lipshie and Paul Danilow, both of New York. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony.

title: Turks Barred at St. Sophia's
description: ISTANBUL, May 29 (AP)The Turkish police stopped an attempt today by about 10,000 Moslems to hold prayer services in the sixthcentury Byzantine Church of St. Sophia. The Moslems were demanding that the church building, now a museum, be turned into a mosque. St. Sophia was converted to a mosque when Istanbul, then Constantinople, was captured by the Ottoman Turks in 1453. It was converted to a museum in 1934.

title: Vernon LeGrand Is Sought in Kidnapping
description: Two women were arrested yesterday and charged in the abduction, beating and imprisonment of a woman whom the police found in their apartment. The police said the woman told them she had been seized outside her Brooklyn home early yesterday by Vernon LeGrand, the son of selfstyled Bishop DeVernon LeGrand.

title: Memorial Day in Stony Creek, Conn.
description: GUILFORD, Conn.  Last year, in time for the Bicentennial, the men of Rescue Fire Company 5 of Stony Creek, Conn., published a small miscellany, in part to celebrate their volunteer fire company's 75th anniversary and partly to raise funds for a new fire house. The booklet contained this historical anecdote which haunts me:

title: Sandra Elaine Mayerson Bride of Scott J. Burns
description: Sandra Elaine Mayerson, a lawyer with the Washington National Corporation, a holding company in Evanston, Ill., and Scott Jeffrey Burns of Northbrook, Ill., a financial analyst with the First Savings Corporation, a whollyowned subsidary of the First Federal Savings & Loan, were married yesterday.

title: Twins Conquer Orioles, 32, as Weaver Orders Wrong Man Walked in Rally
description: Because it was Sunday and because they got some essential help from Manager Earl Weaver of Baltimore and his left fielder, Pat Kelly, the Minnesota, Twins were able to beat the Orioles, 32, yesterday. Minnesota increased its lead in the American League West to three games over the Chicago White Sox. who lost to the Yankees, 52.

title: Miss Spuzich Cards 67201 To Capture Harrisburg Golf
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., May 29 (UPI)Sandra Spuzich shot a final round of 67 for a 201 today to come within one shot of the 54hole record on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour and win the $50,000 Ladies Keysione open. Her earlier rounds were 68 and 66.

title: Colleges Study Plan to Make Grades More Meaningful
description: BERKELEY, Calif, May 29The grades students receive, like the dollars they spend, have gone down in value in recent years, prompting college and university administrators to search for ways to halt what has come to be known as grade inflation.

title: Five Ballets, Two Companies, Several Debuts
description: The variety and breadth within the classical ballet idiom were demonstrated with no trouble at all Saturday, In the evening at the New York State Theater, that range was visible with the New York City Ballet in two contrasting works by George Balanchine: Serenade and Who Cares? In the afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, the American Ballet Theater presented three ballets by Michel Fokine, Both programs featured several debuts.

title: MEMORIAL DAY
description: Today is Memorial Day. Schools, banks, securities and commodities exchanges will be closed and there will be no refuse collections or regular postal deliveries. Subway, bus and commuter lines will operate on holiday schedules with half fares in effect, and Sunday parking rules will pertain.

title: College Results
description: BASEBALL

title: 160 DEAD IN KENTUCKY CLUB FIRE, MORE VICTIMS SOUGHT IN RUBBLE; THOUSANDS ESCAPE FLASH BLAZE
description: SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 29  A fastspreading fire, pouring heavy, blinding smoke throughout one of the largest nightclubs in the Middle West, killed at least 160 persons last night and injured 130. Fire officials, whose efforts to reclaim bodies from the debris were interrupted by rain late today, expressed fear that the toll could go considerably higher.

title: Mets' Box Score
description: METS (N.)

title: Dave Anderson
description: INDIANAPOLIS, May 29And wouldn't you know that in full view of many of the 300,000 spectators at the Indianapolis 500 today, the lady took a bath. But it wasn't a bubble bath. And it wasn't even a perfumed bath. Not for this lady. Janet Guthrie, the first womn driver in the world's most famous auto race, was sitting patiently in her white and green car as her pit crew tinkered with the motor that sputtered through only 27 laps. And there, on her second of eight pit stops she took a bath. In the stifling heat the fuel mixture of alcohol and methanol expanded and spilled out into the bucket seat where she was. The fuel seeped through her blueandwhite flameproof suit and into her skin. That type of bath isn't advertised in the women's magazines. Her skin was burning but she sat there stoically while one of her pit crew poured water over her to dilute the fuel, Janet Guthrie had that diluted fuel on her for almost two hours but she never even twitched. And that's the memory all those around her today will cherish. The lady belonged on the track.

title: Holiday Crowds Find Parades, Carnivals, Cool Weather
description: As cool weather took over yesterday from steamy heat, New Yorkers and their neighbors flocked to countryside and shore and to Memorial Day weekend events.

title: Cosmos Lose in Beckenbauer Debut, 42
description: TAMPA, Fla., May 29The Tampa Bay Rowdies spoiled Franz Beckenbauer's United States debut today, and from now on this city is likely to be known more for its soccer than for its cigars.

title: Horse Shows
description: AT DEVON. A.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in yesterday's Times incorrectly stated that the one issue not discussed in negotiations for a new Panama Canal treaty was the role the United States would play In the defense of the canal after the treaty expires. The issue that has not been discussed is the compensation the United States will pay Panama for use of the canal during the period of transition of control.

title: Track and Field
description: AT ST. JOHN'S METROPOLITAN A.A.U. Track Events

title: Mails Losing Package Business
description: WASHINGTON, May 29The delivery of the nation's packages has changed dramatically in recent years and appears headed for even bigger changes.

title: Let the Day Be Marked
description: Memorial Day was established to honor the Union dead in the Civil War whose graves, as Robert Lowell has written, are quilted by the frayed flags of the Grand Army of the Republic. Without a few speeches, parades or words in the newspapers, the occasion would hardly be remarked nor its cause remembered. In a sense, forgetfulness is a tribute to the present: A son of the Confederacy is currently occupying the White House and most Americans have forgotten the sectional differences over the issue of race that brought them to the bloodiest war this nation has ever fought.

title: Bel Canto Opera Presents Sweethearts by Herbert
description: The light operas of Victor Herbert seem to be enjoying a new lease on life at the Bel Canto Opera. Last May the company revived Babette, and for the last two weekends the composer's more familiar Sweethearts delighted audiences in a modest but thoroughly enjoyable production in the auditorium of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church at 31st Street.

title: Chess:
description: By the time the 10th game of the quarterfinal candidate's match between Lajos Portisch of Hungary and Bent Larsen of Denmark came up, Larsen had every reason to be disheartened. Victory in the series would go to the player who took the majority of points out of 12 games and the score stood at 35 against him.

title: Blazers' Box Score
description: Technical foulsPhiladelphia coach Shue.

title: Egypt Urgently Seeking New Arms
description: CAIROEgypt's armed forces, the most important Arab factor in the Middle Eastern military equation, are desperately seeking to plug the holes in their armament left by the virtual cutoff of Soviet supplies.

title: The Gamble in New Jersey
description: The wheels of chance are about to turn in Atlantic City. New Jersey's State Legislature has now framed, passed, and sent to Governor Byrne its casino gambling bill. When the citizens of the Garden State voted last fall to permit casino gambling in Atlantic City, some were fearful of creating a Vegaslike strip, and a lush opportunity for organized crime. The majority who supported gambling saw a rain of cash into the state's tax coffers and the possibility of reviving a depressed resort. New Yorkers, who have been asked to consider a casino gambling referendum, will naturally be tracking the developments in New Jersey. So will other states looking for extra tax revenues. How does the New Jersey bill stack up?

title: R. MICHAEL SNOWDAY
description: R. Michael Snowday, vice president of the Northeast Diesel Corporation, died Friday of a heart attack. He was 51 years old and lived at 133 Wooster Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Nassau County police officer was struck and killed by a car that was being chased by other policemen in the wrong direction on the Southern State Parkway near North Bellmore, L. I., officials reported.

description: Garrison R. Rice, the president of Peter S. Pasbjerg & Company, a mortgagebanking concern in Springfield, N.J., died yesterday at his summer home in Dorset. Vt. He was 58 years old.

title: CALIFORNIA SURPLUS MAY EASE TAX LOAD
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 28California's taxpayers learned this week that their state government expects to have a surplus of $2.5 billion to $2.75 billion in the corning year, and that officials plan to spend it on education and property tax relief as well as to increase the financial cushion in the state treasury.

title: Orders Last Month For Machine Tools Trailed March Level
description: Machine tool orders in April ran well ahead of a year ago but were below the March total, the National Machine Too! Builders' Association reported over the weekend.

description: The marriage of Cathie Lynne Axelrod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlin S. Axelrod of Harrison, N. Y., to Dr. Dean Andrew Schaffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Schaffer of Scarsdale, N. Y., took place in the Cotillion Room at the Pierre last evening. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi H. Leonard Poler, assisted by Cantor Edward Graham.

title: Lynn Not Hurt Seriously; Red Sox Get Hernandez
description: BOSTON, May 29 (AP)Fred Lynn, the Boston Red Sox's hardhitting center fielder, received some good news today when Xrays of his injured left ankle showed no serious damage.

title: DE GUSTIBUS
description: The curiosity and imagination of cooks and others who read this column are seemingly without limit. We recently wrote a column stating that Parisienne spice, which is used in making pts and terrines in the French kitchen, is no longer imported into this country. We added that the formula for making the spice mixture varied but often included thyme, bay leaf, coriander seeds, mace and so on.

title: Lag in Building Breeder Plants Termed Costly
description: Delays in developing breeder nuclear power plants could cost the United States economy hundreds or even thousands of billions of dollars over the next 75 years, two staff members of the Electric Power Research Institute have concluded.

title: Yanks, Held Hitless 5, Rally to Win
description: The Yankees treated a young pitcher rudely yesterday in their 52 defeat of the Chicago White Sox but after the game Reggie Jackson engaged in an exercise in diplomacy.

title: Block I. Race Taken by Sloop. From Jersey
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 29In distance yacht races on Long Island Sound, like the Storm Trysail Club's annual competition out to Block Island and back, which ended here today, most of the sailors know one another by reputation if not personally or by boat recognition.

title: Inhaled Smoke Killed Most Victims in Fire
description: Most of those who died in the Beverly Hills Supper Club fire were victims of smoke inhalation rather than fatal burns, Kentucky officials said.

title: Some Brokers Offer Customers Comprehensive Financial Plan
description: The womana successful author with a yearly income of $280,000 had a most unusual problem. She was running out of banks in which to put her money.

description: Traders are sharply divided over plans to introduce a futures contract in previously unacceptable grades of green (unroasted) coffee. Page 24.

title: Dr. Stephen Firshein And Dr. Evelyn Smith Wed in Connecticut
description: Dr. Evelyn Felice Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Smith of Meriden, Conn., was married there yesterday, to Dr. Stephen Ira Firshein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Firshein of Silver Spring, Md. The ceremony was performed in Temple B'nai Abraham by Rabbi Albert N. Troy assisted by Cantor Reouven Papir.

title: Sadat Plans to Ask Compensation
description: RAMADAN CITY, Egypt, May 29 (AP) President Anwar elSadat, reacting to President Carter's call for compensation for Palestinians, said today that he would demand $2.1 billion for Egyptian oil explolted by Israel.
