description: ENTRIES

title: Citibank Hopes to Woo Customers With Gamble on Electronic Teller
description: They just look like more cash machines built into bank walls, but to Citibank they are a $50 million gamble that the consumer can be wooed and won with electronic services.

title: Cornell's Chief, Near Retirement, Named to New Post of Chancellor
description: ITHACA, N.Y., May 30 (AP)Dr. Dale R. Corson, the president of Cornell University, was named today to the new post of chancellor by the school's trustees.

title: MOLUCCANS APPEAR TO SOFTEN DEMANDS
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, Tuesday, May 31The South Moluccas terrorists still holding 56 hostages in the north of the Netherlands seem to have softened after a week of determined confrontation with the Dutch Government.

title: Family/Style and Living Sections Put Under New Editors at Times
description: The appointment of two new editor: was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The New York Times.

title: Holiday Pleasure Outdraws Patriotism
description: The old soldiers on the march outnumbered the 300 to 400 spectatorsbut barelyat Manhattan's Memorial Day parade yesterday up Riverside Drive from 72d Street. And when they reached the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, at 89th Street, they found a flagpole but no flag.

title: Balanchine Takes Waltz to Vienna
description: VIENNA, May 29  George Balanchine brought one of his bestknown ballets in threequarter time, Liebeslieder Walzer, to the city of the waltz last night, and a glittering audience at the State Opera. House responded with enthusiasm.

title: The Race for Governor
description: JERSEY CITY, May 30Governor Byrne relaxed between campaign stops here the other day by kicking off his shoes, putting his feet on a desk in the Journal Square law office of Kenneth McPherson and sipping some iced tea.

title: Caesars World, Seeking a Casino in Atlantic City, Is Under Nevada Warning on Business Dealings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30Caesars World Inc. of Los Angeles, which owns Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., and is reported to be completing negotiations to lease two Boardwalk properties in Atlantic City for a gambling casino hotel, has been in trouble in Nevada over suspicions of involvement with Meyer LanskY, the reputed organizedcrime figure.

title: Turks Are Moving Toward the Left as New Jobs in Industry Lure Them From the Land
description: IZMIR, Turkey, May 28Fifteen years ago, Feramuz Eryilmaz came to this shipping and industrial center on Turkey's west coast from the eastern city of Sivas. In the past he has always favored conservative parties, but in the national elections on June 5 he will vote for the Republican People's Party, a social democratic party headed by Bulent Ecevit.

title: Making a Big Splash On 2 Coasts in 1 Day
description: Frank Coughlan, a 53yearold insurance man from San Francisco, spent Memorial Day exactly as planned with two long swims separated by a continent.

title: Amateur Golf Teams Start National Play Tomorrow
description: The national amateur mixed team golf championships, a nationwide club level tournament for players 21 years and over, will begin tomorrow. Qualifying rounds on home courses will take place in six regions for men with handicaps of up to 24 and for women with handicaps of 30 and below.

title: Thomas E. Mullaney
description: One prominent Wall Street invest ment banker recently remarkedsomewhat facetiously but nonetheless approvinglythat William E. Simon, who was Secretary of the Treasury in the preceding Republican administration, must have quietly taken on a new job as an economic speechwriter for President Carter and his Democratic hierarchy. The comment was made after appearances by the President and his aides before Congressional and business groups in the last two months in which they espoused the fiscal conservatism of Mr. Simon and other top officials of the Ford and Nixon Administrations. Last week, President Carter threatened to use his veto power if Congress voted bills in which the spending is excessive.

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSONForrest G., of El Cerrito, Calif., son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Anderson of Wilton, Conn. and brother of Mrs. Robert T. Tale, Jr. Memorial service In Berkeley, Calif. Wed., June 1, 1977.

title: Colombia Coffee Growers Score the Role of Government
description: MANIZALES, Colombia  With the international boom in coffee prices, it would seem that growers in this No. 2 coffeeexporting nation would be awash in prosperity.

title: Jersey Derby To Cormorant By 3 Lengths
description: MAYS LANDING, N.J., May 30With Seattle Slew, the 3yearolds' band leader resting in his Belmont Park barn, five colts he had beaten in Triple Crown races and two others competed today for the top prize in the $124,200 Jersey Derby and for the role of second fiddle in the division.

title: Irish Setter Is Best at Queensboro
description: The huge silver punch bowl went to Ch. McKendree's Bold Venture, the striking Irish setter owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York at the conclusion of the Queensboro Kennel Club's 54th allbreed show in Jacob Riis Park. On his way to the top prize, the setter outclassed 1,219 competitors and won his 11th best in show last night.

title: U.S. Panel to Urge Wide Changes In F.D.A.'s Regulation of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, May 30A Federal panel investigating the Food and Drug Administration has found major shortcomings in its regulation of the pharmaceutical industry and will propose 91 detailed changes tomorrow.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: GOLD AND DOLLAR WEAKEN IN QUIET HOLIDAY TRADING
description: LONDON, May 30 (AP)Gold prices dipped slightly lower and the dollar eased against most major currencies on London bullion and money markets today. This is a holiday in most of Europe.

title: Rabies Vaccine For Wildlife
description: An Albany scientist is in serious condition suffering from rabies, the deadly viral disease he was trying to prevent through research aimed at developing an oral vaccine to stop the spread of the infection in wild animals. The scientist, Jerome Andrulonis, was engaged in a littleknown, hazardous area of medical reAnalysis search for the New York State Health Department. The risks were considered worthwhile because rabies causes one of the most horrible deaths known and poses a major public health problem throughout the world.

title: Florida House Votes Homosexual Controls
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 30 (AP) Responding to a Miami controversy over a ban on discrimination against homosexuals, the Florida House approved today bills outlawing marriages by persons of the same sex and baring homosexuals from adopting children. Opponents charged that neither bill was necessary.

title: Survey Finds Role Of Internal Capital Expected to Crow
description: Depreciation and retained earnings have traditionally been one of the major sources for corporate expansion and study by the Conference Board suggests that reliance on internally generated capital is likely to become even heavier over the next four years.

title: Banks and Exchanges Closed
description: All securities and commodities exchanges throughout the nation were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day. Banks in the threestate areaNew York, New Jersey and Connecticutwere also closed.

title: Master of the Chains
description: For a long time I resisted the feminist argument that I was an oppressor. It was not because I found the suggestion altogether distasteful. Most people harbor secret urges to do a little oppressing now and then, and I was no exception.

title: Join B. Crimmins, Long an Associate Of Edward Kennedy
description: John B. Crimmins, a longtime aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and former aide to Govs. Charles F. Hurley and Paul Dever of Massachusetts, died Sunday at Boston's West Roxbury Veterans Administration Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: For Texas Legislators, Frivolity Marks Session
description: AUSTIN, Tex., May 30??he ornate state Senate chamber had u;ready beer. the scene of one worldclass filibuster earlier in the month. So when Gene Jones of Houston row on Friday afternoon, cleared his throat and began reading slowly from a dusty law book, there was a certain amount of groaning and headholding.

title: Miss Palmore Wed To M.B.Beckerman
description: Karen Jean Palmore, daughter of Dr. Erdman Palmore of Durham, N.C., and Mrs. Stanley Silverstone of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Brim Beckerman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Beckerman of New York. Rabbi Charles Scheer performed the ceremony at the McIntosh Center at Barnard College, from which the bride graduated May I8.

title: Quick Electronic Banking Slowed By the Public's Habits and Fears
description: The way people hank, pay bills and even handle money is being changed, by an electronic revolution among the nation's financial institutions.

title: Maryland Wildlife Center Reports Whooping Crane Egg Bonanza of 21
description: LAUREL, Md., May 30 (AP)Officials at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center here are calling this year's crop of eggs from. the rare whooping crane a real bonanza.

title: Study Sees Danger in Illegality on TV Police Shows
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP)Kojak, Columbo and most other television detectives frequently trample on the Constitution and may be subtly persuading the public that such conduct is acceptable from reallife police officers, two law professors warn.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MAY 31, 1977

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CRUCIBLE An exhibition of more than 150 pieces of 18thcentury Latin American decorative art is on display through Aug, 7 at the InterAmerican Relations Gallery, 680 Park Avenue. The objects have not been exhibited outside their own countries.

title: U.S. Proposes Envoy Exchange With Cuba
description: KINGSTON Jamaica, May 30Sources traveling with Rosalynn Carter on her sevennation tour of the Caribbean and Latin America said today that the United States hd proposed a formal exchange of doplomats with Cuba, but without a full resumption of diplomatic relations.

title: Leaves Four Behind With Time of 10.14
description: NORWALK, Calif., May 30 (AP)Houston McTear, kept out of the Olympics by an injury, stunned one of the finest 100meterdash fields ever assembled with a victory in the Muhammad Ali invitation track meet today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: Crews Find No More Bodies in Day of Searching Burned Supper Club
description: SOUTHGATE, Ky., May 30Firefighters, with the aid of a massive bulldozer and crane, churned through the wreckage of the Beverly Hills Supper Club today. searching for more bodies of fire victims.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Shootings in Westchester

title: A Plausible Approach to Arms Control
description: Arms control talks with the Russians appear to be back on the track after the derailment in Moscow last March, but they are not yet running smoothly or on schedule. That is the message we draw from reports of the latest round in Geneva, including President Carter's assessments. More good manners and flexibility will be needed on both sides if the SALT II treaty is to be ready to supplant expiring portions of SALT I in October.

title: Black Hanged in SouthWest Africa
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, May 30 (Reuters)A black convicted under South Africa's antiterrorism raws of the murder of four whites was hanged at dawn here today, despite appeals on his behalf by the SouthWest African People's Organization. The black nationalist organization said last week that the execution of the black, Filemon Nangolo, would threaten to break down all possibilities of an internal solution to the problems of SouthWest Africa.

title: Hail Covers Minnesota Road
description: MORRIS, Minn., May 30 (AP)Minnesota has been having temperatures in the upper 70's and 80's recently, but yesterday the State Department of Transportation had to send out a snowplow. A crew hooked up a plow to a truck to clear Minnesota 28 between Cyrus and Morris, in central Minnesota, after a storm left as much as six inches of hail covering the road.

title: BANKER IS TO MANAGE FUND FOR TEAMSTERS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30Woodward Kingman, a 51yearold banker, is to assume what may be the greatest challenge of his careermanagement of the formerly corruptionridden principal pension fund of the teamsters' union.

title: Gottfried, Smith Win; Solomon Out
description: PARIS, May 30 (AP)Brian Gottfried overcame France's Patrice Dominguez and a noisy partisan crowd today and reached the quarterfinals of the $300,000 French open tennis championships. Harold Solomon, another American favorite, was beaten.

title: Making the Case for Consumers
description: For the fifth time in seven years, Congress is considering the creation of a separate agency to defend the interests of consumers. The idea is quite simply to inject a consumer perspective into governmental procedures. Federal departments and agencies make thousands of decisions each year that affect consumers, but they are rarely so well heard as equally interested business firms. Representation in Washington requires money and expertise. Business organizations maintain staffs of lawyers and lobbyists to monitor government actions. Consumer groups make an occasional splash on individual issues, but lack the resources to follow the hundreds debates that occur throughout the bureaucracy.

title: Her Disciples Dance to Honor Isadora Duncan
description: There is some debate as to whether Isadora Duncan was born in 1877 or 1878. Just to be on the safe side, two generations of her disciples have just celebrated the 100th anniversary of her birth with a program of dances composed by the legendary Isadora herself and by her first students.

title: Coney Islanders Tell Albany What's What
description: Do you have faith in the future of New York City? That is the question that the Assembly's Committee on Cities was asking yesterday in Coney Island, in the fourth of a series of citywide street forums.

title: Earthquake Felt in Aleutians
description: PALMER, Alaska, May 30 (AP)An earthquake measuring 5.9 on the Richter scale occurred about 70 miles south of the village of Nikolski in the Aleutian Islands today, scientists at the Palmer Observatory reported. No damage was reported in the islands south of the Bering Straits.

title: PRESIDENT WILL SEEK $375 MILLION MORE FOR NEEDY NATIONS
description: PARIS, May 30Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance said today that the Carter Administration would ask Congress for an emergency increase of $375 million in American foreign aid this year to help meet the most acute needs of the world's poorest nations.

title: Bank Conference Hears Message From Kidnappers of Salvadoran
description: GUATEMALA, May 30A meeting of the InterAmerican Development Bank began here today with the reading of an anticapitalist message from the gunmen who kidnapped El Salvador's Ambassador to Guatemala yesterday.

title: Young UndergroundFilm Group Finds Subways Are for Shooting
description: Money...Money...Money! the three men in the subway car gloat, pulling handfuls of fake greenbacks from their attache cases as a handheld color camera records the action for this underground film.

title: CARTER HINTS NEW TIE WITH CUBA, BUT CITES INTRUSION IN AFRICA
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., May 30President Carter suggested today that there might soon be stronger ties between the United States and Cuba, but he cited that nation's military presence in Africa and its political prisoners as continuing impediments.

title: Madrid Tomb Hides Tunnel
description: MADRID, May 30 (Reuters)The police have discovered an unfinished tunnel leading from a tomb in a Madrid cemetery toward nearby Carabanchel jail, which houses several political prisoners, (police sources said today. Sleeping bags, lamps and food were found in the 14foot tunnel, discovered after a woman complained that her daughter's tomb had been disturbed.

title: Rumania Will be Supplied With Coal From Virginia
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday an agreement with Rumania to supply up to 27.3 million tons of high grade metallurgical coal, valued at nearly $2 billion, to Rumania's expanding steel industry.

title: Westchester to Get U.S. Funds
description: The Federal Government will give Westchester County $15,000 to improve and coordinate services for the handicapped, a Federal offcial said last night. The money will provide some staff for a council that will consist of county and volunteeragency leaders and organizations of the handicapped, said the official, Bernice L. Bernstein of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Elmsford, Making Debut, Is Victor in $30,100 Trot
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 30 Elmsford, Canadianowned and making her first start of the season, led virtually all the way tonight to win the $30,100 Goldsmith Maid Trot for 3yearold fillies at the Meadowlands.

title: Judge Rules for a Navy Mother
description: RICHMOND, May 31 (UPI)Lieut. Alice Cook, U.S.N.R., may resume her career as Lieut. Comdr. Alice Cook, U.S.N., thanks to a court decision that motherhood should not necessarily rule out active duty in the military service.

title: Charles Preusse, Wagner Aide, Dies; Was City Administrator for 4 Years
description: Charles F. Preusse, a gruffvoiced New York City official who was known as the chief troubleshooter for four years during the administration of Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died yesterday in Southampton Hospital on Long Island after a brief illness. Mr. Preusse was 75 years old and had homes in East Hampton and at 522 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Economic Scene column in yesterday's editions of The Times, due to an editing error, Harlan Cleveland was identified as a vice president and international economist at Citibank. The officer in question was his brother, Harold van B. Cleveland.

title: Expos Are Victors by 51 and 32
description: While the management resolutely kept trying to trade their best player, the New York Mets resolutely won the battle for last place yesterday when they lost both games of a doubleheader to the Montreal Expos and worsened the sense of disaster hanging over Shea Stadium.

title: Briton, 11, to Contend In Title Chess Bout
description: MANCHESTER, England, May 30 (AP)An 11yearold British schoolboy has made chess history by becoming the youngest person ever to qualify for a national championship final.

title: WILLIAM L. F. GARDINER
description: William L. F. Gardiner, a New York lawyer in realestate and surrogate law, died Sunday at Stamford Hospital in Stamford, Conn., after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

title: The Dance: City Ballet's Men Have a Field Day
description: Men's Liberation has its virtues, too particularly in a ballet company such as New York City Ballet, whose director, George Balanchine, once made the somewhat controversial statement: Ballet is woman. Well, it isn't. Indeed, anthropologists are in agreement that in primitive tribes dancing is more often a masculine than a feminine function. In the wellorganized ranks of classic ballet, female and male should be equal constituents.

title: Irvie Eugene Lattimer, Developer of Devices For A.T. & T., Was 88
description: Irvie Eugene Lattimer, spicealfeatures engineer for the longlines department of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company until his retirement 24 years ago, died Sunday night at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 88 years old.

title: E.F.T.: Convenience Vs. Loss of Privacy
description: What can the consumer gain or lose in an electronic funds transfer world?

title: GILBERT W. TAISHOFF
description: Gilbert W. Taishoff, a builder, realestate broker and consulting engineer, died yesterday at North Shore Hospital, in Manhasset, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

title: Apricot Pits Ordered Returned in Knoxville
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 30 (AP)A Federal judge today ordered the Food and Drug Administration to return 6,700 cases of apricot pits to an East Tennessee businessman who testified they had helped his wife overcome cancer.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Mets' Box Scores
description: EParrish, Kranepool DP Montreal ?? LOBMont real 10, Mets 5. 2BSncier, Staiger, HRPerez (6) SEspinosa. SFRandle.

title: Casino Applicant Was Warned on Business Dealings
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30Caesars World Inc. of Los Angeles, which owns Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., and is reported to be completing negotiations to lease two Boardwalk properties in Atlantic City for a gambling casino hotel, has been in trouble in Nevada over suspicions of involvement with Meyer Lansky, the reputed organizedcrime figure.

title: MARY LEE M'GRATH
description: Mary Lee McGrath, director of the Park Avenue Christian Day School, at 1010 Park Avenue, from 1968 to 1976, died Sunday in her home at 62 West 82d Street after a short illness. She was 53 years old.

title: Viscount Is Open Jumper Victor
description: DEVON, Pa., May 30Buddy Brown, a 19yearold rider from North Salem, N.Y., piloted Viscount to victory in the open jumper class tonight at the Devon Horse Show and finished tied for first place in the battle for the championship.

title: Dennis Koster Plays Own Guitar Work In a Bold Program
description: There were no easy winners, and a few likely losers, on the bold guitar program that Dennis Koster assembled for his concert Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: SUBSAHARAN REGION DISCUSSED IN OTTAWA
description: OTTAWA, May 30Development experts from many countries and international agencies met here today to discuss longrange plans to convert a vast, chronically parched African area along the fringes of the Sahara into a permanent source of food for other needy African nations.

title: RHODESIA SAYS ITS DRIVE INTO MOZAMBIQUE GAINS
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 30 (AP)Rhodesian forces were said to have struck deeper into Mozambique today in search of Rhodesian black nationalists guerrilla bases. Mozambique charged that the invaders were attacking its army bases as well.

title: Trial Is Starting for 77 in Italy Accused of Plotting a Takeover
description: ROME, May 30 (AP)A former military intelligence chief and 76 other persons went on trial here today on charges of participating in rightwing plots to overthrow the Government.

title: SAUDIS REPORTED READY TO TAKE OVER FOREIGNHELD BANKS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 30Saudi Arabia has reportedly decided to take control of all foreign banks operating in that country.

title: AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL DENIES TORTURING HOGS
description: LONDON, May 30 (AP)An animalprotection group has accused Amnesty International of horrendous and disgusting experiments on hogs involving electric shocks and redhot metal rods.

title: MOLUCCANS APPEAR TO SOFTEN DEMANDS
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, Tuesday, May 31The South Moluccan terrorists still holding 56 hostages in the north of the Netherlands seem to have softened after a week of determined confrontation with the Dutch Government.

title: F.T.C. Investigating Airport Car Rental
description: WASHINGTON, May 30 (UPI)The Federal Trade Commission is investigating whether 59 airports in 33 states and Puerto Rico have cooperated in monopolistic practices by car rental firms using their premises.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: School nurses in northern Hunterdon County were to inspect students heads for lice this week as more than 300 cases were discovered at a school here.

title: Art Auctions Setting. Sales Records
description: Art and antiques auctions in New York and abroad have toppled world records recently, establishing new highs for everything from books in print to Iron boot scrapers.

title: Parimutuel Clerks End Belmont Strike
description: Racing at Belmont Park returned to nearnormal stride yesterday after partmutuel clerks ended their 10day strike against the New York Racing Association.

title: Torrez Wins by 54 With a 7Hitter
description: BOSTON, May 30Clell Lavern Hobson Jr., known widely as Butch, never had such a good block thrown on him when he played strong safety for Bear Bryant's University of Alabama football team in 1970.

title: Skydiver Killed in Pennsylvania
description: LIMERICK, Pa., May 30 (AP)A skydiver believed to have made 100 jumps died when her parachute failed to open in an exhibition yesterday, the state police said. Joyce Sevey, 21 years old, was performing with 12 other skydivers at Limerick Airport here, west of Philadelphia, when the accident occurred.

title: Kissinger Likely To Reject Offer From Columbia
description: Dr. Henry A. Kissinger is expected to withdraw from consideration for appointment to a professorship and an endowed chair at Columbia University, according to people close to the situation.

title: Covent Garden Glitters as Artists Present GiltEdged Gala for Queen's Silver Jubilee
description: LONDON, May 30It was an evening of music fit for a queen. Drawing on the resources that have given it new international reknown during the 25year reign of Queen Elizabeth II, the Royal Opera staged a shimmering silver jubilee gala tonight. The Queen and members of her family watched from a specially constructed box as stars from a dozen countries sang operatic excerpts and performed five ballets.

title: WAGNER JR. IS NAMED TO THE LIBERAL LINE
description: The Liberal Party has awarded its ballot line for Manhattan Borough President to Robert F. Wagner Jr. The endorsement was announced by Henry J. Stern, the party's county chairman and Mr. Wagner's fellow Councilmanatlarge for Manhattan.

title: About New York
description: Edward Hopper is 10 years dead and gone from his skylighted studio at 3 Washington Square North, and professors talk about sociology there now in the great wash of light that flows down through the slope of roof glass. Hopper spent 50 years in that light, silently making paintings about the heart of this city, showing people and places defined in solitude and In great angled planes of color and shade.

title: Books of The Times
description: In a footnote right at the beginning of this long and careful book, Daniel Yergin reminds us that Westerners have no access whatsoever to relevant Soviet archives.... No Westerner can know how the Soviet leaders among themselves interpreted and misinterpreted American intentions and capabilities. So the historian today, like the policymaker in the postwar years, must seek to develop a consistent and reasonable interpretation based upon what is available.

title: Arab Prince's Buying of Coop Up for Vote Today
description: A Princetoneducated Arab prince wants to buy an 18room luxury apartment at 640 Park Avenue, but other welltodo apartment owners there haven't decided whether to let him, residents of the building have reported.

title: Missing Teacher's Body Identified
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., May 30 (AP)An autopsy confirmed today that a body found by hikers was that of Carol Ann Todd, 28 years old, who had been stabbed to death. Dental records were used to identify the body of the Falmouth schoolteacher, who disappeared from a North Adams hotel room Dec. 12.

title: Holbert Beats Haywood In Lime Rock Park Test
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., May 30Al Holbert of Warrington, Pa., drove his highly modified Chevrolet Monza to victory today in the $50,000 Camel GT Challenge race at Lime Rock Park. Holbert beat the runnerup, Hurley Haywood, by 11/3 laps, in the International Motor Sports Association 100mile race. Haywood of Jacksonville, Fla., pilots a turbocharged Porsche Carrera.

title: Memorial Services
description: MacDERMOTT Lorraine G. A memorial sorrier) will be held In the Chantry Chapel of St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and $3rd Street, on Thursday, June 2, at 11:30 In the morning. In lieu of flowers, contributions may he made to the Jullliard School Scholarship Fund, Lincoln Center, New York, N.Y. 10023.

title: New York Man Held in Thailand In Connection With Heroin Ring
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 30 (AP)A New York man arrested here in connection with a heroin ring will be returned to the United States to face charges, an official of the United States Drug Enforcement Agency said today.

title: ALEXANDER S. KATZMAN
description: Alexander S. Katzman, president of the S. L. Kayo Company, confectionery importers at 230 Fifth Avenue, died Sunday in Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 315 East 65th Street, and was 66 years old. He is survived by his wife, the former Dorothy Wagenheim; a son, Michael, two grandchildren and a brother.

title: The Golden Dust of Life
description: If the air of late May seems to have a strange, golden glint, particularly in the woodland, it is not only because the sunlight has its own aura. The air itself is dusted with the substance of life, the incredibly extravagant pollen crop from the trees.

title: Nehemiah Sets U.S. Schoolboy Mark
description: Renaldo Nehemiah surpassed the national schoolboy record for the 120yard high hurdles three times yesterday at the Eastern States outdoor track and field championships, but only one clocking was official and that one was the best.

title: Darken Your Graying Hair, and Hide Your Fright
description: I am male, white, 46. I have undergraduate and graduate degrees from two reasonably wellknown Eastern institutions. My first job lasted for four years, my second for ten, my third for sewn. I have a wife, three daughters, a mortgaged home and a 1972 Beetle for, which I paid cash.

title: Inquiry Suggests Korean Agents Tried to Gain Control of Bank in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, May 30Federal investigators have found evidence that the Diplomat National Bank, originally formed to serve the AsianAmerican community here, was the target of a takeover attempt by alleged agents of the South Korean Government.

title: Cecil Bowman of New York Hospital Drowns in Upstate Boating Mishap
description: Dr. Cecil R. Bowman, an assistant physician at New York Hospital and a fellow at the Cornell University Medical College, drowned in a boating accident in the Adirondacks near Tupper Lake, N.Y., on Saturday. He was 31 years old.

title: Paint Factory Burns
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., May 30 (AP)Fire destroyed the Pittsburgh Paint and Glass Company building here today, the police said. The fire broke out at the Market Street site about 8:30 A.M. and within a few hours completely leveled the building. Fueled by the highly combustible products within the factory, flames shot up 50 to 60 feet in the air.

title: The Gamble on Gambling
description: TRENTON, May 30  Governor Byrne and other backers of casino gambling for Atlantic City are trying to overcome criticisms of the enabling legislation on the Governor's desk with an avalanche of economic statistics.

title: Americans Hit Japanese on Promotions
description: It sounds like a textbook dispute between the local nationals and their foreignowned employers. Some parties blame a culture barrier. Others point to a differing work ethic, the language problem, and the sheer difficulty of doing business in a foreign land.

title: Holiday Pleasure Outdraws Patriotism
description: The old soldiers on the march outnumbered the 300 to 400 spectatorsbut barelyat Manhattan's Memorial Day parade yesterday up Riverside Drive from 72d Street. And when they reached the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, at 89th Street, they found a flagpole but no flag.

title: L.A.A City Committing Suicide
description: ANDOVER, Mass. I left Los Angeles 13 years ago to go to college. It was then, and still is, the most maligned city in the country. Hated for being openly late 20th century, a whipping boy for the cities that copied its mistakes, Los Angeles competes now only with New York as a center of cultural activity and adventure. It is energized. It is present tense. It is, however, spiritually empty and environmentally decadent, and a city to which I have never returned for long.

title: Taxes & Accounting
description: In the last decade or so, the art of budgeting has taken on an aspect of the fashion world: A new styleor simply a fad, some critics saybecomes popular for a few years, only to be replaced in turn by a newer trend.

title: Japanese Christian Is Awarded A Doctorate by Jewish Seminary
description: Having spent the last 15 years risking his Christian faith and confusing his Japanese tongue, Jacob Yuroh Teshima finally won his earthly reward this month; he was awarded a doctor's degree from the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

title: Wells Twombly, PrizeWinning Sports Columnist
description: Wells Twombly, sports columnist for The San Francisco Examiner, who won several national awards for his writing, died yesterday at Kaiser Hospital in Redwood City, Calif. Mr. Twombly, who was 41 years old, entered the hospital May 20 for treatment of an acute internal disorder.

title: BANKS' RETURN ON EQUITY UP 6% TO RECORD IN 1976
description: The nation's 14,000 insured commercial banks earned a record $7.6 billion in 1976 on stockholders equity of $72.3 billion, an increase In earnings of 6 percent from 1975, a bank publication reported yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: Alvin Roth of New York City and Barbara Rappaport of Springfield, N.J., are a formidable partnership in any company, and perhaps the best mixed pair in the world.

title: Coney Islanders Tell Albany What's What
description: Do you have faith in the future of New York City? That is the question that the Assembly's Committee on Cities was asking yesterday in Coney Island, in the fourth of a series of citywide street forums.

title: William Buckley, Trainman, Branches Out
description: God, this is spooky, said William F. Buckley Jr., the columnist, novelist, sailor and magazine editor. You can't even see the tracks. It's like being in a tank. Mr. Buckley was riding in the front scat of a jeeplike vehicle specially equipped to run on railroad tracks, the celebrity member of the first expedition to ride the overgrown tracks of the Catskill Mountain Branch of the onceflourishing Ulster and Delaware Railroad since the last freight made the run eight months ago.

title: NisshoIwai Officer Proposes Training Americans in Tokyo
description: If American employees complain of lack of opportunity and object to better fringe benefits and more pay for Japanese sent here why not dispatch the Americans to Tokyo for training and pay them better benefits than the Japanese?

title: LOUIS WESTFALL MUNRO, FORMER HEAD OF DOREMUS
description: Louis Westfall Munro, who retired in 1968 as president of Doremus & Company, the advertising an dpublic relations firm at 120 Broadway, died Saturday in his home on Ridge Road, Syosset, L.I. He was 81 years old.

title: Carter Appoints ExAide of Nixon To Nuclear Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 30To give a new push to his drive to deter the spread of nuclear weapons, President Carter has selected Gerard C. Smith, armscontrol chief in the Nixon Administration, to become Ambassador at Large for highlevel negotiations with other nations on the nuclear issue.

title: Paul Desmond, Alto Saxophonist With Dave Brubeck Quartet, Dies
description: Paul Desmond, whose alto saxophone was as essential to the Dave Brubeck Quartet as Mr. Brubeck's piano, died early yesterday at his home at 77 West 55th Street. He was 52 years old.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: ERudolph, Cornutt, Horndon. DPSanFrancisco 3. LOBSan Diego 4, San Francisco 8, 2BClark, Ivie 2, DoRader, Turne. 3BWinfield. HREvans 2 (5), Hendrick (5), Clark (1). SMcGiothen.

title: Carter Appoints ExAide of Nixon To Nuclear Role
description: WASHINGTON, May 30To give a new push to his drive to deter the spread of nuclear weapons, President Carter has selected Gerard C. Smith, armscontrol chief in the Nixon Administration, to become Ambassador at Large for highlevel negotiations with other nations on the nuclear issue.

title: Armenia's Culture Thrives As a Paradox Within Soviet
description: YEREVAN, U.S.S.R.In some respects the Soviet Union seems like a collection of separate countries united by little more than ubiquitous statues of Lenin. Of course the pervasive Communist Party organization enforces political conformity and the Government exerts centralized economic control.

title: Eckersley Tops Angels On NoHitter
description: CLEVELAND, May 30 (AP)Dennis Eckersley of the Cleveland Indians, who pitched 7 23 hitless innings to wrap up his last outing, hurled a nohitter at Municipal Stadium tonight in beating Frank Tanana and the California Angels. 10.

title: TRAVIS K. HEDRICK, 73; A FORMER NEWSMAN, DIES
description: Travis K. Hedrick, a retired labor union public relations official and a former reporter for The Chattanooga Times and The Associated Press, died in Arlington County Hospital, Arlington, Va., yesterday morning of cancer. He was 73 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Lovers of the Delaware River, a magnificent stream that, although within easy reach of millions, has somehow retained much of its pristine beauty and vitality, are rejoicing that an enlightened program of water releases from its three New York Cityowned reservoirs is under way.

title: Negative Thinking Sells No Burgers
description: At least once every eight years the American people entrust the Presidency to a man with no experience on the job, but the owners of baseball teams dislike such risks. When in the market for a manager, most of them look for someone who has held the position elsewhere, not necessarily with distinction.

title: Ridley Wins in Opener Of British Amateur Golf
description: GANTON, England, May 30 (AP)Fred Ridley, a 24yearold law student from Winter Haven, Fla., defeated Pat Mulcare of Ireland today, 7 and 6, in the first round of the British Amateur golf championship.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Bondmen Are Optimistic After 2 Surprising Weeks
description: For two weeks, the credit markets have been caught by surprise, first with prices declining when many people though they would rise and then rising when many believed prices would drop. By the end of last week, however, the fog over the credit market seemed to have lifted, and a more confident consensus has emerged. As the credit markets head into June, the outlook for higher fixedincome prices at lower interest rates is bright, many credit market analysts now conclude. Bond prices dropped unexpectedly just before and after the weekend of May 21 and 22 as the effective rate for Federal fundsthe basic interest rate in the money market and the rate most directly influenced by the Federal Reserverose to 5 percent. That was slightly higher than many Fed watchers had anticipated and so they concluded that the Federal Reserve had decided to tighten monetary conditions to a slight degree.

title: CORRECTION
description: In The Economic Scene column in yesterday's editions of The Times, due to an editing error, Harlan Cleveland was identified as a vice president and International economist at Citibank. The officer in question was his brother, Harold van B. Cleveland.

title: Miami Homosexual Issue Dividing Clerics
description: MIAMITwo area ministers, longtime acquaintances who are on opposite sides of the June 7 Dade County referendum on civil rights of homosexuals, met by chance in an elevator here last week. One cleric, indirectly referring to the bitter dispute that has shattered friendships, asked the other, Do you still like me?

title: Court Curb of Deportations Leads to Paralysis of Investigations Aimed at Illegal Aliens
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 30Investigations of illegal aliens in California have been paralyzed by paper work issuing from mass requests for a stay of deportation under a Federal District Court order in Chicago, according to officials for the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service here.

title: Candidates for Governor Indicate Tax Isn't Only Issue
description: TRENTON, May 30Questions being put by organizations to the candidates for Governor indicate that the state income tax may not he the allencompassing issue after all.

title: Watercolors of Birds Are Stolen; Value Is Estimated at $400,000
description: KEY WEST, Fla. May 30 (AP)Thieves stole more than 400 of James J. Audubon's watercolors of North American birds, valued at $400,000, from his restored home here, the police said.

title: A California College With No Campus Is Succeeding
description: FOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif., May 30 More than 20.000 persons in Orange County, south of Los Angeles, are getting an education these days at a college without a single building or fulltime teacher.

title: Dark Gets Padres Moving With a Sweep of Giants
description: The decision by Ray Kroc, the owner of the San Diego Padres, to hire Alvin Dark as the new manager of his ball club is beyond criticismso far. Dark, who was named to replace John McNamara on Sunday, joined his new team in San Francisco yesterday and led the Padres to victory in both games of a doubleheader, 128 and 98.

title: A Flourish of Ruffles to Soften the Edges
description: They circle the neck in the vicinity of the collar bones or climb up to the chin in the manner of an 18thcentury dandy. Sometimes they edge a jacket or form a flounce on a skirt. They transform a shirt into a blouse and they add a flirtatious feeling to almost anything.

title: Naumburg Concert Refreshes
description: Ideal spring weather encouraged an unusually large crowd to attend the Naumburg concert on Central Park's Mall late Sunday afternoon. Nearly every bench was full for the occasion, which opened the 52d continuous season of free outdoor concerts established in 1905 by Elkan Naumburg.

title: Mrs. Carter Discusses Policy, and Rain, in Jamaica
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 30Rosalynn Carter and Prime Minister Michael Manley of Jamaica discussed finances, Cuba, Panama, human rights and rain today as the First Lady made the first stop on her sevennation diplomatic mission to Latin America.

title: Advertising
description: The advertising business could be committing suicide  killing itself with a shortrange, pennypinching attitude toward personnel training.

title: Ba Maw, Prime Minister of Burma Under Japanese in World War II
description: RANGOON, Burma, May 30 (UPI)Ba Maw, 85, the head of Burma's Government during the Japanese occupation in World War II, died Saturday, it was reported today.

title: Yonkers Racing
description: ENTRIES

title: U.S. Panel to Urge Wide Changes In F.D.A.'s Regulation of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, May 30A Federal panel investigating the Food and Drug Administration has found major shortcomings in its regulation of the pharmaceutical industry and will propose 91 detailed changes tomorrow.

title: Market Place
description: It is widely agreed in Wall Street that International Business Machines has been the outstanding growth stock of the postWorld War II period, and the stock remains the top holding among institutions. But for the first time, it seems, some analysts are beginning to question whether I.B.M. can continue to hold its commanding lead in computers and thus rate its heavy institutional following.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: 14 Firemen Injured in Fire
description: A twoalarm fire caused extensive damage yesterday in a sevenstory apartment building at 9520 222d Street in Queens Village, Queens. The fire was brought under control nearly three hours after it was reported at 5:30 P.M. Fourteen firemen were treated for minor injuries, and several families were evacuated due to heavy smoke conditions.

title: Binghamton Legion Blind Bowling Victor
description: Bob Toner of Binghamton, N.Y., bowled a 1,815pin combined series in doubles and singles events yesterday and helped American Legion Post 80 to win the team title in the 30th American Blind Bowling Association tournament at the Madison Square Garden Bowling Center.

title: Use of Scrubbers With Coal Boilers Pushed by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  The Carter Administration is moving on two fronts to put into force one of the most costly and controversial environmental protection proposals of the President's monthold national energy plan, a requirement that new coalburning boilers be fitted with pollutionfiltering, flue gas scrubbers.

title: Thomas P. Beaumont, Executive At Several Companies, Was 53
description: Thomas P. Beaumont, a former vice president of United Brands in Boston and an executive for 15 years with the Young & Rubicam advertising agency, died on Saturday while visiting relatives in Greenwich. N.Y. He was 53 years old.

title: Parimutuel Clerks End Belmont Strike
description: Racing at Belmont Park returned to nearnormal stride yesterday after parimutuel clerks ended their 10day strike against the New York Racing Association.

title: U.S. Man Gets Kidney From Finn
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 30 (AP)A North Dakota man is recovering at University of Minnesota Hospital after receiving a new kidney from a donor in Finland. Gerald Heggar, 36yearsold, of Grand Forks, N.D., received the kidney in a fourhour transplant operation Friday, 46 hours after a 32yearold Finnish man was killed in an auto accident in Helsinki.

title: Kenya's Ban on Hunting Draws Wide Applause; Goal Is Conservation and Poachers Are Target
description: Although conservationists applauded the hunting ban announced May 19 by the Kenyan Government, many people familiar with the wildlife situation in that East African country say the move's major impact will not be to halt the decimation of wild animals directly but to focus attention on a much larger threat poaching. Without the sport hunters to blame, it is being said, Kenyan officials will have to come up with some other explanation if the wildlife population continues to decline as rapidly as it has in recent years and if large numbers of carved tusks, leopard skins, zebra hides and other wildlife products continue to be available for sale in Kenya.

title: Apples Beat Soviet Union
description: ATLANTA, May 30The New York Apples came from behind tonight to beat the Soviets, 2723, and extended their winning streak to four straight marches. They return home tomorrow night for the first of five matches

title: Cubans Win in Volleyball
description: NAGANO, Japan, May 30 (AP)A Cuban women's volleyball team beat a Japanese university allstar squad, 159, 157, 156, in an exhibition match today.

title: A Sculptor Takes on Grownups, and a Potter, Multiple Forms
description: Carol Anthony is like a novelist who has worked for years on characterization and has finally learned the skills of projecting depth and dimension. Her papiermachpeople, artfully sculptured and ingeniously costumed, have always been arresting. In the past, she has concentrated her talents on capturing the spirit of childhood. Now she has taken on adults.

title: In Memariam
description: AXTONILI. Paul Warren, M.D., USNR. Yesterday, today, tomorrow, forever. Doorly loved. Mom, Deb, Chris 8 Ko'a

title: J. H. Todd, 83, of Shipyard Family
description: J. Herbert Todd, a retired executive of Todd Shipyards Corporation, died in Pinehurst, N.C., yesterday after a brief illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Austria's Defense Chief Resigns Under Fire Over Arms for Syria
description: VIENNA, May 30 (Reuters)Defense Minister Karl Luetgendorf resigned today to avoid almost certain dismissal in a lousing political quarrel over Austrian arms shipments to Syria.

title: Kissinger Likely To Reject Offer From Columbia
description: Dr. Henry A. Kissinger is expected to withdraw from consideration for appointment to a professorship and an endowed chair at Columbia University, according to people close to the situation.

title: Around the Nation
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., May 30 (AP)Alabama Chief Justice C. C. Torbert ordered today an end to civil jury trials and said that only essential criminal jury trials would be held until the financial crisis of the court system was resolved.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Carol Mired in Litany of Urban Pains and Pleasures
description: Arthur, Sainer's Carol in Winter Sunlight, being performed at the Theater for the New City, 113 Jane Street, through June 5, is less a play than a catalogue of urban pains and pleasures.

title: List of Identified Victims of Fire
